Abstract\n\nThis c o l l e c t i o n i n c l u d e s papers on a var-iety of t o p i c s , e s p e c i a l l y\na e r o n a u t i c s . Early work of t h e National Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics\non a i r c r a f t s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l appears i n t h e f i r s t s e c t i o n and is\nfollowed \'by o r i g i n a l c o n t r i b u t i o n s i n a i r f o i l theory, i n c l u d i n g t h e o r i e s\nof sweptback and s l e n d e r a i r f o i l s . S e v e r a l papers are devoted t o t h e\ntheory of minimum d r a g and t o t h e theory of t h e o b l i q u e wing.\nP a p e r s on geometrical o p t i c s appear next. Perhaps t h e most s i g n i f i c a n t of t h e s e i s t h e design of a f a s t (F/.66) monochromatic l e n s based\non an i n v e r s i o n of t h e Schmidt arrangement.\n\nSeveral papers based on work a t Avco-Everett Resqarch Laboratory\non c a r d i a c assist devices are included and show elementary a p p l i c a t i o n s\nof f l u i d dynamics t o t h e design of blood pumps and i n p a r t i c u l a r t h e\ni n t r a - a o r t i c balloon pump.\nThe l a s t s e c t i o n p r e s e n t s some simple h e u r i s t i c techniques i n\nr e l a t i v i s t i c kinematics - based on conformal c o o r d i n a t e s i n two\ndimensions. Here t h e a p p l i c a t i o n t o space-like motions provides\nan i n t e r e s t i n g d u a l i t y with E i n s t e i n i a n kinematics.\n7. Key Words (Suggested by Author(s) )\n\n19. (of this page)\n\nUnclassified\n\n21.\n\nNO.\n\nof Pages\n\n1,041\n\nFor sale by the National Technical Information Service, Springfield, Virginia 221 61\n\n22. Price\'\n\n$15.25\n\niii\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nFOREWORD\n\nThis volume is a tribute to a very remarkable man. It has\nbeen my great pleasure to have been associated with him for the\npast six years and, since I came late to the business of aeronautics, I had never had the pleasure of meeting Dr. Robert T.\nJones before. During the period that I have had the opportunity\nto work with him I have developed an enormous respect for his\ntechnical abilities and also for his character as a man. His\ngrasp of the physical sciences is as broad as that of anyone I\nknow. It ranges from practical aeronautical engineering to the\nmost advanced and abstruse statistical mechanics. What is more\nremarkable is that R. T.\'s understanding is not superficial.\nIn an amazingly short time R. T. can master a field to the point\nwhere he can make original contributions. R. T. is also an\nexcellent teacher. He has a profound influence on those around\nhim. In addition, his critical faculties are also exceedingly\nsharp. The Ames Research Center is indeed fortunate to count\nR. T. as one of us. He is unique and his work has added\ngreatly to the Center\'s scientific and technical reputation.\nIt is a genuine pleasure as well as an honor to have him here.\n\nHans Mark\nDirector\nAmes Research Center\n\nV\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nINTRODUCTION\nThe p u b l i c a t i o n of t h i s remarkable c o l l e c t i o n commemorates t h e 65th\nb i r t h d a y of a very remarkable man, D r . Robert Thomas Jones, Aeronautical Engin e e r , who f i r s t went t o work f o r NACA 41 y e a r s ago. During t h i s long C i v i l\nS e r v i c e c a r e e r , h e h a s become one of t h e world\'s l e a d i n g aerodynamicists, made\nd i s c o v e r i e s t h a t have changed t h e h i s t o r y of a e r o n a u t i c s , and received import a n t honors. What s o r t of man is t h i s , whose career h a s been so long and\nwhose c o n t r i b u t i o n s have been s o many and so important?\nhim\n\n-\n\nThis question is, of course, a loaded one\nas many w i l l r e a l i z e who know\nf o r nothing about Bob Jones i s commonplace!\n\n-\n\nF i r s t , consider how he g o t i n t o a e r o n a u t i c s . A f a s c i n a t i o n w i t h a v i a t i o n\ni n t h e 1920\'s w a s , t o b e s u r e , commonplace among u s who w e r e schoolboys then.\nI n Macon, Missouri, where he l i v e d , young Bob read A e r o D i g e s t , t r e a s u r e d i t s\ncover p i c t u r e s of t h e a i r p l a n e s of t h e day, and pored over i t s t e c h n i c a l a r t i c l e s on performance e s t i m a t i o n , s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l , and stress a n a l y s i s .\nAssembling t h e s e and NACA Reports, h e began t h e design and c o n s t r u c t i o n of a\ns m a l l , motorcycle-engined a i r p l a n e , u p s t a i r s i n h i s house. An upusual highschool mathematics t e a c h e r , Iva Z. B u t l e r , helped him t o understand stress and\ns t r a i n , b u t high-school graduation intervened, t h e a i r p l a n e remained unfini s h e d , and Bob went o f f t o t h e University of Missouri i n 1927.\n\nBut t h e a v i a t i o n bug had b i t t e n him badly. H e discovered Walter D i e h l \' s\nfamous E n g i n e e r i n g Aerodynamics and found i t more e x c i t i n g t h a n t h e r e q u i r e d\ncourses of h i s freshman year. H e l e f t t h e u n i v e r s i t y a f t e r t h a t f i r s t year\nby working f o r Charles Fower\'s f l y i n g cirand e n t e r e d t h e a v i a t i o n i n d u s t r y\ncus, which flew Standard J-1 b i p l a n e s ; Bob c a r r i e d g a s o l i n e cans, patched wing\nt i p s , and w a s paid i n f l y i n g lessons!\n\n-\n\nI n about 1929, t h e r e w a s c o n s i d e r a b l e a c t i v i t y i n a v i a t i o n i n t h e United\nStates, i n c l u d i n g t h e Middle West. There w e r e names l i k e Alexander-Eaglerock,\nsome s t i l l around i n 1975 and o t h e r s\nBeech, Cessna, Travel-Air, and Wac0\nn e a r l y f o r g o t t e n . A g r e a t demand f o r a "family f l i v v e r of t h e air" w a s\nexpected. I n Marshall, Missouri, t h e Nicholas-Beazley Company began manufact u r e of t h e Barling NB 3, a s p o r t y , three-place, low-wing, c a n t i l e v e r monoplane. Bob, w i t h h i s h i g h l y p r a c t i c a l ( i f b r i e f ) background i n t h e f l y i n g\nc i r c u s and a good recommendation from Charles Fower, landed a job t h e r e . It\nw a s n o t , a t f i r s t , an engineering j o b , b u t young Jones made i t c l e a r t h a t t h e\nengineering o f f i c e w a s where he wanted t o b e - and when a vacancy suddenly\noccurred, t h e r e h e w a s ! Together w i t h t h e company\'s c h i e f engineer, Thomas\nKirkup, Bob applied D i e h l \' s aerodynamics, c a r r i e d o u t stress a n a l y s e s , and\nperformed ( l a t e i n t o t h e n i g h t ) s t a t i c tests t o f a i l u r e . But Nicholas-Beazley,\nw i t h many o t h e r s , w a s wiped o u t i n 1930 by t h e b u s i n e s s c o l l a p s e .\n\n-\n\nThe a v i a t i o n i n d u s t r y recovered l a t e r i n t h e \' ~ O \' S , and s u r e l y Bob\'s\neven t y p i c a l l y\nt o become an a i r c r a f t\nf i r s t j o b s had prepared him admirably\nmanufacturer o r chief engineer - another Glenn Martin, Donald Douglas, o r\nJohn K. Northrop. But whatever f a t e s c o n t r o l t h e d e s t i n i e s of a e r o n a u t i c a l\nengineers, w i t h o r without c o l l e g e degrees, had o t h e r p l a n s f o r Robert Jones.\n\n-\n\n-\n\nvii\n\nWhen Nicholas-Beazley folded, he returned home to study Glauert\'s AerofoiZ and\nAirscrew Theory and $funk\'s FundamentaZs of FZuid D y d e s for A i r c r a f t\nDesigners. His father was chairman of the local Democratic committee, and\nthis helped young Bob get a job running an elevator in the House Office Building in Washington, D.C. Surely the above-mentioned fates had a hand in this,\nfor the building was across the street from the Library of Congress. Bob paid\nvisits to Dr. Albert I?. Zahm, the Library\'s Director and once a member of the\nNACA. They must have talked about mathematics, for Bob decided to study that\nfield. He began with Hamilton\'s quaternions! And when a Congressman, Honorable David J. Lewis, went to Dr. Zahm to request instruction in mathematics\nand physics - the Congressman was 65 and had finished with law and government Dr. Zahm sent him to the bright elevator boy across the street. Bob taught\nthe Congressman algebra and calculus.\nAt about this time, Bob made another friend whose influence on his career\nwas tremendous: Dr. Max M Munk, who had left the NACA, set up an office in\n.\nWashington as consultant and patent attorney, and was giving evening courses\nat Catholic University. (He had also studied law, passed the bar exams, and\nlearned Russian.) When he discovered that the elevator boy had studied his\nbook, he suggested that he take his evening course - a graduate course. When\nBob said that he might not be prepared for it (a suggestion that\'was certainly\nnot characteristic of young B b ) Dr. Munk gave him a little oral exam and\no!,\nenrolled him. Bob took Munk\'s evening courses for about three years - vector\nanalysis, airfoil theory, and relativity theory - and drew upon this sound\nearly teaching throughout his career. Thus Bob is truly one of the "Prandtl\ngrandchildren" and an heir to that great tradition, with its deep, intuitive\nappreciation of the power of applied mathematics, without attraction to\nmathematics or mathematical elegance for its own sake.\nThe election of Franklin D. Roosevelt (1932) brought the Public Works\nAdministration, and PWA opened up emergency jobs at Langley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory. Dr. Zahm and Congressman Lewis saw Dr. George W. Lewis,\nNACA Head, and recommended Robert Jones for one of these jobs; Bob went to\nLangley, reporting to Carl J. Wenzinger, Charles Zimmerman, and Fred Weick, on\nt\na nine-month assignment as Scientific Aid. The fates had their way: I\nrequired a sequence of unlikely events and remarkable people, but Robert T.\nJones was embarked on a career in research in the NACA and under the supervision of some unusually capable bosses.\nNot surprisingly, ordinary linear differential equations was a subject\nmissing from Bob\'s informal educational background - although he did know the\nquaternions and had read Grassmann\'s AusdehnwzgsZehre and similar classics in\nthe original - so with Weick\'s and Zimmerman\'s guidance, he "learned by doing"\ndifferential equations. He published some of the earliest results of step-bystep solutions of the equations of airplane motion (obtained on desk calculating machines), such as the transient motions following abrupt, unit-step\ncontrol deflections and gusts. He recalls that he became a sort of local\nauthority on linearity after once calculating the transient motion following a\ntwo-unit step input, and comparing the results with unit-step results! He was\nalso one of the first to apply Heaviside\'s operators to problems of airplane\ndynamics.\nviii\n\nBut t h e nine-month temporary appointment w a s about t o expire. Bob\'s\nbosses, Fred Weick, and Henry Reid, D i r e c t o r of t h e Langley Laboratory, t r i e d\nt o a r r a n g e f o r him t o t a k e a C i v i l S e r v i c e exam so they could h i r e him perman e n t l y , b u t the C i v i l S e r v i c e r u l e s s p e c i f i e d a Bachelor\'s degree. Weick and\nReid then thought t o i s s u e a s p e c i a l C i v i l S e r v i c e e x a m t h a t would r e q u i r e\neverything t h a t Bob knew. I n due course a s p e c i a l C i v i l S e r v i c e examination\nw a s i s s u e d w i t h q u e s t i o n s on Hamilton\'s quaternions, o p e r a t i o n a l c a l c u l u s , airc r a f t s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l , wing theory, and a few o t h e r s u b j e c t s . To t h e\ns u r p r i s e of those a t Langley, a f e l l o w showed up who o f f e r e d t h i s e x o t i c comb i n a t i o n and a Bachelor\'s degree as w e l l . Weick assigned him t o Bob Jones,\nwho put him t o work. Bob f i n a l l y g o t a permanent appointment on a subprofess i o n a l grade. Some y e a r s l a t e r , when he approached t h e f i r s t p r o f e s s i o n a l\ngrade P-1, he again encountered t h e requirement f o r t h e Bachelor\'s degree.\nThis t i m e t h e NACA w a s more ingenious - t h e s t a t e d requirements f o r grade P-2\nd i d not mention any degree, so NACA promoted him d i r e c t l y t o t h a t grade!\nBy t h e t i m e World War I1 began, Bob had published important papers,\ni n c l u d i n g a most ingenious way t o f i n d t h e t r a n s i e n t l i f t on f i n i t e - s p a n wings\n(page 193). H e had become deservedly well-known i n a e r o n a u t i c a l circles,\ne x p e c i a l l y as an e x p e r t i n s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l . A t Northrop A j r c r a f t w e\nw e r e s t r u g g l i n g w i t h t h e problems of t h e all-wing a i r p l a n e s\nXB 35, YB 49,\netc. - and every t r i p t o Langley F i e l d , f o r wind-tunnel tests o r o t h e r busin e s s , included a v i s i t t o Bob t o d i s c u s s s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l , and e s p e c i a l l y\nt h e p r o p e r t i e s of sweptback wings. When t h e f i r s t guided missiles w e r e developed, Bob worked c l o s e l y w i t h t h e Army S p e c i a l Weapons u n i t . I n t h o s e days\nt h e missiles w e r e a c t u a l l y p i l o t l e s s a i r p l a n e s , and one of them w a s a Northrop\nall-wing design w i t h t u r b o j e t power ( a r e b u i l t turbo-supercharger).\nThe autop i l o t w a s made by t h e Hammond Organ Company. M r . Laurens Hammond s t a r t l e d us\nby proposing one b l a c k box i n t h e r i g h t wing w i t h a p i t c h gyro, and another i n\nt h e l e f t wing w i t h a t i l t e d gyro f o r lateral c o n t r o l . Each of t h e s e cont r o l l e d only i t s own "elevon" (combined e l e v a t o r and a i l e r o n ) ; t h e r e w a s no\nconnection between t h e two a u t o p i l o t s and no connection between t h e two elevons. Even Bob Jones w a s h o r r i f i e d by t h e i d e a , b u t t h e l i t t l e a i r c r a f t flew\nw i t h f a u l t l e s s s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l ; t h e r e w a s , a f t e r a l l , aerodynamic coup l i n g between i t s l e f t and r i g h t s i d e s , although t h e dynamics of t h e system\ncould c e r t a i n l y not b e divided i n t o l a t e r a l and l o n g i t u d i n a l motions. Bob w a s\nimpressed w i t h t h e unimportance of b i l a t e r a l symmetry!\n\n-\n\nH e f i r s t worked o u t h i s famous theory of low-aspect-ratio wings i n 1944\n(page 369). H e w a s embarrassed when i t w a s r e f e r r e d t o under h i s name,\nbecause h e thought i t w a s an obvious extension of D r . Munk\'s classical and\nwell-known work. The rest of us have never found t h a t t h e extension, involvi n g as i t does t h e r e c o g n i t i o n and treatment of t h e t r a i l i n g v o r t i c e s t h a t l i e\nBob d i d not even publish i t\nbehind a l l t r a i l i n g edges, i s a t a l l "obvious".\na t f i r s t , b u t later r e a l i z e d t h a t i t a p p l i e d t o high-speed flow, including\nsupersonic, as w e l l as t o low-speed, because t h e flow n e a r t h e a x i s of t h e\nMach cone i s s i m i l a r t o incompressible flow.\n\nA t about t h e same t i m e , he remembered from an o l d NACA Technical Note of\nt h a t you can c a l c u l a t e t h e e f f e c t s of sweepback and\nMunk\'s\nT.N. 1 7 7 (1924)\nThe two-dimensional\nd i h e d r a l a n g l e i n a wing by an "independence principle":\nflow around t h e wing due t o t h e stream component perpendicular t o t h e wing\n\n-\n\n-\n\nix\n\na x i s i s independent of t h e flow due t o t h e stream component along t h i s a x i s .\nBob r e a l i z e d t h a t t h i s independence p r i n c i p l e d i d n o t depend upon incompressib i l i t y , and t h u s h e discovered t h e "theory of simple sweepback" (page 377),\nwhich i s c e r t a i n l y one of t h e most important d i s c o v e r i e s i n t h e h i s t o r y of\naerodynamics. A t f i r s t he made t h e mistake of p u t t i n g t h e low-aspect-ratio\nand t h e sweep t h e o r i e s i n t h e same paper, b u t t h e NACA e d i t o r i a l committee,\nwhich had t o approve t h e paper, b e l i e v e d t h e former and not t h e latter. A s\nBob says, "It h a s t o b e remembered t h a t a t t h a t t i m e t h e r e w a s thought t o b e a\nvery g r e a t d i f f e r e n c e between subsonic and supersonic flow," s o t h a t i t seemed,\nt o some s k e p t i c s , impossible t o render a supersonic flow e s s e n t i a l l y subsonic\nby such a simple device as sweepback.\nWhile t h e argument w i t h t h e e d i t o r i a l committee w a s s t i l l i n progress,\nBob\'s colleague, Robert H e s s , read Adolph Busemann\'s 1935 paper concerning\nsupersonic flow, and they r e a l i z e d t h a t Busemann\'s argument would l e a d t o t h e\ns a m e r e s u l t as J o n e s \' s , i f t h e wing w a s swept behind t h e \'Mach cone. But\nBusemann had n o t discussed t h i s case i n h i s paper, so t h e e d i t o r i a l c o m i t t e e\nremained unconvinced. Bob divided t h e troublesome paper i n two p a r t s , and t h e\nlow-aspect-ratio p a r t w a s published. NACA began experiments i n an e f f o r t t o\nconfirm t h e s t a r t l i n g conclusions of t h e simple-sweep theory. Before t h e\nexperiments w e r e completed, V. E. Day occurred, A l l i e d engineers went i n t o\nGermany, and t h e news came back t h a t t h e Germans knew about t h e e f f e c t of\nsweep and were using i t on a l l of t h e i r new designs.\nFor h i s discovery of t h e sweep e f f e c t and o t h e r c o n t r i b u t i o n s , Bob w a s\ngiven t h e Sylvanus A l b e r t Reed Award by t h e I n s t i t u t e of t h e Aeronautical\nSciences i n 1946. It w a s a l s o i n 1946 t h a t h e l e f t t h e Langley Laboratory and\nmoved t o Ames.\nAbout t h e t i m e h e moved t o t h e West Coast, Bob acquired a new i n t e r e s t :\nt e l e s c o p e s . I n c h a r a c t e r i s t i c f a s h i o n , t h i s l e d him t o a deep study of geometrical o p t i c s . H e learned t h e a r t of g r i n d i n g s p h e r i c a l m i r r o r s and set up\nan impressive o p t i c a l shop i n t h e garage of h i s Palo Alto home. Also typic a l l y , he made i n v e n t i o n s and o r i g i n a l d i s c o v e r i e s (which he c a l l s "minor") i n\nt h i s f i e l d . The l e n s described s t a r t i n g on page 917 had a speed of f/0.66 and\nw a s "a s o r t of conjugate of t h e Schmidt telescope."\nWhen t h e Space Age began i n 1957, Bob and h i s w i f e expected t e l e s c o p e s t o\nb e much i n demand. They formed t h e Vega Instrument Company, and went i n t o\nproduction on a six-inch t e l e s c o p e of t h e type described s t a r t i n g on page 895,\ns e l l i n g f o r about $800. They s o l d about t e n of t h e s e and went on t o a more\ne l e g a n t instrument: a six-inch Newtonian-Maksutov, s e l l i n g f o r $1700. The\ni d e a w a s t o make fewer t e l e s c o p e s and more money. Bob\'s son, Edward, worked\nf o r t h e Vega Instrument Company, as d i d a machinist and an o p t i c i a n . Although\nt h i r t y of t h e Maksutovs w e r e made, t h e company\'s p r o f i t s hovered near zero.\nOf course, Bob\'s i n t e r e s t and knowledge i n astronomy w a s very timely:\nNACA became NASA, t h e "space agency," and Bob w a s one of t h e few a e r o n a u t i c a l\nengineers who knew h i s way around t h e sky. H e served f o r several y e a r s on t h e\nAstronomy Subcommittee. H e had been f a s c i n a t e d by r e l a t i v i t y theory s i n c e\no\nt a k i n g Munk\'s n i g h t courses i n Washington. N w t h a t space travel a t g r e a t\nX\n\nspeeds w a s a real p o s s i b i l i t y , h e followed up a number of o r i g i n a l i d e a s i n\nt h i s f i e l d (pages 927-956).\nBut he a l s o continued t o make profound d i s c o v e r i e s i n aerodynamics. One\nw a s t h e "supersonic area r u l e " which c o r r e c t l y c a r r i e s i n t o t h e supersonic\nregime t h e concept of e q u i v a l e n t body of r e v o l u t i o n , which had been found so\nu s e f u l i n t h e t r a n s o n i c regime (page 609). H e thought about t h e e f f e c t s of\nsweepback on boundary-layer behavior (page 473) and discovered an "independ(Professor P r a n d t l , V. V. Struminskii, and t h e\nence p r i n c i p l e " h e r e , as w e l l .\np r e s e n t w r i t e r a l l came independently t o t h i s r e s u l t a t t h e s a m e t i m e !\nD r . Munk w a s somewhat s k e p t i c a l but t o l d me, "Bob Jones s a y s t h e s a m e t h i n g ,\ns o i t must b e r i g h t . " )\nAnother discovery w a s t h e e x i s t e n c e of a new kind of\nleading-edge s i n g u l a r i t y i n thin-wing theory (page 533). A l l of t h e s e papers\nare t y p i c a l examples of Bob\'s i n s i g h t and h i s d i r e c t , i n t u i t i v e s t y l e of\nw r i t i n g . Lesser aerodynamicists o f t e n f i n d h i s arguments too concise, and t h e\nl i t e r a t u r e of t h e f i e l d i n c l u d e s papers i n which a u t h o r s re-do Bob\'s work,\nproviding longer proofs, and discover a g a i n Bob\'s r e s u l t s .\nI n 1956 Bob and Doris Cohen w e r e asked t o w r i t e an important s e c t i o n of\nt h e Princeton Series, High Speed A e r o d y d c s and Jet Propulsion. This collabo r a t i o n produced t h e s e c t i o n e n t i t l e d "Aerodynamics of Wings a t High Speeds."\nOne of t h e f e a t u r e s of t h i s s e c t i o n i s t h e a n a l y s i s of t h e drag of e l l i p t i c a l\nwings, including t h o s e t h a t f l y a t a n a n g l e of yaw. Thus Bob r e t u r n e d t o t h e\nc o n s i d e r a t i o n of sweepback e f f e c t s and asymmetrical c o n f i g u r a t i o n s .\nThe a n a l y s i s showed Bob t h a t e l l i p t i c wings are i d e a l and t h a t , a t high\nspeeds, they should b e yawed. H e rememberedtheunimportance of b i l a t e r a l symmetry. I n a series of papers (pages 657-883), h e has pointed o u t t h e a t t r a c tive properties\nboth aerodynamical and s t r u c t u r a l\nof yawed (oblique) wings\nf o r supersonic a i r c r a f t . The s p a r s of such wings c a r r y t h e bending moment\nr i g h t a c r o s s ; i t i s n o t put i n t o t h e variable-sweep mechanism. Bob and h i s\nThe a e r o n a u t i c a l world\nNASA c o l l e a g u e s are pursuing t h i s i d e a vigorously.\ns t i l l s e e m s h e s i t a n t t o accept c o n f i g u r a t i o n s without symmetry. Nevertheless,\nI, f o r one, f u l l y expect t o see f u t u r e t r a n s p o r t a i r p l a n e s w i t h "Jones o b l i q u e\nwings.\n\n-\n\n-\n\nH e r e again are examples of Bob\'s i n s i g h t i n t o engineering problems: The\na e r o e l a s t i c p r o p e r t i e s of t h e o b l i q u e wing have f r i g h t e n e d a number of engin e e r s , f o r t h e upstream panel s u r e l y wants t o d e f l e c t a e r o e l a s t i c a l l y upward\nand t h e downstream panel downward. To Bob i t seems obvious t h a t t h e s e e f f e c t s\nsimply do not occur i n f l i g h t . A study of t h e e q u i l i b r i u m of r o l l i n g moments\nw i l l confirm t h a t he i s r i g h t . The d e t a i l s are l e f t t o t h e r e a d e r ; it must b e\ns a i d t h a t t h e conclusion is n o t q u i t e "obvious," even t o most a e r o n a u t i c a l\nengineers!\n\nPages 957-1017 r e p r e s e n t s t i l l another f a c e t of R. T. J o n e s \' s career:\ns t u d i e s of t h e bio-mechanics of blood flow. These w e r e i n v e s t i g a t i o n s c a r r i e d\no u t a t t h e Avco Everett Research Laboratories.\nBut t h e r e is s t i l l another, most important s i d e of Bob Jones, and one\nt h a t t h i s all-too-brief b i o g r a p h i c a l sketch has ignored t o t h i s p o i n t . H e is\nt h e f a t h e r of s i x c h i l d r e n (two adopted), of whom t h e e l d e s t , Eddy, i s now a\n\nxi\n\nman of 4 1 years. Bob\'s r e l a t i o n s h i p t o them has been e x c e p t i o n a l l y warm and\nrewarding. A t y p i c a l example comes t o mind: Daughter P a t t y i s a v i o l i n i s t ,\nand by about 1956 had progressed s o w e l l t h a t s h e needed a good v i o l i n . H e r\nremarkable f a t h e r agreed, and decided t h a t h e would study t h e a c o u s t i c s of\ngood v i o l i n s and make one f o r P a t t y ! Here, i n h i s own words, is t h e s t o r y :\n"Milton Van Dyke gave m e some r e p r i n t s of s c i e n t i f i c a r t i c l e s\non t h e v i o l i n by h i s o l d physics p r o f e s s o r , W. A. Saunders of\nHarvard. Saunders had made e l e c t r o n i c - a c o u s t i c tests of many\nv i o l i n s , i n c l u d i n g some v a l u a b l e o l d I t a l i a n ones, and had e l i c i t e d\nt h e h e l p of Jascha H e i f e t z . By following Saunders\' frequencyresponse curves, I should be a b l e t o make P a t t y a super-violin!\nSo\nI set up t h e e l e c t r o n i c t e s t i n g , bought t h e wood, and a f t e r some\nmonths of spare-time work turned o u t a v e r y good-looking v i o l i n .\nUnfortunately i t s tone seems t o have d e t e r i o r a t e d w i t h t i m e , o r perhaps i t wasn\'t as good as w e thought a t t h e t i m e , and so I had t o\nmake h e r a second one ( s e e page 1019). The second one s e e m s t o be\nr e a l l y good, and P a t t y plays i t a t recitals and i n t h e L a J o l l a Civic\nSymphony. I a m now (1975) f i n i s h i n g number 6, but No. 2 has been\nt h e b e s t u n t i l now. Am experimenting w i t h 1500-Hz v i b r a t i f o n dampers\n( t h i s i s t h e "nasal" range) and have made an e l e c t r o n i c v i o l i n which\nm f r i e n d Irwin Hahn of t h e Berkeley Physics Department, and a\ny\nv i o l i n i s t , t h i n k s i s v e r y good."\nI n 1971, Bob w a s awarded t h e degree of Doctor of Science,\n\nhonoris causa, by t h e U n i v e r s i t y of Colorado, " i n acknowledgement\nof h i s s c i e n t i f i c eminence and h i s service t o society."\nhe w a s e l e c t e d t o t h e National Academy of Engineering.\n\nI n 1973\n\nAeronautical engineer, a p p l i e d mathematician, astronomer, designer of\nt e l e s c o p e s , bio-mechanicist, maker of v i o l i n s , i n v e n t o r , a u t h o r , d i s c o v e r e r of\nprofound p r i n c i p l e s , c i v i l s e r v a n t , devoted f a t h e r - our f r i e n d Bob i s a l l of\nthese. H e is a l s o a man of exemplary c h a r a c t e r and a most d e l i g h t f u l compani o n on any occasion, whose i n t e l l i g e n c e and i n t e l l e c t u a l honesty s h i n e b r i g h t l y\nfrom t h o s e clear, b i g , b l u e eyes. N one r e a l l y b e l i e v e s he has reached 65\no\nyears, f o r he i s obviously a g e l e s s ! H e has RO i n t e n t i o n of r e t i r i n g f o r some\nt i m e . W e can b e c e r t a i n t h a t a i r p l a n e s , f l u i d flow, v i o l i n s , t h e stars, and\nperhaps many o t h e r t h i n g s w i l l continue t o f a s c i n a t e him and l e a d him t o new\ntruths i n the future!\nW i l l i a m R. Jones\n\nJanuary 1930\n\n1\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nWING ANALYSIS :\n\nPOBJOY RACEPLANE*\n\nR. T. Jones\n\nThe Pobjoy Raceplane i s a l i g h t , low winged monoplane designed f o r high\nspeed, maneuverability, and general high performance.\n\nThe estimated charac-\n\nteristics are :\nGross Weight,\n\n5 76#\n\nNet Weight,\n\n511#\n\nWing Span,\n\n21.75\'\n\nWing Area,\n\n60\'\n\nThe wing designed f o r t h i s plane i s o f a new type being patented by\nM r . H. G. Landis, and possesses many novel and unconventional f e a t y e s .\n\nThe\n\ngeneral arrangement o f t h e s t r u c t u r e w i l l be seen i n f i g u r e s (1) and (2).\nSince i t i s of t h e multispar type and n o t s u b j e c t t o a rigorous a n a l y s i s\nr e s o r t was made t o an approximate c a l c u l a t i o n supplemented by a s t a t i c t e s t\nEA\non a s e c t i o n of t h e wing (see "TEST ON A M T L WING").\nThe approximate method was completely v e r i f i e d and s u f f i c i e n t d a t a\nobtained t o design a wing f o r t h e r a c e r .\nfollows:\n\nSeveral minor changes were made as\n\nThe s h e a r bracing was changed from a P r a t t t r u s s i n g with tension\n\ns t r i p s t o Warren t r u s s of channel members, t h e t r u s s members were centered\non t h e o u t s i d e of t h e beam flanges i n s t e a d of on i t s n e u t r a l a x i s a s before,\nt h e gauge of t h e m a t e r i a l was increased and t h e s i z e of t h e members decreased.\nThese changes were thought d e s i r a b l e from t h e r e s u l t s o f t h e t e s t and serve\nt o strengthen t h e s t r u c t u r e by reducing t h e p o s s i b i l i t y o f l o c a l f a i l u r e and\ni n c r e a s i n g t h e allowable stress i n t h e m a t e r i a l .\n\n*Engineering Report:\nJan. 1930,\n\nNicholas-Beasley Airplane Co., Marshall, Mo., Dec. 1929-\n\n3\n\nThe wing is constructed o f aluminum a l l o y (25 ST) having t h e following\nproperties:\n\nYield Point, 30,000#/";\n\nTensile Strength, 55,000#/tr.\n\nThe gauge\n\nused i s be\ninvestigated.\n\ntest.\n\nThe v a l i d i t y of t h i s assumption was a l s o demonstrated by t h e\n\nThe u l t i m a t e load s u s t a i n e d by t h e s t r u c t u r e i s n o t appreciably a f f e c t e d\n\nby t w i s t i n g s i n c e t h e moments of i n e r t i a o f t h e s p a r s decrease progressively\nfrom t h e c e n t r o i d a s shown i n Fig. ( 2 ) .\n\nI n t h e a n a l y h e p r o p o r t i o n a l moment c a r r i e d by each s p a r it i s only necessary\nt o determine t h e t o t a l moment a t t h e s e c t i o n and, i n t h e bay, t h e end load\nproduced by t h determining t h e end loads i n t h e s p a r s and b r a c e wires t h e s h e a r s a t\nt h e fuselage and wire f i t t i n g s w i l l first be found by t a k i n g t h e moments of\nt h e e l l i p t i c a l t i p load and t h e r e c t a n g u l a r load i n t h e bay s e p a r a t e l y and\nequating t o equilibrium a t t h e two p o i n t s .\n\nThe t r u s s w i l l then be solved by\n\nr 5.\n\nThe maximum s h e a r 1 load occurs a t t h e wire attachment and is 1885#\n\n(see Fig. 3 ) .\nTEST OF SHEAR BRACING\n\nThe purpose o f t h i s t e s t was t o determine t h e margin of s a f e t y of t h e\ns h e a r t r u s s e s i n t h e m u l t i s p a r wing designed f o r t h e Pobjoy Raceplane.\n\nThis\n\nwing (see Wing Analysis) c o n s i s t s o f arc flanges o r s p a r s connected by\ni n c l i n e d Warren t r u s s e s of channel s e c t i o n members, t h e whole being blanked\nand formed from a s i n g l e s h e e t of aluminum a l l o y .\n\nI n forming t h e h e flange\n\ni n o r d e r t o prevent l o c a l f a i l u r e o f t h e free edges by r e l i e v i n g t h e s t r e s s\ni n them.\n\nBecause of t h i s i n t e n t i o n a l e c c e n t r i c i t y and t h e f i x i t y of\n\nt h e s t r u t ends it was thought advisable t o determine t h e s t r e n g t h o f t h e\nchannels by a c t u a l t e s t .\n\n11\n\nThe t e s t was c a r r i e d o u t i n t h e following manner:\n\nA sample frame o f t h e\n\ns h e a r bracing was made up, using t h e same m a t e r i a l (.040-25 ST) and d i e s used\nf o r t h e a c t u a l wing.\n\nThis frame was b o l t e d t o a s t e e l angle a t two p o i n t s and\n\nt h e load a p p l i e d a t t h e apex o f t h e frame as shown i n Fig. 6 .\n\nThis a p p l i c a t i o n\n\no f t h e load simulates t h e conditions e x i s t i n g i n t h e wing, corresponding t o t h e\ntransmission o f end load i n t o t h e flanges and producing t h e same effects a t\nthe joints.\n\nThe P/A stress i n t h e s t r u t s is r e l a t i v e l y small (see Wing\n\nAnalysis) and l i t t l e doubt was f e l t as t o t h e a b i l i t y o f t h e channel t o t a k e\nt h e load, t h e main purpose of t h e test being t o determine t h e effects of t h e\nsecondary stress.\nThe load c o n s i s t e d o f i r o n weights and was suspended from t h e frame by\nmeans of two steel s t r a p s pinned through with a 3/16 b o l t .\n\nThe \'location of\n\nt h e b o l t and t h e a p p l i c a t i o n of t h e load a r e shown i n Fig. 6.\n\nUsing a l l t h e\n\nweights a v a i l a b l e , a load of 320# was a p p l i e d t o t h e s t r u c t u r e and produced no\nv i s i b l e deformation.\n\nSince t h i s was i n excess of t h e requirements of t h e wing\n\nand i t was n o t thought d e s i r a b l e t o reduce t h e s i z e o f t h e members f o r s t r u c t u r a l reasons, t h e t e s t was n o t c a r r i e d f u r t h e r .\n\nThe load c a r r i e d by each\n\ns t r u t was approximately 227# and t h e P/A stress developed, 9 0 8 0 # / " .\nThe m a t e r i a l was t h e Aluminum Company of America\'s 25 ST a l l o y and has\nt h e following p r o p e r t i e s :\n55,000#/".\n\nMin. T e n s i l e Strength,\n\nDue t o lack o f d a t a on open dural s e c t i o n s i t i s d i f f i c u l t t o\n\no b t a i n a comparison but it i s believed t h a t with t h e slenderness r a t i o used\nt h e r e s u l t s are s a t i s f a c t o r y .\n\n12\n\n13\n\n14\n\n15\n\n16\n\n1885\n\nI\n\nI\n\nb\n\nE,9. /3)\n\n- Concluded.\n\n17\n\n18\n\nx\n\n19\n\n20\n\nCALCULATION OF THE MOTION OF AN AIRPLANE UNDER THE\nINFLUENCE OF IRREGULAR DISTURBANCES\nRobert T. Jones\nLangley Field, Virginia\n\nOctober 1936\n\n21\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nURNAL OF THE\nAERONAUTICAL SCIENCES\nVolume 3\n\nOCTOBER, 1936\n\nNumber\n\n12\n\nCalculation of the Motion of an Airplane Under the Influence of\nIrregular Disturbances\nROBERT T. JONES, Langley Field, Virginin\n(Received August 17, 1936)\n\nSUMMARY\nHE paper illustrates the application of matheniatical advances made in electricity and other branches\nto problems of airplane dynamics. The HeavisideUromwich methods of solution of linear differential\nequations are described and it is shown how these\nniethods avoid the consideration of boundary conditions\nand of particular or complementary integrals. It is\npointed out that if the solution of the differential equation is obtained for the case of a unit disturbance, the\neffect of varying disturbances may be found therefrom\nby Carson\xe2\x80\x99s Theorem. A graphical solution of Carson\xe2\x80\x99s\nIntegral for irregular disturbances is given.\nThe procedure of ohtaining unit solutions of the\nequations is then taken up and the analogy between\nHeaviside\xe2\x80\x99s symbolic series solution and a physical procedure of approximation is shown. It is suggested\nthat a fictitious impulsive disturbance be used in the\ntreatment of initial motions. Bromwich\xe2\x80\x99s interpretation\nof the operational method is briefly described and the\nexpression of the irregular disturbance functions by\ndefinite integrals is shown.\n\nT\n\nDEFINITIONS\nU,,-Equilibrium flight velocity.\nw-Linear velocity in plane of symmetry of airplane and normal to UO.\np-Rolling angular velocity of airplane. (About\nUo as axis).\n\nq-Pitching angular velocity of airplane. (About\naxis normaJ to Uo and to the plane of symmetry).\nL-Rolling nioinent per unit moment of inertia of\nairplane.\n2-Force per unit mass of airplane. (Along w ) .\n\nLp, Z,,\n\n.\n\ndL\n. etc., = -, dZ etc.\n-,\ndw dw\n\nThe use of some mathematical discipline in the study\nof disturbed motions of airplanes seems essential if a\nconsistent advance in the improvement of airplane\nflying and handling qualities is to be made. The study\nof stability alone has thus\xe2\x80\x99far not been of very great\nusefulness in this respect partly because it has been\ndifficult to establish the interpretation of the niathematical definition of stability in terms of control and\nflying qualities.\nA study of the specific effects of disturbances and\ncontrol manipulations is in many respects more instructive than the study of stability alone. A calculation ol\nthe motion of the airplane gives a comprehensible\nresult ; in terms of velocities, accelerations, etc., while\nthe stability calculation must be considered incomplete\nas it yields only an indication of the character of the\nfree motion. Thus if appears that the study of airplane\ndynaniics may be more profitable if the question of\nstability is subordinated to specific questions involving\nthe effects of gusts and control manipulations.\nIt has been considered that the representation of the\nmotions of an airplane under the influence of irregular\ndisturbances would require a prohibitive labor of cal-\n\n23\n\nKUiSLKl\n\nculation. Such differential equations as occur in airplane dynamics are, however, of the same form as those\nused in certain problems of electricity and in other\nbranches and many of the advances made there can be\nadapted to aeronautical problems. It will be seen that\nthese advances result in very practical simplifications\nof the mathematical procedure.\nThe question of the solution of differential equatiolls\narises in the study of airplane dynamics because it is\neasier to write expressions for the detailed component\naccelerations of an airplane in motion than it is to write\nexpressions giving the movements directly. The analysis of the problem, the expression of equations for the\ncomponent accelerations, consists simply in attributing\na component of reaction in each degree of freedom of\ntlie airplane to each component of motion or displacement. The analysis need not be restricted to the airplane as a rigid body, for component deformations of\nthe machine may often be treated as additional degrees\nof freedom.\nAccording to Bryan\xe2\x80\x99s theory of airplane stability the\ncomponent reactions are considered to be directly proportional to the displacements or motions. Originally\nthis assumption was used in application to vanishingly\nsmall motions since the consideration of such motions\nwas sufficient to etablish the stability of steady flight.\nThe latter advance of aerodynamics has shown that the\nsimple linear laws of variation of aerodynamic reactions with the motions should give good approximation\nfor movements of the airplane such as are encountered\nin ordinary maneuvering. Hence the theory was\nextended to the caluculation of unsteady motions of aircraft in general.\nThe assumption of linear laws of aerodynamic reaction (together with other commonly used simplifying\nassumptions) leads to the representation of the accelerations of a disturbed airplane by linear differential equations. It is usually necessary to consider several com.\nponent motions simultaneously, since a movement of the\nairplane in one degree of freedom generally reacts on\nand modifies the movements in other degrees. Thus one\nis led to a set of simultaneous equations. The parameters of these equations, expressing the proportions\nbetween motions and air forces or moments, are termed\n\xe2\x80\x9cstability derivatives.\xe2\x80\x9d\nThe set of equations containing only the reactions\nthat the airplane naturally receives when displaced from\nequilibrium flight are the so-called \xe2\x80\x9ccomplementary\nequations\xe2\x80\x9d and are those used in the study of stability.\nThis set of equations has a whole family of possible\nsolutions. The possible solutions of a set of complementary equations do have one unique characteristic\nhowever, and that is the indication as to whether or not\nthe natural free oscillations of the airplane tend to\ndiminish with time.\nIf it is desired to calculate the motion of an airplane\ndue to some disturbing influence, such as a gust or a\n\n24\n\nI,\n\nJUNJL>\n\nFIG.1. The superposition of disturbed motions.\n\nmanipulation of the control, it is necessary to include\nterms in the equations that express the component\naccelerations attributed to the disturbance. Thus in\nthe case of a deflected control the known moment\nexerted (per unit moment of inertia of the airplane) is\nadded to the other terms in the appropriate equation.\nSuch disturbing reactions must be given in terms of the\ntime before the equations can be solved. The equation\nexpressing the acceleration in free pitching motion is :\n\n&- wM,\ndt\n\n- qMa = 0\n\nIf, however, a distu:bing pitching moment due to the\nelevator, say, is acting, the equation is written :\n\nwM, - qMa = M(1)\nand it is implied that the right hand side is a function\nof 1.\n\nAlthough the component motions of the airplane\nmutually interfere and must be calculated simultaneously\n(that is, by simultaneous differential equations), the\neffects of component disturbances may be calculated\nseparately and later added in any desired proportion.\nThus if a given impressed rolling moment, acting alone,\ncauses a 20\xe2\x80\x9d bank of the airplane in one second and n\ngiven yawing moment, also acting alone, produces 5\xe2\x80\x9d of\nbank in the same time the combined effect of bath acting\nsimultaneously will be a 25\xe2\x80\x9d bank.\nA somewhat similar statement may be made with\nregard to the effects of disturbances that are not applied\nsimultaneously, viz. ; that if a given disturbance which\narises at the time t = 0 is later augmented in some\namount the effect of the increment of disturbance will\n\nCALCULATION OF T H E MOTION\n\nOF AN\n\nAEROPLANE\n\nFIG. Simple types of disturbances.\n2.\n\nrun its course independently of the effect of the original\ndisturbance. Thus in a problem involving the correction of a gust disturbance by a manipulation of the control a history of the motion due to the uncorrected gust\nnlay be calculated and an entirely independent motion,\ndue to the assumed corrective control manipulation,\nadded later at any desired point. Fig. 1 illustrates\nthis principle.\nThese important characteristics of the dynamical system regarding the superposition of effects of disturbances lead to the consideration of the effect of a simple\n\xe2\x80\x9cunit disturbance.\xe2\x80\x9d The concept of a disturbing acceleration of unit magnitude applied instantly at the time\nt = O to a dynamical system otherwise at rest is\nattributed to Heaviside, who employed it in the development of his Operational Calculus. Carson* utilized this\nconcept to calculate the effect of a varying disturbance\nof arbitrary form.\nThe unit disturbance, otherwise known as the \xe2\x80\x9cunit\nfunction,\xe2\x80\x9d is defined by :\nl ( t ) = 0 when t < 0\n(1)\nl(t) = 1 when t > 0\n(see Fig. 2).\nIn Elettricity this symbol is used to denote a unit\ne.ii1.f. instantly applied at t = 0. The corresponding\nuse in Aeronautics would be to denote a unit impulsive\nlinear or angular acceleration.\nAs an example of the apcplicatjon of this concept suppose that it is required to find the combined pitching\nmotion (4) and the vertical translation (w)of an airplane due to the sharp edged vertical gust of (constant) velocity m. The simultaneous equations for\nthese motions are:\n\n-_\ndw\ndt\n\nw z w - q(Z,\n\n+ U,) =\n\n1 :\n\nFIG. Carson\xe2\x80\x99s integral.\n3.\n\nIf the motions thus calculated are\nWIZ (t) and P ~ Z\n(0\nand the motions calculated for a unit disturbance substituted into the second equation are\n\nWIM (t)\n\nand q1M 01,\n\nthen the motions due to the gust womay be found from:\nw(t) = ZOW,(t)\nd t ) = Zoqlz(t)\n\n+ Mow1dt)\n+ Moqidt)\n\nCarson\xe2\x80\x99s Theorem\xe2\x80\x99, which enables the calculation o i\nmotion due to any irreguiar variation of disturbance,\nis simply a statement of the generalized superposition\ntheorem in terms of a definite integral. Let w , ( t ) be\nthe motion calculated for a unit disturbance l ( t ) , and\nsuppose that it is desired to find the motion w ( t ) due\nto some varying disturbance, say Z(t). According to\nCai-son\xe2\x80\x99s Theorem\nw(t*)= W l ( t 0 )Z ( 0 ) +fW&\n\nW J a\n\n= Z\xe2\x80\x9d\n\n(4)\n\n- t ) ZYt) 4\n\n(5)\n\nwhere w, ( t A ) is the motion at the time ( t d ) after\nthe impression of the unit disturbance. (See Fig. 3.)\n-_ wM, - qM, = woMv = Me\ndq\nd\nt\nIn the most general case the impressed disturbance\nThe procedure is to perform the calculation with a will be given as a function of the time simply by a\nunit disturbance substituted into the first equatiotl, thus curve, as in Fig. 4 (curve B). If the \xe2\x80\x9cindicia1 motion,\xe2\x80\x9d\nor motion of the system due to a unit disturbance, is\ndw\nWZ, - q(Z*\nVO) = 1 (1)\nalso given by a curve (curve A ) the two may be com&\n(3) bined by a simple artifice and the general solution\n-- w M - qM, = 0\n4\n~\nobtained by a graphical integration.? The integral of this deceleration gives a decrement of p which may then be applied\nto the first approximation. The new approximation\nagain requires correction because the value of p assumed\nin calculating the damping was tdo high. The required\nintegral may be shown to be\n(33)\n\ngiving the value zero for negative t and the value 1 for\npositive t. Here the limit, or path, of integration\nextends along the imaginary axis and to the right of the\nsingular point at the origin. With the limit of the integral thus specified it is permissible to integrate in addition along any other path provided it is shown that the\nadditional path does not change the value of the integral\nas defined. Then it is easy to prove that a closure of\nthe path along a semicircle to the left of the imaginary\naxis does not contribute to the integral if t is positive.\nThe path then encloses one singular point, 0, and the\nvalue of the integral is, by the residue theorem4\n\nThe result is multiplied by 1 ( t ) to indicate that it is\nzero when t is negative. JONES\nT\nSUMMARY\n\nA simpliified treatment of the application o HeaWiside\xe2\x80\x99s\nf\noperational methods to problems of airplane dynamics is\ngiven. Certain graphical methods and logarithmic formulas that lessen the amount of cornputation involved are\nexplained.\nT e problem of representing a gust disturbance or\nh\ncontrol manipulation is taken up and it is pointed out\nthud in certain cases arbitrary control manipulations may\nbe dealt with as though they imposed spe&ic constraints\non the airplane, thus avoiding the necessity of any integration whatever.\nThe application o the calculations described in the text\nf\nis illustrated by several examples chosen to show the use\no the methods and the practicability of the graphical and\nf\nlagarithmic computations described.\n\ntion of such equations are given by Wilson and Routh\n(references 1 and 3) and in mathematical textbooks.\nThe problems met in airplane dynamics are often more\ncomplex than the examples treated in textbooks and,\nwhen an attempt is made to apply the given methods\nto their solution, difliculties of computation arise.\nI n view of the importance of investigating these\nproblems and since their solutions involve lengthy calculations, it is desirable that as many mathematical\nsimplifications as possible be employed. Heaviside\xe2\x80\x99s\nmethod gives such a simplification, the solution of the\ndifferential equations being accomplished symbolically\nby a single \xe2\x80\x9cexpansion theorem.\xe2\x80\x9d\nTHE DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS FOR THE DISTURBED\nMOTIONS\n\nAn airplane in uniform flight may be thought of as a\nfree rigid body in equilibrium. Deviations of the airplane from this equilibrium condition may be caused\nThe theory of airplane dynamics in its present form by reactions due to control movement, gustiness in the\nis due mainly to the original researches of Lanchester air, or by some inAuence such as the stopping of an\nand Bryan on the stability of airplanes. Later inves- engine. The motions of the airplane following such a\ntigators, notably Bairstow and Wilson (reference l), disturbance may be calculated if the momentary\napplied and extended the original conceptions of the accelerations or forces are known. It is obvious that\ntheory. Deviations from equilibrium\nI n their usual form, problems of airplane dynamics in either sense will introduce reactions; hence motions\ndepend for solution on the integration of simultaneous of the airplane axes relative to both air and earth\nh e a r differential equations. Methods for the integra- must be considered.\nINTRODUCTION\n\n33\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nThe aerodynamic reactions to the motions arise\nfrom changed relative air velocities ,over the d i e r e n t\nparts of the airplane. The calculation or measurement of these component aerodynamic reactions leads\nto quantities known as \xe2\x80\x9cresistance derivatives\xe2\x80\x9d or\n\xe2\x80\x9cstability derivatives,\xe2\x80\x9d which are taken as constant\nfactors of proportionality between the reactions and\nthe velocities or displacements of the motions. For a\nmore detailed exposition of the concept of stability\nderivatives, the reader is referred to standard textbooks on aeronautics.\nOn account of the bilateral symmetry of the airplane\nit is customary to divide the motions into two inde\npendent groups, the lateral and the longitudinal, each\nconsisting of three degrees of freedom:\nRolling.\n(A) Lateral motions _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ Yawing.\nSideslipping.\nPitching.\n(B) Longitudinal motions- - - - Vertical translation.\nForward translation.\nPresumably the reactions to small increments of\nlongitudinal speed or displacement do not sensibly\ninfluence the lateral motions and the two groups may\nbe independently treated. I n order to illustrate the\ncalculation of the history of a motion due to a given\ndisturbance, examples of lateral motions are chosen\nalthough the methods used are equally applicable to\nany set of degrees of freedom of the airplane. The\nquantities that arise in the consideration of the lateral\nmotions are defined in the follou-ing table:\nVelocities and displacements of airplane axes:\nU,, equilibrium flight velocity along X axis.\nr, component of flight velocity along Y axis\n(sideslipping).\np , component of angular velocity about X axis\n(rolling).\nr, component of angular velocity about 7; axis\n(yawing).\n\xe2\x80\x98 , angle of bank (relative to gravity).\np\nForces and moments resolved along airplane axes:\nY,\ncomponent of force along Y axis.\nL, component of moment about X axis (rolling\nmoment).\nN , component o f moment about Z axis (yawing\nmoment).\nAccelerations of airplane:\nYo=Y/m (force per unit mass).\nL,,=L/mkxZ (moment per unit moment of inertia)\nNo=N/mkz2 (moment per unit moment of inertia)\nGust yelocities resolved along airplane axes:\nI+,, component of gust velocity directed along P\naxis.\nro, component of angular velocity of gust about 7\naxis.\nyo, component of angular velocity of gust about X\naxis.\n\nI\n1\n\n34\n\nNoTE.-The\nsigns of the gust velocities are so\n:hosen that a positive gust produces the same aerolynamic reaction on the airplane as a positive velocity\n,E the airplane in still air. The resolution of gust\nrelocities along the moving axes is exact only to the\nirst order of the small quantities involved.\nAirplane characteristics used as parameters:\n\nY,\ny\n\xe2\x80\x98\n\nI\n\nN\nU\n\nStability derivatives in terms of accelerations of airplane, thus:\n\nNp=g/mkzz\n3P\n\nN\nP\n\nN,\n\nI\n\nWith the definition of the component motions that\nIre to be considered, the stability derivatives will be\nif the form:\n\nwhere L, h7,Y , respectively, are the rolling moment,\nthe yawing moment, and the sidewise force, as they are\nxstomarily defined.\nI t has been found convenient to transform all\nitability derivatives and disturbing effects into terms\nIf accelerations of the airplane rather than retaining\nthem as moments and forces. I n cases of\nl i l a n e motions this equation is normally of the fourth\nlegree in D ; hence it is not practicable to find the roots\nGrectly. Although a number of methods for approxinating the roots of such equations have been devised,\n,he most direct way is to draw a curve of the function\nF(D) against D, locating the real roots as the points\n:rossing the D axis. Usually in equations of this\n;ype qear roots may be isolated by separating the\n:quation into two parts. Thus, if\n\nli\n\nF(D)=D4+aD3+bD2+cD+d=0\nthere will usually be a large real root near\n1\n\nir D=-a,\n\n(1 1)\n\nIT= -aD3,\n\nand a small one near D=--.\n\nd\nC\n\nThis\n\nlivision follows from the consideration that large roots\ntre more dependent on the coefficients of the higher\npowers of D and small roots, on the lower powers.\nIf the natural motion of the airplane contains oscillatory components, as it usually does, there will be pairs\n3f conjugate complex roots of the polynomial F(D)=O\nin addition to the real roots. (See referWhen considering controlled motions, it is often just\nence 1.)\nas reasonable to assume that the airplane is under a\nGUST DISTURBANCES\n\n38\n\nTHE CALCULATION OF DISTURBED MOTIONS OF AN AIRPLANE\n\nkinematic constraint, or prescribed acceleration, im\nposed by the control as to assume that the pilot use\nthe control in an arbitrary way. This assumptioi\nleads to the inversion of the integration problems here\ntofore considered, because the motion of the airplan,\nis itself predetermined and the forces and moments (or\nmore properly, accelerations) required to be suppliec\nby the controls are calculated by differentiation. Thi\nability of various control devices, to produce a givei\nmaneuver of the airplane may thus be compared an(\nthe degree of coordination required of the other con\ntrols may be studied.\nThe foregoing procedure is a particularly useful wa;\nof studying the lateral-control effectiveness in turns\nTurn maneuvers, which usually begin and end in leve\n\nnaturally follows by differentiating this equation. If\nthe turn i s to be \xe2\x80\x9cperfect,\xe2\x80\x9d that is, with no sideslipping,\nthe rate of yawing throughout must bear a definite\nrelation to the angle of bank, namely,\n.\nr=- 9 sin\n\nu\na\n\nor, simply,\n9\nr=-p\n\nu\na\n\nif\n\ncp\n\np\n\n(28)\n\nis under 30\xe2\x80\x99\n\nDifferentiating the expressions for p and r gives the\naccelerations in rolling and yawing and hence the\n\nt\n\n(A)\n\nvo =\nFIGURE 5.--Specifieationsfor a turn maneuver in which the wnstraints are given by\n\nP-2;\n\n~=I$$AAI+AI~~~I~~+WA~\nwsht:\n\nY\n\nn\n\nr-&p.\n\nmoments, which will arise from two sources: the\nreactions due to natural stability and the reactions\nproduced by the displaced controls. The reactions\narising from the motions are found by combining the\nknown stability derivatives with the angular velocities\np and T , obtained from the specification equations (27)\nand (28). The parts of the moments necessarily\nsupplied by the controls are then obtained by deducting these from the total moments. I n the case of the\naileron control, secondary moments in yaw result from\nthe application of rolling moment, which modify the\namount of rudder control displacement necessary.\nCONTROL AGAINST GUSTS OR ENGINE FIULURE\n\nIn order to deal with attempted control of a given\ndisturbance it is important to consider that there is\ninvariably a lag in the pilot\xe2\x80\x99s reaction in countering\nthe motion. The usua\nprocedure in making a turn is to bank the machine ul\nto a definite angle, holding this angle steadily for a shor\nc\ntime while in the steady part of the turn, and then t\nrecover to level flight on the completion of the desirec\nangle of turn. Weick and Robert T. Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1936\n\n45\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 570\nTHE EFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS IN PRODUCING MOTION OF AN AIRPLANE\nAS COMPUTED FROM WIND-TUNNEL DATA\nBy FREDE. WEICX and ROBERT JONES\nT.\n\n-\n\nSUMMARY\n\nAn analytical study o the lateral controllability o an\nf\nf\nairplane has been made in which both the static rolling\nand yawing moments supplied by the controls and the rea+\nf\ntions due to the inherent stability o the airplane have\nbeen taken into account. The investigation was undertaken partly for the purpose o coordinating the results o\nf\nf\na long series o wind-tunnel investigatwns with phenomf\nena obselved injlight tests; for this reason a hypothetical\naverage airplane, embodging the essential characteristics\no both the wind-tunnel models and the full-size test airf\nplanes, was assumed for the study.\nStability derivatives f o r the average airplane and for\nseveral of the actual jlight-test airplanes were computed,\nand computations were made in a n attempt to reproduce\nby the theory the conditions o several actual jlight tests.\nf\nComputations made o forced rolling and yawing motions\nf\no an F-22 airplane caused by a sudden dejlection o the\nf\nf\nailerons were found to agree well with actual measuref\nments o these motions.\nThe conditions following instantaneous full deJlections\nof the lateral control have been studied, and some attention\nhas been devoted to the controlling o complete turn maneuf\nf\nf\nvers. A portwn o the work was devoted to a study o controllability at stalling angles, and the results o this applif\ncation o theory werefound to agree qualitatively withjlightf\ntesting experience.\nf\nThe angle o bank produced in 1 second, p,, by a dejkction o the rolling control m a y be taken as a relative measf\nf\nf\nure o the control effectiveness. In the analysis o controllability below the stall, it was found that a simple\nmeasure o the rolling effectiveness o a control is given by\nf\nf\nf\nthe sum o a constant times the rolling moment and a con-\n\nstant times the yawing moment. !l\'hus a relative weight or\nimportance is given to the secondary yawing moment produced by the rolling control. I t was concluded that the\nimportance o such secondary moments can be minimized\nf\nby alteration o the moments o inertia o the airplane.\nf\nf\nf\nIncreasing the yawing moment o inertia reduces the\nf\nf\neffectiveness o a given yawing control in producing either\nyawing or rolling motion. Changes s\'f rolling moment\no inertia have little direct effect on either the rolling or\nf\nyawing motion produced by a given rolling control moment.\nThe study o Conditions above the s t d indicated that\nf\nsatisfactory control could not be expected without some\nprovision to maintain the damping in rolling and that a\ndangerous type o instability would arise i the damping\nf\nf\nwere insuficient. The quantity L, N,-L, N,<O was\nfound to give a good measure o this type o instability.\nf\nf\nINTRODUCTION\n\nFor some time the N. A. C. A. has been conducting\na program of research on lateral control for the specific\npurpose of obtaining information that would lead to\nimprovement of control at the low speeds and high\nangles of attack above, the stall, a region in which\npresent conventional ailerons are known to be unsatisfactory. Several series of wind-tunnel investigations\nhave been completed and an attempt has been made to\ncompare a number of widely different lateral-control\ndevices on the basis of what has been considered their\nprimary function-the provision of rolling moment.\nSome of the secondary characteristics, such as the\nyawing moments given by the controls and their effect\non the damping in rolling, were considered but only\nby comparing the various values separately. Flight\n\n47\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ntests were then made with the devices that seemed to\npromise the best lateral control at the stall. Some of\nthem did not perform as had been expected from the\nwind-tunnel tests (see reference I, indicating that the\n)\nfirst approximation, based largely on the rolling\nmoments given by the devices, was an insufficient basis\nfor comparison and that the complete interaction of\nthe secondary factors must very likely be considered.\nReferences 2 to 5 describe important work that has\nbeen done on the lateral control of airplanes in both\nnormal and stalled flight. Reference 2 gives a general\naccount of the problem of control of the stalled airplane; references 3 and 4 describe investigations of the\nlateral control and stability of Merent biplane types.\nThe present report contains the results of a study of\ncontrol effectiveness made by means of computations\nthat take into account the secondary factors includmg\nthe yawing moments given by the controls, their effect\non the damping in rolling, the other lateral-stability\nderivatives, and the moments of inertia of the airplane.\nTwo methods of computation are used. In the first,\nthe rolling and yawing motions are computed step by\nstep for the conditions following a sudden deflection of\nthe lateral control; in the second method a complete\nturn is arbitrarily specified and the co-ntrol moments\nand deflections necessary to perform the maneuver are\nfound. The first method is used to compare the\neffectiveness below the stall of various lateral-control\ndevices and to investigate primarily the effects of\nchanged stability characteristics above the stall.\nThe results of calculations made for normal unstalled\nconditions are compared with measurements made in\nflight using different types of lateral-control devices.\nThe effects of certain changes in the lateral-stability\ncharacteristics below the stall are also studied. The\nmethod used in the study of complete turn maneuvers\nhas proved to be a very practical way of dealing with\nspecific control problems. Here all the stability\ncharacteristics of the airpIane are taken into account\nbut the lengthy and tedious integration of the equations\nof motion is avoided by predetermining the actual\nmovements of the airplane in the form of some desired\nmaneuver and then finding the manipulation of the\ncontrols that would be necessary to execute the specified maneuver. The coordination of the rudder with\nn\ndifferent types of ailerons has been studied i this way.\nMOTION FOLLOWING SUDDEN CONTROL APPLICATION\n\nThe method used for calculating the motion following\na sudden application of the controls consists of a step-\n\nby-step integration. In most cases the control moments were assumed to be applied constantly throughout the motion.\n\n48\n\nAssumptions and symbols.-The assumptions usually made in the study of airplane stability were used\nhere, including:\n1. That the a r forces and moments arising from disi\nplacements of the airplane, relative to its steady condition of flight, are proportional to the displacements or\nto their rates.\n2. That the components of moment due to the different components of motion are additive (i. e., the rolling\nmoment due to the combined rolling and sideslipping\nmay be computed as though the rolling and sideslipping\nhad occurred separately).\nThe axes used in specifying the moments, angular\nvelocities, etc., are fixed in the airplane and therefore\nmove relatively to the a r and to the earth. The X\ni\naxis passes through the center of gravity of the airplane\nin the plane of symmetry and is chosen to point directly\ninto the line of the relative wind when the airplane is\nflying steadily. In other respects the axes form a conventional trihedral system, intersecting at the center of\ngravity of the airplane, the Z axis pointing downward\nin the plane of symmetry and the\'Y axis pointing along\nthe direction of the right wing. The motions discussed\nare those of the moving axes relative to the undisturbed air with the exception of the angle of bank,\nwhich is measured relative to the horizontal.\nThe symbols used in the various formulas are d e k e d\nas follows:\n\nU,, velocity along X axis -in steady\nflight.\nw, velocity of sideslip.\np , angular velocity in rolling.\nr, angular velocity in yawing.\nq, angle of bank.\n2)\n\n@=-\n\nangle of sideslip.\n\nJ\n\nu\n0\n\n#\n\n6, angle of control setting.\n\np component of force along Y axis.\n,\nL, rolling moment (about X axis).\nN, yawing_moment (about 2 axis).\naL\n\n_\n.\n\nmkx\n\n,rolling acceleration due to rolling.\n\nbN\n-\n\nA$=%\n,yawing acceleration due to rolling.\nmkz\netc.\nCgSb where C, is the control rollingGLa=-----p\nmkx\nmoment coefEcient.\nc,,qSb where C,, is the control yawing"=(\n6=\nmoment coacient.\n\n{\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS IN PRODUCING MOTION OF AN AIRPLANE\n\nb, wing span.\ne, wing chord.\n\nS,wing area.\n\nI, tail length (distance from c. g. to\nt d post).\nmkxz, moment of inertia of airplane about\naxis.\nmkz2, moment of inertia of airplane about\nZ axis.\nr, dihedral angle.\nA, sweepback angle.\nEquations of motion.-The moments acting on the\nairplane during its maneuvers are considered to be\ndivided into two main groups: (1) Those due to the\ndeflected controls, and (2) those arising from the motions of the airplane. The motions are usually supposed\nto be started by the action of the controls alone but, a t\neach succeeding instant, to be conditioned by factors\nthat vary directly in magnitude with the motions or\ndisplacements relative to the air. The effects of the\nmotions are described by quantities known as \xe2\x80\x9cresistnnce,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cstability,\xe2\x80\x9d derivatives. The part of a rolling\nmoment due to rolling motion i s calculated by the\nbL\nexpression p r ; the partial rolling moment due to\nP\ncombined yawing and rolling is given by:\nbL bL\n\nx\n\nPbp+%\nIt will be found convenient to replace the actual\nmoments by their corresponding angular accelerations,\nwhich are proportional to them. Since\nbL\nthe component of rolling acceleration due to rolling\nmotion is simply\nPL,\nIf the airplanc is moving in a11 its dcgrees of latcral\nlrecdom with deflectcd controls, the tfotA nccclcrntion\nill rolling is cxpressed by\n\n@ =6La+\nat\n\n+\n\np +rL, ~ P L ~\n~\n\n(1)\n\nwhere &La the part of the acceleration due to the conis\ntrol. Likewise the sum of the components of yawing\nacceleration is\nd\nT\n&=SN6 fpN.uf r N r\n(2)\n\nsidewise air forces (i. e., terms containing Y) were\na\nneglected. The most important term here is Ys;\nrough estimate shows that its greatest probable effect\nwould be negligible for the type of maneuver\ninvestigated.\nSince the axes changes their orientat.ion in the airplane with different lift coefficients, they w i l l not be\ndirectly in line with the axes of the principal moments\nof inertia. The corrections are small, however, and\nhave been neglected.\nIntegration of equations.-The equations show that\nin order to calculate the acceleration of the motion at\nany time, the velocities p , T, and the angle of sideslip B\nmust be known. This knowledge is, of course, available only when all accelerations before the time in\nquestion are known; an integration is therefore necessary. This integration may be conveniently performed\nby dividing the time during which the motion occurs\ninto very small steps and by assuming that the velocities\nremain constant over these small intervals. I a\nf\nparticular instant is denoted by the subscript n , the\naccelerations a t this instant may be calculated by tlic\nformulas\n\nIf the preceding time instant is denoted by n-1, the\naccelerations at each succeeding instant may be calculated step by step, using the velocities computed\nfrom the previous instant. Thus:\n\nl\xe2\x80\x98he riglib-liancl sides of bliesc cquatioiis coubaiil o111.y\nquantities known from the precoding instant. At tlic:\nstart, n=O, all the velocities and angles arc takcn <as\n\nzero, and the accelerations are caused by the control\nmoments alone,\n\n($),=6 La\n\nI%\n\n=\n-\n\n+\n\nThe equation for the angle of sideslip contains both the\ncentrifugal effect due to turning and the effect of\ngravity,\n(3)\n\nIt is to be noted that, when the angle of sideslip P\nwas computed, the component accelerations due to the\n\nA typical example illustrating the step -.y-step computation is given in table I.\nComparison of computed and measured motions.-The results of a number of flight tests of the F-22\nairplane equipped with several widely Werent lateral-\n\n49\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUl\'ICS\n\ncontrol devices have been used as checks of the computations. These tests were conducted by gliding the\nairplane a t various steady speeds and suddenly deflecting the aileron control to its full extent. Instrument\nrecords of the resulting rolling and yawing angula;r\n\nF i e , seconds\nF~GLIXE\n1.-Rolling and yawing motion of F-23 airplane with long narrow silerons.\nFlaps up; CL=I.O\n\nE a series of lateral-control devices (reference 7). The\nind-tunnel program included experiments to deterline several important lateral-stability characteristics\ns well as the static rolling and yawing moments\nroduced by the control devices; the results of these\n\nTime, seconds\nQGWEE3.--Rolling\n\nand yawing motion of F-22 airplsne with balanred short wide\nailerons. Flaps up; C ~ - l . l 0 .\n\nnine# seconds\n\nZme, seconds\nFIGURE\n2.-Rolling and yawing motion of F-23 airplane with long narrow aileronr\nFlaps down: C~=1.75.\n\nvelocities were made as a measure of the effectiveness o\nthe various controls. (See references 1 and 6.)\nThe procedure in these experiments simulated vec\nclosely the conditions assumed in the computations\nalthough the flight records showed that about 0.li\nsecond was actually required to accomplish the ful\ndeflection of the control, which was assumed to b\na\ninstantaneous in the computations. In the corn\npaxisons included, this discrepancy was eliminated b:\nappropriate shifts of the time scales.\nThe flight tests were intended to supplement :\nprogram o tests made in the 7- by 10-foot wind tunne\nf\n\n50\n\nFIGURE\n\nexperiments furnished the necessary basis for reproducing the conditions of the flights in the computations. The quantities needed in the computations,\nincluding the resistance derivatives, wese determined\nfrom the known dimensions of the F-22 airplane by\nthe methods given in appendix I.\nWhen computed motions and flight records were\nfist compared, it was found that in many cases the\ninitial accelerations in roll predicted from the rolliig\nmoments obtained in the wind tunnel were larger than\nthose shown by the motions recorded in flight. Thus,\nthe full value of the rolling moment measured on the\n\n4.-Rolling and yawing motion of F-23 airplane with retractable ailerons.\nFlaps up: CL=I.O.\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS I N\n\nmodels was apparently not realized in flight. Examination showed this lack of agreement to be especially\napparent in the cases of devices that would be expected\nto exert the greatest twisting effect on the wings and,\nsince appreciable twisting of the actual wings had been\nobserved in full-scale wind-tunnel experiments, the\ndiscrepancy was attributed to this effect. Calculation\nshowed that in the most extreme case (that of ordinary\nnarrow-chord ailerons) a linearly distributed angle of\ntwist reaching 1 . 7 O at the wing tip would account for\nthe observed difference and that the rolling-moment\ncoefficient would be reduced from 0.056 to 0.043. In\nthis case the a g h t test was made a t a dynamic pressure\nof 9 pounds per square foot. With this first correction\nas a basis, a general correction formula was used in\nwhich the reduction in rolling moment was given as a\nproportion of the dynamic pressure and the change in\nsection pitching-moment coefficient produced by deflecting the controIs.\nFigures 1 and 2 show the rolling and yawing motions\nof the F-22 equipped with long, narrow ailerons. This\nparticular airplane was also equipped with flaps that retracted into the wing ahead of the ailerons. (See reference 6.) Figure 1 illustrates the effect attributed to\ntwisting of the wings. The higher curve was obtained\nwhen a value of the rolling-moment coefficient based\non a wind-tunnel test of a solid wooden model was used.\nThe yawing angular velocity curves showed remarkably\ngood agreement in these two cases, especially as regards\nthe period of the oscillation of this motion.\nThe comparison of the yawing curves in figures 3\nand 4 is not so favorable as in the former cases. In\nfigure 3 it appears that the yawing-moment coefficient\nas computed from the wind-tunnel data was slightly\ngreater than that recorded. In this case the control\nmoment coefficients used in the computations were\nobtained from full-scale wind-tunnel tests of the actual\nairplane; hence no correction for wing twist was applied. The curves of figure 4 apply to a modified\nF-22 airplane equipped with retractable ailerons. It\nis possible that this control device, which is similar\nto a spoiler, has some effect on the yawing moment due\nto rolling. The disagreement in the yawing curves\nwould seem to indicate that too large a negative value\nwas assumed in the computations.\nThe curves of computed rolling motion show no\nconsistent disagreements with the curves plotted from\nthe flight measurements, the differences being of opposite sign in several cases. It seems probable that these\ncomparisons represent the general accuracy obtainable\neither in the experiments or in the calculations.\nCOMPUTATIONS FOR AVERAGE AIRPLANE IN IJNSTAJAED FLIGHT\n\nThe results of the flight experiments with the F-22\nairplane were not suitable for direct comparisons of the\neffectiveness of the various controls used because the\nairplane was modified considerably during the progress\nof the experiments (see references 1 and 6) so that\n\n2ODUCING MOTION OF A N AIRPLANE\n\ndifferent sets of stability derivatives and moments of\ninertia had t o be used in the computations to represent\nthe different individual tests. In order to secure data\nof more general significance and to make a more systematic investigation of control effectiveness than was\npossible in the flight experiments, it was thought\ndesirable to make a series of computations based on a\nstandard set of airplane characteristics, including\nstandard resistance derivatives and moments of inertia.\nAt the same time it was desired to retain the basic\ndimensions of the F-22 machine so that there would\nbe a t least a partial check with the flight-test work a t\nall times.\nthese\nSpecifications of average airplane.-With\nconsiderations in mind the specificationsof an arbitrary\nstandard airplane were devised. The weight and the\nwing area and span of the F-22 airplane were retained\nbut, since other dimensions were obtained from statistical averages, the machine was called an \xe2\x80\x9caverage\nairplane.\xe2\x80\x9d These statistical averages were obtained\nby studying the specifications of a number of conventional airplanes of different sizes, weights, and types.\nData from 20 to 40 airplanes were used for the determination of average values of the folIowing characteristics:\n1. The ratio of the total fin and rudder area to\nthe wing area.\n2. The ratio of the tail length (i. e., distance\nfrom c. g. of airplane to the tail post) to the\nwing span.\n3. The ratios of the radii of gyration in rolling\nand yawing to the wing span.\n\nThe moments of inertia were obtained from data listed\nin reference 8. That the characteristics thus obtained\ndid not differ appreciably from those of the F-22 is\nshown by the following table:\nRangepf.\nCharae\neharacterr4Ia teristies of\nof F-22 airSverage\nplane used in airplane\nEight tests\n~\n\nWeight. ___...._.________._..----.--.-.......pounds.. 1 . ~ 1 , f f i O\n1,6m\n32\n30- 32.8\nWingspan _.._._____.....______----......\n- . . .feet..\n...171\n161- 1 \xe2\x80\x99\nWingarea_._._......________...........7 2\n. squarefeet..\n.\n1.\n08\n1.\n01\nArea of finand rudder.........___.___.._..-.-.-.do...14.6\n1.\n46\nTail length _...___...._..._____--.........--... .feet-.\nmk\n\n1.216\n6961,554\n....._________..._._.-.---.......-......\n\n1....______\n~\n\nI\n\n1.700\n\nComputations based on a purely dimensionless average airplane were considered, but it was thought that\nthe results would have a more concrete meaning if they\nwere presented in terms of an airplane of particular\nsize, especially since they could then be directrlycompared with the fkght results.\nUnstalled-flight computations.-Most of the lateralcontrol devices tested in the wind tunnel did not cause\nany change in the stability derivatives of the wings\n(spoiler devices are a notable exception). In such cases\nthe sole effect of the control in producing motions can\n\n51\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nTime, second\n(a) (b) C1=0.04 C.=O\n(e) (d) CFO\nFIGUEE (a, b, c, d).-Computed rolling and yawing motions of average airplane.\n5\n\n52\n\nCn=O.Ol\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS IN PRODUCING MOTION OF A N AIRPLANE\n\nbe attributed to the static rolling and yawing moments\nproduced; consequently, a large class of devices could\nbe investigated, in effect, by extending computations\nover a suitable range of combinations of static rolling\nand yawing moments.\nOn account of the linearity of the equations of motion\nit was possible to calculate t.he effects of yawing moments\nand rolling moments separately and later to add them\nin any desired proportion. Thus, a t each of the three\nlift coefficients two computations were made, one to\ndetermine the motion due to a yawing moment and the\nother to determine the motion due to a rolling moment.\nThe following table lists the values of the coefficients\nthat were used:\nCL:0.35; 1.0; and 1.8 (20 percent c split flaps, f d\nspan).\nC,, : 0.01 and 0.\nGI : 0 and 0.04.\nIn these cases the dihedral angle assumed for the average airplane was 1O.
