These parameters are shown plotted\nagainst lift coefficient (as a measure of the %ght speed)\nin figures 7 and 8 and represent the principal results\nof the series of computations for unstalled flight.\nDiscussion of below-stall computations.-The factors\nshown in figures 7 and 8 may be used to compare the\neffectiveness of various lateral-control devices on the\nbasis of the motions and displacements they would\nproduce on a 1,600-pound airplane of average stability\ncharacteristics. By showing the effect of secondary\ncontrol moments in producing motion of the airplane,\nthey give a measure of the relative $eight to be assigned such secondary moments in comparing different\ndevices. These factors will, of course, be somewhat\ndifferent for airplanes of different stability characteristics and the relative effects of secondary control moments will be expected to be somewhat different also.\nThe average airplane is simply a convenient yardstick\nin this respect.\nI the factors given in figures 7 and 8 are used as\nf\nabsolute measures of the amount of motion produced\nin 1 second (aside from their use simpIy in comparing\nvarious control devices), a greater error will be committed in applying them to airplanes of different size\nthan in applying them to airplanes of somewhat different stability characteristics. Reference 9 gives the\nnecessary rules for correctly applying the present data\nto airplanes of any size or weight in which certain\ndefinite aspects of similarity are preserved. The theory\nrequires that the airplanes be geometrically similar\nalthough they may have different densities. Practically, this requirement necessitates that the outward\nforms of the airplanes be similar and that the ratios\nof the radii of gyration about each axis to the Wing\nspan be the same. The motions of the different sized\nairplanes are compared a t equal values of the lift coefficient. With equal values of the wing loading the\nangular velocities are inversely proportional to the\nspans: Thus,\n\n76740-37-2\n\n53\n\nI"=\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMIWEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ntad as ordinate\n\n2o\nu\n\nand\n\n2Uo\n\npb\n2U\no\n\n)r\n\nSgb\nWith similar airplanes of different wing loadings the\nstate of motion existing a t a given time for one will\ngenerally pertain to a different instant for another,\nwhich is also true of an airplane of the same size and\nloading but flying in air of different density. Given\nthe motion of the average airplane a t 1 second, the\ninstant to which this state of motion (as indicated by\n\n\'P2m\n3tc.\nIn the case of the average airplane the influence of\nrnoderate dihedral on the lateral controllability below\n\nFIOURE\n7.-Parameters for computing displacement of average airplane at end of 1\n\nsecond with various combinationsof rolling and yawing moments.\n\nthe value of pb/2 U,) pertains on a similar airplane may\nbe found from:\nP O\ns-U\n2 m\n\nt\'= 1 xS\'L\n2\n\n(9)\n\nvl\n,\nr\'\nn\n\nPlots representing the motion of an airplane in nondimensional terms have as abscissa\n\nspo\n\n-X t\nm\n\n54\n\nFIOURE\n8.-Parameters for computing motion of average airplane at end 01 1 second\nwith various wmbinations of rolling and yawing moments.\n\nthe stall was small, as is shown in figure 9. If, however,\na large dihedral effect is combined with considerable\nadverse yawing tendency from the ailerons, the lateral\ncontrol may become ineffective. This condition is\nmost likely to occur a t low speeds with flaps deflected\nbecause under these conditions the wings show their\ngreatest tendency to roll when yawed (dihedral effect)\nand because the aileron yawing moment is usually\ngreatest a t h g h lift coefficient. Furthermore, since the direct\neffectof roll moment of inertia on the rolling motion is\napparently slight, it is possible that increasing mkz2 by\n\nL\n\n</=*\n_--\n\n__-\n\np\n\nTme, sernnd\nFIGURE\nlO.--Diagram illustrating effect of change of moments of inertia on rolling\nand yawing control\n\ndistributing weight along \'the wing span would actually\nincrease the aileron effectiveness if considerable adverse\nyawing moment were present.\nCOMPUTATIONS FOB STALLED FLIGHT\n\nExperiments with lateral control at angles of attack\nabove the stall having been made both in the flight and\nthe wind-tunnel research projects, it was desired to\nextend the present investigation to cover this condition also. Accordingly, a study of the results of both\nseries of tests was made with the object of determining\nwhether the conditions encountered in practice could\nbe reproduced in theory.\nUnfortunately, the wind-tunnel experiments showed\nthat no certain determination of the factors (resistance\nderivatives) involved in the motion of a stalled airplane\nwas possible. On the other hand, the flight experiments\nindicated that these factors apparently had no definite\nvalues (according to their usual definition), inasmuch\n\n55\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nas the action of the airplane could not be foretold\nfrom one experiment to the next. For example, the\noutcome of a simple aileron movement might in one\ninstance be a roll in the direction urged by the control;\nwhereas a t another time, under practically the same\nconditions, the foil would be the reverse of that intended.\nStability derivatives above stalling angles.-The\nreasons for the apparently contradictory results of the\nflight tests may be found in the wind-tunnel measure-\n\nof rolling moment due to rolling and sideslip at various\nangles of attack. Rectangular Clark Y monoplane; data from tests in the 7- by\n10-foot wind tunnel.\n\nPloURE ll.-Coe5cients\n\nments of the stability characteristics made a t these\nhigh angles; these measurements show that motions\nof the wings may develop unstable moments, which\ncould quickly overpower static rolling or yawing moments given by the controls. Figure 11 shows typical\nmeasurements of coefficients by which these quantities\nare determined. These curves show that the rolling\nmoment due to sideslip of a straight wing increases\nenormously as the stall is approached, reaching values\n7 or 8 times as great as those at medium angles below\nstalling. Under the same conditions the damping\n\n56\n\nmoment in rollkg changes sign and becomes nil\n%ding\xe2\x80\x9d (autorotational) moment.\nObviously many of the assumptions of the method as\nused in investigating unstalled-flight phenomena are\nnot true in the case of stalled flight. I n particular, the\nassumed independence of small longitudinal and lateral\nmotions, which is supported by both experience and\nreason for the ordinary-flight range, cannot be said to\nhold under these new conditions because t5e values of\nthe derivatives change very rapidly with small changes\nof Iongitudinal attitude (angle of attack). The assumption that the components of a moment arising from\ndifferent sources may be added together as though their\ncauses occurred separately is apparently borne out only\nin the abstract sense of representing the average\ncondition.\nIn spite of these limitations of the method, it was\nconsidered feasible to extend the computations to the\ncondition of stalled flight in the sdudy of the general\nconditions encountered in controlling such flight,\nalthough the results of the computations made for\nthese conditions do not have the same significance as\nthose made for conditions below the stall. The former\nresults gave quantitative estimatgs of the amount of\nmotion produced by given control moments; the extension of the computations to stalled flight will only\nillustrate the various phenomena that may result from\nthe conditions predicted by the Wind-tunnel experiments.\nExperience in attempting controlled flight above the\nstall has shown that the possibility of controlling such\nflight depends as much on the natural stability characteristics of the airplane as on the possibility of\nsecuring adequate controlling moments. Because of\nthis fact the present,computations were made primarily\nto investigate the effects of changed stability characteristics (derivatives). Another important reason for\nchoosing various combinations of stability derivatives\nis the fact that no very definite values can be assigned\nto them for a particular lift coefficient, as was possible\nin the unstalled-fight range.\nFor these reasons the investigation of controllability\nabove the stall is necessarily preseated in a manner\ndifferent from that used in the cases of ordinary flight.\nThe wind-tunnel measurements were studied to find the\napproximate variation of the resistance derivatives over\na range of angles of attack definitely above the stall,\nchosen to include the region of most violent instability.\nThe particular lift coefficient assumed was n e c e s s d y\nsomewhat loosely defined (CL=1.2);it was so taken\nto represent extreme stalling as well as intermediate\nconditions. The calculation of the stability derivatives\na t these angles is given in appendix I.\nIn the variation of the stability characteristics to\ntake account of the range of possible condit:ons, the\neffects of the parts of the airplane other than the wings\nwere not considered. The wing characteris\xe2\x80\x99tics which.\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS I N PRODUCING MOTION OF A N AIRPLANE\n\nsiiow thc greatest variation in this region and which\napparently have the greatest effect on the stability are:\n1. The damping in rolling, L,.\n2. The rolling reaction due to sideslip, LB.\n3. The yawing reaction due to rolling, N,.\nAccordingly, three values for each of these were chosen,\ncovering the range shown by the wind-tunnel data and\nrepresenting two extremes and pne mean condition.\nThese values were designated a, b, and c and are listed\nin table 1 .\n1\nTABLE 11.-VALUES\nOF STABILITY DERIVATIVES\nUSED ABOVE STALL\nDesignation\n\nL8\n\nnoment coefficient of -0.02. Either of these phenomena\n\nNP\n\n~~~~\n\ng\nc\n\n3.75\n3.50\n\n-7.4\n-11.4\n-14.4\n\n-0.20\n.53\n1.06\n\nIn each case it will be noted that letter c denotes the\nmost extreme condition likely to be encountered.\nCondition a may be fairly assumed to apply only to\ncases where some provision is made to prevent the\nwing tips from stalling, which may be accomplished by\nwashout or twist or by means of some such device as\ntip slots. (See appendix I for determination of these\nderivatives.)\nThe computations were made to cover more than a\ndozen different combinations of these values of the\nderivatives in conjunction with a given fixed pair of\ncontrol rolling and yawing moments. These arbitrary\ncontrolling moments were chosen to represent rollingand yawing-moment coefficientssomewhat greater than\nthose obtained with ordinary ailerons but which might\nbe attained in practice with rather large ailerons, especially those of the short, wide type described in reference 7, I. As in the previous computations (below\nstall), the sign of the standard yawing-moment coefficient was alternated, giving the effect of favorable and\nadverse, as well as zero, secondary yawing moment.\nRange of investigation of stalled flight.-Since in\nt.liesc computations the plan was to study the possibility o control rather than to obtain any numerical\nf\nmeasure of control effectiveness, the procedure of the\ncomputations was sometimes varied in such a way as to\nrepresent attempts of the control to check motions of\nthe airplane as well as to start them. In some cases\nthe motion was assumed to be due to some external\ncause and to exist a t the start of the computations,\nwhile in other cases the initial setting of the control\nwas reversed after a short interval in an attempt to\ncheck the motionit had already produced. The effects01\nboth favorable and adverse yaw were tried in these cases\nResults of computations.-Figure 12 shows rolling\nmotions resulting from suddenly applied and continuously maintained aileron deflections giving a rollingmoment coefficient of 0.04 and an adverse yawing-\n\nFIGURE -Rolling motions resulting from application of adverse-yaw aileron L O I I 12\ntrol in stalled flight with different coinbinations of stability derivativcs, C A I 01;\nc.=-0.02\n\noccurred within the predictable range of tlie stability\nderivatives.\nThe effects of smaller control rolling and yawing\nmoments may be visualized simply by reducing the\nscales of the motions. Thus in figure 12 the motions\ncalculated for Cc=0.02 and Cn=-O.Ol would be just\nhalf those plotted.\nFigure 13 shows the results of attempts to check an\ninitial disturbance in rolling with both favorable- and\nadverse-yaw ailerons. The failure of the adverse-yaw\nailerons is due mainly to the yawed attitude they produce, although the actual yawing motion accounts for\nan appreciable effect. Figure 14 differs from figure 13\nin that it includes also conditions-in which the initial\n\n57\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nmotion countered by the ailerons was assumed to be\ndue to the action of the control rather than to an external disturbance in rolling. Here the ailerons were\ncalled upon to check whatever yawing motion they had\npreviously produced. In this case it w i l l be noted that\nthe favorable-yaw ailerons encountered difJiculty because it was hard to recover from the initial motion\nthey had produced.\nFigure 15 shows the effect of a delay in attempting to\nrecover from rolling and yawing motion. Because of\nthe instability of the airplane, the motion could not be\nchecked even though the yawing moment of the ailerons\nW W favorable. Thus, for the particular case illustrated,\nn delay of 0.1 second in reversing the control changed\nthe action from one in which the airplane followed the\n\n;tall is the loss of the damping in rolling. Below the\n;tall this damping is the most powerful constraint of the\nLirplane, and the effects produced by its sudden drop\n.o zero or to a negative value exert a great influence on\nb e behavior of the machine. Apparently no airplane\n:an be considered safely controllable above the stall\nf the autorotational tendencies observed in windtunnel tests of plain wings are retained.\nDuring a roll maneuver in stalled flight there may be,\nIn addition to the control moment, certain other factors\nthat tend to accelerate the rolling. These factors arise\nbecause the rolIing motion by itself usually tends to\n\nFIGURE\n14.-Rate-of-rolling curves showing effect of favorable and adverse aileron\nyawing moments in attempting to control initial motion in pure rolling and IU\nreversing initial control position. When using tht\nstep-by-step method, it was found convenient t c\ntabulate each separate component of the rolling anc\nyawing accelerations due to the stability factors a\ni\nwell as the components of motion. (See table I.) II\nthis way a complete history of the contribution of eacl.\nfactor was obtained, thus enabling a study of the con\ntrollability in terms of the stability derivatives.\nUndoubtedly the most important single factor con\ntributing to tlic rincontrollable instability above thc\n\n58\n\ninduce a favorable yawing action above the stall.\nThus when the right wing is dropping, its added drag\ncauses a yaw to the right, retarding the wing tip and\ncausing a loss of lift due to decreased speed and tending\nto aggravate the dropping of the wing. The factors\nthat directly oppose these rolling and yawing motion,\nby damping tend to check this sequence if they are\npresent. The first two effects, which aid the angular\nmotion indirectly, relate to L, and N,, proportional,\nrespectively, to the rolling moment due to yawing and\nthe yawing moment due to rolling. Evidently if these\nmoments overcome the direct damping tendencies,\nthe angular motion will tend to accelerate of its own\naccord or will diverge. Suppose for the moment that\nthese opposing tendencies just balance each other,\nthat is,\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS W PRODUCING MOTION OF A N AIRPLANE\n\nInasmuch as p and T are simultaneous, there wiK cording to the magnitude of the tendency exhibited by\nexist a relation between the derivatives that is inde- the value of the criterion, as shown in figure 16. I a rolling moment with no secondary\nf\nyawing moment had been assumed in these cases, each\ncurve would have shown an increasing acceleration in\nrolling greater than that given by the control and ac-\n\nIt may be shown that the question of whether the\nairplane tends to sideslip inward or outward a t the\nbeginning of a rolllng motion depends on the m a g i tude of N , compared with g/U0. As rolling commences\nfrom level @ght the yawing tendency due to the rolling\n(which is usually positive above the stall) causes the\ndowngoing wing to be dragged back, creating an outward sideslipping tendency. This tendency is opposed\nby the action of gravity when the plane is banked,\ntending to produce inward sideslip. The condition\nthat the outward and inward accelerations cancel is\nthat\nrUo=gp\n(12)\n\n59\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nnssiiiiling sin cp cqual to cp. The angular acceleration in\npawing requisite to this condition is\n\ndrdL\ndt Uop\nIn a rolling disturbance the yawing angular acceleration will be due only to N,, or:\n\nHence the condition that a rolling disturbance from\nlevel flight result in neither outward nor inward sideslippingticthat\nN,= 9\n(15)\nand the relative magnitudes of these quantities may be\ntaken as an indication of the resultant tendency.\nThe airplane may diverge in the combined rolling\nand yawing motion previously discussed without sideslipping although such will not generally be the case.\nNear stalling angles the magnitude of the dihedral\neffect of the wings increases enormously (especially if\nthe actual dihedral angle is small) and, if the tendency\nof the airplane is to sideslip outward while rolling and\nturning, any divergence in the rolling and yawing motion (indicated by negative L,N,- L,N,) will be greatly\naggravated. The question of whether the dihedral\neffect will increase the instability is determined by the\nsign of tlie quantity (N,-g/Uo). The magnitude of\nthe effect of the sideslipping tendency thus determined\nobviously depends on the stability derivatives in sideslip Lo and N or, more conveniently, on Lo/Nb. The\no\nvalues of N , computed for the stalled-flight conditions\nb and c were considerably larger than g/Lr0,indicating\nthat the natural tendency would be toward outward\nsideslip during a lateral maneuver. In such cases No\nwould excrt a stabilizing influence, tending to straighten\nniit, tlic skid. Tlio values of thesc sidcslippingcritcrionq\nl\'nr thc cases sliown in figures 12 to 16 arc given in\nhble\n\nTIT.\n\n~ A U L X\nTlT -\n\nCON\'I\'ILOI,I,AUII,ITY CIII\'L\'EKIONS 1?01<\nCAR15S S H O W N I N FIGURER 12 10 16\n\'\n\nI\n\nSideslip\n\ndyKg indication I\n-E,N~ N,-clUo\naaa\n\naab\nacb\nhna\nhab\nbba\nhcb\nma\n\nbbr\n1\n\n2\n3\n\nSideslip\nn lability\n\nLetor\n\nN @\n-2\n\n(1)\n\n- 1.76\n-1 75\n-1.75\n\n0\n0\n\n0\n3.50\n0\n\nPositive values indicate ir.stability\nNegative value5 indicate Instability.\nPositive values indicate outward sideslipping tendency.\n\nPossible modifications of characteristics to improve\nstability above the stall.-Of\nthe factors influencing\n\n60\n\nthe lateral controllability, the stability characteristics\nthat depend on the moments developed by the wings\nappear to be most important, since it is to be expected\nthat they will be changed most by stalling. I n addition to the damping in rolling, the wing moment\ncharacteristics that show marked change a t the stalling\npoint and contribute to the instability are L,, Lo, and\nN,. The factor L,, proportional to the rolling moment\ndue to yawing, depends on the lift coefficient and on\nthe spanwise distribution of lift. Obviously, the\ngreater the lever arm of the supporting lift, the greater\nL, will be and, since it is desired to make L, smaller,\ntapering the wings or shortening their span should\nhelp. The factor Lo at normal angles of attack depends\nalso on this spanwise lever arm of the lift and on the\ndihedral angle. At stalling angles different tip shapes\nhave considerable effect and the relation between the\ndihedrd angle and the rolling moment reverses, the\ngreatest moment being shown by the straight wing\nwith square or upturned tips. (See fig. 11.) Here\nalso, shortening the span and tapering the wing should\nimprove conditions. The use of ,a moderate dihedral\nangle appears desirable in the stalled condition. Tlic\nother Wing characteristic, N,, would be favorably\naffected by shortening the span of the wings. Here\nits magnitude depends mainly on the rate of increase\nof the profile drag of the wings and on the effective\narm of the increase. If no damping in rolling (L,)\nis present, there will be no induced N , but in this case\nthe slope of the wing profile-drag curve is almost certain to be very great, more than accounting for the\ninduced effect. (See appendix I.) Taper or washout\nof the wings should help this situation. The provision\nof damping in rolling calls for keeping the wing tips\nfrom stalling; this requirement is compatible with all\nthe others mentioned except that for small L,. The\ndesirability of maintaining the damping, however, far\noutweighs this consideration.\nIn the ronsidcrn tion of modifications of wing c l ( ~ s i ~ n\nto improve tho contrnllnbilitjy n t high angles, it) ir,\ninipnrtniit to tnlte nrcnunt of tlic premature tip-shlliiig\nl~l~eiioiiinin\ncsliihitctl by tapered wings. As WIIS\npointed nut in tlic previous discussion, reducing Id 14.\nlift and the slopc of the drag curvc near the tips woiilcl\nlead to improved conditions. If this improvement is\neffected simply by tapering the wings, however, thc\nnet result may be detrimental to controllability on\naccount of the premature loss of roll damping dile to\nthe stalling of the tips. In the case of any Wing with\nan extreme reduction of chord, the downwash distributes itself in such a manner as to tend to maintain a\nmore uniform distribution of the actual lift, so that the\nlift coefficient, and hence the effective angle of attack,\nof the reduced-chord sections is greater than at other\nsections. Pressure-distribution tests show that the\ntip portions of a 5 :1 tapered wing reach their maximum\nlift coefficients at angles as much as 5 below the\n\'\nstalling angle of the center portions of the Wing. Thus,\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLG I N PRODUCING MOTION OF AN AIRPLANE\n\ntapering the wings cannot be expected to improve the\ncontrollability a t low speeds unless the taper is accompanied by some washout, or unless other provision\nis made to prevent the tips from stalling.\nIt may be inferred from the foregoing discussions\nthat the effects of high aspect ratio will be detrimental\nto controllability and stability above the stall. It is\neasily seen how the unstable tendencies of the wings\nwould be more unfavorable to controllability if the\nwings were of large span. I the span is large in prof\nportion to the lever arm of the rudder control, the wings\nmay easily develop yawing tendencies that will coinpletely overpower the rudder moments. Furthermore,\nsince rapid yawing motion induces a rolling moment\nthrough L,, it is important to provide a large damping\nin yawing as an indirect check on the rolling as well as\non the yawing motions. Thus it appears that considerable tail length and fn area are desirable to increase\ni\nboth N, and NB. Inasmuch as there ordinarily exists\na great disproportion between the dampings in rolling\nand yawing below the stall, it is probable that fairly\nlarge increases in h , would be permissible without\nT\ncausing undesirable stiffness of the rudder control a t\nhigh speeds. Increasing NB by using larger vertical\ntail surfaces is especially desirable because in that way\nthe available rudder control is increased. Data on\nconventional airplanes show that the rudders used\nproduce the weakest of the three controlling moments;\ntheir maximum moment is often smaller than the secondary yawing moment of the ailerons, yet the rudder\ndeals with the largest moment of inertia of the airplane\nand should be the most effective control in checking\nthe unstable yawing tendencies of the wings (as, for\ninstance, in spinning). It appears that considerable\nimprovement in these characteristics could be effected\nby enlarging the fin surface of conventional machines.\nIf the increased rudder control is found to be undesirnble at high speed because of too great sensitiveness, a\ncorrespondq increase in N,, the damping in yawing,\nshould remedy this trouble and still further improve\nt . 1 1 ~Controllability a t high angles. Thus if the tail is\ninadc longer as the vertical surface is increased, the\ncontrol characteristics at high speed should not be\niiniavorably affected. i t appears unlikely, however,\nthat such improvements could result in the retention of\nsatisfactory control above the stall if the autorotational\ntendencies shown by ordinary wings in wind-tunnel\nexperiments are developed.\nTURN MANEUVERS\n\nThe foregokg computations were designed to represent the procedure employed in a particular type of\nfight test to compare the efficiency of various control\ndevices purely on the basis of their independent action\nin producing roll. Another type of flight test, qualitative in nature, consisted of performing normal turn\n\nmaneuvers with the airplane, using the device in conjunction with the other controls and observing the\namount of coordination that was required.\nThe first type of computation together with the fight\ntests showed that the roll-producing effectiveness of\nsome devices would be influenced by the occurrence of\nconsiderable incidental sideslipping, much of the apparent improvement due to favorable secondary yaw\nbeing obtained by the production of outward sideslipping.\nSince it was not known in any quantitative way how\nthe presence of this sideslipping tendency due to the\nsecondary aileron moments would affect the controllability in making actual turn maneuvers, it was decided\nto make an analysis of these conditions, representing\nanalytically as nearly as possible the second stage of the\nfight tests.\nEXPLANATION OF METHOD OF COMPUTATIONS\n\nIn certain instances in the former computations a\nsimple sort of controlled maneuver was used in which\nan initial deflection of the ailerons was reversed, representing an attempt to check a motion previously\nproduced by them. (See fig. 13.) It was realized that\nan extension of this procedure could be applied to the\npresent problem by means of step-by-step integrations\nof the motion due to any arbitrarily specified way of\napplying the controls. This adaptation of the former\nmethod would have required a knowledge of the control\nmanipulations necessary to perform a normal turn, as\nwell as lengthy step-by-step calculations. For these\nreasons it was considered more feasible to predetermine\nthe actual motion of the airplane than to fix on an\narbitrary way of applying the controls. Furthermore\nit seemed reasonable to presume that the pilot of an\nairplane would conform his use of the controls to suit\na desired maneuver, rather than to prescribe beforehand his use of the control and accept whatever motion\nof the airplane followed.# He would then judge tho\neffectiveness of the control by the way it had to be uscd\nto obtain a desired result.\nAs the outcome of these considerations, tho pro1)hii\nof investigating turn maneuvers presented itself in II\nway inverse to the previous problems. Here the motioi~\nof the airplane was given and the requisite use of thc\ncontrols was sought. Previously the airplane motions\nhad been determined from the controlling accelerations\nby integration, whereas here the accelerations incident\nto a given motion were to be determined; thus the\nprocess would simply be a differentiation.\nPeriodic or trigonometric functions of the time\nnaturally suggested themselves for the representation\nof the angular velocities and displacements during a\nturn maneuver. By the use of trigonometric functions\nof the time, any conceivable maneuver of the airplane\nthat begins and ends in level flight may be specified;\nthat is, any given manner of varying the attitude or\n\n61\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nangular velocity of the airplane during a given kterval\nmay be described by a formula such as\np , or p, or . . . etc.\n=A, sin nt+A, sin 2nt+AP sin 3nt+etc.\n(16)\n\nBy a suitable choice of n the maneuver may be made to\nextend over as long or as short a time as desired.\nIn the present case it was intended that the airplane\nroll up to a moderate angle of bank, starting with the\nwings level, and check its rate of rolling so as to maintain this bank angle steadily, then roll back to the\nlevel condition after a definite time interval. Throughout this interval the airplane was to be yawing appropriately while banking and in the correct amount to\nprevent sideslipping during every part of the maneuver. Thus the turn was to be \xe2\x80\x9cperfect\xe2\x80\x9d in that no\nsideslip was permitted and the coordination of the\nlateral controls (ailerons and rudder) necessary to\naccomplish such a maneuver was to be studied.\nA few trials in plotting cosine curves against time\nshowed that the expression\np=-Al\n\ncos nt-% Al cos 2nt+constant\n\n(17)\n\nwould represent a bank that assumed a steady angle at\nthe midpoint of the maneuver, starting with zero at\nthe time t = O and becoining zero again at t=T/n.\nArranging for the bank to become steady at the midpoint of the maneuver and choasing nt so as not to\ncoincide with the natural period of the free motions of\nthe airplane obviated the possibility of any reinforced\noscillation phenomena during the maneuver. The\nform of the curve of bank angle against time plotted to\nthis formula is shown in figure 17.\nIn order to attain the specified bank a t every instant,\na definite rate of rolling is required at all times, which\nis obviously found by differentiat.ingthe bank equation;\nthus\nd\n2n\np = z = n A 1 sin n t + T A , sin 2nt\n(18)\nIn order for the airplane to turn without sideslipping,\nthere must be a coordination between the banlring and\nyawing at all times. The outward and inward accelerations must cancel, that is:\n\nrUO=g sin p\n\n(19)\n\n(See equation (12).)\nThis equation enables the calculation of r from\nassuming the condition that\n\np\n\nis satisfied. The curve of yawing angular velocity\nplotted against time is thus very similar in shape to thc:\nbad<-angle curve, reaching n steady value a t its mid-\n\npoint.\n\n62\n\nThe specification of the angular velocities and angles\nthe airplane in the foregoing manner is analogous to\nthe specification of constraints of the motion. The\ntotal accelerations necessary to constrain the airplane\nto the specified motions are calculated by differentiating\nthe expressions for the angular velocities, p and r.\n(See equat.ions (17) and (18).)\n3f\n\ndP-d%- 8 A ,\nz-z2-n\n\n4n2\ncos nt+-Al\n4\n\ncos 2nt\n\n(21)\n\nmd\n\nThese accelerations are not furnished altogether by\nthe controls but have components due to the air reactions on the moving airplane. The air reactions are\ncalculated from the resistance derivatives and,when\ndeducted from the total accelerations, give the components necessarily supplied by the deflected controls.\nThus the acceleration supplied by the rolling control\nwill be\n&=-& --pL,-rL,\ndP\n(23)\nIf the application of rolling control is accompanied by a\nsecondary (adverse or favorable) yawing moment, the\nrudder control will have to accommodate this moment\nas well as the residual acceleration of the yawing\nmotion. This secondary yawmg moment may be\nconsidered to be a function of the rolling moment and\n;\nits acceleration written as f @La) then\n\nsN6=z-pNp-rNr-f\ndr\n\n@La)\n\nEquation (24) gives the amount of rudder coordination\nnecessary with a given aileron-control device. The\nrolling- and yawing-moment coefficients corresponding\nto these acceleratibns may be calculated by known\nmeans from the speed of fight and the airplane dimensions.\nIn the derivation of the equations for the turn\nmaneuvers no account was takeo of the pitching motion\ninvolved. Obviously if a banked airplane is turning\nwithout loss of altitude there will be a component of\nn\npitching involved in the motion. As was errpltkned i\nthe description of the step-by-step method of computation the pitching motion may be considered separately\nand independently of the lateral motions since the airplane is symmetrical about the plane in which pitching\noccurs. Presumably, the only ways in which pitching\nmotions can influence the lateral motions are by a\nchange of speed or attitude introducing changes i the\nn\nlateral-stnbility derivatives or by gyroscopic couples.\nIn the case of a prescribed turn maneuver the maximum\ngyroscopic couple may be estimated in advance and the\nrelative importance of its effect may be foreseen. The\nother secondary influence may bc partly accounted for\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS IN PRODUCING MOTION OF AN AIRPLANE\n\nby assuming a certain increased speed throughout the\nturn. Either the air speed or the attitude will, in\ngeneral, vary continuously throughout the turn if no\naltitude is lost or gained. For turns up to 30" angle\nof bank the change in stability derivatives thus produced will be sliiht and may be satisfactorily campen-\n\n-4\n.\n0\n\n1\n\n2\n\n3\n\n4\n\n5\n\nrhere Poi the dynamic pressure a t steady-flight speed\ns\ns\n,nd p is the angle of bank a t which the airplane i\nssumed to lose or gain no altitude.\nRESULTS AND DISCUSSION\n\nThe foregoing procedure was applied to the c s e of\nhe average airplane performing 30\xc2\xb0 banked turns a t\nT ~ ~ O speeds. These computations showed that the\nnaximum yawing moment necessary at the lowest\nspeed was 10 times as great as that a t high speed, while\n,he maximum rolling-moment coefficient increased only\nL times under the same circumstances. Figure 19\nllustrates this increase of coefficient necessary to per\xe2\x80\x98 o m the specified maneuver in the same time at the\nower speeds.\nFigure 20 shows the effects of favorable and adverse\n;econdary aileron yawing moments on the rudder con,rol necessary throughout the turn. Positive yawing\nnoments indicate a setting of the rudder in a direction\n,o aid the turning. It will be noted that the existence\nIf any secondary aileron moment calls for a counteractng movement of the rudder applied simultaneously\nMith the ailerons a t the beginning of the turn. With\nio secondary aileron moments the curves show that the\n;imultaneous initial deflection of both ailerons and\n.udder is not required, the turn being initiated by the\ntilerons alone with the rudder being. applied after the\n;tart. In the case of favorable secondary yawing monents an initial setting of the rudder opposite to the\niirection of the turn is required, while on beginning\nh e recovery the rudder has to be moved slightly in a\nlirection that would normally tend to continue the\nturning. It appears that ailerons giving no secondary\nyawing moments of either sign would .require the least\nrudder coordination in making turns without sidedipping.\nCONCLUSIONS\n\n1. The agreement of the computations with Idic\n\nmaneuver may be presumed to be of any time extent by\nassuming a continuation of this steady point, which\noccurs a t T seconds.\nThe results of a series of these computations showed\nprincipally the effect of flight speed on the degree of\ncontrol deflection necessary to perform a given maneuver and the effect of favorable-yaw and of adverse-yaw\nailerons on the amount of rudder control required.\nFigure 18 shows the rolling- and yawing-moment coefficients necessary to accomplish the maneuver a t speeds\ncorresponding to the three different lift coefficients.\nFor the average airplane these were:\n\n64\n\nresults of flight tests verifies the usefulness of thc\nmethod utilizing stability derivatives for the study of\ncontrollability both above and below the stall.\n2. The angle of bank produced in 1 second, PI, by n\nfull deflection of the lateral control may be taken ns a\nrelative measure of the control effectiveness. In the\ncase of a conventional airplane this measure is given\nby a simple formula involving the static rolling and\nyawing moments produced by the control, namely:\nrpl\n\n=constantX Cz+constantX C,,\n\n3. The effect of secondary adverse yawing moments\non the aileron control may be moderated by increasing\n\nthe moment of inertia about the yaw axis, although\nit is to be expected that the power of the rudder will be\ncorrtxpondingly reduced. Increasing the moment of\ninertia about the roll axis should have little direct\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS IN PRODUCING MOTION OF AN AIRPLANE\n\ninfluence on the lateral-control effectiveness with a\ngiven rolling-control moment.\n4. The tendency for a given adverse yawing moment\nto render the laterd control ineffective becomes greater\nwith increasing dihedral. In no case should the ratio\nof the control adverse yawing moment to the rolling\nmoment be dowed to exceed (in absolute magnitude)\neither:\n(a) The ratio of yawing to rolling moment acting on\nthe airplane in sideslip; or\n(b) The ratio of yawing to rolling moment acting on\nthe airplane in yawing.\n5. It appears that ailerons giving nearly zero yawing\nmoment would require the least coordination of the\nrudder control in executing turn maneuvers without\nsideslip.\n6. The study of conditions above the stall indicates\nthat satisfactory control cannot be expected unless\n\nTABLE 1.-STEP-BY-STEP\n\n1.68\n\n0\n.05\n\n.lo\n\n.20\n.30\n.40\n.50\n.60\n\n.70\n.80\n.90\n\n1.00\n\n1.680\n1.409\n1.181\n\n-.7m\n\n.518\n\n.329\n.199\n.lo9\n.5\n00\n.M)9\n\n-.013\n-*027\n\n0\n\n.OM\n.154\n\n--In4\n\nXAi\n\nXAt\n\n+8.-1\n\n+\'p"-l\n\nX-0.663\n\n--I0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n0\n\n.n\nz\n\n.004\nf019\n.M6\n\n.436\n.456\n.467\n.472\n.473\n.472\n\n.165\n.211\n.257\n.3M\n\n.351\n.4a3\n\nC,=O]\n\n8"\'\n\n-\n\n-___\nsee.\n\nXAt\n+P.-1\n\ntlj\n\nLANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nLABORATORY,\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMXITTEE AERONAUTICS,\nFOR\nLANGLEY\nFIELD,\nVA., ,4pril20, 1936.\n\n-\n\n\'pn\nPn-1\n\n6L6+2Li\n\nThis condition appears to be next in importance\ndirect damping in rolling.\n\n[c\'=l.o;\ncl=o.M;\n\nPm\n\n(ah=\n\nL&r>LNp\n\nCOMPUTATION O F MOTION OF AVERAGE AIRPLANE\n\n--\n\nTime\n\nsome provision is made to maintain the damping in\nrolling a t these angles.\n7. Tests of wings with very large sweepjack, such as are used on tailless airplanes, have been\nnade in which the rolling mom*entdue to yaw actually\nVeversed its sign when the stall was reached.\nYAWING ACCELERATION DUE TO EOLLING, NO\n\nIt is m n d that the ef\xe2\x82\xacect of a rolling motion of\nwe\n,he wing can be replaced by a relative rolling motion\n\nAspect r a i i o\nFIGURE\n%.-Rolling moment due to sideslip. The derivative Lo follows from\nthe formula:\ndC\nb\nLo=-lSq04)\ndp mkxa\nInasmuch as the wind-tunnel tests were of rectangular wings of aspect ratio 6, the formula (33)\napplies directly to them. Correction factors for calculating the rolling moment due to the dihedral oj\nyawed wings of different aspect ratios and taper ratios\nare given in figure 25. These corrections were deduced\nfrom theoretical calculations made at the Laboratory\n(reference 11) on the span load distribution of wings\nhaving their right and left semispan portions set at\ndifferent angles of attack and are somewhat differeni\nfrom those deduced previously for the damping in\nrolling.\nAbove stalling angles none of the given formulas 01\ncorrection factors apply. In this region a straighi\n\nof the air about the X axis of the airplane. Thus in\npositive rolling the relative air stream is rising toward\nthe right wing tip and descending on the left. The lift\nvectors, being perpendicular to the relative wind at\neach point of the span, are inclined forward with\nrespect to the 2 axis on the right and backward on the\nleft, resulting in a negative yawing moment for positive\nrolling of the wing. (This varying resolution of the lift\nvectors along the span is unimportant in computing\nthe rolling moment due to rolling since the angle\npb/2Uoki m l.\nal )\nIn addition to the changed resolution of the lift\nvectors along the span, there is an increased drag on\nthe downgoing wing that tends to reduce the negative\nyawing tendency. It should be noted that an asymmetrical change in the lift distribution, such as that\ncaused by rolling, results in greater changes in the\ninduced drag at various sections of the wing than\nwould be produced by symmetrical lift changes. (See\n\n68\n\nfor aspect ratio\n\nEFFECT OF LATERAL CONTROLS IN PRODUCING MOTION OF A N AIRPLANE\n\nreference 14.) Hence the uncorrected results of\nmeasurements made on the wing in direct lifting\ncannot be used in computing the rolling or yawing\nmoments of a rolling wing.\nFigure 26 shows the resolution of the lift at a point\nof the span y on the downgoing side of the wing. A study of the results of these tests\nindicated that at low angles of attack the yawing\nmoment may be estimated from the area and disposition of the vertical fin with a suitable allowance for\nthe fuselage effect. Although airplane bodies when\ntested alone almost invariably show an unstable yawing\ntendency about the center of gravity, when tests of a\ncomplete model are made the results may show an\nadditional stabilizing influence of the fuselage, possibly\ndue to interference effects. At high lift coefficients the\nwings may exert considerable influence. The effect of\nthe fuselage depends, of course, on its disposition with\nrespect to the center of gravity and also on the nose\nshape. Models, especially those with uncowled radial\nengines, often show only 40 or 50 percent of the righting\nmoment calculated for the fin and rudder alone.\nThe part of the yawing moment in yaw due to the\nvertical fin surface may be estimated by means of the\ndata previously used for the calculation of N,,\n\nIn cases of airplanes having wings set at a dihedral\nangle some provision must be made for an additional\nyawing moment in yaw that arises as a consequence of\nthe setting of the wings. In straight flight, lift vectors\ndrawn on each wing half, being inclined inward by the\nangle of dihedral, would intersect on the Z axis vertically above the center of gravity. These lift vectors\nremaining at the same time petpendicular to the\nleading-edge lines and to the relative wind direction\ndo not intersect when the wing is yawed, giving rise\nto a couple. This correction is of no importance, however, and need not be\n:onsidered. The same is true of the logical correction\nthat should be applied to the wind-tunnel measurements\naf rolling moment in yaw, which were actually made\nabout an axis pointing directly upstream and hence\nnot quite in line with the axes considered ip the report.\nThe only correcting terms that are of sufficient magnitude to be considered here are those affecting L,, Lo,\ntlnd N , and arising from the fact that the fn and body\ni\nsurfaces are disposed below the rolling axes. A., 1924.\n\nREPORT NO. 579\nA STUDY OF THE TWO-CONTROL OPERATION OF AN AIRPLANE\nRobert T. Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1936\n\n73\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 579\nA STUDY OF THE TWO-CONTROL OPERATION OF AN AIRPLANE\nBy ROBERT JONES\nT.\n\nSUMMARY\n\nThe two-control operation of a conventional airplane\nis treated by means of the theory of disturbed motions.\nThe consequences o this method of control are studied with\nf\nregard to the stability of the airplane in its unconstrained\ncomponents of motion and the movements set up during\nturn maneuvers.\nIt is found that the motion of a conventional airplane\nis more stable when an arbitrary kinematic constraint i s\nimposed in banking than when such constraint is imposed\nin yawing. Several hypothetical assumptions of piloting\nprocedure, each of which is considered to represent a\ncomponent of the actual procedure, are studied. Di#erent\nmeans of two-control operation are also discussed and it is\nconcluded that a reliable rolling-moment control that does\nnot give the usual adverse secondary yawing moment\nshould be most satisfactory. Several special modijications\nintended to make the airplane more suitablefor two-control\noperation are also discussed, and it is found that relatively\ngreat weathercock stability (Ne)would be desirable.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nA number of flights have been made with airplanes\nutilizing both the aileron-elevator and the elevatorrudder combinations for two-control operation. Some\nquestion exists as to whicli of these modes of operation\nis likely to prove the better and also whether either of\nthem is capable of affording the controllability requisite\nto safety in fLight. Such questions must, of course, be\neventually decided by experience, no mathematical\nanalysis being sufficiently broad to deal with all aspects\nof the problem. It is believed, nevertheless, that certain conceptions gained from an analysis of the problem\nmay be useful in furthering development along these\nlines.\nOne of the purposes of the present work was to\nascertain on theoretical grounds which of the two\npossible modes of operation was more likely to prove\nsatisfactory. It was also desired to find what changes\nmight be effected in a conventional airplane to make it\nmore suitable for two-control operation.\nThe analysis of the various dynamical problems that\narise makes use of many concepts that are discussed\nat length in reference 1. The treatment of airplane\nmotion as a problem of dynamics is based primarily on\n\nthe assumptions of the theory of airplane stability as\ndeveloped by Bryan and others; for the elucidation of\nthis theory the reader is referred to text books on\naeronautics.\nMATHEMATICAL TREATMENT OF CONTROLLED\nMOTION\n\nThe motion of an airplane with adequate control\nabout its three axes may, in one sense, be regarded as a\npurely constrained motion. From this point of view,\nthe act of piloting the airplane must be\'considered to be\nthe use of the available control means for overcoming\nthe inherent aerodynamic and inertial reactions of the\nairplane, causing it to follow a more or less definitely\nconstrained motion induced by the controls. The\nnatural oscillation and damping of the free motion of\nthe airplane do not appear, then, in the controlled\nmotion because the pilot has accommodated his use\nof the available control to the governing of these\ninherent tendencies. Accordingly the stability or instability of the airplane will be apparent only in the requisite use of the controls to perform a given maneuver.\nIt has been found by experience that the lateralstability characteristics of an ordinary airplane are\nsuch that it is feasible to abandon one of the direct\nconstraints of the later81 motion in ordinary flight\nmaneuvers. All lateral maneuvers that are to be\nperformed with a minimum of sideslipping or sidewise\nacceleration require a definite coordination between\nthe banking and yawing motions; it appears that a\nconventional airplane will naturally tend to fulfill this\nrequisite relation in greater or less degree, on account\nof the inherent stability, even when one of the lateral\ncontrols is abandoned.\nUnder the conditions of two-control operation the\nmotion of the airplane cannot be considered as an entireJ.y constrained motion. The pilot of such a machine\ncan exercise direct constraint in only one of the three\ncomponents of lateral movement and must depend on\nthe natural tendencies of the airplane for the requisite\ncoordination of the other motions. In order to show\nthis coordination the airplane need not be entirely\nstable with all controls released, but it is imperative\nthat there be satisfactory stability in those components\nin which the machine is unconstrained. Thus, if an\n\n75\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nairplane is to be controlled by the ailerons and elevator\nalone, it must be satisfactorily stable in combined\nyawing and sideslipping, in which it is free; if control\nis by rudder and elevator, corresponding stability in\ncombined banking and sideslipping is necessary.\nI the controls are considered to impress constraints\nf\nin those components of motion in which they operate\ndirectly, the movements of a two-control airplane may\nbe studied by the method of forced oscillations. Thus,\nif the airplane controlled by ailerons is caused to follow\na definite course in banking, in which it is considered\nto be constrained, this motion will impress disturbing\nforces and couples leading indirectly to yawing and\nsideslipping motions. The yawing and sideslipping\nmotions must, however, be considered to be unconstrained and to be conditioned by the natural stability\nof the machine as well as by the impressed disturbances.\nThe disturbing forces or couples impressed in those\ncomponents in which the airplane is unconstrained\nare caused by the constrained movements and are\nconsidered proportional to them. The factors of\nproportionality are simply the appropriate stability\nderivatives of the airplane. Thus, if the machine is\nconstrained to follow a definite sequence of rolling\nmotions by the application of a suitable contxol moment,\na disturbing acceleration in yawing that is proportional to the given rate of rolling at each instant will\nbe impressed, namely:\ndr\nimpressed -=pxN,,\n\nr, yawing component of angular velocity.\nv, component of 3ight velocity along Y\naxis (sideslip).\n(p, angle of bank (relative to gravity).\n8, angle of sideslip vlUo, approximately.\n6, angle of rudder or aileron deflection.\nY,force component along the direction\nof the Y axis.\nL , rolling-moment component.\nN , yawing-moment component.\n6La=Llmkx2,Control moments per unit moment of\n&Na=N/mkzz, inertia of airplane.\ny e Stability derivatives in terms of unit\nL, mass or moment of inertia of air-\n\n1\n\n1\n\nA number of secondary considerations will be neglected in the mathematical analysis of the problems\nto make the mathematical expressions as simple 8s\npossible and because it is not considered important to\nsecure exact numerical results for studying the general\nproblem. For these approximate calculations the\nlateral and longitudinal motions of the airplane will be\nconsidered separable during turning flight. A check\nof the maximum gyroscopic couples encountered shows\ndt\nIn order to express the foregoing ideas defkitely it that they are negligible for the present study, although\nwill be necessary to resort to mathematical treatment it is probable that the longitudinal and lateral oscillaof the motions. It is convenient for this purpose to tions in turning flight can be separated for only a\nchoose a set of axes rigidly h e d in the airplane a t its relatively short time after the passing of a disturbance.\ncenter of gravity and inclined a t the angle of attack a, Another assumption-made is that the effect of a comso that the X axis points into the direction of the ponent torque applied to the airplane is an angular\nrelative wind in steady flight at the specified lift co- acceleration about the axis of the torque. In general,\ne5cient. The following notation and diagram define the angular acceleration does not have the same axis\nas the applied torque but in the present case the referthe quantities used i the subsequent equations.\nn\nence axes chosen lie near the assumed principal axes of\ninertia, and the difference of moments of inertia. taken\nabout various axes i4 not great. In addition, the\nflight of the airplane is assumed to be horizontal and\nthe speed not to vary appreciably from the average\n(U,) in a given case.\nAccording to the previously outlined treatment, the\nmovement of the airplane in at least one of the lateral\ncoordinates will be m o a e d by a constraint. The\ncomplete set of three degrees of freedom is not in this\ncase expressed in the usual three simultaneous equations of motion, for this procedure would imply that\neach component of the motion was affected by the\nZ\nother two, whereas the present problem calls for an\nU,, forward (X-wise) velocity in steady independent expression of one of them. Thus, it is\nassumed that the available control is SuSSciently\nflight.\np , rolling component of angular veloc- powerful to force any desired motion in the controlled\ncomponent. When setting up the equations, this\nity.\n\n76\n\nA STUDY OF THE TWO-CONTROL OPERATION OF AN AIRPLANE\n\nmotion will be considered to be given as a function of\nthe time.\nIt is important to emphasize in the interpretation\nof the mathematical analysis the practical significance\nof the assumptions used. The solution of the equations requires that the complete history of the variation\nof one of the components of the motion (or the contral\nsetting) be known beforehand. This variation is not\nsubsequently altered to accommodate the variation of\nthe other motions as would be the case if an intelligent\npilot were a t the controls. It may be imagined that\nthe pilot has only one degree of attention. Having fixed\non a procedure of rolliig the airplane, he concentrates on\nthe execution of this alone, paying no attention to the\nconsequences in yawing or sideslipping. It would be\nfeasible to assume that the pilot concentrated his\nattention on carrying out a predetermined manipulation of the controls, without regard to any of the\nmotions set up. This assumption is, however, considered to be too far removed from actuality to be of\nmuch use in analyzing the problem. It would be of\nmore practical interest to assume that the pilot had\nsufficient skill to enforce a desired motion in every\nrespect, taking no account of the control manipulations.\nThe control manipulations required could then be\ncalculated and an idea of the degree of skill necessary\nto attain a perfect result could be derived therefrom.\nWith two-control operation a perfect coordination\nf\nof the motions is, of course, not possible. I the pilot\nenforces complete control over one component of the\nairplane\xe2\x80\x99s motion, h\xe2\x80\x98e must do so a t the expense of\ncontrol in some other component. The residual component is then considered to be free. In practice the\npilot can exercise an indirect influence on all lateral\nmotioas with only a single lateral control. Hence, it\nis possible to assume that a skilled pilot could enforce\ncomplete control over the yawing motion even though\nhis available control exerted only rolling moments\ndirectly. Then the rolling motion must be considered\nfree and not subject to the pilot\xe2\x80\x99s attention although\nhis available control operates directly on this motion.\nSuch an assumption obviously cannot give an accurate\ndescription of anything occurring in practice. The\nsame is true in some degree of any other assumed procedure that can be mathematically treated. The actual\nprocedure of a pilot is undoubtedly an indeterminate\nand variable synthesis of such elementary procedures.\nThe study of a single assumption of this nature is\ntherefore incomplete, constituting simply a part in the\nanalysis of the problem.\nIn order to illustrate the variety of assumptions\nthat may be treated, four equations, containing\nmovements both of the airplane and of the control\nsurface, will be set down:\n\n~-g\xe2\x80\x98p+~U0-vYv\ndv\n\n-0\n\n* - - - ~ L ~ - ~ L , - ~ L . - - G=O~\nL\ndt\n@-pNp-rNr-vN,-6N6=0\ndt\nda\na-p\n\n=O\n\nThese equations are to be satisfied simultaneously and,\nsince there are more variables than equations, one of\nthe variables must be given in terms of the time to\neffect a solution. Any assumption of the kind considered may be applied by setting one of the variables\nequal to a function of t . Thus the equations of motion\nwith an arbitrarily prescribed course in rolling are:\n\ndr\n---rN,-vN,,-6Na=\nNpp(t)\ndt\nSimilarly, if the pilot uses the control to enforce\nsome given motion in yawing, the equations are:\ndv\n--gp-VY,\ndt\n\n= - Uor(t)\n\n--pLpdP\nvLv- 6La= Lrr(t)\ndt\n-pN,-vN,--GNa= N A t )-z(t)\nd\nk p , 0\n\ndt\nSolutions of the foregoing differential equations have\nthe general form\nv,p16,or r=(CleAgf+C2eAz1+ . CneXnt)+{(t) (4)\n.\nThis type of solution has two significant components;\nthe part enclosed by parentheses represents the occurrence of the natural oscillations and damping in the\nf\nresultant motion. I the natural modes of motion are\nstable, this component will disappear with time and\nf\nthe solution will be represented by { ( t ] . I the impressed disturbance is periodic, the motion will a t first\ns\nbe conditioned by the natural period but, if this i\ndamped, will later follow the impressed period in accordance with Herschel\xe2\x80\x99s theorem. In these cases\nthe term ( ( t ) may be called the \xe2\x80\x9csteady-state solution.\xe2\x80\x9d\nUnder the assumed conditions of two-control operation the pilot enforces one component of the motion\nand relies on the reaction of this motion on the uncontrolled component to induce an appropriate\n\n77\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ndity on the manipulations of the control required\n,o enforce the desired constraint i bank as well as the\nn\nitability of the free yawing and sideslipping oscillaions. Whatever rolling motion is assumed, a solution\nIf the complementary equations will appear as a comionent of the final solution.\nThe third equation of (5) may be solved for v and the\neesulting expression substituted into the first equation,\n3 t c . Such instability would indicate that an arbitrary constraint in rolling (such as\nattempted level flight) could not be maintained by the\nailerons alone.\nConventional ailerons give rise to adverse yawing\nmoments in an amount approximately independent of\nthe speed of flight while the rolling moments and\nstabilizingfactors are much reduced at the lower speeds.\nThe result is that the ratio K approaches the foregoing\nundesirable magnitude at the highest lift coefficients.\nIt is therefore considered that ordinary ailerons working on a part of the wing surface that sustains a high\nlift would not be desirable for two-control operation.\nTable I1lists the results of calculations of the stability indexes of the average airplane in free yawing and\nsideslipping modons at several lift coefficients. Ol9f e36 i\n015* . a 6 i\n\n-.\n\n.\n\n79\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nThe fact that the auxiliary equation for the case of\nfree rolling and sideslipping motion with yawing control\nhas roots of such widely different magnitude is an\nindication that the motion may be separated into\ndistinct modes. The large real root (nearly equal to\nLp)indicates the sharp damping of an initial rolling\nmotion and is of such magnitude that the wings may\nbe considered to be in a measure constrained against\nroUing relatively to the air. A possible rolling motion,\nhowever, that will not be appreciably damped consists\nin rolling about an instantaneous center some distance\nabove the center of gravity of the airplane. For\nrotation of the airplane as a rigid body about this\npoint the rolling m m e n t due to sideslip will balance\nthe damping of the rolling.\' The height, Y L , of the\ninstantaneous center above the center of gravity is\nfound from:\nvLo=-pL,\nwhere\nv= -pz\nwhence\n- L =L\nP\nZ\nz\n(17)\nThe mode of motion represented by the small complex\nroots (table 111) thus consists in a swinging oscillation\nof the airplane about the metacenter 5 as a pendulum\nsuspended from that point. The characteristic roots\nfor the pendulum motion would be\n\n:ontrol or indirectly by rolling the airplane as a whole.\n[f the latter effect were used to constrain the yawing,\nthe resulting motion would be excessively unstable.\nrhus, in order to prevent a sidewise disturbance from\nyawing the airplane (r=O), the pilot must execute a roll\n3uch that the forward wing is depressed (pNp=-vNo).\nThis roll provides the occasion for an increase of side3lip due to the bank and requires, in turn, more rapid\nrolling so that the motion diverges quickly. Secondary\naileron yawing moments of either sign moderate this\ninstability and the motion may become stable if the\nyawing moment is favorable.\nThese considerations indicate that the pilot could\nnot maintain an exact yawing constraint by the use of\nailerons alone. On the other hand, this inability is\nprobably not of great importance since the assumption\nof piloting procedure is obviously artificial and since\nthe former calculations (stability with constraint in\nrolling) indicated that, if the ailerons were used to\nhold the wings level, the free yawing oscillationswould\nbe short and quickly damped. (See table 11.) Thus\nit appears that, in order to prevent any yawing whatever\nduring a disturbance, the pilot weuld have to execute a\ndivergent bank whereas if he merely held the wings\nlevel the yawing motion might be unnoticeable. The\ndivergent bank consists in a rotation of the airplane\nabout the metacenter\n\n,-\n\n(1 8)\n\nwhich are seen to be approximate roots of equation which is now situated below the airplane. This\nlimiting ratio may be compared with the ratio of the\nsecondary aileron yawing moments to the rolling\nmoments. If the secondary moment is adverse and\nexceeds a certain proportion of the rolling moment,\nan equilibrium condition in which the ailerons do not\nproduce a bank of the airplane becomes possible. In\nthis condition a gradual deflection of the ailerons would\nmerely eause the airplane to assume a yawed attitude,\nturning slowly under the influence of the side pressure\nvY,. In both cases the sideslip will ordinarily be\npositive (toward the center of the turn) although the\nairplane does not, necessarily lose altitude on this\naccount.\nFigure 1 illustrates the combined sideslipping and\nyawing of a two-control airplane during a steady turn.\n\n127-72\n0273-\n\n81\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMIWEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nIn the case of rudder control the inward sideslip must\nbe such that vL,=-rL, to prevent rolling. This\ncombined sideslipping and yawing motion may be\nascribed to a rotation of the airplane about some point\naft of the center of gravity. I the distance of this\nf\npoint behind the center of gravity is denoted by Z L\n\nAt the lowest speeds (CL=l.O and 1.8) %M is less\nthan &, indicating that negative rudder and aileron\nsettings will be required during steady positive turns.\nFigure 2 shows results of calculations of the controlmoment coefficients for equilibrium in turning at\n\nr%Jo=-rL,\n\nfor the case of rudder-controlled turns. For rotation\nof the airplane about this point the rolling moment\nvanishes, hence the point is a metacenter for the rolling\nmoment. The X axis will be tangent to the flight\npath a t this point in rounding a turn, as shown in\nfigure 1.\nSimilar considerations apply in the case of operation\nwith a rolling-moment control with fixed rudder.\nHere the metacenter is for a vanishing yawing moment,\nthe amount of sideslip being that necessary for\nvN,=-rN,.\nThe distance of the metacenter aft of\nthe center of gravity is found from\nor\n\nAn interesting point arises in connection with the\nrelation of the two metacenters (5L and % N ) . For\npositive rotation of the airplane about a point nearer\nthe center of gravity than %N the residual yawing\nmoment will be negative; hence if the metacenter\nzL is nearer the center of gravity than &, steady\nturning with rudder operation will require a positive\nsetting of the rudder, i. e., in a direction to aid the turn.\nConversely, if control is by rolling moments, the steady\nmotion will be a rotation about %N and, if the residual\nrolling moment for rotation about this point is negative\n(ZL<%N),\nthe rolling control setting will be positive,\nalso in a sense aiding the turn. Obviously, the condition % N < Z L corresponds to instability since in this\ncase with either mode of two-control operation the\ncontrol setting during a steady turn would be one\nappropriate to recovery from the turn. This condition\nis analogous to the spiral instability discussed by LanChester. The following table gives the metacenters\n%L and zN for the average airplane a t various lift\ncoefficients:\n\nI\n\nI\n\nFIGUEE\n3.--4ngles ofsideslipduring steadyturns at varionsangles of bank with dijierent modes of two-eontrol operation.\n\nThe only possibiity of outward or negative sideslip\nduring the steady turn occurs when rolling and yawing\nmoments are applied in combination. In any event,\nspiral stability, if present, must be considered as a\nsmall effect (with conventional airplanes) ; and the\ncontrol setting during steady turns is, if positive,\nalmost certain to be small so that secondary moments\nwill have little effect. (See fig. 4, CL=0.35.)\n\nTWO-CONTROL OPERATION IN UNSTEADY TURNS\n\nThe consideration of the equilibrium state is sufficient for the study of conditions during slowly executed\nmaneuvers of sufficient duration for the natural free\noscillations of the airplane to die out. In the case of\nrapid maneuvers performed by more or less quick\nmovements of the control the equilibrium conditions\nconare of secondary importance and the primsideration is the oscillation and damping of the free\nmotion.\nAccording to the previously outlined treatment, the\nmotions of the two-control airplane set up during unsteady turns will be studied by considering a constraint\nimpressed on the motion in the particular coordinate\nin which the available control operates. Thus in one\ncase of rudder control a d e h i t e sequence of yawing\nmotions appropriate to the turn maneuver under consideration will be assumed. The free rolling motion\nthat the airplane takes up during the manewer wilf\nthen be studied and compared with the rolling motion\nthat would be considered appropriate for the execution of the maneuver.\nThe investigation of unsteady conditions during\nvarious maneuvers required that the equations of motion (equations (1) to (3)) be solved for different types\nand variations of the impressed disturbances. The first\nstep in the procedure consisted in obtahimg solutions\nof the equations for (\xe2\x80\x98unit disturbances\xe2\x80\x9d substituted\ninto each coordinate of freedom.\nThe unit disturbance is defined by\n1 ( t ) =O when t<O\n1 (t) =1 when t>O\n\n1\n\n(see reference 3 ) and is taken to represent a disturbing\nacceleration of unit magnitude applied instantly a t\n\nt=O.\nThe solutions of the equations of motion for this\ntype of disturbance were found by methods described\nin reference 4. The result thus obtained is analogous\n\nti .0/6\nY\n\nk\n9.012\n\n:\n\n.D\n\np\n\n.OOB\n\ni\n\n6\n\n\xe2\x80\x98$ .004\nb\n\n%\n\n+\n-.\n\nP,\n\n-\n\n4\n\n0\n\nf\n\n2\n\nEIWJEE 6.-Yawing\n\n3\n\n4\n\n5\n\n6\n\n7\n8\n?be,\nseconds\n\n3\n\nIO\n\nII\n\n12\n\nf3\n\nI4\n\nmotion due to unit sfde disturbanw; twocontrol airplane constrained in r o l l i (aileron opsration; x=O).\n\n83\n\nto the so-called "indicial admittance" of the electriccircuit theory and was combined with Carson\'s generalized expansion theorem (see reference 5) to obtain\nthe motion due to the varying forms of disturbance.\nIf q ( t ) is the motion calculated for a unit disturbance\n\nAs the curves show, the actual yawing is delayed for\nan instant but in each case oscillates about the mean\nvalue given by (35). Figure 8 is of interest in illustrating the\ntwo more or lcss distinct modes of motion in free rolling\nand sideslipping. It will be noted that the rolling\nstarts very rapidly (with an initial angular acceleration of one radian per second per second) but soon\ntakes up the slow swinging oscillation. As in the previous case of rolling motion, the steady state finally\napproached is a definite angle of bank.\nThe foregoing calculations are of interest in indicating how the different types of two-control airplanes\nmay be expected to respond to attempted maneuvers.\nThe first step in the calculation of an actual complete\nmaneuver is to arrive at a specification for that part o\nf\nthe motion which is assumed to be constrained. It\nwill be of interest to compare the motions executed by\nthe two-control airplane with the most perfect possible\ncoordination of the motions that might be obtained\nwith three-control operation. Obviously, it will be\nnecessary to specify a maneuver that is within the powei\nof the control to produce and it-\'urill be desirable tc\nconform the specification to a type of turn likely to bc\n\n;hows the control-moment coefficients necessary to\n:onstrain the rolling and yawing motions to the speciied maneuver with perfect three-control operation.\nUnder the conditions of two-control operation the turns\n\n-\n\nTime, seconds\n\nFIGURE\n9.-Angle of bank and rates of rolling and yawing specified for 30* bank twocontrol turn maneuvers.\n\nwill not be perfect owing to the sideslipping and it is\nto be expected that this sideslipping will in SOT\ndegree modify the control settings.\n\n85\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COWTTEE FOR BERONAUTICS\n\nIn the calculations illustrated in figure 11 the banking\nmotion was assumed to be forced to follow the ideal\nbank by means of a rolling control and the resultant\nfree yawing motions were computed.
