C,==tO.PlCc (~=M.16).\n\nThe curves shown were calculated by equation (2)\nand take account of the increments of control displacement necessary to accommodate the rolling moments\nintroduced by the yawing and sideslipping oscillations.\n\nA STUDY OF THE TWO-CONTROL OPERATION OF AN A I R P U N E\n\nThe effect of these increments of control displacement\nis to modify the stability of the yawing and sideslipping\nmotions, an adverse yawing moment reducing the\ndamping and lengthening the period. The results indicate especially the disadvantage of adverse yaw and\nshow that some improvement may be had from a\nfavorable yawing moment.\n\nintroduced is of the same form as pNp and may be\ncalculated as\nNp\'= (NP-.Lp)\n(37)\nThe condition for perfect coordination of banking\nand yawing motion during the turn requires that the\nacceleration in yawing be very nearly proportional to\nthe rate of roiling; namely,\n\n& _ u,x p\nat A\n\n(38)\n\nThe component of rolling control directed toward\nopposing the damping in rolliig is applied in this way\nci\n<\n@yl\n\n$8\n\nY6\n\n\'L.0\n\no i\n\n26\n\n?\n\n4.\n\nTNne, seconds\nFIQUEE\n14.-The effect of favorable seeondary yawing moment on yawing motion\nduring 3 \xc2\xb0 bank m e n v e r performed with rolhng control; C ~ 1 . 6 . 6.=0.21C1\n0\n(-.5.\n%01)\n\nI n order to study more closely the possible beneficial\neffects of a favorable aileron yawing moment, it is of\nsome interest to analyze further the control application\ninto several components. The component that results\nin modification of the stability through the action of the\nsecondary yawing moment may be considered to be\ndirectly favorable to improved coordination of the\n\n.\n\nTime, seconds\nFIOUBE -The effect of increased N. on sideslip duririg twocontrol 30\xc2\xb0 bank\n16\nmaneuver;aileronoperation (no secondary yawing moment); Ci,=l.O.\n\nand it is seen that this component of the secondary\nfavorable yawing moment is properly directed toward\nimproved coordination of the yawing motion. The\ncomponent of control application necessary to accelerate the rolling motion does not, however, lead to a\ndesirable secondary yawing acceleration since this\nacceleration is not proportioned to the rolling velocity.\n\nTime, seconds\nFIQUFZ\n15.-The eEect of i n c r m d N.on yawing motion during 30\xc2\xb0 bank maneuver;\nd a m n operation (no seoondary yawing moment); Cc=l.O.\n\nyawing motion because it shortens the natural oscillation period and increases the damping. With a given\nproportion of favorable yawing moment, increasing the\ndihedral angle should result in further improvement in\nthis respect since the apparent weathercock stability\n(N,-KL,) is increased in that way. Another wmponent of the applied rolling wntrol is directed to overcoming the damping of the rolling incident to the\nmaneuver. The secondary yawing disturbance thus\n\nThis component results in the primary disadvantage\nassociated with favorable-yaw ailerons. Quick or\nirregular movements of the control may lead to pronounced yawing oscillations if the secondary moment\nis very great.\nIt appears that a decisive method of improving the\naileron-operated two-control airplane would be to\n\n87\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nincrease the weathercock-stability factor N,. This\nmethod would serve directly to reduce the sideslipping\nto a minimum both in steady turning and in rapidly\nexecuted turn maneuvers. Figure 15 shows the effect\nof doubling N , on the yawing motion during the maneuver performed at C,=l.O. This modification of the\nairplane shortened the natural period of the oscillation\nand resulted in the yawing action taking place more\nquickly. The effect on sideslip is shown in figure 16.\n5\nAlthough the maneuver ends with about \' of outward\nsideslip, this value will be quickly reduced to zero on\naccount of the natural stability of the motion. With\ndifferent timing of the maneuver it may, of course, be\nbrought to an end with no residual sideslip. The\nfollowing table shows the effect of arbitrarily increasing\nN, on the natural period of the yawing oscillations:\nRatio of\nN . to that\nof average\nairplane\n\nPeriod\n\n~\n\n_\n1\n2\n4\n\nFurther improvement in the operation of the aileron:ontrolled machine could be had by decreasing the\nyawing derivative in rolling N,. Alteration of this\nlerivative apparently would require fundamental\nZhanges in wing design, improvement being in the direction of lower aspect ratio, which might, of course, conEict with other requirements.\nAs pointed out, the maneuvers assumed in these calculations are considered to be more rapid than usual in\n\n,\n\n_\n\nSecond8\n4 1G\n2.92\n2 05\n\nIt is to be noted that an increase in vertical-fin area\nwill increase the derivative N , as well as No and will\nthus result in greater damping of the motion.\n-\n\nTime, seconds\n\nFIGURE\n19.-Free angles of bank during turn maneuvers performed with Ndder\ncompared with ideal bank curve; yawing constraints for 3 \' bank maneuver.\n0\n\nP\n\nTime, seconds\n\nFIGURE\n18.-Yawing motion necessary to enforce assumed 3 bank maneuver with\n0\n\'\nNdder operation; C~=1.0.\n\nA certain disadvantage associated with increased N,\nis the relatively greater tendency for spiral instability\nand the consequent necessity for holding the control\nagainst the steady turn. It may be expected, however,\nthat this undesirable tendency could be overcome by\nproperly proportioning the dihedral of the wings. The\ngreatest possible effect of increase of vertical-fin area\nwould be to cause the metacenter for yawing moments\nGN (see discussion of stability) to approach coincidence\nwith the fin; it would then appear necessary to arrange\nthe metacenter for rolling moments ahead of this point\nin order to accommodate any desired increase of verticalEn area and secure spiral stability.\n\n88\n\nnormal flight, since they represent the use of a large\nproportion of the control power ordinarily available at\nthe lower speeds. With slower maneuvers the coordination of the motions of the two-control airplane would\nbe expected to be much better, especially when the\nduration of the maneuver becomes large relative to the\nnatural period of oscillation of the airplane. Figure 17\nshows the result of a calculation in which the duration\nof the 6.28-second maneuver was doubled.\nIt is worth noting that the actual deflection of the\nflight path of an airplane relative to the earth is accomplished much more directly by banking than by steering.\nRegardless of tbe sideslipping and coordination of angular motions, any decided acceleration of the path must\nbe brought about by inclination of the lift and is not\ndirectly affected to any great extent by rotating the\nairplane in yaw. Such deflection of the path would be\nthe principal objective in turning to avoid an obstacle.\nThus the airplane with rolling-moment control should\nbe capable of avoiding obstacles equally as quickly 8s a\nconventional three-control airplane. As is the case\nwith three-control operation, the tendency of a twocontrol airplane to accelerate downward when banked\nmust be counteracted by a movement of the elevator.\nI the airplane is assumed to execute a sharp turn to\nf\navoid an obstacle, the primary consideration will thus\nbe the ability to produce a specified bank. Under such\n\nA STUDY OF THE TWO-CONTROL OPERATION OF AN AIRPLANE\n\nconditions the pilot of the rudder-operated airplane\nwould be expected to make an effort at indirect control\nof the bank without regard to the coordination of the\nyawing motion. The question then arises as to what\nyawing motion would have to be prescribed in the case\nof the rudder-controlled machine to enforce the desired\nmotion in banking.\nFigure 18 shows the yawing motion that results in a\nbank curve similar to that given in figure 9. It appears\nthat, in order to attain the bank angle as shown, a\nrelatively powerful rudder control would have to be\napplied about one-half second in advance of the usual\nstart of the turn. Further calculations showed that the\nprescribed yawing motion could be attained throughout\nif a rather large amount of rudder control were avail-\n\notion is too slow and the damping is too slight to\ntable even an approximate coordination of the mom s Within the short time of duration of the maneuver.\nFigure 21 shows the angles of sideslip attained with\nte various modes of operation considered, summarizing\nte results of the calculations.\nThe reasons for the inability of the rudder-controlled\nrplane to execute rapid turns are: First, that the\nrcondary rolling reaction due to yawing motion is\nsufficient to overcome the relatively great damping\n\' direct rolling motion; second, that for a rapid turn\nle rate of rolling required on entry and recovery\n-eatly exceeds the maximum rate of yawing; and third,\niat the free rolling and sideslipping oscillations set up\n*enot very well damped. The greatest possibility for\n\nTime, seconds\nIGURE\n\nTime, seconds\n\nFIGURE\n20.--Free rolling motion during turn maneuvers performed with rudder;\nyawing constraints for 30\xc2\xb0 bank maneuver.\n\nable. That such an attempt to follow a definite course\nin banking would require a vigorous use of the rudder\nis evident from the oscillation of the yawing curve.\nIn the case of two-control operation with a constraint\nin yawing by means of the rudder, the yawing motions\nshown in figure 9 were assumed and the resulting\nfree rolling motions were calculated. Figures 19 and\n20 show the results of such calculations made a t different lift coefficients. The angles of bank and rates of\nrolling attained are compared with those that would\nbe appropriate to the constrained yawing motion.\nIt is apparent from these and the preceding figures\nthat the two-control airplane operated with the rudder\ncannot be expected to perform rapid maneuvers of the\ntype considered. The natural reaction of the rolling\n\n21.-Angles of sldeslip during two-control turn maneuvws with different\nmodes oi operatidn; 30" bank turn maneuver.\n\nnprovement would appear to be in increasing the\nwould call for\nerivatives L, and Y,.The fist (Lo)\nicreased dihedral angle and would serve to shorten\nhe natural period of the rolling and sideslippingmotion,\nrhile the second (Yv)would call for +creased area of\nhe side projection of the airplane and should improve\nhe damping of the oscillations. The following table\nhows the effects of changing these derivatives on the\natural period and damping of the oscillations at\n!,=l.O.\nRatio of derivative to that of average\nauplane\n\nI\n\nI\n\nL\n.\n\ny\n.\n\nI I \'g:; I I :\'; I\n\n12.4\nTime to damp )f, seconds____.._.__\nPer;od,seconds.-l__________________\n15.3\n\n7\n.\n;\n\n89\n\nREPORT NATIONAL ADVISOPY COMMI\'ITEE FOR AERONAUTIC3\n\nCONCLUSION\n\nduced, the coordination with rudder control improves\nsomewhat a t the lower speeds. This effect would be\nespecially apparent if the rudder were applied in such\na way as to enforce indirectly a desired banking motion. Such indirect control requires, however, that the\nrudder be deflected in advance of the desired effect.\nThe yawing that arises when the bank is indirectly\ncontrolled with the rudder is a very poor approximation to the ideal yawing and calls for large and irregular\ncontrol movements.\nThe amount of sideslipping during steady turns is\nnot greatly different with either mode of operation. In\neither case it appears desirable that the free motion of\nthe airplane show spiral stability so that control settings\nopposing the turn will not be required.\nIn general, it is concluded that a reliable rollingmoment control that does not give a secondary adverse\nyawing moment would afford the most satisfactory\nmeans for two-control operation. It appears that a\nmoderate amount of favorable secondary yaw would\nbe desirable although certain disadvantages appear if\nthe proportion is too great.\nThe disadvantage in two-control operation lies not\nso much in the imperfection of control of the flight path\nof the airplane relative to the earth as in the sideslipping\nand sidewise accelerations that arise through the imperfect coordination of the yawing and banking\nmotions. It appears possible that this tendency may\nbe so reduced by the use of suitable control organs\nand properly modified stability characteristics as to\nbe unobjectionable.\n\nThe lateral motion of a conventional airplane is more\nstable when constrained in rolling than when constrained i yawing. The stability of the free yawing\nn\nm d sideslipping motion is greater than that of the\nentirely free motion; the stability of the free rolling\nand sideslipping is less than that of the entirely free\nmotion.\nI a rolling-moment control is used to enforce an\nf\narbitrary constraint in banking, the free yawing that\nresults will be approximately coordinated to the bank\nif the airplane has the average degree of weathercock\nstability (N.). The yawing in this case is also approximately adjusted to the speed of flight so that\nwith a given bank maneuver a more rapid rate of\nyawing is attained a t low speed than a t high speed, as\nis desirable. The deviation of the yawing from the\nideal is greater, however, a t lower speeds and is also\ngreater in quick turns than in more slowly executed\nf\nones. I the rolling control were designed to give a\nmoderate favorable yawing moment, the coordination\nof the motions would be improved. Improvement may\nalso be effected by increasing the weathercock stability. If, however, the aileron control gives the usual\nproportion of secondary adverse yawing moment, the\ncoordination of the yawing with the banking will be\nrelatively very poor. The motions may then become\nunstable and uncontrollable in an extreme case a t high\nlift coefficient. These latter statements are particularly\napplicable to conventional-type ailerons which are\nconsidered as undesirable on this account for use at\nlow flight speed unless compensated by the rudder.\nA rudder control may be used to enforce a constraint LANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nLABORATORY,\ne\'ther directly on the yawing motion or indirectly on\nFOR\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE AERONAUTICS,\nthe rolling motion provided that the maneuver specified\nLANGLEY\nFIELD,\nVA.,August 18,1936.\nis not too rapid nor the disturbances encountered too\nREFERENCES\nsevere. Jones and Albert I. Nerken\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nDecember 1936\n\n91\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nNATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE F R AERONAUTICS\nO\n\nTECHNICAL NOTE NO. 586\n\nTHE REDUCTION O AILERON OPERATING FORCE\nF\nBY DIFFERENTIAL LINKAGE\n\nB Robert T. Jones and Albert I. Nerken\ny\n\nSUMMARY\n\nIt is shown t h a t t h e c o n t r o l f o r c e of o r d i n a r y ailerons may be reduced t o zero over a range of d e f l e c t i o n s and\na t a given f l i g h t c o n d i t i o n by t h e use of an a p p r o p r i a t e\nd i f f e r e n t i a l movement. Approximations t o t h e i d e a l motion\no b t a i n a b l e w i t h a simple l i n k a g e are discussed and a c h a r t\nt h a t enables t h e s e l e c t i o n of an a p p r o p r i a t e crank arrangement i s presented. Various a s p e c t s of t h e p r a c t i c a l applic a t i o n of t h e system are discussed and i t i s concluded\nt h a t a s m a l l f i x e d t a b , d e f l e c t e d t o t r i m both a i l e r o n s\nupward, would be advantageous.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nOne of t h e most e x a c t i n g requirements of a lateralc o n t r o l system i s t h e p r o v i s i o n of an adequate degree of\nc o n t r o l with a s m a l l expenditure of o p e r a t i n g e f f o r t . It\nappears t h a t a d i f f e r e n t i a l l i n k a g e can, when properly designed, be a v e r y e f f e c t i v e means of reducing t h e operati n g f o r c e of o r d i n a r y a i l e r o n s . Several o t h e r advantages\naccrue t o t h e d i f f e r e n t i a l and such systems are widely\nused. The p o s s i b l e r e d u c t i o n of c o n t r o l f o r c e appears t o\nbe of primary importance, however, and i t i s t h e r e f o r e of\ni n t e r e s t t o d i s c u s s some r u l e s f o r t h e design of a l i n k a g e\nt h a t w i l l a f f o r d t h e g r e a t e s t advantage i n t h i s r e s p e c t .\nThe r e d u c t i o n of o p e r a t i n g f o r c e w i t h a d i f f e r e n t i a l\nl i n k a g e i s accomplished by t a k i n g advantage of t h e upf l o a t i n g tendency of t h e a i l e r o n s . This f l o a t i n g tendency\ni s apparent i n measurements of a i l e r o n hinge moments,\na t t h e neuwhich g e n e r a l l y show an o f f s e t moment (Ch,)\nt r a l s e t t i n g . ( S e e f i g . 1 . ) This moment varies w i t h ang l e of a t t a c k and w i t h a i r f o i l p r o f i l e .\n\n93\n\nN.A.C.A.\n\nTechnical Note No. 586\n\nWith a d i f f e r e n t i a l l i n k a g e t h e a i l e r o n s on o p p o s i t e\nt i p s of t h e wing begin t o move a t d i f f e r e n t rates immedia t e l y a f t e r t h e y are d e f l e c t e d from n e u t r a l , t h e downgoing\na i l e r o n moving more slowly t h a n t h e upgoing one. Thus\nw i t h t h e a i l e r o n s d e f l e c t e d t h e upward p r e s s u r e on t h e upgoing a i l e r o n , which t e n d s t o i n c r e a s e t h e d e f l e c t i o n , h a s\na g r e a t e r mechanical advantage at t h e c o n t r o l s t i c k than\ndoes t h e upward p r e s s u r e of t h e downgoing a i l e r o n . The\ncombination of a reduced upward p r e s s u r e and an increased\nmechanical advantage of t h e upgoing a i l e r o n tends t o n u l l i f y t h e e f f e c t of t h e i n c r e a s e d upward p r e s s u r e and reduced\nmechanical advantage of t h e downgoing a i l e r o n t o t h e ext e n t t h a t w i t h i n c e r t a i n limits t h e o p e r a t i n g f o r c e may b e\nreduced o r even reversed.\nI f t h e a i l e r o n s are connected t o t h e c o n t r o l s t i c k\nw i t h n o n d i f f e r e n t i a l gearing, t h e e f f e c t of t h e i n i t 4 a l\nhinge moment a t t h e n e u t r a l s e t t i n g i s not f e l t i n t h e\ns t i c k f o r c e r e q u i r e d \xe2\x80\x98to d e f l e c t them. A l a r g e\nu p f l o a t i n g a n g l e ( i n d i c a t e d by l a r g e ChP) and a r a p i d l y\ni n c r e a s i n g d i f f e r e n c e between t h e mechanical advantages of\nt h e two a i l e r o n s make f o r t h e d i s p l a c i n g tendency, whereas\na l a r g e s l o p e of t h e hinge-moment curve and a l a r g e average mechanical advantage of both a i l e r o n s ( l a r g e d6/d9)\nmake f o r a l a r g e r e s t o r i n g force. I f t h e c o n t r o l s t i c k i s\nt o tend t o r e t u r n t o n e u t r a l when d i s p l a c e d , chs must b e\na t least s l i g h t l y negative.\n\nAn examination of t h e hinge-moment curve ( f i g . 1)\nw i l l show that t h e balancing e f f e c t of t h e d i f f e r e n t i a l\ncan b e simply described i n terms of t h e work of d e f l e c t i n g\nt h e a i l e r o n s . Work is gained by allowing t h e a i l e r o n t o\nrise. The r e s u l t a n t work i s found by deducting t h a t exe r t e d on t h e down s i d e from t h a t gained on t h e up s i d e .\nThe two components are represented by t h e areas under t h e\nhinge-moment curve on e i t h e r s i d e of n e u t r a l . Once t h e l i m i t i n g curve showing t h e def l e c t i o n s t h a t r e s u l t i n zero operating f o r c e i s determined, i t becomes necessary t o d e v i s e a geometrical arrangement of levers t h a t w i l l approximate t h i s motion.\nAlthough i t i s not thought d e s i r a b l e completely t o\ne l i m i n a t e t h e c o n t r o l f o r c e at any f l i g h t c o n d i t i o n , i t\ni s u s e f u l t o consider t h i s c o n d i t i o n as a l i m i t i n g adjustment of t h e d i f f e r e n t i a l . The spacing of the crank centers\nand the relative radii of the two cranks may therefore be\nleft to be dictated by other considerations.\nFigure 5 shows a type of stick-force curve that satisfies two very simple criterions. This modificat i o n served t o i n c r e a s e t h e maximum f l o a t i n g a n g l e of t h e\na i l e r o n s from 12" t o ZO", thereby p e r m i t t i n g t h e use of a\nd i f f e r e n t i a l w i t h a g r e a t e r maximum downward d e f l e c t i o n .\nIt w i l l be noted, i n a d d i t i o n , t h a t t h e s t i c k f o r c e req u i r e d f o r c o n t r o l a t high speed (% = 0.35) i s much\n\nless, and i s a l s o more n e a r l y coincident w i t h t h e f o r c e\nr e q u i r e d a t low speed (CL = l . O ) , than w a s t h e case w i t h\nt h e unmodified a i l e r o n s . The b e n e f i c i a l e f f e c t of a f i x e d\nt a b would b e expected t o be even more apparent i n t h e case\nof narrow-chord a i l e r o n s .\nInasmuch as t h e f l o a t i n g a n g l e s corresponding t o 15"\na n g l e of a t t a c k ( f i g . 8) w e r e used i n t h e s e l e c t i o n of t h e\nd i f f e r e n t i a l s , t h e c o n t r o l w i l l begin t o show overbalance\na t t h i s a n g l e of a t t a c k . LATERAL CONTROL RESEARCH\nFred E. Weick and Robert T. 3ones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1937\n\n117\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 605\nRESUME AND ANALYSIS OF N. A. 6. A. LATERAL CONTROL RESEARCH\nBy FREDE. WEICKand ROBERT . JONES\nT\nSUMMARY\n\ndevices that seemed most promising were tested hi\nflight (references 2 aud 3). In many cases, however,\ndevices that produced what seemed to be satisfactory\nrolling moments and favorable yawing moments did\nnot give satisfactory control.\nAn analytical study of control effectiveness was\ntherefore made (reference 4) taking into account a\nnumber of secondary factors, including the yawing\nmoments produced by the controls, the effect of the\ncontrols on the damping in rolling, the lateral-stability\nderivatives of the airplane, the moments of inertia, and\nthe time required for the control moments to become\nestablished after the deflection of the surfaces. The\ncomputations consisted of step-by-step solutions of the\nequations of rolling and yawing motion for the conditions following a deflection of the controls. The results\nof these computations based on aerodynamic data obtained from wind-tunnel tests of wings incorporating\nvarious devices agreed satisfactorily with the results\nmeasured in flight for widely different forms of control,\nsuch as ailerons and spoilers.\nThe study of conditions above the stall indicated\nthat satisfactory control could not be expected without\nsome provision to maintain the damping in rolling and\nthat a dangerous type of instability would arise if the\ndamping were insufficient. Since damping in rolling\ndepends on an increase in the lift of the airfoil with\nincreasing angle of attack, it follows that, in order to\nobtain satisfactory lateral control, the outer or tip portions of the wing, which govern the rolling moments,\nmust remain unstalled. If damping in rolling is retained, it is practically insured that control moments\nwill be retained as well.\nThe progress of the investigation has thus led to a\nmore accurate interpretation of the results of the windtunnel tests. In the present paper the experience\ngained during the c o m e of the investigation is made\nINTRODUCTION\nthe basis of a revised method of comparison of lateral\nIn 1931 the Committee started a systematic wind- control devices. Wind-tunnel measurements of control\ntunnel investigation of lateral control with special and stability factors (reference 1) are utilized in conireference to the improvement of control at low air putations to show the banking and yawing motions\nspeeds and a t high angles of attack. Many different that would be produced by the controls acting on a\nailerons and other lateral control devices have been small typical airplane. These computations follow the\n.\nsubjected to the same systematic investigation in the method of analysis given in reference 4 In section I of\n7- by 10-foot wind tunnel. (See reference 1.) The the report the new basis of comparison is explained and\n\nAn analysis of the principal results of recent N. A . C. A.\nlateral control research is made by utilizing the experience\nand progress gained during the course of the investigation.\nTwo things are considered of primary importance in\njudging the effectiveness o f diferent control devices: The\n(calcuhted) banking and yawing motion of a typical small\nairplane caused by a deJlection of the control, and the stick\nforce required to produce this dejlection. The report includes a table in which a number of different lateral control\ndevices are compared on these bases.\nExperience gained while testing various devices in\nJlight with a Fairchild 22 airplane indicated that, following a sudden deJlection of the control at low speed, an\nangle o f bank of 15" in 1 second represented a satisjactory\nminimum degree of effectiveness for this size of airplane.\nSome devices capable o f giving this degree of control were,\nhowever, considered to be not entirely satisfactory on account o f sluggishness in starting the motion. Devices\nlocated near the trailing edge of the wings had no detectable\nsluggishness. Lateral control forces considered, desirable\nby the test pilots varied f r o m 2 to 8 pounds; 16 pounds was\nconsidered excessive.\nTest Jlights demonstrated that satisfactory lateral control\nat high angles of attack depends as much on the retention o j\nstability as on aileron effectiveness.\nThe aerodynamic characteristics of plain sealed ailerons\ncould be accurately predicted by a modifiation of the\naerodynamic theory utilizing the results of experiments\nwith sealed jlaps. straight narrow-chord sealed ailerons\ncovering 60 to 80 percent o f the semispan represented about\nthe most escient arrangement of plain unbalanced ailerons\nfrom cons&rations of operating force. The stick force of\nplain ailerons can be effectively reduced by the use of a\ndijerential linkage in conjunction with a small $xed tab\narranged to press the ailerons upward.\n\n119\n\nREPORT MO. 605-NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\na number of the devices that were tested in reference 1\nare analyzed and compared. The principal items of\ncomparison are collected into a table. Section I1\npresents an analysis of the rolling, yawing, and hinge\nmoments of plain flap-type ailerons and deals with the\napplication of these data in the design of control\nsystems.\n\nI. COMPARISON OF LATERAL CONTROL\nDEVICES\nREVISED BASIS OF COMPARISON\nAIRPLANE USED I N COMPAEIISON\n\nThe procedure adopted in the lateral control investigation has comprised a wind-tunnel test program followed by fhght tests of the different devices on the\nFairchild 22 airplane. Not all of the devices tested\nin reference 1 have been tried in flight, however, and\nthe present report may be considered an analytical\nextension of the flight-test procedure that was applied\nto some of the devices. The procedure employed to\ntest lateral controls in flight is simulated by means of\ncomputation. Thus, the comparative criterions used\nherein are based on application of the devices to a hypothetical Fairchild 22 type of airplane, which is the type\nused in the fhght tests.\nThe Fairchild 22 airplane was necessarily somewhat\nmodifled for each different flight test and wings of different moment of inertia, plan form, and section were\nused in some cases. The wing of the hypothetical airplane assumed in the computations represents an average of the tested wings. Furthermore, since the characteristic ratios of dimensions (tail length, tail area,\nradii of gyration about various axes, etc.) used agree\nvery closely with statistical averages of these quantities, the assumed airplane may be considered to embody\naverage stability characteristics. The principal characteristics of the assumed airplane are as follows:\n\ndesirable value to attain. Where a compromise must\nbe made between the rolling moment and some other\ncharacteristic of the control system, particularly the\ncontrol force, a decidedly lower valueof the rolling\ncriterion may be used. It appears that a value posdbly as low as half the original one may be found\nreasonably satisfactory for practically all conditions of\nsight with nonacrobatic airplanes.\nThe criterion of rolling control used in the present\nanalysis is the angle of bank attained in 1 second following a sudden deflection of the control. This criterion\nshows the actual amount of motion produced and\ndepends on both the acceleration at the start and the\nfinal rate of roll. It includes the effect of yawing\nmoment given by the control as well as the stability\ncharacteristics and moments of inertia of the airplane.\nThe values of the criterion are found by computation\nand as such are applicable only to the particular type\nof airplane (F-22) that has been assumed.\nExperience gained in flight tests of the Fairchild 22\nairplane with various lateral control devices indicated\na minimum satisfactory amount pf rolling control corresponding to about 15\' of bank in 1 second. (See\nfig. 1.) Ailerons capable of giving this amount of bank\n\nWeight, W____._._..._... lb.\n. .._.______\n.\n1,600\nWing span, b_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _32 ft. _ _ _ _ . _ . . . _ _ _ _ _ _\n__\nWing area, S_ _ . _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ . _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _\n171 sq. ft.\nWing loading, W/S_.__- - - - - - -. 9.4 Ib. per sq. ft.\n--- - - - Area of fin and rudder_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ 10.8 sq. ft.\nTail length___.__.___..._.____________\n14.6 ft.\n.\nI=\n- - - - - - - _ _ - -.-.- -. _ _ - - - - 1,216 slug-ft.\'\nIz_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _8lug-ft.a\n1,700\n\n_____\n\nROLLING ACTION\n\nIt is recognized that different types of airplanes require different amounts of control. At the start of\nthe wind-tunnel investigation of lateral control devices\nrepresent(reference 1) a rolling criterion (RC= C,/CL)\ning a conservative lower liiit of rolling control for all\ntypes was assumed. The assumed satisfactory value\nof the rolling criterion was 0.075, which corresponds to\na lateral movement of the center of pressure of 7.5\npercent of the wing span. Recent experience indicates\nthat this value is likely to be ample for any condition\nof fllght that might be encountered and is therefore a\n\n120\n\nFIGURE\nl.-Banking of Fairchild 22 airplane after sudden deflection of lateral oontrol devices at low speed. (The narrow plain ailerons and the retractable ailerons\nwere considered to give a satisfactory amount of control; the floating-tipailerons\nwere reported as weak.)\n\nat low speed have been found reasonably satisfactory\nin practice with this type of airplane. Owing to the\npresent general use of high-lift flaps on airplane wings,\nthe size and deflection of ailerons are usually determined by the low-speed condition of flight witb the\nflaps deflected. For comparative computations, in the\npresent report, a lift coefficient of CL=1.8 is assumed as\nrepresentative of the low-speed condition of flight with\n\nRaSUMa AND ANALYSIS OF N. A.\n\nflaps. The sizes or deflections of the lateral controls\nare selected in each case to give an angle of bank of 15\xe2\x80\x99\nin 1 second a t CL=1.8.\nIn addition to providing a suflicient amount of banking motion, two further desirable characteristics of the\nrolling action are: (1) The response of the airplane in\nroll to any movement of the lateral control surface\nshould be immediate, any noticeable delay or hesitac\ntion in the action being objectionable; and (2) the\naction should be so graduated that the acceleration and\nmaximum rate of roll increase smoothly and regularly\nas the stick deflection is increased. Conventional\nailerons or similar lateral control devices located near\nthe trailing edge of the Wing easily meet these requirements and show, in analyses of motions recorded in\nflight, practically instantaneous response of rolling\nacceleration to control-surface movement. From 0.1\nto 0.2 second is ordinarily required to deflect the\nsurfaces and, during this interval, the rolling acceleration apparently keeps pace, although only a slight\namount of rolling motion is accumulated by the time\nof full deflection. Comparison shows that good\nsynchronization of the calculated motion with the flight\nrecords was obtained when the assumed full deflection\nwas taken a t the instant the actual deflection reached\nhalf its ultimate value. This assumption was used\nin the computations for plain ailerons and other\ndevices t,hat gave no indication of sluggish rssponse\ncharacteristics.\nCONTROL FORCE\n\nDuring the course of the lateral control investigation\nit became apparent that the force required to move tht\ncontrols is of extreme importance in obtaining satisfactory lateral control. As shown by the flight tests oj\nreferences 2 and 3, an airplane that requires a lighl\ncontrol force is likely to seem more controllable to a\npilot than one that requires a heavy control force, ever\nthough with full deflection the heavier control may bt\n1\nconsiderably more powerful than the lighter one. 1\nseems desirable to have the control force as light as pos\nsible and yet to maintain the feeling of a definite new\ntral position. This characteristic is especially impor.\ntant in the aileron control since the effort expended ir\nmoving the stick sidewise is relatively greater than foi\nother control movements. (See reference 5.) Correla.\ntion of test-flight reports and control-force records indi.\ncates that the forces required to operate the aileron2\nshould not exceed about 8 pounds in order to be con.\nsidered desirable. A lower limit of stick force of aboui\n2 pounds a t full deflection is apparently considerec\nessential so that there may be a noticeably regulatec\nincrease of force with deflection. Friction of the con\ntrol mechanism plays an increasingly important pari\nas the operating force is reduced and should in no cast\nbe great enough to mask the \xe2\x80\x9cfeel\xe2\x80\x9d of the control. I\nis probabIe that with sufficiently little friction a forcc\nnot greatly in excess of 2 pounds would be considerec\n\n4. LATERAL CONTROL RESEARCH\n\nnost desirable. A force of 15 pounds i to be consids\nred excessive.\nAs previously stated, the size or maximum deflection\nI f the control devices compared in this paper have\nn\nIeen selected to give an angle of bank of 15\xe2\x80\x99 i 1 secmd following full deflection and, considering the avertge airplane fitted with a high-lift flap and flying at a\nift coefficient of 1.8, the ailerons are compared (see\n#able I) on the basis of the stick force required to\ntttain this angle of bank of 15\xe2\x80\x99 in 1 second at lift\n:oefficients of 0.35, 1.0, and 1.8, which compose the\nisual flight range. The lift coefficient of 0.35 repreients the conditions of high-speed and cruising flight.\nFhe lift coefficient of 1.0 is considered to represent two\n:onditions, the first being that of low-speed Gght with)ut a flap, such as is used in an approach to a landing\nKith an unflapped airplane, and the second being one\nKith a flap fully deflected, which represents as high a\n;peed as is usually attained in that condition. The\nralue C,=1.8 can be obtained only with the flap delected and represents the low-speed flight condition\nKith the high-lift device in use. Whqn representative\nd u e s of this nature are used, it is necessary to examne the complete original data to show that the critical\nd u e s are representative of conditions throughout the\nlight range. Such an examination has been made for\n;he comparisons of the present report.\nThe stick force for a 15\xe2\x80\x99 bank in 1 second is used as\nthe basis of comparison at all flight speeds and lift co3fficients even though the conventional ailerons will\nproduce a decidedly greater bank in 1 second at higher\n3peeds. The 15\xe2\x80\x99 value is taken throughout because it\ni considered to represent the maximum control likely\ns\nto be used in ordinary flight at any speed and is there[ore of greater interest as a basis for stick forces repired than the maximum possible deflection, as long\nBS the force at maximum deflection does not approach\nthe strength of the pilot\xe2\x80\x98\nThe data for some of the ailerons were obtained with\nplain unflapped wings with which a lift coefficient of 1.8\ncould not be attained and, in order to have all the\nlateral control devices on a comparable basis whether\nmounted on flapped or unflapped wings, their sizes and\nmaximum deflections were selected to give essentially\nthe same rolling effect as the others at a lift coefficient\nof 1.0. The analysis showed that conventional ailerons\nwhich give an angle of bank of 15\xe2\x80\x99 in 1 second on a\nflapped wing a t a lift coefficient of 1.8 could, when\nfully deflected, give an angle of bank of 22.5\xe2\x80\x99 with the\nflap retracted a t a lift coefficient of 1.0. The ailerons\non the unflapped wings were therefore selected to be\ncapable of giving 22.5\xe2\x80\x99 bank in 1 second at a lift coefficient of 1.0, but the values of the stick forces required\nwere computed for partial deflections giving a 15\xe2\x80\x99 bank\nin 1 second a t lift coefficients of both 1.0 and 0.35. The\n&st aileron of table I is of the conventional unbalanced\nflap type on a rectangular wing of aspect ratio 6. It\nhas a chord 0.25 e, and a span 0.40 b12 and has equal\n\n121\n\nREPORT NO. 605-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nup-and-down linkage. It w i l l be noted that, for an airplane equipped with these ailerons, the stick force computed for a 15O bank in 1 second at the cruising-flight\ncondition is 4.7 pounds with aileron deflections of only\nf3.4O. At a lift coefficient of 1.0, representing the lowspeed flight condition for the unflapped wing, the same\namount of control was obtained with a stick force of\n3.6 pounds and aileron deflections of f7.4O. Al the\nl\nstick forces are given for an assumed aileron linkage\nsuch that at the maximum deflection the control stick,\nwhich has a length of 20 inches on the Fairchild 22\nairplane and is so assumed for the average airplane, is\ndeflected 2 O from neutral. The maximum aileron\n5\ndeflection is 11.2O and is the deflection required to\nproduce a bank of 22.5\xe2\x80\x99 in 1 second at CL=l.O. Here\nthe ailerons are not being taxed to their fullest extent.\nThe maximum amount of control specified in a design\nhas a predominating effect on the operating force.\nFigure 2 shows a calculated example of the variation of\n\nin which the increase of control is obtained, as will be\nmore fully developed in a later section.\nYAWING MOTION AND SIDESLIP\n\nThe effect of the yawing moment produced by the\nailerons is considered in two ways. First, the secondary\neffect of yaw on the rolling motions is inherently included in the computed banking effectiveness. Thus,\nthe bank in 1 second is that produced by the ailerons\nf\nwithout aid from the rudder. I it is assumed that a\nsufficiently powerful rudder were used in such a way\nas to prevent sideslip, a given aileron device would,\nin general, produce a somewhat greater banking effect.\nThis assumption is not used here, however, and the\ndeflections of the control surfaces given in table I are\nthose required to produce the specified angle of bank in\n1 second with the particular combination of rolling and\nyawing moments produced by the aileron in question.\nThe second effect considered is the sideslip produced\nby the sudden use of the aileron control for banbing.\nIn flight the rudder is used to avoid sideslipping and\nthe amount of rudder action necespary for this purpose\nis in direct proportion to the sideslip incurred by the\nailerons alone.\nThe angle of sideslip accompanying a 15O bank in 1\nsecond following the sudden displacement of the lateral\ncontrols is also given in table I. The first aileron\nlisted, it w i l l be noted, produces a sideslip of 7 O at CL=\n1.0 and of 3 O at CL=0.35 when the rudder is not used\nto correct for this condition.\nLATERAL STABILITY\n\nMffximum anqfe of bonk h I sec, AMs,\ndeg.\nbetween stick force and maximum amount of control obtained.\nFairchild 22 type sirplane; 0.80 sealed ailerons deflected f20\xe2\x80\x9d;aileron chord\nvaried.\n\nFIGURE\n2.-Relation\n\noperating force with specified control in which it was\nassumed that ailerons with equal up-and-down motion\nand the most efficient length and deflection ( & Z O O )\nwere used in each case. The rate of increase of operating\nforce with amount of control depends on the manner\n\n122\n\nIn the ordinary unstalled-flight range the effects of\nthe lateral-stability factors on the lateral control obtained are included in the computations of the angle of\nbank reached in unit time. The angle of bank 4, is the\nangle that would be produced by the control operating\non the average airplane. The effect of a given control\non an airplane of greatly different lateral-stability\ncharacteristics might, of course, be considerably different\nthan indicated in this case.\nOne of the most important factors in the interaction\nof lateral stability and control below the stall is the\neffect of the secondary yawing moment induced by the\ncontrol and an allowance for this effect should be made in\nthe proportioning of the airplane for lateral stability.\nModifications that tend to increase spiral stability in\nfree flight (namely, reduced vertical-fin area and increased dihedral) tend to render the airplane uncontrollable under the action of ailerons giving adverse\nyawing moment. The degree of \xe2\x80\x9cweathercock\xe2\x80\x9d stability\nshould be sufIicient to restore the airplane from a yawed\nattitude when the wings are held level by use of the\nailerons. For safety in this respect the ratio of adverse\nyawing to rolling moment given by the ailerons should\nnot be allowwl to approach the ratio of yawing to rolling moments that naturally act on the airplane either\n\nRfiSUME AND ANALYSIS OF N. A. C. A, LATERAL CONTROL RESEARCH\n\nin pure sideslipping or pure yawing motion. (See\nreference 6.)\nOne of the lateral-stability factors, the damping in\nrolling, has been shown by the analysis in reference 4 to\nhave a critical effect on the controllability obtained,\nsatisfactorylateral control requiring that positive damping exist. Since the damping in rolling depends on a\npositive slope of the left curve, the damping exists only\na t angles of attack of the outer portions of the wing that\nare below the maximum lift coefficient. While some\nsemblance to control may be obtained a t angles of\nattack above the stall if controls giving favorable yawing moments as well as sufsciently powerful rolling\nmoments are used, the instability associated with\nuneven stalling and autorotation is so violent that it is\nnecessary for the pilot to use the controls continually to\nf\nkeep the airplane near the desired attitude. I s a ciently rapid rolling is once started, either by the controls\nthemselves or as the result of gusty air, it cannot be\nstopped. The angle of attack at which the damping in\nrolling becomes zero and above which autorotation takes\nplace CY^,=^) is used herein as an indication of the\nlimit of the flight attitude above which satisfactory\nlateral control cannot be obtained. This value was\ngiven in the reports of reference 1 for both the angle of\nattack at which autorotation was selfstarting and the\nangle of attack at which the damping became zero when\nthe wing was rotating at the rate pb/2V=0.05, a value\nrepresentativeof the rolling likely to be caused by gusty\nair. The latter value of CY has ordinarilybeen found to be\nabout lo lower than the former value and, being therefore more decisive, is used in the present report. The\ndifference between the angle of attack for zero damping\nand the angle of attack for the maximum lift coefficient\nof the entire wing (CYL,=O-LYC,,,~.) has been tabulated\nunder Lateral Stability to show whether the maximum\nlift coefficient can be expected to be reached in flight\nbefore satisfactory lateral control is lost. It will be\nnoted that for ailerons 3 and 4 the wing loses its damping in roll at an angle of attack lo higher than that at\nwhich the maximum lift coefficient is reached. Thus, as\nfar as the stabilitJT is concerned, lateral control should\nbe possible throughout the entire unstalled-flight range,\nincluding the angle of attack for maximum lift coefficient.\nWING PERFORMANCE CHARACTERISTICS\n\nThe same criterions used throughout the reports of\nreference 1 to show the relative performance characteristics of the wings are used in the present report and\nare tabulated in the last three columns of table I.\nThe maximum lift coefficient CL,., is given as an\nindication of the wing area required for a desired minimum speed. The ratio CL,JCb,,mis an indication of\nthe speed range and, for a given minimum speed, shows\nthe relative effects of the wings on the maximum speed\nattainable. The ratio LID taken at a value of the lift\ncoefficient CL=0.70 is an indication of relative merit i\nn\n\nclimbingflight. In a series of performancecomputations\nmade for airplanes of different wing loadings and power\nloadings and with both plain and slotted wings, this\ncriterion was found to be satisfactory throughout the\nentire range. It should be noted that the comparative\nvalues used in the present report are baaed on tests made\nin the 7- by 10-foot atmospheric wind tunnel and hence\ndo not coincide in absolute value with results of testa\nmade at Merent Reynolds Numbers.\nAPPLICATION TO AIRPLANES OF DIFFERENT SIZES AND LOADINGS\n\nBecause the ilight experience that led to the specscation of a satisfactory degree of control was restricted\nto the Fairchild 22 type of airplane, there is some doubt\nabout the application of this experience to other types\nand especially to large or very small airplanes. The\nFairchild 22 type of airplane, of course, serves as well\nas any other when different aileron devices are simply\ncompared among themselves. The principles governing the extension of the computations of motion to\ngeometrically similar airplanes of dserent sizes and\nloadings are well known and can be applied here, but\nthis extension of the computations does not definitely\nanswer the question as to what constitutes a satisfactory\ndegree of control for large (or very small) airplanes.\nAccording to the principles of dynamical similarity,\nlarge or small similar airplanes of the same wing loading\nwould show the same linear rise and fall of the wing\ntips(%)\n\nduring a 1-second banking motion. Large\nand small airplanes do actually show a tendency toward\nsimilarity in important dimensions and size of control\nsurfaces, and it seems logical to assume that a given\nvalue of the vertical distance described by the wing\ntips within 1 second following a sudden control deflection that represents a satisfactory amount of control\nfor the Fairchild 22 airplane should be satisfactory for\nany size of airplane.\nFor similar airplanes the linear distance described\n\n(q)\n\nby the wing tips in banking\nis independent of\nthe size. Figure 3 shows this distance plotted against\nwing loading and gives the separate effects of rolling\nand yawing moments of coefficient 0.01 at different\nlift coefficients. The banking effect of any combination\nof rolling and yawing moment may be found by\nsuperposition, i. e.,\n\nThe ordinates of the figure give directly the circumferential displacement of the wing tip in feet for a\nunit of 0.01 rolling- or yawing-moment coefficient.\nIt is important to note that the banking effects of\nrolling and yawing moments can be separately considered and later added in any desired proportion to\nobtain the totaI combined effect.\n\n123\n\nREPORT NO. 605-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nThe computations show that, in general, smaller\nvalues of the control-moment coefficients are required\nto produce a given wing-tip displacement in a unit of\ntime for the more heavily loaded airplanes. Another\npoint of interest in connection with the secondary\nadverse yawing moments produced by conventional-\n\nis assumed for each point. Figure 4 shows that the\nstick force required to obtain a given angle of bank in 1\nsecond is practically the same for all wing loadings up\nto 10 pounds per square foot but that it increases\nsomewhat as the wing loading increases further.\nWith moderately large airplanes, somewhat higher\nstick forces are apparently tolerated by pilots without\nserious objection. With extremely large airplanes,\nhowever, the operating force becomes too great to be\nsatisfactorily overcome by the pilot and either servo\ncontrols or auxiliary power is required. With auxiliary power, the pilot might presumably operate a valve\nor easily deflected controller governing a special power\n\nt!\n\n9\n\n$f\nx\nw\n\n.?\nx\'\n2\n\nz\n\n0\n\n/O\n\n20\n\n30\n\nW i n g /oadinq, /b.per sq. ff.\nFIQURE\n4.--Relstion hetween the wing loading and the stick force required for a\ngiven amount of control ( + 1 ~ , , = 2 2 5 ~ ;C~=1.0).\n\nsource that deflected the control surfaces.
