The computations were made\nfor three aspect ratios, 6, 10, and 16, and for three taper\nratios, 1.00, 0.50, and 0.25. The wing p h n forms used\nonly approximate those of linearly tapered wings with\nrounded tips.\nLIFT DISTRIBUTIONS\n\nRolling, yawing, and sideslipping motions introdme\nvarying resolutions of the relative-wind velocity over\nthe wing. It is evident that these variations can, to a\ncertain extent, be replaced by a fictitious warp or twist\nof the wing in straight fliht. The procedure followed\nhere is to calculate the spanwise lift and drag distributions for the fictitious twist (i. e., that replacing the\neffect of motion) in the ordinary way, but to incline the\n\nTHEORETICAL STABILITY AND CONTROL CHARACTERISTICS OF WINGS\n\n151\n\nREPORT NO. 635-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nlift and drag components so as to maintain them along\nthe perpendicular and the parallel to the actual local\nrelative-wind velocity. A further refinement of the\ntheory would involve the influence of the curvature of\nthe wing wake. Since the helix angles bvdlved in the\nmotions are small (pb/2V<0.1 and p.b/2V<O.1) and\nsince that region of the wake nearest the wing is of\npredominant infiuence, this correction may be neglected.\nInasmuch as the various stability derivatives thus\ndepend upon a summation of appropriate components\nof the lift and the drag loading along the span, it was\nnecessary to determine these distributions for each of\ntho wings with several different angle-of-attack distributions. For this purpose the Lot2 method of calculation (references 1 and 2) was used. In order to keep\nthe computations from becoming too lengthy, the chorddistribution function that occurs in this method was\nexpressed by, at most, three terms of a cosine series (as\nin table I). Although this expression caused the chord\ndistributions of the actual wings (fig. 1)to differ slightly\nfrom those for linearly tapered wings with rounded sips,\nsuch a procedure was justified because these slight departures in plan form had only a small effect on the\ncharacteristics but permitted a large saving in the computations required. Thus only the terms near the\ndiagonal running through equations (19) of reference 2\nentered into the computations. As the various derivatives for the elliptical wing could be obtained relatively\neasily, they were sometimes computed in order to determine the shape of the various derivative curves; it was\ntherefore possible to use fewer points in fairing similar\ncurves for the tapered wings.\nThe wing theory was applied in a special way so as\nto obtain results applicable to any arbitrary twist of\nthe wings. The theoretical span loading being a linear\nfunction of the angle-of-attack distribution, the loading\ndue to arbitrary twist can be built up, as will be indicated later, from certain elementary loadings by superposition. The elementary loadings considered were\nthose caused by simple unit jumps of angle of attack\noccurring at different points of the span.\nFor each of the nine tapered wings, the first 20\nFourier coefficients determining the load distributions\nwere computed (10 odd and 10 even) for the cases of\nunit angles of attack extending inward from the wing\ntip and covering various amounts of the semispan.\nThe rest of the wing was in each case assumed to be at\nzero angle of attack. The portions thus covered were\n0.25, 0.50, 0.75, and 1.00 of the semispan.\nIn spite of the great number of harmonic terms retained, the conditions near the points of discontinuity\ni the angle of attack required special treatment. The\nn\nproblem of these end conditions has been solved by\nBet2 and Petersohn (reference 3) and their results were\nn\nutilized i fairing the load curves through this region.\nFigure 2 shows the elementary loadings that were calculated, including the modified fairing. The results\npertain specifically to the chord distributions illustrated\n\n152\n\nin figure 1 but interpolation might be made for intermediate plan forms.\nIt is evident that any angle-of-attack distribution,\nsymmetrical or unsymmetrical, may be built up of\nelemental steps of the type used in deriving figure 2.\nFigure 3 illustrates the procedure of hding the resultant\nload distribution. Thus, the loading contributed by\nelement 10 of figure 3 (a) is obtained by deducting the\nload curve due to an increment of angle of attack extending between 6 and C from that duo to an increment\nextending between A and C. Although this process\ncould be continued until the load distribution was completely determined, the same results can be more easily\nobtained from influence lines, which give the load at a\nparticular spanwise station due to the effect of unit\nangle-of-attack changes extending inward various\n\n(a) Angledf-attackdistribution.\n(b) Load distribution for elemant (O.\nI)\nFIGURE\nI.--LOad components for an element.\n\namounts from the right wing tip. Such influence lines\nare given in figures 4, 5, and 6 for eight evenly spaced\npoints across the wing semispan. Each line was obtained by cross-plotting the values of C l d C , at the interQ\nsections of the loadink curves of figure 2 with vertical\nlines drawn at the particular stations. (For exampIe,\nthe points of intersection of line Z-Z, fig. 2 (b), with\nthe various curves represent the load induced at the\n0.25-semispan point by uniform angle-of-attack increments that extend in varying- amounts from the wing\ntip. These intersections identify the corresponding\ncurves of figs. 4 to 6.)\nIn order to illustrate the use of the influence lines in\ndetermining the lift distribution ag well as to show the\ndegree of accuracy with which they may be used, the\ninfluence lines will be applied to predict the loading for\na tapered wing (X=0.25, A=6) corresponding to the\nangle-of-attack distribution shown in figure 7 (a).\nThe particular angle-of-attack distribution used is\ndefined by the equation\n-+-)sin\nc\n3csmn\n30\nc 4bsm6\n\nTHEORETICAL STABILITY AND CONTROL CHARACTERISTICS OF WINGS\n5\n\n4\n\n3\n\n2\n\nI\n\n0\n4\n\n3\n\n:Ic/cs\nd\n\n2\n\nI\n\n0\n\n4\n\n3\n\n2\n\n/\n\n0\n-10\n\n-8\n.\n(a) h=1.00.\n\n-6\n.\n\n-.4\n\n-.2\n\n0\n\n.\n2\n\nRelofive disfonce f r o m wing center\n\nx=a.m.\n\n.\n6\n\n.4\n(0)\n\n.\n8\n\n1.0\n\nh=0.25.\n\nFIQUBE-1dueucn lines for determining the load distribution. The following procedure illustrates the use of the influence lines to determine the lift at the 0.75-semispan point due to this distribution of twist: (1) The influence curve labeled\n0.75 in k r e 4 (c) is reproduced beneath the angle dis-\n\n\'or which these elements are drawn, as in sgufe 7 (c).\nBecause a negative angle would induce a negative load\nr t the point in question, AI is plotted aa a negative\nvalue. Although the agreement is not precise,\nit must be remembered that the solid curve represents\na case where no series approximation was necessary;\nhence it may be concluded that the influence-line\nmethod of determining the lift distribution is as accurate as any other for practical purposes.\nAside from other possible applications, the load distribution may be used to determine the stability derivatives for certain cases not specilkally covered by the calculations. In the subsequent charts, it is sometimes\nnecessary to stipulate either that the initial angle-ofattack distribution be symmetrical about the Wing\ncenter line or that the dihedral angle be constant along\nthe span. In the usual\ns\nlift range below the stall, this derivative may be considered to be independent of either initial wing twist or\nangle of attack and of the wing dihedral. In conventional cases, practically the entire damping moment for\nthe airplane may be attributed to the wings. It can be\nseen that the moment contributed by a tail surface,\ngeometrically similar to the wing but with only one-\n\nIonents being the more important. Comparison of the present values of C,, with similarly derived values given in\nreference 4 indicates that the effect of rounding the\nwing tips is to reduce the theoretical restoring moment\nby about 6 percent for wings of aspect ratio 6.\nYAWING MOMENT DUE TO ROLLING\n\nDuring a rolling motion, the wing experiences a linear\nantisymmetrical change in angle of attack along the\nspan and, as a result, antisymmetrical loadings are\nadded to those that originally were on the wing. Changes in taper ratio did, however, have an\nappreciable effect on the value of C , (fig. 8) with the\nresult that the ratio of the yawing to the rolling moment\nin roll will, in general, increase with increase in taper.\nInasmuch as the inclination of the lift vectors at the\nouter portions of the span has such a predominating\neffect on the yawing moment, the most effective means\nof reducing C- for a given wing lift coefficient i s to\ngive the wings washout toward the tips.\nThe yawing moment due to rolling is, in conventional\ndesigns, largely due to the wings. The\nstrip theory.\nThe direction of the moment is such that, with the special distributions for which the derivatives of figure\nsystem of axes used, a positive rolling moment generally 12 apply are both uniform and symmetrical about the\n\n160\n\nTHEORETICAL STABILITY AND CONTROL CHARACTERISTICS OF WINGS\n\nwing center line. This\nlimitation in the applicabiIity of these curves as compared with the previous ones is due to the fact that the\nprinciple of superposition does not apply in cases where\nthe variation is not linear with CY. The computed\nresults may, however, be used to determine the variation of Cn7for the most useful case, namely, that of a\nwing without twist. For this purpose, the proper\nobtained from figure 13, which is a cross\nvalues o Cn,/a2\nf\nplot of the end points of figure 12, are multiplied by the\nsquare of the actual angle of attack.\nThe part of the yawing moment due to the profile\ndrag can be determined from the easily derived equation\n\nwhere cdo and c are functions of the distance y along the\nspan. It is possible, by assuming cd,, constant and by\nneglecting terms of the second order, to obtain a coefficient ACn,that may be used with the equation\nWuocoinr=\n\nAcn,\n\nr6\n\ndue to the induced drag exceeds that due to the profile\ndrag. I it i assumed that a=0.3 and CD,=O.O1, then\nf s\nthe respective values of Cn7and AC.,, would be 0.0522\nand 0.0031 for a rectaagdar wing of aspect ratio 6.\nThe damping moment contributed by the wings i\nn\nyawing motion is, in most cases, secondary but i not\ns\n\nplan\' view\n\nFront view\n\n!\n\n(13)\n\nResfffthg ar-tqfe-of-of tack dsfribution\nto compute the part of the yawing moment due to the\nFIQUBE\n15.-Eflect of irregular dihedral on sideslip.\nprofile drag. The values of the profile yawing moment, as given by equation (13), are sufEciently\naccurate for most wings since ca0 generally varies only negligible with respect to the damping moment conslightly across the span. The variation of the coef- tributed by the fuselage and the vertical tail surfaces.\nn\nThe damping i yawing due to the wings depends upon\nwith taper ratio is given in 6gure 14.\nGcient ACn7/CD,\nthe angle of attack as well as upon the plan form;\ntherefore the relative amounts wntributed by the\nwings and tail surfaces may vary considerably.\nAlthough it was not possible to give a general chart\nfor determining the damping i yawing for symmetrin\ncally twisted wings as was done with the previous derivatives, it can nevertheless be said that the addition of\nload toward the tips, whether by washing or by an\nincrease in taper ratio, would increase the wing damping\nmoment due to a yawing angular velocity.\nROLLING MOMENT DUE TO SIDESLIP\n\nTaper rofio, h\n\nFIGURE14.-Pro1Xedrag yawing derivative. AN8.,m,ng=AC*,&S6\n\nThe total wing yawing moment due to yawing is the\nsum of the moments given by equations (11) and (13).\nAt low lift coefficients, the profile drag contributes the\ngreater portion of the wing damping moment in yawing.\nAt moderate or high lift coefficients, however, the part\n\nThe manner in which the changes i angle of attack\nn\nthat cause a rolling moment are brought about during\na sideslipping motion is shown in figure 15 by a sketch\nof a wing having positive, negative, and zero dihedral\nover various portions of the span. For simplicity, the\nwing i s assumed to have no initial twist and the dihedral\nangles are assumed constant over each of the portions\nA, 6, and C. For small angles of sideslip 8, the increase in angle at tip A is, to a h t approximation,\nequal to r&;whereas, at the opposite tip A\', there is\nan equal decrease of the angle of attack. The portions\n6-43\',\nhaving no dihedral, contribute no change in angle\nof attack when the wing is sideslipping. At the center,\n\n161\n\nREPORT NO. 635-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nhowever, owing to the negative angle of dihedral rc,\nthere is an effective decrease in angle of attack over\npast C equal to r,p and on C\' there is a similar increase\nin angle. Figure 15 shows the resulting effective\nangle-of-attack distribution for the particular shape of\ndihedral assumed.\nThe effect of this distribution is similar to that caused\nby two pairs of ailerons equally and oppositely deflected\nwith the inner pair opposing the rolling action of\nthose at the tip. Positive areas of dihedral on the\nadvancing wing tend to add load onto that wing. For\nthe system of axes chosen, all areas with positive\ndihedral produce a negative rolling moment with a\npositive angle of sideslip. T i moment, like the rolling\nhs\nmoment due to roll, is independent of the initial wing\ntwist as long as no portion of the wing becomes stalled.\nThe rolling-moment derivative due to sideslip CJB\nmay be determined from figure 16, which gives the\nvariation of C,p for various unit antisymmetrical\nangle-of-attack distributions (i. e., symmetrical portions\nwith constant dihedral) that extend out from the wing\ncenter and cover various relative amounts of the wing\nsemispan. I n the usual case, where the dihedral\nangle r is constant along each semispan, the value of\nthe rolling moment due to a sideslip angle p can be\nobtained from the equation\nwhere the appropriate values of Cb/r, obtained from\nfigure 16 at the relative distance equal to 1.0, are multiplied by the dihedral angle in radians. I n more\nunusual cases as, for example, where only the tips are\nturned up or where the wing is given a gull shape for\nany reason, it is stiU possible to determine a coefficient\nof rolling moment due to sideslip simply by adding the\neffects of the various parts in the way previously described. Thus, for the wing shown in figure 15, let\nA=6, X = l . O , ra and r,=o.l radian and assume that\nit is desired to find the proper value of CtB use in\nto\nequation (14). The part due to the tip portions A-A\'\nis A, (from fig. 16 (a)) X ra=0.195 X 0.1=0.0195.\nThe part due to the center portions C-C\' is As x r,=\n0.065X0.1=0.0065. The resulting value of Cb to\nbe used in equation (14) is thus 0.0130. The extension\nof this method to a curvilinear variation of r along\nthe span may be easily made by plotting the values of\nr at each point of the span and using the method given\nin a previous section for integrating for the total effect.\nThe results of figure 16 indicate that equivalent\nangle-of-attack changes caused by unit lengths of\ndihedral portion near six-tenths of the relative distance\nfrom the center are, in general, slightly more effective\nin producing rolling moment than unit lengths of dihedral at the tips. Such a result is due partly to the\nfact that the load curves near the tips are rounded and\npartly to the fact that, for the tapered wings, the larger\nareas affected by lengths of dihedral near the 0.6 point\ntend to compensate for the shorter moment arms\nthrough which the change i loading acts.\nn\n\n162\n\n7\n\nTHEORETICAL STABILITY AND CONTROL CHARACTERISTICS OF WINGS\n\nAlthough, during a sideslipping motion, positive\ndihedral produces a righting moment, a similar though\ngenerally smaller effect may also be produced by the\naddition of vertical area above the longitudinal wind\naxis. Also, on account of interference effects, the\nproportion of the airplane rolling moment contributed\nby the wings may vary considerably with the external\nappearance of the airplane.\nIt is usually considered, i practice, that a straight\nn\nwing will have some dihedral effect, but tests of Wings\nwith well-rounded tips (reference 5) do not support this\nuiew. I n cases of wings with blunt tips or in cases\nwhere chords of the sectians near the tip do not lie in\none plane, some dihedral action i s shown.\n\nIt will have been apparent from the preceding discussion that the results of figure 16 may also be applied\nto predict the rolling moment caused by an dlron\ndeflection in unyawed flight since ailerons, equally and\noppositely deflected, cause changes in the angle-ofattack distribution that are similar to the changes\ncaused by dihedral. Strictly speaking, however, the\nchange in angle of attack due to dihedral cannot have\nquite the same effect as a similar change produced by\nailerons because the ordinary lifting-line theory, when\napplied to yawed or sweptback wings, omits the effect\nof the stagger of the trailing vortices and the inclination\nof the bound vortex. Although the present theory has\nnot been modXed to take this effect into account, there\n.\n7\n.\n6\n\n5\n\n4\nk\n.3\n\n.E\n\n.I\n\nr,\nu\n\n.I\n\n.J\n\nflop o r ai/eron chord/Wng chord\nFIGURE\n18.-Vsriation of k with ratio of flap or ailoron chord to wlng chord.\n\nis ample justification for omitting it in the computations as experiments indicate only second-order differences (see reference 5) for the usual angles of yaw and\nsweepback.\nFor the computation of the rolling moment due to an\naileron deflection 6, the appropriate value of CI6to be\nn\ninserted i the equation\nFIGWEI?.-Comparison between experimental and computed values of Ct# (ox.\nperimontal data from referenca 6).\n\nLaireras=\n\nC&sb\n\n(15)\n\nmay also be found from figure 16. Figure 20 i l s\nxs\nlutrates the mmponents of the section lift and drag\nvectors that produce yawing moments. The advanced\nwing having the larger lift will also have a larger induced\ndrag and hence a componentmoment is set up that tends\nto turn the wing so as to reduce the sideslip; at the same\ntime, however, the mntrq moment due to the components of the lift acts to advance the forward half of\nthe wing still more. As was the case with the yawing\nderivative due to rolling, the moments caused by the lift\ncomponen~predominate and, as a result, the net\ntheoretical moment is an unstable one; or, in other\nwords, with the system of axes chosen, a negative\nyawing moment results when the dihedral and sideslip\nangles are positive.\nThe explanations advanced in some textbooksneglect\nthe inward slope of the lift vectors and lead to an incorrect sign of the yawing moment.\nThe yawing moment in sideslip is given by the e q u e\ntion\nThe derivative Cn6is given in\n21 as a ratio in\ntern of ra because its value depends linearly upon the\nmagnitude of the product of these variables. The\nhave been computed for unit symmetrivalues of Cn6/ra\ncal sngle-of-attack distributions that extend out on\neither side of the center line and cover 0.25, 0.50, 0.75,\nand all of the wing span. These curves may be used to\ndeterniine values of CnB any initial angle-of-attack\nfor\ndistribution symmetrical about the wing center line,\nprovided also that the angle of dihedral is constant\nacross the wing span. Although the rolling derivative\ndue to sideslip can be obtained (from fig. 16) for a curvil n a variation of dihedral along the span, it is necessaq\nier\nto stipulate that either a or r remain constant if the\nprinciple of superposition is to be applied in the determination of Cno. The combination of variable symmetrical twist and uniform dihedral being more common\nthan the converse, the computations were shortened by\nincluding curves for only the case of uniform dihedral.\nThe resultant value of C , (to be used in equation\n,\n(16)) is found by either an integration or a summation\nof the effects of elements of angle of attack extending\nalong the span. The process to be followed where\ngraphical evaluation is necessary has been illustrated\nin Sgure 10, with the ordinates of Sgure 10 (a) changed\nto ra. The ordinates and abscissas of the remaining\npsrts are to be changed as required. For untwisted\nWings with uniform dihedral, the value of Cno/rais\nobtained by multiplying the value read a t a relative\ndistance of 1.0 by the wing angle of attack and, i\nn\nturn, by the dihedral angle.\nThe curves of Sgure 21 being generally steeper beyond the 0.5 point, the deduction of increments of\n\nangle of attack a t the tip, i. e., giving the wing washout, would be the simplest means of decreaaing the\nunstable yawing moment caused by the wings in a\nsideslipping motion.\nAlthough the predicted variation of the yawing\nmoment with dihedral is confirmed, experiments show\na residual stable yawing moment a t zero dihedral that\ni not predicted by the ordinary theory. T i residual\ns\nhs\nmoment is greater for wings with blunt tips and i\ns\ngreater a t zero or negative lifts. It will be noted that\nthe theoretical yawing moment is itself the small resultant of two large contrary effects and is thus of the\nsame order as a number of possible secondaryinfiuences.\n\nLANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nLABORATORY,\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTIC8,\nLANGLEY\nFIELD, April 19, 1958.\nVA.,\nREFERENCES\n1. Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1938\n\n167\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 638\nTHE INFLUENCE OF LATERAL STABILITY ON DISTURBED MOTIONS OF AN\nAIRPLANE WITH SPECIAL REFERENCE TO THE\nMOTIONS PRODUCED BY GUSTS\n13y\n\nR O R E I ~. JONES\nTT\n\nSUMMARY\n\nDisturbed lateral motions hazje been calculated for a\nhypothetical small airplane with various modijkations o\nf\nfin area and dihedral setting. Special combindims of\ndisturlring factors to simulate gusts are considered and\nthe influence o lateral stability on the motions is discussed.\nf\nThe modifications o the airplane include changes of\nf\ndihedral from 0" to 10" and changes o the weathercock\nf\nstability from zero to Cn,=0.iS7 (the eguivalent o a fit&\nf\nas ,?urge as i O percent o the wing area). The positions of\nf\nthe modijied airplanes on the lateral-stability churts are\nshown.\nFin area and wing dihedral werefound to be o primary\nf\nimportance in side gusts. It was found that the roUing\naction of the wing with as much as 5" dihedral was dist i d y unfavorable, especially when the weathercock stability waa small. I t is pointed out that the greatest susceptibility to lateral disturbances lies in the inherent\ndamping and coupling moments developed by the wing.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nInherent stability, as defined in mathematical treatment, must be considered only one of several essential\nflying qualities of an airplane. Other important qualities belonging in this category are steadmess in rough\nair and responsiveness to control. Although the\ndifferent flying qualities depend largely on the same\ngoverning factors, they may not call for similar proportionings of the factors. It is known, for instance,\nthat the requirements for stability and control may\nconflict.\nWhat is ultimately desired, or course, is a definik\nunderstanding of the individual requirements for staf\nbility, control, and steadiness in rough air. Most o\nthe earlier work has been devoted primarily to the study\nof stability alone. A noteworthy early work on the\n)\neffects of gusts is that of Wilson (reference 1. More\nrecently the results of an investigation dealing with the\neffects of different degrees of stability on the motions\nfollowing assumed initial conditions have been published (reference 2 ) . The purpose of the present work\nis to study the amplitudes of the motions set up by\ngusts or other disturbances, particularly insofar as these\nmotions are affected by the lateral-stability characteristics. It i hoped that the study will be useful in\ns\n\nndicating combinations of stability characteristics\nkhat result in good riding qualities.\nThe mathematical treatment employed is, in prin.iple, an extension of that used by Wilson nntl other\nmrly writers. The methocls of calculation are, liom ever,\nnore concise and the development is not restricted to\nspecial types of gust. The operational method of\nresolving the effects of disturbances was used. (See\nFeference 3.)\nAccording to the theory, the motion caiisetl by any\n"andom variation or sequence of the disturbing factors\nnay be built up by superposing the effects of abrupt\nmit increases of the disturbance, which corresponds, in\nhhe case of gusts, to the effects of elementary sharp-edge\n:ross-currents. Thus the effects of random gusts can be\nargely visualized in the effect of a unit sharp-edge gust.\nSTABILITY FACTORS ASSUMED\n\nThe chief differences of lateral stability considered\nwere assumed to be brought about by changing the fin\narea and dihedral of a hypothetical small monoplane.\nDifferences in other proportions of most airplanes of\nconventional form have only secondary effects (in\nunstalled flight) and, furthermore, are not usually dictated by considerationsof stability. The exact arrangement of the hypothetical airplane, such as the vertical\ndisposition of the wing with respect to the fuselage,\nmay be taken as indefinite. Differences of arrangement can, of course, have large secondary influences on\nthe action of the fin or dihedral, which are usually\nattributed to aerodynamic interference. It is reasonable to assume that the effects of such interference will\nbe similar to the effects of actual changes in the size\nof the h or the amount of dihedral.\nThe airplane assumed in the calculations is a small\n1,600-pound monoplane having rectangular wings with\nrounded tips. The other proportions, including the\nradii of gyration about various axes, the tail length, etc.,\nare based on average values of these quantities for 21\nnumber of conventional machines. The stnbility derivatives and other characteristics of the airplane arc\nessentially the same as those used in reference 4,except\nfor the differences of fin area and dihedral, and apply to\npower-off e h t . The axes and symbols employed\nthroughout are given in detail in reference 4. Additional symbols that occur in this report are given in the\nfollowing lit:\n\n169\n\nREPORT NO. 638--KATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nac,, ~\nC n P = -yawing moment due to rolling.\nd-\'I\n\nX, l\', and Z,axes fixed in the nirglttne so thtit S\npoints into the relative wind in st,ently flight. (See\nreport cover.)\nri,, steady-flight velocity.\nO=tan-\' VI[\',,.\nDerivatives (see report cover for formulation of\ncoefficients) :\n\n21:,\n\nClr= -IdC, rolling moment due to yawing.\nrb\nd2L\n0\n\'\n\nC =- dC, yawing moment due to yawirig.\n+ -J rb\n\na-211,\n\nCYa=-, side force due to sideslip.\n&CY\nL\ndC\nC,g=B\'l rolling moment due to sideslip.\n\nN - - 1 dN\n-.\n"-mk,\' a n\n\ndC.\nCna=-, yawing moment due to sideslip.\n\nIt was found convenient to tlesignnnte the five cases\nof modification by symbols representing the different\nfront views of the airplane. I t slionlrl he nientionrtl thnt I<orvinKroukovsky\'s forniiilns :ire niore stiited to the rmpiricdstirtistid iinalysis in whirli they wtw eniployrd tliaii\nto the tlt+mninirtion of nbsolute v~iluesof C,,p/C,o\nfor\nthis stirbility ellart. In most cases, wid-tunnel tests\nshow values of CnP\nsmaller thiin those predicted so that\n\nthe specified range, if given in wind-tunnel values,\nwould probably fall somewhat lower than indicated in\nfigure 1.\nThe value Cnp=Odoes not, of course, correspond to\nan airplane with no vertical tail surface. Experience\nhas shown that the unstable yawing moment of a large\nwellstreamlined fuselage may entirely offset the stabilizing action of a fair-size fin. This occurrence is naturally more probable if the fin area is originally small;\nhence the smallest arca likely to be used in a modern\ndesign (4 perccnt of the wing area) was chosen to represent the condition.\nIt is, in general, difficult to predict the values of\neither Cnp C , for a given design. It will be realized\nor\nthat the corresponding values of fin area and dihedral, as\nreferred to in tliis report, apply only under certain\nidealized conditions and are employed primarily as a\nmatter of convenience in fixing ideas on the problem\nReference 9 gives a summary of test values of Cna,\nincluding a discussion of pertinent factors and drawings\nof the models tested. The data included in that paper\nshould aid the designer in judging the weathercock\nstability.\n,\nINFLUENCE OF LATERAL STABILITY ON MOTIONS DUE\nTO ARBITRARY DISTURBANCES\nGENERAL DESCRIPTION OF LATERAL MOTIONS\n\nThe equations of lateral stability generally sliow two\nreal roots together with one conjugate complex pair,\nindicating three \xe2\x80\x9cmodes\xe2\x80\x9d of motion. Different clisturbances will result in motions compounded of these\nthree modes in different proportions.\nTable I1 lists the roots, or stability indices, \xe2\x82\xacor the\nvarious cases considered. The first mode (corrcsponding to the root hl), represents primarily the lieavy damping of any movement involving rolling of thc wings rchtive to the air. At normal flight speeds, this damping\nis such that the wings are in a large measure constrained against such relative moverncnt normal to\ntheir chords.\n\n(a) C~=0.35; U0=150. p. s.\n1\n(b) C\xe2\x80\x98=l.O; Uo=88.5 f. p. s\n(c) C~=1.8; Uo=GG I. p. s.\n\nFIGURE\n1 --Stability chart showing positions of the assumed airplanes.\n\nTABLE 11.-STABILITY\n\nINDICES, RATES OF DAMPING, AND PERIODS\n(0.095 or\n-0.105)\n\n0.35\n1.0\n1.8\n\n.35\n1.0\n1.8\n.35\n1.0\n1.8\n.35\n1.0\n1.8\n.35\n1.0\n\nI. 8\n\n-5.477\n-3.255\n-2.533\n-5.472\n-3. m\n-2633\n-5.466\n-3. m\n\n-z a n\n-5.369\n-3.070\n\n-.2\n230\n-5.573\n-3.4R0\n-2.872\n\n0. 1%\n,212\n\n.273\n128\n.210\n\n.\n.mz\n.I T ,\n\n--.6080\n\n.258\n\n.1347\n\n.m\n.ID\n,225\n.m7\n.124\n\n.I s 9\n\n.MO\n\n__ - .\n.\n\n___- I - - -0.4190\n--.a74\n\n-. 0070\n.WX5\n\n.06M\n0\n\n.om\n.Mal\n\n.I770\n\n.m\n\n-.awl\n\n-.01R1\n\n-. 1045\n\na\n\n1.645\n\xe2\x80\x9c2.32\n\xe2\x80\x981 1.13\n15.0\n1.55\n1.53\nm\n\n1.133\niMi\n2. n\n\n.\n\n.137\n.TB\n\n2 (B\n5 71\n1. 005\n\n-0. 1720\n\n-.I386\n\n-. 1794\n\n-.495\n3637\n5247\n\n-_\n\n-.\n-. 680\n-. 4797\n-. 0075\n-.571\n-_\n529\n795\n423\n\n-.\n-.\n-. 235\n-. 3219\n\n.1\n\n-0.69\n\n.\n\n4.01\n4.98\n3.85\n1.39\n1.90\nI315\n1.44\n1.14\n1.21\n1.30\n\n2. 22\n\n0.708\n.f(211\n. S m\n2.45\n\n2.013\n\n1. III\n\n1L17\n.I1\n1\n.\n\n.\n\nli4 I\n,937\n1.02\n\n1.6i6\n\n1.54G\n3.03\n\n5.04\n\n2. 14\n\n.sin\n\n.iRI1\n.SFl\n.fXM\n\n1. R3!1\n2 35\n1.119\n1.415\n2. .55\nI. 8%\n\n1. li!Ji\n\n.R(i8\n\n1.c;a\n\nI. 031\n1 iin\n.\n.GI(;\n\n.Rlill\n\n.\n\n* Th8 value -0.65iA representstime to diminkh by h.\nb\n\nd\n\nI e -0.105pr for tuna to diminish by\nia\nQuarterperiod.\nRor this m,-0.69hr has limn usnl.\n\n2/10 when A2 is negative; USB 0.095/x2\n\n-\n\n.!I?:,\n\nfor timc to increw by 1/10 \\I hen A? is I~ositivc.\n\n171\n\nREPORT NO. 6 3 G N A T I O N A L ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nThe second mode distinguishable in the lateral\nmotions (corresponding to A,) is a practically continuous turning motion, which may either coin-erge or\ndiverge. Normal stability of this mode represents the\nslow natural rccorery from a banlred turn. The rate\nof increase or decrease of the turning motion is slow,\nprimarily on account of the inseiisitiv-eness of the airplane to displacenient in bank and the strong rcsistance\nto rolling motion. The slow spiral always occurs with\ninward sideslip.\nThe third mode (X,) is the familiar oscillti tion, consisting usually of a yawing and sideslipping motion.\nSuch rolling as occurs in the oscillation is detrrnliried\nby the tendency of the wings to follow a path outlined\nby the dihedral in front view. The wing, when sideslipping, tends strongly to roll in a way involving the\nleast angle-of-attacli change along the span. Thus the\noscillations involve a \xe2\x80\x9cweathercoclrJ\xe2\x80\x99 motion combined\nwith a rolling nearly in phase with the sideslip.\nWith fairly large fin area, the oscillations are rapid\nand are quickly clamped. Under most conditions the\namplitude is small. As the fin area is reduced, however, the period becomes slower and, with normal\ndihedral, the oscillation takes on the character of a\nswinging in bank and sideslip under the action of\ngravity. The point of instability is reached when the\noscillation degenerates to an almost pure rolling and\nsideslipping motion, so that the damping derivative in\nyawing, Cn,, has little effect on the occurrence of\nundamped oscillations. As has been shown (reference\n4),unstable oscillations can readily occur if the airplane\nis constrained in yawing.\nAlthough both the oscillation and the slow mode of\nconvcrgence are largely governed by the fin area and\nthe dihedral, the rapid convergence AI is practically\nindependent of either of these factors. The damping\ncomes, of course, from the wings and is an inherent\ncharacteristic of conventional airplanes. This damping is excessive and is undesirable, since it indicates\ngreat sensitiveness to rolling gusts or to vertical gusts\nwith a gradient along the wing span. The damping of\nrolling can be reduced by increasing the lateral moment\nof inertia, but the possible improvement appears to be\nsmall.\n\nairplane. With conventional control devices, the disturbances do remain practically independent of tlie\nmotions. The orientation of the gusts is not dependent\non the motion of the airplane, and deviations caused by\nsuch outside disturbances will introduce changes in the\nmagnitudes of the disturbing factors themselves. For\nsmall displacements, these changes are of second order\nn\nand are negligible. For large displacements i gusts it\nmay, liowever, be necessary to cany out the caleulntion\ni several steps, altering the magnitude of the diiturbn\nnnce as the orientation of the relative wind changes.\nThe data needed for the computation of motion under\nany given set of conditions are the histories of motions\nfollowing sudden unit disturbances. Computations of\nsuch unit motions were made during the course of the\ninvestigation reported herein and the results were used\na s the basis for the more complete calculations given\nLater.\nSpecifically, the unit disturbance referred to is a\nforce (Y) or a couple ( L or N ) having the value zero\nup to the time t = O and maintaining a constant d u e\nthereafter. The magnitude is such as to cause a\nunit linear or angular accelerhtion of the airplane.\nAccording to well-known mathematical rules, the\nmotions under such conditions are given by equations\nof the form\n\np y ( t )= p , , ~ f p l , l e \xe2\x80\x9d f + p y 2 e X ? f + p y 3 ~ n f b(t+t,,)\ncos\n\n(1)\n\nrvlicre pya, p u t , arid t,Irare constants, calculated raliics\nof which are given in table 1 1 and A,, Xp, a+& and\n1,\na-ib are the roots, or stability indices. (See table\n11.) Three components of motion for each of three\ncomponent disturbanres are given. Thus, p&) denotes\nthe rolling velocity clue to a unit side disturbance\nBnd rL(t) denotes tlie yawing velocity due to a unit\nrolling disturbance.\n\nCALCULATED MOTIONS\n\nThe equations of motion of the airplane form a linear\nsystem so that the effects of disturbances can be compounded by addition. Thus, if any sequence of application of forces or couples to the airplane is given, it is\npossible to compute the resultant theoretical motion a t\nany instant by addition, or integration, of separate\neffects. The impressed forces or couples may he due\nto control manipulation or to gusts, alone or in coinbination.\nThe foregoing statement refers to a resolution of the\nimpressed disturbances along the axes fixed in the airplane. The disturbances are assumed to take on preassigned values independent of the movements of the\n\n172\n\nPlots of tliese equations were made with scarcely\nany additional computation. The procedure is illust.ratcd by figure 2. First the coefficients, \xe2\x80\x98s given in\n7\n\n8\n0\n\nj00000000\n\n0\n\ns\n\nm\n\n000000 \'00000000\n\n000000\n\n0\nN\n\n0\n0 0 0 0 0 0 \' 0 00 0 0 0 0\n\n:\n:\n\n000000 \'00000000\n\nn\n.\n\nm\n\nINFLUENCE OF LATERAL STABILITY ON DISTURBED MOTIONS OF AN AIRPLANE\n\n0"\n\n173\n\nREPORT NO. 638-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ntable 111, were marked off on the ordinate scale. The\ntime intervals within which the various modes diminish\nor increase by one-half, or by one-tenth in the case of\nkz (see table II), werc then spaced off on the abscissa\nand points on the curves were found by diminishing\nor increasing the ordinates successively as indicated\nby the sign of the root. The oscillatory mode was\nobtained by drawing in the envelope (given by +py3,\nsay) and spacing off the quarter periods, beginning at\nthe point indicated by the phase angle of this mode.\nThe cosine curve was then simply sketched in as shown.\nThe final curves were found to give remarkably good\nchecks when applied in the original differential equations o motion. Such a check shows the correctness\nf\nof both the method of plotting and the analytical\nsolutions (equation (1) and table 111).\nIf the impressed disturbance is given as a function\nof t by a curve, it will usually be sufficient to approximate this curve by the addition of a number of successive positive and negative steps. The combination of\nsteps necessary to reproduce the disturbance leads\ndirectly tr, the addition of the elementary motions for\nthe resultant motion. Otherwise, for example, if the\nvariation of disturbance is given by L(t),then the resultant motion p ( t ) at any t6imet due to L(t) beginning\nat t=O may be found by Duhamel\xe2\x80\x99s theorem, thus\np ( t ) due 10 o a r f a b l e r o z r f w momenl=p&(t) L(0)\nwhere pL(t) and p,(t-t,) are obtained from table 111.\nAn explanation and a graphical method for evaluation\nof such integrals are given in reference 3.\nMOTIONS IN SIDE GUSTS\n\nThe motion caused by a unit increment of gust\nvelocity is found by compounding elementary disturbances in such a way as to simulate the disturbing action\nof the gust. Thus, in a side gust of velocity vo, the disturbing acceleration along Y will be voY, and angular\nvo\ndisturbances will be vo L,, N,.\nAs explained before, the effects of any usual variation\nof gustiness can be largely foretold from the effect of a\nunit sharp-edge gust. The variable gust can be built\nup from small increment jumps of gust velocity corresponding to sharp-edge cross-currents and the final\nmotion will approach that obtained by superposing the\nmotions due to the individual elements.\nThe effect of a sharp gust from the side is similar to,\nalthough not exactly the same as, the effect of an initial\nangle of sideslip. For the side gust, it is necessary to\ntake account of the period of penetration of the airplane\ninto the current. The first effect will be to push the\nnose of the airplane downwind whereas an instant later\nthe current will strike the fin, turning the machine into\nthe gust. The action of dihedral in causing the machine to roll away from the gust will also occur be\xe2\x82\xacore\nthe fin is affected. These effects are, however, of short\n\n174\n\nduration and do not alter the motion to any great extent\nafter the first fraction of a second, except in cases of\nsmall weathercock stability where the fuselage contributes a large unstable yawing moment.\nThe computations that follow are based on the assumption that the rolling action of the gust begins a t\nt = O and that the yawing action begins when the airplane has traveled far enough to carry the fin into the\ncurrent. The case of Cn,=O was treated by assuming\na yawing couple equal and opposite to that of the 4-percent fin applied when t=O, this couple being neutralized at the instant the fin entered the gust.\nA possible further refinement of the calculations\nwould involve the delay in building up the full lift forces\non the various surfaces. Mathematical methods for\ndealing with various lags or rates of growth of the aerodynamic reactions have been developed, but their\ndescription is beyond the intended scope of the present\nreport. It may be said, however, that, for motions as\nslow as the natural oscillations of a rigid airplane, this\neffect (judging by the theoretical predictions) is quite\nnegligible.\nFigure 3 illustrates the results of the calculations\nbased on a IO-foot-per-second sharp-edge side gust.\nThe curves shown are for flight at C,=l.O but the\nsame general trends appeared in the calculations made\nfor other lift coefficients.\nThe most noteworthy difference shown is the effect\ni\nof deficiency of fn area on the banking motion (figs. 3\n(a) and 3 (b)). The airplane with IOo dihedral and\naverage fin was not displaced so much in bank by the\nside gust as was the airplane with 5 O &he&ral and a\nsmall f n The initial rate of rolling, however, was\ni.\ngreater with the greater dihedral.\nWith a given dihedral an increase of f n area cuts\ni\ndown the banlcing motion although, aIter a certain\nsize is reached, the gain becomes slight, as is illustrated\nby figure 3 (a). W,ith neutral weathercock stability\n(fig. 3 (c)) the change of heading on entering the gust\nis at first small and, although the motion is stable, the\noscillation in azimuth seems to be reinforced for a\ntime by the rolling. This action is to be attributed to\nthe phase lag between the r o l h g and the yawing effects\nupon penetrating the sharp-edge current. It scems\nprobable that an appearance of inherent instability\nmay be reached at a point considerably above the\nmathematical limit for undamped oscillations. (See\nfig. 1.) It is known, for instance, t,hat unstable oscillations may result from an attempt to hold the wings\nlevel with ordinary ailerons unless CnB a definite\nhas\npositive value.\nThe side gust is equivalent to a sudden shift in the\nwind directinn, corresponding to a change in azimuth\n# as indicated in figurc 3 (c). The normal airplane\n,\nswings about :ind tcricls to approach this hentling. I t\nwill be noted t l i a t the airplane with the large fin turns\nfairly sharply into the wind and, since the banking\n\nINFLUENCE OF LATERAL STABILITY ON DISTURBED MOTIONS OF AN AIRPLANE\n\n175\n\nREPORT NO. 638-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nmotion is small, tends to keep the same flight path\nrelative to the earth for a short time. After about 6\nseconds, however, tlie spiral divergence begins to be\napparent and the motion finally results in turning\ndownwind.\nAn example of extreme spiral divergence is illustrated\nby the airplane with no diliedral. In this case, however, the airplane banks and turns directly upwind.\nThe airplane with large dihedral illustrates the opposite condition and shows the predominance of oscillations that generally characterizes the effect of dihedral.\nHere the airplane tends back toward its original azimuth heading, drifting sidewise with the gust.\nThe airplane with 5\' dihedral banked rather sharply\naway from the gust, whereas the airplane with zero\ndihedral showed an undesirable tendency to bank and\nslide into the gust. It was therefore a matter of\ninterest to try some modifications lying in between\nthese two conditions. It was realized that the rolling\ncould not be entirely suppressed by such modifications\non account of the phase relationships involved in the\nmotions.\nIt appeared that lo or 2 O of effective dihedral would\ngive about the least banking motion in the side gust\nand hence this condition was investigated. Inasmuch\nas the airpltme might have shown a noticeable spiral\ndivergence a t low speeds with the normal fin area, this\narea was arbitrarily reduced, bringing the weathercockstability factor Cngdown in about the safne proportion\nas the dihedral factor C,. The values selected were\nCn,=0.025 and CIg=-0.035, which corresponds to\n2 O effective dihedral.\nThe position of this airplane on\nthe lateral-stability chart is denoted by the point A\nin figure 1 (b).\nThe results for airplane A are compared with the\nothers in figures 3 (a) and 3 (b). It will be noted that\nthe bank is somewhat smaller than in the case with 5 O\ndihedral and a large fin but that the bank persists for a\nlonger time. The difference made by the change from\n5 dihedral to 2\' seems surprisingly small. A some\'\nwhat greater difference would be expected if the fin\nhad not been reduced. It should be borne in mind\nthat the yawing disturbance is reduced by cutting down\nthe fin.\nThe curve for airplane B (fig. 3 (a)) shows the result\nof attempting to secure spiral stability (at C,=l.O)\nby cutting down the fin of the airplane with 5 dihedral.\n\'\n(Note that airplane A is slightly unstable.) Tlie value\nof CnSin this case is about half that assumed for the\nmean condition. (See fig. 1 (b).) The banking displacement seems nnclesirably large (coinpnrat3ively)iri\nthis case.\nOTHER TYPES OB GUST\n\nThe flight velocity of the airplane being normally\nlarge with respect to gust velocities, it is permissible to\nconsider the gusts as being stationary in time with\nrespect to the flight path. Thus the gusts are con-\n\n176\n\nsidered to exist as a fixed pattern in the air ahead of the\nairplane and not to vary in time within the short space\nrequired for the machine to travel its own length.\nAs mentioned before, when the airplane enters a\ncross-current in level flight, a gradient of sidewise\nvelocity along the length of the fuselage will exist.\nThe effect of this gradient is similar to the effect of a\nrelative yawing motion superposed on the side velocity.\nFor a uniform gradient the additional yawing moment\nwould be (-dv,/dx) XN,. The calculations involved\nthis factor by virtue of the time lag assumed in application of the yawing moment due to the fin, and upon\nthis basis they should be applicable to any roasonnble\nvariation or gradient of sidewise velocity.\nA somewhat different situation arises when the airplane is climbing or descending through a cross wind\nthat varies with height, as, for instance, when descending through the earth boundary layer for a cross-wind\nlanding, for then no perceptible gradient of sidewise\nvelocity along the length of the airplane will exist.\nThe motions that arise in these cases can be compounded\nby integration from the motion following an initial\nangle of sideslip. This motion is: not greatly differen6\nfrom that caused by entering a sharp cross-current and\nthe same general conclusions will apply.\nIt appears that a true yawing gust, consisting of pure\nangular relative motion of the air, could act only\nmomentarily on the airplane. The sidewise velocity\nwould predominate after the first two- or three-tenths\nof a second with the airplane flying a t normal speed.\nGradients of velocity along the wing span, however,\nmight persist for longer periods.\nAway from the ground influence, gradients of forward velocity and of vertical velocity along the wing\nspan must be considered as being about equally probable. At normal Aight speeds, the vertical gradients\nproduce by far the greater effects. As was mentioned\nbefore, the damping of relative rolling motion is such\nthat the airplane very quiclcly takes on the angular\nvelocity of the gust gradient.\nFigure 4 shows the rolling motion calculated for the\nmedium airplane ( 5 O dihedral and 6 percent fin) in a\nmomentary rolling gust pOb/2Uo=0.05. It will be\nnoted that the airplane takes on approximately half\nthe rolling velocity of the gust within one-fifth second.\nAs might be expected, observations have shown that\nvertical currents tend to diminish near flat ground.\nThus side gusts and yawing gradients are more likely to\naffect the airplane while it is landing and taking off. At\nvery low speeds with Aaps down, tlie rolling tlcrivtitivci\ndue to yawing becomes :IS grc:tt :IS that tlue to rolling\n(see t:it)le I) so t h t in this condition\n:tirplnnc is\n:illkcc.ted as much by spnwisc gratlicnts of 1ongitucliri:il\nvelocity xs it would be by the rolling gradients. (Note\nalso that the effect of the rolling gradients is less a t\nlow speed.)\nFigure 5 shows the banlcing reactions of the various\nairplanes in a sudden, persistent yawing-gradient gust.\nt\n\nh\n\nb\n\nINFLUENCE OF LATERAL STABILITY OP\n\nTime. sec\nFIGURE -Typical rolling motion caused by a sudden rolling gradient\n4\npob\n~\n~ 05(t>O), 0\n-\n\nU0=88 5 f. p s.\n\nIISTURBED MOTIONS OF AN AIRPLANE\n\nfirst second, since the disturbing factors (rolling\nl\nmoments due to yawing velocity) are the same in al\ncases. The subsequent motions show the influence of\ndifferent degrees of spiral stability and instability.\nThe primary dishrbing factor in the yawing-gradient\ngust being proportional to the derivative L, (rolling\nmoment due to yawing), the greatest room for improvement would be to reduce this derivative. Taper and\nwashout (such as are attained with a partial-span flap)\nare beneficial in this respect. It is estimated that L,\nmight have been reduced by one-third of the given\nvalue (see table I) at CL= 1.8 if a 50-percent-span flap\nhad been assumed. The effect of plan form is not so\npronounced, leading to a reduction of one-sixth for a\n4: 1 taper.\nI n general, a reduction of the rolling moment due to\nyawing seems desirable from considerations of lateral\nstability. The magnitude of this derivative with controls k e d is, like that due to rolling, primarily a consequence of the general lay-out of the airplane and is\nnot dictated by considerations of stability. It appears,\nhowever, that the magnitude of L, with controls free\n(or loosely held) could be reduced or reversed by making use of an appropriate combination of ailerons with\nincreased upward pressure (attained by cambering the\nailerons) and a differential linkage, as described in\nreference 10. An appropriate linkage would eliminate\nthe necessity of applying contrary aileron pressure\nduring steady\'turns and would also eliminate the spiral\ninstability with controls free.\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\n\nA s h d y ol tlic cfkcts of gusts givcs tlilrcwllrt indica-\n\nThe gust assumed corresponded to a difference of longitudinal velocity between the two wing tips of about 9\nfeet per second (7$/2Uo=0.05).\nAll the examples\nshow roughly the same banking tendency within the\n\ntions depcndirig on the interval of tiirrc consitlcrctl.\nDuring the first stagcs, the upsetting moveincnts of the\nstable airplane may be more severe than those of a\nslightly unstable one. If the airplane is under control\nand if the gusts are of noticeable magnitude, then the\nmotion during the first % o r 3 seconds is of primary\nconcern. For uncontrolled flight or for flight in relatively calm air wlierc disturbances could beconrc apparent only through introtlucing a clivcrgcnce, the 1:iter\nstnges of tlie motion are of interest.\nIn a consideration of the early stages of tlie inotion,\nit is evident that the requirements of fin area and\ndihedral for spiral stability a t low speed conflict somewhat with the requirements for steadiness in side gusts.\nIf spiral instability is present, the rates of divergence\nintroduced by various disturbances appear to be small\nas long as there is a moderate cliheclral action present.\nThe condition of zero (effective) dihedral leads, however, to definitely undesirable rates of divergence.\nIf average weathercock stability (cn8=0.05 to 0.07)\nis assumed, the optimum magnitude of the rolling derivative due to sideslip for steadiness in side gusts\nappears to be about C,,=-O.Ol to -0.04, correspond1\ning to an effective dihedral of \' or 2O. Spiral stability\n\n177\n\nREPORT NO. 638-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nthroughout the flight range could be secured with this\ndihedral by cutting down the fin effect. The latter\nchange would lead to somewhat greater banking displacements in the gusts and would also be detrimental\nto aileron control, unless such control were obtained\nwithout adverse yawing moments.\nThe damping of rolling i such that the airplane very\ns\nquickly takes on any rolling component of gust velocity.\nThe usual modifications of the lateral-stability factors\nhave but little influence on the immediate effects of the\nrolling gust. An automatic device, acting so as to cut\ndown the damping of rolling (relative to the air),\nshould be advantageous from considerations of riding\ncomfort.\nThe effects of longitudinal gradients of gust velocity\nbecome fairly large a t low flight speeds. Noticeable\nimprovement can be obtained by the use of partialspan flaps or by otherwise concentrating the lift toward\nthe center of the wing, but this conclusion applies, of\ncourse, only as long as no portion of the wing is brought\nnear the stalling point.\n\nLANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nLABORATORY,\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS,\nVA., June 8, 1958.\nL.4NGLEY FIELD,\n\n178\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Jones\ny\nSUMMARY\n\nThe method of operators i s used i n t h e a p p l i c a t i o n of\nnonuniform-lift theory t o problems of a i r p l a n e dynamics.\nThe method i s adapted t o t h e determination of t h e l i f t under\np r e s c r a e d conditions of motion o r t o t h e determination of\nt h e motions with prescribed d i s t u r b i n g forces.\nINTRODUCTION\nProblems i n a i r p l a n e dynamics are u s u a l l y t r e a t e d on\nt h e assumption t h a t t h e a i r f o r c e s are i n s t a n t l y adjusted\nt o each motion of t h e airplane. Since t h e development of\nrecent t h e o r i e s f o r t h e nonuniform motion of a i r f o i l s , it\nhas become p o s s i b l e t o consider more exact l a w s f o r t h e adjustment of t h e l i f t .\nThe nonuniform-lift theory has already been applied t o\nc e r t a i n dynamical problems, notably t o t h e problem of f l u t ter. These a p p l i c a t i o n s have, however, been confined e i t h e r\nt o approximate s o l u t i o n s o r t o cases i n which t h e type of\nmotion is prescribed beforehand. The more u s u a l problem,\ni n which t h e r e s u l t i n g motion i s unknown, r e q u i r e s t h e sol u t i o n of i n t e g r a l equations. The present paper shows how\ns o l u t i o n s of t h e s e equations may be obtained f a i r l y simply\nby o p e r a t i o n a l methods.\nSUPERPOSITION O LIFTS\nF\nI n nearly every aerodynamic problem, t h e approximations\nt h a t must be made t o e f f e c t s o l u t i o n s are such as t o lead t o\nl i n e a r r e l a t i o n s . Thus, i n t h e case of t h e unsteady l i f t of\na wing, Laplace\'s equation combined with t h e assumption of\n\n181\n\nN.A.C.A.\n\nTechnical Note No. 667\n\na n \' u n d i s t o r t e d wake l e a d s t o a linear r e l a t i o n between t h e\nl i f t and t h e angle of attack. Such a r e l a t i o n means t h a t\nt h e l i f t due t o t h e sum of two v a r i a b l e motions i s equal\nt o t h e s m of t h e l i f t s f o r t h e two motions taken independent l y\n\n.\n\nI n p a r t i c u l a r , i f t h e l i f t following a sudden u n i t\njump of angle of a t t a c k i s known (see reference l ) , then\nt h e l i f t f o r any v a r i a b l e motion i s e a s i l y obtained by\nbreaking t h e given motion down i n t o a succession of small\njumps o r s t e p s and adding t h e l i f t s incident t o each one.\nThe case t r e a t e d by Wagner thus becomes t h e key t o t h e\nc a l c u l a t i o n of l i f t f o r any v a r i a b l e motion.\nWagner\'s function (reference 1) giving t h e l i f t a f t e r\n\na sudden u n i t jump of angle of a t t a c k (two-dimensional\nThe superposition of\ncase) may be denoted by cz (5).\n1\n\nl i f t s f o r any v a r i a b l e motion a ( s ) , as previously explained, is accomplished by t h e i n t e g r a t i o n of Duhamel\'s\nintegral\n\n(See reference 2.)\nOPERATIONAL SOLUTION OF INTEGRAL EQUATIONS\nIt is evident t h a t , i n order t o take account of unsteady air-flow phenomena i n t h e theory of a i r p l a n e dynamics (including s t a b i l i t y and r e l a t e d problems) t h e customa r y instantaneous equations of motion must be replaced by\nequations involving t h e i n t e g r a l (1). The equations of\nmotion then become l i n e a r i n t e g r a l equations. Solutions\nof t h e s e equations may be conveniently obtained by operat i o n a l methods.\nLet D represent t h e operator d/ds and l e t 1 = l ( s )\nrepresent t h e u n i t jump function, t h a t i s , a function of s\nhaving t h e value 1 a t s > 0 and having t h e value 0 a t\ns < 0. The cak&f\nt i m are based on the operational method.\nllhe starting lift of the $nite wing is found to be only\nslightly less than that o the infinite wing; whereas the\nf\n$mi&t may be considerably less. T e theoq indicates\nh\nthat the initial distribution of KB is SimiEar to the $\nd\ndisikibdion.\nCU~VES\nshowing the variatwn of l$ after a sudden unit\ni\nchange $n angle of attack, during penetration o a sharpf\nedge g&t,and during a continuous oscillation, are given.\nOperational equivdknts o thesefunctions have been devised\nf\nto fm\'litate the calculation of lift under various conditions\nof motion. A an application of these formulas, the\ns\nvertical acceleration o a loaded wing caused by penetrat;ng\nf\na gust h s been calculated.\na\n\nKutta condition. An essential feature of the problem\nis the determination of the influence of this wake on\nthe flow at the wing.\nIt is important to note that the wake is supposed\nto remain plane and undistorted. As 8 consequence of\nthis assumption, the effects of different wakes are\nadditive,.permitting the various flows to be built up by\nsuperposition. Thus, if the solution for the growth of\nthe increment of lift following a sudden change of normal velocity-or, what amounts to the same thing\nunder the assumptions involved, a sudden change in\nthe angle of attack-is known, this solution may be\nused as the element in an integral that gives the lift in\nany variable motion. With this point in mind, attention will at first be directed to the special case in which\nthe wing starts suddenly from rest at t =O with the\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe two&ensional\npotential theory of airfoils in\nnonuniform motion was given by Wagner (reference 1)\nand has been &tended to problemsinvolving the motion\nof hinged or fl&ble airfoils by Theodorsen (reference 2)\nand Eussner (qference 3).\nIn the case of steady motion, a correction is known to\nbe necessary before the results of the two-dimensional\ntheory can be applied to wings of finite aspect ratio.\nA theory for the unsteady lift of k i t e wings was developed in reference 4. This theory has since been somewhat improved mathematically by making use of\noperational methods in the solution of the integral\nequations. (See reference 5.) The present repo t\ncombines t i previous work and extends the theory o\nhs\nshow the effects of gusts.\n\nl\n\nTHE INDICIAL LIFT\nINFJXENCE OF TEE W A K E\n\nOwing to the presence of circulation, the lifting wing\nleaves in its path a surface of discontinuity, the local\nvortex strength of which is determined by the rate of\nchange of circulation taken both across the span and\nalong the flight path. (See fig. 1.) The distribution\nof vorticity in the wake is determined by the assumption that the flow field at each instant conforms to the\n\n_v,\n\nStart\n\nf\nFIQWE1.-Flow c a d by wing starting from rest.\n\nnormal velocity w and the flight velocity Uo, the\nvelocities remaining constant thereafter.\nLIFT NEAR TEE START\n\nThe starting lift of any wing may be expressed by a\nsimple theorem based directly on the Kutta condition.\nAs a consequence of this condition, the portion of the\nwake adjacent to the trailing edge must move as an\nimpermeable extension of the wing surface. Thus, the\nfirst element of wake formed must move with the same\nnormal velocity as the wing. The flow produced a t\nthe first instant is what might be caused by the wing\nin process of growing wider at the rate Uowhile moving\nilownward with the velocity w. The starting lift may\nthen be thought of as the reaction to uniform motion\nIf the wing as a body with increasing mass:\nL=- dm\'\nat\n\nREPORT NO. 681-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMWTTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nwhere m\' is the mass representing the aerodynamic\ninertia of the wing in normal motion.\nIn order to apply equation (1) to the finite wing,\nthe inertia factor for such a wing must be known as a\nfunction of the width. Solutions for elliptic plates are\ngiven by the clmsical hydrodynamic theory, and these\nsolutions can be used to represent approximately the\ninitial rates of increase of inertia of wings of oval or\nelliptic plan form.\nThe distribution of potential over each chordwise\nsection of an elliptic plate in normal motion has the\nsame form as the corresponding two-dimensional\npotential. Thus\n\n#&\n+/\n\n(2)\n\nwhere E is the elliptic integral giving the ratio of the\nsemiperimeter to the span. At bhe normal velocity\nw=E, the potential distribution over any chord is\nrepresented by a circle having the chord as diameter.\nf\n(See fig. 2 . ) I the edge of the plate distorts into a\nslightly wider ellipse, the change in potential arisfng at\nany point will be measured by the difference between\nthe original and the slightly expanded circles. (The\nchange in the factor E during widening may be neglected for ordinary aspect ratios.) The pressure dif\nferenceacross the plate with changing potential is given\nby the formula\n(31\n\n4\n\ni\nI\n\n111\nW\n\nIntegration of this pressure over any section givea the\nift coefficient for angle of attack a of the plate,\n\n(7)\nwith each local center of pressure at the quarter-chord\npoint.\nThe start of the plane elliptic wing being equivalent\nb a uniform lengthening of each chord, the true elliptio\noutline is not preserved. Such a change, however, may\nbe shown to conform very nearly to a change into\nanother, slightly larger, ellipse at all points except those\nvery near the tips. Furthermore, if the wing is assumed\nto distort in any of a number of ways into a slightly\ndifferent elliptical plan form, the change of aerodynamic inertia will be found to be but little affected by\nthe change in shape and to depend primarily on the\nover-all change in size. Each such distortion can be\nthought of as representing a certain distribution of the\nstarting velocity U around the edge of the Wing.\nEquation ( 5 ) is exact for all distortions of this class,\nInasmuch as they may be made to fall on either side of\nthe distortion represented by U= bonstant (representing the start of the rigid wing), the equation is also\nconsidered applicable to this case.\nTHE DOWNWASH CORRECTION\n\nA reasonably accurate curve of the growth of lift\nmight now be drawn by connecting the starting value\n\n,l~\nBasic ffow\n\nvo U t\nFIQWE2.-The wske and the distrlbutionof potential over the chord shortly after\nthestart.\n\nand, from the geometry of the circle,\n\nThe pressure across the plate with the normal velocitj\nw=E and the flight velocity Uois, therefore,\n(6,\n\n196\n\nrrmsfwmed flow\nFIGWE\n3.-Elemeut of circulatory flow.\n\n(equation ( ) asymptotically to the known steady\n7)\nvalue given by the Prandtl theory. Calculations have\n\nTHE UNSTEADY LIFI\xe2\x80\x99 OF A WING OF FINITE ASPECT RATIO\n\nshown, however, that, after the wing has progressed a\ndistance of the order of one semispan, the effect o\nf\nf i t e width of the wake can be treated simply as a\nmodi6cation of the angle of attack of the entire wing,\nas in the steady-lift theory. A closer approach to the\ntrue form of the curve may be obtained by proceeding\non this basis.\nBefore the three-dimensional problem is considered,\nit\nbe helpful to review certain aspects of the twodimensional theory (reference 1). In order to make\nthe analysis nondimensional, a l velocities are expressed\nl\nin terms of the flight velocity Uoand all lengths, in\nterms of the half chord.\nFigure 3 shows the elementtwo-dimensional flow\nused as a starting point by Wagner (reference 1).\nThis flow is caused by two vortices, representing, respectively, an element of circulation around the wing\nand the vortex left in the wake when this circulation\noriginated. The streamlines of this flow are eccentric\ncircles. One such circle (of unit radius) is chosen to\nrepresent the wing section and the axes are so placed\nthat this circle has its center at the origin. The geometry of the resulting pattern is such that, when the\nwake vortex is a t z, the Wing vortex will be at l/z.\nThis spacing preserves the unit circle as a streamline\nof the flow.\nTransformation of the pattern by the formula\n\nIn essentially the manner described, Wagner (refernce 1) calculated the two-dimensional flow around a\nring section following a sudden Uuit change in angle of\n-ttack. The integrated pressures over the airfoil give\n, lift coefficient that asymptotically approaches the\naown steady value 2 ~ whereas the starting lift\n;\noefficient is found to be exactly one-half this value.\nLe center of pressure remains a t the quarter-chord\n\xe2\x80\x98\nh\n)oint throughout the motion.\nIn the ca4e of the finite Wing, an element of the wake\nv i l l be as depicted in figure 3 but d, addition,\ni\nn\n:ontain vortices completing each circuit to the wing\n!bough the tips. The length of the tip vortices may\n)e approximated by assuming that they extend to the\n:hordwise centroid of the wing circulation. After some\n\nt\np\n_-------------_\n\n1.0\n\n0\n\nFIGUBE 4.-Position of the centroid of discontinuityin the wing for different positions\n\nof the wake vortex.\n\nflattens the unit circle into a thin-line wing section and\ndistorts the originally circular streamlines into oval\nJoukowski Egmes. The transformed pattern thus represents the circulatory flow around a flat wing section\nwith an associated countervortex in the wake. In the\ntransformation, the centroid of Wing vorticity remains\nat the position of the original bound vortex while the\nwake vortex is shifted forward somewhat as shown\n(fig. 3).\nEach elementary flow of the type shown contributes\na certtiii velocity around the trailing edge of the airfoil.\nThe flow due to an instantaneous change of angle of\nattack of the airfoil may be superposed on these flows\nand will contribute a trailing-edge velocity of opposite\nsense. On this basis, the problem of circulation with\nvarying angle of attack may be solved by an inverse\nprocedure. Assume some convenient distribution of\nwake vorticity and cailculate (by integration) the trailing-edge velocity at each point along the flight path\ncorresponding to the prescribed wake. The particula1\nvariation of angle of attack necessary to cancel this\ntrailing-edgeflow a t each instant (Kutta condition) can\nthen be determined. I a number of such curves arc\nf\nfound, they may be added in various ratios so as to\napproximate some prescribed variation of angle 01\nattack; the corresponding circulation c u v w are added\nin like ratios.\n\nz\n\nsalculation, the equivalent length of the tip vortices\nin terms of the distance traveled s reduces to\n\nz= Js (s+2)\n\n(9)\n\nfigure 4 iUustrates the rapid travel of the centroid of\ndiscontinuity within the wing subsequent to its initial\nposition at the trailing edge.\xe2\x80\x98 It is seen that, after a\ntravel of several chord lengths, the centroid may be\nhs\ntaken at the middle of the wing section. T i assumption will later be used.\nFigure 5 shows how an elementary loop vortex in the\nwake of a finite wing can be formed by cancelation from\nan element of the wake of an infinite wing. These results may also be used\nin conjunction with the equations given by Theodorsen\n(reference 2) to predict the a r forces on wings with\ni\nhinged flaps.\nIn all cases treated, the airfoil has been considered\nas moving in air that would otherwise be a t rest. . Another problem of considerable interest is the prediction\nof lift during passage of the airfoil through gusts.\nThe two-dimensional theory for this case was developed\nby Kiissner (reference3) and has since been corrected in\ncertain details by von K&rmBnand Sears (reference 8).\nThe basic solution required in the gust problem is\nthe solution for a unit sharp-edge gust of uniform upward velocity. I n order to obtain this solution, it is\nuseful to substitute for the change in direction of the\nrelative air velocity an equivalent fictitious bending of\nthe airfoil in still a r such that it has a t every point a\ni\nn\nangle of attack equal to the angle that would otherwise\nbe produced by the gust.\nThe effect of a bend progressing along the chord of\nthe airfoil.may be calculated by thin-airfoil theory\n(reference 9, chs. 1 1 and IV). A part of the effect\n1\nappears as a change in angle of attack of the airfoil as\na whole, namely:\n\n-cos-ys -1)r+&(2 -8)\n\nAa,= 1\n\'\n\n7Lp(s)A=B\n= 1.500r(1.0Q0-0.448e-o-2808\nL\n\n5,(s)\n\noI\n\n-0.272e-0*7268-193e-a.008)\n0.\n\'(45)\n=2.000r( 1.OOO -0.236e-0*w88\n\n(42)\n\nThe corresponding part of the lift is obtained from the\nindicid-lift function CLa(s) by superposition. I n\naddition, a reaction caused by acceleration of the noncirculahry potential flow exists during the time the\nairfoil is partly immersed in the gust. In two-dimensional flow, the additional reaction is\nACs,= 24s (2-s)\n\n(43)\n\nNo corresponding expression for the finite wing ie\nknown, but it may be reasoned that the maximum correction will be no greater than that indicated by the\ninertia factor of the rigid elliptic disk, 1/E. Hence, the\nformula\nAcL,=&lsF)\n\n(44)\n\nwas used for the finite wings as an approximation.\nThe consideration of wings with curvature or sweepback introduces another W c u l t y into the analysis,\nsince the sections of such wings will not strike the edge\nof the gust simultmeously. The two v o r t i c e s are connected by a s h e e t\ncontaining only t h e spanwise component of d i s c o n t i n u i t y .\nT h i s arrangement can be derived by t h e s u p e r p o s i t i o n of\nv o r t i c e s of t h e t y p e shown i n f i g u r e 3 .\nThe c e n t r o i d of wing c i r c u l a t i o n i s assumed t o remain\ns t a t i o n a r y a t t h e c e n t e r of t h e wing chord. The response may therefore\nbe considered instantaneous. Although the general case involves motions that combine changes sf angle of attack,\na, and of angular displacement, 8, the lift increments\nresulting from each motion have been separately treated,\nIn this form.,the results are directly applicable to the\ndifferential equations of motion of the airplane.\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\nAlthough the indicia1 lift of the tail surface actually shows a pronounced variation, it is permissible to\nconsider the effect of a simple lag if only moderate rates\nof motion are involved. The lag functions shown in figures 5 and 6 give the lift quite accurately during any motion that can be compounded of frequencies lower than one\n8\nn\n.5.\ncycle in 1 half chords ( < 0 3 )\n\nI will be noted that these expressions differ from\nt\nthose assumed by Cowley and Glauert in two ways. First,\nthe value of the function from 0 to 2 is not zero but\nis a positive value, which accounts for the upwash that\nthe tail initially encounters. Second, the distance after\nwhich the value of the function becomes negative is not\nequal to the tail length, 2, but occurs at a distance\nsomewhat greater than the tail length. This distance accounts for the lag in the growth of downwash and the lag\nin the development of lift by the tail and may be called\nthe effective tail length.\n212\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 771\n\nAlthough t h e r e s u l t s t h u s f a r have been obtained f o r\none s p e c i f i c wing and t a i l arrangement, t h e e f f e c t i v e t a i l\nl e n g t h and t h e magnitude of t h e e f f e c t t o be expected may\nbe determined f o r o t h e r cases.\nAccording t o t h e t h e o r y , t h e p a t t e r n of t h e wake\nformed by t h e wing remains unchanged as i t passes downstream. I n a d d i t i o n , t h e r a p i d changes of induced v e l o c i t y a t t h e t a i l occupy a f a i r l y s h o r t d i s t a n c e i m e d i a t e l y\nahead of and back of t h e edge of t h e wake. For any u s u a l\nt a i l l e n g t h , t h e r e f o r e , t h e t i m e h i s t o r y of t h e l i f t on t h e\nt a i l i s not s u b s t a n t i a l l y a l t e r e d i n r e l a t i o n t o t h e ins t a n t a t which t h e wake s t r i k e s t h e t a i l . JONES\nand DORIS\nCOHEN\n\n-SUMMARY\n\nthe most detailed is that of E. Bartsch on lateral\nmotions of an airplane with free rudder and ailerons\nAn investigation i s made of the conditions essential to\nthe stability of a n airplane with free control surfaces. (reference 1). In order to make specificrecommendaCalculatwns are based on typical airplane characteristics tions applicable to modern design, a study of stability\nwith certain factors varied to cover a range of current more complete and detailed than any available was\ndesigns. Stability charts are included to show the limiting undertaken. Calculations were made covering both\nvalues of the aerodynamic hinge moments and the weight longitudinal and lateral motions and the elevator-free,\nhinge moments of the control surfaces for various positions the rudder-free, and the aileron-free conditions. The\nof the center o gravity of the airplane and for control computations were based on a set of typical airplane\nf\nsystems with various moments of inertia. The eyects of characteristics, except for parameters introduced to\nreducing the chord and of eliminating thegoating tendency cover such variations in control-surface design as seem\no the surface, o changing the wing loading, and o\nf\nf\nf most likely to affect stability. The results that might\ndecreasing the radius of gyration of the airplane are also be expected under corrcsponding conditions in airplanes\nindicated. An investigation has also been made of the with different over-all mass characteristics have also\nnature of the motion of the airplane with controls free and been indicated.\nof the modes of instability that may occur.\nSYMBOLS AND COEFFICIENTS\nStability with the controls free generally depends more\ncritically on the design of the control system than on the\nThe following symbols are used in addition to those\nstability characteristics of the airplane. Fortunately, tlic\nrudder and the Jerons exert their principal influencer\non different modes and only a slight loss in accuracy i\nr\nincurred if each mode is treated separately.\nOscillation of the rudder control will be primarilj\ninfluenced by coupling with the yawing oscillations o\nthe airplane. The small rolling oscillations simul\ntaneously induced will generate neither very stroq\nyawing moments nor very strong rudder hinge moments\n\n228\n\nThis equation is closrly analogous to equation (6) lor\nlongitudinal motion. The corrcsponding coefficients\nhave similar values with the exception of CyB,\nwhich is\nmuch smaller than the corresponding term C becausc\n,\n.\nthe normal force that is developcd by the wing in\npitching is absent in the lateral motions.\nThe roots of the stability equation again indicate two\nmodes of motion. Thus, in a typical case, the roots\nare -0.008f0.035i and -0.2550.28i. In this instance, the modes are both oscillatory. The first\npair of roots indicates a lightly damped oscillation of\nsuch a frequency (pcriodr9Ochord lengths) as tozinvolvr\nsensible coupling between thc yawing of the airplane\nand the swinging of the rudder. Thc second mode is of\nmuch higher frequency and undoubtedly represents the\nnatural oscillation of the rudder with the airplane acting\nas a practically rigid support. When the restoring\nmoment c h 6 is reduced, the second mode becomes\naperiodic and eventually divergent as the motion becomes less rapid. Oscillatory instability appears first\nn the slower modc, as in the case of the elevator.\n\nAN ANALYSIS OF THE STABILITY O F A N AIRPLANE WITH FREE CONTROLS\n\nThe calculations of the stability boundaries covered\nchanges in rudder chord, changes in the airplane\nmoment of inertia mkz2, and changes in the weathercock stability factor CnB.
