Small simultaneous yawing and sideslipping motions will also occur but, because their\nreactions on the rolling and thc hinge moments are\nsmall, they may be neglected. The resulting equations\nare:\n\nor, in nondimensional form,\n\n(9\nD\n\nMass -moment paromefer, f\nFIGWBE\n14.-Aileron-free stability boundaries.\n\np,\n\n45; k x , 1.80.\n\ngain in this margin of stability is obtained by increasing\ncn&and reducing the floating tendency c a p of the rudder.\nReducing the chord of the rudder decreases both c s\no\nand c",, and hence considerably widens the margin o\nf\nstability. (See fig. 12.) Complete ehnhation of CB\nh\nby the use of a nonfloating type of balance eliminates the\nlikelihood of divergence within the normal range of\nweight distribution (fig. 13). Such a gain, howevcr,\nwould be achieved only by sacrificing some margin o\nf\noscillatory stability.\nThe lateral oscillations of an airplane with controls\nk e d are known to be influenced by coupling between\nthe rolling and the yawing motions. These oscillation2\ntend to become undamped when the weathercock\nstability cnpapproaches zero. Freeing the rudder\ncontrol diminishes c6 and may thus lead to this type\nof oscillatory instability. The condition for zerc\nweathereock stability is approximately that for straight\n\n230\n\nctD.>~+\n- (G,,D\n\n-\n\n+ct,)~\n\n01\n\n=\n\n(13)\n\n(ED-ChD+)D+f bakuZD2-CnD,D-CnJ6 = O\nIn the aileron control, a part of thc mechanism\nnormally rotates about an axis at right angles to thc\naileron hinge axis. As a result, a part of the aileron\ntorque produced by angular acceleration of the airplane is proportional to the product of inertia of the\naileron itself and another part is proportional to the\nmoment of inertia of the control stick or wheel. Both\nquantities are included in\'ithe parameter E. Thus:\nm,Ffqm&,2\n(14)\n5P\n\ns a p\n\nwhere the subscript s refers to the control stick and TJ\nis a constant inserted to take account of any difference\nof gearing between the control and the aileron.\nThe calculations, based on values of the derivatives\ngiven in the appendix, cover two aileron widths: 15\npercent and 30 percent of the wing chord. In both\ncases, the ailerons were assumed to cover 50 percent\nof the wing semispan.\nVariations in the floating tendency of the aileron\nwere also considered but were found to havc littlc effect\non the stability. The results given may therefore be\napplied to any of the existing types of balance that\ngive smooth hinge-moment curves?\nThe boundaries for stability in the two possible\nmodes are presented in figure 14. Instability appears\nCertain ailerons 01the Frise type that show a reversal of the hingemoment slope\nm y develop nncontrollable oscillations of fixed amplitude. This condition is dis-\n\ncussed io relerence G\n\nA N ANALYSIS OF THE STABILITY OF A N AIRPLANE WITH FREE CONTROLS\n\nin the form of increasing oscillations and is most liiely\nto occur when the ailerons have a high degree of aerodynamic balance and too great a mass moment or\nmoment of inertia. As the moment of inertia decreases,\nthe boundary for undamped oscillations approaches\nthat for straight divergence (which is itself independent\nof the moment of inertia), and it becomes possible for\nboth types of instability to exist simultaneously. The\ncondition to prevent straight divergence,\n\nis, however, always satisfied when there is damping of\nthe oscillations.\nStraight divergence, as encountered in the eIpvatorfree and the rudder-free conditions, is indicated when\nthe constant term of the stability equation is negative,\nthat is, when\nc , c , Chwcl:ca\nl * h?\n(16)\nThis condition is not likely to occiir unlcss the aerodynamic balance is nearly complete.\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\n\nExperience has shown that, before the actual limit\nof stability is reached, the airplane undergoes oscillations which, although damped, are still persistent\nenough to be undesirable. The boundaries given in\nthe stability charts are therefore of value chiefly as\nindications of the effect of certain design factors; they\ns\nare useful quantitatively only a outside limits, not to\nbe approached too closely. Further experiments will\nbe necessary to determine the margin of stability required for smooth operation in gusty air.\nOn the other hand, the charts are to a certain extent\nconservative because they do not take into account the\npossibility of friction of the control system, a factor\nthat would widen the margin of stability.\nThe indications of the present study may be summarized as follows:\n1. There is a limit to the effectiveness of the aerodynamic balance that may be safely employed with\nany conventional control system. I n most cases, it\nappears difficult to secure stability with the hinge\nmoment reduced to less than 25 percent of its value\nfor the unbalanced surface.\n\n2. Reduction of the floating moment Cbm2 it can\nif\nbe brought about independently of a\naerodynamic balance, causes a shift d the boundary\nfor divergence. (Cf. figs. 3 and 7 and figs. 12 and 13.)\nThe effect is particularly noticeable i &e m e o the\nn\nf\nrudder, where the likelihood of this form of instability\ni materially decreased.\ns\n3. Within the usual range of chambrktics, the\nElevator and the aiIeron controls are\nssuseeptible\nto oscillatory instability than to the rapid\ndivergent instability. The stability with either of\nthese controls free may be improved by (a)using a less\neffective aerodynamic balance, (b) decreasing the mass\nmoment and the moment of inertia of the control, or\n(e) using a control surface of narrow chod.\n4. Divergence is a more likely form of h h b i l i t y for\nided\nthe rudder control (figs. 10 and 11) and\nbalby reducing the effectiveness of the\nance or, as has been suggested, by us\nthat\nreduces the floating tendency of the rudder>although a\nhighly effective balance of a type thah reduces the\nfloating tendency may result in oscillatory instability.\n5. The oscillatory stability qf the elevator-free\nsystem is but little affected by the rest0\nthe airplane in pitch (Cma). the case o the yawing\nIn\nf\nmotions, howcvcr, the existence of a strong restoring\nmoment (Cns)increases the likelihood of oscillatory\n0)\ninstablity. (Sce, for example, fig. 1 .\n6. I n all cases, an increase in the rclatim radius of\ngyration of the airplane resuIts in an increased range of\nstability (cf. figs. 3 and 4; see also fig. IO), but changes\nin weight without corresponding changes in the rotary\ninertia have little effect. (See fig. 5.3\n7. The use of a narrow control surface is recommended as a means of increasing the control-free\nstability as well as from other considerations. The\nmarked effect of reducing the chord is shown by a\ncomparison of figure 8 with figure 3 and of figure 12\nwith figure 10.\n\'\n\nLANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nLABOWTOBY,\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE AERONAUTICS,\nFOB\nLANGLEY\nFIELD, T ~ .August 15, 1940.\nT\n,\n\n231\n\nAPPENDIX\nSTABILITY DERIVATIVES\n\nThe gcomctric and the aerodynamic charactcristics\nused in the stability calculations arc given in tables I\nto IV.\nTABLE1.-GENERAL\n\nAIRPLANE CHARACTERISTICS\n\nT a i l h .................................\n. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 2.75\nWing chord\nHorizontal-tail area . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\n.............................\n.I53\nWing area\nVerticd-tail area. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\n...............................\n.ffi\nWing area\nH o r i z o ? ! d .............................\n............................\n.50\nWing chord\nVertical-tail chord.. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\n.............................\n.333\nWing chord\nAileronchord........................................................\n.....\n.....\n.15\nWing chord\nAileron span . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\n................................\n.50\nWing semispen\nWing aspect ratio . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\n..............................\n6\nHorizontal-tail aspect ratio . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\n.........................\n3.75\nVertical-tail aspect rat,io.. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3.00\n..........................\n\nThe aerodynamic coe5cients are, in most cases,\nbased on experimental results; theoretical values arc\nused only where such results were not established.\nDiscussions of the more commody used derivatives will\nbe found in references 7, 8, and 9. Jones and Doris Cohen\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1941\n\n235\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 722\nG PRESSURE DISTRIBUTION IN\nTWO-~I~ENSIONAL\nFLOW\nBy ROBERT JONES and DORIS\nT.\nCOHEN\nSUMMARY\n\nB y a generalization of the Joukowski method, a procedure i s developed .for effecting localized modijications of\nairfoil shapes and f o r determining graphically the resultant\nchanges i n the pressure disfribution. The application qf\nthe procedure to the determination of the pressure distribution over airfoils of original design i s demonstmted.\nIIorwLulas .for the lift, the moment, and the nerodynawic\ncenter are also given.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nIt is possible, by a simple gcometric construction,\nto modify aiiy given streamline shape in such n way\nthat thc effect of tlic modification on the prcssurr distribution, tlic lift, and tlie moment can be readily\ndeterrnincd. The construction i s cssentially that used\nin deriving the familiar Joukowski airfoils from a circlr\n(reference 1) although i t may be applicd to an airfoil\nshape to introduce modifications of thc outline. Thr\nmethod is based on tho conccpt of complex numhrrs\nbut its application requirrs no familiarity with tlicm.\nBy two or more successivc applications of the construction to a circle, it is possible to derive shapcs of\nsuch diversity as to permit the approximatioil of near17\nany airfoil of current design. For the airfoil derived\nin this way the pressure distribution can be determined\ncxactly, so that thr only error likely to occur is in thc\nrcproduction of the exact airfoil shape. Any inaccuracy\nin this approximation is immccliatcly apparent and can\nbc made as small as is considered tlcsirablr.\n\npoint of the modified airfoil, then, is located by the\nresultant of the vector Oz and its reciprocal vector.\nThe construction by which a figure is modified applies equally well to all its streamlines, altering them\nto conform to the distortion. The change in spacing\nof the streamlines near the boundary of the figure will\nshow directly the effect of the transformation on the\nvelocity in that region because the velocity varies\ninversely with the spacing. The factor by which the\nelements of length near a point z are changed may be\nshown to be the ratio of the length of the diagonal from\n\nFIGURE\n1.-Construction to determine a point on the modifled airfoil.\n\nk2/z to z (the vector z-k2/a) to the vector 02. Then the\nratio of tlie velociey a t a point z+k2/z to the velocity\na t the corresponding point z of the original figure is\nMODIFICATION OF AN AIRFOIL\nthe inverse of this factor.\nThe method consists entirely in applications of a\nThe problem of determining the pressure distribusingle construction; desired effects are obtained by the tion is reduced by Bernoulli\xe2\x80\x99s relation P=Po--pV2/2\nproper choice of a parameter k and of the location pf to that of finding the distribution of the velocity. I\nf\nthe axes with respect to the figure to bc transformed. the velocity distribution over the original figure is\nThis basic construction applicd to an airfoil surface is known, tlic vclocity distribution over the modified\ndemonstrated in figure 1. It is reasonable to suppose,\nof the length of Oz and a t an angle -4 with thex-axis, however, that the actual velocity distribution over the\nwhere 4 is the angle made with this axis by Oz. A modified airfoil may be obtained with good accuracy\n\n2 37\n\nREPORT NO. 722-NATIONAL\n\n,4DVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nfrom a distribution experimentally determined for the\noriginal airfoil, provided that: (1) the experimental and\nthe theoretical distributions do not differ too greatly\nand (2) the modification itself does not introduce too\ngreat a change in the distribution.\nThe requirements of each problem will suggest the\nproper choice of the axes and of k. A few general\nobservations may be helpful in this connection. It is\nevident that the origin must be in the neighborhood of\n\n\\. .y-axis\n\nI\n\nModified airfoil\n\n1 y-axis\n\n(d)\n\n1\n\nOrigmnal airfoil\n\nFLGURX\nZ.-The effect of varying the parameters 01 the construction\n\nthe section to be modified since tbr point nearest tlic\norigin is shifted the greatest distance. The dircctior\nin which a point is shifted depends on the inclination oj\nits vector to the axes, and the shift may have a rclativc4j\n1\nsmall component normal to the airfoil boundary. I\none axis is roughly parallel to the section of the surfact\nto be modified, the point of grcatcst deviation wil\nusually be very near the intersection of the surfacc\nwith the other axis. It will tlicrefore be usrful to notc\nthat the displacement of a point on either axis ir\nP/d, where d is the distance of the origin from the point\nPoints on or near the x-axis are shifted outward fron\nthe origin; points near the y-axis arc moved inward\nThe transformations of figure 2 show the naturc of tht\nmodifications to be obtained by various choices of thc\naxes and of k. Sharp modifications occur when tlic\nairfoil intersects either axis at a distance from tlit\norigin only slightly greater than k.\n\nIt is expected that thc method as outlined w i l l be\niseful in ascertaining the, effect on the velocity distriJution of a localizcd modification of an airfoil. It is\n?ossiblc, however, to approximate a more extensive\nnodification to any desired degree of accuracy b y\n;uccrssivc applications of the same transformation, thc\nvrlocity bcing calculated at each stage by tslie rulr\nilready given.\nAPPROXIMATION OF A GIVEN AIRFOIL\n\nThe foregoing discussion is concerned with tlie\nproblem of cff ccting small modifications of existent air;oils for which the velocity distribution is known. It\nIS sometimes required to predict the theoretical cliarachistics of an airfoil not dcrivcd in this way. I n such\ni\ncase, it is customary to use tlie known flow around a\nirclc as a starting point. If the transformation\n$iscussed licre is applied to 5 circle, the result is an\nmal shape with circular-arc camber, as demonstrated\nby Joukowski. (Scr rrfcrcncc 1 .) It should be possible\nto procrecl to modify t,liis figurc (or its special form, a\nJoukowski airfoil) as was tlonc in tlir prcccding section\nto an cxprrimrntally known airfoil. I n gcncral, liowcver, it woiiM requirc. many stGps to reproduce an\narbitrary airfoil in this way bccausc modifications of\ntlic sliapc alrracty approaching an airfoil would, of\nnccessicy, be small and localizcd. On tlic other hand,\nif tlic procedure were reversed, it would be found that\nariy airfoil may be derivcd by a single step from a\nfigure closely approximating a circle, a figure which\nwill Iirrrinaftcr bc callcd tlic \xe2\x80\x9cdistorted circle\xe2\x80\x9d of the\nairfoil. Tlir distorted circlc may thcn be considerrtl\ntlic result of modifying a cirrlc, a result obtained in\ntlic samc way as were the slightly modified airfoils of\ntlic prccrding section.\nFor t,lic first step in this proccse, thc clc+rminatiori\nof the tlistortrd circlr corresponding to tlie desirrd\nairfoil, rcfercnrc could br niadc to Theodorscn antl\nG:irri.ck (rrfcrcwx ?) or von KBinih and Rurgrrs\n(rrfrrcncc 3), who givr exact formulas for tlie distortctl\ncircle ill tcrms of tlir airfoil coordirmkrs. A graphical\nmrtliod bascd on thc simplcr transforniation that is\nbring usrd in this psprr niakes it possible, lion cver, to\nobtain the tlistortrd circlr mercly by trial.\nTlic entire prorrtlurr is illustrated st.cp by step 111\nfigiirc 3. The const.ruction\nare\nthen proceeds as follows:\nI n order to serve as a first approximation of the\ndistorted circle, a circle is drawn to fit thc four intersections with the axes as closely as possiblo. It should\nbe remembered that, because this step is a first approximation, great accuracy is not a consideration. W i e n\nthe vectors z follow this circle, the vectors k2/z, constructed as previously described, are found to terminate\nin a smaller circle, which is termed for convenience the\n\xe2\x80\x9creciprocal\xe2\x80\x9d circle. This reciprocal circle may be easily\nlocated from its intersections with the axes (fig. 3 (c)).\nk2\nVectors Oz and 0- are then dralin from the origin\nZ\n\nto t.he circle and to the reciprocal circle at equal angles\nbelow and above the x-axis (fig. 3(d)). The midpoint\nz,\xe2\x80\x99 of t,he diagonal z-k2!z connrcting the ends of thew\nvectors will not, in general, fall exactly on thc airfoil.\nA point of the distorted circle zb is located by adjusting\nwith dividers the lrngth of Oz, along Oz so that thc\ndiagonal to its reciprocal is bisected by the airfoil.\nThe point of the airfoil z, n t which this bisection occurs\nwill actually be indistinguishable from tlie intersection\nof tlie first diagonal uith the airfoil: this fact is useful\nin making the correction. Because tlic corrections to\nk2\nthe vectors Oz and 0- are in approximately the samct\n2\n\nratio as the vectors. the decrcwe in K\xe2\x80\x99/z that corresponds to an increase in the length of Oz may be rstimated and the reciprocal relation bc maintained by\neye. Any desired degree of accuracy niny be obtniiietl\nby checking numerically the lcrigtlis of thc vcvtors.\nThe distorted circle obtained in this way must now\nbe approximated by applying a transformation of tlir\nform z+k2/z to the circlc most ncarly approximating it.\nFor this purpose the circlc already drawn for the prcccding step will usually bc satisfactory, although it\nmay have to be shifted slightly to obtain a more convenient distribution of the distortion. Depressions\nshould occur as nearly as possible on opposite sides of\n&he circle, with distended portions between them.\n(See fig. 3(e).) The x-axis should then be passed\nthrough the distended portions and the y-axis, through\nthe depressions. Some adjustment will be nccclcd to\nsatisfy the condition that the segments of the axes c u t\noff by the eirclc and the rorresponding distortions bc\napproximately in inverse proportion, that is, that their\nproduct at, racli intersection bc constant. The parameter k for the transformation is then the square root\nof this product.\nCarrying out tho transformation of tlie circle a t\nthis point serves a t onee to check thc cstimntcd parameters or to suggtbst an adjustment and to provide thc\nconstruction lines that will be needed to determine thc\nvelocity distribution. Similarly, thc distorted circle\nthus obtained from tlic circlc should bc reduced to tlie\ndesired airfoil.\nIn figure 3(f) thc complctc double transformation\nand the lincs neccssary for the computation of the vcloc-\n\n2 40\n\nity distribution are aiown applied to L poiiit of thc\ncircle of figure 3(e).\nOccasionally an airfoil will give fisc to a distorted\ncirclc that cannot be obtaincd by a singlc modification\nof a circle. I n such a casc an additional transformtition may bc applied either to acliicvc tlic dcsircrL\ndistortion of thc circlc or to modify locally an airfoil\nthat can be derived by two transformations.\nVELOCITY DISTRIBUTION OVER AN AIRFOIL DERIVED\nFROM A CIRCLE\n\nIt is apparent that a large variety of uscful airfoil\nshapes can bc obtaincd by two or more successive applications to a circle of the transformation z+k2/z.\n(Two typical examples are shown in fig. 4.) Tho first\ntransformation primarily determines the gcneral outline\nof tlic airfoil. The second transformation reduces the\nfigure to the dimensions of an airfoil and clctermincs\ntho nose radius, the thickness, and the camber. It\nmay be of interest to note that in the first transformation k is small relative to the radius of the circle; in\nthe second transformation thc ratio of k to the radius\nof thc circle is only slightly less \xe2\x80\x98than 1.\nThe mctliod of finding the velocity a t a point on an\nairfoil derived in this manner is deduced from the\nfollowing considerations:\nThe velocity n t a point z on the circlv i s givcii by\nthe formula\nVz=2V, sin\n\nr\ne+- 2n-r\n\nwliere r is the radius of tlic circlc, ,\xe2\x80\x99\\ is tlic wind vcLlocity, and e is tlic angle that t,hc radius to tlir point z\nmakes with the tlirvctiori of thc air strcam. Ttic cirrulation r is detcrmincd by the K u t h condition. Jones\nNational Advisory Committee for Aeronautics\n\nNovember 1941\n\n245\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nTheoretical Correction for the Lift\nof Elliptic\nROBERT T. JONESt\nNational Advisory Committeefor Aeronautics\nsection theory the magnitude of the\ncirculation, and hence of the lift, is determined by\nthe velocity that would be induced near the trailing\nedge of the section in a non-lifting potential flow. In\nthree-dimensional flow the problem is complicated by\nthe presence of the wake and no simple basic solution\nhas been found. Treatment of the problem of a wing of\nfinite span has therefore been on the basis of the twodimensional theory, corrected for the effect of the\nwake.*\nThe correction commonly applied is that introduced\nby Prandtl and known as the lifting-line theory. The\ndownflow induced by the wake is considered, in this\ntheory, to reduce the relative normal velocity and hence\nthe edge velocity of the wing. It is assumed, however,\nthat once the true angle of attack is determined for any\nsection of the wing its effect in producing circulationand\nlit is the same as in two-dimensional flow. This assumption is expressed by the equation\n\nI\n\nN THE WING\n\nc, = 2r(a - aj)\n\nIf the velocity distributions of the circulatory flow\nare also assumed to be similar to those given by the\nwing-section theory, the circulation required to satisfy\nthe Kutta condition at each section should be reduced\nby the same factor. The corrected formula for the\nlift is then\n\nc\n,\n\n= (27r/E)(a -\n\ncyi)\n\n(21\n\nThis correction may be given a physical interpretation by considering that a finite wing offers a longer\nedge around which the air may escape (see Fig. l),\n\nFIG. Correction factor E for the &e& of the\n1.\nperimeter ratio on the lift: CL = (Zr/E)(a - e<)-\n\n(1)\n\nwhere 2 r is the slope o the lift curve for the thin wing\n7\nf\nof infinite aspect ratio, LY is the angle of attack of the\nsection, and ai is the induced angle o downflow.\nf\nEq. (1) takes into account the effect of the wake in\ndiminishing the relative normal velocity of the wing. A\nfurther correction is indicated by the fact, established in\nhydrodynamic theory, that the surface velocities induced by a given relative motion of a body in-threedimensional flow are generally smaller than those in\ntwo. For example, the maximum, or \xe2\x80\x9cedge\xe2\x80\x9d velocity\naround an infinite cylinder is 1, while that around a\nsphere of the same cross-section is \xe2\x80\x99/2. Similarly, if the\nvelocity around the edge of an endless thin plate is\ntaken as unity, the corresponding velocity around the\nedge of a circular disc is found to be 2/7r, or 0.637.\nIn the case of an elliptic disc the velocity at every\npoint is reduced by the factor 1/E, where E is the ratio\nof the semiperimeter of the ellipse to the span. (See\nappendix.) Further investigation shows that the\nchordwise cross-sections of the non-lifting potential\nflow are similar all along the span o the elliptic plate\nf\nand are the same as those obtained from the wing-section theory except for this constant reduction factor.\nReceived July 31, 1941.\nt Assistant Aeronautical Engineer.\n* More recently the problem has been treated on the basis of\nthe acceleration potential, which vanishes i the wake.\xe2\x80\x99 The\nn\nmethod is still one of considerable a c u l t y , however.\n\nand that the air velocities are therefore less in the proportion that the length of the edge is greater. The rule\nis not exact for plan forms other than the elliptical.\nSince the velocity of the non-lifting potential flow\nis constant all around the edge of the elliptic plate, the\ncirculation required will be proportional to the chord at\neach section. The circulation is thus elliptically distributed spanwise. Such a distribution, with the chordwise distribution assumed earlier, leads, as in the liftingline theory, to the relation\nL Y ~=\n\nCJTA\n\n(3)\n\nwhere A is the aspect ratio.\nq\nSubstitution of this value into E . (2) gives\n\nC,\n\n=\n\nBnorA/[EA\n\n+ 2)\n\n(4)\n\nSince the chordwise distribution of the circulation in\nthree-dimensional flow is assumed similar to that in\ntwo, and since the similarity is only proved for the noncirculatory flow, Eq. (4) must be considered a correction of the wing-section theory rather than a solution\nof the three-dimensional problem. The assumption of\nsimilarity, although its validity is subject to somewhat\nthe same limitations in general, appears to be a more\njustifiable one than the assumption of equality made\nin the lifting-line theory.\nThe problem of three-dimensionalflow around a lifting elliptical plate has been treated by Krienes2 using\n\n247\n\nL I F T O F ELLIPTIC W I N G S\n\nW\n\n7\n\n8\n\n6\nA\n\n3\n\n2\n\n\'\n0\n\nI\n\n2\n\n3\n4\n5\n6\nASKl RmO. A\n\n7\n\n8\n\n9\n\n10\n\nFIG.2. Theoretical variations of lift-curve slope with\naspect ratio.\n\nPrandtl\'s concept of the acceleration potential. The\ncalculations involve the superposition of a series of\nsolutions of Az4 = 0 in ellipsoidal coordinates (Lam6\nfunctions), the coefficients of the series being obtained\nfrom simultaneous equations. Although the overall\nlift depends on only one coefficient, calculations of the\nspan loading and the drag would require all the terms\nof the infinite series and was therefore not considered\npracticable.\nThe lift coefficients obtained by Krienes\' method are\nshown in Fig. 2. Results obtained by correcting the\nwing-section theory in accordance with Eq. (4) are\ncompared with Krienes\', and the agreement is seen to be\ngood for ordinary aspect ratios.\nA m e derived from Blenk\'s calculationof the vortex\ndistribution in a rectangular plate3 also agrees closely\nwith Eq. (4).\nIt is found that the additional correction to the wingsection theory accounts for an appreciable fraction of\nthe loss in lift that is usually attributed to viscosity. It\nhas been difficult to reconcile the magnitude of the inefficiency with the observed dimensions of the wake,\nwhich in the case of smooth wings, is extremely narrow\na t the trailing edge. The foregoing correction accounts\naf\nfor as much as h l of this discrepancy in cases of wings\nwith sharp trailing edges. (See Fig. 3.)\nAccording to Munk\'s theorem, the induced drag is\nnot affected by a displacement of the lifting elements\nin the direction of the chord; hence the relation between the lift and the induced drag may be derived on\nthe basis of the lifting-line theory. Also, since the pitching moment of the elliptic wing involves the same correction as the lift, no change of aerodynamic center\nlocation with aspect ratio is indicated.\nThe three-dimensional potential flow around the\nelliptic disc may be used also as the basis for calculating\nthe lift of an elliptic wing with varying angle of attack.\nOn account of the linearity of the equations, the general problem may be reduced to a determination of the\ngrowth of lift following a sudden start of the motion with\nthe fight velocity V and the normal velocity w = Va.*\n\n4\n\ni23\nCONMNTION41WING\nW N G WITH SHPRD ll&UNG EDGE\nW WITH BLUNT W H G E E\nG\nK\noRLlPTlCAl CWNDER\n\n0\n1\n0\nt 2O\nTHICKNSS R W , r\n\n0\n\nFIG. Experimental and theoretical lift-curve slopes.\n3.\nAspect ratiq. 6.\n\nSince the steady or asymptotic value of the lift is\nalready known, the most important point is the determination of the lift near the start of the motion.\nAs a consequence of the Kutta condition, the layer of\nair leaving the wing at the trailing edge must satisfy\nthe same boundary condition as the adjacent wing surface for a short distance downstream. Thus the layer\nof air in contact with the wing retains the motion imparted by the wing and for a short distance after the\nstart this layer (the vortex wake) behaves as an impermeable extension of the wing surface.\' The flow a t\nthe first instant after, the start is thus what might be\ncaused by the wing in process of growing wider a t the\nrate V while moving with the normal velocity w. The\nstarting lift L,,o may then be thought of as the reaction to uniform motion of the wing acting as a body with\nincreasing mass:\n\nL,,,\n\n=w\n\n(dm\'ldt) = w (dm\'/dc)V\n\n(5)\n\nwhere m is the mass representing the aerodynamic\n\'\ninertia of the flow and G is the apparent length of the\nchord. Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nDecember 1941\n\n251\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nNATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nTECHNICAL NOTE NO. 837\nNOTES ON THF, STABILITY AND CONTROL\nOF TAILLESS AIRPLANES\n\nB Robert T. Jones\ny\n\nSUMMARY\n\nProblems involved i n t h e s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l of\nt a i l l e s s a i r p l a n e s are discussed. Such f a c t o r s as t h e loc a t i o n of t h e aerodynamic center and i t s e f f e c t on t h e\nl o n g i t u d i n a l s t a b i l i t y , l o n g i t u d i n a l trim with h i g h - l i f t\ndevices, t h e e f f e c t s of various changes i n t h e shape of {the\nwing on lateral s t a b i l i t y , and t h e e f f e c t s of nacelles are\ncovered.\nIt appears t h a t s u f f i c i e n t s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l l a b i l i t y can be secured without sweepback. With sweepback, a\nf l a p over t h e center s e c t i o n of t h e wing may be used t o\nserve t h e d u a l purpose of e l e v a t o r control and h i g h - l i f t\ndevice. Sweepback introduces undesirable s t a l l i n g charact e r i s t i c s , however, and may r e q u i r e a u x i l i a r y devices t o\nprevent s t a l l i n g of t h e t i p s .\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe advantage i n arrangement and performance t h a t t h e\nt a i l l e s s a i r p l a n e has over t h e conventional type has already been t h e s u b j e c t of considerable discussion. The\npresent paper is c h i e f l y concerned with aerodynamic fact o r s as they a f f e c t t h e s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l of tailless\nairplanes.\nWith t h e aerodynamic information a v a i l a b l e a t p r e s e n t , t h e designer should be a b l e t o p r e d i c t with confidence t h e behavior of an a i r p l a n e t h a t resembles i n design\na reasonably conventional wing. There i s s t i l l , however,\na l a c k of information on t h e loading of wings with l a r g e\nangles of sweepback and on t h e loading of wings of very\nlow aspect r a t i o .\n\n253\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 837\nSYMBOLS\naspect ratio\nangle of attack\nwing span\nangle of sideslip\nwing chord\nCL\n\n=\n\nLift\n\ns\n\nlift coefficient\n\n-uo2\nP\n\nw 2\n\ncz\n\n=\n\ncm=\ncn\n\n=\n\ncy =\n\nD\n\nL\nSw 2 Uo2 b\nP\n\nM\n\n% $ uo2\n\nsw\n\n= -\n\nds\n\n254\n\npitching-moment coefficient\nc\n\nN\nSw P Uo2 b\nY\n\n2\n\nrolling-moment coefficient\n\nyawing-moment coefficient\n\nside-force coefficient\nuo2\n\nderivative with respect to distance\nalong flight path\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 837\n\n6\n\ne l e v a t o r o r rudder d e f l e c t i o n\n\n5, kz\n$,\n\nr a d i i of gyration about axis\nindicated by s u b s c r i p t\nlength of fuselage\nm a s s of a i r p l a n e\nangular v e l o c i t y i n r o l l i n g\nangular v e l o c i t y i n pitching\nangular v e l o c i t y i n yawing\n\ns = - UOt\nC\n\nd i s t a n c e along f l i g h t path\na i r p l a n e axes\n\nZ\nLONGITUDINAL STABILITY AND CONTROL\n\nAn ordinary wing with a s l i g h t r e f l e x camber and dihed r a l has a l l t h e aerodynamic c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s necessary\nf o r both lateral and l o n g i t u d i n a l s t a b i l i t y . A s i n t h e\nconventional a i r p l a n e , l o n g i t u d i n a l s t a b i l i t y i n g l i d i n g\nf l i g h t i s p r a c t i c a l l y assured i f t h e c e n t e r o f , g r a v i t y i s\nlocated s l i g h t l y ahead of t h e aerodynamic c e n t e r of t h e\n)\nFor wings of normal aspect r a t i o and diwing ( f i g . 1.\nmensions t h e aerodynamic center is located a t about 2 4\npercent of t h e mean chord. A t very low aspect r a t i o s t h e\naerodynamic c e n t e r moves ahead and upward, and t h e a t t a i n ment of s t a b i l i t y and balance becomes more d i f f i c u l t . The\nl o c a t i o n i s a l s o appreciably changed by t h e addition of a\nstreamline n a c e l l e o r by sweepback. Changes i n wing sect i o n generally have only a s l i g h t e f f e c t . An e x t r e m e reduction i n thickness toward t h e t r a i l i n g edge may cause a\nbackward displacement of 2 o r 3 percent. Conversely, i t\ni s possible t o produce a forward s h i f t of t h e s a m e amount\nby abnormal thickening of t h e rear portion.\nThe a d d i t i o n of a streamline fuselage o r n a c e l l e\ncauses a forward s h i f t of t h e aerodynamic c e n t e r , thus nec e s s i t a t i n g a more forward l o c a t i o n of t h e c e n t e r of grav-\n\n255\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 837\ni t y . According t o c a l c u l a t i o n s made by\nKIissner (reference 3 ) , a s t r a i g h t wing moving i n t o an increasing gust w i l l experience no pitching moment whatever about t h e quarter-chord l i n e . Figure 15 shows c a l c u l a t e d\n\n.\n\n26 1\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 837\n\nrates of damping of t h e f r e e lateral o s c i l l a t i o n s f o r typi c a l v a l u e s of t h e s t a b i l i t y d e r i v a t i v e s . The v a l u e of\nused corresponds t o a d i h e d r a l a n g l e of approximately\nCzB\n2". An i n d i c a t i o n of t h e v a r i a t i o n of lateral s t a b i l i t y\nwith C\nand C z\na t low v a l u e s of C\nmay b e obn3\n#\nB\nnr\nt a i n e d from t h e c h a r t s given i n r e f e r e n c e 7.\nI f sweepback i s employed, t h e f a c t should be borne i n\nmind t h a t a pronounced r o l l i n g o r p i t c h i n g i n s t a b i l i t y may\ndevelop a t high a n g l e s of a t t a c k because of premature t i p\ns t a l l i n g a s s o c i a t e d w i t h a lateral flow of t h e boundary\nl a y e r . The e f f e c t of sweep is t o i n t r o d u c e a component of\nt h e r e l a t i v e l y g r e a t chordwise p r e s s u r e g r a d i e n t i n t o a\nd i r e c t i o n a t r i g h t a n g l e s t o t h e main stream v e l o c i t y over\nt h e wing. The v i s c o u s drag of t h e stream t h e n cannot act\nt o prevent flow of t h e boundary l a y e r l a t e r a l l y i n t o regions of lower p r e s s u r e over t h e forward p o r t i o n s of adj a c e n t wing s e c t i o n s . The r e s u l t is t h a t t h e boundary\nl a y e r flows toward t h e t i p s of a swept-back wing and premat u r e s e p a r a t i o n occurs. F i g u r e 16, p l o t t e d from d a t a given\ni n r e f e r e n c e 8, shows t h i s e f f e c t on s e c t i o n s near t h e t i p s\nof two r e c t a n g u l a r wings with sweep. The e x i s t e n c e of t h i s\ne f f e c t may a l s o b e i n f e r r e d from t h e tests of r e f e r e n c e 9,\ni n which t h e swept-back wings tended t o nose up when\ns t a l l e d . (See f i g . 17.) With 30" sweepback t h i s tendency\np e r s i s t e d even when t h e wing w a s given 8.5" washout. L i t t l e\ni s know about t h e v a r i a t i o n w i t h angle of sweep, although\nt h e t e s t s of r e f e r e n c e 9 showed a n a p p r e c i a b l e e f f e c t a t\nan a n g l e of 15". From t h e s e i n d i c a t i o n s , i t would s e e m adv i s a b l e t o i n c o r p o r a t e some a u x i l i a r y boundary-layer cont r o l d e v i c e , such as leading-edge s l o t s , i n t h e d e s i g n of\na t a i l l e s s a i r p l a n e having c o n s i d e r a b l e sweepback.\n\nCONCLUSIONS\n\n1. With c a r e f u l d e s i g n i t should be p o s s i b l e t o sec u r e s a t i s f a c t o r y s t a b i l i t y and c o n t r o l i n a t a i l l e s s airplane. The small r o t a t i o n a l damping h a r d l y a f f e c t s t h e\nshort-period l o n g i t u d i n a l o s c i l l a t i o n s , although t h e dampi n g of t h e s t a b l e l a t e r a l o s c i l l a t i o n i s l i k e l y t o b e reduced somewhat, p a r t i c u l a r l y at high speeds.\n2. Although t h e damping i n p i t c h i n g h a s a s m a l l e f f e c t on t h e s t a b i l i t y w i t h normal center-of-gravity locat i o n s , t h e t a i l l e s s a i r p l a n e i s i n g r e a t e r danger of in-\n\n26 2\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 837\n\ns t a b i l i t y due t o an abnormal backward s h i f t of t h e c e n t e r\nof g r a v i t y because t h i s i n s t a b i l i t y becomes more s e r i o u s\nas t h e damping i s reduced.\n\n3 . A s t h e weathercock s t a b i l i t y o r t h e damping i n\nyawing i s reduced by e l i m i n a t i o n of t h e t a i l s u r f a c e s , i t\nbecomes more important t o overcome t h e a i l e r o n yaw and\nt h e yaw due t o r o l l i n g .\n\n4. A considerable reduction of t h e disturbances produced by vertical g u s t s i s p o s s i b l e i n t h e case of a t a i l less a i r p l a n e without sweepback. This e f f e c t , which i s\ndue t o a favorable p i t c h i n g motion, depends on t h e s t a t i c\ns t a b i l i t y and t h e moment of i n e r t i a of t h e a i r p l a n e .\n5. The use of sweepback makes i t p o s s i b l e t o employ\na partial-span f l a p as a h i g h - l i f t device. It a l s o simp l i f i e s t h e problem of securing weathercock s t a b i l i t y And\ndamping i n yawing. Wind-tunnel tests of wings with sweepback show, however, t h a t it i s necessary t o guard a g a i n s t\na pronounced r o l l i n g and p i t c h i n g i n s t a b i l i t y near t h e\nstall.\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory,\nNational Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics,\nLangley F i e l d , VA., October 2 , 1941.\n\n26 3\n\nNACA Technical Note No. 837\nREFERENCES\n1.\n\nJacobs, Eastman N., and Ward, Kenneth E: Interference\n.\nof Wing and Fuselage from Tests of 209 Combinations\nin the N.A.C.A. s h a v e b e e n made t o i n v e s t i g a t e t h e\np o s s i b i l i t y o f r e d u c i n g t h e h i n g e moments o f a c o n t r o l\ns u r f a c e by b e v e l i n g t h e t r a i l i n g edge.\nT h e t e s t s w e r e made\nwith a 9-percent-thick a i r f o i l having a 30-percent-chord\nA f a i r e d b e v e l e d shape, 5 p e r c e n t of t h e a i r plain flap.\nf o i l c h o r d i h e h i n g e moment c a u s e d b y a g i v l e n\nd e f l e c t i o n of t h e f l a p and 8 0 - p e r c e n t r e d u c t i o n i n t h e\nh i n g e moment d u e t o t h e a n g l e o f a t t a c k o f t h i s a i r f o i l\nA b l u n t e r b e v e l e d p o r t i o n of\nf o r a wide r a n g e of a n g l e s .\nt h e s a m e t h i c k n e s s g a v e o v e r b a l a n c e and r e v e r s a l of t h e\nElliptical\nf l o a t i n g tendency over a s m a l l angular range.\nt r a i l i n g - e d g e shapes w e r e a l s o t r i e d b u t w e r e found t o be\nsomewhat l e s s e f f e c t i v e t h a n t h e s h a p e s e n d i n g i n a n a c u t e\nangle.\nA s e m i c i r c u l a r t r a i l i n g edge produced only a s l i g h t\nc h a n g e i n t h e h i n g e moments b u t c a u s e d a d r a g i n c r e m e n t much\ng r e a t e r t h a n t h a t of a n e f f i c i e n t beveled shape.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nT h e h i n g e moments o b t a i n e d i n t e s t s o f a i r f o i l s w i t h\np l a i n f l a p s have o f t e n been observed t o f a l l c o n s i d e r a b l y\nb e l o w t h e v a l u e s p r e d i c t e d by t h e p o t e n t i a l - f l o w t h e o r y .\nIt\nh a s a l s o b e e n n o t e d t h a t t h e h i n g e moments o b t a i n e d i n\nd i f f e r e n t t e s t s show w i d e r d i s c r e p a n c i e s t h a n d o o t h e r a i r f o i l characteristics.\nS e v e r a l y e a r s a g o t h e NACA h a d o c c a s i o n t o t e s t a f l a p\nI n t h i s case\nw i t h a p a r t i c u l a r l y t h i n , s h a r p t r a i l i n g edge.\nt h e h i n g e moments w e r e h i g h e r t h a n u s u a l a n d a g r e e d b e t t e r\nwith the theory.\nThus, i t appeared t h a t t h e d i s c r e p a n c i e s\ni n t h e h i n g e moments o b t a i n e d i o n c o n c e r n i n g t h e\nn a t u r e of t h e f l o w n e a r t h e t r a i l i n g edge and t h e e f f e c t\nof s m a l l d e p a r t u r e s from t h e K u t t a c o n d i t i o n .\nI n t h e i d e a l flow, the Kutta condition requires t h a t\nt h e a i r leaving t h e t r a i l i n g edge maintain t h e d i r e c t i o n of\nThe\nt h e mean c a m b e r f o r a s h o r t d i s t a n c e d o w n s t r e a m .\nv e l o c i t i e s on t h e upper and lower s u r f a c e s approach t h e\nsame v a l u e w i t h t h e r e s u l t t h a t t h e p r e s s u r e d i f f e r e n c e o r\nT h e c u r v e m a r k e d "a"\nl i f t v a n i s h e s a t t h e t r a i l i n g edge.\ni n f i g u r e 1 shows t h e l i f t d i s t r i b u t i o n o v e r a n a i r f o i l\ns e c t i o n w i t h t h e flow conforming p e r f e c t l y t o t h i s c o n d i t i o n .\nThe g u i d i n g a c t i o n of a s l i g h t l y b l u n t o r b e v e l e d t r a i l i n g\nedge w i l l n o t b e p e r f e c t , however, and i n s u c h a case a rel a t i v e l y g r e a t negative l i f t w i l l be developed across t h e\ne d g e , a s shown b y c u r v e "b" i n f i g u r e 1 . A d e l i b e r a t e\nt h i c k e n i n g of t h e a i r f o i l , d e s i g n e d t o p e r m i t f u r t h e r\nd e v i a t i o n from t h e K u t t a c o n d i t i o n , might t h e r e f o r e l e a d t o\nt h e t y p e o f p r e s s u r e d i s t r i b u t i o n r e p r e s e n t e d b y c u r v e "b"\ni n f i g u r e 1. I t w a s t h o u g h t t h a t t h e e f f e c t m i g h t b e u s e d\nt o p r o v i d e aerodynamic b a l a n c e f o r a c o n t r o l s u r f a c e and\ni n o r d e r t o t e s t t h i s t h e o r y a s e r i e s of w i n d - t u n n e l e x p e r T h e s e t e s t s h a v e r e c e n t l y b e e n made\niments w a s planned.\nand form t h e s u b j e c t of t h e p r e s e n t p a p e r .\nTESTS\nA p p a r a t u s and Models\nI n f i g u r e 2 a r e shown t h e s h a p e s t e s t e d .\nThese shapes\na r e o f two t y p e s - b e v e l e d a n d e l l i p t i c a l .\nI n t h e c a s e of\nt h e b e v e l e d f l a p , t h e p o i n t a t which t h e b e v e l i n g of t h e\nf l a p began w a s f a i r e d i n t o a n a r c i n o r d e r t o a l l o w smooth\nflow.\nThe p o r t i o n o f t h e f l a p e x t e n d i n g f r o m t h e c e n t e r\nof t h i s a r c t o t h e t r a i l i n g e d g e w i l l b e r e f e r r e d t o h e r e Because t h e a c t i o n of t h e b l u n t\ni n a f t e r as t h e "bevel."\nt r a i l i n g e d g e i s i n some w a y s s i m i l a r t o t h a t o f a n a u t o m a t i c b a l a n c i n g t a b (see f i g . 3 ) , t h e b e v e l e d s h a p e s w e r e\nd e s i g n e d t o a p p r o x i m a t e t h e o u t l i n e of s u c h t a b s i n t h e\nbalancing position.\nThe 2 0 - p e r c e n t b e v e l c o r r e s p o n d s t o a\n20-percent\ncf\ntab deflected\nloo. T h e e l l i p t i c a l s h a p e s\na r e of somewhat s i m i l a r p r o p o r t i o n s .\nA f l a p having a bulged\nportion near the hinge was also tried.\nWith t h e e x c e p t i o n\no f t h e b u l g e d f l a p , a l l s h a p e s t e s t e d w e r e o b t a i n e d by i n t e r c h a n g i n g t r a i l i n g - e d g e b l o c k s h a v i n g t h e s e s h a p e s on a\ns t a n d a r d 2 - f o o t - c h o r d by 4 - f o o t - s p a n m o d e l of l a m i n a t e d\nmahogany.\n\n284\n\nT a b l e I g i v e s t h e o r d i n a t e s of t h e s t a n d a r d s e c t i o n\n( d e r i v e d f r o m t h e NACA 0009 a i r f o i l b y d r a w i n g s t r a i g h t\nl i n e s from t h e 55-percent s t a t i o n back t o t h e removable\nt a i l block).\nThe d i m e n s i o n s of t h e r e m o v a b l e t a i l p o r t i o n s\na r e shown i n f i g u r e 2 a n d t h e o r d i n a t e s o f t h e b u l g e d f l a p\na r e g i v e n i n t a b l e 11. A s shown i n f i g u r e 2 , t h e f l a p w a s\nof the p l a i n u n b a l a n c e d t y p e , 30 p e r c e n t o f t h e a i r f o i l c h o r d\ni n width.\nT h e t e s t s w e r e made w i t h t h e g a p b o t h s e a l e d a n d\nopen.\nThe p r o c e d u r e o f t h e t e s t s w a s s i m i l a r t o t h a t f o l l o w e d\ni n r e f e r e n c e 1. T h e y were made i n t h e NACA 4 - f o o t b y 6 - f o o t\nv e r t i c a l t u n n e l , modified as d e s c r i b e d i n r e f e r e n c e 2.\nThe\nl i f t , t h e d r a g , a n d t h e p i t c h i n g moments w e r e m e a s u r e d o n\na three-component balance,\nT h e h i n g e moments w e r e m e a s u r e d\ne l e c t r i c a l l y with a calibrated torque rod b u i l t i n t o t h e\nmodel.\nThe model e x t e n d e d c o m p l e t e l y a c r o s s t h e c l o s e d\nt e s t s e c t i o n of t h e t u n n e l , s o t h a t t h e f l o w w a s v e r y n e a r l y\ntwo-dimensional.\nT h e t e s t s were made a t a d y n a m i c p r e s s u r e\no f 15 p o u n d s p e r s q u a r e f o a t , c o r r e s p o n d i n g t o a v e l o c i t y\no f a b o u t 7 6 m i l e s p e r h o u r a n d a t e s t R e y n o l d s number o f\n1,430,000.\nThe f l a p d e f l e c t i o n w a s v a r i e d i n 50 i n c r e m e n t s\n300. I n some c a s e s c h e c k p o i n t s a t + 2 0 f r o m\nf r o m 00 t o\nL i f t , d r a g , a i r f o i l p i t c h i n g moment ,\nneutral w e r e obtained.\na n d f l a p h i n g e moments w e r Jones and Doris Cohen\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1942\n\n307\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nEPORT No. 73\n\nBy ROBERT . JONES and DORIS\nT\nCOHEN\n\n-\n\n-\n\nSUMMARY\n\ndeflection of the surface. This is a problem in the\ncalculus of variations, in which the expression for the\neffectiveness is the integral to be kept constant; the\nexpression for the hinge moment is the integral to be\nminimized; and the hinge line, defined by a relation\nbetween the spanwise station and the ratlio of flap\nchord to airfoil chord, may be considered the path of\nintegration to be determined so as to satisfy the foregoing conditions. I n the case of a rudder or an elevator,\nthe effectiveness is measured by the change of lift on\nthe tail surface produced by deflection,of the flap; in\nthe case of ailerons, it is measured by \'the rolling moment produced.\nIt will be seen in the course of the discussion that\nall constant factors may be combined in the final result\nINTRODUCTION\ninto a single factor of proportionality. All the funcOne of the primary difficulties in airplane design has tions and relations discussed hereinafter d l therefore\nbeen to keep the stick forces required to deflect the be treated without regard to such factors.\nThe following symbols will be used in the developcontrol surfaces at reasonably low values. This problem has inevitably increased in seriousness with the ment:\nspan of airfoil\nsize and the speed of modern airplanes. There is as b\nspanwise station measured from plane of\nyet, however, no basic principle of control-surface Y\nsymmetry\ndesign that engineers will agree minimizes the ratio of bl2\nstick force to effectiveness. Examination of typical O=eos-Ix parameter indicating spanwise station\ndesigns indicates that hinge-moment reductions as\nbI2\nlift per unit span at any section due to unit\ngreat as 40 percent may be achieved in some cases A h\nflaD deflection\nwithout lowering the effectiveness of the flap; that is,\nchange in effective angle of attack a t any\nthe efficiency may be increased by two-thirds.\nsection due to unit flap deflection\nThe present study, which neglects structural and\nsection l i t coefficient\nsimilar considerations, is a mathematical analysis leadchord of airfoil\ning to the plan forms for rudder, elevator, and ailerons\nchord of flap\nthat will be most effective in producing a given amount\nratio of flap chord to airfoil chord (c,/c)\nof control with the least operating force. The solutions\nchord of airfoil at plane of symmetry\nare applicable to any airfoil of conventional plan form\nangle of flap deflection\nto the same extent as are the usual assumptions of the\nsection lift-curve slope\naerodynamic theory of airfoils, on which the analysis\naspect-ratio pammeter\nis based. Further discussion covers the extent, the\nhinge moment\nlocation, and the shape of partial-span control surfaces\nFourier series coefficients\nto give the greatest efficiency.\nFourier series coefficient proportional to lift\nTHEORETICAL ANALYSIS\nFourier series coefficient proportional to\nIt is required to find the plan forms for rudder,\nmoment\nelevator, and ailerons that will require the least stick\nconstants determined by C\'s and p\nforce to produce a k e d amount of control per unit\narbitrary proportionality factor\n\nA theoretical analysis i s made to determine the optimum\nchord distribution, location, and extent o control surfaces,\nf\nwith the ratio o hinge moment to effectiveness as the crif\nterion. This empirical curve is closely approximated, for flaps up to 70-percent chord, by the equation\n\nThe expressions for the lift and the rolling moment\nobtained by this method take into account the important effect of the aerodynamic induction associated\nwith airfoils of finite span. In the expression for the\nhinge moment, this factor will be neglected; that is,\nthe end loss in aerodynamic loading and a variation,\n\nDETERMINATION OF OPTIMUM PLAN FORMS FOR CONTROL SURFACES\n\ncaused by the floating tendency of the flap, in the hinge\nmoment developed by the induced downwash will be\nomitted. Both of these effects are small for narrowchord flaps. Without these effects the hinge moment\nis simply proportional to the square of the flap chord\na t each section. The resulting\nchord distributions, plotted about a straight 50-percent\nchord line, are shown in figure 2.\nThe solutions were found to be strikingly independent\nof the form of the airfoil. In figure 3, the shapes for\nthe movable surfaces are shown for the three airfoils\njust described. The optimum ailerons are seen to vary\nhardly a t all from airfoil to airfoil. The outlines for\nmaximum lift efficiency, although differing slightly,\n\n311\n\nREPORT NO. 731-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nnevertheless suggest the general conclusion that the\nmost desirable control surfaces in this respect are of\nnearly constant chord.\nFrom this result it follows that the most efficient\nairfoil plan form for longitudinal control is also one of\nnearly constant chord, because such a combination of\nairfoil and flap will have a nearly uniform distribution\nBlunt\n\nHinge\nline\n\ne\n\nin any case, to hold rigidly to the optimum shape a t\nthe extreme tip if such a design introduces a cusp in\nthe k e d portion of the surface.\nThe corresponding presentation of the solution for\nthe ailerons is given in figure 5. The ailerons shown\nwe approximately 15 percent of the mean chord of the\n&foil. Seen in this aspect ratio, the ailerons appear\nnot to vary greatly in width over their span. As is to\nbe expected, however, they do taper off somewhat\nGoward the center where the small moment arm would\nIbviously make a larger area inefficient.\nThe choice of a straight hinge line has led to the introluction of sweepback in these plan forms. It should\nbe remembered, however, that the solutions as expressed\n>y figure 3 are mathematically very general ones and\n:over, w i t h the limits of accuracy of the lifting-line\ntheory, any width of flap, any shape of hinge line or\nparter-chord line, and any normal aspect ratio. The\n\n-\n\nHinge\nhe\nFIGURE\n4.-AirIoils\n\n--\n\nof optimum plan form lor lift. Average\nchord r8tio, 20 percent.\n\n01 figure 3 with flags\n\nof effective angle of attack. Calculations also show\nthat, if each of the airfoils given by the foregoing distributions were provided with a flap of optimum shape, a\nsomewhat smaller movable surface, and hence a smaller\nhinge moment, would be required to increase the lift\non the blunt wing a given amount per unit deflection\nthan on either of the other two. On the other hand,\nsince aileron effectivenessdepends on the ratio of rolling\nmoment to damping moment, a tapered wing is seen to\nbe most efficient for lateral control.\nIn figure 4 the flaps are plotted in relation to the\nairfoils. The flaps as drawn are 20 percent of the mean\nchord of the airfoil. It will be noted that, for the\ntapered airfoil, this is the maximum width at which the\nshape of the flap can be maintained. Ordinarily as\nhigh a taper as shownwouldnot be used and a 20-percent\nor wider flap would be possible. It is not important,\n\n312\n\n-\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\nnrrryr\n\n/me\n\nJapered\n\n,\n\n-I\n\nFIGURE\n6.-AirIoils of 5gure 3 with ailerons of optimum plan form. Average chord\nratio, 15 percent.\n\naspect ratio, i n p , affects the expressionsfor F (6) in equations (22) and (23), but calculations made for an aspect\nratio of 2 resulted in outlines that could not be differentiated in plottingfrom thosegiven in figure 3. Thus, the\naspect ratio enters the solutions only in so far as it limits\nthe applicability of the lifting-linc theory. The solulions are also expected to apply in a general way to\n\nDETERMINATION O F OPTIMUM PLAN FORMS FOR CONTROL SURFACES\n\nunsealed flaps which, although less effective than sealed\nflaps, may be supposed to show similar variations of\neffectiveness with chord.\nA separate investigation was made to determine on\nwhich of the airfoils considered the derived control\nsurfaces would produce the most lift for a given hinge\nmoment, with a view to estimating the loss resulting\nfrom the use of a tapered stabilizer. The calculated\ndifference of 8 percent between the tapered and the\nblunt airfoils was not so great as might have been\nexpected. It is supplemented, however, by other aerodynamic effects such as fuselage interference, which\nmay make the use of area near the fuselage inefficient.\nAilerons on a blunt wing would similarly give more\nrolling moment for a certain hinge moment than on a\nmore tapered wing. Since the tapered wing requires\nless powerful ailerons because of the small damping\nmoment, the actual rate of rolling would be definitely\ngreater for a given hinge moment; thus in the last\nanalysis, the tapered wing must be considered the most\nefficient from considerations of aileron control.\n\nEaps for greatest efficiency are dso indicated by these\nf\n:onsiderations. I the ratio for a given shape is everywhere the same, the greatest lift or rolling moment must\nbe contributed by the element of the h p that has the\nmaximum chord (and therefore the maximum hinge\nmoment). I any other element of equal span is to be\nf\nused to develop the same lift, that element must either\nbe deflected through a greater angle or increased in\nwidth. It is assumed that the maximum degree of\ncontrol possible within the efficient range of f h p deflection, which is about +20\xc2\xb0, is desired, and the control\nshould therefore not be increased at the expense of\n\nPARTIAL-SPAN FLAPS\n\nAt this point a question arises as to the design of\npartial-span flaps, their shape, optimum length, and\nlocation. The most efficient shape for such flaps can\nbe deduced from a review of the preceding developf\nment. I a portion of the airfoil span has no movable\narea, the value of Aa, will be zero over that region and\nthe expressions for A, and A, given in equations (14)\nand (15) will reduce to integrals covering only flapped\nportions of the span. The limits for H given in equation (16) may be similarly changed. Then the reasoning remains the same; only the limits of integration are\nchanged to agree with the extent of the flap and, these\nlimits being identical for the functions involved, the\nrelations between the integrands may be expressed as\nbefore and the same solutions will be obtained. It\nfollows that flaps extending over a part of the span of\nan airfoil should have the same shape as the portion of\na flap of optimum shape covering that same part of\nthe span.\nAnother interesting characteristic of these shapes,\none from which further deductions concerning partialspan flaps may be made, appears when the solution\ngiven in equation (19) is substituted in expressions\n(14), (15), and (16) for the effectiveness and the hinge\nmoment. It is seen that the integrands of these expressions are identical except for the discarded factors of\nproportionality. This fact may be interpreted as\nmeaning that the surfaces found have, for any particular solutipn, a constant ratio of effectiveness to hinge\nmoment all along the span, or that any portion of a\ngiven flap of optimum shape is as efficient as any other\nportion.\nThis characteristic leads again to the conclusion that\npartial-span flaps should be segments of the optimum\nfull-span shapes. The extent and the location of the\n\ne\n/oo\n\nspanwise sfation,\n\n80\n\n60\n\nE\n.\n20\n\n40\n\nAilerons. .&rrzeoS\n\n0\n\nspan\n\nFIGURE6.-Rolling-moment and hinge-moment curves for pertid-span ailerons\nElliptical wing, aspect ratio, 6.\n\nflap deflection. If the chord is increased, it will be\nwith the square of the lift (equation (13)) and the\nhinge moment will then be increased with the square of\nthe chord (equation (16)) or the fourth power of the\nlift. The conclusion is obvious: The most efficient\nflap of a given span will cover the portion over which\nthe ordinates of figure 3 are the greatest. This result\nis of particular significance as applied to ailerons, which\nshould therefore extend inward from the tips.\nIt also follows that the greatest efficiency is obtained\nby using the longest possible control surfaces. Shorter\nflaps must of necessity be wider to produce the same\neffect, and the increase in chord causes a sharp drop\nin efficiency. This consideration should influence not\nonly the design of the flaps but also the design of the\ntail surfaces themselves.\nFigures 6 and 7 are a quantitative representation of\n\n313\n\nREPOR\xe2\x80\x99I\xe2\x80\x98 NO. 73 1-NATONAL\n\nAUVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nthe situation. In thesc figures, thc \xe2\x80\x9chinge-moment\nfactor\xe2\x80\x9d is the number by which the hinge moment of\nthc partial-span control surfaces would be multiplied if\ntheir effectiveness were increased (by increasing the\nchord) to equal that of tho full-span surfaces. Tlic\n\xe2\x80\x9crolling-moment factor\xe2\x80\x9d is tlic rolling moment drveloped by partial-span ailerons (to thc tip) of optimum\nshape, expressed as a fraction of thc moment clcveloped\nby tlie full-span ailerons of which they are a part.\nI n the case of ailerons, tlic loss of efficiency is not.\nvery great if thc extremc inboard portion is dispensed\nwith, but the rate a t which the efficicncy drops incrruscs\nrapidly as the span of tlic ailerons is lessened. For\nexample, if on a particular wing only tlic outrr GO pcrcctnt\nof the optimum ailerons of a certain percentage chord\nwere used, approxhately 16 perccnt of the rolling moment would be sacrificed. If it werc desired, however,\nto retain the full power of the control, a GO-pcrcent\nincrease in hinge moment would be incurred; or, from\n\npcrcent, however, tlic rcsultant incrcasc of control forcc\nis not so great as for partial-span ailerons.\nApplication of thc principles outlimed has been made\nto a modcrn airplane, with ailrrons as shown in figure 8.\nCalculations indicatc a 30-pcrccnt reduction in liingc\nmoment (with no loss of rolling moment) duc to irnprovemelit of the plan form of tlic ailerons a10\nan additional 10 percent of the scmisptui wcre allotted\nto each aileron, tlie required operuting forcc would be\nreduced to 45 percent of that for tlic. original ailerons,\nand the efficiency would be more than doublccl.\n\n\\\n\nI\n\n\\\n\nII\n\n-2\n\nf&- 1\n\nc\nIO0\n\nSponwtse stofion,\n\n80\n\n612\n60\n40\nFlaps, percen f span\n\n20\n\nFI(.cRE 7 --I~ingC-moment and e.ffrctlvenc~s\ncI1rvcI lor parllal-span flails\ntail surlaw, a y m t ratio, 6.\n\n0\n13111plllnal\n\nCONCLUSIONS\n\nCoiitrol surfaces of maximum efficiency (requiring a\nminimum operatiny force to achieve a given amount of\ncontrol) may bc tlesignttl almost without regard to the\n:liaracteristics of tlir wings 01\xe2\x80\x99tiiil surfa:.es to which\nthey arc to bc :~ttnrlletl. Esrrpt, pc~l~tups, very\non\nlow-nsprct-ratio tail surfacrs (nspvct retio less than 2),\nnaps slioiild be of almost constant chord ovrr the span.\nTlic optimum sliapc for ailrrons is of maximum width\nnear thc lip of tlic wing and lias a slightly convex\ncurvature as it tapers toward tlie center. Partial-span\ncontrol surfaces should be sections of these optimum\nshapes and should includc tlic regions of maximum\nchortl. For maximum cfficicncy, however, brcuuse tlic\nhinge mornciit increascs ns tlic fourth power of tlic lift\nwvlicm the gain in lift must be acliicvetl by increasing\nthe chord, flaps nnd ailerons should bc as long and\nnarrow as is compatible with structural and otlirr design considcr:Aons.\n\nanother point of view, a 60-percent aileron will always\nrequire an opcrating forcc 60 percent greater than is\nLAI~OR.\\TOI~Y,\nf\nentirely necessary for the same cffcctivmess. Wetmore\ny\n\nSUMMARY\nAn a n a l y s i s w a s made t o show t h e relative e f f e c t i v e n e s s of s t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l f u e l tanks, a f u e l tank i n\nt h e form of a wing mounted i n a b i p l a n e p o s i t i o n , and\na u x i l i a r y wing panels a t t a c h e d a t t h e wing t i p s t o increase t h e span as temporary means f o r i n c r e a s i n g t h e\nrange of a f i g h t e r - t y p e a i r p l a n e . The a i r p l a n e cons i d e r e d i s r e p r e s e n t a t i v e of e i t h e r an Army o r Navy\nsingle-engine heavy f i g h t e r . F i g u r e s and c h a r t s f o r t h e\nv a r i o u s devices considered show t h e r e s u l t s of calculat i o n s of range, d u r a t i o n of f l i g h t , and take-off d i s t a n c e\nf o r both land-base and carrier operation.\n\nThe r e s u l t s i n d i c a t e d t h a t t h e wing-tip e x t e n s i o n s\nw e r e t h e most promising of t h e d e v i c e s considered. It\nw a s estimated t h a t 10-foot t i p e x t e n s i o n s - t h a t i s , an\ni n c r e a s e i n span of 20 f e e t - used i n conjunction w i t h a\ns t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l f u e l t a n k would i n c r e a s e t h e range\nof t h e a i r p l a n e 125 t o 130 percent without any i n c r e a s e\ni n t h e d i s t a n c e r e q u i r e d t o t a k e off from e i t h k r a land\nbase o r a carrier. With 5-foot t i p e x t e n s i o n s , t h e range\nwould be i n c r e a s e d 65 t o 70 p e r c e n t , under t h e same l i m i t a t i o n s . The t a n k wing w a s found t o cause some r e d u c t i o n\ni n t h e e f f i c i e n c y of t h e a i r p l a n e i n t e r m s of m i l e s p e r\ng a l l o n . The added area would p e r m i t a g r e a t e r f u e l load\nt o b e c a r r i e d , however, f o r a given take-off d i s t a n c e and\nt h e range would thereby be increased. For a given takeoff d i s t a n c e from a land b a s e , t h e c a l c u l a t e d i n c r e a s e i n\nrange due t o t h e tank wing w a s about 45 p e r c e n t . The increase f o r a given carrier take-off would be about 20\npercent.\nI n c r e a s i n g t h e range 50 percent by c a r r y i n g\ne x t r a f u e l i n a s t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l tank without any\no t h e r m o d i f i c a t i o n s t o t h e a i r p l a n e would r e q u i r e an\n\n317\n\ni n c r e a s e of 20 percent i n take-off d i s t a n c e from a land\nbase and 32 percent from a carrier.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe range of f i g h t e r - t y p e a i r p l a n e s i s o r d i n a r i l y\nr e l a t i v e l y s h o r t because of high span loading and l i m i t a t i o n s on t h e space a v a i l a b l e f o r f u e l . Permanent modif i c a t i o n s i n t h e d e s i g n of t h e a i r p l a n e t o achieve longer\nranges would not be a c c e p t a b l e because of t h e consequent\nimpairment of o t h e r c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s t h a t are o r d i n a r i l y\nof g r e a t e r importance. Under c e r t a i n circumstances, however\nf o r example, f o r f e r r y i n g purposes\ni t would b e\nof g r e a t v a l u e t o i n c r e a s e t h e range of f i g h t e r a i r p l a n e s\nby temporary d e v i c e s , d e s p i t e s a c r i f i c e s i n o t h e r performance c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s .\n\n-\n\n-\n\nConsiderable i n c r e a s e s i n range may be obtained by\nc a r r y i n g s t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l f u e l tanks but only a t t h e\nc o s t of a p o s s i b l y p r o h i b i t i v e i n c r e a s e i n take-off d i s Several methods, designed t o i n c r e a s e t h e range\ntance.\nwithout i n c r e a s i n g t h e take-off d i s t a n c e , have been suggested. One of t h e s e methods c o n s i s t s e s s e n t i a l l y i n\nmaking t h e e x t e r n a l tank i n t h e shape of an a i r f o i l t o\ni n c r e a s e t h e t o t a l wing area. Another method c o n s i s t s\ni n adding area a t t h e wing t i p s , which h a s t h e advantage\nof i n c r e a s i n g n o t only t h e wing area f o r take-off b u t\na l s o t h e span and, thereby, t h e e f f i c i e n c y i n t e r m s of\nm i l e s per g a l l o n of f u e l . Such area might be added i n\nt h e form of temporary e x t e n s i o n s a t t a c h e d i n p l a c e of t h e\nremovable f a i r i n g s on t h e o r i g i n a l wings.\nDetermination of t h e most expedient method w i l l depend on a number of f a c t o r s o u t s i d e t h e f i e l d of t h e\np r e s e n t i n v e s t i g a t i o n , such as p i l o t endurance, area\na v a i l a b l e f o r take-off, and s t r u c t u r a l c o n s i d e r a t i o n s .\nThe following a n a l y s i s i s intended t o provide a compari s o n of t h e suggested methods on t h e b a s i s of maximum att a i n a b l e range, f l y i n g t i m e r e q u i r e d , and take-off d i s t a n c e s from e i t h e r a land base o r a carrier. The calc u l a t i o n s w e r e made f o r an a i r p l a n e t h e c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s\nof which may be considered r e p r e s e n t a t i v e of e i t h e r an\nArmy o r Navy single-engine heavy f i g h t e r .\n\n318\n\nANALYSIS\n\nAirplane.- The c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of t h e a i r p l a n e cons i d e r e d i n t h e a n a l y s i s are:\n\n...............\nWing span, f e e t . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\nWing incidence a n g l e , degrees . . . . . . . . . . . .\nGround a n g l e ( l o n g i t u d i n a l a x i s ) , degrees . . . . . .\n\nWing area, square f e e t\n\n310\n\n41\n2\n12\n\nEmpty weight (design g r o s s weight less\n\n. . . . 11,000\nEngine displacement, cubic inches . . . . . . . . . . 2800\nSupercharger . . . . . . . . . . . two-stage, gear-driven\nP r o p e l l e r . . . . . . . . . . . three-blade, constant-speed\n2:l\nPropeller gear r a t i o . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .\nMaximum speed a t sea level, m i l e s per hour . . . . .\n317\n. . . - 300\nCapacity of i n t e r n a l f u e l tank, g a l l o n s .\nnormal f u e l l o a d ) , pounds\n\nA s k e t c h of t h e a i r p l a n e w i t h a tank wing\'of 300g a l l o n c a p a c i t y (4-ft chord by 20-ft span) is shown i n\nf i g u r e 1. The take-off speed\nw a s taken as 5 percent i n excess of t h e power-off s t a l l i n g\nspeed and t h e r o l l i n g - f r i c t i o n c o e f f i c i e n t , as 0.05.\nAirrun d i s t a n c e s were estimated from t h e r e s u l t s of step-bys t e p i n t e g r a t i o n s of t h e a i r - r u n f l i g h t p a t h , based on\nt h e assumption t h a t t h e l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t a t which t h e airp l a n e t a k e s off would be maintained up t o t h e 50-foot\nh e i g h t . The deck-wind v e l o c i t y w a s taken as 25 knots and t h e\nr o l l i n g - f r i c t i o n c o e f f i c i e n t , as 0.02,\nThe method of r e f e r 322\n\nence 2 w a s used f o r t h e c a l c u l a t i o n of t h e take-off\ntances.\n\ndis-\n\nFor both land-base and carrier take-offs, account\nw a s taken, as w e l l as p o s s i b l e , of t h e e f f e c t s of s l i p s t r e a m\nand proximity of t h e ground. The p a r a s i t e d r a g of p a r t s of t h e\na i r p l a n e i n t h e s l i p s t r e a m w a s assumed t o be increased i n\np r o p o r t i o n t o t h e i n c r e a s e i n dynamic p r e s s u r e i n t h e s l i p stream. It w a s assumed t h a t t h e induced drag a s s o c i a t e d\nw i t h t h e l i f t increment due t o t h e s l i p s t r e a m would be t h e\ns a m e as though t h i s l i f t increment w e r e obtained w i t h a\nf l a p having a span equal t o t h e s l i p s t r e a m diameter. The\ne f f e c t s of ground i n t e r f e r e n c e on t h e l i f t - c u r v e s l o p e and\ninduced drag w e r e estimated on t h e b a s i s of Wieselsberger\'s\na d a p t a t i o n of b i p l a n e theory ( r e f e r e n c e 4 ) .\nRESULTS AND DISCUSSION\nChart f o r range and take-off d i s t a n c e . - A c h a r t , from\nwhich t h e range, mean speed o r d u r a t i o n of f l i g h t , and takeo f f d i s t a n c e s from a land base o r a c a r r i e r may be estimated\nf o r any of t h e c a s e s considered, h a s been constructed from\nt h e r e s u l t s of t h e c a l c u l a t i o n s of range and take-off d i s t a n c e and i s given i n f i g u r e 4 . T h i s p l o t shows l i n e s of c o n s t a n t mean speed\ns l o p i n g t o t h e l e f t with i n c r e a s i n g v a l u e s of khe r a t i o of\ntake-off weight t o empty weight, given on t h e diagonal scale\nt o t h e r i g h t , and thereby t a k e s account of t h e f a c t t h a t\ncurve\nC D\nf o r a given c o n d i t i o n i n c r e a s e s with i n c r e a s i n g weight.\nInasmuch as t h e v a l u e of n / C\n( f i g . 3) f o r a given speed\ni s found t o b e p r a c t i c a l l y independent of loading f o r t h e\nengine-operating c o n d i t i o n s assumed, t h e v a l u e corresponding\nt o a given v a l u e of L/D w i l l v a r y somewhat with loading.\nThe v a r i a t i o n , however, i s s m a l l and v a l u e s of n / C f o r\nt h e a i r s p e e d corresponding t o t h e average of t h e f u l l and\nempty loading f o r each a i r p l a n e c o n d i t i o n were t h e r e f o r e\nn L\nused i n determining t h e - - curves.\nC D\nt h e speed corresponding t o a given p o i n t on t h e\n\n323\n\nI n t h e upper right-hand s e c t i o n of t h e c h a r t , curves\nT L\nd e f i n i n g t h e r e l a t i o n between -\\- and Wt/We\nf o r conC D\ns t a n t v a l u e s of range are p l o t t e d . I n\no r d e r t o estimate t h e mean v e l o c i t y , a v e r t i c a l l i n e is\nT L\ndrawn down from t h e p o i n t corresponding t o t h e v a l u e of -\\C D\nused i n determining t h e range. The p o i n t of i n t e r s e c t i o n\nof t h i s l i n e w i t h a h o r i z o n t a l l i n e drawn from t h e previously\nscale g i v e s t h e mean speed\ne s t a b l i s h e d p o i n t on t h e Wt/We\n\n-\n\n-\n\nof t h e f l i g h t\nabout 206 m i l e s p e r hour f o r t h e example.\nThe d u r a t i o n of t h e f l i g h t i s given by d i v i d i n g t h e range\nby t h e mean speed and i s found t o be about 9.95 hours.\nThe same procedure would be followed f o r t h e c a s e of takeo f f from a c a r r i e r , using t h e carrier take-off curves ins t e a d of t h e land-base curves.\nF i g u r e s 5 and 6 have been prepared from t h e c h a r t i n\nf i g u r e 4 t o provide a more d i r e c t comparison of t h e v a r i o u s\nmeans f o r i n c r e a s i n g t h e range. Figure 6 g i v e s t h e v a r i a t i o n of\ntake-off d i s t a n c e s w i t h range when t h e d u r a t i o n of f l i g h t\nf o r a given range i s t h e s a m e f o r a l l cases as t h a t f o r t h e\no r i g i n a l a i r p l a n e o p e r a t i n g a t maximum e f f i c i e n c y .\n\n324\n\nStreamline e x t e r n a l tank.- I n f i g u r e 5 i t is shown\nt h a t , by i n c r e a s i n g t h e f u e l c a p a c i t y of t h e a i r p l a n e from\n300 t o 600 g a l l o n s through t h e u s e of a s t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l\nt a n k , t h e maximum range would be increased from about 1450\nt o 2600 m i l e s o r about 80 p e r c e n t . The take-off d i s t a n c e\nfrom a land b a s e would be increased from 2160 f e e t t o\n2960 f e e t o r about 35 p e r c e n t , From a carrier, t h e takeo f f d i s t a n c e would be increased from 308 t o 500 f e e t o r\nabout 62 p e r c e n t . The e x t e n t t o which an i n c r e a s e i n\ntake-off d i s t a n c e from a land base would be a c c e p t a b l e\ndepends, of course, on t h e s i z e of a i r f i e l d a v a i l a b l e .\nFor carrier o p e r a t i o n , however, any material i n c r e a s e i n\ntake-off d i s t a n c e would probably be a s e r i o u s disadvantage.\nTank wing.- The t a n k wing i s e s s e n t i a l l y a temporary\nmeans of providing added wing area i n order t h a t t h e\na i r p l a n e may t a k e off w i t h a g r e a t e r f u e l load f o r c e r t a i n\nlong-range missions and, a t t h e same t i m e , provides t a n k ;\nspace f o r t h i s e x t r a f u e l . This a u x i l i a r y wing would\nprobably be mounted as t h e upper wing of a b i p l a n e as\nshown i n f i g u r e 1. With such an arrangement, i t would be\nt h e o r e t i c a l l y p o s s i b l e t o i n c r e a s e t h e e f f e c t i v e span of\nt h e a i r p l a n e t o some e x t e n t but t h e h i g h a s p e c t r a t i o t h a t\nwould be r e q u i r e d f o r t h e a u x i l i a r y wing would probably\nunduly complicate t h e s t r u c t u r a l problems. For t h e purposes of t h i s a n a l y s i s , i t w a s assumed t h a t a tank wing\nof a s p e c t r a t i o 5 w i t h a n area of 80 square f e e t and\na f u e l c a p a c i t y of 300 g a l l o n s would r e p r e s e n t a reasonably\np r a c t i c a b l e case. This arrangement e n t a i l s a r e d u c t i o n i n\nt h e e f f e c t i v e span of t h e combination of about 2 percent i n\ncomparison w i t h t h e o r i g i n a l a i r p l a n e . The wetted area and\nhence t h e parasite-drag i n c r e a s e due t o t h e tank wing,\nfurthermore, is about t w i c e t h a t of a body of r e v o l u t i o n of\ne q u a l volume. A s a r e s u l t , t h e a i r p l a n e w i t h t h e tank wing\ni s somewhat less e f f i c i e n t t h a n t h e a i r p l a n e w i t h a streaml i n e e x t e r n a l tank.\n(See f i g s . 3 and 4.)\nThe e f f e c t of t h i s reduced e f f i c i e n c y shows i n f i g u r e 5\nas a r e d u c t i o n i n range from 2600 t o 2440 m i l e s with a 600g a l l o n f u e l load. The t a n k wing does, however, g i v e an\ni n c r e a s e i n range f o r a given take-off d i s t a n c e , because of\nt h e g r e a t e r f u e l load t h a t can be c a r r i e d . For land-base\no p e r a t i o n , t h e tank wing i n c r e a s e s t h e range from 1440 t o\n2100 m i l e s o r about 45 percent f o r t h e same take-off d i s t a n c e as f o r t h e o r i g i n a l a i r p l a n e w i t h t h e normal f u l l f u e l\nload of 300 g a l l o n s . For carrier o p e r a t i o n , t h e range would\nb e increased t o 1750 m i l e s o r about 20 percent. The e f f e c t i v e n e s s of t h e t a n k wing f o r carrier o p e r a t i o n i n comparison\n325\n\nw i t h t h a t f o r land-base o p e r a t i o n is reduced because t h e\nf l a p on t h e o r i g i n a l wing i s used f o r t h e carrier take-offs\nand t h e added wing area due t o t h e t a n k wing does n o t , i n\nt h i s case, p r o p o r t i o n a t e l y i n c r e a s e t h e take-off l i f t .\nWing-tip extensions.- Increasing t h e span of an airplane, o t h e r t h i n g s remaining equal, w i l l p r o p o r t i o n a t e l y\ni n c r e a s e t h e maximum range a t t a i n a b l e with a given f u e l\nload. T h i s f a c t s u g g e s t s t h e u s e of a u x i l i a r y p a n e l s ,\na t t a c h e d t o t h e wing t i p s i n p l a c e of t h e removable t i p\nf a i r i n g s ( s e e f i g . 2 ) , as a promising means f o r i n c r e a s i n g\nt h e range.\nInasmuch as t h e g r e a t e s t range i s a t t a i n e d a t moderate\nspeeds, i t i s p o s s i b l e t h a t t h e s e temporary t i p extensions\ncould be c o n s t r u c t e d of f a i r l y l i g h t wood o r p l a s t i c . Furthermore, because t h e wing of a f i g h t e r a i r p l a n e i s designed\nf o r loadings much g r e a t e r than t h o s e encountered i n level\nf l i g h t , major changes i n t h e main wing s t r u c t u r e might not\nIt i s suggested t h a t , by using a g r e a t e r\nbe necessary.\nt a p e r i n t h e t i p e x t e n s i o n s as shown i n f i g u r e 2 and a t\nt h e same t i m e s u i t a b l y i n c r e a s i n g t h e camber of t h e airf o i l s e c t i o n s , t h e gust loads imposed on t h e main wing\ns t r u c t u r e by t h e t i p extensions can be considerably reduced\nwithout m a t e r i a l l y a f f e c t i n g t h e range o r t h e take-off\ndistance\n\n.\n\nThe t i p extensions would considerably reduce t h e\nl a t e r a l maneuverability of t h e a i r p l a n e . For t h e a i r p l a n e\nconsidered, i t i s estimated t h a t t i p e x t e n s i o n s of 10-foot\nspan ( o v e r - a l l span increased from 41 t o 61 f t ) would dec r e a s e t h e maximum v a l u e of t h e t i p h e l i x a n g l e pb/2V\na t t a i n a b l e w i t h t h e a i l e r o n s about 30 p e r c e n t .
