F l i g h t tests have shown t h a t t h e\nmoment of i n e r t i a of an a i r p l a n e about i t s l o n g i t u d i n a l\na x i s can b e a t least doubled without m a t e r i a l l y a f f e c t i n g\nl a t e r a l maneuverability; accordingly, t h e added moment of\ni n e r t i a due t o t h e t i p extensions should have no n o t i c e a b l e\ne f f e c t on t h e response t o a i l e r o n c o n t r o l .\nThe r e l a t i v e l y low s t a b i l i t y t h a t i s normally c h a r a c t e r i s t i c of f i g h t e r - t y p e a i r p l a n e s would tend t o i n c r e a s e p i l o t\nf a t i g u e on a long-range f l i g h t . The temporary devices used\nf o r i n c r e a s i n g t h e range should t h e r e f o r e be designed, ins o f a r as p o s s i b l e , t o improve t h e s t a b i l i t y , Increased\nl o n g i t u d i n a l s t a b i l i t y could b e obtained by providing sweep-\n\n326\n\nback i n t h e wing-tip e x t e n s i o n s or by p r o p e r l y disposing\nt h e f u e l load c a r r i e d i n e x t e r n a l tanks. Wing-tip extens i o n s might be designed w i t h s u f f i c i e n t d i h e d r a l a n g l e t o\nimprove s p i r a l s t a b i l i t y , i f necessary, i n o r d e r t h a t t h e\np i l o t could f l y w i t h rudder a l o n e i n smooth a i r .\nThe u s e of wing-tip e x t e n s i o n s , e i t h e r a l o n e o r i n\nconjunction w i t h s t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l f u e l t a n k s , appears t o\nbe t h e most e f f e c t i v e of t h e means considered f o r i n c r e a s i n g\nt h e range a t t a i n a b l e w i t h f i g h t e r a i r p l a n e s . Not only i s\nt h e e f f i c i e n c y of t h e a i r p l a n e i n c r e a s e d , as shown i n f i g u r e s 3 and 4 , w i t h t h e r e s u l t t h a t t h e range w i t h a given\nf u e l load is g r e a t e r , but a l s o t h e added wing area w i l l\ng i v e a s u b s t a n t i a l improvement i n take-off d i s t a n c e . I n\nf i g u r e 5, t h e maximum range of t h e a i r p l a n e w i t h 600 g a l l o n s\nof f u e l is shown t o be increased from 2600 t o 3030 m i l e s\nw i t h %foot t i p e x t e n s i o n s and t o 3450 m i l e s w i t h 10-foot\nt i p extensions. The wing-tip extens i o n s , i n c o n t r a s t w i t h t h e t a n k wing, appear e q u a l l y\ne f f e c t i v e i n i n c r e a s i n g t h e range f o r a given take-off\nd i s t a n c e from e i t h e r a land base o r a carrier because t h e\ni n c r e a s e d l i f t - c u r v e s l o p e w i t h t h e wing-tip e x t e n s i o n s\ng i v e s a r e l a t i v e l y h i g h e r take-off l i f t f o r t h e f i x e d\na n g l e of a t t a c k of t h e carrier take-offs t h a n i s obtained\nw i t h t h e tank wing.\nInasmuch as an i n c r e a s e i n span reduces t h e a i r s p e e d\na t which maximum e f f i c i e n c y is a t t a i n e d , t h e t i m e of\nf l i g h t over a given d i s t a n c e w i l l be g r e a t e r w i t h t h e\nwing-tip e x t e n s i o n s t h a n w i t h t h e o r i g i n a l a i r p l a n e o r\nw i t h t h e t a n k wing, i f t h e primary c o n s i d e r a t i o n i s t h e\nattainment of a given range w i t h t h e least p o s s i b l e f u e l\nload o r take-off d i s t a n c e . This case i s represented i n\nf i g u r e 5. Comparison of f i g u r e s 5 and 6\nshows t h a t t h e f l y i n g speed f o r t h e a i r p l a n e equipped w i t h\nwing-tip e x t e n s i o n s could b e increased t o t h e e x t e n t t h a t\nt h e d u r a t i o n of f l i g h t f o r a given range i s t h e same as f o r\nt h e o r i g i n a l a i r p l a n e without s e r i o u s l y i n c r e a s i n g t h e takeoff d i s t a n c e s f o r a given range o r , conversely, without g r e a t l y\nreducing t h e range a t t a i n a b l e f o r a given take-off d i s t a n c e .\n327\n\nC0NCLUI)ING REMARKS\n\nO t h e methods considered f o r temporarily i n c r e a s i n g\nf\nt h e range of f i g h t e r - t y p e a i r p l a n e s , t h e u s e of a u x i l i a r y\nwing-tip e x t e n s i o n s appears t h e most promising. With 5-fOOt t i p e x t e n s i o n s , t h e\nrange would b e increased 65 t o 70 p e r c e n t , under t h e same\nlimitations.\n\n-\n\nAn a u x i l i a r y wing of &foot chord and 20-foot span\nmounted above t h e main wing and providing t a n k c a p a c i t y\nf o r 300 g a l l o n s of e x t r a f u e l , w a s shown t o g i v e somewhat\nlower e f f i c i e n c y i n t e r m s of m i l e s per g a l l o n t h a n t h e\no r i g i n a l a i r p l a n e w i t h t h e e x t r a f u e l c a r r i e d i n a streaml i n e e x t e r n a l tank. The tank wing would permit a g r e a t e r\nf u e l load t o b e c a r r i e d f o r a given take-off d i s t a n c e\nbecause of t h e added wing a r e a , and t h e range would thereby\nbe increased. For a given take-off d i s t a n c e from a land\nbase, t h e i n c r e a s e i n range w a s estimated t o be about 45\npercent. The i n c r e a s e f o r a given c a r r i e r take-off would\nbe about 20 p e r c e n t .\nI n c r e a s i n g t h e range 50 percent by c a r r y i n g e x t r a\nf u e l i n s t r e a m l i n e e x t e r n a l tanks without any o t h e r modif i c a t i o n s t o t h e a i r p l a n e would e n t a i l a n i n c r e a s e of\n20 percent i n take-off d i s t a n c e from a land base and\n32 percent from a carrier.\nS e l e c t i o n of t h e most s u i t a b l e method f o r a p a r t i c u l a r\na p p l i c a t i o n w i l l of course depend on o t h e r f a c t o r s b e s i d e s\nt h e a t t a i n a b l e range and take-off performance, such as\ns t r u c t u r a l problems, p i l o t endurance, and area a v a i l a b l e\nf o r take-off.\nFor example, i f i n a given case t h e d u r a t i o n\nof f l i g h t w i t h e x t e r n a l tanks a l o n e i s equal t o t h e endurance\nof t h e p i l o t and i f t h e area and t h e span a v a i l a b l e f o r takeoff are adequate, t h e r e w i l l b e l i t t l e advantage i n t h e u s e\nof more e f f i c i e n t methods.\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory,\nNational Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics,\nLangley F i e l d , V a ,\n\n328\n\nREFERENCES\n1.\n\nDiehl, Walter S . : Engineering Aerodynamics.\nRonald Press Co., 1928, pp. 36-40.\n\n2.\n\nHartman, Edwin P.: Considerations of the Take-Off\nProblem. Jones and Harry Greenberg\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1944\n\n335\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 798\nEFFECT OF HINGE-MOMENT PARAMETERS ON ELEVATOR\nSTICK FORCES IN RAPID MANEUVERS\nBy ROBERT JONESand HARRY\nT.\nGREENBERG\n\n-\n\nSUMMARY\n\nThe importance o the stick force per unit normal acceleration\nf\nas a criterion of longitudinal stability and the critical dependence o this gradient on elevator hinge-moment parameters have\nf\nbeen shown in previous reports. The present report continues\nthe investigation with special reference to transient e$ects for\nmaneuvers o short duration.\nf\nThe analysis made showed that dijerent combinations o\nf\nelevator parameters which give the same stick force per unit\nacceleration in turns give wiclely dijerent force variations during\nthe entries into and recoveries f r o m steady turns and during\nmaneuvers o short duration such as abrupt pull-ups. A comf\nf\nf\nbination o relatively large negative values o the restoring tendency C,,, and theJloating tendency Chal7approaching those o\nf\na n unbalanced elevator, results in a stick force that is high during\nthe initial stage o a pull-up and then decreases, and may even\nf\nreverse, as the acceleration i s reduced at the end of the maneuver.\nThe stick force per unit acceleration i s greater for abrupt than\nfor gradual control movements.\nI f the negative value of Ch, is reduced so that the corresponding value o Ch,\' becomes slightly positive, the reversal o force\nf\nf\nmay be eliminated and the force may be brought nearly in phase\nwith the acceleration. There i s a limit to the permissible reduction of the value of Cha, however, because as\napproaches zero\nthe stick force per unit acceleration may become 1ower.for abrupt\nthan for gradual maneuvers and may thus lead to undesirably\nlow stick forces at the beginning of the maneuver.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe stick force per unit normal acceleration as measured\nin steady turns or pull-outs, which was proposed as a criterion of longitudinal handling in reference I , is now generally accepted as a basic measure of longitudinal stability.\nThe critical dependence of this stick-force gradient on elevator hinge-moment parameters and on mass unbalance of\nthe control system was shown in reference 2. It was found\nthat a given stick-force gradient can be obtained by any of a\nseries of combinations of these parameters satisfying certain\nprescribed relations.\nFurther consideration of the problem and some recent\nflight experience, however, have shown the need for investigating the transient effects that occur during the change\nfrom steady unaccelerated flight to steady accelerated fight.\nThese transient effects cause a difference between the stickforce gradients in a steady turn and in a maneuver of short\nduration such as a pull-up.\nThe purpose of the present report is to investigate the\n\n__.\n\nvariation of elevator stick force and normal acceleration\nduring the transition interval preceding the shady turn and\nalso during turns or pull-ups of short duration. The effect\nof combinations of hinge-moment parameters is considered;\neach combination is chosen to give the same stick-force\ngradient in a steady maneuver. Time histories of the stick\nforce and normal acceleration are found for predetermined\nvariations of elevator deflection. An attempt is made to\nexplain and to suggest a remedy for the large variations of\nstick force with time observed during pull-ups cf short duration on different airplanes in flight. A previous analysis,\nsomewhat similar to the present one, was made in England\n(reference 3) but included a smaller range of hinge-moment\nparameters.\nSYMBOLS\n\nA\nb\n\naspect ratio of wing\nwing span\n\n6,\n\nelevator hinge-moment coefficient\n\nC\nL\n\nairplane lit coefficient\n\nC,\n\npitching-moment coefficient about\ncenter of gravity (Pitchm;syment\n\nC\nC,\n\nD\nF\nS\n\nF,,\n\n...\n\n(F)\n\nairplane\n\nwing chord\nelevator chord\ndifferential operator (dJds)\nstick force, pounds\nF5 cases representing particular combinations of\nhinge-moment parameters\nstick-force gradient in maneuvers\nacceleration of gravity\nhinge moment; positive when tends to lower\nelevator\nmass moment of elevator control system about\nelevator hinge; positive when tends to lower\nelevator\nradius of gyration of airplane about Y-axis\ntail length, half-chords\nmass of airplane\nnormal acceleration per g of airplane due to\ncurvature of flight path; accelerometer reading\nminus component of gravity force\ndynamic pressure\nwing area\n\n74lm6-47\n\n337\n\nREPORT NO. 7 9 8-NATIONAL\n\nS*\nS\n\nT\nt\nU\n\nV\nXa.c.\n\na\n!\nffl\n\n6\n\ne\nx\nP\n\nP\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nelevator area\ndistance traveled, half-chords (2Vt/e)\nperiod of elevator motion\ntime\nindependent variable used in Duhamel\xe2\x80\x99s integral\nvelocity\ndistance between center of gravity and aerodynamic center; positive when stable\ndeflection of elevator per unit movement of\nstick, radians per foot\nangle of attack, radians\nangle of attack at tail, radians\ndeflection of elevator; positive downward\nangle of pitch of airplane\nroot of stability equation\nairplane-density parameter (m/pSb)\nmass density of air\n\nSubscript:\nmax\nmaximum\n.Subscripts a!, Da, D2a, ai, DO, 6, and D6 indicate derivatives; for example, C m D o = s .A dot over asymbol indicates\ndifferentiation with respect to time.\n\nC 6 is given as a function of time, the solution for a! The angle of attack at the tail can then be\nfound from\n\naa! a!+lhDe\naa!\n\na,=-t\n\nThe normal acceleration, which is considered positive upward, is proportional to the change in angle of attack a! and\nis given by\n\nMETHOD OF ANALYSIS\n\nn=-\n\nThe following assumptions are made in the present analysis:\n(1) Variation in forward speed is negligible\n( 2 ) Stability derivatives are constant; that is, any possible\nnonlinearity of coefficients is negligible\n(3) Effects of power are negligible\n(4) Effects of control-system moment of inertia are\nnegligible\n(5) Control-system mass unbalance is all located at airplane center of gravity\nThe equations of motion of an airplane subjected to a\nprescribed elevator motion can be obtained from reference 2 .\nI forward speed is assumed constant, there are three equaf\ntions of motion. The first two equations determine the\nmotion of the airplane if the control motion is specified.\nThe third equation determines the hinge-moment coefficient,\nwhich depends on the motion of the control surface and the\nairplane. These equations are\n\n(%+ 2ApD)\n\nCY-\n\n2 ApDe= 0\n\nv*CL,\n~\n\ncg 2 A p\n\na\n!\n\nThe value of the stick force can be obtained by substituting\nthe derived values of a! and De and the given value of 6 in\nthe hinge-moment equation (equation (3)). These\nfive different combinations of the hinge-moment parameters\nwere selected to give, for one center-of-gravity location, the\nsame stick-force gradient in a steady turn, as determined by\nthe formula for stick-force gradient in a gradual pull-up or\nsteady turn given in reference 2, which is\n\nThe locus of points in the C,,,,C,,, plane corresponding to\na value of the stick-force gradient of 5 pounds per g and a\ncenter-of-gravity location 7% percent chord ahead of the\naerodynamic center is shown in figure 2 for a mass-balanced\nand also for a mass-unbalanced elevator. The amount of\nunbalance corresponding to the line marked h=5 would\nrequire a pull of 15 pounds on the control stick for balance.\nThe five points marked F l , . . . Figure 6, for example, shows that the\nof the aerodynamic center (see fig. 2) are as follows:\n\xe2\x80\x9cmaneuver point\xe2\x80\x9d (c.g. location for zero stick force per g) for\ncase Fl is 4.2 percent chord ahead of the aerodynamic center\n(point where Cm,=O). T=4seconds\nE\nV = m miles per hour;%\'. r.=0.075c.\n\nare plotted in figures 7 and 8. I n figure 7, the stick force\ncorresponding to Fl (cy. a t maneuver point) is positive at\nfirst and then reverses and becomes negative. The maximum values of the positive and negative forces are approximately equal. As the center of gravity is moved behind the\nmaneuver point for Fl (fig. 8), the negative maximum force\nis greater than the positive; this increase would be expected\nsince a negative force is required to hold the airplane in a\nsteady turn. The stick forces for F3 and F5 remain positrive.\nThe elevator deflection required to produce a given accelerat.ion, however, decreases as the center of gravity moves\nrearward.\nAirplane speed has no effect on the shape of the stickforce and acceleration curves, if compressibdity effects are\nneglected and if the product of speed and duration of maneuver is held constant; for example, the shape of the curves of\nfigures 3 to 5 is unchanged if the speed is halved and the\nduration is doubled. The effect of increasing speed therefore is the same as the effect of increasing duration in the\nsame ratio.\nDISCUSSION\n\nBefore the various elevator cases and degrees of stability\nfor which the computations were made are discussed, i t\nappears desirable to explain the effects of the separate param-\n\n3 40\n\neters that combine to give the resultant elevator forces in\npull-ups. These effects, as already stated, are the variation\nof hinge-moment coefficient with elevator deflection, BS\nindicated by Ch8;\nthe variation of hinge-moment coefficient\nwith angle of attack at the tail, as indicated by Ch+ the\nvariation of hinge moment with angular velocity of the\nelevator about its hinge; the mass unbalance (bobweight\neffect); and the effective moment of inertia of the elevator\nsystem.\nBecause preliminary computations indicated that the\ninertia of the elevator system had a negligible effect on the\nstick force for the shortest maneuver assumed, it was\nneglected in the analysis. For airplanes larger than the one\nconsidered in this report and for other special cases, inertia\nof the elevator systrm may be an important factor.\nThe influence of the important parameters is shown in\nfigure 9, which gives a breakdown of the factors contributing\nto the stick-force curve for case F4in figure 5. Case F4 was\nchosen because it was the only condition in which all the\nparameters were combined.\nFigure 9 shows that the effect of C,, is to produce a component of stick force in phase with elevator deflection. The\nmagnitude of this component of the stick force depends\nsolely on the elevator deflection a t a given speed and is\nindependent of the duration of the maneuver.\n\nEFFECT OF HINGE-MOMENT PARAMETERS ON ELEVATOR STICK FORCES I N RAPID MANEUVERS\n\nFIGURE\nB.-Lines of mnstant stick-Iorw gradient. 6.=0 and 5 pounds prr a.\n\nFIGURE -Stick force and normal acceleration due to rapid elevator motion. T=lsecond:\n5\nV=4M)miles per hour,z, ..=0.075c.\n\nThe normal acceleration produced by the elevator decreases as the duration of the maneuver is made shorter.\nThe stick force per unit acceleration due to the Ch8term\ntherefore increases as the maneuver becomes more rapid.\nThe effect of the mass unbalance of a bobweight is to\ncontribute a component of force that is in phase with and\nsolely dependent on the normal acceleration of the airplane.\nThe stick-force gradient due to the bobweight is therefore\nindependent of duration of maneuver. Although figure 9\ndeals with a mass unbalance that tends to depress the trailing\nedge of the elevator, in the general case the unbalance may\nbe of the opposite sign so that push instead of pull forces\nresult.\nThe effect of C,,., is similar to that of the bobweight since\nthe component of force caused by Chatis nearly in phase\nwith the acceleration. The slight difference in phase between the values of 0 1 ~\nand n is the effect of the rate of change\nof airplane angle of attack. For maneuvers of short duration,\nthis slight phase shift causes a noticeable difference between\nthe action of Chmz of a hobweight.\nand\n\nTime, t, sec\nFIGURE\n7.-Stick force and normal accelerationdue to rapid elevator molion. T=2 seconrls;\n.\nV=4w miles per hour: I ..-O.O4Zc.\n\n341\n\nREPORT N O . 7 9 S-NATIONAL\n\nTrmPlGVRE 8 -Stmk\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ne-\n\nloree and normal acceleration due to lapid elevator motion. T=2 seconds;\nV=400 miles per hour, z o a =O Olc.\n\nThe component of force due to the angular velocity of the\nelevator may be very important for maneuvers of short\nduration. It has the effect of reducing the stick-force\ngradients in cases in which the maximum force occurs after\nthe elevator has reached maximum deflection.\nThe cases for which the results are presented in figures 3 to 5\nwere chosen to show the effects of different combinations\nof the hinge-moment parameters subject to the designer\xe2\x80\x99s\ncontrol. The parameter C,, is the same for all cases. I n\ncase F,, the desired stick force for a steady turn is achieved\nby a balance of relatively large negative values of c h , and\nChar. The stick forces due to these two parameters are in\nopposite directions so that the net value in a steady turn is\ndue to the difference in their effects. In a maneuver of the\ntype shown in figure 1, the elevator-deflection curve leads\nthe normal-acceleration curve; hence c , has the preh\ndominating effect in the initial stages of the maneuver and\nthe negative Cl,et,in the later stages. This fact accounts\nfor the high stick forces in the first half of the maneuver and\nthe reversal of force in the second half for case Fl. The\ndifference is more noticeable in the shorter maneuvers. As\nthe duration of the maneuver decreases, the lag between\n\n342\n\nFIGURE\n9.-Components of stick force for ease F in fimrre5.\nd\n\nairplane motion and elevator deflection becomes greater and\nthe maximum value of the acceleration for the given elevator\ndeflection becomes smaller. Both of these factors tend to\nreduce the importance of the Cha,component in the early\npart of the maneuver and to increase the maximum force\nrequired for a given maximum acceleration. This variation\nof maximum force per unit maximum acceleration shown in\nfigure 10 is quite large.\nFor case F,, the desired stick force for steady turns is\nachieved through the action of Ch,alone. All curves for F2\nwould have the same magnitude for any duration of maneuver\nand would be in phase with the elevator-deflection curve but\nfor the contribution of ChD6-The effect of Ch,, increases\nwith the rapidity of the elevator movement and causes a\nphase shift in the force curve relative to the elevator deflection, which results in a slight increase in the maximum value\nfor the shortest maneuver. A slight push force near the\nend of the maneuver is produced by C,,,. Figure 10 shows\nthat in case F2 the maximum force per unit maximum\nacceleration increases as the maneuver is shortened although\nnot so much as in case F,\nThe balance is achieved in case Fa through action of\n\nEFFECT O F HINGE-MOMENT PARAMETERS O N ELEVATOR STICK FORCES I N RAPID MANEUVERS\nc h a t alone.\nIn this case, the maximum stick force attributed to c h a r is nearly i phase with the acceleration and,\nn\nconsequently, the maximum value occurs after maximum\nelevator deflection when the elevator is being moved back\nto its original position. The forces at the beginning of the\nmaneuver are consequently smaller than in cases Fl and F2\nand may be too small for satisfactory handling qualities.\nThe effect of c h , , is to decrease the maximum force by an\nincreasing amount as the maneuver becomes shorter. The\ndiscontinuity in the F3 curve (and also in the F4 and F5\ncurves) for the 1-second maneuver results from the disappearance of the C,,, component a t the completion of the\nelevator motion. Figure 10 shows that the maximum force\nper unit maximum acceleration for case F3 decreases as the\nmaneuver is shortened; this effect is primarily a result of the\naction of ChDr\n\nfor case Fl, shown in figures 7 and 8, is caused by the greater\nangular response of the airplane to a given elevator deflection that occurs with reduced stability. The greater\nresponse changes the balance between the Ohat\nand c h , components. If the stick force is independent of c h , , as i case\nn\nF3 and Fs, the form of the stick-force curves is unchanged by\nvariation of the center-of-gravity location. Figure 11 shows\nthat the variation of maximum force per unit maximum\nacceleration in a rapid maneuver with center-of-gravity\nlocation becomes less as the value of C,,, is reduced.\nThe adjustment of the elevator parameters so that the\nstick forces for steady turns are directly proportional to the\nnormal acceleration produced and independent of center-ofgravity location is generally conceded to be desirable. It\nappears possible from the analysis to accomplish these conditions by m a k g the stick forces depend primarily on c h , $\nor on a bobweight, provided the entrance and recovery are\nmade slowly. It is not definitely known whether this condition of strict proportionality is desired in maneuvers of\nshort duration. I n these cases, however, when the entry\nIO\n8\n\n86\n\n\\\n\nc4\n2\n\n0\nI\n2\n3\n4\n5\n6\n7\nc.4 /ocaimn, percent chord\' ahead o f ax.\nFIGURE\n11.-Variation ofmaximumstick farce per unit maximum accelerationwith canter-ofgravity location. T=2 sewnds, V=4W miles par hour.\n\nDuration of maneuver,\n\nX\n\nsec\n\nFIGURE -Maximum stick for* pcr unit maximum aceelerationagainst duration of\n10\nmaneuver. zo..=O.O75c.\n\nFor case F4, the stick force for steady turns is achieved\nmainly by a balance of negative c h a f and bobweight effects.\nAs a result of the large mass unbalance required, the maximum force in the 1-second maneuver occurs at the end of the\nelevator motion.\nThe stick force is achieved solely through the action of mass\nunbalance, or a bobweight, in case Fs. Computations have\nbeen made for only the 1-second maneuver. The action of\nthe bobweight, as previously mentioned, is similar to that of\nChnfbut for a slight phase shift. The phase shift for a\nmaneuver of short duration is sufficient to reduce the adverse\ninfluence of c h D 6 . This case would show a slightly greater\ndecrease of maximum force per unit maximum acceleration\nthan case FAwith decreased duration of the maneuver.\nThe change of stick force with center-of-gravity location\n\nand recovery are of necessity rapid, strict proportionality\nbetween stick force and acceleration appears impossible\nAccording to figure 10, a\nbecause of the action of c h , , .\nstick-force gradient that is independent of duration of\nmaneuver but varies somewhat with center-of-gravity location can be obtained for a case intermediate between F2 and\nF3. This case would correspond to a certain amount of\nand\nnegative Cn,and positive Ckmf would also result in higher\nstick forces a t the start of the maneuver. A bobweight\nthat increases the stick forces can be substituted for the\npositive cam,.\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\n\nA small stick-force gradient in steady turns can be obtained\nwith fairly large negative values of the restoring tendency\nCh, and the floating tendency c h a t , approaching those of an\nunbalanced elevator. Although suitable for slow maneuvers,\nthis combination of parameters leads to a high initial value\nfollowed by a reversal of the stick force in abrupt maneuvers.\nThis dficulty can be avoided and the stick force can be made\n\n343\n\nREPORT NO. 7 9 8-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nto follow closely in phase with the airplane normal1acceleration during both abrupt and slow maneuvers by decreasing\nh and by making ChQI\nslightly positive.\nthe value of c 8\nI Cn, made zero, the stick-force gradient depends entirely\nf\nis\non a positive value of C,,, and is unaffected by the location\nof the airplane center of gravity. I n this condition, however,\nthe stick force required to initiate a maneuver may be undesirably light. I n order to prevent undesirably light stick\nforces a t the beginning of a maneuver, a small negative\nmust be retainefi.\nThe use of a bobweight in tlir e,evator control system has\nan effect similar to that of increasing ChQ.\nalthough, in rapid\nmaneuvers, there are slight Phase d i f f ~ e n c ein the sticks\nforce variations.\n\n344\n\nLANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERON-4UTICAL LABORATORY,\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE AERONAUTICS,\nFOR\nLANGLEY\nFIELD, October II,1 9 4 .\nVA.,\nREFERENCES\n1. The\ni n c r e a s e d l o c a l v e l o c i t y around t h i s c o r n e r , which i s\nfollowed by an a d v e r s e p r e s s u r e g r a d i e n t , i s r e s p o n s i b l e\nf o r t h e flow s e p a r a t i o n .\nWhen b e v e l e d a i l e r o n s w e r e c o n s t r u c t e d f o r t h e\nXP-51 a i r p l a n e , t h e b e v e l w a s b u i l t up by s p r e a d i n g\nt h e upper and lower s u r f a c e s apart behind t h e h i n g e\n(see f i g , 1, c o n f i g u r a t i o n B, and f i g . 2 of r e f e r e n c e l ) ,\nmaking a s l i g h t i n s i d e c o r n e r on each s u r f a c e . During\nt h e f l i g h t tests, i t w a s n o t e d t h a t t h e s e a i l e r o n s\nshowed a somewhat g r e a t e r u s e f u l range of d e f l e c t i o n s\nand gave s l i g h t l y b e t t e r c o n t r o l a t low speed t h a n d i d\nthe original ailerons.\nI n an a t t e m p t t o f u r t h e r i n c r e a s e t h e u s e f u l range\nof a n g u l a r d e f l e c t i o n s , t h e a i l e r o n shown i n f i g u r e 1,\nc o n f i g u r a t i o n C , w a s designed. The more pronounced i n s i d e\nc o r n e r a t t h e a i l e r o n h i n g e p o i n t causes an i n i t i a l p o s i t i v e p r e s s u r e peak, so t h a t a c e r t a i n amount of d e f l e c t i o n i s p o s s i b l e b e f o r e t h e p r e s s u r e curve becomes f l a t .\nThe purpose of t h e p r e s e n t i n v e s t i g a t i o n made i n t h e\nLangley Memorial A e r o n a u t i c a l Laboratory two-dimensional\nlow-turbulence t u n n e l w a s t o determine t h e g e n e r a l\n\n347\n\naerodynamic c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of t h i s a i l e r o n and, i n\np a r t i c u l a r , t o determine i t s u s e f u l a n g u l a r range.\nEH D\nAPPARATUS AND M T O S\n\nA scale model having a 36-inch wing chord and\n35.75-inch span w a s made t o correspond t o t h e measured\no r d i n a t e s of an i n t e r m e d i a t e s e c t i o n of t h e a i l e r o n\np o r t i o n of t h e wing (16 i n c h e s outboard from t h e i n b o a r d\nend of t h e r i g h t a i l e r o n ) of t h e XP-51 a i r p l a n e . The p r o f i l e d r a g and l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t s w e r e based on a nominal wing\nchord of 36 inches.\nThe a i l e r o n h i n g e moments were\nmeasured by means of a c a l i b r a t e d t o r q u e rod and t h e\nc o e f f i c i e n t i s based on t h e a c t u a l chord and span of\nthe aileron.\nA l l tests w e r e made a t a dynamic p r e s s u r e of\n59.7 pounds p e r s q u a r e f o o t , which corresponds t o a\nv e l o c i t y of about 150 m i l e s p e r hour and a test Reynolds\nThe test program i s\nnumber of approximately 4,000,000.\ngiven i n t h e following t a b l e .\n\n348\n\nAileron d e f l e c t i o n , +30", f o r a l l runs\nRun no.\n\nAileron\n\nGap condition\n\n1\n1\n\n0\n0\n\n1\n\n0\n\nSeal\n\n2\n\n0\n\nSeal\n\n2\n\n0\n\nSeal\n\n3\n\n0\n\nSeal\n\n3\n\n0\n\nSeal\n\n3\n\n0 , 24.1\n8.3\n\nSeal\n\nSeal\nN o seal\n\nSurf ace\ncondition\nSmooth\nSmooth\nRoughness\nstrips\nSmooth\nRoughness\nstrips\nSmooth\nRoughness\nstrips\nRoughness\nstrips\n\nRESULTS AND DISCUSSION\n\nE f f e c t of hinge-gap seal.- The e f f e c t s of s e a l i n g\nt h e hinge gap on t h e a i l e r o n c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s can b e seen\nfrom t h e r e s u l t s presented i n f i g u r e 3. With t h e gap\nopen t h e r e i s a tendency f o r a i l e r o n 1 t o overbalance\nf o r s m a l l d e f l e c t i o n s . Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1944\n\n363\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 801\nA METHOD FOR STUDYING THE HUNTING OSCILLATIONS OF AN AIRPLANE WITH A SIMPLE\nTYPE OF AUTOMATIC CONTROL\nIiy ROBERTT.JONES\n\nSUMMARY\n\nA method i s presented .for predicting the amplitude and\nfrequency, under certain simplijying conditions, of the hunting\noscillations of a n automatically controlled aircraft with lag in\nthe control system or in the response of the aircraft to the controls.\nIf the steering device i s actuated by a simple right-left type of\nsignal, the series of alternatingjixed-amplitudesignals occurring\n(luring the hunting m a y ordinarily be represented by a \xe2\x80\x9csquare\nwave.\xe2\x80\x9d Formulas are given expressing the response to such a\nvariation of signal in terms of the response to a unit signal.\nA more complex type of hunting, which m a y involve cyclic\nrepetition of signals of varying duration, has not been treated\nand requires further analysis. Several examples of application\n,)f the method are included and the results discussed.\n\nequation defining the natural periods of oscillation and the\ndamping of the aircraft without signal. The function f ( D )\nand the particular solution C(t) depend on the time variation\nof control displacement produced by a signal and on the\nstability characteristics of the airplane in the degrees of\nfreedom in which the control operates. (See reference 3.)\nIn the case of a continued signal, the usual form of the function C ( t ) is\n\nC(t) c-I+o\n=\nct\n\nwhere C, is the steady rate of turn called for by the signal\nand\nis a constant. (See fig. 1.)\n:\nSiqnal\n\n\xe2\x80\x98\n\nrime. t\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nWhen an airplane or other aircraft is directed by a simple\nright-left signal from an automatic steering device, the\nresult is usually a maintained hunting oscillation about the\ndesired path. The amplitude of this oscillation is influenced\nby the amount of backlash or \xe2\x80\x9cdead spot\xe2\x80\x9d in the control\nsystem and by the damping of the motion of the airplane.\nIn the following analysis the amplitude and frequency of\nthese oscillations is investigated in terms of the response\ncharacteristics of the airplane.\nANALYSIS\n\nThe aiialysis is based on consideration of the response of\nthe airplane (in terms of angle of yaw or pitch) to a continued\n(unit) signal (fig. 1). This response may be calculated by\nthe ordinary theory of dynamical stability and is conveniently represented in operational form (references 1 and 2) as\nfollows:\nFIGURE\n1.-Typical responw to continued sigual.\n\nThe unit response ordinarily occurs in the form\n\nfrom which is obtained\n\nRl(t)=C(t)+(C,e~lr+Cze~zr+ .)\n..\n(2)\nwhere Clt) is the steady-state motion, Cl and C2 are the\nconstant coefficients of the Heaviside expansion, and XI, Xz,\nand so forth, are the nonzero roots of the characteristic\n\nDuring a hunting oscillation, the automatic steering device\nreverses the signal periodically as the airplane swings through\nthe desired heading. A typical hunting oscillation is shown\nin figure 2. Here it is assumed that the reversal of signal\nis delayed either because of a \xe2\x80\x9cdead spot\xe2\x80\x9d in the steering\ndevice or because of backlash in the control mechanism or a\ncombination of the two. As indicated, the oscillation will\nhave a fundamental period 2 ~ / w(where w is the angular\nfrequency of the hunting oscillation) but may also involve\n\n365\n\nREPORT N O . 80 1-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ncomponents of higher frequency, depending on the natural\nmodes of oscillation of the airplanc. Ordinarily, the shorterperiod components do not have suEcient amplitude to cause\na reversal of the signal during a half cycle. In these cases\nthe variation of signal with time will be represented by a\nsimple \xe2\x80\x9csquare wave,\xe2\x80\x9d which niay be expressed as a function\nof time by\n(3)\n\ndead spot. With the frequency determined, it is possible\nalso to find the amplitude of the oscillation and the maximum\ndeviation of the airplane from its path.\nIn the simplest cases the required information may be\nobtained directly from equation ( 6 ) . These functions will show peaks near values of n w\n\n1\n4 E- sin n w t\nr ,n\n,\n\n( n = l , 8 , 5, . . .)\n\n-.\n..\n,.\xe2\x80\x9c...\nfrequencies\nResmant\n\nI\n\n..\n.I\n\n% .\n- .\n\n1\n\nwhere t = O is taken to represent a time a t which the signal\nbecomes positive.\n\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9dJ\n4\nr-----\n\nI\n\nDead spot\nFIGURE\n%-Ciirves showing in-&ihax\nnnd out-ut-phdwcorni)oncncs uf reaponso I O\nperiudic signs1\nI. The amplitude of the response\na t this instant is therefore\n\n\xe2\x80\x994L\n;\n\n1\n\n1\n\nmJ)+p(3w)+p(5w)+.\n\nEquation (ti) gives the forced oscillation of the airplane in\nresponse to an alternating signal in the form of a square wave\nof any frequency w.\nBy investigating the form of these forced oscillations at\nvarious frequencies it will be possible to ascertain whether\nsuch oscillations, under the conditions of automatic control,\nwill give rise to the assumed alternating signals of equal\nduration, and thus to establish certain ranges of w over which\ni\nl\nhunting of this type can occur. A further condition is that no more than\none complete crossing of the dead spot occurs within onehalf cycle; that is,\n\nEXAMPLES\n\nIn order to demonstrate and check the procedure described,\nassume a simple response characteristic in which the airplane immediately starts turning at a constant rate, as\ndirected by the signal. Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1946\n\n369\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 835\nPROPERTIES OF LOW-ASPECT-RATIO POINTED WINGS AT SPEEDS\nBELOW AND ABOVE THE SPEED OF SOUND\nBy RORERT JONES\nT.\n\nSUMMABY\n\nLow-aspect-ratio wings having pointed plan forms are treated\non the assumption that the flow potentials in planes at right\nangles to the long axis ofthe airfoils are similar to the corresponding two-dimensional potentials. For the limiting case o f small\nf\nangles o attack and low aspect ratios the theory brings out the\nfollowing signijcant properties:\n(I) T h e lijt o f a slender pointed airfoil momng in the direcf\nf\ntaon o its long axis depends on the increase in undth o the sections in a downstream direction. Sections behind the section\no maximum width develop no lift.\nf\n(2) The spanwiserloading o such an airfoil i s independent\nf\no the plan f o r m and approaches the distribution giving a\nf\nminimum induced drag.\n( S ) T h e lijt distr%butiono a pointed airfoil traveling pointf\nforemost i s relatively unaffected by the compressibility of the air\nbelow or above the speed o sound.\nf\nA test of a triangular airfoil at a Mach number of 1.75\nverified the theoretical zvllues of lijt and center o pressure.\nf\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe assumption of small disturbances in a two-dimensional\npotential flow leads to the well-known thin-airfoil theory\nof Munk (reference 1) and the Prandtl-Glauert rule (references\n2 and 3) a t speeds less than sonic. At speeds above the speed\nof sound, application of the same assumptions leads to the\nArkeret theory (reference 4) according to which the wing\nsrctions generate plane sound waves of small amplitude.\nAs is wdl known, the Ackeret theory predicts a radical change\nin tho properties of such wings on transition to supersonic\nvdocities and these changes have been verified by exprriments in supersonic wind tunnels (reference 5 ) .\nBoth the Avk(,ret theory and the Munk theory apply to\nllic casr of a wing having a large span and a small chord.\nThe present discussion is based on assumptions similar to\nthose used by Adicrcit a n d hiunk but covers the opposite\nextreme, namely, the* wing of small span and large chord.\nIn the latter case the flow is expected to be two dimensional\nwhen viewed in planrs prrpendicular to the direction of\nmotion.\nA theory for tlrc rectangular wing of small aspert ratio\nhas been given by Bollay ( i r f ( w i w c ~\n6). Bollay assumes a\nseparated, or discontinuous, potential flow similar to the\nwell-known Kirchoff flow and shows that under these\nrirrumstances the lift is proportional to the square of the\nangle of attack. Bolloy tlocss not consider tho effect of\ncompressibility. The present treatment (\'overs other plan\nforms and, although based on diEcrcnt assumptions, is not\n\ninconsistent with Bollay\xe2\x80\x99s theory in the limiting case of small\nangles of attacli.\nBy limiting the plan foims to small vertex angles, the\nproperties of the wings in compressible flow a t high subsonic\nand a t supersonic speeds are also covered. Tsien (reference 7)\nhas pointed out that Munlr\xe2\x80\x99s airship theory (reference 8)\napplies to a slender body of revolution at speeds greater than\nsonic. The lift and moment of such a body are not expected to change appreciably with Mach number. The\npresent paper gives an analysis of the low-aspect-ratio airfoil based on similar assumptions and shows that little change\nof the lift distribution of an airfoil of pointed plan form lying\nnear the center of the Mach cone is to be expected.\nSYMBOLS\n\nflight velocity\nangle of attack\nwing area\naspect ratio\n\n(y)\n\ndistance along axis of symmetry of pointed airfoil,\nmeasured downstream from nose\nspanwise distance, measured from axis of symmetry\nvertical distance from plane of wing\ntime\nadditional apparent mass (spanwise section)\nloca1 span\nchord\nderisity of air\ndynamic pressure -pV\n\n(:\n\n9\n\nlocal lift force (per length dx)\nlocal lift coefficient\xe2\x80\x99 ____\n(rlbldx)\nintlucecl drag\ninduced-drag coefficient\ntotal lift\nlift coefficient\n\n($1\n\nsurface potential\nspanwise-location parameter\nlocal pressure difference\nMach number, ratio of flight velocity to speed of\nsound\ndistance of center of pressure from nose of airfoil\npitching-moment coefficient\nlift a t Mach number M\nlift a t zero Mach number\nmaximum (used as subscript)\n\n78887.549\n\n371\n\nREPORT NO. 835-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nTHEORY FOR WINGS OF LOW ASPECT RATIO\n\nThe flow about an airfoil of very low aspect ratio may be\nconsidered two dimensional when viewed in cross sections\nperpendicular to the longitudinal axis. With this idealization, the treatment of the low-aspect-ratio airfoil becomes\nexceedingly simple; formulas are obtained that are similar\nin some respects to those derived by Munk (reference 8)\nand Tsien (reference 7) for an elongated body of revolution.\nPerhaps the simplest case from the analytical point of\nview is that of the long, flat, triangular airfoil traveling\npoint-foremost a t a small angle of attack. Viewed from a\nreference system at rest in the undisturbed fluid, the flow\npattern in a plane cutting the airfoil a t a distance x from\nthe nose is the familiar turo-dimensional flow caused by a\nflat plate having the normal velocity Va. (See fig. 1.)\nObserved in this plane, the width of the plate and hence the\nscale of the flow pattern continually increase as the airfoil\nprogresses through the plane. This increase in the scale\nof the flow pattern requires a local lift force I equal to the\ndownward velocity Va times the local rate of increase of\n\'\nthe additional apparent mass m , or\n\ndm\'\ndx\n\n=p f f -\n\nwell-known formula from two-dimensional-flow\nb2\nm\'=r-p dx\n4\n\nwhere b is the local width of the plate.\n\nHence\n\ndm\' db\n_ -r 2bp d x dX\ndx\n\nI per length dx will be given by the expression\nl=ra\n\nDividing by\ncoefficient\n\nb\nX\n\ndb\n\n= 2 p v bb dx\n--\n\nwhere b+/bb is a function of y.\nthe equation\n\nor\np\n\n(3)\n\nDifferentiation of 4 yields\n\n201 db\nsinedx\n\n(4)\n\n)\n\nsince\n\nand the lift\n\n= 2 p v d4J\n-\n\nThe pressure distribution thus shows an infinite peak along\nthe sloping sides of the airfoil similar to the pressure peak\na t the leading edge of a conventional airfoil. The distribution along radial lines passing through the vertex of the\n\ndm\'\nl=Vffdt\n\nBy\ntheory,\n\nupper to the lower surface of the airfoil. (See fig. 2 . ) An\ninstant later, in the same plane, the ordinates are those of a\nslightly larger ellipse, corresponding to an increase of 4. The\nlocal pressure difference is given by the local rate of increase\nof +, that is,\n\nf V 2 bdb dx\ndx\n\n4V 2and by t,he area b dx gives the local lift\n\ntriangle (lines of constant 1J is unifcrm (fig. 3), however,\nbI2\nand the center of pressure coincides with the center of area.\nEquations (1) and (4)show that the development of lift\nby the long slender airfoil depends on an expansion of thr\nsections in a downstream direction; hence a part of the\nsurface having parallel sides would develop no lift. Furthermore, a decreasing width would, according to equation (4),\nrequire negative lift with infinite negative pressure peaks\nalong the edges of the narrower sections. I n the actualflow,\nhowever, the edge behind the maximum cross section will\nlie in the viscous or turbulent wake formed over the surface\nahead; and for this reason it will be assumed that the infinite\npressure difference indicated by equation (3) cannot be developed across these edges. It is this assumption, corresponding to the Kutta condition, which gives the plate the\nproperties of an airfoil as distinct from another type of\nbody, such as a body of revolution.\n\nt"\n\ndb\ne,=rff dx\nWhen this flow is considered in more detail, it is found from\nthe two-dimensional theory that the surface potential rp is\ndistributed spanwise according to the ordinates of an ellipse,\nthat is,\n4J= f vffJ($Y-\n\n= f V a Zbs i n e\n\ny\n2\n\n(2)\n\nwhere cos 6 =-Y and the sign changes in going from the\nbl2\n\n372\n\nFIGURE l.-Flow patf2rn.\n\nFIGURE\nz.-Potential.\n\nPROPERTIES OF LOW-ASPECT-RATIO POINTED WINGS\n\nWith the aid of the Kutta condition, it may easily be\nshown that sections of the airfoil behind the section of greatest\nwidth develop no lift. A potential flow satisfying both the\nboundary condition and the Kutta condition may be obtained\nby the introduction of a free surface of discontinuity behind\nthe widest section. This surface of discontinuity (fig. 4)\nwould be composed of parallel vortices extending downstream from the widest section of the airfoil as prolongations\nof the vortices representing the discontinuity of potential\nover the forward part of the airfoil. This sheet, although\npossibly wider than the downstream sections of the airfoil,\nstill satisfies their boundary condition, since the lateral\narrangement of the vortices is such as to give uniform\ndownward velocity equal to J7a over the entire width of the\nsheet including the rearward portion of the airfoil. Since\nthe pressure difference across the airfoil is proportional to\nb+/bx and since this gradient disappears as soon as the\nvortices hecome parallel to the stream, no lift is developed\non the rearward sections.\nIntegration of the pressures in a chordwise direction from\nthe leading edge downstream to the widest section will give\nthe span load distribution and the induced drag. The span\nload distribution is\n\nor, from equation (31,\n\n~\n\nbL =2p\n\n~~\n\nFrom equation ( 2 ) ,\n\nhY\n\n+=\n\nVU\n\n\'22\n\n2\n\nv+\nsin\n\nr SPEEDS BELOW AND ABOVE THE SPEED OF SOUND\n\nThe lift of the slender airfoil therefore depends only on the\n1\n\nwidth and not on the area. If the lift is divided by zpVzS\nand if the aspect ratio A is considered to be b." then\n,,,\n\ns\n\nCL=;Aa\n\n(7)\n\nand the induced-drag coefficient is\n\nFrom equation (8) it appears that the resultant force lies\nhalfway between the normal t o the surface and the normal\nto the air stream.\nIt is seen that in the case of a rectangular plan form the\nsimplified formula (equation (4)) gives an infinite concentration of lift at the leading edge and no lift elsewhere,\nwhercas a more accurate theory would show some distribuf\ntion of the lift rearward. I the rate of increase of the width\nbecomes too great, the flow cannot beiexpected to remain\ntwo dimensional. It can be shown by examination of the\nknown three-dimensional (nonlifting) potential flow around\nan clliptic disk (reference 9), however, that the twodimensional theory gives a good approximation in the case\nof an elliptical leading edge, which indicates that the theory\n\ne\n\nHence bI&y is elliptical and independent of the plan form.\nWith the elliptical span load the induced drag is a minimum\nand is equal to\n\ndL\n\nA second integration of\n\n--\n\nbY\n\ndy across the widest section\n\ngives the total lift, which is\n\n"=&\n\n7r\n\nAspect ratio, A\nFIGURE\n5.-Comparison oi lilt calculate&by present theory for elliptical wings oi low aspecl\nratio with results of Krienes (reference 10).\n\npv2ff!l,na22\n\n(6)\n\nis applicable over a large range of nose shapes. In figure 5 is\nshown a comparison of the lift calculated by the present\ntheory for elliptical wings of low aspect ratio nith the\nresults of the more accurate three-dimensional potential-flow\ncalculations of Krienes (reference 10). The results are in\ngood agreement up to aspect ratios approaching 1. Application of equation (4) gives a center of pressure on the\nelliptical plan form a t one-sixth of the chord. Figure 6 also\nshows this value compared with values given by Erienes\'\ntheory. In this respect it appears that the agreement is\nnot so good as for the lift.\n\n-----\n\nEFFECT OF COMPRESSIBILITY\n\nFIQUBE\n(.-Wake.\n\nI n order to show the effect of compressibility, use will be\nmade of the theory of potential flow with small disturbances.\nGlauert (reference 2) and Prandtl (reference 3) have demonstrated that, a t subsonic speeds, a distribution of potential\nsatisfying Laplace\'s equation will satisfy the linearized\ncompressible-flow equation if the distribution 4 (2,y, z) is\n\nI\nI\n1\nI\n\nI\n\n~\n\nFIQURB\nI.--Pressure distribution.\n\n373\n\nREPORT NO. 836-NATIONAL\n\nAspecf\n\nratio,\n\nADVISORY COMMIT TEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nA\n\nFIGURE\n6.-Compnrison of center of pressure cnlcnlated by present theory for elliptical\nwings of low aspect ratio with results of Krienes (leference 10).\n\nforeshortened along the direction\ntransformation\n\nof motion by the\n\nThis fact may be applied in a calculation procedure by starting with a fictitious airfoil longer in the x-direction than the\ntrue one and calculating the potential distribution for this\nairfoil by methods of incompressible flow. The correct\ndimensions and correct distribution of +-are then obtained\nwhen the transformation is applied.\nFor the long slender airfoil, the potential distribution a t\neach section is similar to that for an infinitely long body;\ntherefore d+/dx and hence the local pressures vary in inverse\nproportion to the length. The foregoing calculation procedure gives a null result in this case, since the pressures\ncalculated for the fictitious airfoil at M=O will be reduced\nin the same ratio that the length is increased and the Lorentz\ntransformation to restore the correct length will also restore\nthe same pressures as those obtained a t M=O. Since\nb+/dz is unchanged by the transformation, the normal\nvelocity component and hence the angle of attack are unchanged also. These results can be obtained by referring\ndirectly to the linearized equation for the potential\n\nMach cone (fig. 7). The condition of a small vertex angle is\nalso necessary in order that the potential distribution of\nequation (2) may apply. In the case of a wing with a bluntleading-edge plan form, abrupt changes in the flow arise on\ntransition to supersonic velocities, and potential flow of the\nsubsonic type no longer exists.\nThe lift and lift distribution for rectangular surfaces a t\nsupersonic speeds have been calculated by Schlichting (reforence 11). Figure 7 shows the variation of lift-curve slopc\nwith Mach number as obtained from Schlichting\'s results for\nrectangular wings of two different aspect ratios and for the\nrange of speeds in which the two Mach cones from the tips\ndo not reach the center of the wing. I n t.he subsonic r n g e ,\nvalues given by the Prandtl-Glauert rule are shown. These\ncurves are compared with the values indicated by the present\ntheory for a triangular wing lying near the center of the\nMach cone. Figure 8 shows the travel of the center of pressure for these plan forms. It is to be noted that, with the\nblunt-leading-edge plan forms, the center of pressure travels\nfrom a point near thc quarter chord to a point near the midchord when the velocity is increased above the speed of\nsound.\n\nMach number, ill\nFIGURE\n\'i.-Varintion of lift with Mnch numher for ciiflrrrnt 111.mfrrins.\n\n(See reference 3.) If the airfoil is sufficiently slender,\nd2+/dx2can be neglected in comparison with d+/dr except\nnear the edge. Since the lift is proportional to d+/dx, the\nincrease of the lift with Mach number can therefore be\nneglected in comparison with the lift.\nIt is important to note that the theory of small disturbances is not limited to subsonic velocities and that, so long\nas the term ( 1 - M 2 ) 3%in equation (9) remains small, the\nsolution in the region of the wing will continue to be given\nby the potential (equation (2)). Evidently the Mach number cannot be increased indefinitely, for then the coefficient\nwill become so large that the first term will no longer\nof d2+/dx2\nbe negligible. The required condition will be satisfied, however, by adopting a pointed plan form with the vertex angle\nso small that the entire surface lies near the center of thc\n\n3 74\n\n*\n\n(t\n\n0"\n%\n\n6\n\n50\n\n9\n\n2\nI\n\'@O\n\nI\n\nI \'\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI I\n\n\'\'\'\' \'\nI\n\nLO\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\n20\nMach number, A4\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n30\n\nFIGURE\nR.-\'i\'rnvrl of wnter 01 pressure with Mach uumbrr Inr dificrrnt plan forms.\n\nPROPERTIES OF LOW-ASPECT-BAT10 POINI\'ED WINGS AT SPEEDS BELOW AND ABOVE THE SPEED OF SOUND\n\nTESTS OF A TRIANGULAR AIRFOIL AT SUPERSONIC SPEED\n\n8. Munk, Max M.: Tlie Aerodynaniic Forces on Airsliip Hdls.\n\nAs a test of thc foregoing analysis, a small triangular airfoil in the form of a steel plate with rounded leading cdgcs\nwas constructed and tested in the Langley model supersonic\ntunnel. The tests were made at a Mach number of 1.75.\nFigure 9 shows the details of the model and figure 10 summarizes the results of the test. At zero angle of attack a\nsmall lift and a small pitching moment occur, which are presumably the result of the camber given the airfoil by rounding off the leading edges in the manner shown by section\nA-A in figure 9. In general, the results are in good agreement with the theory if an allowance is made for this camber,\nas shown in figure 10.\n\nNACA Rep. No. 184, 1924.\n9. Lamb, Horace: Hydrodynan~ics. Sixth ed., Cambridge Univ.\nPress, 1932, pp. 146153.\n10. Krienes, Klaus: The Elliptic Wing Based on the Potential Theory.\nNACA T M No. 971, 1941.\n11. Sehlichting, H.: Airfoil Theory a t Supersonic Speed NACA T M\nNo. 897, 1939.\n4"\n\nJ\n\nCONCLUSIONS\n\n1. The lift of a slender, pointed airfoil moving in the di-\n\nrection of its long axis depends on the increase in width of\nthe sections in a downstream direction. Sections behind\nthe section of maximum width develop no lift.\n2. The spanwise loading of such an airfoil is independent\nof the plan form and approaches the distribution giving a\nminimum induced drag.\n3. The lift distribution of a pointed airfoil traveling pointforemost is relatively unaffected by the compressibility of the\nair below or above the speed of sound.\n\nN\n\n"\n\n-\n\nM o w fing attachmenf.\'\n\nSee fion A-A\n\nFIGURE\n9.-Alrfoil tested in Langley model supersonic tunnel\n\nLABORATORY,\nLANGLEY\nMEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE AERONAUTICS,\nFOR\nFIELD, May 11,1945.\nVA.,\nLANGLEY\n\nREFERENCES\n1. Mach numbci.\n1.75; Reynolds number, 1,WO.ow).\n\n375\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT NO. 863\nWING PLAN FORMS FOR HIGH-SPEED FLIGHT\nRobert T. Jones\nLangley Memoria1 Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1947\n\n377\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 863\nWING PLAN FORMS FOR HIGH-SPEED FLIGHT\nBy ROBERT\nT.\n\nSUMMARY\n\nIt i s pivinterl oui that, i n the case qf a n airfoil o f inJnite aspect ratio moving at a n angle of sidedip, the pressure distribp\ntion i s determined solely by that component qf the motion in a\ndirection normal to the leading edge. A follows fhat the attachment of plane wauee to the airfoil at near-sonic or supersonic speec1.s (Ackeret theory) m a y be auoidecl a i d the prersure\ndrag m a y be W ~ U C Q I Iby the use of plan forms in which the angle\nof sweepback i s greater than the Mach angle.\nThe analysis indicates that for aerodynamic pficiency, wings\ndesigned f o r jlight at supersonic speeds should be swept back\nat a n angle greater than the Mach angle and the angle q f sweepback should be such that the component q f velocity normal to\nthe leading edge i s less than the critical speed of the airfoil\nsections. This principle m a y also be applied to w\xe2\x80\x99ngs designed\n-fnr subsonic speeds near the speed qf sound,.for which the induced\nm the thickness tniaht ofhe\nra!ocities result\nciently great to\nshock waves.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe theory of potential flows with small disturbances is\nparticularly suit,ed for application to aeronautiral problems\nbecause the assumptions of small disturbances and isentropic flows on which this theory is bawd agree with tlic\nrequirements for efficient flight. Theories of large disturbances, which deal with tlic formation of shock waves, are of\nlesser practical interest since surh theories describe the losses\nof energy and the large drags assoriatsd with unsuitable\nforms.\nAt subsonic speeds the assumption of small disturbances\nleads to the well-known thin-airfoil theory and the PrandtlGlauert rule (references 1 and 2) ; whereas a t supersonic\nvelocities this assumption leads to the Ackeret theory\n(reference 3), according to which the wing sections generate\nplane sound waves of small amplitude. The assumption of\nsmall disturbances, although mathematically valid in the\nlimiting case, does not, of course, insure that such a condition\nwill exist with an actual body of finite thickness. Fortunately, experiments have been made that show in a general\nway the limits of applicability of this assumption. Of particular interest are the experiments of Ferri (reference 4) and\nStanton (reference 5 ) .\nAt. present both the experiments and the theory have\nbren restricted primarily to the two-dimensional flow caused\nby motion of the wing at right angles to its long axis. For\nthis case the theory shows a radical change in the properties\n\nJONW\n\nof tlic wing on transition from subsonic to supcrsonic speeds.\nA t subsonic speeds the air flows smoothly over the wing scction and no pressure drag arises. At angles of attack a\nsuction forcc is developed on the nose of the airfoil of sufficient magnitude to bring the resultant air force forward\nrelative to the chord axis to a position nearly a t right angles\nto the rcllativc wind. As soon as the speed of sound is\nrsccetled, howevrr, the nature of the flow changes and these\nfavorablc characteristics disappear. Instead there arise a\npressure drag proportional to the squarc of the thickness and\nan additional drag equal to the lift times the angle of attack.\nThese adverse effects are associated with the formation of\nplane sound waves by the airfoil. Predictions of the theory\narc borne out by experiments in supersonic wind tunnels.\nThe purpose of the present report i,s to show how thc\nadverse effects of high speed may be minimized by the use\nof a relatively large angle of sweepback, so that the type of\nflow described in tlic Arlwret theory no longer occurs. Certain cffects of sweepback have, of course, been known for\nsomc time (refcrences 6 to 9). Kussner (reference 8) mentions compressibility effects of sweepback a t subsonic\nspeeds. Busemann (reference 9) considers the effect of\nsweepback a t supersonic speeds and points out that the\ndrag associated with flows of the Ackeret type may be reduced by the use of sweepback. Busemann does not,\nhowever, consider angles of sweepback greater than the\nMach angle, which rcsult in a different type of flow.\nSYMBOLS\n\nangle of attack\nangle of sideslip or sweepback\nvelocity components along T , y ,\ncoordinates\ntransformed coordinate\nwing span\nwing chord; velocity of sound\nthickness\nvelocity of flight\ndisturbance-velocity potential\nlift\ndrag\nlift coefficient\ndrag coefficient\nMach number\nlocal pressure difference\ndynamic pressure\n\nc\xe2\x80\x9d\n\nspanwise-location parameter\n\n816587- -49\n\n379\n\nREPORT NO. 8 63-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nTHEORY OF WING AT AN ANGLE OF SIDESLIP\n\nThe primary effects of sweepback may be illustrated by\nconsidering the problem of a long and approximately cylindrical airfoil a t an angle of sideslip. Two such airfoils may\nthen be combined (with due allowance for their interference)\nto give a sweptback plan form.\nFirst consider the airfoil with its long axis parallel to the\nx-axis and with the relative wind at an angle P. to the coordinate system as in figure 1. By following equation (sa) of\nreference 2 the differential equation of the flow may be\nwritten\n\nThe Prandtl-Glauert rule follows from the assumption\nthat only the velocity component u is comparable to the\nvelocity of sound. I n the present example both u and v,\nsince they contain components of the flight velocity, are of\nthe order of magnitude of the sound velociiy c. On the\nother hand, if the flow patterns in planes perpendicular to\nthe long axis of the wing are similar (two-dimensional flow),\nthe terms buldx and bvlbx vanish.\nIf small velocity disturbances are assumed, the term w/c\nmay be neglected and the term\n\n1..,\n---vcos /9\n\nFIGURE\nl.-Plac\n\n380\n\n212\n1-2\n\n1\n\n-\n\nv (cos~p\n\n) where V cos\n\n0 is the component of the flight\n\nvelocity in the direction normal to the long axis of the wing.\nBy using this relation and introducing the disturbance potential (6, there is obtained\n\nIt is important to note that, the derivation of this equation\ninvolves no restriction on the flight ve1ocit.y V , which may\nbe subsonic or supersonic. The restriction is that the disturbance velocities b+/by and 34/bz be small relative to c.\nIf Vcos p is less than the sound velocity c, the substitution\n\nyields Laplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation\n\nand it follows that the flow patterns are similar to those\noccurring in an incompressible fluid except for an increase\nof the pressures in t,he ratio\n\nmay be replaced by\n\nI V cos p is greater than e, the substitution\nf\ny \xe2\x80\x99=\n\ns\n\nview of airfoil showing axes used in equation (1).\n\nY\n\nv cos p\n\n(5)\n\nresults in the hyperbolic equation\n\nwhich is the basis of the Ackeret theory.\nThe derivation of equations (4)and (6) is actually a special\ncase of a more general statement, namely, that the component\nof translation of a cylindrical body in the direction of its long\naxis has no effect on the motion of a frirtionless fluid. In\nthe case of a wing of constant section moving through still\nfluid, the flow is determined by the normal components of\nvelocity of its solid boundaries and these components in turn\nare completely specified by the component of motion in\nplanes perpendicular to the axis V cos 0. When the normal\ncomponent of velocity V cos 0 is less than sonic, then the\nwing-section flows are determined by solutions of Laplace\xe2\x80\x99s\nequation. As is well known, these flows show no pressure\ndrag due to thickness of the airfoil. On the other hand, if\nthe normal component exceeds the velocity of sound, the\nflow patterns are of a different type and are characterized by\nplane sound s-aves. In this case a pressure drag arises and\nthe suction for-? at the leading edge disappears (fig. 2 (a)).\n\nWING PLAN FORMS FOR HIGH-SPEED FLIGHT\n\n(n) I - r m B > E .\n\nPlan view\n\n(h) V c o s B < c\nFIGURE\n?.--Eff~ct01 leadingedge angle on pressure distrihntion.\n\nA physical explanation of tlic occurrence of smooth flow\npatterns and pressure distributions at supersonic velocities\nis as follows: If V is greater than c but V cos 0 is less, then\nthe angle of sideslip or sweepback is greater than the Mach\nangle (see fig. 2 (b)) and the airfoil will lie behind the characteristic lines along which pressure influences arc transmitted\n(Mac11 lines). Thus, although tlic fluid dircrtly upstream\nfrom a given section can rewivc no pressurc signal from this\nsection. the flow behaves as though it did receive such signals\nbecause of the successive influenc3eof similar sections farther\nupstream along the airfoil. The streamlines will thus be\ncaused to curve and follow paths appropriate to a subsonic\nflaw, although the speed is everywhere supersonic.\nFigure 3 illustrates the effect of sweepback on the change\nin cross section of a stream tube passing near the upper surface of a cambered airfoil. As is well known, the equations\nof fluid motion show a reduction in the area of a stream tube\nin the region of increased velocity above the airfoil when the\nvelocity of flight is subsonic but show an increase in the\nrross section when the velocity of flight is supersonic. In\nfigure 3 the component normal to the leading edge T\' cos 0\nis subsonic; and hence in section view the strcumlincs, following the pattern for subsonic velocities, appear to contract as\nthey flow over the upprr surfacse. I n plan view, however,\nthe resolution of velocities shows that the flow lines bend RF\n\nSection view\nFIGCRB\n3.-Chdngc in area of stream tube over upper surfnee ofsweptback wing.\n\nthey pass over the wing in such a way as to increase the\nstream-tubc area. In case the velocity of flight is supersonic, the latter effect must predominate, as is required by\nthe equations of motion. \'\nThe order of magnitude of the pressure-drag coefficient.\nand its variation with angle of sweepback are indicated by\nfigure 4. The calculations were made by applying the\nAckeret theory and formulas (4)and (5) to a wing of infinite\naspect ratio. A simple biconvex wing section was assumed\nand the angle of attack was varied so as to maintain a constant lift coeffcient of 0.5. The calculations were made for\na Mach number of 1.4,with the result that a t 45" the angle\nof sweepback becomes equal to the Mach angle and the\nfactor\n\nbecomes infinite. At this point the pressure drag due to\ntliirkncss becomes infinite and the drag due to angle of\nt\nattack (shown by the curve marked z=O) vanishes.\n\n381\n\nREPORT NO. 86 3-NATIONAL\n\nADVISOXY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\ni\n\nSection\n\nstaggering the elements in a rearward direction behind the\nMach lines as in figure 5 . I n the type of\nflow considered by hIunk, t,hereforc, a reduction in the drag\nA\n\nFIC.URE\n6.-Staggcicd lifting elemrnts in supersonic floli.\n\na\n\nFIGUKE\nl.-Variation\n\ndes\nof pressiut? drag with angle 01 slieepbock lor inRnite aspect ratio.\nM-1.4; Cr,=0.5.\n\nIn the case of a wing of finitr aspect ratio, it seems probable that in the regions of the center section and the tips\npressure drags .of thr same order as those indicated for tliesc\nsections by the Ackeret theory will appear. If the wing is\nof sufficiently high aspect ratio, however, the fraction of the\nwing area affected will bc negligible and thc pressiirc drag\nwill be nearly that given in figure 4. The other drags involved are: (1) skin-friction drag, which may be of the\norder of 0.01, and (2) induced drag, which for an aspect ratio\nof 8 is also about 0.01.\nWINGS OF FINITE SPAN AND THICKNESS\n\nSchlichting (reference 10) proposes a trapezoidal plan form\nwith tips cut away a t the Mach angle as the ideal supersonic\nwing, since in this case the wake has no influence on the lifting\nsurface and the drag is no greater than that of a wing of infinite\nspan. In the plan forms proposed by Srhlichting, however,\nthe resultant forcr remains a t right angles to the chord ;hence\nthe pressure drag is equal to the lift tinies the angle of attack.\nWith this type of flow thrre is 110 fnvorablr effect of aspect\nratio.\nIt is interesting to note that a favorable interferrnce may be\nobtained by separating the wing into lifting elements and\n\n382\n\nof clement B, caused by moving it into a position of greater\nupwash (that is, moving it backward relative to A), would be\ncompensated by an equal increasr in the drag of olcment A,\nrrsulting from tho loss of upwash a t A. (Sec fig. 5.) I n\nsupersonic flow, however, this rcciprocd relation clocs not\nexist since a lifting clement can produc~~ upwash ahcntl of\nno\nits Mach cone. lifting elements sparrd a t right angles to thr\ndirection of fliglit therrforc have no favorable intrrfrrenw,\nand it is evident that the lift-drag ratio (miriot lw improved\nmerely by increasing the aspect ratio of tlic lifting systrm.\nFavorable intrrferencc can be obtained only by arranging thr.\nlifting elements brliintl tbc Mach lines, as shown in figurr 5.\nFurther analysis is needed to determine the flow near thc\ncenter section of thc swcptback wing bccaiise in this region\nthe flow will not remain two-dimensional, as has twrn assumed. Departures from cylindrical flow rausctl by tlir tips\nwill be small since their influence cannot extend forward of\nthe Mach lines drawn from the points a t which thrse dcpartures originate in the plan form. As pointed out by Busrmann and Schlichting (references 9 and IO), cylindrical flow\nmay be preserved right up to the tips by nitting them OR\nalong the Mach lines. (Sre fig. 6.)\nAt. large angles of sweepback th(J flow near thc, vcrt.t.s i\ns\nexpected to be similar to that ovrr thc low-aspwt-ratio triangular airfoil discussed in refrrenrc 12. Figure 7 shows tho\nlift dist,ribution obtained in referrnce 12 and shows qualitat ively the type of approximation involved.\n\nWING P L k I FORMS FOR HIGH-SPEED FLIGHT\n\n/\n\n\\\n\n,\n\xe2\x80\x99\n\n/\n/\n\n/\n\n\\\n\\\n\n\\\n\n/\n\n\\\n\n/\n\n\\\n\n/\n\n\\\nFIGURE\nB.-Wing\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\nL i f f distribution ---\n\n\\\n\n-_-p A\nq\n\nwith tips cut away along the Mach lines.\n\ndb\n\n2a\n\nsin f? d x\n\n(reference 10)\n\nFinite thickness is expected to result in a pressure drag on\nthose sections near the center of the wing and further study\nis also required to establish the flow due to thickness in this\nregion. Some insight into the problem of flow near the center section may bc furnished by thc known solutions for\nsupersonic flow in three dimensions (reference 13). Finite\nthickness may also cause pressure drag in regions where the\nHow is two-dimensional if the induced velocities are great\nenough to cause shock waves. This effect may be avoided\nby increasing the angle of sweepback so that the normal\ncomponent of velocity not only is subsonic but is less than\nthe critical speed of the airfoil sections. This principle may\nalso be applied to wings designed for subsonic speeds near\nthe speed of sound.\n\nSec fion A -A\n\n2\na\nsin\n\ndb\n\ne\n\ndo\n\n-_AP\n9\n\nSection 6-6\n\nL.4NGLEY MEMORIAL\nAERONAUTICAL\nLABORATORY,\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE AERONAUTICS,\nFOR\nVA.,\nLANGLEY FIELD, June 23, 1945.\nREFERENCES\n\nE.: The Effect of Compressibility 011 the Lift of ai) Aerofoil. Jones and Kenneth Margolis\ny\n\nSUMMARY\n\nThe theory of s m a l l d i s t u r b a n c e s i s a p p l i e d t o t h e c a l c u l a t i o n\nof t h e p r e s s u r e d i s t r i b u t i o n and drag of a closed body of r e v o l u t i o n\nt r a v e l i n g a t supersonic speeds. It i s shown t h a t toward t h e rear\nof t h e body t h e shape of t h e p r e s s u r e d i s t r i b u t i o n i s s i m i l a r t o\nt h a t f o r subsonic flow. For f i n e n e s s r a t i o s between 10 and 15 t h e\nt h e o r e t i c a l wave drag i s of t h e same o r d e r as probable v a l u e s of\nt h e f r i c t i o n a l drag.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nMethods f o r c a l c u l a t i o n of t h e flow over a body of r e v o l u t i o n\nt r a v e l i n g a t supersonic v e l o c i t i e s have been known f o r some t i m e .\n(See r e f e r e n c e s 1 and 2.)\nI n v e s t i g a t i o n s along t h e s e l i n e s have,\nhowever, been confined c h i e f l y t o bodies having t h e form of\na r t i l l e r y p r o j e c t i l e s . The drag of s l e n d e r bodies and t h e e f f e c t s\nof f a i r i n g t h e rear of t h e s e bodies are t h e r e f o r e of c o n s i d e r a b l e\ni n t e r e s t i n connection w i t h t h e problem of f l i g h t a t speeds above\nt h e speed of sound.\nI n view of t h e i n t e r e s t i n p o s s i b l e a e r o n a u t i c a l a p p l i c a t i o n s\ni t w a s thought worth w h i l e t o apply t h e known methods t o a\np a r t i c u l a r case of a closed body having both a tapered nose and a\ntapered t a i l . The a b s c i s s a s of t h e i n d i v i d u a l sources are\ndenoted by\n5. P o s i t i v e v a l u e s of f ( < ) denote sources and\nn e g a t i v e v a l u e s denote sinks. B adding t h e p o t e n t i a l s due t o\ny\nt h e s i n g l e elementary sources f ( S ) d < t h e r e s u l a n t flow\n\ni s obtained.\nThe problem i s t o determine a source d i s t r i b u t i o n i n such a\nway t h a t\n\nwhere dR/dx g i v e s t h e shape of t h e meridian curve of t h e body\nIt i s shown i n r e f e r e n c e 1 t h a t t o a f i r s t\nof r e v o l u t i o n .\napproximation f o r a s l e n d e r body t h e source s t r e n g t h i s prop o r t i o n a l t o t h e rate of change of t h e c r o s s s e c t i o n of t h e body,\nthat is\ndR\nf(x) = R dx\n\na s i m i l a r approximation can be a p p l i e d t o o b t a i n t h e source\nd i s t r i b u t i o n f o r a body i n subsonic flow. The d i s t r i b u t i o n s are,\ni n f a c t , t h e same i n t h e two c a s e s w i t h t h e exception t h a t i n t h e\nsupersonic flow t h e v a l u e of f ( x ) must b e doubled t o account\nf o r t h e e l i m i n a t i o n of t h e f l u x through t h e forward cones.\n\n390\n\nNACA TN No. 1081\nBy choosing f ( ) = c x - x) and solving equation ( ) the\nx\n(3\n6,\nfollowing expression for R was obtained:\nC (1\n\nR =\n\n-\n\n2\n\nX )\n\n2\nThis expression may be recognized as the equation of a surface\nobtained by revolving a parabolic arc about its chord. The\nfineness ratio of the body is determined by the value assigned\nthe factor c\n.\nOn substituting c C -5 ) for f 5\n(3\n()\nvelocity increment a$/ax at point (x,r)\nequation ( . ) p.39, reference 1)\n95,\n\nin equation ( 4 ) , the\n(e\nis found to be - s e\n\n,\n\n- 1)\nd5\n- El2 - B2r2\n\n(3E2\n\ni-\n\n(3x2 -\n\n9\n\n1 i\n- B2r2\n\nover the body.\nAlong the axis behind the body the integration gives\ncv\n\nr\n\n(3x2\n\n-\n\n1)\n\n1\n%\n\nx + l\n\n-\n\n6x1\n\nI\n\nThe pressure coefficients were calculated by the formula\n\n(7)\n\nNACA TN No. 1081\n\nRESULTS\nCalculations have been made for a Mach number of 1.4 and for\nthree thickness ratios d/L of 0.0667, 0.10, and 0.15 corresponding\nto fineness ratios L/d of 15, 10, and 6.67, respectively. The\nresults for the three bodies are shown in figures 3, 4 , and 5,\nrespectively, and are compared with the theoretical pressure\ndistributions over these bodies in an incompressible fluid. A\ndiscussion of the errors involved in the linear theory and the\nvariation of the pressures with Mach number will be found in\nreference 3.\nComparison of the distributions in a compressible fluid and\nin an incompressible fluid shows a certain similarity, especially\ntoward the rear of the body. The effect of supersonic speed\nappears to be similar to the effect of a lag inasmuch as the\nnegative pressure peak and the region of pressure recovery are\ndisplaced rearward. The pressures along the axis behind the body\nare just twice those produced by an incompressible fluid, as may\nbe seen by referring to the velocity field of a single source.\nThe results obtained herein for the three-dimensional body\nare in marked contrast to the results obtained for two-dimensional\nbodies, or wing sections, having similar cross sections. As is\nwell known, in the two-dimensional case no pressure recovery\ntakes place at supersonic speeds, the pressure at a point being\ndetermined solely by the inclination of the surface at that point\nso that positive pressures occur wherever the cross section is\nexpanding and negative pressures occur wherever the cross\nsection is diminishing. Figure 6 shows the comparison of the\ntwo-dimensional and three-dimensional bodies for the 0.10\nthickness ratio.\nThe essential difference between the two- and threedimensional flows corresponds to the difference noted by Lamb\n(reference 4 ) between the characteristics of a plane sound wave\nand an axially symmetrical wave diverging from a center. As\nnoted by Lamb, the plane wave, which corresponds in the present\ncase to the flow produced by the two-dimensional wing section,\nis propagated indefinitely without change of form; whereas the\naxially symmetrical wave, which approximates that produced by an\nelement of the slender body of revolution, does not follow the\nform of the disturbing motion but leaves a "tail" of diminishing\nintensity and indefinite extent. Thus the wing section leaves\nno pressure disturbance in its wake, whereas the axially\nsymmetrical body is followed by an indefinite region of positive\npressure. Integration of the axial components of the pressures\n392\n\nNACA TN No. 1081\n\na c t i n g on t h e body, however, shows t h a t t h e p o s i t i v e p r e s s u r e a t\nt h e rear of t h e three-dimensional body i s s u f f i c i e n t t o cancel\nonly a small f r a c t i o n of t h e t o t a l p r e s s u r e o r wave drag.\nThe wave-drag c o e f f i c i e n t s based on t h e maximum f r o n t a l area\nw e r e found t o b e 0.049, 0.11, and 0.24 f o r t h e bodies w i t h t h i c k n e s s\nr a t i o s of 0.0667, 0.10, and 0.15, r e s p e c t i v e l y . Figure 7 shows\na comparison of t h e s e v a l u e s w i t h t h e wave drags of corresponding\ntwo-dimensional wing s e c t i o n s . It w i l l b e noted t h a t t h e wave\ndrag of t h e f u s e l a g e form i s approximately p r o p o r t i o n a l t o t h e\nsquare of t h e t h i c k n e s s r a t i o .\nAn approximate estimate of t h e t o t a l drag of a body may be\nobtained by adding v a l u e s of t h e f r i c t i o n a l drag t o t h e wave drag.\nA r a t h e r complete treatment of t h e f r i c t i o n a l drag of bodies of\nr e v o l u t i o n a t subsonic speeds i s a v a i l a b l e from r e f e r e n c e 5. B\ny\nuse of v a l u e s from r e f e r e n c e 5 corresponding t o a f u l l y t u r b u l e n t\nboundary l a y e r and a Reynolds number of 108 , t h e following estimates\nof t h e t o t a l d r a g s of the bodies w e r e obtained:\n\nThickness r a t i o\n\xe2\x80\x98Da\n\n0.0667\n\n.10\n.15\n\nC\nDvol\n\n0.14\n.17\n.29\n\n0.032\n.051\n.ll\n\nThe drag of a given volume i s an important c r i t e r i o n i n t h e\ncase of a n a i r p l a n e f u s e l a g e and i t w i l l be of i n t e r e s t t o compare\nt h e s e v a l u e s w i t h a t y p i c a l v a l u e a t t a i n a b l e a t subsonic speeds.\nFor a Reynolds number of lo8 and a t u r b u l e n t boundary l a y e r , t h e\nb e s t v a l u e given by Young ( r e f e r e n c e 5) corresponds t o a t h i c k n e s s\nr a t i o of 0.2 and i s approximately\nC\n= 0.016\nDvol\nCONCLUDING REMARKS\n\nThe t h e o r e t i c a l p r e s s u r e d i s t r i b u t i o n over a closed body of\nr e v o l u t i o n t r a v e l i n g a t supersonic v e l o c i t i e s shows a p r e s s u r e\nrecovery a t t h e rear of t h e body s i m i l a r t o t h a t occurring a t\n39 3\n\nNACA TN No. 1081\n\nsubsonic speeds. The e x t e n t of t h e region of p o s i t i v e pressure\nis, however, n o t s u f f i c i e n t t o have a pronounced e f f e c t on t h e\nwave drag. It appears t o be necessary t o use extremely slender\nshapes t o o b t a i n t o t a l drag values comparable t o those of a\nconventional a i r p l a n e fuselage a t subsonic speeds. For fineness\nr a t i o s between 10 and 15 the t h e o r e t i c a l wave drag is of t h e same\norder as probable values of t h e f r i c t i o n a l drag.\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\nNational Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics\nLangley F i e l d , Va., J u l y 8 , 1946\n\nREFERENCES\n\n1.\n\n2.\n\nPrandtl, L.:\nGeneral Considerations on t h e Flow of\nCompressible Fluids.
