Jones\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1946\n\n40 3\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No. 851\nTHIN OBLIQUE AIRFOILS AT SUPERSONIC SPEED\nBy ROBERT JONES\nT.\n\nSUMMARY\n\nThe well-known methods o thin-airfoil theory have been\nf\nf\nextended to oblique or sweptback airfoils o Jinite aspect ratio\nmowing at supersonic speeds. The cases considered thus j a r are\nsymmetrical airfoils at zero lijt hawing plan forms bounded by\nstraight lines. Because o the conical f o r m o the elementary\nf\nf\nflow jields, the results are comparable in simplicity to the\nresults o the two-dimensional thin-airfoil theory f o r subsonic\nf\nspeeds.\nIn the case o untapered airfoils swept back behind the\nf\nMach cone the pressure distribution at the center section is\nsimilar to that given by the Ackeret theory for a straight airfoil.\nW i t h increasing distance f r o m the center section the distribution\napproaches the .form given by the subsonic-$ow theory. The\npressure drag i s concentrated chiefly at the center section and\nor long wings a slight negative drag m a y appear on outboard\nsections.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nIn reference 1 it was pointed out that the wave drag of\nan infinite cylindrical airfoil disappears when the airfoil is\nyawed to an angle greater than the Mach angle. This\nobservation led to the conclusion that the drag of a finite\nairfoil could be greatly reduced by the use of sufficient\nsweepback. With such a sweptback wing the wa-i-e drag\nwould be associated with departures from the ideal twodimensional flow a t the root or tip sections and would thus\nbe a function of the aspect ratio. The present report extends\nthe theory of reference 1 to take account of these efl\xe2\x80\x99ects.\nThe treatment is based on the theory of small disturbances\nin a frictionless compressible fluid. The idealized fluid and\nits equations of motion are identical with those employed in\nacoustics in the theory of sound waves of small amplitude.\nThe application of the theory is thus limited to bodies having\nthin cross sections so that the velocity of motion imparted\nto the fluid is small relative to the velocity of sound and so\nthat the pressure disturbances produced are small relative\nto the ambieht pressure.\nThe adaptation of the sound-wave theory to the aerodynamics of moving bodies was suggested many years ago\nby Prandtl. The theory was applied by Ackeret (reference2)\nto thin airfoils moving at supersonic speed. Ackeret\xe2\x80\x99s\ntreatment. is limited, however, to infinitely long cylindrical\nairfoils moving transversely. The present theory may be\nconsidered an extension of Ackeret\xe2\x80\x99s theory to take into\n\naccount wings of finite span and wings having tapered or\nsweptback plan forms. In the case of sweptback plan forms\nthe results are markedly different from those obtained by\nthe Ackeret theory and approach. the values indicated in\nreferences 1 and 3.\nIn reference 4 Busemann describes a method for calculating the supersonic flow over bodies which produce a\nconical pressure field. Busemann shows that the flow\naround cones of circular cross sections as well as the flow\naround the tip of a rectangular lifting surface satisfies\nthis condition. The fact that a great variety of threedimensional flows can be constructed by the superposition of\nconical and cylindrical flow fields leads to an essential simplification of the airfoil theory a t supersonic speeds.\nThe present treatment differs from Busemann\xe2\x80\x99s in that it is\nfurther limited to flat bodies, that is, bodies which are thin\nin both longitudinal and transverse sections. This additional restriction leads to a much simpler mathematical\ntreatment and one which is applicable to a wide variety of\nairfoil shapes. Symmetrical nonlifting bodies arc also\ntreated in reference 5 where use is made of integral expressions corresponding to the velocity potential of plane-source\ndistribution.\nSYMBOLS\n\nV\nA\n4\n\nflight velocity\nMach number ,\nx , y , z coordinates\npoint on X-axis\nE\nzI\nlimit of integration\ndisturbance-velocity potential\nu, c, w disturbance-velocity components\nvalue of u at zz\nuz\nu\nvalue of u for conjugate arrangement\np\nlocal pressure\ndynamic pressure -pV\n4\nP\ndensity of air\nP,, Qn Legendre functions\nI\nsource-strength factor\nD\ndifferential operator\nC\n,\ndrag coefficient\nt\nthickness of wing\nslope of line source (absolute value)\nm\nC\nchord of wing\nC\n#\nJ\n\nG 9\n\n79524949\n\n405\n\nREPORT NO. 8 5 1-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nTHE OBLIQUE LINE SOURCE\n\nThe assumptions of small disturbances and a constant\nvelocity of sound throughout the fluid lead to the wellknown linearized equation for the velocity potential $ (see\nreference 6)\n(1 --2Gf2)$*,+\n\n$uvS$**=O\n\n(1)\n\nthe other components may be obtained by integrating the\ngiven component to obtain the velocity potential and then\ndifferentiating the results along the desired directions to obtain the desired components. This procedure is especially\nuseful in the thin-airfoil theory, where the complete velocity\nfield may not be required.\nAdopting the foregoing procedure, one may write\n\nThe analysis is simplified by introducing the coordinates\nx1=x\n\n--I\n\n\\\n\nyl= JM2-1 y\n%= -1\nJ 2\nM\n\nDropping the subscripts from the transformed coordinates\ngives\n$zz-#Jvv+,z=\n0\n(3)\nAccording to the thin-airfoil theory the pressures on the\ntransformed airfoil are given by\n\nS i c e u is proportional to the pressure, such a solution corresponds to a point source in the pressure field. The\nsolution for an oblique line source may be obtained by\nintegrating for the effect of a row of point sources along the\nline y = mx. It will be shown that such a line source satisfies\nthe boundary condition for a thin wedge-shape body. This\nsolution, as well as other expressions relating to oblique airfoils, can be most conveniently expressed by referring to the\noblique coordinates\nz\'= x- my\ny\' =y -mx\n~\n\nz\'= J1 -m2 z\n\nand the slope of the airfoil surface\n\ndz\n\n(See fig. 1.) (See\nreference 6 for the derivation of these elementary solutions.)\nBecause of the linearity of equation (1) a solution may be\nused to denote one of the velocity components rather than\nthe velocity potential. (Actually, of course, the thin-airfoil\ntheory shows an infinite velocity a t such points, but this is\nto be interpreted as a velocity of the order of magnitude of\nthe flight velocity V. (See fig. 4.r\nSimilarly\nFigure 3 illustrates this result.\n\nu-1-\n\n2uf u+,\n\nrepresents the pressure field for an airfoil having diarnondshape cross sections.\nThe superposition required for several sources or sinks\ncan be accomplished by manipulation of a single curve if it\nis remembered that u is a function of the ratio x/y. This\nsuperposition is greatly simplified by the conical form of the\npressure field for each single line source. Because of this\nform, the whole distribution in the plane z=O is, in effect,\nrepresented by a single curve. Since the\nsubsonic type of distribution shows no pressure drag, there\nis a continuous falling off of the pressure drag with increasing\ndistance from the root section. The pressure drag of the\noblique wing thus arises chiefly on the foremost section, and\nit. follows that the drag coefficient of the wing as a whole\ndiminishes with inereasing aspect ratio. It will be shown\nsubsequently that the effect of cutting the wing off along a\nline y=Constant to produce a downstream tip causes a\nrcduction of the pressure drag on the adjacent sections; and\nif the aspect ratio is sufficiently high, the pressure drag in\nthe region of the downstream tip may actually be negative.\nIf the wing lies ahead of the Mach lines (m>l.O) the\nSckeret type of pressure distribution occurs and a pressure\ndrag arises over the wholc length. A complete\nsweptback wing may be obtained by the addition of a symmetrical or conjugate arrangement of source lines below the\nX-axis. Values of u for this conjugate arrangement may be\ndenoted by E. Figures 2 and 3 show \'i for a single inclined\ni\nsource and figure 5 shows calculated pressure distributions\na t several sections along the span for a complete sweptback\nairfoil having beveled sections. The addition of the conjugate source lines doubles the pressure a t the root section,\nbut this interference effect falls off rapidly along the span.\nIt is noted that, as in figure 4, the most significant change\nin pressure distribution occurs along the expansion wave\noriginating a t the trailing edge of the root section. Figure 6\nshows the variation in pressure drag along the span for this\nairfoil obtained by integrating the chordwise components of\npressure at the different sections.\nThe addition of a reversed source-sink distribution having\nits origin displaced to a point O2 (see fig. 7) will show the\neffect of cutting the wing off in a direction parallel to the\ndirection of flight. It will be evident that the effect of such\na tip is characterized by the subtraction of the curves Z and\nis limited to the area lying within the Mach cone which\noriginates at the tip. It is interesting to note that pressure\ndistributions of the Ackeret type, except reversed in sign,\nare added near the tip; hence, cutting the tip off in this manner reduces the drag of adjacent sections.\n\n409\n\nREPORT NO. 8 5 1-NATIONAL\n\nl l +\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\n+\n\nFIGURE\n7.-Addition of reversed source-sinkdistribution to produce tip.\n\nFigure 8 shows the p --=e distributions over a rectangu\'\nlar airfoil having a leading edge a t right angles to the flow.\nI n the triangular area ahead of the Mach cones originating\natzthe tips the pressure is constant, as given by the Ackeret\ntheory, whereas behind these Mach cones the pressure drops\nsharply.\n\n/\nC\n\nAIBFOIL OF BICONVEX SECTIONS\n\nSechon\n\nCurved surfaces require a continuous distribution of sources\nand sinks alined with the generators of the surface. Jones\nh n e s Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1948\n\n415\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT No.\n\n902\n\nSUBSONIC F\xe2\x80\x99LOW OVER THIN OBLIQUE AIRFOILS AT ZERO LIFT\nB y ROBERT . JONES\nT\n\nSUMMARY\n\nA previozls report gave calcdutions for the pressure distribution ocer thin oblique airfoils at supersonic speed. The\npesent report extends the calcukations to subsonic speeds.\nIt is-found that theJEowsagain can be obtained by the superposition of elemenday conicalJfowJields. I n the case o the\nf\nswept-back wing the pressure distributions remain qualitatively\nsimilar a subsonic and supersonic speeds. ZJmsa distribution\nt\nsimilar to the Aekeret type of distribution appears on the root\nsections of the swept-back wing a\xe2\x82\xac M=O. The resulting positive pressure drag on the root section is balanced by negative\ndrags on outboard sections.\n\nIn general, the present development follows closely that of\nreference 1 and the reader should consult that report for\nadditional details of the method. The solutions are given\nexplicitly for M=O but are extended to other Mach numbers\nby the well-known Pranatl transformation.\nTHE OBLIQUE LINE SOURCE\n\nIt is well known that an individual velocity component of a\npotential flow will satisfy the same differential equation as tlir\npotential. In the approximation of the thin-airfoil theory\nt,he pressure depends only on the individual componrnt u,\nthat is,\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nSo far as is known, attempts to extend airfoil pressuredistribution calculations to three-dimensional flow have\nbeen confined to cases of thin lifting surfaces. I t has generally been assumed that the component of the pressure\ndistribution arising from the thickness of the airfoil will be\nbut little affected by the finite span, or aspect ratio, of the\nwing. This supposition is borne out by the known incompressible-flow solutions for flat ellipsoids. These solutions\nshow that the usual variations of aspect ratio produce small\neffects.\nCompressible-flow theory shows, however, that the effects\nof plan form become more pronounced at higher speeds.\nThe theory indicates a progressive reduction of the equivalent aspect ratio as the Mach number approaches 1.0.\nHence a t these speeds the three-dimensional character of tlic\nflow can no longer be neglected. Of particular interest are\nthe deviations from two-dimensional flow near the root\nsections of a swept-back wing, since the adverse effects of\ncompressibility may arise first in this region.\nIn the present report three-dimensional flows are obtained\nfrom a distribution of \xe2\x80\x9cpressure sources\xe2\x80\x9d in the chord plane\nof the airfoil. The shapes thus obtaincd are symmrtrical\nairfoils at zrro lift. The calculations are simplified by\nconsidering airfoils composed of conical or cylindrical surfacrs.\nIn these cases the sourres can be arranged into lines of uniform\nstrength following the generators of the surface. The relation\nbetween the strengths of the l i e sources and the shape of\nthe airfoil is the same as in reference I ; that is, each line\nsource produces a deflection of the streamlines crossing over\nthe source. The pressure field of the line source again can be\nrepresented by systems of straight rays of equal pressure\n(isobars) radiating from the ends of the line source.\n\nwhde the slope of the surface depends only on the individual\ncomponent w , that is\ndz w\n\n&=9\n(See appendix for symbols.) Hence in the thin-airfoil theory\nit is often more convenient to deal directly with the vrlocitirs\nu and w a solutions of Laplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation than to derivr\ns\nthese components from a velocity potential cp.\nSince u is proportional to the pressurr, a solution of\nLaplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation can represent directly the prrssurr distribution, hence the term \xe2\x80\x9cpressure potential.\xe2\x80\x9d In this\nterminology, the fundamental solution\n\nrepresents a point source of pressure rathrr than a point\nsource of fluid.\nTo get the effect of a row of sourrcs, or a linr sourcr, along\nthe z axis between thr points a and b, i t is nrcrmary to intrgrate equation (3):\nd5\n\nThe pressure field of the finite line source thus consists of thr\nsum of two conical prrssurr firlds radiating from the ends of\nthe line source. (Ser fig. 1.) In tlir supersonic casr (rvfcrcnce I ) , the radial isobars forming thc conical firltl wrrc\n\n84331449\n\n417\n\nREPORT NO. 902-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nI\n\nI\n\ni\n\nO\n0\n\nFIGURE\nI.-Pressure field for line soura: o length (b-n).\nf\n\nconfined to the downstream h--ch cone. Here, however,\nthe isobars extend over the whole space.\'\nIf the direction of flight is along the axis of the source\n(x axis), the flow will satisfy the boundary condition for a\nbody of revolution. However, if the line source is turned\nout to a position oblique to the stream, the boundary shape\nwill be distorted and, if the angle of obliquity is large enough\nto place the line source well outside the diameter of the\noriginal body, the figure formed will be an oblique wedge.\nThe nose angle of the wedge is formed where the streamlines\nof the main flow cross the l i e source.\nAt supersonic speeds the expression for the oblique line\nsource was obtained by applying an equivalent of the Lorentz\ntransformation, for which the wave equation is invariant.\nThe equivalent transformation for Laplace\'s equation is a\nrotation of the axes, given by\nx\'=x+my\ny\'=y-mx\n\nz\'=zJlfm2\nconieal pressure field for either the subsonic or the supersonic line source may be ob\ntamed directly from thegeneral solutions o Laplnce\'s equations o zero degree m 2,y, 2 given\nf\nf\nby W. F. Doukm. (See reference 2, page 357.) Following\nthc thin-airfoil theory, the pressure over the chord plane\n(z-+O) is taken as the pressure over the actual aidoil surface.\nAIRFOILS BOUNDED BY PLANE SURFACES\n\nIt was seen that the effect of a line source in the pressure\nfield is to cause a deflection of the streamlines crossing the\nS O I I ~ W . The deflection thus produced is equal and opposite\na t points above and below the chord plane, so that the\nsource spreads the streamlines apart. I the source is\nf\nfollowcd by a sink of equd strength, an equal opposite deflection of thc streamlines will occur as they cross over the sink.\nThe figure formed by the streamlines near the plane z=O\nwill thus be a plate of uniform thickness with a beveled\nlrading ~ t l g e . ~\n(See fig. 3.)\nAccorduig to the thm-arrfod thwry the thiekues of the f m\ni ends abruptly a t thc cnds\nal lhc wurw l a i s . 4 more exact consideration would be expected to show some rounding\nJI 1 hr I t p al t l w s ~tlgl.as mdiatcd m fimrc3.\n\nb4X1449\n\nI\n\nSecfion\n\nFIGUBB\n3 -Construction ofthe pr~ssuic\ndistribution over 3 hevrlcd leading alze.\n\n2\n\n419\n\nHEPOKT S O . 9 0 2-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AEKOSATTICS\n\nTlie pressure distribution over such a beveled edge may\nbe obtained very simply by superimposing the pressures laid\noPi on radial isobars originating from the four corners of the\nbevel. Figure 3 illustrates this process for a bevel having a\nsquare plan form. Only isobars from one tip are shown\nbecause of the symmetry of the figure.\nIn figure 3 , the line source and the line sink are parallel\nto the y axis, hence\n\nAhead of or behind this section the prcssures cancel.\nI n ease of a curved airfoil surface the chord can be tlividccl\ninto elements composed of source-sink pairs, the strengths of\nwhich are proportional to the slope of the surface a t the point.\nin question. Each pair then contributes a pressure proportional to the local slope and contributes no pressure a t other\npoints. Hence, equation (14) applies when dz/& is variable\nalong the chord.\n\nI t can be seen that if the aspect ratio of the figure is increased\nto a large value the ends of the line sources will be separated\nby a great distance and the isobars in intermediate regions\nwill approach parallel straight lines, hence the flow field\napproaches a cylindrical or two-dimensional form. The whole pressure distribution\na t one tip is thus obtained by considering only those isobars\nradiating from the opposite tip. It is evident that in the\ncase of a long narrow rectangular wing the pressures a t\neither tip will be approximately one-bdf the pressures over\nthe middle portion of the wing.\nIn case the wing is oblique the tip sections will no longer\nbe at right angles to the axes of the sonrce lines and the rays\noriginating from the adjacent ends of the source lines will\ncontribute to the pressure over the tip. I t mn be shown\nthat this component of the tip pressure distribution is\nsimilar in form to the Ackerct type of distribution, that is,\nthe pressure a t any point of the surface is proportional to\nthe slope of the surface a t that point.\nConsider h s t the sloping surface formed by a pair of\noblique source-sink lmes. The tip section lies along the\nlines of constant pressure of magnitude proportional to\nsinli-\' I/m. Between the source and sink the pressures are\nadditive, so that\n\n420\n\n\'\n\nBiconvex Section\n\nu-iwccQ,/1.ll_+i~PpI\nfx)\nFIGURE\n4.-Two-diiensianal relocity innetions for \'.verlge and bicnnvcr srctmns.\n\nThe foregoing arguments of course apply only a t the tip\nsection of the oblique wing. Hence the pressure on the root section\nincreases more rapidly with Mach number than do the pressures a t other sections of the swept?-backwing. Furthermore, the shape of the pressure distribution over the root\nsection approaches the Ackeret shape more closely as the\nMach number approaches 1.O. As shown in reference I, the\npressure distribution on the root section is exactly this shape\na t supersonic speeds, that is,\n\nand a t the tip by\n\nPlun\n\n41p\n\nSince ~inh-~--tcosh-\' large values of the argument, the\nfor\nswept-back airfoil shows no discontinuity in the. type of\npressure distribution on passing through the speed of sound.\nI t will be evident that similar reasoning can be applied to\nthe tip sections.\nAIRFOIL OF BICONVEX SEFTION\n\nThe use of a finite number of sources and sinks results in\nairfoil sections composed of straight segments. Such sections are undesirable, since they show infinite pressure peaks\na t the bends in the surface. Surfaces having continuous\ncurvature require continuous distribution of sources and sinks\nalined with the generators of the surface. The simplest of\nthese is the biconvex profile in which the upper and lower\nsurfaces are parabolic arcs and have constant curvature.\nSuch a profile requires line sources of finite strength to form\nthe desired angles of intersection of the arcs a t the leading\nand trailing edges together with a uniform distribution of\nsinks along the chord plane between the two sources.\nThe pressure field for a uniform sheet of line sources is\nobtained by integrating the field of a single line source in\ns\nthe x direction. The influence of the symmetrical, or conjugate, arrangement is\nobtained by substituting -m for m in equation (21). J o n e s\n\nSUMMARY\nRecent developments i n s u p e r s o n i c flow t h e o r y are a p p l i e d\nt o o b t a i n estimates of t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o s t h a t may b e\nachieved by a i r c r a f t employing swept-back wings. L i f t - d r a g\nr a t i o s g r e a t e r t h a n 1 0 t o 1 can b e m a i n t a i n e d up t o a Mach\nnumber of 1.4 by t h e u s e of l a r g e a n g l e s of sweep and h i g h\na s p e c t r a t i o s . A s t h e speed i n c r e a s e s i n t h e s u p e r s o n i c r a n g e\nt h e a t t a i n a b l e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o s d e c r e a s e and t h e g a i n due t o\nsweepback a l s o a p p e a r s t o diminish. A e f f i c i e n t c o n f i g u r a t i o n\nn\nf o r M = 1.4 would r e q u i r e about 60\xc2\xb0 sweepback, an a s p e c t\nr a t i o of 4 and a wing l o a d i n g of o n e - t h i r d t h e atmospheric\np r e s s u r e . For a wing l o a d i n g of 50 pounds p e r s q u a r e f o o t t h e\nc r u i s i n g a l t i t u d e would be 60,000 f e e t and t h e i n d i c a t e d\na i r s p e e d 290 m i l e s p e r hour.\n\nINTRODUCTION\nThe work r e q u i r e d t o p r o p e l a n a i r p l a n e a g i v e n d i s t a n c e\ni n s t e a d y f l i g h t i s e q u a l t o i t s weight t i m e s t h e d i s t a n c e\nt r a v e l l e d d i v i d e d by t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o of the a i r p l a n e .\nHence t h e f u e l e x p e n d i t u r e p e r m i l e of f l i g h t need n o t i n c r e a s e\nw i t h speed s o l o n g as t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o of t h e a i r p l a n e can\nbe maintained. However, w i t h p r e s e n t s h a p e s a p r o h i b i t i v e\nl o s s of l i f t - d r a g r a t i o o c c u r s on p a s s i n g beyond t h e speed of\nsound and i t i s e v i d e n t that a r a d i c a l change i n c o n f i g u r a t i o n\nw i l l b e n e c e s s a r y f o r e f f i c i e n t f l i g h t a t h i g h e r speeds.\nThe problem of an e f f i c i e n t c o n f i g u r a t i o n f o r f l i g h t a t\ns u p e r s o n i c s p e e d s w a s i n v e s t i g a t e d by Busemann i n 1935\n( r e f e r e n c e 1). Busemann concluded t h a t an improvement i n t h e\nl i f t - d r a g r a t i o a t s u p e r s o n i c s p e e d s could b e o b t a i n e d by\nsweeping t h e wing back a t a n a n g l e j u s t ahead of t h e Mach\ncone. R e l a t i v e l y much g r e a t e r\n\n427\n\nNACA TN No. 1350\ne f f i c i e n c i e s are o b t a i n a b l e when the wing i s swept back behind\nt h e Mach cone. The change i n t h e t y p e of flow when t h e wing\nl i e s i n s i d e t h e Mach cone, and t h e r e s u l t i n g increase i n\ne f f i c i e n c y have been brought o u t i n r e f e r e n c e 2. However,\nb o t h r e f e r e n c e 1 and r e f e r e n c e 2 are r e s t r i c t e d t o considerat i o n s of two-dimensional flow and hence a s p e c t - r a t i o e f f e c t s\ncould n o t b e determined. Recent developments i n aerodynamic\nt h e o r y have overcome t h i s d i f f i c u l t y , making i t p o s s i b l e t o\nestimate t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o o b t a i n a b l e w i t h p r a c t i c a l\nconfigurations.\nThe p r e s e n t r e p o r t a p p l i e s t h e s e new t h e o r e t i c a l r e s u l t s\nt o o b t a i n estimates of t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o s that may b e\nachieved w i t h an e f f i c i e n t a i r c r a f t a t s u p e r s o n i c s p e e d s .\nThe estimates are a l l based on t h e t h e o r y of small d i s t u r b ances, f i r s t because t h i s i s t h e o n l y adequate t h e o r y\na v a i l a b l e , and second because i t i s reasoned t h a t an a i r c r a f t\nproducing a l a r g e d i s t u r b a n c e i n t h e e x t e r n a l flow would b e\ninherently ibef f i c i e n t .\n\nA t v e r y h i g h Mach numbers even t h i n b o d i e s and s m a l l\na n g l e s of attack c a u s e r e l a t i v e l y l a r g e p r e s s u r e d i s t u r b ances and consequent h e a t i n g of t h e f l u i d . H e r e t h e h e a t i n g\ne f f e c t of f r i c t i o n becomes no l o n g e r n e g l i g i b l e .\n(Such\nc o n d i t i o n s are l i k e l y t o b e encountered by r o c k e t s ; however,\ni n t h e s e cases t h e e f f i c i e n c y of s t e a d y f l i g h t may n o t b e of\nprimary concern.) The p r e s e n t a n a l y s i s i s t h e r e f o r e l i m i t e d\nt o more moderate speeds where t h e e f f i c i e n c y i n s t e a d y f l i g h t\ni s of primary importance and where i t i s e v i d e n t t h a t such\ne f f i c i e n c y can b e achieved by known means.\n\nFUNDAMENTAL RELATIONS FOR WING LOADING,\nALTITUDE AND MAXIMUM LIFT-DRAG RATIO\nThe l i f t - d r a g r a t i o of a c o n v e n t i o n a l a i r p l a n e depends\np r i m a r i l y on i t s e x t e r n a l c o n f i g u r a t i o n and on t h e a n g l e of\na t t a c k and does n o t vary g r e a t l y w i t h speed provided t h e\nc o r r e c t r e l a t i o n between wing l o a d i n g and a l t i t u d e i s maint a i n e d . The t h i c k n e s s d r a g\nc o e f f i c i e n t of the r e c t a n g u l a r a i r f o i l i s t h e r e f o r e independent\nof a s p e c t r a t i o when\n\nwhere\nA = aspect r a t i o\n\nWhen t h e wing i s swept w e l l behind t h e Mach cone t h e\nflow over most of the wing i s of t h e s u b s o n i c type.\n(See\nThe p r e s s u r e d r a g i s s m a l l and may b e\nr e f e r e n c e 2.)\na t t r i b u t e d t o d e p a r t u r e s from t h e s u b s o n i c t y p e of flow i n\nt h e r e g i o n of t h e r o o t s e c t i o n . I n t h i s c o n d i t i o n t h e\noutboard s e c t i o n s of the wing have l i t t l e o r no d r a g , and\nhence t h e d r a g c o e f f i c i e n t i s i n v e r s e l y p r o p o r t i o n a l t o t h e\na s p e c t r a t i o . A t h i g h e r s p e e d s , when t h e Mach a n g l e\napproaches t h e leading-edge a n g l e , t h e d i s t r i b u t i o n of d r a g\nchanges and t h e d r a g c o e f f i c i e n t i n c r e a s e s r a p i d l y , p a r t i c u l a r l y on t h e outboard s e c t i o n s . I f t h e l e a d i n g edge i s\nt o o n e a r t h e Mach cone, t h e d r a g of t h e swept wing w i l l\nexceed t h a t of t h e s t r a i g h t wing.\nF i g u r e 2 shows a p l o t s i m i l a r t o f i g u r e 1 of t h e\nv a r i a t i o n of d r a g w i t h Mach number f o r t a p e r e d swept-back\na i r f o i l s . The optimum l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t\n\n447\n\nNACA TN No. 1350\nc a l c u l a t e d by e q u a t i o n\n\n(lo),\n\ni s a l s o shown i n f i g u r e 15.\n\nF i g u r e 16 shows t h e v a r i a t i o n of (L/D)ma w i t h m a t\nd i f f e r e n t Mach numbers.\nIt i s n o t e d t h a t t h e optimum v a l u e of m\ni s d i f f e r e n t f o r d i f f e r e n t Mach numbers; t h e r e a p p e a r s t o b e\nno f i x e d r e l a t i o n between t h e sweepback a n g l e and t h e Mach\nangle. It w i l l b e noted t h a t up t o M L 2 t h e\nswept-back wing i s much more e f f i c i e n t t h a n t h e s t r a i g h t wing.\nThe d i f f e r e n c e is smaller a t t h e h i g h e r Mach numbers, however,\nand t h e advantages of sweepback a t v e r y h i g h Mach numbers may\nb e q u e s t i o n e d . I n each case t h e e f f i c i e n c y d i m i n i s h e s w i t h Mach\nnumber.\nAlthough t h e c o n f i g u r a t i o n s shown i n f i g u r e s 14 and 15\nappear from t h e c a l c u l a t i o n s t o g i v e t h e b e s t l i f t - d r a g r a t i o s ,\ni t i s n o t t o b e assumed t h a t t h e s e c o n f i g u r a t i o n s are a c t u a l l y\nthe m o s t s u i t a b l e f o r p r a c t i c a l u s e . I n p r a c t i c e t h e wing must\nof c o u r s e have a f i n i t e t i p chord and may a l s o r e q u i r e some\ncamber o r twist t o avoid t h e high c o n c e n t r a t i o n of l o a d n e a r\nt h e t i p s . A l s o , as h a s been p r e v i o u s l y remarkpd, t h e l o c a t i o n\nof t h e t r a i l i n g edge on, r a t h e r t h a n behind, t h e Mach l i n e s\nw a s c h i e f l y a computational device. I t i s p r o b a b l e t h a t a\ng r e a t e r sweep of t h e t r a i l i n g edge would b e d e s i r a b l e .\nSuch m o d i f i c a t i o n s w i l l of c o u r s e cause changes i n t h e\nl i f t - d r a g r a t i o . However, i t i s b e l i e v e d t h a t t h e h i g h e s t l i f t d r a g v a l u e s shown can a c t u a l l y b e approached w i t h p r a c t i c a l\nconfigurations\nThe t h e o r e t i c a l v a l u e s of C D ~ / C L \xe2\x80\x99 f o r t h e\nwing w i t h i t s t r a i l i n g edge along t h e Mach cone are somewhat\nmore f a v o r a b l e t h a n t h e v a l u e s t o b e expected w i t h a wing\nhaving i t s t r a i l i n g edge behind t h e Mach cone. O t h e o t h e r\nn\nhand, t h e l o c a t i o n of t h e t r a i l i n g edge along t h e Mach l i n e i s\nu n f a v o r a b l e from t h e s t a n d p o i n t of t h i c k n e s s d r a g , as shown by\nf i g u r e 2 , Hence t h e n e t e f f e c t of t r a i l i n g - e d g e l o c a t i o n on\ne\n\n44 8\n\nNACA TN No. 1350\n\n(L/D)max\ni s n o t expected t o b e v e r y pronounced.\nThe b e n e f i c i a l e f f e c t s of t a p e r i n g t h e wing i n d i c a t e d by f i g u r e 1 7 may\na l s o b e assumed t o h o l d q u a l i t a t i v e l y f o r more moderate d e g r e e s\nof t a p e r .\n\nA i r f o i l Section\nNo a t t e m p t w a s made i n t h e a n a l y s i s t o f i n d an optimum\na i r f o i l p r o f i l e . The s e c t i o n assumed f o r t h e c a l c u l a t i o n s\nhas a parabolic thickness d i s t r i b u t i o n .\nI n p r a c t i c e , as\np r e v i o u s l y mentioned, i t would b e n e c e s s a r y t o round o r\ncamber t h e l e a d i n g edge t o a c h i e v e t h e p r e d i c t e d v a l u e s of\nC D ~ / C L ~ . It might a l s o b e advantageous t o u s e (with t h e\nt a p e r e d p l a n form) a cusped t r a i l i n g edge. T h i s d e v i c e would\ne n a b l e t h e d e s i g n e r t o t a k e advantage of t h e h i g h l i f t t o b e\no b t a i n e d by p l a c i n g t h e t r a i l i n g edge a l o n g t h e Mach l i n e s ,\nwhile e f f e c t i v e l y giving the thickness d i s t r i b u t i o n a greater\na n g l e of sweep and t h u s a v e r t i n g t h e l a r g e wave d r a g which\narises when t h e g e n e r a t o r s of t h e t h i c k n e s s d i s t r i b u t i o n are\nt o o n e a r t h e Mach l i n e s .\n\nF r i c t i o n Drag\nThe allowance of 0.006 made f o r t h e f r i c t i o n d r a g c o e f f i c i e n t of t h e wing corresponds t o a t u r b u l e n t boundary l a y e r\na t a Reynolds number of lo7. The assumption of t u r b u l e n t\nf r i c t i o n f o r b o t h wing and f u s e l a g e i s b e l i e v e d t o b e\nc o n s e r v a t i v e , s i n c e t h e r e are i n d i c a t i o n s t h a t l a r g e areas of\nlaminar flow can b e achieved a t s u p e r s o n i c s p e e d s . The\nimportance of m a i n t a i n i n g l a m i n a r flow o r o t h e r d i s e reducing\nt h e f r i c t i o n can b e s e e n from t h e magnitudes of t h e v a r i o u s\nd r a g components w i t h t h e b e s t c o n f i g u r a t i o n ( f i g . 15, m = 0.5)\na t a Mach number of 1 - 4 . The v a r i o u s components are shown\ni n t h e following t a b l e :\n(1) Thickness d r a g of wing\n0.0041\n0060\n(2) F r i c t i o n d r a g of wing\n0020\n(3) Thickness d r a g of body\n(4) F r i c t i o n d r a g of body\na 0036\n(5) Drag of v e r t i c a l t a i l\n.0010\n.0167\nT o t a l d r a g a t z e r o l i f t : CD, Drag due t o l i f e\nC D =\n~\n-0167\nTotal drag\n0 0334\nF r i c t i o n d r a g (2) + ( 4 )\n0 0096\ne\n\ne\n\n449\n\nNACA TN No. 1350\n\nNote t h a t t h e f r i c t i o n d r a g i s more t h a n 50 p e r c e n t of t h e\nt o t a l d r a g a t z e r o l i f t . I n t h i s case the maximum l i f t - d r a g\nr a t i o is 10.7; w i t h completely laminar flow t h e r a t i o would\ni n c r e a s e t o about 15.\n\nOptimum Wing Loading and A l t i t u d e\nThe a n a l y s i s i n d i c a t e s t h a t r e a s o n a b l y good aerodynamic\ne f f i c i e n c i e s are o b t a i n a b l e up t o Mach numbers of 1.5. A t\nM = 1.4 t h e b e s t c o n f i g u r a t i o n s t u d i e d s h o u l d o p e r a t e n e a r a\nl i f t c o e f f i c i e n t of 0.35.\nFrom e q u a t i o n ( 5 ) , t h e wing l o a d i n g\nf o r t h i s case works o u t t o b e about one-half t h e atmospheric\np r e s s u r e . T h i s p r e s s u r e d i s t u r b a n c e can no l o n g e r b e considered\ns m a l l and t h e q u e s t i o n arises as t o whether t h e l i n e a r i z e d\nt h e o r y can b e c o n s i d e r e d a p p l i c a b l e i n t h i s case. No a c c u r a t e\na n a l y s i s of t h i s l i m i t a t i o n can b e given a t p r e s e n t . However,\nan approximate c r i t e r i o n can b e deduced by comparing t h e flow\nover t h e swept-back wing w i t h t h e two-dimensional s u b s o n i c flow\nover a wing s e c t i o n a t t h e same component Mach number as\ns u g g e s t e d i n r e f e r e n c e 2. When t h i s comparison i s made f o r\nc o n f i g u r a t i o n s n e a r t h e optimum i n f i g u r e 15 i t i s found t h a t\nt h e wing s e c t i o n s are o p e r a t i n g beyond t h e i r c r i t i c a l Mach\nnumbers a t t h e i n d i c a t e d optimum l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t . Thus i t\na p p e a r s t h a t t h e optimum l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t w i l l a c t u a l l y b e\ns m a l l e r than i s i n d i c a t e d by t h e l i n e a r i z e d t h e o r y . For t h e\nb e s t c o n f i g u r a t i o n a t M = 1.4, i t a p p e a r s t h a t t h e optimum\nl i f t c o e f f i c i e n t may b e n e a r e r 0.25 t h a n t h e 0.357 i n d i c a t e d\nby f i g u r e 15. I n t h i s case t h e L / h a w i l l b e diminished\nfrom 10.7 t o 10, and t h e optimum wing l o a d i n g from one-half t o\napproximately o n e - t h i r d atmospheric p r e s s u r e . A t sea l e v e l\nt h e wing l o a d i n g r e q u i r e d would b e 700 pounds \xe2\x80\x98per s q u a r e f o o t ,\nb u t f o r o p e r a t i o n a t 60,000 f e e t t h e much more r e a s o n a b l e f i g u r e\nof 50 pounds p e r s q u a r e f o o t i s o b t a i n e d . A t t h i s a l t i t u d e t h e\nt r u e a i r s p e e d i s 900 m i l e s p e r hour and t h e i n d i c a t e d a i r s p e e d\n290 m i l e s p e r hour.\n\nA e A e r o n a u t i c a l Jones\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nJuly 1947\n\n473\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nNATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE F R AERONAUTICS\nO\nTECHNICAL NOTE NO. 1402\n\nEFFECTS OF SWEEPMCK ON BOUNDARY LAYER\n\nAND SEPARATION\nB Robert T. Jones\ny\n\nSUMMARY\nFollowing t h e l a w of stress adopted i n t h e Navier-Stokes equations,\nt h e c o n f i g u r a t i o n of t h e v i s c o u s flow i n p l a n e s a t r i g h t a n g l e s t o t h e\na x i s of an i n f i n i t e c y l i n d e r i s found t o be independent of t h e a x i a l\nmotion of t h e c y l i n d e r . I n t h e l i m i t i n g case of a yawed o r swept wing\nof v e r y high a s p e c t r a t i o , c e r t a i n boundary-layer and s e p a r a t i o n phenomena\nare t h u s determined independently by t h e crosswise component of v e l o c i t y .\nIt f o l l o w s t h a t t h e e f f e c t of sweepback i s t o i n c r e a s e t h e area of\ns t a b l e laminar flow and t o d e c r e a s e t h e l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t a t which flow\ns e p a r a t i o n occurs.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nExperimental o b s e r v a t i o n s of t h e v i s c o u s flow over o b l i q u e wings\nand bodies p r e s e n t such complex phenomena t h a t even t h e most approximate s i m p l i f y i n g p r i n c i p l e may b e of v a l u e i n i n t e r p r e t i n g t h e s e\nobservations. I n t h e case of compressible flow, such a s i m p l i f y i n g\np r i n c i p l e w a s found by studying t h e i d e a l i z e d problem of t h e p e r f e c t l y\nc y l i n d r i c a l o b l i q u e flow, corresponding t o t h e i n f i n i t e a s p e c t - r a t i o\nwing, o r t h e i n f i n i t e l y s l e n d e r body. I n t h a t case, t h e equations\nof motion t o g e t h e r w i t h t h e boundary c o n d i t i o n s a p p l i c a b l e t o a moving\nc y l i n d e r i n a f r i c t i o n l e s s f l u i d showed t h a t (1) t h e flow p a t t e r n and\np r e s s u r e d i s t u r b a n c e s i n planes a t r i g h t a n g l e s t o t h e c y l i n d r i c a l axis\nare determined s o l e l y by t h e component of v e l o c i t y i n t h e s e p l a n e s\nand, (2) t h e a x i a l motion of t h e c y l i n d e r produces no e f f e c t on t h e flow.\nN w t h e q u e s t i o n is: Can similar g e n e r a l i z a t i o n s b e made concerning t h e\no\nviscous flow produced by a n i n f i n i t e c y l i n d e r moving o b l i q u e l y ? For\nt h i s case, t h e Navier-Stokes equations, t o g e t h e r w i t h t h e given boundary\nc o n d i t i o n s , supply a d e f i n i t e answer. It can b e shown t h a t p r o p o s i t i o n\n(1) s t i l l a p p l i e s while p r o p o s i t i o n (Z), of course, does not. Thus i t\ni s t o be expected t h a t v a r i o u s f e a t u r e s of t h e viscous flow such as\nboundary-layer t h i c k n e s s and s e p a r a t i o n p o i n t - observed i n p l a n e s\nif\n\n475\n\nNACA TN No. 1402\n\nat\n\nr i g h t a n g l e s -- c y l i n d r i c a l axis w i l l b e determined s o l e l y by\nto the\nt h e component of v e l o c i t y of t h e c y l i n d e r i n t h e s e planes.\nOBLIQUE VISCOUS F O\nLW\n\nTo v e r i f y t h i s f e a t u r e of t h e o b l i q u e flow, consider f i r s t t h e\nd i s t u r b a n c e produced by a pure crosswise motion of t h e c y l i n d e r . The\nmotion and t h e s t a t e of stress w i l l b e t h e same i n a l l c r o s s s e c t i o n s .\nEach p a r t i c l e i n a given c r o s s s e c t i o n i s t h u s a s s o c i a t e d w i t h a whole\ns t r i n g of p a r t i c l e s , o r a f i l a m e n t , connecting t h e v a r i o u s c r o s s s e c t i o n s\nand moving as a u n i t . Obviously w e may i n t r o d u c e any a r b i t r a r y lengthw i s e t r a n s l a t i o n of t h e s e f i l a m e n t s without a f f e c t i n g t h e i r progress\na c r o s s t h e c y l i n d e r , s i n c e each p a r t i c l e w i l l simply move from one\nc r o s s s e c t i o n t o another similar one. Such a lengthwise motion of t h e\nf i l a m e n t s w i l l , of course, i n t r o d u c e shearing stresses i n t h i s d i r e c t i o n ,\nb u t t h e s e stresses w i l l n o t a f f e c t t h e rate of shear and hence w i l l\nn o t a f f e c t t h e shearing stress i n t h e crosswise d i r e c t i o n .\nThe independence of t h e c r o s s flow and t h e a x i a l flow i s , of course,\nt h e r e s u l t of t h e l a w of shearing stress adopted i n t h e Navier-Stokes\nequations. The s h e a r i n g stress i n one d i r e c t i o n i s taken t o be prop o r t i o n a l t o t h e rate of shearing i n t h i s d i r e c t i o n and i s independent\nof t h e rate of s h e a r i n g i n o t h e r d i r e c t i o n s . A t high rates of shear\nwhere a n a p p r e c i a b l e temperature rise i s involved, t h e independence of\nt h e s h e a r i n g stresses can no longer b e assumed. Such c o n d i t i o n s occur\na t v e r y h i g h Mach numbers and are, of course, beyond t h e range of v a l i d i t y\nof t h e Navier-Stokes equations.\nTHE LAMINAR BOUNDARY LAYER ON AN OBLIQUE FLAT PLATE\n\nThe s i m p l e s t case of v i s c o u s , c y l i n d r i c a l flow is t h e laminar\nboundary l a y e r over a f l a t p l a t e (Blasius flow). The w e l l known\nr e s u l t of B l a s i u s shows a p a r a b o l i c i n c r e a s e of boundary-layer thickn e s s beginning a t t h e l e a d i n g edge, i.e.,\n\nI n accordance w i t h t h e foregoing statements t h e boundary-layer t h i c k n e s s\na t any g i v e n p o i n t w i l l n o t be a f f e c t e d by t h e i n t r o d u c t i o n of an\na d d i t i o n a l v e l o c i t y p a r a l l e l t o t h e leading edge o f t h e p l a t e . I n\nf a c t , B l a s i u s \' formula shows no change i n 6 i f w e change x so t h a t\n\n476\n\nNACA TN No. 1402\ni t i s measured along t h e d i r e c f i o n of t h e new r e s u l t a n t v e l o c i t y since,\ni n t h i s case, both x and V are changed i n t h e same r a t i o , f i g u r e 1.\nThe r e s u l t a n t drag on t h e oblique p l a t e l i e s i n t h e d i r e c t i o n of t h e\nr e s u l t a n t v e l o c i t y , but t h e component f o r c e i n t h e d i r e c t i o n a t r i g h t\nangles t o t h e leading edges can be determined s o l e l y from t h e v e l o c i t y\ncomponent i n t h i s d i r e c t i o n .\n\nAn approximate s o l u t i o n f o r t h e laminar boundary l a y e r on an\noblique p l a t e with a favorable pressure gradient has been given r e c e n t l y\nn\nby Prandtl i n reference 1. O t h e assumption t h a t t h e flow i n t h e\nboundary l a y e r departs only s l i g h t l y from t h e d i r e c t i o n of t h e main\nstream, P r a n d t l obtains t h e v e l o c i t y p r o f i l e of t h e boundary layer i n\ntwo mutually perpendicular d i r e c t i o n s . It appears t h a t t h e r e s u l t a n t\nf r i c t i o n drag i s inclined away from t h e stream d i r e c t i o n toward t h e\nd i r e c t i o n of t h e favorable pressure gradient.\nWIND-TUNNEL TESTS O CIRCULAR WIRES\nF\nI\n\nWith more complex flows involving pressure stresses as w e l l as\nviscous stresses complete s o l u t i o n s have been obtained only f o r very\nlow Reynolds numbers. A t high Reynolds numbers t h e pressure stresses\npredominate but v i s c o s i t y plays an important p a r t through i t s e f f e c t\non separation. Thus i n t h e case of a c i r c u l a r cylinder t h e flow separates\napproximately half-way around t h e surface and a KZlrmZln vortex street\nis formed i n t h e wake. One would expect t h a t t h e geometry of t h i s\np a t t e r n , t h e vortex frequency, etc., would depend only on t h e crosswise\ncomponent of v e l o c i t y .\nFig. 2 shows t h e r e s u l t of a wind-tunnel test on a c i r c u l a r w i r e\na t d i f f e r e n t angles of yaw (reference 2). I n these tests t h e Reynolds\nnumber based on t h e crosswise component varied from lo2 t o lo3\na\nrange i n which t h e drag c o e f f i c i e n t i s nearly constant. Over t h i s\nrange t h e crosswise component of t h e drag f o r c e on t h e w i r e should be\n\n-\n\nproportional t o\n\nand t h e tests do i n d i c a t e t h i s variation.\n\n(V cos f3)2\n\nI n t h e case of t h e c i r c u l a r cylinder t h e r e is a c e r t a i n c r i t i c a l\nReynolds number a t which t h e l i n e of separation s h i f t s r a p i d l y t o a\nmore rearward position. This s h i f t i s accompanied by a marked reduct i o n i n t h e drag c o e f f i c i e n t . I f t h e cylinder i s oblique, t h e c r i t i c a l\nReynolds number should be delayed t o a higher speed such t h a t\n\nV cos B d\nV\n\n= Rcritical\n\n477\n\nNACA TN No. 1402\n\nSTABILITY OF LAMINAR FLOW\n\nIt is well known that a laminar boundary layer or surface of\ndiscontinuity becomes unstable at certain Reynolds numbers. Calculations of the stability of the laminar boundary layer in twodimensional motion have been made by Tollmein, Schlichting and,\nmore recently, by Lees and Lin. The theoretical predictions have been\nverified experimentally in important respects by Dryden, Schubauer\nand Skramstad (references 3 and 4 ) , who find that transition to\nturbulent flow can result from fluctuations in the laminar layer. In\nthe case of a yawed plate or airfoil the calculated boundary-layer\nwaves would, of course, have their crests and troughs aligned with the\nleading edge and their stability would be determined by the Reynolds\nnumber of the crosswise component of the stream velocity. In case\ntransition is caused by such oscillations one would expect the transition\nline to recede from the leading edge with increasing angles of yaw in\na stream of constant velocity. On the other hand, if transition is\ncaused by roughness of the surface, a cylindrical flow cannot be assumed\nand the transition may, of course, be affected differently:\nAn interesting case which departs radically from the usual\nassumptions made for a cylindrical boundary has been investigated by\n.\n)\nG. I Taylor (see reference 5. Taylor investigates the stability of\nviscous flow in the annular space between two concentric circular\ncylinders in relative rotation. After a certain Reynolds number is\nexceeded the cylindrical form of the flow disappears and a regular\nvortex formation appears with the vortex rotations at 90\xc2\xb0 to the\nrotation of the cylinders, and alternating periodically along their\nlength. Gortler and Liepmann find similar three-dimensional disturbances\nin other cases of boundary-layer flow along convex walls. According\n)\nto Liepmann(reference 6 transition from laminar to turbulent flow\nresults from this three-dimensional type of instability if the surface\nis concave, but transition on a plane or convex surface results from\nthe two-dimensional type of wave motion mentioned earlier.\nFLOW SEPARATION AND MAXIMDM LIFT\nThe separation of flow over a straight wing occurs when the\nadverse pressure increase opposing the motion is sufficient to reverse\nthe momentum of the fluid in the boundary layer (see Fig. 3 ) . In the\ncase of the oblique wing the resultant pressure gradient is of course\nat right angles to the long axis of the wing and both this pressure\nand the components of the viscous stress distribution lying in this\ndirection will be determined by the crosswise component of velocity.\n\n478\n\nNACA TN No.\n\n1402\n\nHence t h e circumstances leading t o separation of flow over t h e s t r a i g h t\nwing w i l l be reproduced if t h e crosswise component of motion of t h e\noblique wing i s t h e same as that of t h e s t r a i g h t wing. I n both cases\nseparation w i l l be taken t o mean t h a t t h e f l u i d i n t h e boundary l a y e r\nhas l o s t t h e component of momentum t h a t carries it across t h e wing,\nIn t h e oblique case t h e boundary l a y e r w i l l then flow i\'n a d i r e c t i o n\np a r a l l e l t o t h e long axis.\nThe known adverse e f f e c t s of sweepback on t h e l i f t and drag of a\nwing can be a t least p a r t i a l l y explained by t h i s analysis. According\nt o t h e two-dimensional theory a wing which shows boundary-layer\nr e v e r s a l and maximum l i f t a t CL\n1.4, if yawed 45O, would show\nseparation accompanied by a f u l l y developed lateral motion of t h e\nboundary l a y e r a t CL = .7.\nI n each case t h e l i f t would drop and t h e\nr e s u l t a n t f o r c e would f a l l back t o a p o s i t i o n nearly a t r i g h t angles\nt o t h e chord because of t h e l o s s of t h e suction f o r c e on t h e leading\nedge. A t 60\xc2\xb0 yaw t h e predicted m a x i m u m l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t would be only .35.\nWind-tunnel observations of t h e boundary-layer flow over swept-back wings\nagree q u a l i t a t i v e l y with t h e s e predictions i n regard t o flow separation\nbut do not show t h e expected l o s s i n maximum l i f t . Instead of a drop\ni n l i f t a f t e r boundary-layer separation, some experiments i n d i c a t e\nan i n c r e a s e i n l i f t curve slope a t t h i s point. Ordinarily t h e f o r c e s\nand moments on t h e swept wing do begin t o show non-linear v a r i a t i o n s\na t t h e separation point, however, and t h e r e i s a sharp rise i n drag a t\nt h i s point i n d i c a t i n g t h a t t h e l o s s of suction a t t h e leading edge does\noccur. The tendency t o follow t h e two-dimensional theory up t o t h e\npoint of separation and t h e p a r t i a l f a i l u r e of t h e theory a f t e r separat i o n i n d i c a t e s t h a t t h e "end e f f e c t s " are much g r e a t e r i n the separated\nflow than i n t h e unseparated flow. This s i t u a t i o n is not s u r p r i s i n g\nfrom t h e physical standpoint, s i n c e t h e influence of t h e t i p s would\nobviously be more extensive i n t h e case of a t h i c k separated region\nthan i n t h e case of a r e l a t i v e l y t h i n boundary layer. It must be\nsupposed, however, t h a t as t h e aspect r a t i o of t h e swept-back wing\ni s increased i t s maximum l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t w i l l show an increasing\ntendency t o follow t h e cos2 l a w . The experiments on oblique c l r c u l a r\nw i r e s , which involve l a r g e regions of separated flow and y e t follow\nt h e two-dimensional theory, lend support t o t h i s hypothesis.\n\n-\n\nA e Aeronautical Laboratory,\nms\nNational Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics,\nMoffett F i e l d , C a l i f .\n\n479\n\nNACA TN No. 1402\n\nREFZRENCES\n\n1. I n o r d e r t o d e p i c t such motions mathematically, a f r i c t i o n l e s s ,\np e r f e c t l y e l a s t i c f l u i d i s , t h e r e f o r e , adopted and a v e l o c i t y f i e l d uvw\nmust b e found which i s c o n s i s t e n t w i t h Newton\'s l a w s and which\na g r e e s a t t h e a i r f o i l s u r f a c e w i t h t h e outward, o r normal, v e l o c i t y\nimparted by t h e motion of t h e a i r f o i l . The p r e s s u r e d i s t r i b u t i o n over\nt h e a i r f o i l s u r f a c e may l i k e w i s e be taken as t h e p r e s s u r e i n t h e chord\nplane and i s obtained from t h e well-known formula f o r t h e p r e s s u r e i n a\nsound wave\n\n486\n\no r , i n steady f l m\n\nfrom which\n\nThus f a r , nothing h a s been s a i d about subsonic- o r s u p e r s o n i c - f l i g h t\nv e l o c i t i e s . This d i s t i n c t i o n arises i n equation (2) and i n t h e form of i t s\ns o l u t i o n s when M 3 1\n.\nExcept f o r t h i s d i s t i n c t i o n , v a r i a t i o n s of M are of no consequence\nmathematically s i n c e they can be r e p r e s e n t e d by an e q u i v a l e n t change i n\nt h e scale of x r e l a t i v e t o t h e o t h e r coordinates. This change (of scale\ni s known as t h e Prandtl-Glauert transformation and i s given as\n\nor\n\nThe formula t o b e used depends on whether t h e f l i g h t v e l o c i t y i s subsonic\no r supersonic.\nI n t h e l a t t e r case, t h e s i g n i f i c a n c e of t h e transformation\ni s e a s i l y seen, s i n c e t h i s transformation serves t o maintain t h e c o r r e c t\ni n c l i n a t i o n of t h e Mach waves t o t h e l i n e of f l i g h t a t d i f f e r e n t speeds.\nIt should b e noted t h a t t h e sudden t r a n s i t i o n of t h e d i f f e r e n t i a l equation\nfrom t h e e l l i p t i c t o t h e h y p e r b o l i c type a t M = 1.0 i s a f e a t u r e of t h e\nsteady-flow equation (equation (2)) and does n o t , of course, arise i n\nconnection with equation (1).\nThe e s s e n t i a l f e a t u r e s of t h e s t e a d y flow a t subsonic o r supersonic\nspeeds can then be a s c e r t a i n e d from s o l u t i o n s of t h e reduced o r normalized\nequations, For M = 0 ,\n\n487\n\nand f o r\n\nM\n\n=\n\n1.41,\n\n4 s - ($yy - 4zz\n\n= 0\n\nA s may b e shown by d i r e c t d i f f e r e n t i a t i o n , e q u a t i o n s (3) and ( 4 ) p o s s e s s\nt h e primary s o l u t i o n s\n\n4\nwhere\n\na,\n\n8 , and\n\ny\n\n= f(ax\n\n+\n\nBy\n\n+ yz)\n\nare q u a n t i t i e s determined s o t h a t f o r e q u a t i o n (3)\n\na2\n\n+\n\n+ y2\n\n= 0\n\na2\n\n- $2 - y2\n\n= 0\n\n$2\n\nand s o t h a t f o r e q u a t i o n ( 4 )\n\nThe c y l i n d r i c a l flow f i e l d , which i s t h e b a s i s of t h e two-dimensional o r\nwing s e c t i o n t h e o r y , i s o b t a i n e d by s p e c i a l i z i n g t h e primary s o l u t i o n\nt o t h e two c o o r d i n a t e s x and z .\nI n t h i s case f o r e q u a t i o n ( 3 )\na = 1.0 and y = i ; and f o r e q u a t i o n ( 4 ) c1 = 1.0 and y = 1.0 s o t h a t\nt h e g e n e r a l s o l u t i o n s f o r t h e c y l i n d r i c a l o r two-dimensional flow f i e l d\nbecome\n\n4\n\n= f(x f iz)\n\nor\n\nu = f\'(x 5 iz)\nw = 5 i u\n\nThe g e n e r a l s o l u t i o n i s t h e b a s i s of t h e Munk t h e o r y , as w e l l as t h e more\ne x a c t wing s e c t i o n a n a l y s e s which depend on t h e t h e o r y of f u n c t i o n s of a\ncomplex v a r i a b l e . A t s u p e r s o n i c speeds t h e corresponding s o l u t i o n s are\n\n488\n\n= f ( x 2 2)\n\nor\n\nu = f\'(x f\n\n2)\n\nw = + u\n\nT h i s l a t t e r form of s o l u t i o n , which r e p r e s e n t s a p l a n e sound wave of\na r b i t r a r y i n t e n s i t y a t 45\' t o t h e normalized c o o r d i n a t e axes, i s t h e\n. b a s i s of t h e Ackeret theory.\nThe g e n e r a l form of flow f i e l d g i v e n by s o l u t i o n s of t h e . t w o\n. The s k e t c h on t h e l e f t - h a n d\nforegoing types is i l l u s t r a t e d i n f i g u r e 1\ns i d e i s t h e f a m i l i a r s u b s o n i c s t r e a m l i n e p a t t e r n f o r a symmetrical biconvex\nwing s e c t i o n . I n t h e s u b s o n i c p a t t e r n t h e v e l o c i t y and p r e s s u r e d i s t r u b a n c e s\nd i m i n i s h uniformly w i t h d i s t a n c e and i n t h e case of s t e a d y flow The f i e l d\np o s s e s s e s a f o r e and a f t symmetry which r e s u l t s i n no p r e s s u r e drag o r wave\ndrag. The s k e t c h on t h e right-hand s i d e ( f i g . 1) i l l u s t r a t e s t h e marked\nd i f f e r e n c e i n s t r e a m l i n e p a t t e r n t h a t arises when t h e c r o s s w i s e v e l o c i t y\nof t h e c y l i n d r i c a l f i e l d i s s u p e r s o n i c . I n t h i s case t h e phase r e l a t i o n\nof u and w i s s h i f t e d (from 1 t o i) and t h e p r e s s u r e d i s t r i b u t i o n\ni s antisymmetric, r e s u l t i n g i n a wave drag. T h i s d r a g a p p e a r s as t h e\nenergy i n t h e p l a n e sound waves emanating from t h e a i r f o i l . The change\nfrom s u b s o n i c t o s u p e r s o n i c t y p e of flow f i e l d arises when t h e rate of\np r o g r e s s of t h e flow p a t t e r n through t h e s t i l l f l u i d exceeds t h e v e l o c i t y\nof sound. With c y l i n d r i c a l flow, t h e f i e l d i s n o t a f f e c t e d by an a x i a l\nv e l o c i t y of t h e c y l i n d e r and t h e p a t t e r n p r o g r e s s e s a t a rate determined\no n l y by t h e c r o s s w i s e motion of t h e c y l i n d e r . Hence, t h e s u b s o n i c t y p e\nof flow may p e r s i s t on a yawed wing even though t h e f l i g h t v e l o c i t y i s\nsupersonic.\n(See r e f e r e n c e 2.)\nThe s k e t c h i n t h e lower p a r t of f i g u r e 1 r e p r e s e n t s a c r o s s s e c t i o n\nof a c o n i c a l flow f i e l d of t h e t y p e o r i g i n a t e d by Busemann. c speeds is most evident i n t h e c a s e of t h e long narrow wing w i t h\n\nits leading edge perpendicular t o t h e d i r e c t i o n of f l i g h t .\n\nThe flow\n\nf i e l d i n t h i s case w a s described many y e a r s ago by J. Ackeret and shows\ntwo p l a n e waves of sound spreading above and below t h e wing i n a wedgeformation.\n\nAckeret\'s c a l c u l a t i o n s show p o s i t i v e p r e s s u r e s over t h e\n\n503\n\nf r o n t of t h e a i r f o i l and n e g a t i v e p r e s s u r e s over t h e rear r e s u l t i n g\ni n a "wave drag" which i s normally several times as g r e a t as t h e\nsurface friction.\n\n(See r e f e r e n c e s 1 and 4 . )\n\nF o r t u n a t e l y t h i s sudden i n c r e a s e of drag can b e avoided by\nsweeping t h e wing back behind t h e bow wave.\n\nWith such a swept-back\n\nc o n f i g u r a t i o n only t h e foremost s e c t i o n of t h e wing meets t h e a i r\nwithout any p r e p a r a t i o n .\n\n(See f i g . 4 . )\n\nS e c t i o n s f a r t h e r along t h e\n\nspan a l l l i e behind t h e zone of i n f l u e n c e of t h i s foremost s e c t i o n .\n\nA s described i n r e f e r e n c e 5 t h e e f f e c t of t h e l a t e r a l l y spreading\nzone of i n f l u e n c e of t h e forward s e c t i o n s i s t o create a flow p a t t e r n\nof t h e subsonic type over t h e o u t e r o r rearward s e c t i o n s .\n\nWith such\n\na swept-back wing t h e unfavorable e f f e c t of t h e supersonic speed t h u s\nappears only on t h e forward s e c t i o n s\n\n- while\n\nt h e o u t e r p a r t s of t h e\n\nwing show t h e d r a g l e s s t y p e of flow a s s o c i a t e d w i t h subsonic speeds.\nI n t h e l i m i t i n g case of an i n f i n i t e l y long o b l i q u e wing t h e r e is no\nchange of flow c o n f i g u r a t i o n on passing through t h e speed of sound\nand t h e wing behaves simply as i f i t w e r e f l y i n g a t t h e reduced\ncrosswise v e l o c i t y corresponding t o i t s a n g l e of o b l i q u i t y .\nMaintaining t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o by sweepback r e q u i r e s t h a t t h e\nwing b e kept w e l l behind t h e bow w a v e and, of course, t h i s r e q u i r e s\na g r e a t e r a n g l e of sweep a t higher speeds.\n\nWith a c u t e a n g l e s of sweep-\n\nback a d i f f i c u l t y arises i n t h a t v i s c o s i t y causes t h e flow t o s e p a r a t e\nfrom t h e upper s u r f a c e of t h e wing a t r e l a t i v e l y s m a l l v a l u e s of t h e\nlift.\n\n504\n\nHence t h e r e i s a l i m i t t o t h e p o s s i b i l i t y of maintaining high\n\nl i f t - d r a g r a t i o s by t h e u s e of sweepback.\nRecently a number of i n v e s t i g a t o r s have succeeded i n applying\nP r a n d t l \' s theory t o t h e determination of t h e a i r f l o w over bodies and\nwings adapted t o supersonic f l i g h t .\n\nBy making u s e of t h e s e r e s u l t s ,\n\nand by i n c o r p o r a t i n g i n them a n allowance f o r t h e probable s k i n\nf r i c t i o n , I have made some e s t i m a t e s of t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o s w e can\nexpect t o achieve a t v a r i o u s f l i g h t speeds w i t h t h e b e s t c o n f i g u r a t i o n .\n(See r e f e r e n c e 6.)\n\nA t each speed a s l e n d e r body and wings having t h e\nThe r e s u l t s are shown i n\n\nb e s t a n g l e of sweepback are considered.\nf i g u r e s 5 and 6.\n\nA s shown on f i g u r e 5 t h e a n g l e of sweepbaak i n each\n\ncase i s such t h a t t h e component v e l o c i t y normai t o t h e l e a d i n g edge of\nt h e wing i s 0.65 times t h e v e l o c i t y of sound.\n\nI have not extended t h e\n\nc a l c u l a t i o n s beyond 1-1/2 times t h e speed of sound because of t h e\nl i m i t a t i o n previously mentioned.\n\nHowever, i t does appear t h a t a r a t i o\n\nof l i f t t o drag i n excess of 10 t o 1 can be maintained up t o t h i s\n\nspeed.\nOur estimated v a l u e s of t h e l i f t - d r a g r a t i o can be combined\nwith t h e c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of a turbo-jet\n\nengine t o f u r n i s h an o v e r a l l\n\np i c t u r e of t h e probable economy of f l i g h t a t t h e s e speeds.\n\nFortunately\n\nt h e p r o p u l s i v e e f f i c i e n c y of t h e t u r b o - d r a g r a t i o .\nFor t h e range of supersonic speeds shown a n a i r p l a n e of normal\nd e n s i t y and loading would b e r e q u i r e d t o o p e r a t e a t a n a l t i t u d e of\nt h e o r d e r of 60,000 f e e t .\n\nThe l i m i t i n g v a l u e of 1-1/2 t i m e s t h e\n\nspeed of sound corresponds t o a f l i g h t speed of 1000 m i l e s p e r hour.\nA t t h i s speed w e should be a b l e t o g e t 1.5 m i l e s p e r g a l l o n of f u e l .\nIt i s i n t e r e s t i n g t o n o t e t h a t t h i s v a l u e corresoonds t o a v a l u e of\n\nmare t h a n 15 m i l e s per g a l l o n when t h e weight i s reduced t o c o r r e s pond t o t h a t of a n o r d i n a r y automobile.\n\n506\n\nREFERENCES\n\n1 Ackeret, J.: Air Forces on Airfoils Moving Faster than Sound.\n.\nNACA TM No. 317, 1925.\n2\n.\n\nVon K 4 d n , Th.: The problem of Resistance in Compressible\nFluids. Jones and Leonard Sternfield\nLangley Memorial Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nJune 1949\n\n515\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nNATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTZE FOR AERONAUTICS\nTECHNICAL NOTE 1901\n\nA METHOD FOR PREDICTINGTHE STABILITY\nI N ROLL O F AUTOMATICALLY CONTROLLED AIRCRAFT B S D ON\nAE\n\nTIE EXPERIMENTAL DETERMINATION OF THE CJURACTERISTICS\nOF AN AUTOMATIC PILOT\n\nBy Robert T. Jones and Leonard S t e r n f i e l d\n\nSUMMABY\n\nA method i s suggested f o r p r e d i c t i n g t h e s t a b i l i t y of automatic a l l y controlled a i r c r a f t by a comparison of c a l c u l a t e d frequencyresponse curves f o r t h e a i r c r a f t and experimentally determined\nfrequency-response curves f o r t h e automatic p i l o t . The method i s\na p p l i e d only t o s t a b i l i z a t i o n i n r o l l . The method i s expected t o be\nu s e f u l as a means of e s t a b l i s h i n g t h e s p e c i f i c a t i o n s of t h e performance\nrequired of t h e automatic c o n t r o l device f o r p i l o t l e s s a i r c r a f t\ndesigned as m i s s i l e s .\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nExperience has shown t h a t t h e provision of automatic s t a b i l i z a t i o n\nf o r small p i l o t l e s s a i r c r a f t designed as m i s s i l e s i s extremely d i f f i c u l t . The d i f f i c u l t y i s a r e s u l t of t h e high-frequency o s c i l l a t i o n s of\nsmall-size a i r c r a f t t h a t r e q u i r e r a p i d c o n t r o l movements and small t i m e\nl a g s , c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s which are d i f f i c u l t t o obtain, p a r t i c u l a r l y when\nt h e space a v a i l a b l e f o r t h e c o n t r o l servomotors and i n t e l l i g e n c e u n i t s\ni s considered. I n an unpublished a n a l y s i s made a t t h e Langley\nAeronautical Laboratory of t h e NACA, t h e problem of determining t h e\ns t a b i l i t y of an automatically controlled a i r c r a f t with l a g i n t h e\nc o n t r o l system w a s analyzed t h e o r e t i c a l l y by assuming a simplified\nequation f o r t h e c o n t r o l motion, t h i s equation being obtained from t h e\nknowledge of t h e behavior of t h e automatic p i l o t . Because of t h e\ni r r e g u l a r response c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s o f t e n found i n automatic p i l o t s ,\nhowever, t h e c o n t r o l motion is d i f f i c u l t t o represent mathematically\nand, hence, t h e simplified equations of t h e c o n t r o l w e r e found t o be\ninadequate f o r t h e a n a l y s i s .\n\n517\n\nNACA TN 1901\nThe p r e s e n t paper suggests a method f o r p r e d i c t i n g t h e s t a b i l i t y\nof a n a i r c r a f t based on t h e experimental determination of t h e c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of i t s automatic p i l o t . The procedure c o n s i s t s e s s e n t i a l l y i n\nc a l c u l a t i n g t h e c o n t r o l motion required t o maintain a continuous\ns i n u s o i d a l motion of u n i t amplitude f o r t h e degree of freedom being\ninspected. The motion of t h e c o n t r o l i s obtained f o r a range of\nfrequencies; t h e phase a n g l e of t h e c o n t r o l motion and t h e r a t i o of\namplitude of c o n t r o l motion t o a i r p l a n e motion are p l o t t e d as a f u n c t i o n\nof frequency. S i m i l a r curves are e s t a b l i s h e d f o r t h e a u t o p i l o t by\no s c i l l a t i n g i t and recording t h e c o n t r o l motion. The two sets of d a t a\nare then compared t o determine whether t h e a i r p l a n e w i l l b e s t a b l e under\nc o n t r o l of t h e automatic p i l o t . The method i s developed i n d e t a i l only\nf o r s t a b i l i z a t i o n i n r o l l . It may be used by t h e a i r p l a n e designer f o r\neither determining t h e s u i t a b i l i t y of an e x i s t i n g automatic p i l o t f o r a\np a r t i c u l a r a p p l i c a t i o n o r s p e c i f y i n g t h e c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of t h e automatic p i l o t needed f o r t h e a p p l i c a t i o n .\n\nSYMBOLS\n!\n\nm\n\nmass of a i r p l a n e , s l u g s\n\nk\nX\n\nr a c i l l a t i o n , seconds\nDETERMINATION OF CONDITIONS FOR NEUTRAL STABILITY\n\n\'\n\nThe method of determining t h e c o n d i t i o n s f o r n e u t r a l s t a b i l i t y i s\ni l l u s t r a t e d i n f i g u r e 1. The c a l c u l a t e d phase a n g l e of t h e c o n t r o l\nmotion and t h e c a l c u l a t e d r a t i o of t h e amplitude of c o n t r o l motion t o\na i r p l a n e motion are p l o t t e d a g a i n s t angular frequency as shown by t h e\ns o l i d - l i n e curves. The upper dashed curve is a p l o t of t h e experimental r a t i o of t h e amplitude of c o n t r o l motion t o a u t o p i l o t motion\na g a i n s t angular frequency. The lower t h r e e dashed curves are t h r e e\np o s s i b l e experimental phase-angle curves f o r t h e automatic p i l o t . The\ni n t e r s e c t i o n of t h e experimental and c a l c u l a t e d control-amplitude\ncurves e s t a b l i s h e s t h e approximate frequency of t h e a i r p l a n e w i t h t h e\na u t o p i l o t i n o p e r a t i o n . I f , as i n t h e c a s e of t h e intermediate experimental phase-angle curve, t h e i n t e r s e c t i o n of t h e experimental and\nc a l c u l a t e d phase-angle curves i s a t t h e s a m e frequency as t h e i n t e r s e c t i o n of t h e control-amplitude-ratio curves, t h e a i r p l a n e may be\nn e u t r a l l y s t a b l e and may b e expected t o o s c i l l a t e continuously a t t h i s\nfrequency. It is, however, more u s u a l t h a t t h e i n t e r s e c t i o n of t h e\nexperimental and c a l c u l a t e d phase-angle curves w i l l n o t be a t t h e same\nfrequency as t h e i n t e r s e c t i o n of t h e control-amplitude-ratio curves.\nI f t h e phase-angle curves, as i n one case shown, i n t e r s e c t a t a higher\nfrequency t h a n t h e control-amplitude-ratio curves, t h e a i r c r a f t w i l l be\ns t a b l e . I f , as i n t h e remaining case, t h e i n t e r s e c t i o n of t h e phasea n g l e curves i s a t a lower frequency t h a n t h e control-amplitude-ratio\ncurves, t h e a i r c r a f t w i l l b e u n s t a b l e . Because of t h e n o n l i n e a r\nc h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of t h e c o n t r o l system, i t i s g e n e r a l l y necessary t o\n\n519\n\nNACA TN 1901\nmake the experiments for different amplitudes. With a dead spot\n(insensitivity to small deviations) there will probably be some amplitude below which the system will be unstable.\nCalculated frequency-response curves for the aircraft.- In the\napplication of the method to the case of aileron control of an aircraft\nor a missile independently stabilized about all three axes, the equation\nof motion for determining the control movement is\n\nThe calculated steady-state solution of the aircraft in response to a\nsinusoidal forcing function of unit amplitude 6 = sin wt is\n4 = c$max\nsin (ut + (p).\n(See reference 1 ) The values of (pmx\n.\nand 8 are obtained over the desired range of angular frequencies w\nby the substitution of iw for D in the equation\nI\n\n6 _-\n\nqbS\n\n\'\nU\n\n+ Cz\n\nD\n\nThis substitution is equivalent to specifying an undamped sinusoidal\nmotion and results in the expression A + iB from which can be\nobtained -4max\n\n, k vand\n\n6 = tan-lB.\n\nA\n\nThe angle 8\n\nmay denote\n\neither a phase lag or lead, depending upon its quadrant. If 8\n\nis in\n\n- the third or fourth quadrant, the control lags behind the displacement,\nbut if 8 is in the first or second quadrant, the control leads the\nmotion of the airplane. The ratio of the amplitudes 6 and 4\nand may be defined as the control-amplitude ratio K of the\nhlaX\ncontrol system, that is, the ratio of maximum control deflection to\nmaximum displacement in bank. A plot of - K and 8 against w shows\nthe combination of control-amplitude ratio and phase lag or lead necessary to maintain fixed-amplitude oscillations at any given frequency.\nThese results are the calculated frequency-response curves due to a\nsinusoidal motion of the aircraft.\nis\n\nDetermination of equivalent sine wave for the automatic-pilot\nresponse.- The experimental frequency-response curves are obtained by\noscillating the automatic pilot sinusoidally at various amplitudes\nthrough the desired range of frequencies. The control is assumed to\noscillate at the same frequency as the automatic pilot but because of\n\n520\n\nNACA TN 1901\n\nt h e physical c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of t h e a u t o p i l o t t h e c o n t r o l motion may\nd i f f e r widely from a t r u e s i n e wave and may show a r b i t r a r y phase,\namplitude, o r wave-form r e l a t i o n s ( f i g . 2). It i s necessary, therefore,\nto determine an equivalent sine-wave response f o r any a r b i t r a r y c o n t r o l\nmotion.\nI n order t o determine t h e equivalent s i n e wave f o r an a r b i t r a r y\nc o n t r o l motion, t h e following relations are assumed:\n(1) The work done per c y c l e by a c o n t r o l following t h e equivalent\ns i n e wave on an a i r c r a f t having a harmonic displacement s i n w t must\nbe t h e same as t h a t done by t h e actual c o n t r o l v a r i a t i o n .\n\n(2) The angular impulse of t h e equivalent s i n e w a v e a c t i n g on t h e\na i r p l a n e over a h a l f c y c l e must equal t h e change i n angular momentum of\nt h e a i r p l a n e caused by t h e a c t u a l c o n t r o l motion during t h e same\ninterval\n\n.\n\nThe work done by a nonharmonic f o r c e B(t)\na harmonic motion s i n u t i s proportional t o\n\n$L\n\nof frequency\n\nw\n\nupon\n\n/\n\nT\n\nB1 =\n\n6 ( t ) cos u t d t\n\nwhere t h e period of t h e o s c i l l a t i o n i s\n\nT = - and\n2*\n0\xe2\x80\x99\n\nB\n\n1\n\nis t h e c o e f f i -\n\nc i e n t of t h e component cos u t . (See reference 2.)\nThis component of\nt h e c o n t r o l motion t h a t i s out of phase with t h e a i r c r a f t motion i s t h e\nonly harmonic of t h e Fourier series representing t h e f o r c i n g funct i o n B(t) which c o n t r i b u t e s t o t h e work done on t h e a i r c r a f t . The\nangular impulse is obtained by i n t e g r a t i n g t h e curve of c o n t r o l deflect i o n a g a i n s t t i m e over a h a l f cycle. This component of t h e c o n t r o l\nmotion i n phase with t h e s i n u s o i d a l motion of t h e a i r c r a f t , obtained\nfrom t h e second r e l a t i o n , i s\n\nT/2\nB(t) d t\n\nwhere A1 i s t h e c o e f f i c i e n t of t h e component s i n u t . The r e s u l t s i n\nf i g u r e 3 i n d i c a t e t h a t , f o r each control-amplitude r a t i o , t h e experimental values of 8 are g r e a t e r than t h e c a l c u l a t e d phase l a g , and\nhence t h e a i r c r a f t would be unstable. Unpublished r e s u l t s from windtunnel tests i n d i c a t e d t h a t t h e motion w a s unstable, as predicted from\nt h e curves of f i g u r e 3 .\nI n an e f f o r t t o m a k e t h e a i r c r a f t s t a b l e , t h e parameters of t h e\nautomatic p i l o t w e r e modified and a d d i t i o n a l wind-tunnel tests were\nperformed. The conditions s e l e c t e d f o r t h e s e wind-tunnel tests w e r e ,\nhowever, d i f f e r e n t from those conditions f o r which t h e experimental\nfrequency-response curves w e r e obtained and hence no d i r e c t p r e d i c t i o n\nof t h e a i r c r a f t s t a b i l i t y could b e made. The r e s u l t s of t h e windtunnel tests with t h e modified automatic p i l o t indicated a steady\n\n523\n\nNACATN 1901\n\no s c i l l a t i o n , and records taken of t h e tests showed t h a t t h e values\nof K and 8 agreed very c l o s e l y w i t h t h e combination of K and 8\ndetermined from t h e c a l c u l a t e d frequency-response curves. It i s o f t e n d e s i r a b l e , however, t o determine the.\nperformance of a n automatic c o n t r o l device required t o cause t h e motion\nof t h e a i r c r a f t t o damp a t a s u f f i c i e n t l y r a p i d rate. Although no\ns a t i s f a c t o r y a n a l y s i s of t h i s problem has been given, a q u a l i t a t i v e\ni n d i c a t i o n of t h e rate of damping t o b e expected i n a given case may b e\nobtained by comparing t h e measured phase and amplitude of t h e c o n t r o l\nt o t h e phase and amplitude c a l c u l a t e d t o be required t o enforce a given\nrate of damping.\nS t r i c t l y speaking, t h e assumed exponential damping of t h e motion\nwould r e q u i r e an exponential decrease i n t h e response of t h e a u t o p i l o t\na t decreasing amplitudes. I n general, such a l i n e a r response cannot\nbe expected and hence t h e method w i l l r e q u i r e c a r e f u l judgment i n i t s\napplication.\nThe equation of damped motion i n bank f o r t h e i l l u s t r a t i v e case\nmay be w r i t t e n by adding a real p a r t 11 t o t h e imaginary r o o t i w\n[0.000245(-11\nwhere\n\np\n\n1- iw)2\n\n+ 0.00245(-~ + i u ) ]\n\ni s given a v a l u e as deterrnined by the d e s i r e d rate of damping.\n\nThe motion damps t o one-half\nSolving t h e equation f o r\n\n4\n\n$ , = -0.26456\n\n= 0.000926w2\n\n-\n\n6/4\n\ni t s amplitude i n\n\nT1/2\ng i v e s t h e expression\n\n+\n\n0 . 0 0 0 9 2 6 ~ ~ 0.0092611\n\n=- 0*693 seconds.\n1\n1\n\n+ i(-0.0092& + 0 . 0 0 1 8 5 2 ~ ~ )\n\nThe frequency-response curves shown i n f i g u r e 5 w e r e c a l c u l a t e d f o r\nvalues of 1-1 varying from 0.175 t o 8.31. The method i s\nexpected t o b e u s e f u l as a means of e s t a b l i s h i n g t h e s p e c i f i c a t i o n s of\nt h e performance r e q u i r e d of t h e automatic c o n t r o l device f o r p i l o t l e s s\na i r c r a f t designed as missiles.\n\nLangley Aeronautical Laboratory\nNational Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics\nLangley A i r Force Base, Va., June 13, 1946\nREFERENCES\n\n1. JONES*\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory, N .A.C.A.\nSUbfMARY\n\nIf the *-airfoil theory is applied to an airfoil having a rounded\nleading edge, a certain emor will arise in the determination of the\npressure distribution around the nose. It is shown that the\nevaluation of the drag of such a blunt-nosed airfoil by the thina r o l theory requires the addition of a \xe2\x80\x9cleading-edge force,\xe2\x80\x9d\nifi\nanalogous to the well-known leading-edge thrust of the lifting airfoil. The method of calculation is illustrated by application to\n(1) the Joukowski airfoil in subsonic flow and (2) the thin elliptic\ncone in supersonic flow. The paper concludes with a general\nformula for the edge force which is applicable to a variety o\nf\nwing forms.\n\nvector will be represented by an analytic function of the\ncomplex variable f = x iz; that is,\n\n+\n\nu\n\n-i\nw\n\n= f(4)\n\nThe functionf is chosen to satisfy the desired boundary\nconditions around the slit -1 < x < +1 and to make\nu - i vanish at infinity.\nw\nBy a process of trial, it was found that for the example\nchosen\n\nZc-iw=\n\nINTRODUCTION\nof thin-airfoil theory to airfoils of finite thickness, care must be taken to Near the chord line E = x =toi and\nevaluate the effects of singularities that appear in the\nu/vt 2 1 2x\nthin-airfoil flows. To carry out this limiting\nprocess, we select, in preference to the airfoil surface\nitself, a streamline a short distance above the airfoil\nsurface and, furthermore, allow the integration to extend a short distance ahead of the airfoil nose.
