Figs.\n5 and 6 illustrate these relations.\nAs in the case of the Joukowski airfoil, the elliptic\ncone requires a singularity of the order -1/2 in the\nexpression for the vertical velocity w to represent the\nrounded leading edge. A trial shows that the simple\nfunction*\n\n+\n\nFIG. Pressure distribution over thin elliptic cone in supersonic\n7.\nflow.\n\napproximation to the actual surface velocity distribution in the vicinity of the rounded nose. The exact\nshape and pressure distribution over the rounded nose\nare thus not determined by the thin-airfoil theory.\nThe determination of the drag of the nose portion without knowledge of its exact shape or pressure distribution is possible, however, because of the invariant property of the contour integral.\nSimilar considerations apply in the case of a lifting\nairfoil. Here, an inclined thin plate is used as an approximation to a lifting airfoil of finite thickness, and\nthe leading-edge force (a forward thrust in this case) is\ndetermined from the singularity in the flow around the\nedge of the plate. The plate in this case represents a\nline of discontinuity, or a vortex sheet, along the\ninterior of the airfoil.\nIn either case the application of the theory to compressible flows is made on the assumption that the configuration of the flow exterior to the airfoil remains essentially- similar to the corresponding incompressible\npotential flow. The contour of integration (Fig. 3)\nis further supposed to lie in a region where the additive\nvelocities are small, so that the velocity u and the\ncorresponding pressure can be corrected by the PrandtlGlauext rule.\n\nELLlprIc CONE SUPERSONIC\nIN\nFLOW\nAs an example of a supersonic flow, consider the case\nof the flattened elliptic cone which was previously considered by Squire. Adopting a variation of Busemann\'s method,a the velocity field may be described by\nan analytic function of the variable where\n\nsatisfies the boundary condition for an elliptic cone of\nmaximum thickness xt having its leading edges along\nthe lines y = *mx.\nThe horizontal perturbation velocity u, which determines the pressure distribution ( A 9 = -puV), is\nfound from w with the aid of the-condition for irrotational motion-that is, bu/bz = dw/bx. In terms of\nthe variable 5 this relation is equivalent to\n\n,\n.\nJ\n\nwhere the integration begins at a point of zero disturbance.\nIntegration for the ordinate of the surface yields\n\nThe constant t is seen to be the maximum thickness of\nthe section at x = 1.0.\nIn the present example, the sweep angle is assumed\nto be greater than the Mach angle so that the elliptic\ncone lies entirely within\' the Mach cone. The velocities u and w then vanish on the Mach cone, and u\ncan be determined by integrating Eq. (12) from - 1 to 1\n\nr\n\n= 2\xe2\x82\xac/(1\n\n+\n\na2)\n\n(9)\n\nand\n\n(14)\n\nwhere\n@ =\n\nAs pointed out in reference 3, the variable e is the argument of the general solution of Prandtl\'s equation, of\nzero degree (cf. references 4 and 5 for the equivalent\nsolution of Laplace\'s equation). The variable b is an\nanalytic transformation of E that maps the interior of the\nMach cone onto the whole complex plane, transforming\nthe Mach cone itself into the positive and negative\nbranches of the real axis outside the points * l . This result has previously been obtained by Squire.\nAs in the preceding example, the drag is determined\nby integrating the product -piw along a stream surface just above the airfoil surface. Eqs. (11) and (14)\nfor u and w actually contain two (Le., the real and\nimaginary) solutions. Since the x d solutions are the\ne\nones uSed here, it is necessary to separate the product\nof the real solutions from the complex product uw.\nWith the aid of Eq. (12), it can be shown that the required product of the real solutions is equal to one-half\nthe real part of the complex product i a limited region\nn\nnear the nose of the airfoil where the term {/can be considered constant.\nWith this latter point in mind, the expression for the\nleading-edge force of a section at z = 1 can be written\n\nor, in coefficient form,\n\nfor both edges.\nThe contour for Eq. (15) crosses only a limited region\nnear the airfoil nose and involves in the limit only the\nsingular term\n- m2).Over the remainder\nof the interval the contour is equivalent to an evaluation of the surface pressure times the surface slope.\nOver this interval the pressure is constant, proportional\nto\n\nNOSE RADIUS = r\n\nFXG. General expression for force per unit length normal to\n8.\noblique leading edge.\n\nGENERAL\nEXPRESSION\nFOR LEADING-EDGE\nFORCE\n\nIn the foregoing example, the flow field is conical,\nand the drag coefficient of each section throughout the\nlergth of the conical body is the same. In more general\nexamples such as that described by Lighthill,2however,\nthis simplifying feature will not appear, and the coefficient of the leading-edge force will vary from point\nto point along the length of the edge. Furthermore, it\nwill not be possible, in general, to represent the entire\ngeometry of the flow field by a function of a complex\nvariable. However, if the body is sufficiently thin and\nflat and presents no abrupt changes in the radius of\ncurvature of the leading edge, the flow field in the immediate neighborhood of a point on the leading edge\nmay be considered to have a cylindrical, or two-dimensimal, form. In such cases the localized region of the\nflow field can be represented by a function of a complex\nvariable, and the contour integration for the leadingedge force can be performed. Fig. 8 illustrates the more\ngenerd relation obtained when this calculation is applied to an elliptical leading edge with nose radius r.\nIt is seen that the f,orce normal to the edge at large\nangles of sweep is approximately equal to that developed by the impact pressure of the normal stream\ncomponent acting on the developed area of the circular\ncylinder having the radius of the leading edge.\n\n{e/({2\n\nand the resulting drag is easily computed from the projected area of the cone-that is,\n\nIn this case, both the drag arising from the approximate surface pressure distribution and the leadingedge force act in the same direction so that the total\ndrag amounts to the sum of Eqs. (16) and (17).\n\nThe quantity t/2m is the "thickness ratio" of the cross\nsections of the elliptic cone. Eq. (18) does not, of course,\ninclude the wake drag that would arise if the cone were\ncut off so as to have a blunt base.\n\n538\n\nREFERENCES\n1 Allen. H. Jones\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nDecember 1950\n\n539\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nNATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE F R AERONAUTICS\nO\nTECHNICAL NOTE 2249\n\nTHE SPANWISE DISTRIBUTION OF LIFT FOR MINIMUM INDUCED\n\nDRAG OF WINGS HAVING A GIVEN LIFT AND A\n\nGIVEN BENDING MOMENT\nBy Robert T. Jones\n\nS M AY\nU MR\nThe problem of t h e minimup induced drag of wings having a given l i f t\nand a given span is extended t o include cases i n which t h e bending moment\nt o be supported by t h e wing i s a l s o given. A s i n t h e c l a s s i c d l problem\nof induced drag, t h e theory i s l i m i t e d t o l i f t i n g surfaces t r a v e l i n g a t\nsubsonic speeds. It i s found t h a t t h e required shape of t h e downwash d i s t r i b u t i o n can be obtained i n an elementary way which i s applicable t o a\nv a r i e t y of such problems. Expressions f o r t h e minimum drag and t h e corresponding spanwise load d i s t r i b u t i o n s are a l s o given f o r t h e case i n\nwhich t h e l i f t and t h e bending moment about t h e wing r o o t are fixed while\nt h e span i s allowed t o vary. The r e s u l t s show a 15-percent reduction of\nt h e induced drag with a 15-percent increase i n span as compared with\nr e s u l t s f o r an e l l i p t i c a l l y loaded wing having t h e s a m e t o t a l l i f t and\nbending moment.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nI n t h e problem of minimum induced drag as o r i g i n a l l y t r e a t e d by Munk\n(references 1 and 2) t h e span of t h e wing and t h e t o t a l l i f t w e r e supposed\nt o be given and t h e d i s t r i b u t i o n of l i f t over t h e span r e s u l t i n g i n a mininnun of drag w a s sought. The s o l u t i o n of t h i s problem thus provided a\nconvenient lower bound f o r t h e induced drag of a wing of given dimensions.\nI n t h e p r a c t i c a l design of wings t h e requirements f o r low induced\ndrag and t h e requirements f o r s t r u c t u r a l s t r e n g t h are opposed. H e r e t h e\nbending moment developed by t h e l i f t becomes an important consideramore important i n many cases than t h e a c t u a l spanwise dimension\ntion\nof t h e wing. Such considerations lead t o t h e problem of determining t h e\nminimum drag with l i m i t a t i o n s imposed on t h e bending moment as w e l l as\non t h e t o t a l l i f t . It is t h e purpose of t h e present paper t o show how\nt h e methods of t h e earlier a n a l y s i s can be extended i n a very simple way\nt o t h e s o l u t i o n of problems involving t h e bending moment of t h e load\ndistribution.\n\n-\n\n541\n\nNACA TN 2249\nA complete l i s t of symbols employed i n t h e a n a l y s i s w i l l be found i n\nt h e appendix.\nG N R L F R U A F R LIFT, DRAG, AND BENDING MOMENT\nE EA OMLS O\nReference may b e made t o t h e o r i g i n a l papers of P r a n d t l and Munk\n( r e f e r e n c e s 1 and 2 ) , o r t o any of t h e s t a n d a r d t e x t books on aerodynamics,\nf o r t h e fundamental developments of wing theory which form t h e b a s i s f o r\nt h e c a l c u l a t i o n s of induced drag. However, i f t h e r e s t r i c t i o n on the span is removed,\ns t i l l lower values of t h e induced drag can be obtained without any\nincrease i n t h e bending moment a t t h e wing root. The lower values are\nobtained by permitting t h e span t o increase and a t t h e s a m e t i m e adopting a more tapered form of t h e loading curve.\nEquation (16) which contains t h e t h r e e v a r i a b l e s l i f t , span, and\nc e n t e r of pressure can be e a s i l y rearranged t o show t h e v a r i a t i o n of\ndrag with span when t h e bending moment and t h e l i f t are held a t fixed\nvalues. I n t h i s case, t h e lateral p o s i t i o n of t h e c e n t e r o f pressure\ny\'s w i l l be fixed, while t h e form and extent s of t h e load curve w i l l\nvary. I n order t o provide a convenient b a s i s f o r comparison t h e span\nand shape of t h e load curves w i l l be r e l a t e d t o t h e e l l i p t i c loading.\nI f S/Se denotes t h e r a & h of t h e semispan of t h e wing t o that of an\ne l l i p t i c a l l y loaded wing having t h e s a m e t o t a l l i f t and bending moment,\nthen equation (16) can be rewritten:\n\nThe q u a n t i t y i n t h e bracket is t h e r a t i o of t h e induced drag t o that of\nt h e corresponding e l l i p t i c a l l y loaded wing. This r a t i o i s p l o t t e d i n\nf i g u r e 4 t o show t h e decrease of drag p o s s i b l e by increase of t h e span.\nThe forms of load curve required f o r t h e minimum drag a t various values\nof s/se are shown i n f i g u r e 5 .\nIt w i l l be noted t h a t a 15-percent reduction of t h e induced drag\nbelow t h a t f o r e l l i p t i c loading can be achieved with a 15-percent\ni n c r e a s e i n span. Further increases of span between 15 percent and\n50 percent (s = 1.15 t o 1.50) y i e l d no s i g n i f i c a n t reductions, however.\nA t s t i l l l a r g e r values of s t h e drag becomes lower, and approaches zero\na t an i n f i n i t e value of s. For extreme values of s/se t h e curves begin\nt o show negative loadings a t t h e t i p s and eventually t h e bending moment\na t c e r t a i n p o i n t s along t h e span w i l l exceed t h a t a t t h e wing root.\n\nA e Aeronautical Laboratory\nms\nNational Advisory Committee f o r Aeronautics,\nMoffett Field, C a l i f . , Sept. 25, 1950.\n\n548\n\nNACA TN 2249\nAPPENDIX\nDEFINITIONS OF SYMBOLS\n\nL\n\ntotal l i f t\n\n2\n\nelement of l i f t\n\nDi induced drag\n\nB\n\nbending moment\n\nP\n\nair density\n\nr\n\ncirculation\n\nwi\n\ninduced downwash velocity a t wing\n\n-\n\nW\n\ndownwash velocity, a t i n f i n i t y\n\nV\n\nlateral v e l o c i t y\n\nV\n\nvelocity of f l i g h t\n\nY,rl\n\ndistances along wing semispan\n\n60\n\npoint of orggin f o r bending moment\n\nS\n\nlength of wing semispan\n\nY\xe2\x80\x99\n\nlateral position of load centroid as a f r a c t i o n of\n\na,b\n\nconstants\n\n( w\n\n2wi)\n\ns\n\n549\n\nNACA TN 2249\n\nREFERENCES\n\n1.\n\nMunk, Max M . :\n1921.\n\n2.\n\nApplications o f Modern Hydrodynamics t o Aeronautics.\nPrandtl, L.:\nNACA Rep. 116, 1921.\n\n3.\n\nBocher, Maxime: Introduction t o Higher Algebra.\nN. T., "The Minimum Drag of Thin Wings in Frictionless Flow," Journal\nof the Aeronautical Sciences, vol. 18, no. 2, Feb. 1951, pp. 75-81.\n@ 1951 by the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences, Inc.\nReprinted by permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and\nAstronautics.\n\n558\n\nCopyright, 1951, by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences and reprinted by permission of the copyright owner\n\nF THE\nUTICAL\n\nAE\nVOLUME 18\n\nFEBRUARY, 1951\n\nNUMBER 2\n\nThe Minimum Drag of Thin\nin Frictionless Flow\nROBERT T. JONES*\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory, N .A.C.A.\nS-Y\n\nThe assumptions of the thin airfoil theory are found to provide certain necessary conditions for the minimum drag of airfoils\nhaving a given total l i t , a given maximum thickness. or a given\nvolume. The conditions are applicable to steady or unsteady\nmotions and to subsonic or supersonic speeds without restriction\non the plan form. The computationof drag and the statement of\nthe conditions for minimum drag depend on the consideration of\na \xe2\x80\x9ccombined flow field,\xe2\x80\x9d which is obtained by superimposing the\ndisturbance velocities in forward and reversed motions.\nI the plan form of the airfoil and its total lit are given, it is\nf\nfound that, for minimum drag, the lift must be distributed in such\na way that the downwash in the combined field is constant over\nf\nthe entire plan form. I the plan form is given and the thickness\nof the airfoil is required to contain a speciiid volume, then the\nthickness must be distributed over the plan form in such a way\nthat the\xe2\x80\x98pressure gradient of the combined field in the dreqtion\nof flight is constant a t all points of the wing. A specification of\nthe thickness along some lie drawn on the plan form is found to\nlead to the requirement that the gradient of the pressure vanishes\non either side of this line. For the drag to be a m i n i u m with\nrespect to small changes in the plan form, the foregoing conditions\nmust extend continuously for a small distance beyond the edge of\nthe plan form.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nT\n\nmoving through a fluid iS attributable partly to the action of tangential, or\nfriction, forces and partly to the action of normal pressures. With well-streamlined bodies, the friction forces\nare ordinarily confined to a relatively thin boundary\nlayer adjacent to the surface, and in such cases that\npart of the drag arising from the normal pressures can\nbe determined on the assumption of a frictionless potential motion in the region outside the boundary layer.\nA practical way of minimizing the pressure component of the drag is to make the body slender and its\nangle of attack small. Man? of the results of the modHE DRAG OF A BODY\n\nPresented at the Aerodynamics Session, Annual Summer Meeting, IAS. Los Angels, July 12-14, 1950.\n...\n* Aeronautical Engineer.\n\nern airfoil theory, such as the theory of the induced\ndrag of airfoils, are based on the assumption that the\n\nvelocities imparted to the air are small in relation to the\nvelocity of fight and, hence, are limited to cases of thin\nairfoils and small lift coefficients.\nIn the present paper, certain necessary conditions\nfor the minimum pressure drag of thin airfoils are derived. The analysis makes use of, and extends, certain\n\xe2\x80\x9creversed flow\xe2\x80\x9d theorems originally derived by Hayes\xe2\x80\x99\nand von K h % n 2\nand is based on the i%ea of superimposing the disturbances in forward and reversed\nmotions originally advanced by Munk.% Althowh\nthe analysis is restricted to motions involving small disturbances, the conditions for minimum drag are found\nto be applicable in a wide variety of circumstances of\nsuch motions. Thus, the motion may be steady or unsteady ahd the velocity of fight may be greater or less\nthan the velocity of sound.\n\nMINIMUM\nDRAG\nDUETO THICKNESS\nIn the linearized theory the effects of camber, or lift,\nand thickness can be treated independently and later\nsuperimposed in any desired linear combination. Wing\nproblems can therefore be divided into two classesi.e., those involving thickness but no lift and those involving a distribution of lift over a surface having zero\nthickness.\nConsider first the case of a thin nonlifting body or\nwing, such as shown in Fig. 1. The surface is assumed\nto be everywhere nearly parallel to a horizontal plane\nin the direction of motion. A distribution of thickness,\nsymmetrical above and below this plane, is supposed\nto be given over the plan form. Computation o the\nf\ndrag of such a body wl involve, first, the determinail\ntion of the pressure distribution over its surface. The\ndrag may then be obtained by one of two methods. In\nthe first method the body is divided into elements of\narea, and the element of drag is obtained from the in-\n\n559\n\nJOURNAL O F T H E AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES-FEBRUARY,\n\nPLAN -VIEW\n\nSIDE\n\nVIEW\n\nSHOWING PRESSURES\nFIG.1 Thin airfoil with elements representing slope of surface.\n.\n\nclination of the local pressure force. In the second\nmethod, which is related to the first through a integran\ntion by parts, the body is divided into small elements of\nvolume, and the drag is computed from the force of\nbuoyancy on each element arising from the local gradient of the pressure distribution.\n\nAs is well known, the pressure distribution over such\na t i ,nearly flat body can be calculated by considerhn\ning only the inclinations or slopes of the surface elements-without regard for the actual displacement of\nthe surface away from the mean plane. The body can\nthen be replaced by a large number of small elementary\nareas having slopes equal to the local slope of the surface. Each such element can be conceived to create a\ndisturbance field of its own, and the geometric character of this field will depend on the properties of the\nmedium (its elasticity, density, etc.) and on the circumstances of the motion. The disturbance fields of\nall elements will be alike except for a factor of strength,\nwhich is measured by the product of the area of the\nelement and its slope. The total disturbance field of\nthe body may be obtained by superimposing the individual disturbance fields of its elements.\nWith the aid of this concept of superposition it may\nbe shown that the drag of such a body is unchanged\nby a reversal of the direction of motion. The pressure\nat each point of the body is obtained by d\ng up\nthe influence at this point of every element of the surf ace. T h q drag is then obtainedby a second summation\ninvolving the total pressure force on each element and\nthe slope of its surface in the dragwise direction. Thus,\ntwo integrations over the surface are required- or four\nintegrals in a l A typical single element of this sum\nl.\n(see Fig. 1) will be represented by the pressure force\non element 2 caused by the pressure field of element 1\n;md multiplied by the slope of element 2. Now the\n\n560\n\n1951\n\npressure field of any element, regardless of the distribution or zone of action of the pressure, will be proprtional in magnitude to the slope and area of the element. The magnitude o the small contribution to the\nf\npressure on element 2 caused by element 1 will therefore be given by the product mlPpl,where ml is the\nh\n\xe2\x80\x9cstrength\xe2\x80\x9d of element 1as determined from t e product\nof its slope by its elementary area (i.e., ml is equal to\nthe frontal area of element 1)and where Pa is the pressure arising at ,element 2 from a unit disturbance at\nelement 1. The increment of drag produced will be\nequal to the product of the pressure mlPa by the area\nand the slope of element 24.e., mlPslm. In reversed\nmotion, element 1 will lie in the same relation to element\n2 formerly occupied by 2 in relation to 1. Hence, P.z~\nis equal to Pn provided the fluid itself is homogeneous.\nare both changed, but their\nThe signs of ml and\nproduct retains the same sign. The corresponding element of drag in reversed motion is, therefore, d n m l ,\nwhich is exactly equal to the element of drag in forward\nmotion. Such an equality can be assigned to every pair\nof elements and therefore must apply to the total drags\non forward and reversed motion.\nIt should be noted that the reversal principle involves\nhardly any restrictive assumptions aside from those involved in the linearization. It applies, therefore, to\nsteady or accelerated motions and to subsonic or supersonic speeds.\nThe fact that the drag of the body is the same for\neither direction of motion leads to the consideration of\na method of computing the drag wherein the forward\nand reversed disturbance fields are considered simulmeously. It is found that the sum of the two drags,\nor twice the actual drag, can be obtained by superimposing the two fields of disturbance vdocitie~and\nconsidering the pressures that would arise from motion\nof the combined field in the flight direction. The\nsuperposition of the two disturbance fields produces a\nfore-and-aft symmetry in the disturbance field of each\nelement, with the result that the combined flow field is\ngenerally simpler in structure than the actual physical\nfield and the calculation of drag is simplified. The\npressure in the combined field is simply the difference\nbetween the pressures in forward and reversed motions.\nIt can be shown that in the combined flow field the\nmutual interference drags of two distributions of thickness are equal. Consider two distributions A and B as\nillustrated in Fig. 2. The two distributions can be divided into an equal number of elements, and elements\nfrom the two distributions may then be paired in an\narbitrary way. Considering two elements such as 1\nand 2 shown in Fig. 2, it is\xe2\x80\x99evidemt from the symmetry\nof the combined field of &ch element that the drag of\nelement 1 caused by element 2 is equal to the drag of\nelement 2 caused by element 1. Since this equality\nholds for every pair of elements, it must hold for the\ntotal distributions A and B.\n\nMINIMUM DRAG OF THIN WINGS\n\nconsider two such\n\nelements of volume added to the\n\noriginal distribution as shown in Fig. 3 Fohwing the\n.\nprinaple o superposition, the drag added by the elef\n\nFIG.2. Elements showing the mutual interference o two wings\nf\ni combined flow.\nn\n\nmentswillbecornpsedoftbreeparts: (1)thedragof\nthe elements in their own pressllre fields; (2) the drag\nadded t the original distriition by the pwssure fields\no\noftheelements; an&(3)thedragoftheelelgentsin\nthe pressllre field of the original distribution. sc\nie\nn\nthevariationintdistriiutionissmallcom~\nt\'\no*\nOPiginal tllickness, item (1) will be of smatler\norder than (2) or (3).* Furthermo- if use is made of\nlw\nthe combined f o field, items (2) and (3) will be equal\nbecause of the mutual drag t h\npreviously demonstrated. The added drag is then equal to twice the\nbuoyancy of the volume elements in the pressure field\nof tbe original distribution. Denoting the pressure in\nthe combined field by P and the volumes o the de\n.\nf\nmen& by vl and v2, as in Pig. 3 we have the following\n.\ntwo equations:\n(1)\n\nFor m change in total vozzLmc:\n\n(2) For m change in drag: v1 -\n\nVI\n\n+ vz = 0\n\n+\n\ny.rz)*\n\n=0\n\nThe two equationswill be consistent if\n\n(3PJaX)l = (bPJaX)s\n\nAIRFOIL SHOWING ADDITION OF EOUAL OPPOSITE\nELEMENTS OF VOLUME.\n\nSince such equations must hold for all positions of\nthe elements within the specified plan form, we conclude that the pressure gradient bPJ& must have the\nsame value a t all points of the wing. For minimum\n\n* Th- fact that the secouddff variation in drag i h p\ns\npositive ensures that a stationary d u e will be a minimum and\nnotamaxhum.\n\n.\nPRESSURE DISTRIBUTION FOR WHICH DRAG\nOF ADDED ELEMENTS IS ZERO.\n\nFIG. 3a (to#).\n\nFIG.\n\n3b (bob).\n\nWe are now in a position to determine the conditions\nfor minimum drag with various specification^ o thickf\nness or volume. Consider, first, the following problem:\nSHOWING PRESSLet the plan form of the wing be given, and suppose\nDISTRIBUTION\nthat the thickness distribution is required to contain a\ncertain specified volume. What distribution of thickness over the plan form will result in the minimum\ndrag? First, let a distribution of t h i h e s s having the\nspecified volume and designed to achieve the minimum\ndrag be given. If the drag is actually a minimum, then\na small variation in the shape of the distribution will\nproduce no first-order change in the drag. The variation in shape must not change the original volume and,\nhence, may be divided into pairs of elements h a a g\nequal and opposite volumes. The drag of each element\nis a force of buoyancy equal to the volume of the element multiplied by the local gradient o the press~re. FIG.4. condition for minimum drag with a given tatalvolume.\nf\n\n"\n,\n\n56 1\n\nJOURNAL OF T H E AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES-FEBRUARY,\n\n1951\n\ndrag, therefore, the thickness must be distributed in\nsuch a way that the drag per unit volume is constant\nover the entire wing in the combined flow field. The\nsigniscance of this condition in terms of the pressure\ndistributions on an oblique airfoil in supersonic motion\nis illustrated in Fig. 4.\nSECTION\nExamples of bodies satisfying this condition are not\nA-B\nV\ndifficult to find. One example is that of a t i ,flathn\ntened ellipsoid accelerating in an incompressible fluid.\nThe drag force in this case is in opposition to the acceleration of the motion and, hence, is attributed to a\n\xe2\x80\x9cvirtual additional mass\xe2\x80\x9d of the body. The surface\npressures due to the acceleration are proportional to\nB\nbq/bt, where Q is the surface potential. As is well\nknown, the surface potential of any ellipsoid moving\nV\nin a direction x parallel to a principal axis is of the form\n---D\nQ = KVx, where K is a constant depending on the\nproportions of the ellipsoid and V is the velocity. In\nSECTION C-D\naccelerated motion, &/at and, hence, the pressure are FIG. Wing showing variation of thickness distribution with\n5.\nked section A-B.\nalso proportional to x, and this is true for motion in\neither direction except that the pressures are changed\ni\nin sign. The pressure distribution in the combined\nflow, therefore, has a constant gradient in the direction\nof x, and the ellipsoid satisfies the necessary condition\nfor minimum drag with a given volume. In this case\nthe condition is perhaps better stated as the condition\nfor minimum virtual voliime with a given actual volume.\nAnother example is that of a biconvex airfoil of infinite aspect ratio in steady motion at supersonicspeeds.\nI the upper and lower surfaces are parabolic arcs, the\nf\nAckeret theory gives a straight-line distribution of pressure from nose to trailing edge for motion in either\ndirection.\nThe foregoing method may be readily extended to\ndPc\n-=O\nother problems of minimum drag involving different\ndX\nC\nspecifications on the thickness distribution. Perhaps\nthe simplest of these is the case in which the thickness\nof the wing is spec5ed a!ong some line such as A-B\nSECTION C-D SHOWING\nin FiG. 5. Over the remainder of the Wing plan form\nPRESSURE DISTRIBUTIONS\nthe thickness is to be distributed so as to achieve the\nFIG.6. Condition for minimum drag with given maximum\nminimum drag under the s p e s e d conditions.\nthickness.\nIn this example we wish to consider variations in the\nthickness distribution which do not alter the shape of\nthe cross section A-B. Any small element of slope Hence, the pressure must not vary in the streamwise\nhaving the strength ml, in Fig. 5, must therefore be direction at points ahead of the section A-B. I the\nas\nf\nfollowed by an equal opposite element mz a t some down- airfoil is further required to close along the trailing\nstream position ahead of the line A-B so that the thick- edge, a similar condition will be imposed on the presness strong the line A-B is not changed. The two equa- sures in the region behind the line A-B (see Fig. 6).\ntions aetennining the necessary condition on the presIt will be noted that the condition for minimum drag\nsure distribution are:\ndoes not impose a restriction on the spanwise variation\nof the pressure and that this variation will presumably\n(1) For no change in thickness along A-B:\nbe determined by the given shape of the section A-B.\nml+mz=O\nIf the shape of the section A-B is not given exactly\nbut is merely required to have a certain frontal area.\n(2) For no change in drag: mlPol M a 0\n=\nthen it is found that the pressure in the combined flow\nand these lead to the relation\nfield must have the same constant value a t all points\nahead of this section. The existence of a constant presP* = Pa\n\nI-\n\n+\n\n562\n\nMINIMUM DRAG OF THIN WINGS\n\nsure means that the drag per unit of frontal area is constant.\nIt is interesting to note that the condition for minimum drag with a given frontal area requires that the\ndrag per unit frontal area be constant over the entire\nwing, while the condition for minimum drag with a\ngiven volume requires a constant drag per unit volume.\nIf the maximum thickness of each streamwise section\nis specified, then the drag per unit thickness must be\nconstant over each section.\n\nMINIMUM\nDRAG A GIVEN\nFOR\nLIFT\nThe foregoing principles of calculation can be carried\nover without essential modification to the problem of\nlift distribution. The drag arising from the lift can be\ncalculated independently of the thickness; hence, the\nsurface\xe2\x80\x9d slightly camwing can be considered a <\xe2\x80\x98lifting\nbered or twisted in such a way as to support the desired distribution of lift. A given distribution of lift\nwill induce a certain downwash velocity, and the resultant inclination of the stream lines must agree with the\nslope of the lifting surface a t all points. The drag of\nthe lifting surface will be computed by integrating the\nproduct of the local lift by the local inclination of the\nlifting surface.\nThe fact that a given distribution of lift has the same\ndrag for either direction of motion can be seen by considering the mutual drags of a pair of lifting elements.\nEach element of lift produces a distribution of downwash over the plane. The actual configuration of the\ndownwash field does not need to be specified, but its\nvalue a t all points is assumed to be proportional to the\nlift of the element. Hence the downwash of an element\nZl a t the position of another element 12 may be expressed\nin the form w21= llWzl, where Wzl is an influence function that depends on the geometric position of element\n2 in relation to element 1. The drag of element 2\ncaused by element 1is, therefore, ZIWz&.\nIn reversed motion the roles of the elements are reversed and the drag of element 1caused by element 2 is\nnow\nand WU = WZI. Similarly, the drag of element 2 caused by dement 1in reversed motion is equal\nto the drag of 11 caused by 12 in forward motion. These\nh\nstatements do not exclude t e possibility that ea& element lies wholly or paftially outside the zone of influence of the other element, and, hence, the reversal principle holds for unsteady or supersonic motions.\nSuppose a plan form and a distribution of lift are\ngiven, and consider again the field of perturbation veloci i s obtained by superimposing the fields in forward\nte\nmotion and in reversed motion. The horizontal perturbation velocities that give rise to the lift will be exactly canceled at each point of the surface. However,\nthe downwash velocities over the surface will not, in\ngeneral, be canceled, and the drag of the given distribution of lift for either direction of motion can be com-\n\nlaw&\n\nputed by considering this lift to act in t e combmed\nh\ndownwash field.\nIf consideration is restricted to the method of calculating drag by combining t e Bow fields in forward and\nh\nreversed motion, it is easily seen that the mutual interference drags of any two lifting areas are equal. The\ndrag of lifting surface A caused by the downwash of\nlifting surface B is exactly equal to the drag of B caused\nby the downwash field of A. This theorem follows\nfrom the symmetry of the combined flow fiela of any\nelement and the equality of interf-m\xe2\x80\x99\ndrags of two\nelements exactly as was previously demonstrated in\nthe case of thickness.\nConsider now a lifting surface supporting a given lift\nL, and suppose that a distribution of lift over the plan\nform designed to achieve the minimum drag under t e\nh\nstated conditions is given. Any small variation in the\net\nshape of the lift distribution which m e s the condition\nof constant total lift can be divided into pairs of elements of equal, opposite lifts. If the drag added by\nevery such pair of elements is zero, then the drag\nadded by any small continuous distributiyn of the required type will also be zero.\nConsidering two such elements of a small additional\ndistribution of lift, it is seen that the drag added to the\noriginal distribution will again consist of three parts:\n(1) the drag of the elements alone; (2) the drag added\nto the original distribution by the downwash fields of\nthe elements; and (3) the drag of the elements in the\ndownwash field of the original distribution. The drag\nof the elements alone will be of second order but will\nalways \\e positive so that the second-order variation\nin drag is positive. Items (2) and (3) will be equal by\nvirtue of the equality of mutual interference drags.\nFor the first-order variation in drag, therefore, we need\nonly consider the elements of lift acting in the downwash of the original distribution. Since the elements of\nl i t are equal and opposite, +eir drags will be equal and\nopposite, and the added drag will be zero if the downl\nwash is the same at each element. For al such pairs\nto contribute zero drag, the downwash must be constant\nover the whole wing. Hence, for minimum drag the\nlift must be distributed over the wing in such a way\nthat the downwash in the combined flow field is donstant at all points of the plan form. The condition is\nillustrated in Fig. 7.\n\nEXAMPLES\nOF\n\nTBE:\n\nMINIMUM\nDRAGOF LIFTING\n\nSURFACES\nThe stated condition for minimum drag with a given\ntotal lift obviously includes the well-known condition\nfor minimum induced drag in steady Gght at subsonic\nspeeds4 In that case the combined flow field is nothing\nmore or less than t h e two-dimensional field of motion\ninduced by the vortex wake that is normally trailing\nbut which now extends to i f n t both ahead of and\nniiy\nbehind the wing. The elliptic span loading, which\n\n563\n\nJOURNAL O F T H E AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES-FEBRUARY,\n\n1951\n\nnevertheless considerably simplified when the forward\nand reversed fields are considered simultaneouslyly.\n& ,\nIn the supersonic . E the computationof downwash\nover the surface involves the superposition of lifting\nrepWhose individd distubance fields\nsented by the potential of an elementary honeshoe\nvortex that has the form+\n\nA\n\n\'\n\nfor an element of lift r p V d y located a t the origiu. The\ndownwash at the position x, a near the plane z = 0\nB,\narising from an element o lift a t the position xb 9\nf\n1\ni obtained by differentiating \'p with respect to z near\ns\n8 = 0 and introducing t e displaced origin\nh\n\n-Ed-.\n\nVR c A\n-\n\nFIG. Condition for minimnm drag with a given total lift.\n7.\n\n( A I OBLIQUE LIFTING LINE\n\n(B)\n\nNARROW LIFTING SURFACE\n\nyields the minimum drag in this case, produces a\n\nuni-\n\nform downwash not only over the plan form o the\nf\nwing but over the whole infinite vortex ribbon as well.\nIn addition to providing the conditions for minimum\ndrag, the combined flow field also provides a simplificat o of the actual computation of the drag in spec&\nin\ncases. Thus, in the case of steady motion a t subsonic\nspeeds, the superposition o the forward and reversed\nf\ndisturbance fields, which are three-dimensional, results\nin a two-dimensional field of motion. In Supersonic\nmotion, the combined field retains its threeaun\n* &Onal\ncharacter, but the integration for the downwash is\n\n564\n\nNormally, the computation of: downwash over the\nlifting surface requires that the range of integration be\nlimited to a portion of the plan form so as to exclude\nthe forward branches of the Mach cones, where there is\nno real disturbauce. In the combined flow field, however, both branches of t e cones are to be included, and\nh\nthe integration for the downwash a t each point can be\nextended over the entire plan form provided the sign\no the radicalin the equation is chosen so that the downf\nwash of the lifting dement has the same sign in both\nbranches of the cone.\nOne example that lends i s l to calculation i that of\ntef\ns\nan extremely long n r o wing or "lifting line" at an\narw\nangle of yaw such that the line lies inside the Mach cone\nee\noriginating from its forward tip (see Fig. 8). Hr the\nintegration for the downwash in the combined flow\nfield extends from\'one end o the line to the other, as in\nf\nthe subsonic case, and it is found that an eIliptic distribution of lift results in a uniform dowawash, yielding\nthe value\n\nfor the minimum drag. Here, the quantity m is the\nratio o the dope of the lifting line to the slope o a\nf\nf\nMach line and is less than 1.0 when the croswise mms\nponent of velocity of the lifting line i subsonic. As\nthe angle of yaw is decreased so that the lifting line approaches the Mach cone, the drag of this distribution o\nf\nlift approaches infinitv. a fact that must be taken to\nm a that the concentration o a finite amount of lift\nen\nf\nwitbin an extremely narrow chordwise dimension i\ns\nnot perrnissble when the c r ~ ~ ~ w i s e\nvelocity cornpnmt\ni near sonic velocity or is supemonic.\ns\nFor a lifting surface of narrow proportions lyhg near\nthe center of the Mach cone, it is found that the -pression for the drag can be separatedinto two eomponeuts,.\n\nM I N I M U M DRAG OF T H I N W I N G S\n\none of which depends on the lengihwise distribution of\nlift while the other depends on the spanwise loading.\nThe minimum value in this case is found to be\n\nf A\n\nwhere b is the overall span of the wing and c is the overall length. The m i u value of the drag is achieved\nimm\nn\nwhen both the spanwise and the lengthwise loadings are\nelliptical.\nDETERMINATION p\nOF O\n\nT PLAN\n~ ~\nFORM\n\nIn practi*, the determination of the best distribution\nof lift or thickness for a given plan form may not be so\nimportant as the problem of determining the best shape\nfor the plan form. Unfortunately, it is difficult to\nformulate the latter problem in such a way as to lead to\na single definite solution that will be generally useful.\nThe foregoing analysis does, however, provide one important principle concerning wings of minimum drag.\nSuch wings will be characterized by the fact that the\ndrag is stationary not only with respect to variations\nin the lift or thickness distribution but also with respect to variations in the shape of the outline. Suppose the plan form of such a wing, together with the\ndistribution of lift or thickness satisfying the desired\ncondition for minimum drag, is given. If the drag is to\nremain unchanged when the outline of the wing is displaced through a small distance, then the distribution\nof pressure or downwash corresponding to a minimum\ndrag not only must appear over the plan form itself\nbut must also extend for a small distance, without iirstorder variation, away from the edge of the plan form.\nThat the foregoing condition leads to .a stationary\nvalue of the drag can be seen by considering the effect\nof a small displacement of the outline of a lifting wing,\nas illustrated in Fig. 9. Supposing the total lifts of the\noriginal and the distorted wings to be the same, lift\nmust be removed from the original area and placed on\nthe added area. The first-order variation in drag can\nagain be computed by considering only the effect of the\noriginal downwash field on the added distribution of\nlift. If this downwash, which was required to have a\nconstant value at all points of the original plan form,\nremains constant in the regions of the added area, then\na redistribution of lift from the original to the added\narea will not affect the total drag.\nCurves of variation of the drag with plan-form coefficients seldom show local maxima or minima but show,\nmore often, a monotonic character. As an example\n\nFro. 9.\n\nCondition for drag to be a minimum with respect to\nvariations i plan form.\nn\n\nwe may consider the induced drag of wings a t subsonic\nspeed. Here, the combined flow field, as previously\nnoted, is simply the two-dimensional motion induced\nby the vortex wake, and, in the case of minimumdrag,\nthe downwash is constant over the whole wake extending ahead of and behind the wing. Smce the condition for minimum drag persists along the whole wake,\nthe drag is unaltered by any displacement of the Wing\nboundary in the chordwise direction parallel to the\nwake. I one proceeds beyond the tip of the wing,\nf\nhowever, the downwash changes sign abruptly, and\nIarge values of upwash are encountered. The drag is\nthus not a minimum with respect to changes in the span\nof the wing but can be continually diminished by removing area from the center portions of the wing and\nplacing it at the tips. At supersonic spekds, the minimum drag for a given area and lift occurs when the\nwing surface is disposed along narrow lines lying near\nthe center of the Mach cone and having the greatest\npossible length and span.\nREFERENCES\n\n\'Hayes, Wallace D.. Report No. 889, 1947.\n\n56 5\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nTHEORETICAL DETERMINATION OF THE MINIMUM DRAG\nOF AIRFOILS AT SUPERSONIC SPEEDS\nRobert T. Jones\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nDecember 1952\n\n567\n\nJones, R. T., "Theoretical Determination of the Minimum Drag of Airfoils at\nSupersonic Speeds," Journal of the Aeronautical Sciences, vol. 19, no. 12,\nDec. 1952, pp. 813-822. 0 1 9 5 2 by the Institute of the Aeronautical\nSciences, Inc.\nReprinted by permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and\nAstronautics.\n\n568\n\nReprinted from JOURNAL OF THE AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES\nCopyright, 1952, by the Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences and reprinted by permission of the copyright owner\nDECEBEX,1952\nV O L1 ~ No. 1\n9\n,\n2\n\nTheoretical\nDrag of\n\netermination of the Minimum\nrfoils at Supersonic Speeds\nROBERT T. JONES*\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory,\n\nhSTRACr\n\nConsider a t i wing in frictionless flow and suppose the plan\nhn\nform of the wing and also the total lift to be given. The drag of\nthe Wing will then depend on the way in which the lift is distributed over its surface. In a previous paper, it was shown that\nthe minimnm drag occurs when the superposition of the induced\nn\nn\ndisturbance fields i forward and reversed motion results i a\nconstant value of the induced downwashat all points of the wing\nsnrface. Similar problems involving the ideal distribution of\nthickness over the snrface were found to lead to similar conditions governlng the distribution of pressure in the superimposed\nor \xe2\x80\x9ccombined\xe2\x80\x9dflow field.\nThe present paper describes a method for determining mathematically the combined disturbance field, and in certain cases the\nminimum drag, of wings at supersonic speeds. The simplest\nanalytic example is provided by the wing of elliptic plan form,\nwhich achieves its minimum drag when the lift is distributed\nuniformly over the surface. With a symmetrical distribution of\nthickness. the requirement of minimum drag for a given total volume i found to lead to profiles of constant curvature.\ns\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nat subsonic speeds, it is\nshown that the production of lift by a wing of k i t e\nspan gives rise to a drag force that depends on the distribution of lift over the span. This component of the\ndrag, which arises in frictionless motion, may be related to the energy required for the continual extension\nof the two-dimensional field of motion induced by the\nwake of trailing vortices. Alternatively, by examining\nconditions in the vicinity of the wing sections, the drag\nmay be related to the downward inclination of the air\nstream induced at the position of the wing by the action of the trailing vortices. Following the latter concept, the drag arising from the lift at subsonic speeds\nhas been termed the \xe2\x80\x9cinduced drag.\xe2\x80\x9d It was Shown by\nMunkl that this drag is a minimum for a given l i t and\na given span when the induced downwash is constant\nat all points of an equivalent lifting line, or vortex, having the same spanwise distribution of l i f t as the wing.\nIt was further shown by Munk that the induced drag\nis actually independent of the chordwise distribution of\nlift.\nAt supersonic speeds an additional component of\ndrag arises because of the formation of waves by the\nairfoil, and in this case the drag depends on both the\nspanwise and chordwise distributions of lift or, in other\n\nI\n\nN THE THEORY O F WINGS\n\nPresented at the AerodynamicsSession, Annual Summer Meeting, I.A.S.,July 16-18,1952.\n* Aeronautical Engineer.\n\nN.A.C.A.\n\nwords, on the actual distribution of lifting pressure\nover the surface of the wing. In order to extend Munk\xe2\x80\x99s\nproblem to wings at supersonic speeds i t was necessary\ntherefore to consider cot merely the span as given but\nthe actual shape of the wing in plan view. The problem could then be stated in the following form: For a\ngiven plan form s and a given total lift L,what distribution of the lift L over the surface s results in the\nminimum drag?\nFurthermore, at supersonic speeds a certain drag\narises from the thickness of the airfoil independently\nof the lift. The two components of d h g may, however, be considered separately and later added in any\ndesired combination. To isolate the effect of lift, as distinct from the effect of thickness, it is sufficient to replace the wing by its mean surface, which is supposed\nto be warped or cambered in whatever way may be required to cause the specified distribution of lift. On\nthe other hand, the drag arising from the thickness may\nbe determined by considering the thickness to be symmetrically disposed above and below a flat mean scrface having no lift. In this way additional problems\ninvolving the ideal distribution of thickness over the\nplan form become apparent.\nIn reference 2 it was shown that all distributions of\nlift having the minimum drag for a given plan form and\na given total lift are chafacterized by a single condition. If we suppose the wing with its given distribution\nof lift to be held fixed in a stream of velocity V, then\nthere will arise in the vicinity of the wing and its wake\nadditional small disturbance velocities u, v, and w.\nNow let the direction of the stream be reversed, but suppose that the curvature and inclination of the surface\nis so modified as to maintain the original distribution of\nlift. A new field of disturbance velocities u, v, and w\nwill appear. The wake of trailing vortices will have\nthe same form as before, but the wake will now extend\nfrom the wing in the opposite direction. We may now\nsuperimpose the two fields of disturbance velocities\nand obtain by this means a \xe2\x80\x9ccombined \xe2\x80\x98disturbance\nfield,\xe2\x80\x9d associated with the given distribution of lift.\nFor the drag to be a minimum, the downwash in the\ncombined disturbance field must be constant at all\npoints of the wing surface s.\nI the velocity of flight is subsonic, the superposition\nf\nof the two fields can be shown t o result in a two-dimensional field of motion identical in form to the velocity\n\n569\n\nJOURNAL O F THE AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES-DECEMBER,\n\n1952\n\ntwo-dimensional flows. As will be shown, t i method\nhs\nenables the calculation of three-dimensional wing flows\nthat satisfy the conditions for minimum drag and provides, as examples, formulas for the minimum drag\nof Wings of elliptic plan form at supersonic speed.\nA. Outside the cone R = 0, the disturbanceis zero.\nCOXBIIWD\nD~S~URBANCB OFD LJXWING\n~\nL\nA\nSURFACE\n\nThe combined disturbancefield for an entire lifting surface s is obtained by superimpshg elementary solutions\nof the form (28). This superposition amounts to a double integration of elemenhorseshoe vortices over the\nsurface, the strength of the vorticesa t each point being determined by the local lift Z(x1,yz). After introducing a p\npropriate constants and changing the order of integration s that the contour integral is performed l s ,the exn\nat\npression for the combined potential $ of the lifting surface becomes\n\nIt will be shown later that the double integral over the surface s in Eq. (29) yields a two-dhensional complex\ni\npotential function, the form of t h i s function depending on the parameter 8. The i dintegration over @ (or) X\nthen yields the three-dimensional disturbance. By analogy to well-known fomiulas in two-dimensionalpotential\ntheory,the integration over the surface s may be defined i such a way as to permit differentiation under the inn\ntegrd. Performingthis differentiation for the velocity components f and a, obtain from Eq- (29)\nwe\n\n573\n\nJOURNAL O F T H E AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES-DECEMBER,\n\n1952\n\nThe component a/ V must, of course, vanish at every point of the wing surface.\n\nRelation to Two-DimensionalFlow Theory\n\nIt may now be shown that Eq. (31) represents the\ndownwash in the three-dimensio-nal flow by the superposition of the downwash of infinitely many twodimensional flows. Each two-dimensional flow is\nassociated with an oblique strip drawn in the plane of\nthe wing and having its edges tangent to the outline of\nthe wing plan form. It will appear that the downwash\ncontributed by each strip is given by the familiar\n"lifting line" formula, the loading on each equivalent\nlifting line being obtained by an integration of the surface loading on the wing in an oblique direction (see Fig.\n\nThe integration along x1 may now be performed directly and results in the spanwise loading, which may be\ndenoted by\n\n(35)\n\nNow the quantity Z(x1,yl) represents the lifting pressure,\nand we may replace it by a quantity that takes equal\nand opposite values on the upper and lower sides of the\nWing surface. Similarly, the integrated quantity\nL\'(y1) may be supposed to take equal and opposite\nvalues on the upper and lower sides of the strip, which,\n4).\nfor X = 0, coincides with vortex wake of the wing. In\nFor those parts of the contour consisting of the small fact, if we write\ncircles around X = 0 and l / X = 0, the equivalent loading is simply the spanwise loading. If, in addition, the s9anwise loading is elliptical, then the fnlinia\ntegrated value of the downwash will be a constant.\n\nMINIMUM\nDRAGOF ELLIPTICWINGS AT Sup~momc\nSPEED\nThe foregoing discussion indicated that the downwash\nwill be constant over the plan form if the integrated\nloading in every oblique direction is elliptical. This\ncondition is, of course, merely a sufficient, and not a\nnecessary, one. The condition is met in the case of the\nelliptic plan form having a uniform surface distribution\nof lift. Hence it is concluded that such a uniform surface loading yields the minimum drag in the case of the\nelliptic wing.\nThe downwash of the elliptic wing may be calculated\ndirectly from Eq. ( 1 . Jones\nProceedings of the Conference on High Speed Aeronautics, Brooklyn\n\n1955\n\n579\n\nJones, R. T. "Possibilities of Efficient High-speed Transport Airplanes," in\nConference on High Speed Aeronautics, Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn,\nJan. 20-22, 1955. Proceedings. Edited by A. Ferri, N. J. Hoff, and\nP. A. Libby. Brooklyn, 1955, pp. 144-156. @ 1955 by the Polytechnic\nInstitute of Brooklyn.\nReprinted by permission of its successor, the Polytechnic Institute of\nNew York, Brooklyn, N. Y.\n\n580\n\nPOSSIBILITIES OF EFFICIENT HIGH-SPEED\nTRANSPORT AIRPLANES\nBY\nRobert 1 Jones\n.\nNotionrti Advisory Conuninee for Arronovtics\n\nWe are accustomed to thinking of the airplane in terms of speed.\nLess familiar is the fact that the airplane actually achieves its speed\nwith relatively good fuel economy. Recently I flew, together with eighty\nother passengers, in a scheduled airliner from Kansas City to Los\nAngeles. On this flight we averaged about 8/10 of a mile per gallon,,\nor 65 miles per gallon for each passenger. Thus we achieved about\nthe same mileage as an ordinary automobile while traveling at six\ntimes the speed.\nIt is easily seen that the efficiency of the subsonic airplane depends\non the favorable aerodynamic properties of the wing in this speed\nrange. The possibility of such good lifting efficiency was not obvious\nto earlier students of hydrodynamic theory-because of an uncertainty\nin the choice among possible solutions of the flow equations.\nEarly predictions of airplane performance were based on the choice\nof the Helmholtz flow. In this flow what is now known as the Kutta\ncondition was applied at both the leading edge and the trailing edge,\nand the wing was followed by a wake of dead air attached to its upper\nsurface. One of the first text books on aeronautics I studied was entitled \xe2\x80\x98Aeroplane Construction and Operation,\xe2\x80\x9d by John B. Rathbun\n(Ref. 1). It was written in 1918 when the wing theory as we now understand it was relatively unknown in this country. On page 93, I find the\nfollowing statement: \xe2\x80\x9cAs already explained, the behavior of a body in\nan air stream cannot be predicted with any certainty by direct mathematical calculation and, for this reason, each and every aerodynamic\nbody must be tested under conditions that are as nearly similar to the\nactual working conditions as possible. Prior to Professor Langley\xe2\x80\x99s\nfirst experiments in 1887, mechanical flight with a heayier-than-air\nmachine was derided as an impossibility, even by such scientists as\nNavier, von Helmoltz, Gay-Lussac, and others who proved by the most\nintricate calculations that a body larger than a bird could not be supported by its own energy. Such calculations were, of course, based on\na wrong understanding of air flow and, as no experimental work had\nbeen done up to that time, the flow was assumed according to the individual taste and belief of the demonstrator. The presence of a vacuum on the back of a plate was not understood and, as this contributes\n\n581\n\nHIGH-SPEED AERONAUTICS\nfull two-thirds of the lift, it is an easy matter to see why all of the\nearly predictions fell short of the actual lifting forces. To quote one\nclassic absurdity, the scientist Navier proved mathematically that if\nmechanical flight were possible, then 17 swallows would be capable of\ndeveloping one horsepower.\nAlsoin1918, we find in the work of de Bothezat (Ref. 2) (NACA Rep.\n28) a theory of airfoils based on the assumption of leading-edge separation and the introduction of a K 6 r d n vortex trail in the wake above\nand behind the wing. In his consideration of the tip vortices de Bothezat obtains the modern form o the law of induced drag. This compof\nnent of the dragwas, however, negligible in comparison to that induced\nby the lateral vortices in the wake.\nIn contrast to these more conservative assumptions, the Kutta-Joukowsky theory predicts large values of the lift without accompanying\npressure drag in two-dimensional motion. The degree to which this\nideal dragless type of flow can actually be approached under suitable\nconditions is well illustrated by an experiment made by E. N. Jacobs\n(Ref. 3) at the NACA\'s Langley Laboratory a number of years ago.\nThe airfoil in this experiment had a %foot chord and extended completely across the (low turbulence) wind tunnel (Fig. 1). At an airspeed of 50 miles per hour and an angle of attack of 7", a lift force of\n\nFigure 1 -Airfoil compared with circular wire having\nequal drag.\n\n100 pounds was measured. The drag amounted to only slightly more\nthan one-third of a pound, so that the lift-drag ratio was nearly 300to\n1. For comparison a round rod or wire having the same drag as the\nlifting airfoil is also shown.\nFlows of the Helmholtz or de Bothezat type are not completely contrary to experience, and yet an airplane designed according to those\nformulas would have a decidedly unconventional appearance and would\nrequire a large thrust. A modern airplane in cruising flight obtains\nabout three times as much thrust from the suction developed in the\nflow around the leading edge as it does from its engines. This type of\nassistance from the flow requires a wing of large aspect ratio. In recent years the aspect ratios of transport airplanes have increased to\nvalues of 10 or more. Calculations can be made which show that, if\n\n582\n\nJONES\nthe energy required to transport a given payload were the deciding\nfactor, then stillfurther increases in aspect ratio at the cost of structural weight would be desirable.\nA s is well known, the fuel consumption of most vehicles increases\ndisproportionately when we try to increase their speed simply by installing more horsepower. The airplane differs from earth-bound\nvehicles in this respect, however, sirice, by climbing to a higher altitude, it can increase its speed without necessarily increasing the fuel\nconsumption per mile of flight.\nIn 1929, B. V. Korvin-Kroukovsky (Ref. 4) published a series of\narticles in \xe2\x80\x9cAviation\xe2\x80\x9d entitled, \xe2\x80\x9cThe High Altitude Airplane.\xe2\x80\x9d In that\ndiscussion it was pointed out that high economical cruising speeds\ncould be achieved by an ordinary low-speed airplane if this airplane\nand its power plant could be equipped for operation at high altitudes.\nKorvin-Kroukovsky\xe2\x80\x99s argument was roughly a s follows: The ratio of\nlift to drag of a conventional airplane is determined primarily by its\nexternal form and is essentially independent of the airspeed, the wing\nloading, and the air density. If the airspeed is increased while thd\nairplane is held at a fixed angle of attack, both the lift and the drag\nwill increase with the square of the speed but tend to remain inthe\nsame ratio. Now an airplane of conventionalform and loading achieves\nits maximum lift-drag ratio at a rather high angle of attack, which\ncorresponds to a low airspeed at sea level. One method of increasing the speed is to supply more thrust and counteract theincreased\nlift by reducing the angle of attack. Eventually the horsepower required begins to increase as the cube of the speed and the fuel consumption per mile increases, as it does for other vehicles. However,\nif the airplane is kept trimmed at its optimum angle of attack and the\naltitude is increased so that the air density diminishes in proportion\nto the inverse square of the speed, then the air forces, both the lift\nand the drag, remain constant. In this way the speed can be increased\nwithout the requirement of any additional thrust. Since the drag and\nthe thrust required do not increase, then the energy expended per mile\nof flight remains constaat and we can obtain, theoretically, the same\nnumber of miles per gallon at progressively higher speeds.\nLet us see what happens if we apply this concept to a small lightly\nloaded airplane of the \xe2\x80\x98Cub\xe2\x80\x9d type. Such an airplane might cruiseat\nperhaps 100 miles per hour at a lift-drag ratio of 15 to 1. Suppose a\nthrust of 1/15 the weight can be supplied at any altitude and t!!t some\nexcess thrust is available for climbing. Figure 2 shows the progressive increase of cruising speed with altitude. At 40,000 feet the speed\nwill have increased to 200 miles per hour and at 68,000 feet the Cub\nw l be traveling at 400 miles per hour.\nil\nmay ask whether the fabric wings will withstand such a speed or w\ne r there will be difficulty\nin moving the controls. Of course the indicated airspeed has remained\nat 100 miles per hour so that the air forces remain essentially unchanged. One effect that might be noticeable is a relative loss in the\ndamping of angular motions.\nobvious advantage of this method of\n\n583\n\nHIGH-SPEED AERONAUTICS\n\nALTITUDE\nIN\nM\n\n0\n\n1\n\n2\n\n3\n\n4\n\n5\n\nspEED/SPED AT S\xe2\x82\xacA LEVEL\n\n6\n\n7\n\n8\n\nF g r 2 -Increase o cruising speed w t altitude for constant\niue\nf\nih\nthrust.\n\ngaining speed is that it does not interfere with the ability of the airplane to slow down for landing at lower levels.\nAt first thought one is inclined to ask whether the climb to such a\ngreat altitude would be worth-while for any except the longest journeys.\nAlthough the increased distance involved in the high altitude path is not\nimportant, the time spent at lower altitudes and slower speeds amounts\nto a considerable fraction of the duration of trips less than 500 miles.\nHowever, calculations I have made indicate that, if the means were\navailable, a climb as high as 80,000 feet would save time on a 500 mile\nflight.\nIn this connection it is interesting to note that the plan of operation\nof the Comet airliner, as explained by A. C. Campbell-Orde (Ref. 5)\nin his paper given at the 20th annual meeting of the Institute of the\nAeronautical Sciences, requires a climb to 35,000 feet for the purpose of reaching an alternate airport only 250 miles distant. The saving of time here is essential because of the fuel-burning characteristics\nof the turbojet engine.\nSince density is a relative matter, we might consider, alternatively,\nincreasing the economical cruising speed at low levels simply by increasing the density of theairplane. This method has a marked structural advantage, since the same load would be supported by a more\ncompact structure. A comparison of these methods, that is, increasing altitude vs. increasing airplane density leads to some interesting\nresults. We should also consider the possibility of simply increasing\nthe thrust. This latter method may be thought of as that presently in\nvogue among automobile manufacturers.\nThe followingtable (Fig. 3) shows some results of this comparisonwhich, needless to say, is made on the simplest possible basis. The\nnumbers listed under the three airplanes to the right show various results of doubling the speed in the subsonic range. In the first method\nthe speed is increased simply by increasing the thrust and the balance\nbetween lift and weight maintained by reducing the angle of attack be-\n\n584\n\nJONES\nI\n\n2\n\n3\n\nFigure 3- Comparison of three methods of.increasing speed.\n\nlow the optimum value. In the case of a propeller-driven airplane the\nrange in miles per gallon would fall to about one-half and, because of\nthe increased gust force, the ride would be twice as \xe2\x80\x9cbumpy.\xe2\x80\x9d With jet\npropulsion the range in either case wouldbe rather poor but would not \xe2\x80\x99\nbe decreased by going to the higher speed. Of course a considerable\nincrease in the structural stiffness would be required for the higher\nspeed.\nIn following the second method we would attempt to conceal the same\nmass and payload in an airplane of one-half the size. If this can be\ndone it is seen that the speed may be doubled without any increase in\nthe required thrust. Thus with jet propulsion the range in miles per\ngallon will. be increased by about the same factor. Furthermore, the\nriding qualities of the airplane will be improved. The engineering advantage of supporting the given load on a more compact structure is\nimmediately apparent. One difficulty with this method is that the landing speed increases in the same ratio as the cruising speed.\nIf only the final result is considered, it is clear that an increase of\nthe cruising altitude is the best method of gaining speed. If we can\nassume that gust velocities diminish at higher altitudes then the gust\nforces will be even lower than indicated by the table. Each method is\nessentially limited by the possibilities of engine development. The\ndenser airplane requires the same thrust from engines having onefourth the normal frontal area, while the engines of the high altitude\nairplane must develop the required thrust in an atmosphere of onefourth normal density.\nIt seems that airplane constructors have actually utilized the benefits of increased density as far as practicable, but the result has been\nheavier airplanes rather than smaller ones. Figure 4 shows a logarithmic plot of weight versus wing span for a nuniber of successful\ncommercial aircraft. It will be noted that older airplanes and smaller\nones, whose design has not changed, tended to follow the law of constant wing loading, that is, W s b2. Modern airplanes, especially since\nrestrictions on the landing speed have been removed, tend-to follow\n\n585\n\nHIGH-SPEED AERONAUTICS\n\nI50\n10\n0\nSPAN.\n\nFEET\n\n50\n\n..\n\n."\n\nWEIGHT,\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI"\n\nIbs\n\nFigure 4 -Airplane weights a s a function of a linear dimension.\n\nwhat might be termed a line of \'"maximum density." Such a trend,\ncorresponding to constant weight per unit volume, seems to indicate a\nmaximum practical utilization of the space within the airplane. The\nweight per unit of actual volume along this line approaches tha;t of a\nloaded railway coach. With the original engine used by Orville and\nWilbur Wright the possibility of flight depended on achieving a structure having the minimum density. With present engines it seems that\nthe successful constructor must achieve a maximum density. Although\ncalculations of the landing speed have always occupied an important\nplace in aeronautical engineering, they do not seem to have influenced\nthe final result appreciably.\nFor many years the airplane designer has advocated a decrease in\nlanding speeds, and yet he has evidently been forced by economic considerations to follow the trend of maximum density according to which\nthe landing speed increases with the size and weight of the airplane.\nNot long ago landing speeds greater than 65 miles per hour were considered unsafe. Last year, however, approximately 50,000,000 people\ntook off and landed, mostly at speeds of over 100 miles per hour. The\nlanding of transport airplanes at present-day speeds and loadings has\nproved to be a far safer and more reliable proposition than the landing of early model airplanes, which, with their light wing loadings and\nslow speeds, could hardly be managed in normal winds and gusts.\nThere is, of course, a limit to increases of the economical cruising\nspeed of the subsonic airplane and the same limit appears whether we\nattempt to increase the speed by increasing the density of the airplane\nor by increasing the altitude of flight. This limit is set by the wellknown sudden increase of pressure drag at a critical Mach number.\nI the optimum lift coefficient and the critical Mach number are given,\nf\nthen we can derive an optimum ratio between the wing loading and the\nambient atmospheric pressure Pa. This ratio is\n\nand corresponds to the highest cruising speed without loss of efficiency.\n\n586\n\nJONES\n\nAt CL, = 1.0 and M, = 0.7 we obtain a wing loading of 1/3 of an\n,\natmosphere. Thus, for cruising flight at sea level we require about\n700 pounds per square foot. At 60,000 feet, however, the ambient pressure fallstoonly 150 pounds per square foot, so that the optimum wing\nloading becomes 50 pounds per square foot. This latter value corresponds to the current density of construction and loading and enables\nlandings to be made at not over 100 miles per hour. It is certainly\nsurprising that our present day heavy wing loadings are really best\nadapted to the thin air at 60,000 feet.\nIt has been said that as the speeds of a i r c r g t increase the wings\nmust become proportionately smaller. However, it is hard to discern\nthis trend in the geometric proportions of actual airplanes. Thus, the\nComet airliner which flies at about 4-1/2 times the speed of the Ford\nTrimotor seems to have proportionately even larger wings. Such studies as I have made indicate that if economy of propulsion is to be a\nmajor factor, then the relative proportions of the wings will not diminish even at supersonic speeds.\nWith the velocity given in terms of the Mach number there exists,\nthe temptation to think of supersonic speeds in increments of a whole\nunit. However as our understanding of supersonic wave drag and lift\nincreases it seems increasingly probable that the speeds of commercial aircraft will grow continuously in this range, just as they have in\nthe subsonic range. If we are willing to assume such a continuous\ntransition to the problems of air transportation at supersonic speeds,\nthen it will seem appropriate to follow the trends of loading, density,\nand altitude disclosed by the preceding development of the subsonic\nairplane.\nThe appearance of the wave drag at supersonic speeds does of\ncourse require a marked change in the form of an airplane designed\nfor economical flight. Figure 5a illustrates for bodies of revolution\nthe change in the optimum slenderness ratio on going to supersonic\ns\nspeeds. The volume of both bodies i the same and theproportions\nshown minimize approximately the sum of the drag arising from the\nnormal pressures and from the friction of a turbulent bourldary layer.\nThe balance between friction and wave drag is such that a single object 5 feet in diameter requires a fairing 75 feet long.\nA s a further illustration of the relFtive magnitude of the wave drag\nfor different forms, I show in Figure 5b two models which, accxding\n\nFigure Sa-Change in the ideal proportions of a body of revolution on transition to supersonic speeds.\n\n587\n\nHIGH-SPEED AERONAUTICS\n\nFigure 5b -Models having same drag at low supersonic speed, (zero lift).\n\nto the indications of our experiments, would have the same total drag\nat a low supersonic Mach number. This comparison of course ddes not\napply to cruising flight since the comparison is made at zero lift.\nWith regard to the ideal form of the supersonic wing it is interesting to translate the following from Dr. Busemann\xe2\x80\x99s paper given 20\nyears ago at the Volta Congress in Rome (Ref. 6:\n)\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is clear that the arrow form, quite apart from other considerations, must be favorable since the pressure differences producing lift\nare fully effective, whilst those producing drag have only a component\nin the directionof flight. If now a reduction of the effective Mach number makes. possible the utilization of a greater surface loading at the\nsame angle of incidence, the relative effect of the shearing forces in\nthe friction layer necessarily decreases.\xe2\x80\x9d According to our present\nconcept a \xe2\x80\x9csubsonic\xe2\x80\x9d sweep angle will be required to achieve this objective.\nOn the basis of the papers of Prandtl (Ref. 7) and vonKkm6n (Ref. 8)\nat the 1935 VoltaCongress linearized supersonic floy theory has been\nused to develop the means for estimating the wave resistance of a wide\nvariety of shapes. Even on this simplified basis, however, the formulas\noften become rather complex so that the trends to be followed by the designer are not clearly displayed. One method o obtaining more inf\nstructive formulas is to study the minimum values of the drag under\nvarious engineering constraints. As an example we may think of Munk\xe2\x80\x99s\nproblem of the minimum induced drag of a wing with a limited span.\nAt subsonic speeds, even if we allow a large area for the production\nof lift, the minimum drag can still be achieved by a concentration of\nthe lift along a narrow \xe2\x80\x9clifting line\xe2\x80\x9d having a small exposed area and\nhence small friction. A t supersonic speeds the minimum pressure\ndrag usually requires that the given lift be spread over as large an\narea as allowed by the constraint. An interesting example is provided by the wing of elliptic plan form, which curiously enough seems\nto have especially simple mathematical properties at supersonic\n\n588\n\nJONES\n\n153\n\nspeeds (Ref. 9). Here the optimum distribution shows no concentration of the lift in any preferred region, but spreads uniformly over\nwhatever elliptical area is allotted. The resulting formula for the\npressure drag is\nDmin = 2\npv2s\n\nHere a/b is the axis ratio, subject to the Prandtl-Glauert transformation.\n.\nE. W. Graham, H Luskin, and P. A. Lagerstrom (Ref. lo), in studies made for the Douglas Aircraft Company (Ref. 10 et. seq.), have\nextended these ideas to distributions of lift in three dimensions. As\npointed out to the author by Graham, formula (2) yields the minimum\ndrag not only for the given elliptical area but also for an enlarged area\nbounded by Mach lines and by lines parallel to the stream direction.\nWith a straight ellipse the reduction of drag for a given total lift 0:\nfor a given maximum thickness depends primarily on increasing the\nexposedwingareas. If we consider an oblique ellipse, then a different\nform of dependence appears. In this case Eq. (2) is replaced by\n\nHere m is defined by the shearing transformation of the ellipse:\nx \' = x + m \' y , y\'=y,\na \' is the intercept of the sheared ellipse with the longitudinal x axis\nand b is the maximum semispan (see Ref. 9). If we now assume that\nthe area allotted by our constraint is that bounded by the Mach lines\nand the streamlines as shown in Fig. 6, it is seen that the area actually occupied by the ideal distribution becomes extraordinarily small\nwhen the wing is yawed behind the Mach cone. This change coincides\nwith the reappearance of the Kutta-Joukowsky flow, and enables the\n\nFigure 6-Optimum distribution of lift\nfor area bounded by streamlines and\nMach lines tangent to ellipse.\n\n5 89\n\nHIGH-SPEED AERONAUTICS\nrequirements of minimum pressure drag and minimum friction drag\nto be satisfied simultaneously.\nAt large angles of sweep or yaw the drag due to lift becomes in a\nlarge measure independent of the exact distribution, but depends primarily on the span b and the length 1 of the wing. For such cases the\nsimpler approximate formula\nDmin =-\n\nL2\n\nM 2 -1 L2\n+ *\nz\n\n(4)\n\nshows the essential dependence. The minimum drag occurs when both\nthe lengthwise and the spanwise loadings are elliptical.\nFor supersonic speed we thus require the maximum span b and the\nmaximumlength 1, together with the minimum of exposed area. These\nconditions determine the oblique, elliptically loaded lifting line as an\nideal limiting form for the supersonic wing. It seems unfortunate that\na bilaterally symmetrical form, such as a swept wing or a V-shaped\nlifting line could not satisfy the requirement. However if we bend the\nlifting line at the middle to form a V it is seen that the wave resistance\nincreases considerably.\nIn order to show the effect of more conventional wing forms on potential supersonic cruising efficiency, I have estimated the lift-drag\nratios of several wings in combination with a slender fuselage. Converting these to values of the thrust required by an airplane weighing\n50,000 pounds and cruising at 900 miles per hour yields the values\nshown on Fig. 7. For this comparison the wing thicknesses were selected so as to make possible equal bending stiffness. The order of\nthe comparison would not be changed, however, if a wing of zero thickness were substituted in any one of the examples.\nFor an operating altitude of 60,000 feet the wing loading in the first\ntwo examples should be about 50 pounds per square foot-or the same\n\n5QOO\n\nIbs\n\n7poo I bs\n\n9,000Ibs\n\nFigure 7-Effect of wing form on required cruising\nthrust. Values shown are for 50,000-Ib. airplane.\n\n590\n\nJONES\nas that of a subsonic airplane of this size. Since the indicated airspeed\nat 60,000feet is one-third the true airspeed, the structure needs to be\nsufficiently rigid to withstand-with customary safety margins-a sealevel cruising speed of only 300 miles per hour.\nFigure 7 also shows the relative proportions of a conventional turbojet engine designed to produce 10,000 pounds of thrust at sea level.\nUnder our conditions the thrust will be diminished to about one-fourth\nthis value, so that two such engines would be required in the first example. In this case we obtain a specific range of more than one mile\nper gallon. This latter value compares favorably with that achieved by\nearly model Trimotors, but is of course somewhat less than that obtained with present-day transports operating at subsonic speeds.\nWe hear a greatdeal these days about the "heat barrier." However,\nat 900 miles per hour and 60,000 feet this barrier has notyetbeen\nreached. It may be readily calculated that at this speed the aerodynamic heating is no more sufficient to bring the airplane up to room\ntemperature at these levels. Of course, demonstrations of speed at\nsea level would be rigidly prohibited, both for structural and therqal\nreasons.\nTo adapt the airplane to a lower altitude the wing loading needs to\nbe increased. However, if we assume that the maximum density has\nalready been reached in examples I and 1 , this cannot be done within\n1\nthe limitation of strict geometric similarity. On the other hand, if the\nairplane is adapted to the lower altitude simply by reducing the size of\nthe wing, then the lift-drag ratio will naturally be reduced. In example\nIIIof Figure 7 the wing area was so reduced to suit conditions at 40,000\nfeet. The thrust required to support the given load then increased to\n9000 pounds. Of course if strict geometric similarity could be maintained, a sacrifice of economy would not be involved.\nComparisons of such oversimplified wing-body combinations as\nshown here may not disclose the full effect of a loss in aerodynamic\nf\nefficiency. I the thrust needs to be increased at a given altitude then\nmore or larger engines will have to be used and the possibility of concealing them becomes less. In this process the lift-drag ratio of the\ncomplete airplane may become still more unfavorable than indicated\nby the comparison.\nThese primarily aerodynamic and structural considerations point\ntoward the development of turbojet engines specifically adapted to\noperation in an atmosphere of one tenth normal density. In addition to\nthe numerous other technological problems associated with operation\nat these highaltitudes, the problems of safe descent and effective limitation to low speeds at low altitudes seem important.\n\n591\n\nHIGH-SPEED AERONAUTICS\nREFERENCES\n\n1 \xe2\x80\x9cAeroplane Construction and Operation,\xe2\x80\x9d John B.
