Jones\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1957\n\n593\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nREPORT 1335\nMINIMUM WAVE DRAG FOR ARBITRARY ARRANGEMENTS OF WINGS AND BODIES\nBy ROBEBT . JONES\nT\nSUMMARY\n\nStudies o various arrangements of wings and bodies designed\nf\nto prowide favorable wave interference at supersonic speeds lead\nto the problem of determining the minimum possible value of the\nf\nf\nwave resistance obtainable by any dispositwn o the elements o\nan aircraft within a deJinitely prescribed region. Under the\nassumptions that the total lift and the total volume o the aircraft\nf\nare given, conditions that must be satk$ed i f the drag is to be a\nminimum are found. !Z%ereport concludes with a discussion o\nf\nrecent developments o the theory which lead to an improved\nf\nunderstanding of the drag associated with the production of lift.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nThe losses associated with the production of a given lift in\nfrictionless flow are generally diminished by increasing the\nmass of air entrained or influenced by the wing system. At\nthe same time, however, the loss due to friction becomes\ngreater when the exposed surface area of the wing is increased. To minimize the resultant drag we thus require a\nlifting system which effects the largest entrainment and yet\nhas the smallest exposed surface area.\nAt subsonic speeds the mass of air entrained depends only\non the lateral dimensions of the wing and is not diminished by\nconcentrating the lift within a narrow chordwise dimension.\nThe fact that a lifting line perpendicular to the direction of\nflight has such an extensive lateral influence must be considered a peculiarity of subsonic flow; it depends of course on\nthe unlimited propagation of the pressure field ahead of the\nwing. At supersonic speed the lateral entrainment begins\nonly at the foremost points of the wing surface and is confined to the interior of the rearward-sloping Mach waves from\nthis point. Finally, at extreme speeds for which Newtonian\nflow may be envisioned, the mass of air affected is limited to\nthe mass coming directly into contact with the wing, so that\nthe area of influence is simply the frontally projected area of\nthe wing.\nAnother peculiarity of the subsonic inviscid flow is the\ncomplete lack of resistance associated with the thickness of\nthe bodies or wings. At supersonic speeds, however, such a\ncomponent of drag does arise and this drag appears in the\nenergy required for the continual extension of the wave\nsystem.\nNow the problem of minimizing drag at supersonic speeds\nmay be treated mathematically in eeveral ways, depending\non the constraints adopted in the statement of the problem.\nIf, following Munk\xe2\x80\x99s problem of the minimum induced\ndrag at subsonic speeds, we impose a constraint merely on\nSUpeRedes NACA\n\nthe lift L and the span b of the wing, then we obtain the\nl\nsame value for the drag at a l Mach numbers, namely the\ninduced drag associated with the vortex wake. However,\nto achieve this value at supersonic speeds the wing would\nbe required to have an infinitely great length in the flight\ndirection so that the downward momentum associated with\nthe lift could be introduced gradually along the flight path,\nwithout appreciable wave formation.\nIn order to put the problem of drag at supersonic speeds\nin a definite form the present writer proposed (ref. 1) that\nthe outline or plan form S of the wing be adopted as a\nconstraint rather than single lengthwise or spanwise dimensions. Thus for supersonic speeds we are led to consider\nthe distribution of a given total lift L o&era specified plan\nform S in such a way as to minimize the drag D.\nIn the latter problem it is presupposed that the lifting\nsystem is confined to a plane. However, the possibility\nof favorable interference with three-dimensional arrangements of airfoils and bodies should not be averlooked.\nThus, Busemann has shown (ref. 2) that the wave drag can\nbe completely canceled by reflection between the upper and\nlower wings of a biplane. Later Ferrari (ref. 3) showed\nthat the drag of a body of revolution muld be canceled by\nthe addition of a ring airfoil to catch the wave from the\nnose and reflect it back to the tail.\nThe examples in which the wave cancellation is complete\nare, however, limited to systems in which the net lift 4\nlateral force are zero. Nevertheless, examples cited by\nFerri (ref. 4), Lomax and Heaslet (ref. 5 ) , and Graham\n(ref. 6) indicate that thg wave drag associated with the\nlift can be diminished by various three-dimensional arrangements of wings and bodies. These examples lead to a search\nfor some general statements or criteria regarding the drag\nof such three-dimensional arrangements.\nCONDITIONS FOR MINiMUM DRAG\n\nTo put the present question in a definite form it will be\nassumed the airfoils and bodies are disposed in the interior\nof a definite three-dimensional region R (see &. 1. The\n)\nregion R thus represents a geometrical constraint on the\ndimensions of the aircraft. Three-dimensional problems\nof a similar type have been considered by E. W. Graham\nand his colleagues (ref. 6) who give, for example, the o p t h u m\ndistributions of lift in spherical and ellipsoidal regions.\nHere we assume the total lift L and the volume V to be\ngiven. In a typical situation the lift L will be produced\n\nTN 3530 by Robert T.Jones. 1856.\n\n595\n\nREPORT 1335-NATIONAL\n\n-\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTIC8\n\ni\n\nW=mnstMt\n\nT=0\nax\n\n5\n\nconstant\n\nFIGURE\nI.-Conditions\n\nfor minimum drag distributions of lift and\nvolume in region R.\n\nby one or more airfoils whie the volume V will represent\nthe internal volume of one or more bodies of revolution plus\nthe volume of the wing. The region R may then be thought\nof as the region within which the parts of the aircraft may\nbe disposed so as to gain the maximum favorable interference.\nFrom a slightly different standpoint, R merely represents\nthe maximum dimensions of the aircraft. We shall be\nespecially interested in structures which minimize the\ndrag for the largest possible region, but which in themselves\noccupy only a small part of this region.\nSuppose region R together with a distribution of singularities, such as sources or lifting vortices, is given (see fig. 1).\nThen by Khrmiin and Hayes\xe2\x80\x99 cheorem (ref. 7) the drag will\nbe unchanged by a reversal of the whole system. The\ngeometry of the flow, including that of the airfoils and bodies,\nwill be changed by the reversal but the total lift and the\ntotal volume will not. The drag for either direction of flow\nmay then be computed by means of a fictitious \xe2\x80\x9ccombined\ndisturbance field\xe2\x80\x9d obtained by superimposing the disturbances in forward and reversed motion. I), essentially similar to the\nwell-known Ursell-Ward reciprocal relation, which connects\nthe drag of any two interfering distributions of singularities\nin the combined flow field. According to this relation, the\ndrag of distribution A caused by the interference of a second\ndistribution B is equal to the drag added to B by the interference of A. Now let A be a distribution within RA satisfying conditions (1). For B select a distribution having\nf\nzero total lift and zero total volume. I RB is contained\nwithin RA, then the addition of B will amount simply to a\nredistribution, without changing the given lift L or volume\nV of A. The drag of A + B may then be written i r L shorthand notation\n\n+\n\nD ( A+B)=D.u +DAB DBA\n+DEB\n(31\nThen, since by the mutual drag relation DAB=DLIA1\nthis\nequation may be written as\n\n+\n\nD(A B )=DA,t+*REA\n+DEB\n\nE)A\n\nDE,=L ~ $ + puvB(\n\nHowever, since LE and V, are both zero DBn vanides and\nthe added drag is that of distribution B alone, or DBB. Now\nthe drag of an isolated system can never be negative, hence\nD(A+B) cannot be less than D ( A ) under the conditions (1).\nOn the other hand, suppose, for example that the sidewash ZA were not zero. A distribution of lateral forces\ncould then be found which would result in a negative interference drag, dominating the quadratic term DEBt so that\n&e total drag could be reduced. Hence, if the drag of\ndistribution A actually is a minimum value, then conditions\n(1) must be complied with.\nf\nThe question o uniqueness depends on the existence of\ndistributions of type B for which the drag is zero. As shown\nby Graham, such distributious exist in three dimensions\nand hence the minimum drag corresponding to a given\nregion R may be achieved by a variety of arrangements.\nIn the case of a planar region, such as the plan form S of a\nwing, distributions of lift or volume having zero drag do not\nexist, and hence in these cases the optimum distributions are\nunique.\nd;ii a r\nSince %=-, a+ 5=-ai; and -=z2\xe2\x80\x99 be seen that conax it can\n\naz\n\nay\n\nax\n\nditions (1) do not agree with the linearized flow equation\n(1- - ~ ) & * + Z l l v + i i ; z r = O\n\nin general, but only if\n\n(6)\n\n-\n\nbU4-J\nax\n\n596\n\n(4\n)\n\nHere DBA the drag of B in the combined disturbance field\nis\nof A. Examples such as the Busemann\n\n,\n\nLotwol force distribution\non fin,&\n\naiz\n\nbiplane satisfy the condition --0.\n\nax-\n\nIt is interesting to note that conditions analagous to E=\nconstant and 5=0 were found by Munk in connection with\nthe vortex drag of lifting systems a t subsonic speeds. In\nthat problem, the conditions apply to the twodimensional\nmotion associated with the trace of the wing system in the\nTrefftz plane. If the idea of superimposed disturbance\nfields is utilized in the subsonic problem, one finds that the\ncylindrical flow associated with the Trefftz plane emrtends\nalong the whole fiight path, including the region R. Conditions (1) thus apply at both subsonic and supersonic\nspeeds.\nMunk\xe2\x80\x99s condition of constant dowuwash and zero sidewash were used by Hemke (ref. 8) to calculate the effectiveness of end plates in reducing the vortex drag a t low speeds.\nIn such problems the condition is usually imposed by the\nstatement that the trace of the airfoil system must move\ndownward as a rigid body. It will be interesting to see\nhow this condition might be used under more general circumstances. This application is illustrated in figure 2 for\nan end plate on the tip of a wing.\nWith the wing in forward motion, the lateral velocity\nv, a t the surface of the end plate is simply the lateral slope\nof the fin surface multiplied by the stream. velocity. The\nand this condition is\ncondition iJ=O implies that v,=-v,\nobviously satisfied by keeping the geometry of the fin fixed\nwhen the flow is reversed. At the same time, however,\nrecall that the distribution of lift and lateral force must be\nkept the same in forward and reversed flow. Hence, the\nproblem of finding the optimum setting and camber for such\na fin is solved by finding that particular shape for which the\nflow is exactly reversible, that is, the lateral pressure distribution remains unchanged by a reversal of flow direction.\nAt first it seems impossible to satisfy such a requirement,\nsince, for example, the direction of the force on an inched\nsurface is usually reversed by a reversal of the direction of\nflow. However, the form of the adjacent wing surface\nmust, in general, change with the reversal, since zO#O and\nsince the lift distribution on the wing must remain unchanged.\nThen it is evident that the conditions might be satisfied if\nthe pressures on the fin surface were dominated by the wing\npressures through interference.\nRecently W. Wilmarth (ref. 9) has found several examples\nof wings with end plates which minimize the drag for certain\nprismatic regions.\nThe conditions for minimum drag are of course simply the\nresult of the constraints adopted in the initial statement of\nthe problem; and these are to a certain extept arbitrary.\nNevertheless, experience shows that the study of such\nproblems is likely to disclose essential relations in their\nclearest form.\nWith the aid of the combined flow field and the mutual\ndrag theorem, it is a relatively simple matter to extend the\n\nApl=A+; Lateral face distribution unchanged\n=\n\n-5 ;Fin geometry\n\nunchanged\n\nFIGURE\n!L-Use o condition 3=0 to determine optimum setting of\nf\nvertical fin on wing tip.\n\nconstraints in various ways. Thus in the case of a planar\nwing if both the total lift L and the spanwise loading are\nspecified, minimum drag requires that E be constsnt along\nchordwise strips, but may vary laterally. Here we have\ni\n\nZ=f(v)\n\n(8)\n\nIn case thclengthwise loading is specified we have\nZ=j(x)\n\n(9)\n\nAgain, if the first moment of the load distribution about the\naxis is specified\nE=a,+ap\n(10)\nand so on.\nI the conditions on the combined disturbance velocities\nf\nhold beyond the boundaries of the region R, then the drag\ncannot be changed by extending the distribution of lift or\nvolume into the new region. In general, this will-not be\nthe case, however, and the drag can be continually dimmished\nby increasing the dimensions of R. Thus in the case of a\nmonoplane wing a strong upwash appears beyond the wing\ntips, indicating that thb drag could be diminished by\nincreasing the span. Similarly, sidewash velocities appear\njust above and below the planar region, and the drag could\nbe reduced by extending vertical fins, or \xe2\x80\x9cfences\xe2\x80\x9d into this\nregion.\nIt must be admitted that the considerations have thus\nfar been rather abstract. A more concrete result would\nyield the actual magnitudes of the drag associated with\nvarious regions, as well as the shapes of the bodies or wings.\nAlthough no direct method of calculation has been proposed,\nnumerous examples have been found. Thus reference 6\ngives the optimum distributions of lift in spherical and\nellipsoidal regions.\nA rough lower bound for the minimum wave drag associated\nwith any region may be obtained from Hayes\xe2\x80\x99 formula (ref.\n7) or the formula of Lomax (ref. 5 . With these formulas a\n)\nspatial distribution of lift or volume may be resolved into\na number of equivalent lmear distributions, the latter\nobtained from the intersections of the region R by plane\n?J\n\n597\n\nREPORT 1335-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nwaves lying a t various/ angles e around the 2 axis. The wave\ndrag of the system is then the sum of values for the linear\ndistributions integrated from B=O to ~ = 2 ~The expression\n.\nfor the wave drag of a single linear distribution is the same\n(except for a constant factor) as the expression for the vortex\n.drag of a lifting line in subsonic flow. Thus, for a single\ne l l i p t i d y Ioaded lifting line of length I parallel to the flight\ndirection the wave drag is:\n\nThis value may be used as an approximation for the wave\ndrag of any narrow wing lying near the center of the Mach\ncone. Deviations are to be expected for wider wings;\nhowever, these deviations are not very pronounced, as\nfigure 3 shows. In this figure values of the wave drag\nobtained from exact theoretical formulas are compared\nwith the values given by the approximate expression (11).\nThe \xe2\x80\x9cexact\xe2\x80\x9d values were obtained by superimposing uniformly loaded wings of elliptical plan form and are not the\nminimum values for the resulting plan forms.\nA sufficient condition for the wave drag of a lifting system\nto have a minimum value is that all the projected loadings,\nin addition to the lengthwise loading, be elliptical. In this\ncase we obtain the formula\n(12)\n\nwhere\n\nand Z(0) is the projected length of the region R as defined in\nfigure 4 with fl=Jj$jCi.\nThe value given by equations (12) and (13) is Bctually\nattained by elliptic wings and by distributions of lift in\nspherical or ellipsoidal regions (ref. 6). However, for\n\nI\n\n0\n\nI\n\n.\n4\n\nFILWIZE\n3.-Approximate\n\n598\n\nI\n\nI\n\n.2\n\nm\n\nI\n\n.\n6\n\n.8\n\nI\n\nI .o\n\nexpression for wave drag o lifting surface.\nf\n\nMach plane\n\n1\n\n/\n\n/\n\n./\n\n/\n\n7\n\n*\n\nx\n\n/\n\nFIGURE\n4.-Lower bound for wave drag Ussociated with the Pegion R\nm d the lift L.\n\ntriangular or swept wings of the type depicted in figure 3,\nthe values given by the simpler expression equation (11) are\nmore accurate.\nIn a recent paper (ref. 10) M. I. Kogan has pointed out\nthat determination of the minimum drag of a lifting surface\nhaving no subsonic edges can be reduced to the solution of\nLaplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation in the two-dimensional region bounded\nexternally by the trace of the chqacteristic envelope, and\nbounded internally by the vortex trace of the Wing. In\naddition to pvv+qtl=O, the boundary condition that no\ndisturbance extend beyond the Mach cone corresponds to the\ncondition q=O on the outline of the characteristic trace; S j\n(i. e., the outer rim of the Mach envelope in fig. 1) while the\ncondition of constant downwash corresponds to q,=constant\non the vortex trace.\nThe result given by Kogan has been derived independently\nby E. W. Graham (ref. 11) and by G. N. Ward (ref. 12).\nGraham makes use of the combined flow field, and shows\nthat fields which are two-dimensional throughout the\ninterior of any given characteristic envelope, and which\nsatisfy the condition q-,=G=constant on a vortex trace\npassing through the region, can be constructed.\nSuch solutions correspond to our previous conditions (6)\nand (7) and are not restricted to wings having supersonic\nedges.\nIn Ward\xe2\x80\x99s analysis the physical flow is used, but the drag\nis calculated by using the forward-going surface of the\ncharacteristic envelope as a control surface. Since q = O\nthere in the reversed flow, it can be seen that the values of Q\nin the real flow coincide with those in the combined flow on\nthis surface. By a projection of the disturbance velocities\non this surface, Ward reduces the integral for drag to I)irichlet\xe2\x80\x99s integral, which is a minimum when the derived velocity\nfield satisfies hplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation.\nApplicstions of this method to problems involving thickness and volume have been given by M. A. Heaslet (ref. 13).\nProblems in which both the lift and $he center of pressure are\ngiven have been treated by P. Germain (ref. 14).\nThese theoretical developments provide an interesting\nintuitive picture of the drag associated with the production\nof lift a t supersonic speeds. At subsonic speeds the lifting\nwing leaves in its wake a two-dimensional, essentially incompressible downwash flow bounded internally by thc\n\nXINIMUM WA9E DRAG FOR U B I T R A R Y A\xe2\x82\xaciRANGEMENTS OF WINGS AND BODIES\n\nvortex wake, but unbounded externally. According to\nEelvin\xe2\x80\x99s theorem such an incompressible downwash flow\nsatisfying puv+pzz=O, minimizes &he kinetic energy relative to all other streamline motions satisfying the saIlie\nboundary conditions. For a given lift, (or downward\nmomentum) the kinetic energy, and hence the drag, is\nminimized when the wake moves with constant downwash.\nA t supersonic speeds we are led to consider not the flow in\nthe Trefftz plane a t infinity, but the flow in the last characteristic surface where the zone of inflnence lies entirely\nbehind the wing. The two-dimensional flow obtained by\nprojection on this surface will be limited laterally by its\nintersection with the real Mach wave, where \xe2\x80\x98p must vanish,\nand will be bounded internally by the vortex wake on the\nthe trailing edge of the wing. This flow is certainly not incompressible in general. However, if the wing is to have\nthe minimum drag consistent with the given span and with\nthe given limitations of the lateral zone of influence, then\nby Kelvin\xe2\x80\x99s theorem the flow must imitate the streamlines\nof an incompressible lateral flow in this intervening limited\nregion. For a given total lift the vortex wake should again\nmove with constant downwash.\nThe condition p=O on the rim of the characteristic\nenvelope is exactly the same as that imposed a t the boundary of an open-jet wind tunnel. Hence, we are led to compare the ection of the wing in supersonic flow with that of a\nwing in a finite jet (fig. 5 ) . Wings having small fore and\naft dimensions have a limited lateral entrainment, as shown\nby the small cross sections of their equivalent incompressible\njets (see fig. 6).\nIn Munk\xe2\x80\x99s theory of the minimum induced drag the \xe2\x80\x9carea\nof the additional apparent mass\xe2\x80\x9d associated with the vortex\ntrace of the wing plays an important role. Denoting this\narea by S,\xe2\x80\x98, we have for the drag due to lift\n\nFIGURE\n&-Effect of fore and aft dimension of wing on area of lateral\nentrainment.\n,\n\nmass of the wing in the limited jet determined by the Mach\nwaves. If the Mach number of the stream is reduced, the\nwaves become more nearly vertical and the equivalent jet\nexpands laterally, reaching an infinite cross section a t M= 1 .O.\nBelow M=1.0 the wing is operating in unlimited flow and\nwe then have:\nb2\nS,\xe2\x80\x99=r (15)\n4\nwhich leads to\n2\nD=- 2L\n\nupUZ6\xe2\x80\x98\n\nThis formula actually applies in perfect fluid flow a t all\nspeeds if S is replaced by Sm,\xe2\x80\x98, the additional apparent\n,\n\xe2\x80\x98\n\nOn the other hand, a t extremely high supersonic speeds, the\nequivalent jet contracts into a narrow space around the\nfrontal projection of the wing. In this case the streamlines\nof the downflow in the jet will be nearly straight and parallel,\nas illustrated in figure 6, and the area Sm,\xe2\x80\x99 will be substantially equal to the area of the jet S,.\nJ special cases the two-dimensioDal downflow in the\nh\ncharacteristic trace or jet S, can be readily calculated. Thus\nin the case of the elliptic wing the envelope of characteristics\nhas an elliptic cross section, with the vortex trace of the wing\nextending between the foci. Now if a flat plate moves downward (along z ) in unlimited flow, the potential at the surface\nof any confocal elliptic cylinder will be of the form p,=kzd.\nHence the boundary condition $=O may be satisfied on any\nsuch confocal ellipse by adding a uniform downwash throughout its interior so that w = -k or p= -kz. When the downward momentum of the resultant flow is computed, it is\nfound to correspond to a virtual mass with area Sui\xe2\x80\x98 given\nbv\n\nFIGURE\n5.-Equivalent incompressible jet for wing at supersonic speed.\n\n599\n\nREPORT 1335-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\n-,y\n/\n\n/\n\nmust be concluded therefore that of d the plan forms having\nl\na given characteristic envelope, only those whose surface\narea is extensive enough to enclose the required surface distribution of lift can achieve the minimum drag given by\nequation (14).\n\nAMES AERONAUTICAL\nLABORATORY\nNATIONAL\nADVISORY\nCOMMITTEE AERONAUTICS\nFOR\nMOFFETT\nFIELD,\nCALIF., Aug. 14,1957\nREFEBENCES\n\nFIGUEE\n7.-Effect\n\nof Mach number on lateral entrainment.\n\nIn the case of a long slender wing lying near the center\nof the Mach cone (slender wing theory) the characteristic\ntrace will be circular. An elliptical lengthwise distribution\nof l i f t then produces an incompressible downwash flow\nresembling that of a dipole a t the center of the circle. The\nadded downwash required to make p = O on this circular\nboundary then yields our formula (11) for the wave drag.\nIf we try to find the surface loading or shape that corresponds to the drag given by equation (14),we discover that\nKogan\xe2\x80\x99s analysis has in fact carried us away from our origin l problem in which the plan form of the wing (or the\na\nregioD R occupied by the lifting system) was given. The\ninformation given now concerns only the trace of the wing\nand its Characteristic envelope. Now, the relation between\nthe plan form of a wing and its characteristic trace is certainly\nnot unique. On the other hand the particular form of the\ntwo-dimensional flow on the reversed characteristic surface\nmust require a unique distribution of lift in the plane of the\nwing. (USA.)*)\n\nSome Recent D e v e l o R ~ e ~ ~\nin the Aerodynamii of Wings for High Speeds"*)\nUbersicht: Die in der vorltegenden Arbeit behandelten Gegenstande betref fen 1. eine kiirzlich vorgescblagene Korrekturformel\nf i r den EinfluJ der Kompressibilitat bei der zweidimensionalen Unterschallstromung, 2. Aquivalenzsatz und Flachenregel fur\ntranssoniscbe Stromungen, 3. Reziprozitatsbeziehungen in der linearisierten Tragfliigeltheorie und 4. einige allgemeine Ergebnisse,\ndie mit dem Problem des minimalen Wellenwiderstandes zusammenhangen. Die Arbeit schlieflt mit einem Beispiel uber die Einschniirung des Rumpfes zur Erzielung einer giinstigen Interferenz mit dem Fliigel bei Uberschallgescbwindigkeit.\nSummary: The items discussed in this summary paper are 1. a recently proposed correction formula for the effect of compressibility in two-dimensional subsonic flow, 2. the equivalence rule and the area rule for transonic speeds, 3. reciprocal relations in\nlinearized wing theory, and 4. some general results connected with the problem of minimum wave resistance. The paper\nconcludes with an example showing indentation of the fuselage t o obtain favorable interference with the wing at supersonic\nspeeds.\nRisumi: Les probUmes traitis dans le travail prisent concernent: 1) une formrle de correction, ricemment proposde, destinhe d\nditerminer l\'influence de la compressibiliti dans le cas de l\'dcoulement subronique bidimensionnel; 2 ) le thioreme de l\'iquivalence\net la regk de la surface des icoulements transsoniques; 3) des relations de riciprocitC de la thiorie liniarisie des ailes portantes;\n4 ) quelqaes rdsultats giniraux liis au probl2me du minimum de la rdsistance d\'ondes. Le travail conclut en relevant un exemple\nde retricissement du fuselage destini d provoquer une interfirence plus favorable avec l\'aile aux vitesses supersoniques.\n\nThe student of fluid mechanics cannot fail to be impressed\nby the complexity of the phenomena that arise under\nsimple circumstances. Even if we admit only the simplest\nproperties of the fluid together with elementary\ndynamical laws for the motion, unexpectedly intricate\nmotions may appear. As examples, I may mention the\nperiodic Taylor-Gortler vortices that appear when a\nslightly viscous liquid flows over a concave surface or,\nagain, the characteristic geometrical shapes of rhe\n"patches" of turbulence that have recently been observed\nby Emmonr and Schubauer (NACA TN 3489,Sept. 1955)\nin regions of transition from laminar to turbulent\nboundary-layer flow.\nIn what is commonly understood by the term "airfoil\ntheory" we limit the range and complexity of our\ninvestigations considerably by studying particularly\nsimple flows that are apt to be of efficient service in the\nflight of an airplane. Thus in the Prandtl wing theory we\nstudy the properties of long, narrow wings, which afford\nthe highest aerodynamic efficiency at ordinary speeds\nad-which at the same time admit a mathematical simpli6cation because of their extreme proportions. Furthermore, in Prandtl\'s theory we consider only section flows\nof the Kutta- Joukowsky type.\nWith a different type of section flow, such as might be\nproduced by shakpening the leading edge, the long,\nnarrow wing loses its advantage and the dependence of\n\ndrag on aspect ratio follows more unfavorable laws. (See,\ne. g., ref. [l].)\nThe extraordinary efficiency of a well designed airfoil\n.\nin two-dimensional flow is illustrated in Fig. 1 Such an\nairfoil, of conventional form, may show a lift-to-drag\nratio of 100 to 1 or at smaller lift coefficients, a drag\ncoefficient of 0,005. The latter coefficient corresponds\nroughly to the drag of a circular cylinder having a\ndiameter %oo th of the wing chord.\n\nFig. 1\n\nAirfoil compared with circular wire having equal drag\n\nAs is well known, airfoil flows basically similar to the\nKutta-Joukowsky flow can be maintained up to very\nhigh speeds in the subsonic range. Within this range the\ndrag of the wing consists essentially of the induced drag\nand the surface friction, so that the plan form of the wing\nis determined, roughly speaking, by the criterion of\nmaximum span together with that of minimum surface\n\n*) National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, Ames Aeronautical Laboratory.\n") Paper for presentation at the meeting of GAMM. VDI. and W G L at Gottingen, Germany, October 6, \' , 8, 1955.\n1\n\n603\n\nR.T.\n]ones, Some Recent Developments in the Aerodynamics of Wings\narea. For this range of speeds the straight wing having\nthe highest practicable aspect ratio thus remains the most\nefficient aerodynamic form.\nThe efficient operation of airfoils at the upper end of this\nspeed range seems to require primarily that the sections\nbe thin - so that a method of calculation based on\nexpansion in powers of the thi&ness-&ord ratio would\nappear\nbe especially appropriate. such\nare\nwell known through the work of Gsrtler [2], Huntzs&\nand Wendt [3], Kaplan [4], Imaj [5], and others.\nRecently Van Dyke [6], utilizing a result of ayes [7],\nhas shown that the pressure distribution around a thin\nairfoil in two-dimensional motion can be related in a\nsimple way to the corresponding distribution in incompressible flow by this method. Pressure correction formula for subsonic flow\nm two dimensions, Eq (1) - (4)\n\nAs the speed of sound is approached, the threedimensional wing flow can no longer be approximated by\nthe assumption of locally two-dimensional flows over the\nwing sections. As shown by the linear Prandtl-Glauert\ntheory, the disturbance field of a wing section expands\nvenically without limit, so that the dimensions of the\nregion of disturbance eventually become large compared\nto the chord of the wing sections. The section flow is\nthen no longer a local phenomenon but must be modified\nby the spanwise dimensions of the wing.\nIn linear theory we treat the disturbance field of a\nmoving wing by \' the approximations employed in\nacoustics. Thus the velocity potential of the flow\ndisturbance around the wing at either subsonic or supersonic velocities satisfies the well-known sound wave\nequation\n(5)\n\nIt is interesting to note how far the experimental lift and\nlift distribution follow this simple linear theory in the\ntransonic range. Drag and lift at M.c 1. Rectangular wings,\nNACA 65 A 0 XX profiles\n\n+\n\nv\n\n~\n\n~\n\no\n\n~\n\n2.1. Flugwks. 4 (1956). Heft 8\n\nR. 7.]ones, Some Recent Developments in the Aerodynamics of Wings\n\'\n\nAt higher aspect ratios the values of lift and drag given\nby Guderley and Yoshihara [13] are approached.\nWhen we try to determine the disturbance field produced\nby a body or wing moving at sonic velocity we face the\ndifficulty that the form of the disturbance is not very\ndefinitely connected with the geometry of the body. At\nthis speed extensive longitudinal disturbances can travel\nalmost indefinitely without the assistance of a moving\nsolid. Hence it is perhaps not surprising that a relatively\nintense longitudinal wave is built up by a solid which\ntravels for some time at this speed. Those who have been\nin the path of the well-known "sonic boom" have had a\ndirect experience of this longitudinal wave.\nAccording to the "equivalence principle" of Oswatitsch\n[14], the potential, q, of this large-scale longitudinal\ndisturbance is determined by the longitudinal distribution\nof areas presented in planes perpendicular to the flight\ndirection. Hence, the potential at large distances reduces\nto that for an equivalent body of revolution. In\nWhitcomb\'s paper [ 151 on the "area rule" both the form\nof the wave disturbance and the incremental drag at\ntransonic speeds were shown to depend on this\ndistribution of cross-sectional area. The dependence of\nwave drag on the area distribution was given by Hayes\n[16] as a formal result of the linear theory at transonic\nspeed. In Whitcomb\'s experiments it was demonstrated\nfurther that the drag associated with the thicknesc of a\nwing can be effectively suppressed by removing an\nappropriate "area distribution" from the fuselage. With\nthese new developments it appears that wing theory at\ntransonic speeds should not be limited to the properties of\nisolated airfoils.\nAs a simple test of Whitcomb\'s drag-equivalence idea,\nSpreiter [17] has analysed the results of experiments\nmade at Ames Laboratory on rectangular airfoils having\nvarious aspect ratios and various thickness-chord ratios.\nTo maintain the same area distribution an airfoil having\na high aspect ratio and a thin section is compared with\none of lower aspect ratio but with a thicker section. For\nnonlifting wings with symmetrical sections the rule is\nverified up to aspect ratios of 3 or more. Fig. 4 shows the\ncomparison for aspect ratio 4.\n\n0\n\nI , II,\n, , 12\n,1.0,\n7\n8\n9\nMACH NUMBER\n\nFig. 4. Drag of wings having same area distribution\n\nRectangular wings of the forms shown have, of course, a\nlarge incremental drag at transonic speeds. Perhaps the\nmost effective practical method of reducing the drag at\ntransonic speeds is the use of extreme angles of sweep, thin\nsections, and slender bodies. As an illustration of the\nmagnitudes involved I would like to show drawings of\ntwo models that have been tested by the NACA (Fig. 5).\nThe two models with the relative dimensionsshown would,\naccording to the indication of our experiments, have the\nsame drag a t a slightly supersonic Mach number.\nAt the present time the calculation of three-dimensional\nwing flows at supersonic speed is carried out almost\n\nFig. 5. Models having same drag at low supersonic s p d (zero Izft)\n\nexclushely by means of the linearized theory. The\nprinciples employed in these calculations were brought\ninto sharp focus in the papers of Prandtl [18], von Kdrmdn E191 and Busernann [20] at the 1935 Volta Congress,\nwhile the f irst known application to the three-dimensional\nlifting wing appeared in Sfhlichting\'s paper of 1936 [21].\nLinearization of the flow equations brings the threedimensional wing theory within the realm of classical\nmethods of analysis and so has disclosed a variety of\ninteresting and unexpectedly *simple relations. For\nexample, if we consider a thin wing or body whose\ndisturbance field can be produced by the action of simple\nsources, then the drag of this body will be unchanged by\na reversal of the flow direction. Our attentioq was called\nto this "reversed flow" relation by von Kdrmrin and it\nwas generalized by Hayes [16] to include arbitrary\ndistributions of singularities such as lifting elements and\nsources in three-dimensions. Reversal of the now may\nchange the geometrical shapes however. In an interesting\npaper, Munk [22] has shown how such reversed flow\nrelations can be derived by considering the abstract\ndisturbance field obtained by superimposing the disturbance velocities generated by the forward motion, and\nthose generated by the reversed motion of the system.\nUtilizing this idea, Brown [23] has been able to show\nthat the lift-curve slope of a wing of any planform is\nunchanged by a reversal.\nA more general form of reversed-flow relation in steady\nwing flow theory is the reciprocal relation discovered by\nUrsell and Ward [24]. Starting with a shin lifting surface\nof planform S, we may consider the effect of warping or\ntwisting the wing in various ways, represented by\npermitting the local angle of attack a to vary with the\nposition x, y of a point on the planform. Such a warp or\ntwist a ( x , y ) will give rise to a distribution of lifting\npressure p ( x , y ) which is a linear functional of a determined by the flow equation and by the outline shape of the\nwing. Let a, and p 1 be two functions so related and let\na, and p z be a different, but similary related, pair of\ndistributions for the wing S in reversed flow; then the\nUrsell-Ward relation is\n\nFig. 6 illustrates one of the many interesting applications\nof this theorem. Here a1is taken as a constant value e ual\n3\n2\nto unity, over the whole surface, so that p1 is the distribution of lift arising when the wing as a whole is given a\nPI\n\n,a2\n\nPi\n\nI\n\nI\n\nFig. 6. Reciprocal relation. Eq. (8)\n\n605\n\nZ t,flugv&s. P I1956),Hell8\n.\n\nR. T.\n]ones, Some Recent Developments in the Aerodynamics of Wings\n\nunit angle of attadr. cc, has the value unity over a portion\nof the wing, or a flap, but has the value zero elsewhere.\npz then represents the distribution of lift over the whole\nwing, resulting from the deflection of a flap. The\nreciprocal relation then tells us that the l i t on the wing\ndue to deflecting the flap is equal to the lift on the flap\ndue to deflecting the wing with the flow reversed. This\nrelation is applicable at both subsonic and supersonic\nspeeds. The extension to airfoils in unsteady motion has\nbeen given by Flax [25] and by Heuslet and Spreiter [26]\nwho point out its connection with classical reciprocal\ntheorems of Helmholtz, Maxwell, and Ruyleigh.\nIt is interesting to note that extension of the reciprocal\ntheorem to nonstationary motion provided a means for\nverifying the coincidence between Kuessner and Sears\xe2\x80\x99\n\xe2\x80\x9cgust lift functions\xe2\x80\x9c and Wagner\xe2\x80\x99s function describing\nthe growth of circulation around an airfoil starting from\nrest for wings in three-dimensional flow.\nA classical problem in the theory of airfoils is the\ndetermination of the form of the wing or the distribution\nof lift for minimum drag. Thus we may think of Munk\xe2\x80\x99s\nproblem of the minimum \xe2\x80\x9cinduced\xe2\x80\x9c drag for a given\ntotal lift L and a given span b [27]. At supersonic speeds\nwe have to consider in addition to the induced drag a\nwave drag which depends in a rather complex way on the\ndistribution of lift over the whole surface. Surprisingly\nenough, however, we find a continual recurrence of ideas\nderived from this earlier problem in our studies of wave\ndrag of lifting surfaces at supersonic speeds.\nI n Munk\xe2\x80\x99s problem it was found that minimum drag\noccurs when the \xe2\x80\x9cinduced downwash* is constant at all\npoints of the span. To extend these considerations to\nsupersonic speeds we find it essential to specifiy not\nmerely the span, but the plan form of the wing [28]. By\nmaking use of the reversibility theorem we are able to\nexpress the drag in terms of a fictitious disturbance field,\nobtained by combining linearly the disturbances produced\nby a given distribution of lift in forward and in reversed\nmotion. The mean downwash W,obtained by averaging\nat each point the values in forward and reverse flow, then\ntakes the place of the \xe2\x80\x9cinduced downwash\xe2\x80\x9c and is\nquantitatively equal to the latter if the speed is subsonic.\nThe drag is obtained by integrating over the plan form S the\nproduct of the local lifting pressure A p and themean angle\ni\nof attack i = G/V. With a given total lift L and a given\nplan form S the minimum drag occurs when the mean\ndownwash G has the same value a t all points of S. This\nresult holds whether the speed is subsonic or supersonic.\n\nFig. 1. Conditions for minimum drag: distributions of hft and volume\ni region R\nn\n\n606\n\nIt is interesting to note that the idea of superimposing the\nforward and reversed disturbance fields was utilized in\nMunk\xe2\x80\x99s original proof of the so-called stagger theorem.\nIf we accept the idea of a combined supersonic disturbance field, then the necessary conditions for minimum\nresistance can be generalized to include interfering\ndistributions of lift and volume in three-dimensional\nregions. Here we may think of an arrangement of airfoils\nor lifting elements in space, but limited to the interior of\na region R. If the total lift L and the region R are given\nthen the minimum drag occurs when (see Fig. 7)\nW = const, 6 = 0\nthroughout R. The value of the minimum drag is then\n\n(9)\n\nDmin = L W / K\nThe computation of the drag of interfering lift distributions is simplified by a reciprocal relation, essentially\nsimilar to the Ursell-Ward relation, which appears in\nthe combined flow field. Thus if we consider any two\ndistributions of lift represented by 1, ( x , y, z ) and lb ( x , y, z)\nthen we may write in short-hand notation:\n\n(10)\n\n(11)\n\nDab\n\n=&a\n\nor, in words, \xe2\x80\x9cthe drag of a caused by the (combined)\ndisturbance field of b is equal to the drag of b caused by\nthe (combined) disturbance field of a.\xe2\x80\x9c\nIn view of this, we may write for the total drag\n\nD ( u 4- b) = Daa f 2 D b a f Dbb.\n(12)\nNow suppose that 1, satisfies conditions (9) and suppose\nthat Rb lies entirely within R,. Then\n(13)\n\nDoa = Lb E$v\n\nwith\n(14)\ne \xe2\x80\x99 = const = Da$L,,\n&\nso that the total drag, including the interference, is given\n\nby\n(15)\nD (a f b) = Daa ( I f &/La) -k Dbb.\nAs is well known, the elliptical spanwise distribution of\nlift yields the minimum, drag for a monoplane wing at\nsubsonic speeds. In our studies of minimum drag at\nsupersonic speeds we have found that the closest\nconnection with the theory for subsonic speeds can be\nmaintained if we employ a special method for the\ncalculation of drag. In this method [29] we make use of\nHayes\xe2\x80\x99 idea of equivalent positions of sources or lifting\nelements, together with the idea of the combined\ndisturbance field. Following this method, the combined\ndisturbance field of a lifting surface is constructed by the\nsuperposition of infinitely many plane waves, all lying at\nthe Mach angle, but at varying angles 0 around the flight\naxis ( x axis). At each angle 0 we construct an equivalent\n\xe2\x80\x9clifting line\xe2\x80\x9c by integrating the lift distribution in the\ndirection parallel to these planes. A sufficient condition\nfor the wave drag to be a minimum is that each equivalent\nlifting line be elliptically loaded. I find it quite surprising\nthat the elliptic loading appears again in the problem of\nminimum drag at supersonic speeds, although von Klrmln and Busemann have already noticed a similar\nconnection with the wave drag of bodies of revolution.\n\nWith a wing of elliptic plan form the minimum drag\noccurs when the lift L is distributed uniformly over the\n\n4 ( s 8 A.T.Jones, Some Recent Developments in the Aerodynamics of Wings\nIHeft ,\n)\n\n2. f.\n\nsurface. In this case integration of the surface loading in\nany oblique direction yields an elliptically loaded lifting\nline, as shown by Fig. 8. Since the spanwise loading is\nelliptic, the induced drag or vortex drag is also a\nminimum.\n\nLINES X = CONST, 2.0\nOS%-z S I N 8\n\nLIFTING SURFACE\n\ni\n\ni\n\nFig. 8. Integratlon of surface loading alonq Mad2 planes\n\nThe assumption that the integrated loading for ea& angle\n0 is elliptical can be used to derive a lower bound for the\nwave resistance associated with a given total lift and a\nregion R. This formula is illustrated in Fig. 9. For the\nminimum vortex drag under these conditions we may\nrefer to Munk\'s original paper [ 2 7 ] .\nMACH PLANE\n\nproblems involving the optimum distribution of .~.i&ess\nor volume within a region R or a plan form S.\nFollowing along the lines of the previous discussion, we\nsuppose that a region R is given and also a certain volume\nY to be contained in slender, closed bodies or airfoils\nwithin R. The condition for minimum drag is then that\nthe pressure gradient, proportional to a z / a n , in the\ncombined flow field be constant. Since the total drag is\nobtained by integrating the product of the local pressure\ngradient over the volume, we may say that minimum\ndrag for z given volume occurs when the drag per unit\nvolume is constant thro6ghout the region. It must be\nrememb\'ered, however, that the distribution of drag\nimplied in this statement refers to the fictitious\ndisturbance field obtained by averaging the forward and\nthe reversed disturbances.\nThe drag of interfering bodies and airfoils in threedimensional regions has been discussed in a recent paper\nby Graham, Beane, and Licher [ 3 0 ] . For nonliting\nsystems the wave drag can always be reduced to zero by\nreflections within the system as, in Ferrari\'s well-known\nexample of a shrouded body, or the Buseman72 biplane.\nThe projectile shapes of won Kirmrin [ 7 , Sears [31],\n1]\nand Haack [32] satisfy the condition 3ji/an = const\nthroughout the region R determined by-the interior of the\n"double Mach cone- with vertices at the nose and the t i .\nal\nIn this case, of course, the drag is only a relative minimum.\nHowever, it is interesting to see how we may simplify the\ncomputation of interference drag in such cases as\nillustrated in Fig. 11. Furthermore, by\nmaking this source distribution sufficiently long, the wing\ncan be contained entirely within this region. The interference drag is then simply the volume of the wing, va,\ntimes the constant gradient of pressure in the field around\nthe body; or\n\n+\n\nI\n\n0\n\n.2\n\n4\n\nm\n\n6\n\n8\n\n1\n\n0\n\nFig 10. Approximate expression for wave drag of lifting surface\n\nAs is well known, there exists a certain correspondence in\nairfoil theory between problems involving distributions\nof lift and those involving distributions of thickness. If\nthe solution of a problem of one type is known, then a\ncorresponding solution of the other type can usually be\nconstructed. Thus our studies of wave drag associated\nwith distributions of lift can readily be extended to\n\nva\n\nNEGATIVE VOLUME; V c * - - q\nDlO+C)= Dan -Dee\n\n+\n\nR. Jones\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1956\n\n6 09\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nORT 1284\nT H ~ R OF ~ ~ G - ~ O D Y AT SUPERSONIC SPEEDS\xe2\x80\x99\nY\nDRAG\nBy ROBERT JONES\nT.\n_\n.\n\nSUMMARY\n\nT e relation .JWhitcomb\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9carea &\xe2\x80\x9dto the linearformulas\nh\nfor waue drag at slightly supersonic speeds is discussed. By\nadopting an approximate relation between the source strength\nand. the geomety of a wing-body combination, the wave-drag\ntheory is expressed in &rms ineolving the areas intercepted by\noblique planes or Mach planes. The resulting formulas are\nchecked by comparison with the drag measurements obtained in\nwind-tunnel expeTiments and in experiments withfalling models\nin free air. Finally, a theory for determining mig-body\nshaps o j minimum drag at supersonic Mach numbers is\ndiscussed and some prelimimry experiments m e reported.\nDISCUSSION\n\nAt subsonic speeds the pressure drag arising from the thicknew of the body or wings is negligible so long as the shapes are\nsufficiently well streamlined to avoid flow separation. I n\nthat range there exists no possibility of either favorable or\nadverse interference on the pressure distributions themselves.\nIf one body is so placed as to receivc a drag from the pressure\nfield of another then the second body is sure to iweive a\nrorrcsponding increment of thrust from the first.\nAt supersonic speeds this tolrrance, wliich was permit ted\nthe designer, disappears, and thc drag becomrs sensitive to\nthe shape and aii*angement of the bodics. \xe2\x80\x98I\xe2\x80\x99o be sure, the\nprimary factor here is the thickness ratio, but nevertheless\nthere exist arrangements in wliich a large cancellation of drag\noccurs, Examples of thelatter are: the sweptback wing and\nthe Busemann biplane.\nRecently R. T. Whitcomb (ref. 1) has shown how the drag\nat transonic speeds may he reduced to a surprising extent by\nsimply cutting out a portion of the fuselage to compensate\nfor the area blocked by the wing. The purpose of the present\npaper is to discuss some of the theoretical aspects of this\nf\nmethod o drag reduction and to show how the basic idea\nmay be extended to higher speeds in the supersonic range.\nWbitcomb\xe2\x80\x99s deduction of the \xe2\x80\x9carea rule\xe2\x80\x9d was based on\nconsiderations o stream-tube area and the phenomenon of\nf\n\xe2\x80\x9cchoking\xe2\x80\x9d-which follow from one-dimensional-flow theory.\nEach individual stream tube of a threedimensional-flow field\nmust obey the law of one-dimensional flow. Whiie we cannot actually determine the three-dimensional field on this\nbasis alone, nevertheless it provides a good starting point for\nour thinking. The results demonstrate again the effectiveness of basic and simple considerations.\nI\n\nWhile onedimensional-flow theory thus ppovides a clue\nto the area rule, the necessary principle appears more specifically in the three-dimensional-flow theory. Thus, the\nlormdas for wave drag given by linear theory, if followed\ntoward the limit as M approaches 1.0 (from above), show\nthat the wave drag o a system of wings and bodies depends\nf\n3olely on the longitudinal area distriboliorr of the system as a\nwhole. This was fmt noted by W. D. Hayes in his 1946\nthesis (ref. 2). However, because of the h i t a t i o n s of the\ntheory at transonic speeds, this result was not thought to be of\npractical significance. Later G. N. Ward (ref. 3), E . W.\nGraham (ref. 4 ,and others, restricting themselves to very\n)\nnaxrow shapes, expressed the wave drag in terms of the\nlongitudinal area distribution for Mach numbers above\n1.0, where the linear theory has a better iustification.\nIt should be noted, however, that both of the problems\ncited are limiting cases of the more general problem of supersonic drag and it should be borne in mind that only in certain\ncases has it been possible to rrdurr thr geiiernl theoretical\nformulas to the form of an awn rule. It can be shown that\nthe flow field about arq- system o bodies inn!- br ereateti by n\nf\nrrrtain distribution of soourcc~and sinks over t,he surfaces\nof thr bodies. Hayrs\xe2\x80\x99 formula mid the forinulas given in\nreference 5 rclatc thc tirag of such a s p t r m to t.lie distribution\nof these singdaritics. T o obtain a formula for the wavt\ndrag in t e r m of mpa distributions we have to adopt n simplified relation between the source strrngtli and the geometry\nof the bodies, namely, that the source strength is proportional\nto the normal component of the stream velocity a t the body\nsmtace. There are examples (e. g., Busemann biplanes and\nducted bodies) for whicli this assumption is not valid. If,\non the other hand, we limit ourselves to thin symmetrical\nwings mounted on vertically symmetrical fuselages, there are\nindications that a good estimate of the wave drag a t supersonic speeds can be obtained on the bask of the simplified\nrelation assumed.\nFollowing Hayes\xe2\x80\x99 method of calculation, we find that a t\nM= 1.0 the expression for the wave drag of a system of wings\nand bodies reduces to KBrmin\xe2\x80\x99s well-known formula (ref. 6)\nfor the wave drag of a slender body of revoIutioii, that is,\n\nHere S(X) represents the total cross-sectional area intercepted by a plane perpendicular to the stream at the station\n\nBupersedesIiACA RM A53NlPa by Robert T Junes, I\xc2\xb6%.\n.\n$9481-7\n\n611\n\n,\n\nREPORT 1284-NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\n.b\n\nz=z,cos\n\nand\n%(z) =2A,sin n+\nwe obtain for the wave resistance\np\nD=-7 r8v 2 ZnA,2\n\nOf all the terms of the series, each contributes to the drag,\nbut only A and A, contrihutc to the volume or the base\nI\narea of the systeni. \xe2\x80\x98rhus, to achieve a small drag with a\ngiven base area, or with a giveii over-all volumr within tho\ngiven leiigth, Lliu higher harmonics iii tlic ciirvc S\xe2\x80\x99(s)should\nbe supprcssed. Following Sears (rei. 7) we may expand\nS\xe2\x80\x99(z) in a Fourier series and obtain in this way a formula for\nthe drag which is completely analogous to the well-known\nformula for the induced drag of a wing in terms of its spanwise load distribution. Thus, if we write\n\n612\n\nd k t r i l ) i i t i ~ i givcm I)? iiitwwrtioiis of hl:irli pI:iiw>.\ni\n\na set of parallcl Xlach planrs (SCC fig. 2) \\vc c~ollstructan\n\xe2\x80\x9cequivalrut body of revolution," using thc iiiterccptcd\narras, and compute tlw drag by von IiBrmtin\xe2\x80\x99s formula.\n?\xe2\x80\x98tic theoretical basis of this step is t l i c fact that the completr\ntlirce-tlimensioi~al disturbanc~rficM may be ronstruvtrd by\nthe superposition of elcmeiitarg one-diniciisional disturbances\nin the form of plane waves (ref. 8). I t is evident that the\nset of parallel Mach planes may be placed a t various angles\naround the z axis. In constructing the flow field it is necessary to superimpose disturbances a t all of these ariglcs arid,\nin computing the drag, to consider the drags of all the ccjuivalent bodies of revolution. The final valuc of thc drag is\nsimply the average of the values obtained through a complete\nrotation of the Mach planes.\nln order to make these statements more specific, we may\nwrite tho equation of onc such Mach plaiic as follows:\nX=s-y\xe2\x80\x98cos\n\n8-z\xe2\x80\x98sin 8\n\n~\n\nwhere y\xe2\x80\x99=<M2-1 y, ~ \xe2\x80\x99 = < A 4 ~ - 1 P, and 8 is the anglc of\nrotation of the .\\lac11 plaric. By assigning different valucs\nto A whilc kccpiiig 8 constarit, we obtain a series of parallcl\n\nTEIEORY O F WING-BODY DRAG AT SUPERSONIC SPEEDS\n\nplanes at the same angle 0 around the z axis. By assigning\ndifferent values to 8 while keeping X a constant, we obtain\na set of planes enveloping that Mach cone whose apex lies\nat the point X = z .\nSelecting a value of 8, we cut through the wivg-body\nsystem with a series of planes corresponding to different\nvalues of X . The total intercepted area in each plane is\nthen equated to the area intercepted by this plane passing\nthrough the equivalent body of revolution. If we denote\nthe area intercepted obliquely by dX,8), then the area\nS(X,e) is defined by\nS = s sin p\nwhere p is the Mach angle (i. e., sin p = l / M ) . Thus, S is\nthe area intercepted by normal planes passing through the\nequivalent body of revolution on the assumption that this\nbody is slender. Again, we write\n\ns\xe2\x80\x99(x,e)=,x\n\nb\n\nS(X,O)=ZA, sin n p\n\nwith\n\nX\n\ncos p=X\nO\nHere, however, both the length 2X0 and the shape of the\nequivalent body vary with the angle 8. The drag of each\nequivalent body of revolution, which we may denote by\nD\xe2\x80\x98 (e) is then determined by applying Sears\xe2\x80\x99 formula:\n\nS(x)\xe2\x80\x99.A, sin2\n(Seors-Haack\n\nFIGURE\n3.-Optimurn\n\nbody)\n\narea distribution for given length and volume.\n\nTo check the agreement between these theoretical formulas\nfor the wave drag and experiment.al values, we have compared our calculations with the results of tests made by\ndropping models from a high altitude. This comparison\nwas made by George H. Holdaway of Ames Laboratory who\nsupplied the accompanying illustration (fig. 4). I n some of\nthese cases it was found necessary to retain more than 20\nterms of the Fourier series in order to obtain a convergentj\nexpression for the drag.\nConsidering the variety of the shapes represented here, the\nagreement is certainly as good as we ought to expect from\nour linear simplifications. The agreementjs naturally better\nin those interesting cases in which the drag is small.\n\n-Theory\n---- Experiment\n\nThe total drag of the wing-body system is the average of all\nthese values between O=O and 8=2r, that is,\n\nD=$\n\nD\xe2\x80\x99(8)d8\n\nI n general, the coefficients A , will be functions of the angle\nof projection e. However, calculation shows that the first\ntwo coefficients A , and A, are again related in a simple wa\\r\nto the base area and the volume v. Thus,\n\nA,=-2 2\nS(X)\na x\no\n\nNone of the higher coefficients contribute to the base area\nof volume, but they invariably contribute to the drag.\nThe rules for obtaining a low wave drag now reduce to\nthe rule that each of the equivalent bodies obtained by the\noblique projections should be as smooth and slender as\npossible, the \xe2\x80\x9csmoothness\xe2\x80\x9d again being related to an absence\nof higher harmonics in the series expression for S\xe2\x80\x98(X). Thus\ni n the case of given length and volume the series should\ncontain only the term A2 sin 2p (see fig. 3). It should be\nnoted that in this theory, the equivalent bodies of revolution\ndo not have a physical significance. The concept is simply\nan aid in visualizing the magnitude of the drag of the complete system.\n\nM\nFIGURE\n4.-Comparison\n\nof theory with results of Arnes Laboratory\ndrop tests.\n\nFigure 5 shows an analysis of one of Whitcomb\xe2\x80\x99s experiments. The linear theory, of course, shows the transonic\ndrag rise simply as a step a t M=1.0. We may expect such\na variation to be approached more closely as the thickness\nvanishes. To represent actual values here a nonlinear\ntheory would be needed. For many purposes it will be sufficient to estimate roughly the width of the transonic zone by\nconsiderations such as those given in reference 9. In the\npresent case it will be noted that agreement with the linear\ntheory is reached a t Mach numbers above about 1.08, and\nthe linear theory clearly shows the effect of the modification.\nFor further theoretical studies of wing-body drag, shapes\nhave been selected which are especially simple analytically,\nnamely, the Sears-Haack body and biconvex wings of elliptic\n\n394915-57-2\n\n613\n\nREPORT 1284--NATIONAL\n\nADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR AERONAUTICS\n\nplan form, having aspect ratios of 2.54 and 0.635. Figure 6\nshows the effect of wing proportions on the variation\nof wave drag with Mach number, both with and without the\nWhitcomb modification. In each case the modification has\nthe effect of reducing the wave drag to that of the body\nalone a t M=1.0. I n the case of the low-aspect-ratio wing\nthis drag reduction remains effective over a considerable\nrange of higher Mach numbers. With the higher aspect\nratio, however, the drag increases sharply a t higher speeds,\nso that a t A4= 1.6 the modification nearly doubles the wave\ndrag.\nThe rapid increase of drag in the case of the high-aspectratio wing is, of course, the result of the relatively abrupt\ncurvatures introduced into the fuselage lines by the cutout.\nSuch abrupt cutouts are necessarily associated with wings\nhaving small fore and aft dimensions, that is, unswept wings\nof high aspect ratio.\nThese considerations led to the problem of determining a\nfuselage shape for such wings that is better adapted to the\nhigher Mach numbers. The first step in this direction is,\nobviously, simply to lengthen the region of the cutout-thus\navoiding the rapid increase of drag with Mach number. The\nproblem of actually determining the best shape for the fuselage cutout a t any specified Mach number has been under-\n\nP-Mach d o n e\n\n0\n\n77\n\ny,\ns,sin,u\n\nFIGURE\n7.-Design\n\n271\n\n9\n\nas,\n\n= - q27Ts,dq\n27 0\n7\n\nof fuselage modification for specified Mach number.\n\ntaken by Harvard Lomax and Max. A. Heaslet a t Ames\nLaboratory (ref. 10). Their solution of this problem provides\na definite method for determining the distribution of sources\nand sinks along the fuselage axis that will achieve a minimum\nvalue of the drag for a given wing shupe a t any specified\nMach number. Furthermore, by admitting singularities of\nhigher order-quadrupoles, etc., which would distort the\nrotational symmetry of the fuselage, they have been able to\nshow that the wave drag of a wing-body system can be\nreduced, in principle a t least, to a minimum value associated\nwith the given overall length and volume of the system, that\nis, t,o the value for a simple Sears-Haack body containing the\nwhole volume of the system.2\nBy adopting our simplified relation between the source\nstrength and the body shape, we may describe the result of\nthis theory by a relatively simple concept, which is illustrated\nin figure 7. For modifications of the first type, the problem\nis to determine the area AS, to be removed from the fuselage\nto best compensate for a given wing. (See fig. 7.) Selecting\na station along the fuselage axis and a Mach plane passing\nthrough this station, we revolve this plane around the axis,\nmeasuring a t each angle $ the normal projection, or frontal\nprojection, of the area intercepted where the plane cuts\nthrough the wing., After plotting these areas against $ and\nintegrating between 0 and 27r, we obtain AS, z1s the average\nof the values of S,. At any Mach number the total volume\nto be subtracted from the fuselage is equal to the wing volume. At higher Jlach numbers, since the modification extends over a greater length, the area subtracted a t individual\ncross sections becomes less.\nFigure\xe2\x80\x98 8 shows the calculated result of designing the\nfuselage cutout for a specific Mach number, 1.2 in this case.\nThe lower\xe2\x80\x99curve is an envelope showing the minimum values\nthat can be achieved by such a radially symmetric cutout.\nFigure 9 shows the magnitude of the gain that is theoretically possible by higher order modifications of the fuselage\nshape. There are three lower bounds here, and the symbols\na,, a,, etc., attached to them refer to a representation of the\nfuselage shape by singularities of increasingly higher order.\n\n++\n\n+\n$\n\n\xe2\x80\x98,\n.\n\nI\n\nI\nI12\n\nI\n\n104\n\n100\n\n108\n\nM\n\nFIGURE\n5.-Comparison\n\n.04\n\nof Whitcomb\xe2\x80\x99s experiments with theory.\n\nt\n\nr\n\n.03t\n\n\xe2\x80\x99\n\n/Unmodified\n\n/\xe2\x80\x99\n,Modified\n.Unmodified\n\n%\n\n1\xe2\x80\x992\n\nF~QTJRE\n6.-Effect\n\n6 14\n\nM\n\n14\n1\n\n16\n1\n\n10\n.\n\n1.2\n\n14\n.\n\n1.6\n\nM\n\nof Whitcomb modification on calculated wave drag.\n\n2 This value is, of coursr, not an absolute minimum lorn given volume since, BS shown hy\nFerrari, the Fave drag ai a body can be reduced to zero by special volume distributions (see\nEl. 11).\n\nTHEORY O F WING-BODY DRAG AT SUPERSONIC SPEEDS\n\nThe curve labeled a0 is that given on the previous figure and\nshows the maximum effect of radially symmetric modifications. Van Dyke\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\nMarch 1958\n\n619\n\nJones, R. T. and Van Dyke, M. D., "The Compressibility Rule for Drag of Airfoil\nNoses," Journal of the Aeronautical Sciences, vol. 25, no. 3, March 1958,\npp. 171-172, 180. @ 1958 by the Institute of Aeronautical Sciences, Inc.\nReprinted by permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and\nAstronautics.\n\n620\n\nMARCH,\n\nReprinted from JOURNAL .OFTHE AERONAUTICAL SCIENCES\nCopyright, 1958, by the Institute of the Aeronautlml Sciences and repnnted by p e n s i o n of the copyright owner\n1958\nV O L25, No.3\n~\n\nThe Compressibility Rule for Drag of Airfoil\nNoses\nR. T. JONES* AND M. D. VAN DYKE*\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory, NACA\nSnnraraRY\n\nIt is shown that the drag of any semi-infinite airfoil section in\npurely subsonic inviscid flow follows precisely the PrandtlGlauext compressibility rule. The result for the parabola has\napplication to leadmg-edge corrections in thin airfoil theory.\n\nINTRODUCTION\nBODIES have long been used to represent the noses of elongated aerodynamic shapes.\nThis role assumes increased importance in compressible\nflow, because the approximate linearized theory must\nusually be employed, and it breaks down in the neighborhood of stagnation points.\xe2\x80\x99 It can be corrected,\nhowever, if the flow is known past a simple semiinfinite shape (such as a parabola) that matches the\nactual body near its nose.2 Except in incompressible\nflow, the semi-infinite shape itself cannot be treated\nexactly, but only by another approximation such as\nthe Janzen-Rayleigh method. However, it is shown\nin the present paper that for the drag itself the effect\nof compressibilityis known exactly.\n\nS\n\nEMI-INFINITE\n\nDRAG A PAFL~BOLA\nOF\nIN SUBSONIC\nFLOW\n\nAs discussed by Prandtl and Tietjerqathe drag of a\nsemi-infinite body in inviscid flow is understood to be\nthe limit of the pressure drag on a finite section isolated\nby a transverse slit into which the surrounding pressure penetrates (see Fig. 1). With this definition, the\ndrag (per unit span) of an infinite parabolic cylinder in\nincompressible flow along its axis is UR times the dynamic pressure, R being the nose radius.\nAs the free-stream Mach Number increases to any\nvalue short of uriity, the entire flow field remains sub.sonic and hence free of shock waves, because a parabola exerts only a retarding iduence on the flow.\nLocal pressures do not, of course, follow the PrandtlGlauert compressibility rule even approximately near\nthe stagnation point. Nevertheless, the particular\nweighted average of surface pressures that yields the\ndrag does obey that rule exactly. Thus, at any freestream Mach Number EA less than unity, the drag is\n\nD\n\nairfoil (say, a symmetrical Joukowski section) of thickness r . I the leading edge is analytic, it has a nose\nf\nradius proportional to r2. Now suppose the airfoil\ndivided into a short nose section of length r and a remaining tail section (see Fig. 2), and consider the contribution of each to the total drag. The drag vanishes\nas r approaches zero, but the drag coefficient remains\nfinite if referred to a length of order r2, such as the nose\nradius. The nme section disappears in the same limit;\nbut if it is magnified so that its nose radius remains\nconstant, it approaches an infinite parabola.\nOver the rear section the slope is uniformly small, so\nthat the linearized theory becomes exact in the limit,\ngiving a drag coefficient proportional td (1 - M2)-(\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d)\nOver the nose section linearized theory cannot be applied. However, if the flow is purely subsonic, the\ntotal drag is zero according to Theodorsen\xe2\x80\x99s extension\nto subsonic flow of d\xe2\x80\x98Alembert\xe2\x80\x99s paradox.\xe2\x80\x98 Hence\nthe drag of the nose also varies as (1 - M2)-(\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x992).\nThe same compressibility rule holds for the wellknown leading-edgesuction force associated with angle\nof attack. This is clear from a repetition of the preceding argument with the airfoil considered t o have an\nangle of,attack a! that tends to zero in proportion to the\nthickness r. In the limit we obtain asymmetric flow\npast an infinite parabola (see Fig. 3). One cannot\nspeak of the angle of attack, because the slope of all\nstreamlines tends toward zero far upstream, decaying\nfinally like [ s ~ / ( - x ) ] \xe2\x80\x9d ~where SO is some characteristic\nlength. However, one, can instead characterize the\ndegree of asymmetry of the flow field far upstream by\nspecifying t h i s parameter SO in the dimensionless form\nso/R. (In the limiting process just envisioned, the\n\n= (1/2)pU2 (r/\n?R-\n\nThe proof can be based on consideration of any thin\nReceived December 27, 1956. However, a body has zero drag if it grows more slowly and\n$ b i t e drag if it grows more rapidly. Hence only the\ndividing case of a body asymptotic to a parabola provides a signiscant result.\nSimilar considerations could be applied to a threedimensional semi-infinite body-for example, a body of\nrevolution. However, the significant shape that separates axisymmetric bodies of zero and infinite drag\nhas been found by Gurevich8 to be a peculiar one whose\nradius varies asymptotically as x\'/\'(ln x)-("~). AS in\nplane flow, its ultimate form must be the same as that\nof the dead-water region in axisymmetric free-streamline flow, for which Levinsong has indeed found the\nsame form. Then for a fixed flow pattern far upstream, corresponding to constant SO, the drag of a\nparabola is given by\n\nD\n\n=\n\n(1/2)pU2[r(R s o ) / d I\n-\n\n-W]\n\n(2)\n\nThis rule now holds only below the critical Mach Number, which is less than Unity for asymmetric flow. At\nspeeds above the critical Mach Number, local supersonic zones appear which undoubtedly terminate in\nshock waves, and these invalidate the extended d\'Alembert paradox on which the argument rests. It may be\nnoted in Eq. (2) that even in nonlinear flow the drag\nterms are additive.\nThe rule provides an integral check on detailed approximate solutions. For example, Imai6 has calculated the Janzen-Rayleigh expansion in powers of W\nfor the surface speed on a parabola in symmetric flow,\nretaining terms in M4. Carrying out the complicated\nintegration for the drag gives\n\nD/(1/2)pU27rR = 1\n\n+ ( l / 2 ) M 2+ (3/S)M4+ . . . Again,\nRaplane and others have treated the inclined ellipse by\nthe Janzen-Rayleigh expansion to order Mz, and from\nthat has been extracted the series to M2 for asymmetric\nflow past the parabola.\'\nIntegrating for the drag gives\n( 1 / 2 ) M 2 . . . 1.\nagain the compressibilityfactor [I\nTo obtain sufEaent accuracy for purposes of correcting\ncompressible thin-airfoil theory for lifting round-nosed\nwings,2this last solution should be extended to include\nterms in M4; when that is accomplished the present\nrule willeprovide a useful partial check on the formidable\ncalculationsinvolved.\n\n+\n\nDRAG O\nOF\n\n+\n\n~ SEMI-INFINITE\nR\nBODIES\n\nIt is clear that the proof given for the parabola will\nnot be invalidated by local changes from parabolic\nshape near the vertex. Hence any semi-infinite cylinder that approaches a parabola far downstream has\n(below its critical Mach Number) ~e drag of that\nparabola.
