Jones\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\n\n1959\n\n625\n\nJones, R. T., "Aerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds," in International\nCongress in the Aeronautical Sciences, lst, Madrid, 8-13 September,\n1958. Proceedings. Advances in Aeronautical Sciences , v. 1, p. 34-51.\nNew York, London, Pergamon Press, 1959. @ 1959.\nReprinted by permission of Pergamon Press, London.\n\n626\n\nAERODYNAMIC DESIGN FOR SUPERSONIC SPEEDS\nBy ROBERT\nT.\n\nJONES"\n\nNational Advisory Committee for Aeronautics\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory\nMoffett Field, California\nSummary--The aerodynamic phenomena that may profitably be employed by\nthe designer at subsonic speeds seem now to be well understood. At supersonic\nspeeds such phenomena show a greater and more interesting variety. Search\nfor the minimum number of guiding principles of design thus becomes more\ndiflicdt and more dangerous.\nStudies which can cover an adequate range of geometrical form are at present\nlimited to the linearized version of aerodynamic theory. Such studies, especially\nthose by variational methods, have disclosed certain basic principles of design for\naerodynamic efficiency. In present-day experiments, however, the indicated\ntrends are rather quickly confronted with effects of viscosity and nonlinearities.\nWhile the theory indicates that good values of aerodynamic efficiency are possible\nat supersonic speeds it is not yet clear how closely these expectations may be\napproached in practice.\nIn the present paper several arrangements of supporting surfaces and bodies\nare discussed and in some cases comparisons of theory and experiment are made.\nFinally, certain phenomena connected with lift and drag in a rarefied medium\nare considered briefly.\n\nINTRODUCTION\n\nINits earlier development the subsonic airplane showed a great variety\nin the arrangement of airfoils, bodies, and other parts. For the past 15\nor 20 years, however, those airplanes which have passed the tests of\nexperience have shown little alteration in basic form. The aerodynamic\nprinciples which have determined this form seem now to be well understood and agreed upon.\nThe situation is different in the case of the supersonic airplane. Here\nthe aerodynamic rules seem more complex. No clear direction toward\na specific form is evident. Our theoretical investigations have taken a\nrather wide range-seeming in some cases rather far removed from\npractical questions.\nI n the present paper we shall review some of the recent theoretical\nand experimental work in supersonic aerodynamics with its practical\napplication in mind.\n*Aeronautid Research Scientist\n\n-r.\n\n627\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\nCOMPONENTS O F DRAG\n\nWhen considering the drag of a complete airplane it is natural to\nsimplify our thinking by dividing the drag into components according to\ndifferences in origin. One possibility here is to assign a drag to the individual parts of the airplane and then allow for a certain \xe2\x80\x9cinterference\xe2\x80\x9d\nbetween the various components. This scheme is not completely satisfactory at supersonic speeds since the individual drags often tend to be\noutweighed by the interference. A somewhat more satisfactory division\nassociates a component of the drag with lift-producing elements, elements\nof volume or thickness, and a component of surface friction. Here again\nthe interference must not be discounted and it is necessary to guard against\nthe acceptance of any such division as having a fundamental significance.\nThus the division of drag according to normal pressure and skin\nfriction or \xe2\x80\x9ctangential pressure\xe2\x80\x9d seems a natural one, and yet situations\narise in which this convention is not appropriate. In the case of a cooled\nbody in a rarefied gas stream the resultant stress acts nearly in the stream\ndirection, independently of the inclination of the surface. Here the\nresultant affords a simpler description than any of its components.\nIf we accept tentatively the division according to lift, volume, and\nsurface area, then it is possible to trace the variation in the relative magnitude of these items as the Mach number increases. The range of low\nsupersonic speeds is characterized by the development of large pressures\non surfaces having a small inclination. Thus the drag due to thickness\nor volume is relatively large in comparison with the drag due to lift. At\nthe same time any disturbance causes an extensive lateral influence, giving\nrise to pronounced interference effects. The surface friction is, however,\nhardly changed from its subsonic value, provided the increased tendency\ntoward separation can be avoided.\nAt higher speeds the Mach waves bend back so that the zone of influence\nis contracted laterally into a smaller space around the body. The pressure\ndeveloped by a given surface inclination becomes smaller in proportion\nto the dynamic pressure. For this reason the drag associated with the\nthickness is reduced. To support a given lift the wing must have a larger\nangle of attack, so that the drag due to lift is increased. The friction coefficient with either laminar or turbulent flow diminishes, but not as\nrapidly as the normal pressure.\nThe drag arising from the volume of the wings or bodies is most pro..\nnounced at low supersonic speeds near M = 1 0 For airplanes intended\nl\nto fy in this range a proper distribution of volume according to the area\nrule is important. As in the case of the lift distribution, however, our\nstudies have shown that the minimum of the drag is not a sharp minimum,\nbut there exist many smooth shapes near the optimum which have essentially the minimum drag. From the designer\xe2\x80\x99s standpoint the influence\nof the over-all proportions is perhaps the dominant influence, the wave\n\n6 28\n\nROBERTT.\nJONES\n\ndrag being reduced most effectively, of course, by extending the volume\nin the flight direction.\nM I N I M U M DRAG O F L I F T I N G SURFACES\n\nIn the problem of minimum drag, as previously considered by the present\nwrite+), the plan form of the wing is assumed to be given as well as the\ntotal lift. The result provides a certain unification of subsonic and supersonic airfoil theories through the artifice of a \xe2\x80\x9ccombined flow field\xe2\x80\x9d. By\nconsidering this problem from a different point of view, M. N. Kogan(2)\nhas recently given a derivation in which the significant quantities seem\nto have a closer relation to the physical phenomena. Rather than consider \xe2\x80\x99\na reversed motion of the wing, Kogan utilizes the reversed Mach wave\nas a control surface in applying the momentum theorem to the calculation\nof drag. As a result of this choice, the expression for the drag reduces to\nthe Dirichlet integral of the local disturbance velocities projected on this\nsurface. Thus\n\nwhile the lift is given by\n\nHere yg and \xe2\x80\x98pz are the y and z components of the disturbance velocity\nafter projection on the characteristic surface\nThe lift is thus proportional to the downward momentum of this lateral flow and the drag to\nits kinetic energy. Now, of flows having a given momentum, the one\nhaving the smallest kinetic energy is that one which follows the streamlines of an incompressible fluid. Hence a wing of minimum drag should,\nif possible, produce on this rear characteristic surface a flow satisfying\nLaplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation in two dimensions, that is :\n\nr.\n\nThe projected velocity distribution on the reversed characteristicsurface\nthus plays a role similar to the lateral velocity distribution in the Tref\xe2\x82\xactz\nplane in ordinary wing theory. Unlike the Trefftz plane, however, the zone\nof disturbance on the reversed characteristic surface is limited in extent.\nBeyond the Mach waves from the leading edge the lateral entrainment of\nthe wing ceases, leading to the boundary condition q~ = 0, so that the\nwing operates effectively on a limited jet of air. The problem is thus\nanalytically the same as that of a wing at low speed in an open jet wind\ntunnel (see Fig. 1). The increase of the induced drag which results\nfrom the limitation of the wing in the finite jet is exactly equal to the\n\xe2\x80\x9cwave drag\xe2\x80\x9d of the wing in unlimited supersonic flow. Wings having\n\n629\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\nshort fore-and-aft dimensions have a small area of entrainment, as shown\nby Fig. 2. The effect of increasing the Mach number is shown in Fig. 3.\n\nFIG:1. Equivalent incompressible jet.\n\nFIG.2. Effect of fore-and-aft dimension of wing on area of lateral entrainment.\n\n630\n\n-.\n\nROBERT .JONES\nT\n\nM =2.7\n\nM = 1.4\n\n/\n\nI\n\n\\\n\n\\\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\ni\n\\\n\\\n\nI\nI\n/\n\nFIG. Effect of Mach number on area of lateral entrainment.\n3.\n\nWe recall the formulas of Prandtl and Munk for lift and drag of the\nwing at low speed, that is\n\nL = pwUS\'\nD = *pwaS\'\n\n()\n4\n(5)\n\nwhere w is the downwash and S\' is the area of virtual additional mass of\nthe wing\'s trace. In the new theory these same formulas will apply at\nsupersonic speed if the area S\' is replaced by the area of virtual mass of\nthe wing trace in the finite jet a~ limited by the Mach waves.\nIt seems unlikely that a result of this kind, referring to principles of\nmomentum and energy, would be strictly l i t e d to the linearized version\nof the wing theory. Following this thought, M. D. Van Dyke and I have\nrecently found that equations (l), ( ) and (3) remain valid even when\n2,\nquantities of second order in the velocities and pressures are retained.\nAs ,Ward has indi~ated\'~), relation between the characteristic trace\nthe\nof the wing and its plan form is not unique. Now Kogan\'s analysis yields\nthe minimum drag consistent with a given characteristic trace (including\nthe vortex trace) and a given total lit, or, by an obvious extension, a given\nspanwise load distribution, but it does not give necessarily the minimum\ndrag associated with a given plan form, only a lower bound. For, consider\ntwo outline shapes, one lying within the other, yet both having the same\ncharacteristic trace, so that the two-dimensional solution is the same for\nboth. Subtract one flow from the other: the disturbance is canceled\ncompletely at the characteristic surface, indicating zero drag, yet a dis-\n\n631\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\n3>\n\ntribution of lift remains in the region of the wings. Thus in determining\nthe minimum drag for a specified characteristic trace we are also determining the associated plan form. For the solution of the minimum\nproblem when the plan form is given we have to return to the criterion\nof constant downwash given earlier.\nE. W. Graham(*)has shown that a result similar to Kogan\xe2\x80\x99s can be\nderived by utilizing the idea of the combined flow field. Graham\xe2\x80\x99s\nanalysis provides further a simple determination of the loadings of the\nwing when integrated in various oblique directions. Graham\xe2\x80\x99s analysis\nbrings out the following interesting question: Suppose we have a surface\ndistribution of lift Z(x,y) and suppose the projected linear loadings\nIL(x,,a) obtained by integrating Z(x,y) along lines in various directions\nx = xo ay are known. Can the surface distribution Z(x,y) be determined from IL(x,,a) ?\nGraham(5)gives the following result; if\n\n+\n\nE(x0,a) =\n\nss\n\nZ(x,y)~(~-xO-~y)dx =\ndy\n\nthen\n@\xe2\x80\x99Y) =\n\n&Sf&\n\ns\n\n~ ( x o + ~ , ~ )( 6 ) ~\nd\n\ndx,da\nax, x -~,--oly\n\n(7)\n\nA somewhat more symmetrical relation can be achieved if we substitute\nfor the Dirac delta function, 6, its equivalent Cauchy integral formula:\n\ns\n\nf(x)b(x-x,)dx=\n\n-\n\n+\n\nx 0i)- f(x-\n\noi) dx = f(xo)\n\nThen we may write\n\n-e+\n\nThe integrations should extend over the largest plan form consistent with\nL\nthe projected lengths of the loadings I ,though the9 lift distribution\nZ(x,y) may not do so.\nStudies by variational methods often establish essential relations with\ngreater clarity than other methods. Here the relation of the drag to the\narea of entrainment and to the momentum and energy of the downwash\nflow is perhaps more significant than the relation for the drag to be an\np\nabsolute minimum. Following this thought we may seek functions for c\nwhich satisfy the condition v = 0 on the outer boundary of the characteristic trace and y2 = constant on the wing trace, but which satisfy\nvz2= 0 only approximately. Thus Heaslet and Fuller(6) find\nquite simple expressions for the drag of wings having the plan form of a\nhyperbola by relaxing this latter condition. Their solutions correspond\nto exact minima of the drag for special positions of the center of pressure.\n\n+\n\n632\n\nROBERT.JONES\nT\n\nThe problem of minimum drag when both the lift and the center of\npressure are fixed has been considered by P. Germah(\'). In this case\nthe divergence of the velocity field is not zero as in equation (3) but has\na constant value. From the practical standpoint it may be noted that a\nwing whose width increases toward the rear generally has a smaller drag\nwhen the centroid of the lift distribution is placed ahead of the aerodynamic center. Thus we may say that the triangular wing has a "negative\ntrim drag". The optimum loading of wings having fore-and-aft symmetry,\nhowever, acts at the middle of the wing, behind the aerodynamic center.\nHence wings having fore-and-aft symmetry or wings whose width decreases toward the rear (e.g., a reversed triangular wing) may be expected\nto have a positive trim drag.\nYAWED A N D S W E P T W I N G S\n\nWith planar wings the wave drag is reduced as the lift distribution is\nextended in the flight direction, while the vortex drag is reduced by extending the span. At the same time the friction drag is reduced by\ndiminishing the exposed area of the wing. At subsonic speeds the last\n\'two considerations are effective and they lead to wing forms approaching\na lifting line perpendicular to the flight direction. At supersonic speeds\nthe added condition on the length leads to a long, narrow wing placed\nat an angle of yaw.\nIt is interesting to analyze the yawed lifting line in terms of its area of\nentrainment. The forward and reversed Mach waves are simply circular\ncones drawn from the ends of the line. At subsonic angles of yaw the\ncones are displaced laterally so that the contour of their inter-section,\nwhich outlines the equivalent jet, is an ellipse. The area of this ellipse\nvanishes rapidly, however, and disappears completely as the lifting line\napproaches the Mach angle. The area of entrainment is zero and the\nwave drag given by the theory is infinite at supersonic angles of yaw.\nIf we convert a yawed wing into a swept wing by bending it at the\nmiddle, keeping the same structural slenderness, we see that the length\nin the flight direction is reduced to about one-half. The wave drag is\nthen increased, so that the potential lift-drag is invariably smaller for\nthe bilaterally symmetric arrangement.\nFigure 4 shows the estimated lift-drag ratios for a slender elliptic wing\n.,\nat various angles of yaw. The Mach number considered here is 1 4 so\nthat the transition from flow of the Kutta- Joukowsky type to the Ackeret\ntype occurs in the vicinity of 45". The best angle of yaw is 30", placing\nthe wing at a transverse Mach number of approximately 0.70. The lift\ncoefficient required for maximum LID at this point is, however, too high\nfor the Kutta-Joukowsky type of flow; hence, additional curves have been\ncomputed to show the effect of limiting the lift coefficient based on the\ntransverse component of velocity to values of 1.0 in one case and 0.5 in\nanother.\n\n633\n\nAerodynamic Dsg for Supersonic Speeds\nein\n\n0\n\nt\n\nI\n\nFIG.4.\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\n40\'\n50\xc2\xb0\n6\'\n0\n?Oo\nANGLE OF YAW\nEffect of yaw on lift-drag ratio of elliptic wing.\n\nlo"\n\n20\xc2\xb0\n\n30\xc2\xb0\n\nWhether the wing is yawed or swept, the potential lift-drag ratio increases almost without limit as the aspect ratio is increased. The\npractical limit is reached when the lifting pressures become so great\nthat Kutta-Joukowsky flow is no longer possible. A similar situation\narises in the design of a sailplane. Here the lift-drag ratio increases\nrapidly with aspect ratio up to the point at which the optimum lift coefficient begins to exceed the maximum lift coefficientof the wing sections,\nthat is, when Kutta-Joukowsky flow is no longer possible.\nFigure 5 shows the results of some experiments made by Robert T.\n1\n2\nIO\n\n8\n\nI 6\n\nD\n\n4\n2\n3\n\n.04 .08\n\n.2\nI\n\n.6\nI\n\n20\n\n24\n\n28\n\nCL\n\nFIG. Effect of Reynolds number on lift-drag ratio; M\n5.\n\n634\n\n= 1.53.\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\nMadden at Ames Laboratory on a swept-wing model at a Mach number\nof 1.53. Here the limitation imposed by the action of viscosity on the\nperformance of the long narrow swept wing is evident-especially at low\nReynolds numbers. The sweep angle in this case is 67".\n1\n0\n8\n\nL\ne,\n\n6\n\n4\n2\n\n0\n\n.I2\n\n. 4 .08\n0\n\n.20 .24\n\n.I6\n\nCt\nFIG. . Effect of wing plan form on LID.\n6\n\nFigure 6 shows experimental values of LID obtained by Hall and\nHeitmeyer(*) for a model having a triangular wing. Their values are\ncompared with the highest curve for the swept wing. The models have\nthe same fuselage and are tested at comparable Reynolds numbers.\n\n1\n\n1r\n4\n\n12 THEORY-;,\n\nc--\n\nI /\n/-\n\nlo\n\nL\nD\n\n\\\n\nI\n\n8\n\n6\n\n4\n2\nI\n\nOF\n\nFIG.7.\n\nI\n\n,\n\n.04 .08 . 2\nI\nCL\n\nt\n\n.6\nI\n\n.hO\n\nEffect of Reynolds number on lift-drag ratio; M = 3.0.\n\nFigure 7 shows results of experiments made by Elliott Katzen(B)of\nAmes Laboratory on a wing having 80" of sweep. The Mach number in\n\n635\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\nc-\n\nthis case is 3.0. The airfoil section of the model shown is the well-known\nClark Y, which proved superior to especially cambered sections at these\nReynolds numbers.\nThe curve termed \xe2\x80\x9ctheory\xe2\x80\x9d on the figure (Fig. 7) is simply an estimate\nin which the limitation on the transverse lift coefficient was not imposed.\nAt the peak of this curve the lift greatly exceeds the maximum lift coefficient of the Clark Y ai;foil section in two-dimensional flow. The\ntwo arrows shown indicate values of 1.0 and 2.0 for this transverse lift\ncoefficient. There is clearly an uncertainty in our considerations here\nsince the wing has widely different angles of sweep at the leading and\ntrailing edges.\nIn spite of their limitations, the swept wings nevertheless maintain a\nmargin of superiority over rectangular or triangular plan forms except\nat the lowest Reynolds numbers. The narrow swept wings, however,\nhave a greater structural weight and a smaller usable lift coefficient for\nlanding. Unless their potential LID ratios can be approached more\nclosely in practice, their use is difficult to justify in many applications.\nR E D I S T R I B U T I O N OF L I F T BY FUSELAGE\n\nIn steady flow at subsonic speeds the fore-and-aft influence of the wing\nis complete so that concentration of the lift within a narrow chordwise\ndimension causes, theoretically, no increase in the pressure drag associated with the lift. At supersonic speeds the unlimited forward influence\nof the wing is lacking, and the lifting system itself must have an extension\nin the flight direction if lift is to be produced with a minimum of wave\ndissipation.\nSince the fuselage of a supersonic airplane tends to be long and slender,\nthe question of distributing a part of the lift along the fuselage arises.\nThe possibilities inherent in this suggestion have been studied at Ames\n\ncv\n?\n:\n\ni:\n\n,\n\na\nI\n\nFIG.8.\n\n6 36\n\nI\n,S\n\nDistribution of lift along fuselage.\n\nROBWT JONES\nT.\n\nLaboratory and by the theoretical aerodynamics group at the Douglas\nAircraft Company(l0).\nThe simplest aspect of the problem appears if we consider distributions\nof lift on two narrow surfaces in +e form of a cross (see Fig. 8). Both\nthe spanwise and the lengthwise loadings should have the form of smooth\nregular functions. However, if appreciable lift is carried on the \xe2\x80\x9cfuselage\xe2\x80\x9d\nthen the spanwise loading will show an undesirable concentration at the\ncenter. Similarly, a peak in the lengthwise loading appears from the lift\ncarried on the \xe2\x80\x9cwing\xe2\x80\x9d. Desirable loadings appear when the wing and\nthe fuselage each carries a lift approximately equal to the specified value\nL except at the center, where a downward load of magnitude -L must\nappear. Hence the fuselage should carry positive lift front and rear but\nnegative lift in the middle.\nDetailed calculations show that large gains are to be expected if the\ntheoretical redistribution of lift by the fuselage can be accomplished in\npractice. The lifting pressures required on the fuselage are, however,\nof the same order of magnitude as those developed by the wing. According\nto present experience lifting forces of this magnitude cannot be developed\nby bending or inclining a slender body of revolution without causing flow,\ndetachment and the formation of discrete vortices. Further study of this\ntype of favorable fuselage interference should perhaps include some\naccount of flow detachment or, better still, some means for avoiding it.\nH I G H W I N G ARRANGEMENTS\n\nInteraction between lift and volume begins to appear in the drag when\nthe wing and fuselage are separated vertically. This interference is\nfavorable in the case of a high-wing monoplane, but adverse for the low\nwing. More generally, we may consider an interaction between surfaces\ndeveloping forces in a cross-stream direction and elements of volume.\nSuch interactions do not appear at all in the so-called \xe2\x80\x9csupersonic area\nrule\xe2\x80\x9d. They appear in Hayes\xe2\x80\x99 formula\xe2\x80\x98ll), however, since the latter is\nvalid quite generally for distributions of singularities in three dimensions.\nAn equally general formulation is given by Lomax and Heas\xe2\x82\xacet(12),\nwhich\nexpresses the drag directly in terms of the volume distribution and the\nlateral forces. In the well-known Ferrari ringed body the interaction\nbetween these terms may be considered complete, since the wave drag\nis canceled exactly.\nSuch an arrangement may be made to develop lii, but the wave cancellation is then of course incomplete. The most efficient way to gain lift seems\nto be to omit the lower half of the ring, thus creating a kind of \xe2\x80\x9cparasol\xe2\x80\x9d\nmonoplane with a highly arched wing (see Fig. 9). The possibility of\nobtaining high lift-drag ratios with wing-body combinations of thii form\nhas been carefully investigated in papers by Lomax and Heaslet of the\nNACA (ref. 12, and unpublished) and Beane and Ryan of the Douglas\nCompany(ls). Figure 9 illustrates the wing-body arrangement and shows\n\n637\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\nI\n\nLOMAX\n\nI\n\nI\n\nh\n\nI\n\nI\n\n3\n\n4\n\nFIG.\n9. Estimated lift-drag ratio of body with arched wing.\n\nsome typical results at design conditions. As in the case of planar wings,\nimportant gains could be shown if the fuselage could be assumed to\ndevelop sizeable cross forces. When this possibility is discounted the liftdrag ratios fall considerably but not below those estimated for highly\nswept wings.\nThe arrows represent estimates made by Lomax and Heaslet for a\nwing, a body, and two supporting struts. The flattened body carries no\nnet lift but does support a lift distribution. The wide band covered by\nthe arrows is necessitated by the lack of experimental information on the\nmagnitude of the cross forces that can be generated by body distortions.\nThe curve represents estimates made by Beane and Ryan for a wing\nand body without the wing support system. Their body, however, was\nrequired to carry no lift, even locally. Further, their choice of the\nturbulent skin-friction drag coefficient was higher, 0.0030 as compared\nto 0.0025. The conclusion appears to be that the highly arched wing\nand body can have as high a value of LID as the swept wing and body.\nAs in the case of the swept wing, the estimated LID ratio increases if\nthe wetted area can be reduced by reducing the wing chord. Here again\nwe encounter the limitation imposed by the magnitude of the pressure\ncoefficient. As the wing is made narrower the pressures on the wing\nincrease. The wing pressures are moreover reflected to the rear of the\nbody and increased by a focusing effect. Thus we may expect flow\nseparation at the rear of the body. The influence of these phenomena\non the actual characteristics of such an arched wing arrangement will\nhave to be determined experimentally.\nIn the methods employed by Ferri(I*), and Rossow(15),the physical\naspect of interference phenomena is made evident. Considering the\n\n638\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\ninterference between planar wings and bodies, these studies have shown\ndefinitely favorable effects for high-wing arrangements.\nIt will be interesting to try and determine a lower bound that might\nbe approached by this method of drag reduction. Referring to Kogan\xe2\x80\x99s\nanalysis we find that the conditions imposed on the downwash flow in\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cequivalent incompressible jet\xe2\x80\x9d are unaltered by the presence of\nbodies, provided these do not extend beyond the characteristic envelope\nof the wing. The added bodies may bring the drag of a given wing closer\nto this lower bound. However, if a wing shape can be found which causes\nthe streamlines of the downwash to follow the pattern of an incompressible\nflow, then the addition of bodies cannot reduce the drag, except as they\nmay extend the lateral zone of influence of the wing-body system.\nCANCELATION O F T H I C K N E S S DRAG\n\nAt intermediate supersonicspeeds the wave drag due to thickness can be\nreduced to small values by the phenomenon of wave reflection. There\nexists a great variety of three-dimensional toroidal shapes for which the\nwave system is entirely self-contained; that is, the wave resistance is zero\nat certain Mach numbers, as in the Busemann biplane. One such example with which we have experimented at Ames Laboratory is illustrated in Fig. 10. The model is essentially a tube so shaped as to produce\n\n\xe2\x80\x98\n\n.I 2 r\nFRONT VIEW\n\n0\n\nrI\nI\n\n\xe2\x80\x99,\nSIDE VIEW\nI\n-4O\n\nI\n0\n\nI\n\n1\n\nI\n\n4O\n8O\nI2 O\nANGLE OF A T T A C K\nFIG.1 . Drag of tube having a planar wave system.\n0\n\nin its interior a finite portion of the plane wave system between the wings\nof a Busemann biplane. Such shapes are easily constructed by marking\nout a stream surface of arbitrary cross section in the undisturbed flow\nahead and then calculating the inward deflections of this surface as it\npasses through the plane wave system of the biplane. Since the wave\nsystem has no lateral velocities (Le., no components in the y direction),\n\n6 39\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\nthe boundary conditions may be satisfied most conveniently by referring\nthem to sections of the torus made by vertical planes (see Fig. 10).\nTubular bodies having no wave drag can also be made with multiple\nsymmetry, or with complete rotational symmetry. However, such shapes\nordinarily enclose regions in which the pressure rises to large values\nbecause of focusing. In the case of plane waves the reflection involves\nonly a factor of 2-and this seems to be the smallest value obtainable.\nThe experiments were made by Loren Bright of Am- Laboratory and\nshowed a negligible wave drag at the design Mach number of 2.0. The\nmost complete wave cancelation, however, occurred at a slightly higher\nMach number, M = 2-3. I n Fig. 10 the drag is plotted against angle\nof attack at M = 2.0. At about. 5\xe2\x80\x9d the wave system changes suddenly\nand the drag increases.\nSimilar experiments with a torus designed to produce an oblique\n(i.e., yawed) system of plane waves showed a somewhat more continuous\nbehavior.\nWhiie the experiments showed that the wave drag associated with the\nvolume could be eliminated, the tubular bodies developed rather low\nvalues of lift-to-drag ratio. It seems that the added surface area reqkred\nto enclose the wave system increased the friction drag enough to overbalance the gain in wave drag. At still higher Mach numbers the friction\ndrag becomes increasingly important relative to the thickness drag. The\nuse of wave cancelation between interfering bodies or surfaces is more\neasily justified if the added surfaces are also desirable for some other\nreason, such as stabilization or control.\nL I F T AND DRAG AT HIGH ALTITUDES\n\nIn his article \xe2\x80\x9cSuperaerodynamics\xe2\x80\x9d in the Journal o the Franklin\nf\nInstitute, Feb. 1934(16),\nAlbert F. Zahm refers to flight in the upper atmospheric layers and states that \xe2\x80\x9cSpace craft and projectiles must obey new\nor modified laws of air resistance. These may well be studied in highvacuum wind tunnels or chambers, under guidance,of mathematical\ntheory\xe2\x80\x9d. I remember Zahm\xe2\x80\x98s paper well, since I was a student of his at\nthe time and made drawings for the figures that appear in the paper. I\nalso recall that the paper was not accepted for publication by the journals\nto which it was first submitted. One is tempted to think that it might\nbe a great service if journals published, in addition to their tables of\ncontents, some notice of the rejected contributions.\nZahm considered the flow of individual particles of a tenuous gas and\nindicated the modifications needed for diffuse reflection or re-emission\nof molecules. In later p a p e r ~ ( ~ \xe2\x80\x99 ~ l ~Sanger and H. S. Tsien brought\nE. ) ,\nthese considerations into closer contact with the physics of gases as based\non kinetic theory.\nAt speeds approaching 20,000 feet per second, we may of course dispense with aerodynamic lift for cruising. However, there are indications\n\n640\n\nROBERT.J o m\nT\n\nF G 11. Effect of lift-drag ratio on maxknum deceleration for recovery of\nI.\n\n\'\n\nsatellite.\n\nthat aerodynamic forces however small will play an important role in\nrecovery from purely dynamic orbits or trajectories. Figure 11, prepared\nfrom calculations made by D. R. Chapman\'lQ) Ames Laboratory, shows\nof\nthe maximum decelerations encountered in a spiral descent from an\ninitially circular orbit around the Earth. The descent is uncontrolled\nexcept that the direction of the resultant aerodynamic force is maintained\nat a fixed angle to the direction of motion, corresponding to a fixed LID\nratio. If the body develops no lift the maximum deceleration encountered\nis about 8g. However, even small lift forces result in a much more uniform dissipation of the kinetic energy so that at a lift-drag ratio of one-half\nthe maximum deceleration falls to about 2 g.\nEven such small values of the LID may prove difficult \'to achieve if\nthe deceleration occurs at altitudes above 75 miles. Figure 12 illustrates\n\nFIG.\n12. Aerodynamic force on inclined plate in low-density flow.\n\nthe expected reaction on an inclined flat plate in air of extremely low\ndensity. The oncoming molecules are deposited on the plate and are\nemitted with thermal velocities corresponding to its temperature. For a\nrelatively cool surface at high flight velocities the pressure due to emission\n\n641\n\nAerodynamic Design for Supersonic Speeds\n\n2.0\n\nI .6\n12\n.\n0.8\n0.4\n\nt\n0\n\n30\n\n60\n\n90\n\nANGLE OF ATTACK, a\nFIG. Drag and lift coefficients on inclined flat plate i low-density flow.\n13.\nn\n\ncan be neglected. Under these conditions the aerodynamic force is a\ndrag, given by the relation\n\nD\n\n= pU2S\xe2\x80\x99\n\n(9)\n\nHere S\xe2\x80\x98 = S sin 01, is the frontally projected area of the wing. Figure 13,\nprepared from data given in ref. 20, shows how closely this simple rule\nis obeyed by more precise calculations.\nThe loss of lift in free-molecule flow is a consequence of Knudsen\xe2\x80\x99s\nlaw, according to which the emission of molecules is independent of their\nangle of arrival at the surface. Such behavior is closely approximated\nin experiments conducted thus far(21122).\nIt seems unfortunate that the small departures from Knudsen\xe2\x80\x99s law\nhave served to characterize a whole regime of rarefied gas dynamics as\nthe region of \xe2\x80\x9cslip flow\xe2\x80\x9d. The main effects seem to be related more\ndirectly to the \xe2\x80\x9csticking\xe2\x80\x9d of the molecules rather than to their slipping.\nSince the pressures developed at high speed are large compared to the\nambient pressure, we may expect an extensive range of conditions in which\nthe medium behaves as a gas in the vicinity of the body but as a molecular beam in the exterior flow. The investigation of this semi-continuous\nregime promises a great variety of yet undiscovered aerodynamic\nphenomena.\nIn conclusion, the writer wishes to express appreciation to his colleagues\nat Ames Laboratory for assistance in preparing this paper and to\nH. W. Liepmann of the California Institute of Technology for helpful\ndiscussions.\n\n642\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\nREFERENCES\n\n1. W. HOLDER,:Has the author made experiments on wings with subsonic\nleading edges having sections other than the Clark Y section referred to in the\nlecture ? What improvements of lift/drag ratio does he feel could be achieved by\nusing suitably designed section shapes ?\nR. T. JONES:\nThe wing having 80\xe2\x80\x9d sweep was tested initially with Clark Y\nsections and with its under surface flat. A cylindrical bending of the wing which\nincreased the angle of attack at the apex and decreased it at the tips resulted in a\nslight improvement. A fiuther gain might also result from a modification of the\nsection shape, but the direction in which improvement lies is uncertain because of\nnon-linear effects. Further details of these experiments are presented in NqCA\nT N 4361 by Elliott D. Katzen.\nG. H. L m t : The remark by Mr. Jones that there are at present a great many\npossible layouts for a supersonic aeroplane is one that I should like to endorse.\nThe fact that the designer has such a wide choice from which to select the layout\nmakes his job at present difficult but very interesting; the additional fact that, to-day,\nthere is some doubt regarding military and civil aeroplane requirements, adds to\nhis problems.\nIn such circumstances, the general work being done by Mr. Jones and discussed\nin the lecture is very valuable in helping the designer to make his choice by giving\nhim some idea of the relative aerodynamic \xe2\x80\x9cattractions\xe2\x80\x9d, or the performance\npossibilities, of the different layouts, for example, the relatively small difference,\nshown in one of the slides, between the maximum LID ratio for a \xe2\x80\x9cswallow-tail\xe2\x80\x9d\nand a delta wing suggests that in many cases LID ratio would not be the decisive\nfactor, though in certain applications the additional 10% or 15% could be most\nvaluable.\nI think we shall find the present paper most useful in making comparisons of this\nsort and in indicating ways of tackling the various aerodynamk problems which\narise.\nR. T. JONES a grateful to Mr. Lee for his comments and am glad to have my\n:I m\nopinions reinforced by those of an experienced airp\xe2\x82\xacane designer. Perhaps the\npresent uncertainty in military and civil airplane requirements is simply a reflection\nof our uncertainty concerning the physical limitation on airplane performance.\nSuch requirements can usually be modified rather quickly following the introduction of a new phenomena or design principle.\n\n* National Physical Laboratory, England\n\nt Deputy Chief Designer, Handley Page Ltd., England\n\n644\n\nTHREE-DIMENSIONALWINGS OF MINlMUM PRESSURE DRAG\nRobert T. NEW YORK\n\nCHAPTER 8\n\nTHREE-DIMENSIONAL WINGS\n\nOF MINIMUM PRESSURE DRAG\nby\nROBERT T. JONES*\n\n1. INTRODUCTION\nI n linearized flow theory, certain very interesting extrema1 properties\nof wings can be derived under rather broad conditions without the use of\na complicated mathematical apparatus. The present chapter reviews\ncertain results of this theory and indicates some rather obvious extensions\nto incorporate various auxiliary conditions. Several examples illustrating\nthe relation between the geometrical features of the wing and the lift\ndistribution for minimum drag are given.\n\n2,\n\nMINIMUM DRAG PROBLEM\n\nI n this section, we consider a thin, cambered lifting surface of given\nplanform and investigate the pressure distribution p ( x , y ) which yields\nthe minimum drag under various auxiliary conditions (Ref. 1). For this\npurpose, the drag D in frictionless flow is written in the form\n\nwhere x is a chordwise coordinate, y a spanwise coordinate, and a ( x , y )\nthe rearward inclination of the normal to the surface element dS = d x dy\n(Fig. 1). With regard to the auxiliary conditions, the following isoperimetric constraints have engineering interest:\nL=\n\nJ-1d x d y\np\nS\n\nif the lift is given,\n\n1M, = J-J- PlY I dXdY\nS\n\n(3)\n\n* Principal Research Engineer, Avco-Everett Research Laboratory, Everett,\nassachusetts.\n\n6 47\n\nRobert T. This weighing function has the values f = 1 if the lift is given,\nf = I y I if the bending moment is prescribed, andf = x if the pitching\nmoment is given.\nThe problem considered here consists of minimizing the drag integral\n(1) subject to one or more isoperimetric constraints \'having the form\ndescribed by Eq. (5). Clearly, this problem involves two independent\nvariables (x, y ) and two dependent variables (p, a). The latter, however,\nare related through the partial differential equations and boundary\nconditions describing the flow around the wing or through certain\nintegral\' relations. Since this method of solution is rather complicated,\nwe abandon it and approach the problem through the use of the reverse\nflow theorems already established for a wing in linearized supersonic\nflow (Refs. 2 and 3).\nFrom the linearized theory, it is known that the drag associated with\na given distribution of lift remains unchanged when the direction of\nmotion of the wing is reversed. The angle of attack distribution over the\nwing surface in the reverse flow may be denoted by ar(x, y) and will, of\ncourse, differ from a(x, y) if the pressure distribution p(x, y) is to remain\n\n648\n\n8. Three-Dimensional Wings of Minimum Pressure Drag\n\n127\n\nunchanged. In view of the reverse flow theorem, we may express the drag\nin terms of a combinedflow field obtained by superimposing the disturbances created by the given lift distribution in the forward and reverse\nmotions (Fig. 2). PARTICULAR CASES\nThe previous extremal property for the drag is remarkable for the\neconomy of its derivation. It holds for subsonic as well as supersonic\nflows and is not even restricted to steady motion. Several particular cases\nare now considered.\n3.1, Given Lift.\n\nIf only the lift is prescribed, Eq. (13) becomes\n\n&=A\n\n(16)\n\nmeaning that the angle of attack of the combined flow field is constant\nover the entire planform. Hence, the downwash angle, which is pro-\n\n650\n\n8. Three-Dimensional Wings of Minimum Pressure Drag\nportional to E, is constant. Furthermore, for the subsonic flow regime, the\nspanwise lift distribution is elliptical, as shown by Munk in Ref. 4.\nIncidentally, a change in the chordwise lift distribution does not cause a\nmodification in the induced drag as long as the spanwise lift distribution\nis the same (for further comments, see Section 3.2).\nIt should be noted that the elliptic loading also plays an important\nrole in the minimum drag of supersonic wings. If, following an analogy to\nWhittaker\'s solution of Laplace\'s equation (Ref. 5), we calculate the\ndisturbance field of a supersonic wing by the superposition of twodimensional fields, we find that the downwash is the sum of the contributions due to a series of two-dimensional loadings obtained by projecting\nthe lift distribution in different directions. Thus, a Lower bound for the\ndrag may be obtained by assuming that each projected or integrated\nloading is elliptical. If the planform is elliptic, this lower bound is the\nactual minimum value, providing the pressure is constant. As an example,\nat Mi = 2/z,the minimum drag of an unyawed wing is given by (Ref. 5)\n\nwhere p is the free-stream density, U is the free-stream velocity, a and 6\nare the semiaxes of the ellipse, and S is its area. If the wing is yawed, the\ncorresponding minimum drag is given by (Ref. 5 )\n\nwhere i denotes the imaginary unit, 9 the real part of the complex\n\'\nnumber within brackets, and where the quantities a, b\', and m are defined\nin Fig. 3.\n\nFIG. 3. Oblique ellipse.\n\n651\n\nRobert T. Jones\n\n3.2. Given Lift and Bending Moment. I n steady subsonic flow,\nthe superposition of the forward and reverse disturbance fields results in a\npurely two-dimensional field of motion identical with the flow produced\nby the vortex wake in the Trefftz plane. The inclination E in the combined\nflow field may then be identified with the induced downwash wi of Munk\xe2\x80\x99s\ntheory (Ref. 4), that is,\nE =w,/u\n\n(19)\n\nI n such a two-dimensional field, E is independent of the chordwise\ncoordinate x. Therefore, the specification of a weighing function f which\ndepends on x does not lead to a solution of the problem. However, we\nmay impose various conditions on the spanwise distribution of the lift.\nThus, following Ref. 6, we may specify both the total lift and the\nbending moment. I n this case, the angle of attack of the combined flow\nfield is given by\n5 = A,\n\n+\n\nA21\n\nY\n\nI\n\n(20)\n\nI n Munk\xe2\x80\x99s original problem (Ref. 4 ,the span b and the total lift were\n)\nprescribed, and the optimum lift distribution was found to be elliptical.\nNow, let us consider a family of wings having the same lift and bending\nmoment as Munk\xe2\x80\x99s optimum wing, and let us study the effect of the span\non the optimum lift distribution as well as on the drag. The analysis,\nomitted for the sake of brevity (Ref. 6 ) ,shows that increasing values of the\nspan cause the lift distribution to become more tapered and the induced\n)\ndrag to become smaller (Fig. 4 .\n2.0\n\n1.6\n\n12\n.\n\nDID.\n0.8\n\n0.4\n\n0\n0.8\nF I G . 4.\nmoment.\n\n6 52\n\n10\n.\n\n1.2\n\nb/b.\n\n14\n.\n\n16\n.\n\n8\n\nMinimum vortex drag for wings having a fixed lift and a fixed bending\n\n8. Three-Dimensional Wings of Minimum Pressure Drag\n3.3. Given Lift and Pitching Moment. If an elliptic wing is\ndesigned for a given total lift in supersonic flow, the minimum drag\noccurs when the pressure is uniform. I n other words, the center of\npressure is identical with the center of the wing. Now, it is known that the\ncentroid of the lift added by a change in the angle of attack is ahead of\nthis point, especially if the wing has a low aspect ratio. Thus, the wing\ntrimmed for flight with the optimum loading is unstable in pitch. These\nideas lead us to specify the position of the center of pressure, or the\npitching moment, as well as the total lift.\nNow, if both the lift and the pitching moment are specified, Eq. (15 )\nbecomes\nG=A1+Afl\n\n(211\n\nmeaning that the combined angle of attack is a linear function of the\nchordwise coordinate. By the method of Ref. 5, it can be shown that the\nassociated pressure distribution is also a linear function of the chordwise\ncoordinate, that is,\n\nP\n\n= Pl\n\n+ Pzx\n\n(22)\n\nOmitting detailed manipulations, we obtain the following expression for\nthe minimum drag of an unyawed elliptical wing at M = 1/2:\n\nwhere 3 is the chordwise displacement of the center of pressure with\nrespect to the centroid of the ellipse.\n\n4. NONPLANAR WINGS\nThe foregoing derivation is easily extended to nonplanar lifting surfaces\nsuch as a wing with upturned or downturned tips (Fig. 5). If the angle\nof attack is defined as the angle between the free-stream velocity vector\n\nFIG.5. Wing with drooped tips.\n\n653\n\nRobert T. Jones\nand its projection on the wing surface, the drag is still given by Eq. (7)\nwith the understanding that x is a rectilinear chordwise coordinate and y\nis a curvilinear spanwise coordinate parallel to thpl wing surface. Because\nof the inclination of the pressure, the lift is given by\n\np cos S(3) dx-dy\n\n1=\n,\nS\n\nwhere the angle 001) is defined in Fig. 5. Consequently, if the l i t is the\nonly quantity prescribed, the condition for minimum drag becomes\n= x cos e@)\n\nar\n\n(25)\n\nFor a wing with vertical end plates, cos 0 = 0 over the end plates; hence,\nthe sidewash of the combined flow field must vanish.\n\n5. ALTERNA\'IZ APPROACH\nIn Kogan\'s analysis (Ref. 7), the minimum drag problem is approached\nfrom a different point of view. Instead of superimposing the forward and\nreverse disturbance fields, he utilizes the physically real flow and\nexpresses the drag in terms of quantities integrated over the enveloping\ncharacteristic surface of the wing. Such a characteristic envelope involves\nboth forward and reverse Mach waves tangent to the edges of the wing\n(Fig. 6).\nWith the forward-going characteristic surface Z as a reference, one\nobtains the following expression for the drag:\n\nA\n//\'\n\n\'\\\\\n\n/\n\n\\\n\n/\n\n\'\n\\\n\n/\n\'\nI\n\'\n\n-y=\n,,\n\n/\'\n/\n\n/\n\n\\\n\n___t\n\nUndisturbed\n\nflow direction\n\n/\n\'\n\\\n\n/\n\n\',\n\\,\n\n/\n\'\n\n,\n/\n\n\'\n\\\n\n/\n\n\'\n\\\n\nI\n\n/\n\'\n//\n\n\',\n\\\n\\\n\n"\n\n,/\n/\n\nI\n\nFIG.6. Characteristic envelope of a wing.\n\n654\n\n8. Three-Dimensional Wings of Minimum Pressure Drag\nwhile the total lift is given by\n\nwhere q is the velocity potential and where qa and qa denote the y-component and the z-component of the disturbance velocity after projection\n.\non the surface Z Thus, the drag is proportional to the kinetic energy of\nthis two-dimensional flow, while the lift is proportional to its downward\n\xe2\x80\x99isnpulse. Now, among all the flows having a given impulse, the one with\nthe smallest kinetic energy satisfies Laplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation (Kelvin\xe2\x80\x99s\ntheorem), that is,\n(PVV\n\n+\n\n(Pzs\n\n=0\n\n(28)\n\nHence, minimum drag is achieved when the streamlines of this lateral:\nflow on the rear characteristic surface imitate a two-dimensional incompressible flow. The connection between Kogan\xe2\x80\x99s analysis and our\nprevious treatment employing the combined disturbance field has been\nshown by Graham in Ref. 8.\nFollowing Prandtl and Munk, we are accustomed to thinking\nof the drag of a wing in terms of its area of entrainment. As is\nwell known in subsonic steady flow, the equivalent entrainment with\noptimum loading is represented by a circular jet having a diameter equal\nto the span of the wing. The drag of the wing at subsonic speeds is small\nbecause the area of entrainment is large. At supersonic speeds, however,\nthe lateral influence of the wing is restricted by the Mach waves, so that\nthe downwash associated with a given lift must be greater. Kogan\xe2\x80\x99s\nanalysis gives a quantitative value to these intuitive considerations.\nREFWENCES\n\n1.\n2.\n\n3.\n4.\n5.\n\n6.\n\nJONES, R. T. JONES*\nN A S A Ames Research Center, Moffett Field. Calg\nI theory, aotiSymmetrie arrangements o wings and bodies can have smaller wave drag than corresponding\nn\nf\nmirror-symmetriiarrangements. Thus, a long narrow oblique wing which presents the same aspeet for two opposite\ns\ndirectious of flight i potentially more efficient than corresponding (Le., stmctmaUy equivafent) swept wkg. The\nsingle continuous wing panel also adapts itpelf more readily to varying angles of obliqnity, and hence, to varying\nflight speeds. The present paper reviews previaus work on the aerodynamies and Right stability of oblique wing\ncombinations and suggests a possible mode of application to transport aircraft operating at moderate supersonic\n\nspeeds.\n\nIntroduction\n\n0\n\nNE ofthe unspoken assumptions in aircraft design is that of\nbilateral or mirror symmetry At sloa Right speeds, this\nassumption seems on rather secure ground, partly because of the\nindications of aerodynamic theory. but also because it agrees\nwith the observed evolutionary forms of birds\nAlthough it is perhaps natural to extrapolate the forms of birds\nand animals to the supersonic flight regme, there has been no\nrational discussion ofthe merits of bilateral symmetry for supersonic flight. In fact, once the velocity of sound is exceeded, the\nlaws of aerodynamics change in such a way as to make it seem\ninadvisable to arrange the components of an airplane side by side\nor abreast in a supersonic stream unless there are compelling\nreasons for such an arrangement\nBoth the transonic area rule and the supersonic small disturbance theory show large adverse interference effects for bodies or\nwings m a mirror-symmetric arrangement Figure I shows the\nresult of applying supersonic wave drag theory to two arplanes\nflying in close formation at a slightly supersonic Mach number\nIn the mirror-symmetric arrangement, the drag of each aircraft\nis doubled by the interference of the other, making a total wave\ndrag of four In the staggered or antisymmetric arrangement,\nhowever, the wave interference is favorable so that the drag of\nthe two airplanes is no greater than that of a single one. Figure\n2 shows the same e l k 3 for oblique wing panels. The arrow\nshape, which seems intuitively correct for supersonic speed,\nnevertheless has a predicted wave drag many times larger than\nthe antisymmetric arrangement.\nElements of lift or volume show favorable wave interference if\n\nFig. 1 Wave drag at Mach numbers nears\n1.0.\n\n44\n1\n\n.007\n\nFig. 2 Calculated wave\ndrag of symmetric and\nantisymmetric wings.\n\n1\n\nI\n\nco.oMi-/\n/f\nn\n\n.003\n\n.ooz}\n\n50\xe2\x80\x99 SWEEP\n1 TO I AXIS RATIO\n0\n1\n.\n0\n\n1,l\n\n1.2\n\n13\n.\n\n14\n.\n\n1.5\n\nM\n\nthey are disposed along lines whose normal component of\nvelocity is subsonic Thus, the wave drag of a long narrow wing\ntends toward zero if the wing is swept behind the Mach cone\nThe reversibihty of the wave drag,\xe2\x80\x99 however, indicates that a\ndistribution of lift or volume bavtng a minimum drag should\nshos the same aspect for two opposite directions of flight, i e ,\nwould have fore and aft symmetry. Consideration of the vortex\ndrag indicates further that the projected lift distribution should\nhave lateral symmetry (e g ,elliptic-span loading)\nIt is interesting that supersonic theory favors symmetry in both\nlongitudinal and lateral distributions of volume or lift, but\nevidently not mirror symmetry Intuitively, one feels that a supersonic airplane should take account of the direction of flight in\nits shape, i e , it should somehow \xe2\x80\x9cpoint\xe2\x80\x9d in the direction it is\ngoing However, in view of the reversibility of the wave drag,\ncurrent computer programs must gwe the same value of the drag\nwith the direction of flight reversed Figure 3 illustrates this\nresult t\n\n0=4\n\nI\n\nReview of Aerodynamic Properties of Oblique\nElliptic Wings\nTo obtain a configuration having a minimum wave drag, we\nt\nsuppose first of all that the total M and volume are gven and\nsecond a plane area within which the dimensions must be limited.\n\nReceived May 3, 1971, revision received August 30, 1971\nindex categories: Airplane and Component Aerodynarmcs, Aircraft\nConfiguration Design\n* Senior Staff Scientist Fellow AIAA\n\n?The reversibility theorems are, of course, limited to the pressure\ndrag and the lift curve slope as determined by linear theory Thus, the\neffect of viscosity demands locally different shapes for leading and\ntrailing edges, which are not reversible in practice.\n\n659\n\nR. length\nwhile the wave drag due t o volume goes down with the inverse\nfourth power\nThe second term of Eq ( I ) is the well-known linear formula\nfor the induced drag of a wing having an elliptic span-load distribution The rules determinmg the form of large birds, sailplanes,\ndnd other subsonic aircraft are evident from the first two terms\nof Eq ( I ) Here, one tries to maximize the span Y and to minimize the wetted area (ZS,) by reducing the width of the wing in\nthe flight direction Accordmg to the linear theory (induced drag\ntheory), the drag of the wing at subsonic speeds is independent of\neither the extension or the distribution of lift in the flight direction Hence, the long narrow straight wing or \xe2\x80\x9clifting line\xe2\x80\x9d is ideal\nat subsonic speeds vnce it minimizes the wetted area The\nsuccess of the rule for increasing LID by increasing the aspect\nratio depends, however, on the maintenance of Kutta-Joukowsky\nflow If one tries to approach the \xe2\x80\x9clifting line\xe2\x80\x9d too closely, the\nlifting pressure becomes excessive, and nonlinear effects associated with flow separation or shock losses will intervene In spite\nof these limiting phenomena, sailplanes with extreme proportions\nhave achieved L/D ratios as high as 40 o r 50 to 1\nThe counterpart of the lifting line at supersonic speeds IS the\noblique lifting line mentioned earlier Here the appearance of the\nwave drag [third and fourth terms of Eq (2)] requires that the\nwing have as great a length as possible tn addition to a wide\nspan and a small surface area The rules determining the optimum\nwing form are then similar to those determining the form of a\nsdiipkdne,except that at supersonic speeds one tries to maximize\n\nFig. 6 Drag due to lift;\nbJa Also, shown on the graphs, are the angles of yaw at which\nthe crosswise Mach number exceeds an assumed critical value of\n0.7.\nTo obtain a reasonably uniform distribution of lifting pressure\nat large angles of yaw, the wing must be constructed with a certain\ncamber and twist Calculations of the required camber and twist\nhave been made by R. Carrnichael and A. D Levin of Ames\nResearch Center utilizing the technique of Ref 6 The amount\nof twist indicated for a yaw angle of 45\xe2\x80\x9d. a lift coefficient of 0 5,\nand a Mach number near 1.0 is illustrated in Fig 7 It is seen\nthat the forward going tip must have a positive angle of attack\nwhile the angles of the rearmost sections are negative. A practical\n\nFig. 8 Drag dw to volume;\nobliqwellipticwings;@\nb/a = 10.\n\nway to provide an effective twist that automatically increases\nwith yaw angle is to construct the wing with a certain amount\nof upward curvature in its unyawed aspect, as shown in the figure.\nLinear theory is useful for determining gross shape parameters,\nbut cannot, of course, be relied on for critical details. Thus, for\nthe sections of the wing perpendicular to its long axis, one would\nselect airfoil shapes capable of sustaining a high-lift coefficient at\na high value of the crosswise component Mach number. Increasing the sweep angle will decrease the component Mach numberbut the lift coefficient based on the reduced component velocity\nwill then increase These considerations involdthe critical Mach\nnumber and the lift coefficient in combination and point to the\nchoice of airfoil sections that can develop a high ratio of absolute\nlifting pressure to ambient pressure, i.e.,\nPJP. = (v/~)M\xe2\x80\x99CL\nwithout drag penalty\nThe minimum wave drag for a given internal volume of the\nelliptic wing occurs when the thickness ratio of the sections\nfalls of elliptically toward the tips.\xe2\x80\x99 The formula for the drag\ndue to thickness or volume in the case of the yawed ellipse is\ngiven by J. H. B Smith\xe2\x80\x99 and the results are plotted in Fig 8 for\nan axis ratio of 10 to 1 and a root thickness/chord ratio ofO.l.\nThe wave drag associated with the volume of the wing shows a\nsteep rise as the long axis of the wing turns into the wind, the\ninfluence ofthe inverse fourth power of the projected length. Here,\nhowever, the drag increase associated with nonlinear or supercritical flow over the wing sections may dominate, so that the\nprediction of linear theory will not be adequate. It is here that\nthe newer developments in supercritical wing sections exemplified\nby the work of Piercey, Niewland, and Whitcomb may be\nsignificant for the antisymmetric wing.\nThe drag values, given by linear theory together with a suitable\nestimate of the skin friction, enable the prediction to be made of\nlift-dragratiosofelliptic\nwings at varous Mach numbers and yaw\nangles Such predIctIons wdl be valid if proper account is taken\n\ncDll /,\nM=I.j\xe2\x80\x99I\xe2\x80\x99\n\n= 0.1,\n02\n\nolil.LY4L\n0\n\n3 0 6 0 9 0\n\n0\n\n5\n\nIO\n1\n5\nAXIS RATQ b/a\n\n20\n\n25\n\nFig. 10 Variation of L/D with axis ratio showing effect of limitatha\nof the normal lift coefficient C , ,\nL,\n\n661\n\nR. Figure 9\ntaken from Ref. 8 shows such estimates for an ellipse of 10 to 1\naxis ratio, 10% thickness and a friction drag coefficient of 0.005.\nThe dotted curves show the effect of limiting the section lift coefficients to values of 1.0 and 0.5, respectively Figure 10 shows how\nthe increase of L/D with aspect ratio depends on the possibility of\nachieving rather high section lift coefficients.\nLift-drag values for slanted elliptic wings at M = 2.0 have been\ncalculated by J. H. B. Smith\xe2\x80\x99 and are quoted by D. Kuchemann\nFigure 11, adapted from Ref. 7, shows results of this calculation.\nAt M\xe2\x80\x99 = 2.0 peak lift drag ratios occur at $ = 15\xe2\x80\x9c-20\xe2\x80\x9d corresponding to sweep angles of 70\xe2\x80\x9d-75\xe2\x80\x9d. The optimum crosswise\nMach number indicated by linear theory is approximately 0.7,\nclose to one limit imposed by nonlinear effects\n\nAlAA JOURNAL\n\nWhile satisfactory stability can probably be achieved with the\nyawed wing in the normal flight range, some unusual effects will\ncertainly be apparent. One effect that can be anticipated is a\ncoupling between yaw angle and vertical acceleration, i.e., i?L/2$.\nA simple estimate for a wing at 45\xe2\x80\x9d yaw shows (l/L)(?L/?@)= 1,\nis., lg per radian of sideslip angle $. This value may be compared to the sensitivity of vertical acceleration to angle of\nattack changes. Assuming aC,/aa = 5, and a flight-lift coefficient\nof 1.0 we have (l/LXaL/aa) = 5; hence, the sensitivity to yaw is\nabout f the sensitivity to pitch.\nDynamic coupling between different degrees of freedom is not\nalways undesirable since excessive damping in one mode may be\ndistributed to a mode that would otherwise be deficient. Of\ncourse, conventional treatments of stability, which assume bilateral symmetry with the resulting division into \xe2\x80\x9clongitudinal\xe2\x80\x9d\nand \xe2\x80\x9dlateral\xe2\x80\x9d motions, are inapplicable in this case, and a full\ntreatment involving six degrees of freedom as well as aeroelastic\ndeformations will be required.\nAs is well known, slanted or swept wings tend to stall first at\nthe downstream tips. With the swept wing the loss of lift at the\ntips leads to a nose-up tendency aggravating the stall. In the\ncase of the slanted wing, the situation would Seem worse since\nthe asymmetric stall would lead to bank. The special measures\nused to control the pitchup tendency of swept wings may quite\npossibly not be adequate for a yawed wing of high aspect ratio.\nAt best, it is difficult to envision regular landings with the wing\nin the oblique position, and it seems desirable to incorporate.\nstraightened out for\nvariable geometry so that the wing may\nlanding.\n\nbe\n\nApplication to Transport Aircraft\nWind-Tunnel Tests of Yawed Wing Combinations\nFew wind-tunnel experiments have been made to test the predictions for oblique wings of high-aspect ratio. One set of experiments testing yawed and swept wings in conjunction with a\nfuselage was made by G . H. Holdaway and E. W. Hatfield\xe2\x80\x9d at\nAmes Aeronautical Laboratory (now Ames Research Center).\nThe angles of sweep or yaw in these tests was 40\xe2\x80\x9d and the wing\nthickness-chord ratio, approximately 11% Figure 12 shows the\ndrag at zero lift for two of the combinations tested At M = 10\nthe antisymmetric configuration has much smaller drag, as\nexpected At M = 1.15, however, the normal component of M is\napproximately 0 88, exceedingthe drag rise Mach number of the\nsections. Beyond this point, the drag of the yawed wing is higher\n\nStability and Control of Yawed Wing Aircraft\nWhen the advantages of\xe2\x80\x9csubsonic\xe2\x80\x9d sweep first became mident,\nquestions were raised about the possibility of flying an airplane\nwith the wing set at a large angle of yaw Perhaps the earliest\nexperiments to test the flight stability of such an arrangement\nwere made in 1946 by J P Campbell and H M Drake\xe2\x80\x9d in the\nFree-Flight Tunnel at Langley Field, Va\nCampbell and Drake found that the yawed wing avoided the\nlarge rolling moment due to sideslip and the consequent short\nperiod rolling oscillations of the swept wing They noted that the\nflight characteristics ofthe model remained essentially unchanged\nup to angles of yaw of 40\xe2\x80\x99 and were still satisfactory at 50\xe2\x80\x9d Of\nspecial interest is the observation that deflection of the ailerons\nproduced no observable pitching motion in free Right Evidently,\nthe change of longitudinal lift distributlon produced by deflecting\nthe ailerons is almost immediately cancelled by rolling motion of\nthe model The wing in effect simply follows the helix angle\ndefined by an effective twist associated with the aileron deflection\nwith no significant change in lift distribution The longitudinal\nstability and the trimmed lift are then governed by the position of\nthe aerodynamic center and the horizontal tail setting referred to\nthe oblique axis of the wing Some years later the present writer\ndemonstrated the rather surprising stability of the slanted wing\nby flying models at the first ICAS meeting in Madrid\n\n662\n\nVarying the angle of sweep or yaw has, of course, marked\nadvantages for other flight conditions, such as \xe2\x80\x9cholding\xe2\x80\x9d at subsonic speeds or adapting the airplane to cruise effiaently at\ndifferent Mach numbers Thus, overland flights of a supersonic\naircraft will probably be limited to Mach numbers low enough\nto avoid the sonic boom The same aircraft may fly much faster\nover water\nG H\nhas suggested that the mechanical problems of\nvariable geometry would be effectively eliminated by making an\n\xe2\x80\x9dall-wing\xe2\x80\x9d aircraft Such a step is certainly attractive, but with\ncurrent densities and loadings seems to be possible only for\nairplanes of very great size Lee assumes an airplane designed to\ncruise at M = 2 0 and compares the yawed-wing arcraft with the\nmore conventional delta wing type\nThe yawed wing was found capable of carrying twice the payload on the Atlantic flight chiefly because of its better off-design\nperformance It is antiapated that current supersonic transports\nmay consume as much as my,, of their fuel load in subsonic\nmaneuvers The ability to cruise or hold efficiently at reduced\nspeed would thus be important for the utility of such aircraft\nCurrent delta wing transports require laige amounts of power for\ntakeoff primarily because of large values of weight per unit span.\nSince the takeoff power diminishes approximately as the power\nof the span loading,extending the wing span can be very effective\nin reducing takeoff distance and noise\n\n2\n\n\\\n\nf\n\n0\n1\n\n8\n\n9\n\n1\n0\nMWCY\n\nNIIUT)FO\n\n1.1\n\nI\n\n1.2\n\nLA\n\nFig. 12 Drag at zero lift; comparison of yawed and swept wings.\xe2\x80\x99\n\nREDUCTION OF WAVE DRAG BY ANTISYMMETRIC ARRANGEMENT\n\nFEBRUARY 1972\n\na) Trimmed for M E 1\n\nby upward gust is aerodynamically equivalent to a twist, similar\nto that produced by deflecting ailerons. The air load due to such\na twist is, however, almost immediately cancelled by a rolling\nmotion with the helix angle of the roll (pY/Zu)equal to that of the\ntwist. Hence, the relief provided by the rolling motion should\neffectively cancel the tendency for aeroelastic divergence in the\ncase of the oblique wing. Stresses that arise during the acceleration of the rolling motion would be proportonal to the inertia\nin roll of the masses attached to the wing. Since the single\nfuselage at the center of the wing has almost negligible inertia in\nroll, one arrives at the surprising conclusion that the one-body\narrangement has greater aeroelastic stability than the two-body\narrangement. In either case, stability must be assured by adequate\nwing stiffness and adequate longitudinal stability. Clearly a more\ncomplete analysis, taking account of the free motions of the\naircraft as well as its elastic deflections will be required.\nTable 1 listsestimated components ol drag lor the arrangement\nshown in Fig. 13 at M = 1 . s 1 . 1 with the wing set at 45\xe2\x80\x9d.\nTable 1 Drag estimate for antisymmehic- ans sport aircraft\n\n__ - __\n\nI ) Wave drag of bodies\n2) Wave drag of wing alone\n\nb) Trimmed for\n\n3) Wing-body interference drag\n4) Dragfinterference of tail surfaces\n.5) Friction drag of wing\n6) Nonlinear \xe2\x80\x9cform\xe2\x80\x9d drag of wing\n7) Friction drag of bodies\n8) Friction drag oftail surfaces\n9) Friction drag ofengine nacelles\n\nM < 0.7\n\n-\n\nCD = 0001\n\n00004\n00006\n00005\n0 004\n0.004\n0 0034\nOb016\n00007\n\nCD, = 0.0162\n\n10) Lift induced drag at C ,\n\nc)\n\nTrimmed for M\n\n= 1.3\n\n- 1d\n\nFig. 13 Antisymmetric transport aircraft.\n\nArrangements permitting more conventional values of wing\nloadingandsizeare shown in Figs 13(a-c) and 14 The useoftwo\nbodies connected across by the wing and horizontal tail in a parallelogram arrangement has certain advantages ovei the usual\narrangement for variable sweep Shearing the parallelogram does\nnot displace its center of gravity and only slightly displaces the\ncenter of lift The first-order variation of lateral trim with yaw\nangle can be compensated by constructing the wing with an\nappropriate curvilinear dihedral as indicated earlier\nAs is well known, varying the geometry of the swept wing has\nseveral drawbacks First of all, massive bearings which can carry\nthe wing root bending moment must be used Secondly, movement of the lifting surface backward at supersonic speeds compounds the normal rearward travel of lifting pressure at these\nspeeds With the single slanted wing, however, the wing-beam\nstructure is continuous across the pivots and no primary bending\nloads appear\nIntuitively, one would expect the forward tip of the slanted\nwing to show a tendency for aeroelastic divergence Both slanted\nand swept wings tend to become concave upward when deflected\nunder a gust load, leading momentarily to a tendency to pitch up\nand increase the load However, the observation made in the free\nflight-tunnel\xe2\x80\x9d is relevant here for the case of the slanted wing.\nThe observation was that increasing the effective angle of attack\nof the forward wing tip and reducing that of the rearward tip by\ndeflecting the ailerons did not result in observable pitching\nmotion but only in roll\nIt can be seen that the elastic deflection of the oblique wing\n\n= 0.575\n\n= 0.0162\n\nAt M = 1 2, the yaw angle required is about 50\xe2\x80\x98 and the\nestimated L/D falls to approximately 15 When trimmed for subsonic flight (Fig 13b) the LID should exceed 20 to 1\nIn conclusion, it is admittedly surprising that aerodynamics\nand simple mechanics would lead to an antisymmetric form for\nsupersonic flight The difficulties with such forms may, however,\nbe more conceptual than real and it is hoped that our analysis,\nthough incomplete, will show that such configurations deserve\nmore serious study\n\nRefeiences\nJones, R T ,
