Vol 100,\nMarch 1961, pp 240-241\n\nNEW DESIGN GOALS AND A NEW SHAPE FOR THE SST\nRobert T. Jones\nAmes Research Center\n\nDecember 1972\n\n665\n\nJones, R. T., "New Design Goals and a New Shape for the SST," Astronautics and\nAeronautics, vol. 10, no. 12, Dec. 1972, pp. 66-70. @ 1972.\nReprinted by permission of the American Institute of Aeronautics and\nAstronautics.\n\n666\n\nt\nBy ROBERT T. JONES\nNASA Ames Research Center\n\nNew demands on the SST for better economy and\nless noise make it seem appropriate to consider a\nradically different concept of design. The shape\nsuggested here: an almost perfectly conventional\nsubsonic aircraft equipped with a straight wing of\nhigh aspect ratio, but with the wing arranged so\nthat it can be turned to different oblique angles for\nflight at different Mach numbers.\nNot a new idea at all, turning the wing as a whole\ninstead of sweeping it back from the middle has\nbeen proposed several times in the past by the\npresent writer and others.\xe2\x80\x99- 3,1 O J. P. Campbell\nand H. M. Drake studied the stability and control\nof oblique-winged aircraft in the NACA Free Flight\nTunnel more than 25 years ago.\xe2\x80\x98 Early in the 1960s\nG. H. Lee considered the advantages of an \xe2\x80\x9callwing\xe2\x80\x9d aircraft arranged so that it could be steered\nby flying at varying oblique angle^.^,^ In addition\nto American work, it appears that German\naerodynamicists made classified studies of such\nconfigurations during W W 11. Specifically,\nRichard Vogt of the Blohm and Voss Company\n\nROBERT T. JONES (F) is a senior\nstaff scientist at Ames. He has\nplayed a major part in raising the\naircraft\nthrough\nspeed of\ndeveloping theory for swept and\nslender delta wings. In 1946 the\nAIAA gave him its Sylvanus Albert\nReed Award. He has remained with\nNACA-NASA since 1934, except\nfor seven years with the AVCO\nEverett Research Lab, where h e\ndirected work on cardiac-assist devices. .He has also professionally\nfollowed an interest in optics.\n\nproposed designs of this type, but the projects did\nnot reach the stage of flight test.\nThese proposals do not seem to have been taken\nvery seriously by aircraft designers. In this article,\nconsequently, I would like to call attention to some\nrather remarkable properties of the oblique wing,\nreport some new discoveries concerning the shape\nof such wings, and discuss their adaptation to a\npractical aircraft.\nTo determine an optimum wing sliape, or a\nshape having a minimum of drag, the designer\nmust first of all adopt some constraint on the\ndimensions of the wing. Thus in Munk\xe2\x80\x99s problem\nof minimum induced drag the span of the wing is\nsupposed to be limited. With the total lift given, the\ninduced drag or vortex drag is then found to be a\nminimum when the lift is distributed elliptically\nover the span. Furthermore, the vortex drag is\nindependent of the distribution of lift in the\ndirection of flight. If a limit\xe2\x80\x99ation on the maximum\nlift coeacient is recognized and if the skin friction\nis taken into account, the optimum wing planform\nturps out to be a narrow ellipse with its long axis\nperpendicular to the direction of flight.\nFor supersonic speeds, in addition to the vortex\ndrag and the friction, the designer must weigh a\nwave drag associated with the thickness or volume\nof the wing as well as with the lift distribution.\nThese latter components are not independent of\nthe distribution in the flight direction, but diminish\nrapidly and continuously as the length of the wing\nin the flight direction is increased. So the designer\nmust adopt a limitation on the length of the wing as\nwell as the span. In spite of the additional sources\nAstronautics & Aeronautics\n\n66 7\n\nF-2 OBLIQUE-WINGED MODEL IN AMES 11-11TUNNEL\n\nofdrag, the additional constraint, and the tact that\nthe flow equation is now hyperbolic instead of\nelliptic, the subsonic elliptic wing reappears as the\noptimum for supersonic speeds. The wing merely\ntakes up the greatest \xe2\x80\x9csubsonic sweep\xe2\x80\x9d angle\npermitted by the constraints. The minimum drag\nagain occurs when the spanwise loading is elliptical\nand when the thickness-chord ratio of the wing\nsections falls off elliptically toward the tips.\xe2\x80\x99 ,6\nThe optimum supersonic wing planform thus\ndoes not have the bilateral (mirror) symmetry of the\nsubsonic wing. It is easy to show that the optimum\nthin planar wing cannot have the usual arrow or\ndelta form. According to the reversibility theorems\nof Karman and Hayes a given distribution of lift or\nvolume must have the same wave drag when flying\nin the opposite d i r e ~ t i o n-. ~According to Munk\xe2\x80\x99s\ntheorem the vortex drag must be the same also.\nHence, if the arrow wing were the optimum, the\nreversed arrow would also be the optimum.\nThe reversibility theorems thus indicate that an\noptimum shape should have fore and aft symmetry,\ni.e., should look the same for either direction of\nflight. The oblique ellipse satisfies this criterion,\nhaving both longitudinal and lateral symmetry but\nnot bilateral symmetry. The indication of fore and\naft symmetry is certainly remarkable since neither\nthe supersonic flow field nor the local distribution\nof the drag shows this kind of symmetry. Smalldisturbance theory identifies a limitation here.\nLocal details of the airfoil section shape are\nstrongly influenced by nonlinear effects, and are, of\ncourse, not reversible.\nDecember 1972\n\n668\n\n40\n\n-\n\nF-1 Lift-drag ratios\nof oblique-winged\nmodel as determined\nin the NASA-Ames 11-\n\n.7\n\n.\n8\n\n.9\n\n1\n.\n0\nM\n\n1.1\n\n1.2 1.3\n\n1.4\n\nWind-tunnel experiments at NASA Ames\nResearch Center have specifically tested the\nforegoing theoretical predictions (F-1). The wing\nhas a quasi-elliptic planform of 10-to-1axis ratio\n(aspect ratio 12.7). It was attached in the high wing\nposition to a fuselage of 12-to-1 fineness ratio. The\nairfoil sections, 10% thick, were derived by the\nconventional NACA \xe2\x80\x9c4-digit\xe2\x80\x9d formula. To\nmaintain the desired symmetry of the lift\ndistribution in the yawed position, the wing was\nconstructed without twist but with a calculated\namount of upward curvature, Le., a \xe2\x80\x9ccurvilinear\ndihedral\xe2\x80\x9d in the unyawed position. The wing thus\nhas bilateral syrimetry in the unyawed position.\n\nWith the wing in the oblique positions the\ncurvilinear dihedral has an aerodynamic effect\nequivalent to that of twist.\nA photo here (F-2) shows the elliptic wing-body\nmodel in the Ames 11-ft supersonic tunnel. The\ntests confirmed the theoretical predictions in a very\nsatisfactory way. With the wing straight the\nmaximum lift-drag ratio L/Dmax exceeded 30 to 1\nat Mach numbers (M) up to 0.7, but fell abruptly to\n11 at M = 0.8. The wing was then turned to 45 deg\na d L/Dmax increased to 20 at M = 0.98. At M =\n1 4 and a wing angle of 60 deg, LID was\napproximately 11. In every case these values run\nsignificantly higher than those previously obtained\nwith arrow wing or delta wing-body combinations.\nSince the oblique wing does not have the\ncustomary bilateral symmetry, questions of\n\n7\n\nF-3\n\nRADIO-CONTROLLED FLYING MODEL\n\nF-4\n\nOBLIQUE WINGED AIRCRAFT\n\nstability and control immediately present\nthemselves. Perhaps the earliest experiments on the\ncontrollability of such a configuration were made\nby H. M. Drake and J. P. Campbell in the NACA\'s\nFree Flight Tunnel at Langley Field.4 They found\nthat the oblique-winged model did not have the\nlateral rolling oscillations characteristic of sweptwing models and showed satisfactory stability and\ncontrol up to wing angles of 50 deg. At 60 deg\nhowever, the ailerons become ineffwtive and\nlateral control could not be maintained.\nWith the wing kt at a large angle, the ailerons\nare in a position to cause a relatively large pitching\nmoment in addition to their normal rolling action.\nCampbell and Drake found, however, that aileron\ndeflection in free flight did not produce observable\npitching motions. Evidently the rolling motion\nquickly cancels the unsymmetrical lift distribution\nproduced by the ailerons an6 the resulting pitching\nmoment.\nTo gain further experience in the control and\nstability of oblique winged aircraft, I have made\nand tested radio-controlled flying models, taking\nadvantage of the highly sophisticated techniques\nand equipment developed in recent years by modelairplane builders. Photos (F-3 and F-4) show one of\nthe models. The radio control9 gives linear,\nproportional deflection of all surfaces and in\naddition permits variation of the wing skew angle\nin flight. Takeoffs and landings were made with the\nwing straight. An enlarged 16-mm movie frame (FF-5\n\nENLARGED 16-MM MOVIE FRAME OF R. C.\n\nMODEL IN FLIGHT\n\nAstronautics & Aeronautics\n\n669\n\n5)shows the model in flight with the wing at 45 deg.\nBurnett L. Gadeberg of Ames controlled the\nmodel.\nVariations of wing angle up to and beyond 45\ndeg produced no apparent changes in stability and\nonly a slight change in lateral trim-requiring a 1or 2-deg offset of the ailerons. Elevatoc and aileron\neffectiveness remained normal and we observed no\nchange in longitudinal trim.\nOrdinary maneuvers such as loops and rolls were\nperformed without difficulty at wing angles of 45\ndeg. Coupling between longitudinal and lateral\nmotions did not appear in aileron rolls, but was\nquite apparent in the response to elevator control.\nThus loops performed with the wing at 45 deg\nappeared to take the form of a 45-deg helix,\nindicating that the rotation produced by the\nelevator tends to align with the long axis of the\nwing. With the left tip forward, use of the elevator\nin a left turn tended to steepen the bank angle.\nAnalysis shows that in this case a certain amount of\naileron deflection must be employed with the\nelevator to prevent banking toward the forward tip.\nVarying the sweep by turning the wing as a whole\nhas several practical advantages over the usual\n\xe2\x80\x9cswing wing\xe2\x80\x9d design. It keeps the wing structure\ncontinuous across the pivot and makes the primary\nload on the pivot tension. With separate wing\npanels pivoted at the root, however, much greater\nloads develop on the pivots (F-6). Also, sweeping\nthe wing panels back for high-speed flight\ndisplaces the center of lift rearward, compounding\nthe normal rearward center-of-pressure shift at\nthese speeds. Turning the wing as a whole,\nhowever, does not displace the centroid of area\nrelative to the center of gravity (F-7). Even with\nfixed geometry the structure of the bilaterally\nsymmetric wing is less favorable because of the\nunbalanced torsion at the wing root. The\nunbalanced torsion may be equated approximately\nto increase in beam length for the swept wing (F-8).\nFinally, conforming to the \xe2\x80\x9carea rule,\xe2\x80\x9d the swept\nwing requires a rather localized and deep\nindentation of the fuselage. The optimum fuselage\nshape for the oblique wing, however, is much more\nnearly cylindrical (F-9).\nThe artist\xe2\x80\x99s rendering on the last page of\nthis article shows a conceptual version of a longrange supersonic transport utilizing the oblique\nwing. By attaching the wing to the fuselage so that\nit can be turned to different angles, flight at\ndifferent Mach numbers can be made with the\nutmost efficiency. Thus, for overland flights at\nspeeds slow enough to avoiZl the sonic boom (M 1.01.2) the wing angle must be 45-55 deg. For\noverwater flights at P 1.4, 60-65 deg would be\nd\nneeded. It is anticipated that landings and takeoffs\nwould be made with the wing in the straight\nDecember I972\n\n670\n\nF-6 CONTINUOUS WING STRUCTURE; NO\nBENDING LOAD ON PJVOTS\n\nF-7 CENTROID OF LIFTING AREA NOT DISPLACED\nBY ROTATION\n\nF-0\n\nSTRAIGHT-BEAM STRUCTURE.\n\nF-9\n\nSMOOTH AREA DISTRIBUTION FOR FUSELAOE\n\nConcept of a pivoting-wing SST for commercial operations.\n\nposition. With a straight wing of high aspect ratio,\nthe energy required for takeoff should be less than\nthat required by conventional subsonic jets and\nabout one-fourth that required by current\nsupersonic transports. And limiting the maximum\ncruise Mach number to 1.4 will permit the use of\ninherently quiet fanjet engines. Thus it seems that\na design of the type considered could effectively\nmeet current demands for voiding sonic boom and\nreducing noise around airports.\nReferences\n1. Jones, R. Graham, Robert T. Jones and Frederick W. Boltz\ny\n\nA e Research Center\nms\n\nSUMMARY\nA experimental i n v e s t i g a t i o n w a s conducted i n t h e A e 1 - by 11-Foot\nn\nms 1\nTransonic Wind Tunnel t o determine t h e aerodynamic c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of\nt h r e e oblique high aspect r a t i o wings i n combination with a high finenessr a t i o Sears-Haack body. The t h r e e wings had t h e same e l l i p t i c a l planform\nand base l i n e curvature but had d i f f e r e n t a i r f o i l sections. One wing had\nan a i r f o i l s e c t i o n designed t o have a l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t of 1.0 a t a Mach\nnumber of 0.7, another t o have shock-free supersonic flow over t h e upper\nsurface, and t h e o t h e r t o have a l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t of 1.3 a t a Mach number\nI\nof 0.6.\nLongitudinal and l a t e r a l - d i r e c t i o n a l s t a b i l i t y data were obtained a t\nwing yaw angles of Oo, 4 5 O , 50\xc2\xb0, and 60" over a t e s t Mach number range from\n0.6 t o 1.4 f o r angles of a t t a c k between -7Oand 9: Reynolds numbers f o r\nt h e study were 4 and 6 m i l l i o n per foot. Flow-visualization s t u d i e s w e r e\nmade t o examine t h e nature o f t h e flow on t h e wing surfaces.\nNotable differences were found i n t h e aerodynamic c h a r a c t e r i s t i c s of\nt h e t h r e e wing-body combinations, p a r t i c u l a r l y i n t h e l a t e r a l - d i r e c t i o n a l\nc h a r a c t e r i s t i c s . The aerodynamic e f f i c i e n c y of t h e t h r e e wing-body com-\n\nbinations w a s i n most instances about t h e same, with two of t h e wings gene r a l l y e x h i b i t i n g s l i g h t l y higher maximum values. The other wing was s l i g h t l y more e f f i c i e n t a t Mach numbers where s u p e r c r i t i c a l Slow e x i s t e d on t h e\nwings.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nTheoretical predictions and i n d i c a t i o n s r e l a t e d t o t h e oblique-wing\nconcept have been extensively discussed ( a s i n references 1 and 2 ) and\nrecently i n v e s t i g a t e d experimentally i n t h e NASA-Ames 1 - by 11-Foot T r a n 1\nsonic Wind Tunnel.\nTheory i n d i c a t e s t h a t i n order t o achieve maximum e f f i c i e n c y t h e oblique\nangle of t h e wing must be v a r i e d with Mach number i n such a way t h a t t h e\ncomponent of v e l o c i t y normal t o t h e long a x i s of t h e wing remains subsonic\n\n6 77\n\nand below t h e "drag rise" Mach number of t h e wing s e c t i o n s . The s e c t i o n s\ntaken i n t h e planes perpendicular t o t h e long axis t h e n have a "subsonic"\nshape with a rounded leading edge and camber t o produce a high l i f t\nc o e f f i c i e n t at a high c r i t i c a l Mach number. Three wings, having d i f f e r e n t a i r f o i l s e c t i o n s i n t h e planes perpendicular t o t h e long axis of\nt h e wing, have been t e s t e d i n t h e A e 1 - by 11-Foot Transonic Wind Tunnel.\nms 1\nAll wings have t h e same e l l i p t i c a l planform with an e l l i p t i c axis r a t i o\nof 1 0 t o 1, an unswept aspect r a t i o of 12.7 and a thickness-chord r a t i o\nof 0.1.\nOne wing has an a i r f o i l s e c t i o n derived by t h e w e l l known NACA \'\'4\nd i g i t " formula ( s e e reference ( 3 ) ) . The shape parameters f o r t h e a i r f o i l\nwere s e l e c t e d on t h e b a s i s of previous wind tunnel experience with t h e int e n t i o n of achieving as high a l i f t c o e f f i c i e n t as p o s s i b l e a t a c r i t i c a l\nMach number of O,7.\nThe s e c t i o n has a r e l a t i v e l y b l u n t leading edge with\na radius of 2 percent of t h e chord.\nAnother a i r f o i l t e s t e d was designed by Bauer, Garabedian and Korn\nof t h e Courant I n s t i t u t e , New York University using a hodograph method\nt o o b t a i n a shock-free supersonic zone over t h e upper surface. Data on\nt h i s a i r f o i l a r e given as example 1 ( f i g u r e 5 i n Reference ( 4 ) ) .\nThe o t h e r a i r f o i l w a s designed f o r purely subsonic flow a t a Mach\nThis a i r f o i l has more camber and a design l i f t c o e f f i number O f 0.60.\nc i e n t of 1.3 (based on t h e normal component v e l o c i t y ) .\nNOME!NCLATUXE\n\nThe a x i s systems and s i g n convention a r e shown i n figure 1. L i f t\nand drag a r e presented i n t h e s t a b i l i t y - a x i s coordinate system and all\no t h e r f o r c e s and moments a r e presented i n t h e body-&xis coordinate system.\nBecause t h e d a t a were computer p l o t t e d t h e corresponding p l o t symbol,\nwhere used, i s given t o g e t h e r with t h e conventional symbol.\nPlot\nDefinition\nb\n\nwing span\n\nC\n\nwing segment\n\nB\n\nB\n\nbody\nTEST FACILITY\n\nThe t e s t s were conducted i n the Ames 1 - by ll-Foot Transonic Wind\n1\nTunnel, which i s a variable density, closed return, continuous flas type.\nT h i s tunnel has an adjustable nozzle (two flexible w a l l s ) and a slotted\nt e s t section to permit transonic t e s t i n g over a Mach number range continously variable from 0.4 to 1-4.\n\n6 80\n\nMODEL DESCRIPTION\nThe model consisted of an e l l i p t i c a l planform wing mounted on top\nof a Sears-Haack body as shown i n figure 2(a). Pertinent dimensions of\nthe wings investigated and of the Sears-Haack body, which w a s e m o n t o\nall configurations, are given i n tables 1 through 3 and i n figures 2(a)\nthrough ( a ) . A photograph o f the model i s shown i n f i v e 2 ( e ) , The\nwing w a s pivoted i n the horizontal plane about the 0.4 root chord point\nt o obtain oblique angles of Oo, 4 5 O , 50\xc2\xb0, and 6oom sham i n f i g u r e 2(a).\n\nAll wings had e l l i p t i c & planforms w i t h a straight 25-percent chord\nWing number 1, W\n( see ref. 1)had an NACA 3610-02,40\n(\nl i n e ( f i g , 2 a) )\n1\n\'\na i r f o i l section ( f i g . 2 ( d ) ) perpenbcular to t h e unswept chord l i n e . The\nsecond w i n g t e s t e d (wing number 2, W ) had an a i r f o i l section ( f i g . 3 ( a ) )\n2\ndesigned using a hodograph method t o obtain a shock-free supersonic zone\nover the upper surface. The t h i r d wing t e s t e d (wing number 4, Wb) had a\nsubkonic a i r f o i l section ( f i g . 3(b)) designed f o r a l i f t coefficient of\n1.3 at a Mach number of 0.60. A i r f o i l coordinates f o r t h e t h r e e wings\nare given i n table 2\n.\n\n.\n\nR CD R\nTESTING AND P O E U E\nThe models were s t i n g mounted through t h e base of t h e model body as\nshown i n figures 2 ( a ) and 2 ( c ) , and force and moment d a t a were obtained from\nan i n t e r n a l l y mounted six-component strain-gage balance. The moment center\nw a s on the body center l i n e and longitudinally a t the wing pivot point\nTests were conducted a t Reynolds numbers of 4 and 6 million\n( 0 . 4 t ) .~ ~\n~\nper foo?. The angle-of-attack range, selected t o define maximum l i f t - t o drag r a t i o f o r each configuration, w a s nominally f 8 degrees. Six corn\nponent force and moment data were obtained f o r the wing a t oblique angles\nof Oo, 4 5 O , 50\xc2\xb0, and 60O.\nThe measured balance data were adjusted t o a condition corresponding\nt o free-stream s t a t i c pressure on the model base, The Mach number range\nf o r each oblique angle tested is shown i n t a b l e 4,\n\nRESULTS AND DISCUSSION\nA complete index t o the data figures i s given i n table 5. Among the\nnoteworthy r e s u l t s o r these experiments are t h e exceptionally high l i f t drag r a t i o s obtained i n t h e transonic and low supersonic speed ranges.\n\n681\n\nLift-to-drag r a t i o s f o r the three Wings are sham i n figures 4 through 7\nf o r t h e t e s t Mach numbers and wing-sweep angles. Wing number 2 shows a\nmaximum L/D value of 31 f o r M = 0.80 and zero wing sweep ( f i g . 4, pg. 21).\nWing numbers 1 and 4 both had a m a x h u m L/D value of 1 a t M = 1.40 and\n1\n60\xc2\xb0 of wing sweep ( f i g . 7, pg. 140),\nWing number 2, which w a s designed t o operate with shock-free supersonic flow over the upper surface showed the expected behavior. A t zero\n.0\nwing sweep t h i s a i r f o i l extended the useful Mach d e r fram 0 7 t o appraXimately 0.80. A t 60\xc2\xb0 sweep, however, the crosswise component of Mach number\nat M = 1.40 i s only 0.70, not s u f f i c i e n t t o achieve the design condition\nof t h i s wing. Further refinement of a i r f o i l . selection f o r such oblique\nwings w i l l depend on the extansion of three dimensional w h g theory beyond the linearized formulas now i n use and probably also on more d e t a i l e d\nwind tunnel studies.\n\n-\n\nAnother noteworthy feature of the t e s t results i s the remarkably\ns m a l l s h i f t of center of pressure f o r wing sweep variations from Oo t o\nComparing the pitching moment of the straight wing a t M = 0 7 ( f i g .\n.0\n60\xc2\xb0.\n4, pg. 9 ) with that of the same wing turned 60\xc2\xb0 shows only moderate changes\ni n s p i t e of the f a c t t h a t the fore and a f t dimension (streanwise chord)\nof the wing increased almost ten-fold when the wing w a s swept.\nA similar result can be observed i n the r o l l i n g moment measurements. Figure 4, page 13 shows r o l l i n g moments measured on the wings i n\nthe unyawed position. Presumably such moments a r i s e from accidental\nmanufacturing irregularities o f the models. Figure 7, page 104 shows\nr o l l i n g moments of the same wings turned 60\xc2\xb0. I n the normal f l i g h t range\nthese are only s l i g h t l y greater than those developed on the straight,\nsupposedly symmetrical wings. A t l a r g e r angles of attack. however,\ne f f e c t s of premature s t a l l i n g of the downstream t i p are observed on the\noblique wings. This behavior may be compared with the premature t i p stalling encountered w i t h more conventional swept-back wings. With conventional\nswept-back wings s t a l l i n g of the t i p s causes t h e airplane t o p i t c h up.\nWith the oblique wing only one t i p stalls and the airplane may be expected\nt o roll.\n\nAmes Research Center\nNational Aeronautics and Space Administration\nMoffett Field, California 94035\n\n682\n\nApril 2, 1973\n\n1\n.\n\nGraham, Lawrence A.; Jones, Robert T.;\n\nand Boltz, Frederick W.:\n\nAn Ekperirnental Investigation of an Oblique-Wing and Body Cornbination at Mach Numbers Between 0.60 and 1.4. JONES (F) (far left) a senior staff scientist at NASA-Ames,\nplayed a major part idraising ihe speed of aircraft through developing\ntheory for swept and slender delta wings. In 1946 the AlAA ave him its\nSylvanus Albert Reed Award. H e has been with NACA and fiASA since\n1934, except for seven years with the AVCO Everett Research Laboratory,\nwhere he directed work on cardiac-assist devices. Besides aerodynamics,\nhe has maintained a professional interest in optics. JAMES W. NISBET,\nduring 13 years at Boeing, has worked on nearly all of the current jet\nairplanes as well as in preliminary design and research. Currently\nresponsible for aeroelastic loads in airplane exploratory design, he has\nlong been involved in analysis, wind-tunnel testin and airplane testing\nregarding aeroelasticity and structural dynamics. tefore joinin Boeing,\nhe spent four years with Canadian Westinghouke on the jesign of\nelectrical system controls.\n\nAstronautics &Aeronautics\n\n851\n\nF-1 CONFIGURATION CONCEPTS\n\nFIXED SWEPT\nWING\n\nVARIABLE\nSWEEP WING\n\nDELTA\nWING\n\nComplete results and the assumptions employed\nin the study are contained in NASA CR 114658.3\nThis article emphasizes certain results characterizing oblique-wingdesigns.\nEach airplane was designed to carry 195\npassengers 3000 n. mi. at a speed near the sonic\nground speed. Operation just below sonic ground\nspeed eliminates the sonic boom associated with\noverland supersonic flight. As shown in F-2 (from\nRef. 4) the shock fronts curve slightly as they\nprogress to lower altitude. This curvature, caused\nby the change in speed of sound with temperature,\nestablishes the maximum speed at which a transonic transport can fly without producing a boom\nat ground level. When the shock front becomes\nvertical the boom does not extend to the ground;\nthis would permit boom-free flight at speeds nearly\n50% greater than subsonic jets make today-a\nf\nsaving o some 2 hr 012 east-to-west and I hr on\nwest-to-easttranscontinental U.S.\njlights.\nThe aerodynamic characteristics of all five\nconfigurations were developed using similar\nprocedures. The planform parameters were\nselected to exploit the aerodynamic benefits of each\nconcept. The wing thickness distributions were\nderived from past weight-drag tradeoff studies on\ntransonic transports. The camber and twist\ndistributions were developed by linear theory. The\nbody designs for all configurations were area-ruled\nto yield minimum cruise drag. The nacelle shape\nJanuary 1974\n\n852\n\nOBLIQUE WING\nTWIN FUSELAGE\n\nOBLKlUE WING\nSINGLE FUSELAGE\n\nand location was strongly influenced by the engine\nsize and the configurationalarrangement.\nEngine performance, size, and weight\ncharacteristics were consistent with the results of\nthe Advanced Transport Technology (ATT) study.5\nEngine selection was based on an engine-bypassratio tradeoff study. The penalty of reducing the jet\nnoise by increasing bypass ratio was compared to\nthe penalty associated with jet suppression of\nlower-bypass-ratio installation;. A bypass-ratio-of1 engine with jet suppression .was selected for all\nconfigurations as the most efficient means of\nachieving low noise levels.\nThe swept-wing,variable-sweep wing, and deltawing configurations had the advantage of considerable previous study; and it seems probable\nthat the arrangement of landing gear, engine, etc.\nwas near the optimum in those cases.\nThe oblique-winged aircraft introduced some\nnew problems, and considerable effort was devoted\nto finding a good general arrangement. The emphasis was on the engine and landing-gear\nplacement. There was considerable flexibility in\nlocating the landing gear because takeoff rotation\nand high-angle landing flare were not required. F-3\nshows the arrangement adopted in the final stage\nof the study.\nA balance and loading analysis of the obliquewing configuration indicated the need for a centeroEgravity range of 2570 MAC (mean aerodynamic\n\nF-2\n\nAVOlDlNQ SONIC BOOM\n\nwing configuration and gives an estimate of the\npercent weight savings of the advanced materials\nrelative to conventional aluminum skim-stringer\nconstruction.\nGraphite-epoxy honeycomb was selected for the\nwing, fuselage, and vertical-tail primary structure.\nTitanium was selected for the wing pivots and\npivot-support structure. For configurations other\nthan the oblique wing, the primary wing-structure\nweightsaving was estimated to be 25%. Primarystructure weight savings for the oblique wing was\ndetermined by analysis of both an aluminum and a\nCRUISE MACH NUMBER\ngraphite-epoxy structure. The aluminum oblique\nwing was stiffness- rather than strength-critical;\nthe graphite-epoxy oblique wing was strengthTRANSONIC\ncritical. This resulted in a weightsaving of 35% for\nthe advanced material as compared to aluminum.\nStructural analysis of the graphite-epoxyoblique\nCONSTANT AIRPLANE GROUND SPEED\nwing involved these conditions:\nNO SONIC BOOM-SHOCK WAVES DO NOT REACH GROUND\nA ply arrangement-considering external load\ndistributions and the bending stiffness required for\nchord). It differs significantly\nWind-tunnel results given last January in A/A\nrepresented an elliptic wing having an aspect ratio from a variable-sweepwing pivot. Drag loads and side\nloads were transferred through bearings on the pin\nthese proportions characterized the oblique wing.\nStructural materials were selected for all con- in the piddle of the pivot. Systems going from the\nfigurations based on the Advanced Transport body to the wing were routed through the center of\nTechnology (ATT) study result^.^ F-4 identifies the the pivot.\nAs is well known, swept-forward wings show a\nmaterials selected for the single-fuselage obliqueCRUISE MACH NUMBER\n\n_e_\n\nAstronautics &Aeronautics\n\n853\n\ntendency for aeroelastic divergence. Bending of a\nswept-forward wing panel creates an aerodynamic\nforce which acts to increase the deflection in opposition to the structural stiffness. At a sufficiently\nhigh flight speed or dynamic pressure the\naerodynamic destabilizing force can overpower the\nstructural stiffness, leading to aeroelastic\ndivergence.\nThe behavior of the oblique wing differs from the\nbilaterally symmetric swept-forward wing\xe2\x80\x99s: the\ncoupled rolling motion exerts a stabilizing influence. Aeroelastic instability of the oblique wing\noccurs as an oscillatory instability; there is a\nprogressive lengthening of the period and loss of\ndamping of the elastic bending oscillations of the\n\nfor strength alone. For comparison, it also shows\nstability with the fuselage clamped to prevent\nrolling (as in a wind-tunnel test). At zero flight\nspeed (or, equivalently, zero dynamic pressure) the\nfrequency of the unrestrained airplane as well as\nboth wings of the restrained airplane was 0.93\nHertz. As the speed was increased, the damping\nratio initially increased.\nWith the fuselage clamped, the frequency of the\nforward wing decreased while the frequency of the\naft wing increased. The damping ratio of the\nforward wing decreased rapidly at higher speeds.\n(The so-called \xe2\x80\x9cstatic\xe2\x80\x9d divergence speed is the\nspeed at which both the frequency and damping\nratio become zero.)\n\nF-3 OBLIQUE-WING AIRPLANE\n\nwing combined with rolling motion.\nF-6 illustrates the dynamic model used to study\nthe aeroehstic stability of the oblique wing. The\nwing mass was represented by a series of point\nmasses. The aerodynamic lift distribution was\nrepresented by a section lift coefficient for each of\nthe wing panels. Wing flexibility was represented\nby beam bending and beam torsion, although it\nwas found in the analysis that torsional stiffness\nhad little effect on the stability of a wing with an\noblique angle of 45 deg. Airplane roll was treated\nas a separate degree of freedom in the analysis.\nF-7 shows the results of the analysis of a wing\nwith an aspect ratio of 12.7 (109ellipse) designed\nJanuary 1974\n\n854\n\nF-4 MATERIALS SELECTION FOR AN ADYANCEDTECHNOLOGY OBLIQUE-WING AIRCRAFT\n\nPIVOT STRUCTURE\n\n0\n\nNUMBERS REFER TO PERCENT\nWEIGHT SAVING RELATIVE TO\nAN ALUMINUM SKIN STRINGER\nDESIGN\n\nGRAPHITE EPOXY HONEYCOMB\nGRAPHITE EPOXY INTEGRATE0 ACOUSTIC STRUCTURE\nHIGH TEMPERATURE MATRIX COMPOSITE HONEYCOMB\nDUPONT PRD 49 HONEYCOME\nCONVENTIONAL DESIGN\n\nF-5 STRUCTURAL\nARRANGEMENT OF\nOBLIQUE-WING PIVOT\n\nd.:\n\n4\n\nOBLIQUE WING PIVOT CONCEPT\n\nVARIABLE SWEEP WING\nPIVOT CONCEPT\nf\n\nThe unrestrained airplane did not exhibit this\nstatic instability. As speed was increased, the\nfrequency decreased and the bending deflection of\nthe forward wing increased relative to the aft wing.\nThe wing-bendmg deflections introduced roll\nparticipation into the oscillation. The oscillatory\naeroelastic instability occurred at a higher speed\nthan the speed at which the clamped fuselage static\ninstability occurred.\nAnalyses of aeroelastic behavior which assume\nthat the fuselage is clamped at the wing root appear to be conservative for most oblique-wing\n\nconfigurations. The aspect-ratio-12.7oblique,wing\ndesigned for strength alone became unstable at\nabout 90% of the airplane\'s speed. FAA criteria\nrequire stability up to 120% of the design speed. It\nis evident that a wing of this high an aspect ratio\nwould require considerable additional structure for\nstiffness.\nReducing the aspect ratio to 10.2 (8:l ellipse)\nimproved this situation considerably. F-8 compares\nthe stability of strength-designed aluminum and\ngraphite-epoxy wings of aspect ratio 10.2. The\naluminum wing designed, for strength alone still\ndid not satisfy the requirement for aeroelastic\nstability; it would have to be stiffened with more\nmaterial to improve the stability. On the other\nhand, the graphiteepoxy wing designed for\nstrength alone had adequate stability.\nThe advantage of using graphite-epoxy rather\nthan aluminum for construction of an oblique\nwing, and the importance of aspect ratio, can be\nseen in F-9.A graphite-epoxywing satisfying only\nthe strength requirements offers about 2070 weight\nadvantage. Considering the aeroelastic stability\nindicated, the graphite-epoxy should have an even\ngreater advantage over aluminum. Reducing the\naspect ratio of the wing gave lower weight and\nimproved stability. These results, however, should\nnot be considered as the last word since only an\nelliptic planform was included in this study.\nAstronautics & Aeronautics\n\n855\n\n856\n\n4\n\n900\n\n700\n\nF-10 GROSSWEIGHT\nSUMMARY\n\n5\n\nn\n\n500\n\n0\n\na\n0\n\nPAYLOAD = 40.000 LE\nRANGE -30M)NMI\nMACH I1.2\n\n400\n\n300\n\n2\n\n:200\n+\n\n100\n0\n\nF-11 WEIGHT\nCOMPARISON\n\n0\n\nMACH = 1.2\n\nALTITUDE = 40 000 FT\n\nLIFT COEFlClENT = 2 6\n\n4\n4-]\nnnn\n\nc-"\n\nI - -\n\n8.88\n\n9.25\n\n~\n\n12.66\n\n9.44\n\n,030\n\nF-12 CRUISEDRAG\nCOM PARIS0N\n\n,025\nLIFT\n\n857\n\nFurther planform studies considering the\ndistribution of mass and stiffness as well as the\naerodynamic characteristics of the wing would\nseem to be most important.\nMinimum gross weight (F-10) required to\nperform the 3000-n. mi. mission was determined\nfor airplanes based on the five configurational\nconcepts in this study. Additional work established\nthe gross weight penalty for noise reduction.\nSubstantially lower gross weights were required\nfor the delta-wing and single-body, oblique-wing\nconfigurations than for any of the others. The\ndelta-wing configuration had the advantage of a\nlow structural weight and thus a low operating\nempty weight, as shown in F-11. The single-body,\noblique-wing airplane (F-10) had a smaller gross\nweight because of its lesser fuel requirements. It is\ninteresting to note that the structural weight\npenalty of the oblique wing was not primarily\nassociated with the peculiar features of the design\nnor the variable geometry, but rather it was the\nresult of the basic strength requirements of a highaspect-ratio wing.\nThe single-bodyoblique wing has the advantage\nin aerodynamic efficiency, as shown by the cruisedrag comparison in F-12. The effect of the higher\naspect ratio in reducing drag due to lift is quite\nevident for the oblique-wing configurations.\nAnother major difference in drag of the configurations was found to be the wave drag due to\nvolume. The double-pod installation was primarily\nresponsible for the high wave drag on the fixedand variable-sweep-wing configurations. The low\nwave drag of the single-body oblique wing reflects\nthe integrated body-nacelle arrangement and the\ninherent characteristics of the oblique wing.*\nF-13 describes the impact on takeoff gross\nweight of achieving lower noise levels by enginenacelle treatment. The takeoff-gross-weight increase reflects weight added for acoustical\ntreatment and the associated engine-performance\nlosses. Only the oblique-wing configurations could\nachieve a noise level of FAR 36 minus 15EPNdB.\nThis technically orientated study has yielded, we\nbelieve, a realistic performance comparison of the\nfive wing-planform concepts and gives insight into\nareas unique to the oblique-wing configuration.\nThe oblique wing offers desirable performance, but\nfurther analysis and * wind-tunnel work will be\nneeded to develop a rounded picture of its\npotential. In particular, future work should include\nan economic evaluation of the consequences of\noblique wing\xe2\x80\x99s ability to increase today\xe2\x80\x99s cruise\nspeeds 50%.\nIn terms of the transonic concepts it covers, the\nmost significant conclusions of this study might be\nsummarized as follows:\nJanuary 1974\n\n858\n\nF-13 IMPACT OF NOISE TREATMENT ON\nTAKEOFF GROSS-WEIGHT\nRANGE 3wo NMI\nPAYLOAD40 OM LB\nUESIGN M A W 1.2\n\nAIRFRAME NOISE\nMAY BE LIMITINB\n\n400\n\n5\n\n0\n\n5\n10\nTRADE0 NOISE. AEPNdB\n\n15\n\n1. The oblique-wing airplane had the smallest\ngross weight and the lowest fuel consumption.\n2. Only the oblique-wing airplane could achieve\na noise level of FAR 36 minus 15EPNdB.\n3. The oblique wing is aeroelastically less stable\nthan a sweptback wing but more stable than a\nswept-forward wing. For the designs considered, an\naluminum oblique wing would require a moderate\namount of additional stiffness to meet stability\nrequirements. For graphite-epoxy no additional\nstiffness would be required.\n4. Further development studies supported by\nwind-tunnel tests will be needed to develop the full\npotential of the oblique-wing concept. This should\nbe followed by an economic evaluation treating\nproductivity.\nReferences\ne\n1. Jones, R. T., \xe2\x80\x9cNew Design Goals and a N w Shape\nfor the SST,\xe2\x80\x9d Astronautics & Aeronautics, Vol. 10, NO.\n12, Dec. 1972,pp. 66-70.\n2. Jones, R. NASA Contracts NASI-1071, NAS1-1072, NAS11073, \xe2\x80\x9cStudy of the Application of Advanced\nTechnologiesto Long-Range Transport Aircraft\xe2\x80\x9d.\n6. \xe2\x80\x9cAdvanced Composites Design Guide,\xe2\x80\x9d Advanced\nComposites Division, Air Force Material Laboratory, Air\nForce Systems Command, Wright-Patterson Air For\nBase, Ohio, Nov. 1971.\n\nFLIGHT BELOW THE SONIC BOOM SPEED LIMIT\nobert T. Jones\n\n74\n\n859\n\nJones, R. T., "Aircraft Design for Flight Below the Sonic Boom Speed Limit,"\nCanadian Aeronautics and Space Journal, vol. 20, no. 5, May 1974,\npp. 225-230.\nReprinted by permission of the Canadian Aeronautics and Space Institute,\nOttawa, Can.\n\n86 0\n\nReprinted in Canada from CANADIAN AERONAUTICSAND SPACE JOURNAL\n\nAIRCRAFT DESIGN FOR FLIGHT BELOW THE SONIC BOOM SPEED LIMIT?\n\nby Dr. R.T. Jones*\nNASA Ames Research Center\n\nSUMMARY\nThe avoidance of sonic booms places a constraint on aircraft design and can lead to unusual\nnew configurations. From a comparison among\nseveral candidate designs, it is shown that an\noblique winged aircraft offers many advantages\nwhen structure, stability, flight efficiency, and\nairport noise are considered jointly.\nTo avoid the sonic boom, overland flights\nmust be limited to a subsonic ground speed, Le.\napproximately 1200 km per hour. Since the\nspeed of sound a t low levels is normally 160\nkm/hr faster than it is a t flight altitudes the airplane must fly supersonically in its own medium\nin order t o reach this overland speed limit.\nUnder standard conditions the flight Mach number is about 1.15. However, the flight speed for\nconstant ground speed varies considerably with\nmeteorological conditions.\nWith a strong headwind aloft and a high\ntemperature a t ground level the aircraft Mach\nnumber may be as high as 1.3. Under these conditions the wave\'s made by the airplane are refracted by wind and temperature gradients, become vertical and disappear before reaching the\nground (Figure 1). Under other (exceptional)\nconditions even a subsonic airplane might produce a sonic boom. Flying down wind in a fast\njet stream the lifting pressure may be transmitted to a region where the relative velocity is\nsupersonic.\nMore complete analyses of flight conditions\nand schedules at the sonic boom speed limit will\nbe found in References (1)and (2). It appears\nthat east to west flights across the US could be\nshortened by two hours and west to east flights\nby about one hour. Flight a t constant ground\nspeed, of course, tends to equalize schedules in\nall directions.\n?Presented at the Quarter Century Symposium, University of\nToronto,on the 1st April, 1974.\n\n\'Senior Scientist\n\nAn airplane designed for such service\nshould be capable of efficient flight at various\nspeeds from subsonic to supersonic. Unfortunately, flight a t supersonic speed entails some loss\nof aerodynamic efficiency. However, the loss a t\ntransonic and low supersonic speeds need not be\nas great as the loss a t higher supersonic,speeds.\nIt seems possible that the increased utilization of\nthe aircraft and the time saving for the passengers could make up for a moderate increase of\nenergy consumption per mile of flight.\nThe specific range Rsp of an airplane in payload pound-miles per pound of fuel (or kilogramkilometers per kilogram) is given by\n\nRsp = Ro X q X L/D X\n\n..payload\n\n1x1\n\nairplane\n\nHere Ro is the specific range corresponding to\nthe thermal energy content of the fuel - about\n2700 miles or 4400 kilometers for kerosene (Le.\none kilogram of kerosene contains enough energy to exert a force of one kilogram for a distance\nof 4400 kilometers). L/D is the aerodynamic lift\nto drag ratio of the airplane, typically 15 t o 20\nor higher in the subsonic range (below M = 0.8)\nand 7 to 1 0 in the supersonic range. q is the conversion efficiency of thermal energy to thrust.\nWith the development of the fan jet engine it has\nbecome possible to obtain a conversion efficiency q of 40 percent or more over a wide range of\nspeeds - subsonic or supersonic.\nThe quantities displayed in the formula are\nnot, of course, independent. Thus, a loss in aerodynamic L/D such as occurs at supersonic speed\nwill call for a greater fuel load and hence a smaller ratio of payload to gross weight. Similarly,\nmeasures taken to increase the aerodynamic\nefficiency usually result in increased structure\nweight.\nIt is important t o note that the basic equation for energy economy does not contain the\nflight speed directly but only indirectly as it\nmay affect the L/D or other factors. By adjust-\n\nVol. 20, No. 5, May 1974\n\n86 1\n\nTAILWIND\nu_BMNlC DISTURWNCE\nU E R M N I C MSTURBPlNC\xe2\x82\xac\n\nDNlC\nANCE\n\nm\nNO MNlC BOOM\nGROUND SPEED\n\nSONIC BWM\nGROUND SPEED\n\n1200\nkrn/hr\n\n1260 km/hr\n\nFigure 1\nnit below sonic boom speed limits\n\nEFFECTIVE MACH NUMBER\n\nMrorg< I O\n\nFigure 2\nReduetion of effective maeh number by oblique motion\n\nFigare 3\n\nment of altitude and wing loading the subsonic\nairplane can maintain its high lift to drag ratio\na t any speed up to about M = 0 8 Hence, con..\ntrary to a popular opinion, the subsonic airplane\ndoes not have to pay for its speed in terms of\nmiles per gallon. Following the above relations,\ncurrent subsonic jets could get 60 or more passenger miles per gallon, though they have often\noperated profitably in the range 20 to 30 PMPG.\nAt transonic and low supersonic speeds it appears that with suitable design one could a t least\nequal\' or exceed the latter figure.\nThe l s of lift/drag ratio begins a t M = 0.7\nos\nor 0 8 To minimize the loss at higher speeds we\n..\nmust ask what wing shape can give the highest\nlift to drag ratio a t transonic and supersonic\nspeeds? The surprising answer given by aerodynamic theory is that the narrow straight wing\nof high aspect ratio, ideal for low speed flight,\nalready has the right shape for supersonic speeds\nprovided it can be turned so as to move through\nthe air obliquely.\nWith such a long narrow wing moving a t an\noblique angle it is permissible to divide the flight\nvelocity into two components, one showing the\nair movement across the wing and the other\nalong the length of the wing (Figure 2). The\ncomponent of motion along the length of the\nwing has little effect and so the widg behaves as\nthough it were flying a t reduced speed, corresponding to the reduced component of the flight\nvelocity in the direction perpendicular t o the\nleading edge. By increasing the angle as the speed\nis increased the effective component velocity\ncan be kept subsonic, even though the flight\nvelocity is supersonic.\nWhile the theoretical properties of the oblique wing have been known for many years\nReferences (3), (4). (5), it is only recently that\nwe have obtained experimental verification of\nthe theory in the ll-ft. supersonic wind tunnel\na t NASA Ames Research Center6. In these tests\nwe employed rather conventional subsonic wings\nof quasi-elliptic planform, mounted on a slender\nbody (Figure 3). By pivoting the wing on the\nbody and setting it a t different angles of yaw so\nthat the component Mach number remained below 0.7 we were able to demonstrate lifMrag\nratios higher than either the delta wing or the\nbilaterally symmetric swept back wing at all\nspeeds between M = 0.6 and 1.4. Thus, at M =\n-98and 45O yaw w e obtained an L/D of 20 t o 1.\nAt M = 1.4, 6\' of yaw was required and the\n0\nL/D had fallen t o 1 - about 10% greater than\n1\nthat of a comparable swept wing model. At still\nhigher Mach numbers, the relative superiority of\nthe oblique wing over more familiar shapes is expected to diminish further.\nFigure 3a shows the maximum lift/drag\nratios obtained in these tests. The wings were of\nquasi-elliptic planform having an aspect ratio of\n12.7. The results for three different airfoil sections of 10 percent thickness are shown. Airfoil\n1is a conventional NACA "4-digit" shape having\na critical Mach number of . .Airfoil 2 is a newer\n7\ntype designed by Bauer Garabedian and Korn?\nfollowing the suggestion of R.T. Whitcomb. Airfoil 2 was designed for a Mach number of 0.8 and\n\nCanadian Aeronautics and Space J o u m l\n\n86 2\n\nmaintained a liftidrag ratio of 31 a t this Mach\nnumber with the wing unyawed. A t 60" >raw and\nM = 1.2 to 1.4 the highly cambered section No.\n3 was superior, however.\n\nOBLIQUE ELLIPTIC WINGS\nDIFFERENT AIRFOIL SECTIONS\n\n4o\n\nSubsequent studies have shown that the\nwings employed in these tests are somewhat too\n30\nslender to satisfy the requirements of strength\nand aeroelastic stability. By reducing the aspect\nratio to 1 0 and increasing the root thickness to\n12% it appears that the requirements of strength\nand stability can be satisfied with a small loss of U D 2o\n\nL/D.\nThe elliptic planforfn satisfies the condition\nfor minimum drag (Le. wave drag + vortex drag)\nwhen the overall dimensions of the wing are\nlimited. A more appropriate auxiliary condition\nwould be a limitation on the wing root bending\nmoment8. The resulting planform and span loading is then somewhat more tapered than the\nelliptical. The potential gains in this direction\nare now being investigated.\nThe really significant advantage of the oblique wing lies in the ease with which the sweep\nangle can be varied to suit flight conditions.\nThus, during landing, take-off or holding the\nwing should be straight and in this configuration\nthe L/D ratio was approximately 30 to 1 - a\nvalue which could lead to a very low power requlrement and thus minimize the unwanted display of energy in the airport environment.\n\nI\n\n.8\n\nI\n1.o\n\nI\n1.2\n\nI\n1.4\n\nI\n1.6\n\nM\n\nFigure 3a\nOblique elliptic wings differentairfoil sections\n\n-\n\nCan an airplane with its wing a t such an\nangle be stable or control!able in flight? A preliminary answer to this question was given many\nyears ago by J.P. Campbell and Hubert M.\nDrake, who tested an oblique winged model in\nthe NACA Langley Free Flight Tunnel in 19469.\nCampbell and Drake found their model to be\nmore stable against lateral oscillations than highly swept bilaterdly symmetric models. Even\nthough the ailerons on the oblique wing are in a\nposition to produce large pitching moments, n o\npitching motion was observed in flight - the\nailerons producing essentially pure roll. Stability\nand control were satisfactory up to wing angles\nof 50". At 60", however, ailerons became too\nweak for adequate control.\nMore recently the present writer with the\nassistance of Mr. Burnett L. Gadeburg of Ames\nResearch Center has made experiments with\nlarger (6 ft. span) radio-controlled models in free\nflight. In addition to the normal control channels the radio was equipped with an extra channel t o permit variations of wing and horizontal\ntail angle in flight. Figure 4 shows one of the\nmodels in flight with the wing and tail at 45".\nYaw angles greater than 45" were not attempted\nbecause of the speed of the model (50 to 100\nmph) and the difficulty of visual orientation.\nThe results of the free flight tests may be summarized as follows:\ne Changing the wing and horizontal tail\nangle from 0 to 45 in level flight resulted in n o\nperceptible change in longitudinal trim and a\nbarely perceptible change in lateral trim. The\nmodel nosed down and gained speed to compensate for the loss of lift due to yaw.\n\n* Aileron rolls were performed with normal control movements and without appreciable\ncoupled pitching motion - as observed by\nCampbell and Drake.\n* Elevator control w s accompanied by\na\nstrongly coupled rolling motion. U e of the eles\nvator tends to produce a rotation about the long\naxis of the wing - which is oblique - instead of\nabout the normal pitch axis. Loops performed\nby pulling back the elevator took the form of a\nhelix.\ne The coupled rolling motion produced by\nthe elevator results in differing behavior in right\n\nVol. 20, No. 5, May 1974\n\n86 3\n\nPAYLOAD = I S I43 hG I40 WO LUI\nRANGL * 55611hni l3WU NU11\nINITIAL< R U N AlTlTUOl\n\n-\n\n2-2.\n\n32\n.s\n\n1.2*\n\n388283tdS70001\n110726 11\xe2\x80\x99385001\n61221659U1\n\n226796 ISWOW1\n1:13855 1129UOOl\n436 6 147001\n\n280726 16190001\n1468U4 1312600I\n442 2 1476111\n\n21 1828 1467WO1\nI13832 fZSlllGil1\n\n406123 1913001\n\n216184 148600)\n41\n1\n\n226859 ISIOWI\n\n1561131311001\n\n043\n6224 1130)\nS I\nIS54 151001\n\n0 39\nSO75 I1061\n\n2286 11500I\n92\n296 11601\n\n3505 I115001\n\n03\n.3\n622411301\n10 6\n2225 l71U01\n3018 1101001\n\n63\n31711711\n\n261 1141)\n\n+1.8\n\n- 1s.u\n\n+I 4\n\nI3.1\n2.8\n+ 1.1\n\n411\n\n-1u.2\n+ 3.5\n1.9\n+ 1.5\n\n.\n\n89\n3505 I l l S O O l\n\n- u.5\nr1.4\n\n319 6 t344UI\n\n411\n\n2\n\n0 30\n651 2 I1361\n\nI2 3\n2179 171501\n~947196101\n69\n2545l13741\n\n.\n\nFigure 5\nAircraft characteristics and performance\n\nRAMGE\nPAYLOAD\nNOISE\nENGINE\n\nI MACH i . 2\n-REQUIRED\n\n3,000NMI\n40,OOOLB\nFAR 36\nBPRl 0\n\nI\n\nBODY FUEL\n\nFigure 5a\n\nFuel volume comparison\n\nCanadian Aeronautics and Space Journal\n\n864\n\nTAKEOFF GROSS WEiGHT\n( I O O O K G i ( i 0 0 0 LEI)\n\n400 -\n\n.OO\n000 ~\n\n300 -\n\n.1$.\n\n1\n\nPAYLOAD = 18,143KG (40,OOOLB)\nRANGE = 5560 Km 13000NMI)\nMACH= I 2\nPERIPHERAL TREATMENT, (FAR-36)\n\n200I NCLUDl NG\nRESERVES\n\nIOO-\n\n0-\n\nFigure 6\nbeing estimate of gross weights for the five designs\n\nand left turns. Thus, in turning toward the forward wing tip, use of the elevator tends to steepen the bank; for turns in the opposite direction\nthe elevator has the opposite effect.\nWhile unusual control effects were prominent in rapid manoeuvres they were not noticeable in the use of controls to maintain steady\nlevel flight. Hence, the lack of bilateral symmetry though interesting theoretically, may not\nbe important for high altitude cruising flight\nwhere oblique wing angles would be used.\nFollowing our experiments a t Ames Research Center t& Boeing Commercial Aircraft\nCompany has made, under NASA contract, a\ncomparative design study of transonic transport\naircraft intended to operate a t speeds below the\nsonic boom cut-off speed. One of the objectives\nof the study was to determine whether the apparent advantages of the pivoted wing-might be\nrealized in a practical airplane.\n\nFigure 5a. Figure 6 shows the B,oeing estirhate of\ngross weights for the five designs. It is seen that\nthe swept back wing with variable sweep required the highest gross weight for the mission,\nwhile the oblique winged design had the lowest.\nVarying\'the sweep in bilaterally symmetric fashion imposes severe requirements of mechanical\nstreqgth, leading to excessive weight of the wing\npivot structure. In the oblique design the wing\nstructure is continuous across the pivot and very\nlittle additional weight is introduced by the\npivot structure. The analysis did show, however,\nthat the oblique wing would be rather heavy,\nprimarily because of its high aspect ratio. Of all\nthe designs the delta wing configuration gave\nthe smallest empty weight. The oblique-winged\nairplane had a smaller take-off weight, however,\nbecause of its lower fuel consumption. Figure 7\nshows the configuration suggested by the Boeing\nstudy for an oblique-winged transport.\n\nThe study included consideration of four\ndifferent wing designs (Figure 5); (1)sweptback\nwing with fixed geometry, (2) sweptback wing\nwith variable geometry, (3) fixed delta wing and\n(4)pivoted oblique wings. Details and results of\nthe Boeing study will be found in Reference (8).\nProminent in the Boeing analysis were considerations of structural design and weight, including the use of newer composite materials.\nThe oblique wing designs required a new analysis\nof aeroelastic stability as well as the design of a\nsuitable pivoting structure.\nEach airplane was sized to carry 195 passengers for 3000 nautical miles a t a flight Mach\nnumber of 1.2. It was found that this mission\ncould be performed by any one of the five designs but the gross weight and size of the airplane needed varied considerably. A fuel volume\ncomparison for these configurations is made in\n\nFive 7\nConfiguration wyb\';ested by the W g study for an\ni\nn\nObliqumiwpltr~rt\n\nVol. 20, No. 5, May I974\n\n86 5\n\n400\n\n-\n\n900\n\n-\n\nPAYLOAD 18,(43 KG (40,OOOLB)\nDESIGN MACH I 2\nINITIAL CRUISE ALTITUDE CAPABILITY 11,887\'m ( 39,000F T 1\nTAKEOFF FIELD LENGTH 3505171t l l , 5 0 0 F T )\nFOUR ENGINES BPR = I 0\n\n+AIRFRAME N O I S E\n\n800\n350 -TAKEOFF\n\nMAY BE L I M I T I N G\n\nGROSS\nWEIGHT, LB\n\nTAKEOFF\nGROSS\nWEIGHT,\nKG\n\n/\n\n300\n600\n\n-\n\n500\n\n250\n\n-\n\n-\n\n200-\n\nI t seems possible that future restrictions on\nthe noise made by airplanes may become more\nstringent. Figure 8 shows the estimated increases\nin gross weight that would be required to meet\nsuch increasingly stringent noise requirements.\nIt appears from this study that the oblique wing,\nwhich can straighten itself out for landing or\ntakeoff could achieve the lowest noise levels.\nIn summary, the investigations made thus\nfar, which have included considerations of structure, stability, and flight efficiency as well as\nnoise in the airport environment, point to the\noblique winged aircraft as the optimum design\nfor flight approaching the sonic boom speed\nlimit.\nREFERENCES\n\n(1)Haglund, G.T.: A Preliminary Climatology\no f the Threshold Mach Number and Imp&\ncations for Boomless Supersonic Flight.\n4th Conference o n Aerospace Meteorology,\nAmerican Meteorological Society and\nAIAA, Las Vegas, Nevada, May 1970.\n(2) Goodmanson, L.T.: Transonic Transports,\nAstronautics and Aeronautics, Vol. 9, No.\n11, November 1971.\n(3) Jones, R.T.: Theoretical Determination of\nthe Minimum Drag of Airfoils at Supersonic Speeds. a s t i c l i f t . (See Fig. 3)\nA l t e r n a t i v e l y , i f a i l e r o n c o n t r o l i s a p p l i e d t o prevent r o l l t h e\nl i f t d i s t r i b u t i o n produced by t h e a i l e r o n s a l s o t e n d s t o cancel t h e\nI\n\na e r o e l a s t i c l i f t increment.\n\nWith b i l a t e r a l l y symmetric swept forward wings, t h e f r e e motions\nof t h e a i r p l a n e show no such r e l i e v i n g o r s t a b i l i z i n g i n f l u e n c e , but\nr a t h e r aggravate t h e u n s t a b l e tendency of t h e wing.\n\nThus, bending\n\nswept-forward t i p s upward i n c r e a s e s t h e l divergence w i t h t h e f u s e l a g e\n\ne\n\nAILERON CONTROL AND TRIM OF OBLIQUE WING\nAssuming t h e wing i s a e r o e l a s t i c a l l y s t a b l e w e have s t i l l t o\ni n v e s t i g a t i s equipped w i t h conventional a i l e r o n s .\n\nThe r e s u l t s\n\nshown w e r e obtained w i t h t h e wing a t 60\xc2\xb0 yaw.\nThe model w a s c o n s t r u c t e d w i t h an upwardly c t i v e i n producing t o r s i o n i s g r e a t l y reduced by t h e sweep.\nI n conclusion, these r e s u l t s show t h a t a e r o e l a s t i c divergence ,\nwhich i s c h a r a c t e r i s t mass along t h e wing\nspan may be expected.\n\nSUMMARY\nThe a e r o e l a s t i c s t a b i l i t y of an oblique wing i s studied by means\nof a simple model having t h r e e degrees of freedom.\n\nIt is found t h a t\n\nfreedom i n r o l l exerts a s t a b i l i z i n g influence on t h e behavior of t h e\noblique wing s o t h a t a e r o e l a s t i c bending divergence which i s t y p i c a l\nof swept forward wings does n o t occur i n t h e case of t h e oblique wing.\nI n s t a b i l i t y of t h e oblique wing appears i n t h e form of undamped o s c i l l a t i o n s a t a f l i g h t speed which may be considerably g r e a t e r than t h a t f o r\ns t a t i c divergence of a swept forward wing.\n\nS t a b i l i t y i s dependent on\n\nt h e r o l l i n e r t i a of t h e fuselage and on t h e d i s t r i b u t i o n of mass along\nt h e wing.\n\nBending e l a s t i c i t y of t h e wing has l i t t l e e f f e c t on a i l e r o n\n\nc o n t r o l and t r i m of t h e oblique wing provided equal opposite a i l e r o n\nd e f l e c t i o n s are employed.\n\nREFERENCES\n\n1\n.\n\nG r a h a m , Lawrence A.,\n\nJones, Robert T.,\n\nand Boltz, Fredrick W.\n\n"An Jones\n\nAugust 1954\n\n885\n\nI\n\nJones, R. T., "Coma of Modified Gregorian and Cassegrainian Mirror Systems,"\nOptical Society of America, vol. 4 4 , no. 8, Aug. 1954, pp. 630-633.\nReprinted by permission of the Optical Society of America, Washington, D.C.\n\n8 86\n\nReprinted from JOURNAL\nOF ?HE OPTICAL SOCIETY AMERICA, 44, No. 8, 630633, Aumst, 1954\nOF\nVol.\nP i t d in U. S A.\nrne\n.\n\nComa of Modified Gregorian and Cassegrain\n\nMirror Systems\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\nAm- Aeronazlticd Laboratwy, Netional Advisory Committeefor Awmutics, Mofffett Field, Cdifornk\n(Received February 8,1954)\nThe equivalence of the classical Newtonian, Cassegrainian, and Gregorian mirror systems with respect\nto the first two Seidel aberrations is rederived by means of a simple congruence. The ef\xe2\x82\xacects of arbitrary\nsmall modiiications of the two-mirror systems are then studied and general formulas are derived for the\neffects of such modificationson the spherical aberration and coma. Spherical aberration is corrected to the\nthird ordsr if the amount of glass removed from one surface is replaced at the corresponding zone of the\nother surface (approximate expression of Fermat\xe2\x80\x99s principle). Modifications i which one surface is made\nn\nspherical while the other is adjusted to eliminate spherical aberration result in large increases of coma for\nsystems having the usual ampliiying ratios.\n\nN the standard forms of the Cassegrainiin and\nGregorian telescopes the curves of the primary and\nsecondary mirrors are confocal conic sections, so that,\ninsofar as geometrical optics is concerned, rays parallel\nto the axis of the system will be brought to a perfect\nfocus at the axial image point. There remains, however,\na slight variation in the equivalent focal length of the\nvarious rays throughout the aperture of the instrument,\nso that the magnification is greater for the outer zones\nof the aperture than for the central part. Such a variation also appears in the Newtonian telescope, with a\nsingle parabolic reflector, and produces the aberration\nknown as \xe2\x80\x9ccoma.\xe2\x80\x9d\nIt was shown by A. C. Lunnl that in any combination\nof mirrors having confocal conic sections, the zonal\nmagnification error will be exactly the same as that of\na single parabolic reflector having the equivalent focal\nlength of the compound system. Since the magnification\nerror of a long-focus paraboloid is slight, and furthermore diminishes with the inverse square of the focal\nratio, it follows that the comatic aberration in the conventional Cassegrainianor Gregorianforms is ordinarily\nextremely small.\nPractical experience has shown, however, that the\nexcellence of the calculated properties of these compound-mirror systems is difEcult to achieve in actual\nconstruction. To overcome these dficulties several\nmodifications of the standard Cassegrainian and Gregorian forms have been proposed. Perhaps the best\nknown of these is the construction employed by Dall\nand Kirkham? Here the secondary is made spherical\nand the spherical aberration is corrected by modifying\nthe primary. Descriptions of this and other possible\nmodifications have been given by Allyn J. Thompsonx\nand quoted by Albert G. Ingalls! Recently Yoder,\nPatrick, and Gee6have presented calculations of all the\nthid-order aberrations for an example of the DallKrkham type.\nThe present paper extends the previous discussions\n\nby giving general formulas for the effects of various\nmodifications on the coma of two-mirror systems. The\nformulas are based, of course, on geometrical optics and\nare limited to small apertures such that the fdth and\nhigher powers of the aperture ratio are negligible.\nWithin this limitation they agree with the formulas\ngiven by Schwarzschild for the aplanatic case (zero\ncoma), but show in addition the effects of departures\nfrom aplanatism while maintainiig \xe2\x80\x98zero spherical\naberration.\nConsider frst the unmodified Cassegrainian with a\nparabolic primary mirror p and a hyperbolic secondary\nmirror s (see Fig. 1).Denoting the paraxial equivalent\nfocal length by Fo, the \xe2\x80\x9coblique focal lengths\xe2\x80\x9d Fy= fp\xe2\x80\x99 of\nthe zones y may be found by extending the rays from\nthe focal point f straight through the secondary mirror\nand noting the intersections p\xe2\x80\x98 of these rays with the\nincoming parallel rays. The AbbC sine condition will be\nsatisfied if the intersectionpoints lie on a spherecentered\nand\nat f. In this case the oblique focal lengths Fy, hence\nthe magnification, would be constant for all zones.\nHowever, it is easily verified that in the case of the\nCassegrainian this intersection surface is not a sphere,\nbut is a paraboloid having a focal length equal to Fo.\nReferring again to Fig. 1, consider the conjugate reflecting system formed on the reversed side of the\nsecondary by the extended.rays together with the rays\nextended from the primary toward its focal point f.\nDenoting by A the amplification of the original system,\nit is seen that the concave side of the hyperboloid forms\nthe secondary of a conjugate Cassegrainian system\nhaving the amplification 1/A, and having its focal point\n\nA. C. Lunn, Astrophys. J. 27,280-285 (1908).\n\n* Alan R. Kirkham, Sci. American 158, No.6,374 (1938).\n\nAllyn J Thompson, Sky and Telescope (May, 1948, et sq)\n.\ne..\nAlbert G Ingalls, Sci. American (June, 1933, et sq)\n.\ne..\nSYoder, Patrick, and Gee, J. Opt. SOC. 43, 1200 (1953).\nAm.\n\n8\n\nFIG.l.-Congruenceof rays in the Cawgrainian and the\nrays from a reversed parabolic reflector.\n\n8 87\n\nR O B E R T T. J O N E S\n\nVol. 44\n\nat f\xe2\x80\x99. The surface p\xe2\x80\x99 may be considered the primary of\nthis system if the incoming parallel rays are reversed.\nHowever, the only primary surface that will produce a\nfocus at f\xe2\x80\x99 after reflection a t the hyperboloid s is a\n\xe2\x80\x98\nparaboloid. It follows that the Abbe surface p\xe2\x80\x99 is a\nparaboloid having its focus a t f. A similar construction\n(Fig. 2), but with the paraboloidal surface p\xe2\x80\x99 located\nbehind the primary, is available in the case of the\nGregorian form. Thus in each of these cases the rays in\nthe vicinity of the focal point may be brought into\ncongruence with the rays from a simple parabolic reflector having the same equivalent focal length. The\nNewtonian, the Gregorian, and the Cassegrainian are\nthus all equivalent as far as coma is concerned.\nAX, = AX,\nAs was shown by A. C. Lunnl thii equivalence holds\nFIG. For values of A less than\n1.0 the secondary is concave and with certain proportions approaches a spherical shape.\nIn the construction employed by Dall and =&am2\nthe amplifying ratio is greater than one (convex\nsecondary) and the secondary is made spherical for ease\nof construction and adjustment. COX\n\nA WIDE-FIELD TELESCOPE WITH SPHERICAL OPTICS\n\nU t i l i z i n g a doublet l e n s t o c o r r e c t t h e a b e r r a t i o n s of a s p h e r i c a l m i r r o r ,\nt b writer has designed and constructed a small f / 8 telescope f o r v i s u a l use.\nThe l e n s h a s considerable negative power, so t h a t i t serves as a Barlow lens\nas w e l l as a corrector.\nThe l e n s is 2" i n diameter, placed 6" i n s i d e t h e mirror\'s normal f o c a l\npoint. Administration\nA e Research Center\nms\nMoffett Field, Calif.\n\n905\n\nthese p r i n c i p l e s t h e Russian s c i e n t i s t s have evidently developed t h e\nl a r g e s t rocket boosters.\n\nMilitary pressures from t h e s i d e s have undoubtedly\n\nprovided some i n s p i r a t i o n t o them i n t h i s task.\nLooking toward improvement of t h e rocket, w e seek means f o r\nA t t h e present t i m e acceleration\n\nincreasing t h e v e l o c i t y of t h e exhaust.\n\nof t h e exhaust by electromagnetic forces i s being studied extensively.\nThe ion rocket and t h e plasma rocket u t i l i z e such f o r c e s .\n\nThe photon\n\nrocket, which propels i t s e l f simply by expelling electromagnetic f i e l d\nenergy has been the subject of much speculation.\nvelocity i s equal t o t h e v e l o c i t y of l i g h t .\n\nHere t h e exhaust\n\nI t i s a w e l l founded\n\nt r a d i t i o n o f p h y s i c i s t s t h a t a body alone i n empty space cannot change\nthe p o s i t i o n of i t s center of gravity.\n\nWith t h e photon rocket t h i s\n\nt r a d i t i o n is preserved i n an unusual way through t h e equivalent weight\nof t h e expelled energy.\n\nThe t h r u s t developed by t h e photon rocket is\n\nhowever disappointingly small.\nPresent day technology contains many h i n t s and clues regarding\npropulsive devices beyond t h e rocket.\n\nTo go i n t o t h e p o s s i b i l i t i e s\n\ne\nhere would be, f o r m a t l e a s t , a reckless venture.\n\nW may however\ne\n\na r r i v e a t some i n t e r e s t i n g conclusions i f w e suppose t h a t t h e invention\nof such devices succeeds absolutely\n\n- so\n\nt h a t w e have available a t h r u s t\n\nof comfortable magnitude f o r as long a period as required.\n\nSeveral years\n\nago, following t h i s thought, I published calculations of t h e times\nrequired t o travel t o various p l a n e t s of t h e s o l a r system a t an acceleration\nof 1 g.\n\nThe human organism i s known t o survive upwards of 70 years under\n\nt h i s acceleration, but only 36 hours are required t o get t o Venus.\n\nA\n\nr e c t i l i n e a r acceleration of 1 g i n free space produces a v e l o c i t y of\nt h e order of t h e v e l o c i t y of l i g h t i n one year (32 ft/sec2\n\n1 light\n\nyear/year 2). Survival at such cosmic ray v e l o c i t i e s does indeed raise\nquestions far beyond our present experience.\nF i n a l l y I would l i k e t o mention one experiment which seems t o me\nt h e most e x c i t i n g and perhaps t h e most portentous experiment our scientists\nhave performed t o date.\n\nTo understand t h i s experiment w e must go back t o\n\nt h e development of t h e theory of e a r t h \' s aurora by Stormer, Alfven and\nPoincarg i n t h e e a r l y 1900\'s.\n\nI n one experiment, performed i n 1896,\n\nBirkeland made a small magnetized i r o n model of- t h e e a r t h .\n\nSuspending\n\nt h i s magnetic "earth" i n a primitive cathode ray tube and exposing it t o\n\na stream of e l e c t r o n s , supposed similar t o those emanating from t h e sun,\nhe observed bands of r a d i a t i o n which, as you w i l l s e e from h i s i l l u s t r a t i o n ,\n\nare s t r i k i n g l y similar t o those discovered around t h e r e a l e a r t h r e c e n t l y\nby James A. Van Allen.\n\nAbout t h e time of Van Allen\'s discovery a number\n\nof our l o c a l s c i e n t i s t s were engaged i n carrying out an experiment\n\nsimilar t o , b u t much bolder than Birkeland\'s\nChristofolos.\n\n-\n\nsuggested by N. C.\n\nI n Christofolos\' experiment a s h e l l of r e l a t i v i s t i c\n\ne l e c t r o n s was created enclosing t h e e a r t h along a surface defined by i t s\nmagnetic f i e l d .\n\nI t w a s found necessary t o impose a l i m i t a t i o n on t h e\n\nnumber o f e l e c t r o n s i n j e c t e d i n t o the magnetic shell t o ensure t h a t no\nr a d i a t i o n hazard would be produced.\n\nThe experiment d i d however produce\n\na r t i f i c i a l auroras a t p o i n t s separated by thousands of miles over t h e\nearth\n\ne\n\nThis a b i l i t y on t h e p a r t of t h e s c i e n t i s t s t o create conditions\nwhich involve an i n t e r a c t i o n with t h e whole e a r t h as a planet w i l l c l e a r l y\n907\n\nc a l l f o r increasing a t t e n t i o n on the p a r t of n a t i o n a l leaders.\n\nW can\ne\n\nhardly suppose t h a t our p a s t disputes w i l l be resolved by these new\nthings, but it may become necessary t o neglect some of them\n\n- particularly\n\nthose t h a t have already begun t o appear somewhat conventional. Thus\nprogress i s accompanied n o t s o o f t e n by t h e s o l u t i o n of old problems as\nby t h e i r replacement with new ones.\n\n908\n\n909\n\n910\n\n912\n\n913\n\n915\n\n916\n\nWIDE ANGLE LENSES WITH ASPHERIC CORRECTING SURFACES\nRobert T. Jones\nAvco-Everett Research Laboratory\n\nNovember 1966\n\n917\n\nJones , R. T., "Wide Angle Lenses with Aspheric Correcting Surfaces,I1 Applied\nOptics, vol. 5, no. 11, Nov. 1966, pp. 1846-1849. 0 1966.\nReprinted by permission of the Optical Society of America, Washington, D.C.\n\n918\n\nReprinted from APPLIED OpTICS, Vol. S..Page 1846. Noyember 1966\nCopyright 1966 by the Optical Society of Amenca and reprinted by permission of the copyright owner\n\nngle Lenses with\n\nurfaces\n\nRobert T. Jones\n\nRefracting elements having aspheric correctingsurfaca near the center of curv&ure are analyzed. As in\nthe case of the Schmidt reflector, such systems can have a wide aperture and a wide field of view; in\naddition, they are free from obstructing surfaces. Being uncorrected for $spexsion, however, the refracting systems are restricted to nearly monochromatic radiation. Typical forms o the correcting surfaces\nf\nhave been determined, both by third-order theory and by numerim1integmtion of exact equations.\n\n1. Introduction\nIn La Gemtriel, Descartes shows how lens surfaces\nmay be shaped to achieve axial stigmatism. The curves\ndevised by Descartes for this purpose have since become known as Cartesian Ovals. Later, Huygens2\nshowed how the rear surface of a lens could be shaped\nto correct the spherical aberration o preceding surfaces.\nf\nThese measures, of course, leave uncorrected oblique\naberrations such as coma and astigmatism. In 1930,\nBernhard Schmidt pointed out that the oblique aberrations of a sphericalmirror could be eliminated by placing\na stop at the center of curvature of the mirror. Since\nthe central ray o a pencil always meets the mirror at\nf\nperpendicular incidence, there are, in effect, no oblique\nrays in such an arrangement. Spherical aberration is\nthen corrected by placing a thin aspheric lens at the\nstop. The correcting lens, o course, introduces oblique\nf\naberratioljs of its own, but since it has only enough\npower to correct the spherical aberration of the mirror,\nthese are reduced to small values.\nSuch a principle, utilizing the symmetry o the sphere\nf\nand with correction at the center o curvature, may be\nf\nadapted to refracting elements as well as to the reflector. Though restricted to monochromatic radiation, such refracting systems have advantages in certain applications.\nFigure 1 shows two dioptric systems of this nature.\nIn Fig. l(a), the thickness of the lens is equal to the\nradius of the rear surface, and the aspheric correction\ntogether with the stop are placed at the front surface.\nThe image is formed in air on a surface whose radius\nis equal to the distance between an axial image point\nand the stop.\nThe author is with Avco Everett Research Laboratory, Everett, Massachusetts 02149.\nReceivqd 8 June 1966.\nThis work was supported by U S Air Force under a contract.\n..\n\nII. Type A Lens\nAn approximate form for the correcting surface in\nFig. l(a)* may be obtained by computing the optical\npath difference between the spherical rear surface and\nan appropriate Cartesian oval. The Cartesian oval\nfor stigmatie. refraction of parallel rays at the rear surface is an hyperboloid of eccentricity\xe2\x80\x99n(n = index of\nrefraction). Expanding the equation of this surface in\nterms of the vertex radius r , one obtains\n5\n\n= a\n\n+ (y*/2r) - [y4/(2r)a](n* - 1)+ .. .,\n\n(1)\n\nwhile for the sphere\nz=a\n\n+ ( ~ * / 2 r )+ I Y ~ / ( ~ ~ ) ~ I .\n\n(2)\n\nThe differencein optical path is then\nA2 = -nl\n\n[y\xe2\x80\x98/(2r)\xe2\x80\x9d,\n\n(3)\n\nand this is the equation of the front sulfate, to the\naccuracy of third-order theory. Somewhat better correction can be obtained if this fourth degree curve is\ncombined with a second degree curve in order to bring\nthe slope of the correcting surface to zero at some\nspecified zone y,,, of the,lens. In this case, we would\nhave\n=\n\n[ ( 2 n z ~ , e ~ s ) / ( 2 r ) l n*[y4/(2r)*l\n-\n\n(4)\n\n, The foregoing relations, determined by third-order\n\ntheory, will not be sufficiently accurate for lenses of\nwide aperture. Therefore, we have programmed the\nexact determination o the shape of the correcting surf\nface on the Avco Everett Research Laboratory IBM\n\n* The lens design shown in Fig. l(a) has b\npendently by R. Gelles in a paper presented\nb\n7.\nmeeting of t OpticalSocietyof America (paper WH 1 ) Gelles\xe2\x80\x99\nreport (as yet unpublished) &ea fieid a b e h d o n e w e s determined by geometricmy t r a m $n,ndsuggests an ihtereatihg application of the Schmidt principle in a spectroscope.\n\n1846 APPLIED OPTICS 1 Vol. 5, No. 11 1 November 1966\n\n919\n\nHowever, the spherical aberration of the refractor i\ns\nmuch greater than that of the reflector, so the power of\nthe correcting surface required may no longer be\nnegligible. Thus, in Fig. 2, the curvature of the correcting surface exceeds that of the main refracting surface for values of y > 0.47. I the aperture i dowed\nf\ns\nto exceed this value, one would expect the astigmatism\nassociated with these zones to be as great as that of a\nsimple uncorrected lens.\n\n111. Figure 2 and Table I give a typical\nresult of these calculations.\nWith wide apertures and small field angles, the most\nserious oblique aberration will be coma. In the absence\nof spherical aberration, the extreme Gidth of the coma\npatch for a field angle /3 is given by 6 = 38 If(y) -f(O) 1.\nHere y is the semi-aperture, f(0) is the paraxial focal\nlength, and f(y) is the focal length of the zone y obtained by producing the incoming parallel ray to its\nintersection with the converging ray (see Fig. 2). The\ndiEerencef(y) -f(0)is a measure of the departure from\nthe sine condition.\nFigure 2 shows the calculated departures from the\nsine condition for thelens shape of Fig. l(a). It is noted\nthat the sine condition holds to a high degree of accuracy\nfor apertures considerably greater than those accessible\nto third-order theory. Appreciable departures do not\noccur until value of y >0.6.\nWith coma eliminated, there remains an aberration\nproportional to the square of the field angle j Follow3\n.\ning an analysis by Caratheodorya, it is found that this\naberration depends on the slope and curvature of the\ncorrecting surface and, at a given zone y, is identical\nwith the ordinary astigmatism of an equivalent simple\nlens.\nIn the case of the Schmidt reflector, the local power\nof the correcting surface is ordinarily quite small, and\nthe higher order astigmatism is u s d y negligible.\n\nIn addition to the shapes illustrated in the first\nfigure, one might also consider a lens in which the main\nrefraction occurs at the front surface and with the rear\nsurface figured, but nearly flat. Such a surface, however, lacks the essential properties of the correcting\nlens since rather large oblique aberrations arise in the\nconverging rays. Figure 3 shows the third-order\nastigmatism for several arrangements. In Fig. 3(a),\nthe rear lens surface is flat; if is to be noted that the\nsagittal and tangential focal surfaces curve rather\nshrply toward the lens. Such curvature cannot be\navoided by aspheric figuring.\nComa and astigmatism can be avoided by a suitable\ncurvature of the rear lens surfhce, however. The\ntheory gives r2 = rJn/(n2 - l)]. For theusual values\nof n, the second surface has considerable negative\npower, so the resultant power of the lens is rather small.\nFigure 3(c) corresponds to Fig. 1(a); in this case, both\nthird-order astigmatism and coma vanish.\nAs is well knowna.4 aspheric shapes can be found\nfor two refracting surfaces that will eliminate both\nspherical aberration and coma. A free parameter in\nsuch shapes is the thickness of the lens. By selecting\nthicknesses approximately equal to the radius of one of\nthe surfaces, we obtain forms for these aplanatic lenses\napproximatingthe forms illustrated in Fig. 3. Astigmatism will not be corrected, however, unless the rear surface has considerable negative\npower, as in Fig. 3(b).\nSince the m i refracting surfaces in Fig. 4 are apan\nproximately spherical, it is of interest to determine the\nmagnitude of the error in the sine condition that would\nbe introduced by making the first surface exactly\nspherical. Figure 5 shows such a Huygens lens compared with a neighboring, perfectly aplanatic lens.\nThe small change in shape results in a surprisingly large\ndeparture from the sine condition. Furthermore,\nif the E and E surfaces are nearly parallel, the higher\n\'\norder aberrations i n t r o d u d by them wiU be quite\nsmall. I the Z and E curves actually do satisfy t i\nf\n\'\nhs\nlatter condition, it will not be essential to make both\ncurves aspheric. One curve (E, for instance) can be\nmade spherical, and the small difference in optical path\nlength can be transferred to the other surface.\nFollowing this latter thought, we have made cal\'\nculations for the shape of the 2 surface on the assumption that E has a spherioal shape generally similar to\nthat of the aplanatic curve. Figure 7 and Table I1\nshow one of the shapes determined in such a way for a\nfocal length of 1.2 times the radius of the sphere. Also\nshown are the slight departures from the sine condition\nf(v) - f(0). Here the transfer of elements of the\noptical path has occurred over a small distance separating the E and 8\' surfaces. with the result that the\n\nsine condition is hardly disturbed. It is noted that the\nexample provides a high degree of correction up to an\naperture of f/O.SS.\nThe author would like to acknowledge the msistance\nn\nof J. D.
