Jones\nAmes Research Laboratory\n\nNovember 195 5\n\n923\n\nJones, R. T . , "Times for I n t e r p l a n e t a r y Trips."\nReprinted by permission *om Jet Propulsion, v. 26, no. 2 , February\npage 102.\n\n924\n\n1956,\n\nTimes for Interplanetary Trips\nROBERT T. JONES1\nA r n e Laboratory, NACA, Palo Alto, Calif.\n\nTHE\n\nwriter found it interesting to calculate the times required to travel to the various planets at an acceleration\nof one \xe2\x80\x9cg,\xe2\x80\x9d or 8 X lo4mph/h:\nOf course, with a thrust of such comfortable magnitude one\ncan neglect surrounding gravitational \xe2\x80\x98 fields except for a\nrelatively short distance near take-off or landing. The\n\xe2\x80\x9corbit\xe2\x80\x9d consists of an essentially straight l i e with the thrust\ndirected toward the destination up to the halfway point, but\nin the opposite direction for the remainder so that the velocity\nis zero on arrival.\nThe following table lists the approximate times required,\nand also the maximum velocities acquired in light units V / C .\nt,\n\nMercury\nVenus\nMars\nJupiter\nSaturn\nUranus\nNeptune\nPluto\n\nin days\n2.25\n1.51\n2.08\n5.88\n8.37\n12.07\n15-45\n17.80\n\nv/c\n\n0.0032\n0.0021\n0.0029\n0.0083\n0.0118\n0.017\n0.022\n0.025\n\nIn spite of the small values of v / c the energy expended is\ncertainly large by present standards. Nevertheless, it is\ninteresting to see how quickly even \xe2\x80\x9castronomical\xe2\x80\x9d distances\nsuccumb to the application of a thrust force of such a reasona-,\nble magnitude.\nReceived Nov. 14,1955.\n1\n\nSenior Aeronautical Scientist.\n\n925\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nEXTENDING THE LORENTZ TRANSFORMATION\nBY CHARACTERISTICCOORDINATES\nRobert T. Jones\nAmes Research Center\n\nFebruary 1960\n\n927\n\nJones, R. T., "Extending the Lorentz Transformation by Characteristic Coordinates," American Journal of Physics, vol. 28, no. 2, Feb. 1960,\npp. 109-111. @ 1960 held by the American Association of Physics Teachers.\nReprinted by permission of the American Journal of Physics, New York, N.Y.\n\n928\n\nReprinted from\n\nAMERICAN\nJOURNAL\n\nOF\n\nPHYSICS, 28, No. 2, 109-111, February, 1960\nVol.\n\nPrinted in U. S h\n.\n\nExtending the Lorentz Transformation by Characteristic Coordinates\nROBERT JONES*\nT.\nN a t i d A ~ r ~ ? ~ ~and iS s EAdministration, Ames Research Center, Moffett Field, CaZiforniO\nut t F\n(Received May 28, 1959)\nThe problem considered is that of rectilinear motion with variable velocity. The paper gives,\nby an elementary construction, a system of coordinates which is conformal in a restricted\nregion near the axis of the motion. In such coordinates the velocity of light remains invariant\nf\neven for observers moving with variable velocity. By a particular choice o the scale relation\nthe restricted conformal transformations can be made to reduce to the Lorentz transformation\nf\nf\neverywhere in the case o constant velocity and locally in the case o variable velocity.\n\nN the American Journal of Physics, November,\n1958, Leffert and Donahue call attention to\nirregularities that appear when the Lorentz\ntransformation is extended to problems of\nvariable motion. Figure 1illustrates the difficulty\nalluded to. Here the moving origin of a system\nB is plotted as a curvilinear world line on a\nrectangular system which is not shown, but\nwhich we may designate as A. In such a diagram\n\xe2\x80\x99\nthe lines t = constant associated with B are\noblique and if they are continued as straight\nlines they will cross, leading to a nonuniform\ncorrespondence of events between the A and B\nsystems. This lack of uniformity appears in the\nconventional treatments of the problem, as, for\nexample, in the analysis given by MZl1er.I\nA uniform correspondence can be achieved,\nhowever, if the Lorentz transformation is extended by means of characteristic lines, rather\n\nI\n\n* Aeronautical Research Scientist.\n\nC. Mgler, The Theory of Relativiiy (Clarendon Press,\n\nOxford, 1952), pp. 258-263.\n\n\xe2\x80\x99\nthan along straight t lines. An extension along\nstraight t lines amounts to the assumption that\n\xe2\x80\x99\nthe Lorentz transformation propagates instantaneously in the B system and at the electro:\nmagnetic phase velocity c2/v in the A system.\nThe characteristic lines, however, have the same\nslope in either system, and of course propagate\nat the velocity of light. The use of the characteristic lines establishes a conformal correspondence between the two systems x , it and\nx\xe2\x80\x99, i. As is well known, such transformations\nt\n\xe2\x80\x98\npreserve a constant velocity of light during\naccelerated motions, even in three-dimensional\nspace, if they can be established.2Sa This note\nshows how such coordinates can be established\nin the vicinity of the line of motion for a system\nwith variable rectilinear velocity.\nFigure 2 shows the curvilinear coordinates\nobtained in the xt plane when the Lorentz\nSH. Bateman, Electrical and Optical Wave Hotion\n(Dover Publications, New York, 1955), S14.\n* L. Infeld and A. Schild, Phys. Rev. 26.250-272 (1945).\n\n929\n\nR O B E R T T. Y.\n\n940\n\nReprinted from AMERICAN\nJOURNAL OF PHYSICS, 29, No. 2 124-125, February, 1961\nVol.\n,\nprinted in U S A.\n. .\n\nConformal Coordinates Associated with\nUniformly Accelerated Motion\n.\nROBERT . JONES\nT\nNational Aeronautics and Sflace Administration, Amcs\nResearch Center. Moffe:t Field, California\n\nISCUSSION of specific problems in the theory of\nrelativity is often simplified b y a n appropriate choice\nof the coordinate system. Thus the restricted conformal\ncoordinates described in a previous communication\xe2\x80\x99 provide\na n especially simple analysis of motion with uniform acceleration, known as \xe2\x80\x9chyperbolic motion\xe2\x80\x9d.%\nt\nConformal coordinates x\xe2\x80\x98, \xe2\x80\x98 may be obtained from\nCartesian coordinates x , t by the tramformation\nx\xe2\x80\x99 +ct\xe2\x80\x99 = F(x +ct)\n\nx\xe2\x80\x98-G~\xe2\x80\x99=G(x-G~),\n(1)\nwhere G is the velocity of light. A variable motion of the x\xe2\x80\x98\nsystem will be determined by the choice of the functions\nF a n d G. However, since a function remains constant whenever its argument is constant, light signals have the same\nvelocity c in both x and x\xe2\x80\x99 systems.\nThe scale factor of the transformation is given by the\nproduct fg, where f and g are the ordinary derivatives of\nF and G. The line x\xe2\x80\x99=O may be taken as the world line of\na particle. To satisfy the principle of relativity in the\nvicinity of this particle, we impose the boundary condition,\n\nf g = l along x\xe2\x80\x98=O.\n(2)\nWith this boundary condition, the functions F and G are\ndetermined so that both the transformation and its inverse\nhave the same scale along x\xe2\x80\x98 =O.\nAs a n example, try\n\n=log (x+ct)\nx\xe2\x80\x99 -ct\xe2\x80\x98 =log (x -d).\nX\xe2\x80\x99+Ct\xe2\x80\x99\n\nBy addition]\n2x\xe2\x80\x99=Iog(x%--G2t2).\nThe world line x\xe2\x80\x99=O is then given by the hyperbola\n\nxz -\n\nC2F = 1.\n\nAfter differentiating Eqs. (3), we obtain\nfg =1/ ( x 2 - 8 F )\n\n(3)\n\nwhich has the value 1 along x\xe2\x80\x98=O. Equations (3) thus\nyields the conformal coordinates associated with uniformly\naccelerated motion. The acceleration here has the value\none light-year/year,2 or approximately one \xe2\x80\x9cg\xe2\x80\x9d ; however,\nthe formula is easily generalized.\nI t is interesting t o note that the gravitaFiona1 field in the\n~ \xe2\x80\x98 tsystem is singular at the origin of the xt system. Such\n\xe2\x80\x98\nsingularities \xe2\x80\x99arise when simple analytic formulas are\nemployed. In the present case, the singularity disappears\nif the acceleration is not continued for a n infinite time.\nAs is well known, conformal transformations in Euclidean\nspace are carried out with the aid of functions of a single\ncomplex variable. Such a conformal map may represent the\nstreamlines and equipotential lines of a fluid motion. On\nusing the customary Q and $ for the potential function\nand the stream function, we may write\n\nc\n\n++=F(x +iYh\n\nThe complex potential for a vortex is given by\np+i$ =i log (x+iy).\n\nThis formula is clearly anaiogous to our Eq. (3) for hyperbolic motion. Thus the conformal coordinates associated\nwith hyperbolic motion in Minkowski space become the\ncircular paths of a vortex motion in Euclidean space.\nNow the vortex motion is merely the simplest example\nof a wider class of fluid motions known as \xe2\x80\x9cfree streamline\nflows\xe2\x80\x9d. The boundary condition of such flows is that the\nscale factor of the mapping reduce to unity along a (free)\nstreamline $ =O. This condition is clearly analogous to our\ncondition fg= 1, along x\xe2\x80\x98=O. Thus, every free streamline\nmay be transformed into a n analytic world line with its\nassociated conformal coordinates. The converse is not true,\nhowever, since the possibilities in Euclidean space are\nlimited to analytic functions of a single (complex) variable.\nT Jones, Am. J. Phys. 28, 109 (1960).\n.\nW. Piuli, Theory of Relativity (Pergamon Press. New York, 1958)\n\n1 Robert\n]\n\n2\n\n941\n\nPage intentionally left blank\n\nCONFORMAL COORDINATESASSOCIATED WITH SPACE-LIKE MOTIONS\nRobert T. Jones\nAmes Research Center\n\nJanuary 1963\n\n943\n\nJones, R. T., "Conformal Coordinates Associated with Space-Like Motions,"\nFranklin Institute. Journal, vol. 275, no. 1, Jan. 1963, pp. 1-12.\n@ 1963.\nReprinted by permission of the Franklin Institute, Philadelphia, Pa.\n\n944\n\nJournal\nThe Franklin Institute\nof\n\nDevoted to Science and the Mechanic Arts\nVOl. 275\n\nJANUARY, 1963\n\nNo. 1\n\nCONFORMAL COORDINATES ASSOCIATED\nWITH SPACE-LIKE MOTIONS\nBY\n\nROBERT T JONES\n.\nABSTRACT\n\nConformal transformations in two dimensions provide a simple extension of the Lorentz\ntransformation. The velocity of light appears in such transformations as a singular velocity\nrather than as an upper limit for the velocity. A well-ordered branch of the theory exists\nfor velocities in excess of the velocity of light.\nIf the velocity of a point exceeds the singular velocity in an inertial pystem, then the\nconformal representation of the motion is no longer uniform, but contains a folded region.\nHowever, the branching of the transformation may be determined so that the elapsed time\nalong the path of such a motion remains positive.\nKinematic relations on the other side of the singular velocity seem to complement the\nusual results of relativity theory in an interesting way. Thus it is known that motion at\nthe speed of light occurs along a null geodesic, and\'hence corresponds in a certain sense\nto motion at infinite velocity (that is, in the sense of proper time elapsed). The complementary relation is that a motion of infinite velocity corresponds in the same sense to motion\nat the speed of light.\nINTRODUCTION\n\nIn the world of the physicist everything moves, but always at speeds\nless than the speed of light. The astronomer\'s world, too, is filled with\nmoving objects, moving at u < c. In the world of the mathematician, however, anything is possible, provided only that it is a consequence of something else.\nStrangely enough, writers on physics would like to refer the nonexistence\nof velocities greater than light to a mathematical demonstration-connecting it with the transition of the Lorentz factor 1/ dl - u2/c2 to imaginary values, or to a supposed continuity of the conformal scale factor. It is\n\'Research Scientist, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Ames Research Center,\nMoffett Field, Calif.\n(Note-%\n\nFranklin institute i not rrsponsible for the statements and opinions a d v d by mntributom i the JOURNAL)\ns\nn\n\n945\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\nU.F.I.\n\nknown, however, in the theory of Cerenkov radiation and also in supersonic\naerodynamics that the wave equation remains invariant under transformations having the factor l / d F l for velocities u in excess of the characteristic velocity c.\nSeveral years ago N. Rosen\npointed out that different theories of\nrelativity could be formulated for media having different dielectric properties. For an observer whose experience is confined to such a medium, the\nretarded velocity of light c\xe2\x80\x99 = c/n appears again as a limit for the velocity\nto which a body can be accelerated by electrodynamic action. As Rosen\npointed out, a particle might, however, enter such a region with a velocity\ninexcess of c\xe2\x80\x99 (as in the phenomenon of Cerenkov radiation) and its behavior could not be accounted for by such a theory.\nA theory for particles travelling faster than light may thus be viewed\nsimply as a mathematical formality, or it might be considered a physical\ntheory for the inhabitants of Rosen\xe2\x80\x99s c\xe2\x80\x99 land. There is one additional point,\nhowever, and this refers to the elements of idealization in the classical\ntheory. As is well known, relativistic dynamics depends on the linearity of\nthe wave equation and on the assumption of point particles. These aasumptions are enough to lead to infinite field energy, and in the aerodynamic analogue they are just sufficient to give the sonic barrier an infinite\nrigidity.\nIf one of the foregoing points of view is adopted, then it becomes of\ninterest to investigate kinematic relations on the other side of the singular\nvelocity u = c. Following a conventional terminology, such motions, with\nvelocity u > c, may be termed \xe2\x80\x9cspace-like.\xe2\x80\x9d\nFor the investigation of space-like motions we restrict ourselves first of\nall to purely kinematic relations, and we adopt the simplest possible mathematical model, namely, conformal coordinates and their transformations\nin two dimensions x, t.\nCONFORMAL TRANSFORMATIONS IN TWO DIMENSIONS\n\nIn conformal coordinates the velocity of light remains constant for all\nexperimenters, whether moving or fixed. The invariance here is not merely\na local relation, but holds also for finite displacements. Thus it has been\nshown (2) that an expanding light pulse continues to maintain spherical\nsymmetry about its point of origin.\nFigure 1 shows how this invariant property of electromagnetic signals\nmay be used by two experimenters, A and B, to establish identical Cartesian coordinate systems x , t and x\xe2\x80\x99, t\xe2\x80\x98. In our units the velocity of light is\ntaken as unity and a signal pulse is thus represented by lines expanding\nat 45\xe2\x80\x9d. Though A and B may be in relative motion, each assumes that\nthere is no \xe2\x80\x9cupstream\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cdownstream\xe2\x80\x9d influence on his signals and sets\nevery distant clock at a time halfway between the times of departure and\nreturn of an electromagnetic signal from the origin-in accordance with\nThe boldface numbers in parentheses refer to the references appended to this paper\n\n946\n\nCONFORMAL\nCOORDINATES\n\nJan., 1 6 .\n931\n\nEinstein\'s well-known rules. We have no need here for the assuqp\nthe electromagnetic velocity is the maximum possible. If a\ntransmission existed, we might still prefer to use electromagnetic signals\nbecause of their supposed invariant property.\nif 4 and B are in uniform relative motion, we may establish a conformal\ncorrespondence between their coordinate systems by means of the Lorentz\ntransformation. In Fig. 2 this correspondence is illustrated graphically by\nan artificial distortion of the I# coordinate system so that its corresponding\npoints coincide with those of an undistorted (that is, rectangular Cartesian) A system. In such a diagram the lines t\' = const \'are inclined so as\nto represent B\'s position at the center of an expanding signal pulse.\nf\n\n1\'\n\nI\n\nI\n\nFIG.1.\n\nCOOrdiMteS established by light signals.\n\nThe Lorentz transformation is of course limited to motion at constant\nvelocity. A transformation which maintains the conforma! property for\nvariable motions in two dimensions i s given by (3)\nx\'\n\n+ t\'\n\n=\n\nF(x\n\nX\'\n\n- t\'\n\n=\n\nG(x\n\n+ t)\n- t)\n\nThe lines x\' A t\' = constant may be identified with signal pulses emitted\nby a periodic oscillator or a clbck in the B system. The transformation thus\namounts to a specified variatiqn of the Doppler frequency of time signals\nemitted by B as they might be received in the A system. The Doppler frequencies arg in fact the derivatives:\n\n5=\n\ndG\nd(x\n\n- t)\n\n947\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\n[J.F.T.\n\nSuch variable Doppler frequencies will correspond to a certain variation of the velocity of the B coordinate system. The velwity is given by\n\n--. -f\n-s\n\nu = E )\nx\xe2\x80\x98 =.corut\n\ns +f\n\n(3)\n\nThe velocity of the \xe2\x80\x9cworld line\xe2\x80\x9d x\xe2\x80\x99 =: 0 may be taken as the velocity of the\noscillator B in\xe2\x80\x99the A system. The other coordinate points x\xe2\x80\x98 = const,\nthough at rest relative to B, move with varying velocities in the A system.\nFigure 3 shows a correspondence of the type given by Eqs. 1 for an\nexample in which B moves to the right of A at a velocity 3/5 the velocity of\nlight and comes to rest at the time t = 5, t\xe2\x80\x99 = 4. i t is seen that in spite of\nthe motion, B remains at the center of the signal pulse emitted at the beginning of the trip.\n\nFIG. 2. Lorentz transformation.\n\ne\n\n948\n\nIf we invert the transformation (Eqs. l ) , we find that the velocity is\nreversed at every point. Thus, as would be expected, the velocity of B relative to A is the reverse of the velocity of A relative to B. This relativity of\nvelocities is, however, merely a local relation. Reversal of a field of variable\nvelocities does not in general reverse the displacements. Thus if B moves\nthree units to the right of A, it does not follow that A has moved three units\nto the left of B. Similarly, finite time displacements of the two systems are\nnot equal and there arises a time discrepancy, as is well known.\n\nCONFORMAL\nCOORDINATES\n\nJan., r 6 .\ng31\n\nCOMPOSITION\n\nO TRANSFORMATIONS\nF\n\nT o explore the group properties of the transformation (1) we consider\nthree systems A , B, and C, and apply two such transformations in succession. For the velocity u1 between A and B there is obtained\nu1 =\n\n- fl\n-\n\ns\n1\n\ng +fi\n1\n\nand a similar expression for u2 betMeen B and C. For the resultant velocity\nof C relative to A the composition of two transformationssyields\n\nv3\n\n=\n\n- A h - 01 + u2\nSS +hf2 1 + U l U 2\nIZ\ngg\n12\n\n(4)\n\ni\n\n2\n-4\n\n-2\n\n0\nX\xe2\x80\x99\n\nii\n4\n\nFIG. 3. Conformal transformation,u\n\n=\n\n3/5.\n\nThe latter formula is, of course, the well-known law for the \xe2\x80\x9caddition\xe2\x80\x9d of\nvelocities. Evidently this law does not depend on the principle of relativity,\nbut only on the constancy of the speed of light.\nFigure 4 illustrates graphically the law of composition given by Eq. 4.\nIn its usual context the formula is of course limited to the range u < 1.\nHowever, our extended diagram seems to show more clearly the singular\nnature of the velocity of light. It is evident here that the value u = 1 is not\naltered by composition with any other velocity. If Eq. 4 is interpreted as a\n\n949\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\n[J.F.I.\n\n"8\n\nv, *\n\nVI+ "2\nl+V,V,\n\nFIG.4. Composition of velocities in conformal coordinates.\n\nt\n\nQ\n\nv=\n\nFIG. 5. Doppler shift of time signals.\n\nJan., @%.I\n\nCONFORMAL\nCOORDINATES\n\nformula for \xe2\x80\x9caddition,\xe2\x80\x9d it is seen that the value 1 has the property ordinarily associated with an infinite value. On the other hand, the value u =\ndoes not have its usual property as an.infinite magnitude but is reduced to\nfinite value by addition of (that is, composition with) any finite value. In\nspite of these unusual relations, it will be observed that the composition of\ntwo transformations corresponding to v2 = -uf yields the identical transformation (that is, ug = 0) except for the singular value u1 = 1. There is\nthus no rest system associated with the velocity 1.\nThe law of composition of velocities has been cited to show the nonexistence of velocities greater than light. However, we find in this law\nmerely an expression of the invariance of the velocity of light, valid for any\nvelocity of the coordinate system.\nQ)\n\nSINGULAR BEHAVIOR OF THE D P L R FREQUENCY\nOPE\n\nConformal transformations do not, in general, satisfy the principle of\nrelativity because of an unsymmetrical scale relation. Thus it is found that\n\nTo make the scale change symmetrical we should have\n\nfg\n\n1\n\n=\n\n-\n\nfg\n\nor\n\nfg\n\nil.\n\n(7)\nThere are thus two values of the scale factor f g which lead to symmetry in\nthe relations A to B and B to A . The negative value corresponds to velocities greater than light.\nOf course, if the motion occurs with variable velocity, one cannot specify a fixed value of the scale factor for the whole coordinate tFansformation.\nHowever, if we identify A as an inertial system then the relation of equivalent scale may be satisfied locally all along the path of B in the A system.\nHence, we impose the following boundary condition along the line x r = 0:\n=\n\n+ 1 where u < 1\nf g = { -1 wherev > 1.\nAs Eq. 3 shows, if the velocity of a motion is to exceed 1 then one of the\nDoppler frequenciesf or g must become negative. The transition to a negative frequency may be readily understood with the aid of a simple wave\ndiagram as shown in Fig. 5. As the velocity increases toward 1 the signals\nfrom an approaching oscillator shift to higher and higher frequencies while\nthose on the receding side become slower, approaching zero at a rate determined by the relation f = l/g. The high frequency received from the approaching oscillator persists on transition through u = 1, but the signals\n\n951\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\n[J.F.I.\n\nnow arrive at the stationary oscillator suddenly and in reversed order. The\ntransition of g from positive to negative values thus takes place by way of\ninfinity (see Fig. 6). The frequency f shows no such singular behavior but\nretains positive values on each side of the value zero at u = 1. The discontinuous change of the scale factor fg from +1 to -1 on transition through\nthe critical velocity may thus be explained simply in terms of the expected\nbehavior of the Doppler signals. The possibility of such a discontinuous\nchange seems to have been overlooked in the literature. Thus in (3) and\n(4) the negative value is omitted in the derivation. In t5) the negative value\nis discarded by an argument based on the supposed continuity of the scale\nfactor as a function of velocity.\n\nFIG. 6 . Behavior of the Doppler frequenciesfand g on transition through u\n\n=\n\n1.\n\nIf we suppose that the path of B involves a transition through the speed\nof light, then several sets of time signals will appear simultaneously in A .\nSince the transformation (1) is expressed in terms of the Doppler shift of\ntime signals, it is evident that the correspondence between x,t and x\xe2\x80\x99,t\xe2\x80\x98 will\nbecome multiple-valued. This multiple correspondence may be seen in\nanother way from a simple plot of the function F o r G. If the derivative of a\nfunction changes sign, then either the function itself or its inverse must\nbecome multiple-valued.\nFigure 7 shows the conformal correspondence for a space-like motion of\nB in the inertial system A . It has been assumed that B remains at rest until\n\n952\n\nJan., 1963.1\n\nCONFORMAL\nCOORDINATES\n\nt = t\xe2\x80\x99 = 0 and then moves to the right of A with the velocity u = 5/3,\ncoming to rest at x = 5, t = 3. This particular example may be obtained\nfrom the previous one for which u = 3/5 by a folding of the diagram (Fig.\n3) along lines x - t = const.\nThough B moves faster than light in the A system, we have nevertheless\nsupposed that the propagation of electromagnetic signals takes place in the\nB system exactly as in Fig. 1. The \xe2\x80\x9cupstream\xe2\x80\x9d propagation of signals in\nsuch a system is, of course, an intuitively difficult concept-but not essentially different from that employed in the usual range of the theory.\nSince we have supposed that the conformal property is retained for\nsuch motions, the point B must at every instant lie at the center of light\npulses emitted along its path. In Fig. 7 the marked x\xe2\x80\x98 coordinates illustrate\n\n0\n\n2\n\n4\n\nI\n\xe2\x80\x98\n\nFIG. 7. Conformal transformation, u\n\n=\n\n513.\n\nthis property for the instant t\xe2\x80\x99 = 4. The function g is of course multivalued in this region, but according to our convention the values 0 < x\xe2\x80\x98 < 4,\n0 < t\xe2\x80\x99 < 4 are assigned to the branch g = -2. This convention, which\nmaintains the conformal property, is evidently also sufficient to avoid the\noccurrence of negative time intervals along the path of B in the A system.\nSuch negative intervals, or time reversals, do occur, however, along the\npath of A in the noninertial system B.\nRecently R. Penrose (6) and J. Terrell (7) have shown that the contrac-\n\n953\n\nROBERT JONES\nT.\n\n[J.F.I.\n\ntion of length indicated by the Lorentz transformation is not a visually\nobserved phenomenon. It is interesting also to speculate on the visual\nappearance of a superlight particle. As Heaviside (8) has shown, such a\nparticle would appear suddenly at a point and then split into two\nparticles which appear to recede from each other. This double appearance is illustrated in Fig. 8. In three dimensions the boundary of sensible\ndisturbance expands along a cone behind the body. Such a cone may be\nthought of as an envelope of spherical waves emitted by the body. It is\nreadily seen that any point within the cone lies on the intersec\nsuch spheres and is thus affected by two apparent sources of dis\n\nI\n\n\\\\\n\n\\\n\nFIG. 8. Double appearance of particle travelling at u > 1.\n\nRELATIONS O ELAPSED TIME\nF\n\nEquation 5 may be used to obtain an analytic expression for the elapsed\ntime along a space-like world line. Since dx\xe2\x80\x99 = 0 we have\n-dt\xe2\x80\x9d\nAfter introducing dx\n\n= u dt,\n\n=\n\nfg(dx2 - dt\xe2\x80\x99).\n\n(9)\n\nthere is obtained\ndt\xe2\x80\x99\n\n=\n\ndfg(1 - v\xe2\x80\x99).\n\n(10)\n\nThe boundary condition (8) then yields for u > 1\n(dt\xe2\x80\x98),\n\n954\n\n= 0\n\n=\n\nd n d t .\n\n(11)\n\nJan., 1963.1\n\nCONFORMAL\nCOORDINATES\n\nThe discontinuous change in sign of the Doppler frequency g thus prevents\nthe radical from becoming imaginary.\nThe range of values u > 1 provides relations which seem to complement\nthose of the usual range of the theory. These relations are illustrated in\nFig. 9, which shows the times elapsed in both A ( x , t ) and B(x\xe2\x80\x99,t\xe2\x80\x99) systems\n\nVelocity V\n\nFIG. 9. Elapsed times at various velocities.\n\nfor a trip covering one light year in the A system. For velocities less than 1\nthe elapsed time along an accelerated path ( B ) is always less than that in\nthe inertial system and reaches a minimum value of zero at u = 1. Travel\nat the velocity of light is thus equivalent to infinite velocity. In our theory\nsuperlight velocities offer no advantage to the traveller. At velocities\ngreater than u = fithe travelling twin of the well-known paradox comes\nback older instead of younger. At higher velocities the elapsed time increases and becomes equal to the light time at u = m. Thus infinite velocity\nin the inertial system is equivalent to the velocity of light for the traveller.\nThese dual relations do not make the world of electromagnetic signals any\nless strange, but they seem to make it more symmetrical.\nREFERENCES\n\n(1) N. USA.\nas,\n\n+\n\n+\n\n+\n\nczz)f(t)\nmay be u t i l i to represent\nAbstract-Potential flows of the form = (az by\'\nmotions produced in pulsating bulbs. W e the initial bulb shape may be arbitrary, sequential\nshapes are related by affine transformations.Two componentsappear inthe distribution of pressure, one dependent on the instantaneous velocity and the other on the acceleration. For f o s\nlw\nwith stationarystreamlines the inertial impedance is that of a simple mass, and is proportional to\nthe first moment of the actual mass of fluid contained within the bulb. Examples treated are:\n(1) expanding and collapsing circular cylinders and (2) elliptical cylinders in which the perimeter is held constant.\nThe thickness of the pulsatile laminar boundary layer is found to be approximately one millimeter for conditions in the vicinity of the heart. Conditions for separation and turbulence\n1\ndiffer from those in steady f o .\nlw\n\nFLOWSin pulsating or squeezing bulbs are of\nvery common occurrence, and yet they seem to\nhave received but little attention from fluid\ndynamicists. As an example we may mention\nthe heart, which receives and expels blood nearly\nforty million times a year.\nIf the shape of the heart or bulb were given\nprecisely, or if the course of its motion could be\nprescribed exactly, then one might attempt an\naccurate mathematical analysis of the flow,\ntreating the phenomenon conventionally as a\nboundary value problem of a well-known type.\nHowever, the accuracy with which such biological phenomena reproduce themselves can\nhardly justify great pretension to accuracy in\ntheir mathematical treatment. It seems that in\nthese cases one should use the analysis rather\nmore as a guide to the intuition than as a means\nfor producing quantitative results in specific\ncases.\nConsiderable insight into the squeezing bulb\nproblem may be gained by considering flows of a\nvery simple type. Using Cartesian coordinates\n\nx, y, z, and denoting component velocities of the\nfluid at a point u, v, w,we write:\n\nu=2x)\nv=-y1\n\nx u o xf(t).\n2L\n\n(1)\n\nw=-z)\nSuch a velocity distribution represents the\nirrotational flow of an incompressible liquid,\nand is of course a trivial solution of the NavierStokes equations as well as of Laplace\'s equation. Figure l shows the streamlines associated\nwith this velocity distribution, which will be\nrecognized as an axially symmetric flow with a\n(1957).\nstagnation point at the origin, TIETJENS\nFigure 2 shows how this velocity distribution\nmay be adapted to give the streamlines inside\nthe bulb. To make the equations dimensionally\ncorrect the velocities given by (1) are multiplied\nby the ratio of a characteristic velocity uo to a\n.\ncharacteristic length L uo may be the velocity\nat the exit of the bulb and L may be the distance\nof the mouth of the bulb from the origin.\n\n* Received 5 May 1969\n\n9 59\n\nROBERT T. JONES\nV\n\nFIG.2. Streamlines associated with collapsing bulb.\n\nFIG.1. Axially symmetric f o with stagnation point at\nlw\nOrigiR.\n\nFurthermore, in order to represent the unsteady or pulsatile character of the flow we have\nintroduced a function of the time&) as a factor\nin (1). The potential of the flow is then\n@\n\n= +,f(t)\n\n(x2\n\n)-\xe2\x80\x99\n\n-\n\nzf(t).\n(2)\n\n2\n\nThe velocity profiles given by (1) are flat in\nall three directions. Thus the flow contains no\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nshearing motion and imaginary plane surfaces\nconvected with the fluid remain plane and\nparallel. Thus the flow satisfies the boundary\ncondition of a rectangular box whose sides are\ncollapsing toward the x-axis an4 whose ends are\nmoving outward along the x-axis in such a way\nas to maintain a constant volume. Similarly the\nflow satisfies the boundary condition of a\ncircular cylinder collapsing toward the axis or\nexpanding away from it, and the cylinder may\nhave plane ends.\nThe fact that plane surfaces convected with\nthe fluid remain plane and parallel means of\n\nI\n\nI\n\nSuccessive shapes of bulb\n\nFIG.3. JONES\n\npressure over an expanding and collapsing\ncircular tube having one closed end. The distribution along the tube is parabolic and in the\nlimit approaches the value given by onen\ndimensional flow theory. If the tube pulses i a\ncyclic fashion the pressure associated with the\nvelocity will oscillate at twice the frequency of\nthat associated with the acceleration.\nThe dynamics of flow within the bulb determine only the gradients of pressure and not the\npressure itself. Hence we may introduce an\narbitrary variation of pressure at the mouth of\nthe bulb and the pressure inside will rise and fall\naccordingly, and will be felt uniformly over the\nsurface of the bulb. The most interesting case is\nthat in which the bulb expels its fluid into a long\nelastic tube such as an artery. According to a\nwell-known theory the pressure at the end of the\ntube will be given by\n\nP = Po\n\n+ P uo\n\nC\nY\n\n()\n6\n\nwhere c is the pulse wave velocity in the tube,\nYOUNG\n(1808, 1809). Here the pressure at the\nbulb exit will vary with the outflow velocity u\nand the pressures given by (3) are simply to be\nadded to this pressure. In the case of the left\nheart the component given by (6) is much larger\nthan the variations of pressure developed by\ndynamic motions within the heart.\nThe horizontal or x-component of momentum of the flow is easily computed since the\nhorizontal component of velocity of each fluid\nelement is simply proportional to x. Thus the\nvirtual inertia or virtual mass of the flow is\nproportional to the first moment of the volume\nof the fluid within the bulb. More specifically the\nvirtual mass is equal to the actual mass times\nthe ratio of the centroid of mass R to the length\nL, i.e.\n(7)\n\nforth along the x-axis without sensible change of\nshape. The virtual mass here is simply the actual\nmass of the fluid within the sac.\nIt should be noted that while the forms of the\nstreamlines and the isobaric surfaces are stationary, the fluid itself may oscillate back and\nforth along the streamlines and the magnitude\nof the pressures will vary in accordance with the\nfunctionfit).\nIt will have been noted also that while the\ninitial shape of the bulb is arbitrary, the sequential shape changes are restricted to those obtainable by affine transformations. MOTJLOPOULOS, (1962) proposed a\nmethod for assisting the circulation by inserting\na long narrow rubber balloon into the abdominal\naorta. The balloon is inflated and deflated\nthrough an external air pipe and expels blood\nfrom the aorta in such a way as to assist the\npumping action of the heart. To represent this\nsituation crudely we may consider the flow in\nthe space between two circular cylinders, produced by expansion and contraction of the inner\ncylinder.\nReturning to our frrst example\n\nwe have already noted that it satisfies the boundary condition appropriate to a circular\ncylinder collapsing toward the axis, i.e.\n+r\n\n=\n\n- r 5 where r = (qy" + z2).\n\n(15)\n\n2L\nSince there is no liquid within the inner tube, we\nare at liberty to introduce singularitiesthere and\nby so doing we can obtain a second flow which\nsatisfies the boundary condition of a cylinder\nexpanding radially. JONES\n\nau\n\nav\nau\n2p-.\n2p-, 2pay\'\na2\nax\n\nThe latter two terms require an additional\ncompression from the surface of the bulb acting\nem\ntoward the x-axis while the t r 2p(au/ax)\nrequires a tension along the x-axis. Comparing\nthis term with the Bernoulli pressure at the exit\nof the bulb we have\np/2 u2 E p/2 uo2\n\nand their ratio is 114 (puoL/p)\n\ncondition of normal velocities is satishd and\nthat shearing motions arise in a thin boundary\nlayer at the surface.\nSince the boundary layer is thin we may consider a portion of the inner surface of the bulb\nto be locally flat. In this way the boundary layer\ndevelopment in a pulsatile flow within the bulb\ncan be reduced to the problem of shearing motions produced by tangential oscillations of a\nflat plate. The solution of this latter problem is\ngiven in TIETJENS\n(1957) and shows that the\noscillatory shearing motions diminish exponentially with distance from the surface. The decay\nis given by\nexp-(J~m/2rr)~-\n\nTaking p / p = 0.04 for blood and 0 - 8 sec for\nthe period (= 27r/w), then\nylIe= 0.1 cm.\n\n+\n\nCylindrical surfaces convected with the fluid\napproach the fixed cylinder from both sides.\nFigure 7 shows the streamlines of this flow.\nIn the afkely related shapes we have considered that the surface of the bulb moves with\nthe fluid at every point. Thus the flow satisfies\nnot only the boundary condition of normal\nvelocity, but also the condition of no slip at the\nsurface. If the surface of the bulb actually moves\nin this fashion then the flows discussed above\nwill apply to viscous as well as non-viscous fluids,\nsince the potential flows are in this case exact\nsolutions of the Navier-Stokes equations. The\naddition of viscosity to the fluid will require\nadditional normal and tangential pressures at\nthe surface of the bulb.\nIt is of interest to estimate the magnitude of\nthe additional stresses introduced by viscosity.\nSince the shearing strains (aulay), (avlax), etc.\nvanish, the only surviving terms in the viscous\nstress tensor are\n\nHence shearing motions decay by the factor l/e\nwithin a distance of one millimeter from the\nwall. In other words, the boundary layer has\ntime to grow to a thickness of one millimeter\nduring the period of one heart beat. The stresses\ndeveloped by viscosity within this thin layer will\nof course be much greater than those calculated\nearlier for the body of fluid within the bulb.\nMore difficult questions are those of the transitionto turbulence andflow separation. Reynolds\nnumbers in the vicinity of the heart regularly\nexceed those found by Reynolds for transition\nin a straight smootlipipe. However, comparisons\nof the flow in the heart and aorta with standard\nhydraulic experiments should be made with\ncaution because of the unsteady nature of the\nflow. It seems doubtful that anything resembling\nfully developed turbulent pipe flow will appear\nin the larger arteries. Transitory separation\naccompanied by the formation of jets and vortices may appear, however, but their prediction\nwill require a deeper study than we have undertaken here.\n\nor 1/4 the Reynolds number based on the length\nof the biilb. Since the Reynolds numbers in the\nvicinity of the heart are between lo00 and lO,OOO,\nwe see that the additional stresses introduced\nwithin the fluid by viscosity are very small when\ncompared with the dynamic pressures.\nWhile the afEne transformations can yield\nrealistic bulb shapes, the requirement that the\nsurface of the bulb move with the fluid both in\nn\nby\ntangential and normal directions is unrealistic. Kantrowitz\nAvco-Everett Research Laboratory\n\necember 1967\n\n96 7\n\nJones, R. T., Petschek, H E. and Kantrowitz, A R., "Elementary Theory of\n.\n.\nSynchronous Arterio-Arterial Blood Pumps," Medical and Biological Engineering, vol. 6, no. 3, June 1968, pp. 303-308. @ 1968.\nReprinted by permission of Pergamon Press, Ltd., Oxford, Eng.\n\n968\n\nMed. & biol Engng. Vol. 6, pp. 303-308. Pergamon Press, 1968. printed in Great Britain\n\nELEMENTARY THEORY OF SYNCHRONOUS\nARTERIO-ARTERIAL BLOOD PUMPS*\nROBERT T. JONES, HARRY E. PETSCHEK and ARTHUR R. KANTROWITZ\n\nAvco Everett Research Laboratory, Everett, Mass.\nAbshct-h the technique of arkrio-arterial pumping, a volume of fluid is withdrawn from\nthe aorta during systole and reinject& during diastole, thereby reducing the systolic pressure\nof the heart and adding energy to the systemic circulation. It is found that an upper bound for\nthe effectiveness of such devices is given by the formula\n\nwhere Qhu is the stroke output of the unaided heart and AQh is the increment caused by the\nih\nand\nare\npump w t a stroke Qb. Plu PSu the systolic and diastolic pressures (unaided). APTis\nnormally negative and represents the reduction in ventricular pressure. The division of effort\nof the pump between the reduction of pressure and the increase of flow depends on the physiological-mechanical impedance of the heart. The total effect is, however, independent of the\nimpedance.\n\nARTERIO-ARTERIAL\npumping provides artificial\nassistance to the circulation by withdrawing\nfluid from the aorta during systole and reinjecting it during diastole.\nThe arterio-arterial p-mp may take the form\nof a simple pulsating bulb attached to the aorta\nand may operate without valves of its own provided the natural aortic valve is competent and\nprovided the pump is synchronized with the\nnatural heart. During systolic ejection from the\nheart the bulb is expanded, deflating the aorta\nso that the outflow from the heart is received at\na reduced pressure. During diastole, when the\naortic valve is closed, the bulb is compressed\ninflating the aorta and providing increased\npressure for the systemic circulation. Conventionally, these events are timed by using the\nR-wave of the ECG complex as a signal. This\nprinciple of synchronous pumping is utilized in\nthe Kantrowitz-Avco auxiliary ventricle (Fig.\n1A) and in the technique of intra-aortic balloon\npumping proposed by KoE, Moulopoulis and\nTopaz (see Fig. 1C).\n\nThe action of such devices is obviously complicated by their dependence on the natural\nheart. Thus, the auxiliary ventricle (or balloon)\nmay both reduce the pressure in the left ventricle\nand may permit the natural ventricle to eject a\ngreater volume. The particular division between these two effects will depend on the\nmechanical impedance of the heart as a generator, a quantity which, in turn, depends on the\npathologic physiology of the heart. The purpose\nof the present paper is to indicate that a simple\nrelation for the sum of these effects can be\nderived independently of the mechanical impedance of the natural ventricle.\nWithout trying to settle any physiological\nquestions, it is of interest to attempt to understand the mechanical action of the synchronous\narteriokrterial pump on as simple a basis as\npossible. For this purpose we shall employ a\nsimple \xe2\x80\x9cwindkessel\xe2\x80\x9d model of the aortic system\nand assume linear peripheral resistances. In\nthis model the incremental pressure in the aorta\nis simply proportional to the volume of blood\n\n* First received 25 September 1967 and in revisedform 20 December 1967.\n\n969\n\nROBERT T. JONES, HARRY E. PETSCHEK and ARTHUR R. KANTROWITZ\n\n(A)\n\n(6)\n\n(C)\n\nFIG. 1. Arterio-arterial pumps. A, Thoracic awriliary ventricle; B,\nAuxiliary ventricle in descending aorta; C, Intra-aortic balloon pump.\n\ninjected into it.* The pressure and volume decay\nexponentially with flow through the peripheral\nresistances. Typical physiological values of the\nresistance R and the capacitance C give values\n.\nof RC between 0 7 and 1.5 sec.\nConsider first the effect of an arterio-arterial\npump with the natural heart completely inactive.\nWe assume here that the left ventricle and the\natrium present no impedance to flow and provide a reservoir of blood at a low but constant\n(atrial) pressure and that both the aortic and\nmitral valves open when the pressure in the\naorta falls below this value (see Fig. 2). During\nthe intake stroke the pump must first withdraw\nenough blood from the aorta to reduce the\npressure to the atrial level and thus to open the\nvalves. The remainder of the stroke is then\neffective in withdrawing blood from the reservoir. We then have\n(9)\n\nso that\n- -- PIU-Pm\nAQh\n\nand\nPU\nl\nor expressed as a fractional change in stroke\noutput\nSubtracting (14) from (13) and substituting\nAQh\nQb\nPxu - Pxu\n-=(1co\nQb\n\nQhu\n\nQhu\n\nPiu\n\nThe concept of a \xe2\x80\x9csource impedance\xe2\x80\x9d of the\nheart as it is to be understood in our analysis\nis perhaps not a conventional physiological\nconcept and deserves some elaboration. A\nheart supposed to have a very high, or infinite,\nimpedance will eject a fixed volume with each\nstroke and this volume will not be affected by\nthe pressure in the aorta. Thus, in this extreme\nthe excursion of the heart muscle is supposed to\nbe unaffected by the tension developed in the\nmuscle. In this case the artificial reduction of\npressure in the aorta by the auxiliary pump will\nnot lead to any increase of flow but will result\nsolely in a reduction of ventricular pressure.\nAt the other extreme one can envision a heart\nmuscle which develops its maximum possible\ntension on each stimulus, but which is capable\nof greater or smaller excursion.\nIn the more general case the heart will present\na finite impedance to flow and the effort of the\npump will be divided between a reduction of\npressure in the left ventricle and an increase of\nflow. It is interesting, however, that a relation\ncombining the two effects is independent of the\nimpedance. For the unaided heart equation (7)\nreduces to\nQhu\n\n= Qgu\n\n+ Pi, C (1 - e - 9\n\nwe obtain\n\nand finally\n\nor\n\n----- - Qb PI,-Pa,\nAQh\nr\\p,\nQhu\n\nPiu\n\nQhu\n\nPiu\n\n(16)\n\nThus the total effect of the auxiliary pump is\nproportional to its stroke volume ratio and to\nthe pulse pressure ratio of the unaided heart.\nThe determination of either AQn or APl\nalone requires, of course, a second relation for\nthe source impedance of the heart which is at\npresent unknown.\nEquation (16) may be considered an upper\nbound for the effectiveness since we have\nassumed instantaneous withdrawal and ejection\nfrom the pump. If the pump stroke occupies a\niinite time interval, then the effectiveness will\nfall below that given by (16). Sne our relations\nic\nare linear it is not difficult to extend this result\nto cases of prescribed injection or withdrawal.\n(11) An interesting example which illustrates the\n\nEUEMENTARY THEORY OF SYNCHRONOUS ARTEEUO-ARTERIAL BLOOD PUMPS\n\neffect of finite ejection time is provided by the\ncase in which withdrawal and ejection by the\npump imitate those of the natural unaided\nheart exactly. Assuming the heart to have\ninfinite impedance, the aortic pressure variation\nwill then be left unchanged in form but will be\nshifted in phase by the systolic interval T ~ .The\nventricular pressure will follow the variation of\ndiastofic pressure over an interval T~ near the\n\nLimited experience acquired thus far suggests\nthat the undamaged or healthy heart acts as a\nconstant flow generator so that the effect of\nartificial pumping is chiefly to reduce the left\nThere are\nventricular pressure (A\nindications, however, that the failing heart may\nbe pressure-limited and not flow-limited so that\nthe flow can be increased by the artificial pump.\nIn this case the reduction of left ventricular\npressure will not be so great but the beneficial\neffect on the patient may be greater.\nIn our analysis we have emphasized the\nsimplest possible relations and have obtained a\nresult which is obviously capable of refinement\nin several respects, Thus in equation (12) the\noutflow during systole could be represented\ntFIG.4. Jones\nAvco-Everett Research Laboratory\n\n1969\n\n975\n\nJones, R. T., "Blood Flow," Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics, 1 6 . 1 , 1969,\n71\npp. 223-244.\n@ 1969.\nReprinted by permission of Annual Reviews, Inc., Palo Alto, Ca.\n\n976\n\nReprinted from\nANNUAL REVIEW OF FLUID MECHANICS\nVoL 1 1969\n,\nCoprtight 1969. All rights resewed\n\nBLOOD FLOW\nBY ROBERT JONES\nT.\nAoco-Everett Research Laboratoly, Everett, Massachus&\n\nFor our purposes the blood may be treated as a liquid having about the\ndensity of water in which is suspended a remarkably high concentration\n(40 per cent to 50 per cent) of red cells, together with a smaller volume of\nother so-called \xe2\x80\x9cformed elements\xe2\x80\x9d such as platelets and white blood cells.\nThe liquid component, or plasma, has a viscosity coefficient about 11 times\n2\nthat of water & = .015). On the scale of most arteries the whole blood may be\ntreated as a Newtonian fluid with p 3 to 5 times that of water, depending on\nthe hematocrit. Evidently the concentration of red cells contributes greatly\nto the viscosity. It is not surprising, therefore, that in smaller vessels whose\ndiameter is comparable with that of the cells the behavior i not well des\nscribed by simple rheological coefficients.\nIf the flow region is large compared with the dimensions of the cells,\ntheories of the viscosity of suspensions are applicable and serve to explain\nthe increase of viscosity with increased concentration of suspended particles.\nAn excellent and comprehensive review is that by Goldsmith & Mason (1).\nSuch theories follow the original treatment of Einstein in 1905 (2).\nEinstein considered a dilute suspension of spherical particles which, though\nrigid, were free t o move with the fluid and to rotate under the influence of\nshearing motions. After the appropriate translation and rotation have been\nsubtracted out, the local fluid distortion reduces to a flow in which the undisturbed streamlines are hyperbolic. Einstein calculated the Stokes flow about\na sphere in such a velocity field and related the increased dissipation due to\nthe presence of the sphere to an effective increase of viscosity of the medium.\nHis result is\n\ni\n\n1\n.\n\nwhere t is the volume concentration of spherical particles.\nThe surprising thing about Einstein\xe2\x80\x99s result is the large effect of the suspended particles on the viscosity. A simple division of the medium into rigid\nand fluid portions, assuming that the shearing deformation is limited to the\nfluid component, would produce the result\nP\xe2\x80\x98 = P(1\n\n+\n\nc)\n\n2.\n\nfor small concentrations. Evidently the spheres, though they accommodate\npartly to the shearing motion, produce a greater effect than would be expected from elementary considerations. The result given by Equation 2 is\nactually obtained by G. I. Taylor for gas bubbles (3).\nEinstein\xe2\x80\x99s theory has been extended by Simha and others (4, 5 ) to ellip-\n\n977\n\nJONES\n\nsoidal particles. The values obtained for nonspherical particles are larger\nthan those for spheres, becoming logarithmically infinite for extreme proportions. For flattened ellipsoids of 6 to 1 axis ratio (about the proportions of a\nred blood cell) (4) gives\n3.\n\' = B(1\nP\n54\nFor a concentration of 40 per cent we obtain p\' =3p. Taking the viscosity of\nplasma as p = .015, result i p\'= .045. Though the concentration is by no\nthe\ns\nmeans small, it can be seen that there is rough agreement with measured\nvalues.\nTheories of suspensionslead to a linear, Newtonian, viscosity. Experiments\nwith whole blood (6) show, however, an increasing value of p at small rates\nof deformation. Thus, a t shear rates of 1 per sec, the viscosity is about\ndoubled. The stress level at which the non-Newtonian component begins to\nbe evident is thus about 1/10 dyne/cm2. On the other hand, the normal\nstress corresponding to a pressure of 1 mm Hg is about 1000 dynes/cm2.\nThe relative stiffening of the fluid at low rates of strain will lead to 9\nmodification of the parabolic velocity profile in Poiseuille flow, and in the\nextreme case (Bingham fluid) to a blunt-nosed profile or "plug flow." It is\nof interest to estimate the size of this plug in the case of a typical small blood\nvessel. For Poiseuille flow we have\n\n+\n\n4.\n\nAssuming a vessel of radius Y O = 1 mm with h equal to 1 cm/sec, we\nm\n0\n01\nobtain Y = . 0 cm, or loop. The effect of non-Newtonian viscosity is evidently quite negligible in vessels of l mm or larger. The effect on wall friction in oscillatory or pulsatile flow has been studied by M. G. Taylor (7).\nThe anomalous viscosity of blood becomes more prominent in the smaller\nvessels and capillaries, and it is in these vessels that the primary dissipation\nof energy in the circulatory system occurs. According to Zweifach (8) the\ncollective length of capillaries in the human body amounts to about 60,000\nmiles. The chief pressure drop evidently occurs, however, in somewhat larger\nvessels, arterioles, which control the peripheral flow by means of precapillary\nsphincters [see (9)]. A preliminary study of the mechanical properties of these\nsmall vessels has been reported by Y. C. Fung (10).\nIn such small vessels the flow is greatly complicated by the relatively\nlarge sue of the suspended particles, which may occupy the whole cross\nsection of the vessel. In this regime, rheological concepts become inappropriate and one must analyze the phenomena in detail. An analysis of viscous\nflow in a tube with large spherical particles has been given by Wang &\nSkalak (11).\n\nFLOW PRESSURETHE HEART\nAND\nIN\nAND LARGE\nARTERIES\nIn the heart and the larger arteries the flow is dominated by normal pressures and by the elasticity of the vessels.\n\n978\n\nBLOOD FLOW\ne5 x\n\nk\n\n13%\n\nL\n\nFIG.1 Left heart, aorta, and main branches\n.\n\nFigure 1 shows a greatly simplified sketch of the heart and the aorta\ntogether with some of the main branches. Also shown are typical percentages\nof flow to various organs. The total outflow from theheart, as wl as its\nel\ndistribution, vary widely under different physiological circumstances.\nFigure 2 shows some features of a typical pulse of the left heart. Ejection\nfrom the heart into the aorta is remarkably rapid, Mxumng with an acceleration of lo00 to So00 c m / d (Le., 1 to 5 \xe2\x80\x9cg\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99) and with a peak velocity u as\nhigh as 100 cm/sec [see (12,13)]. In spite of this, the kinetic energy of flow is\nbut a small fraction of the energy of the heart beat. Thus p 2 may have a\n/@\npeak value of 3 to 4 mm Hg, while the aortic pressure varies from 70 to 120\nmm. The major fraction of the pulse energy appears as elastic inflation of\nthe aorta.\nPressure developed in the right heart and the pulmonary artery is considerably smaller than the pressures in systemic arteries. The flow energy\nis thus a larger fraction of the total on the right side, but in neither case\nn\ndoes it dominate. The dominant role of the pressure may be seen i the architecture of the arterial system. Branching arteries show no consistent tendency to come o f in the direction of flow, 90\xc2\xb0 being a common branching\nf\nangle.\nSince the flow in the upper part of the aorta occurs in short spurts fol-\n\n979\n\nJONES\n\nEJECTED V0LUYE.C\n\nt ,sac.\nFIG. Typical pulse of left heart.\n2.\n\nlowed by longer periods of near zero velocity, it is of interest to estimate the\nunsteady growth of the viscous boundary layer during this period. Such an\nestimate shows that the boundary layer can grow to a thickness of approximately 1mm during the ejection period. Since the aorta is two or more centimeters in diameter in this region, the flow is evidently far from that described by Poiseuille\'s law.\nThe Reynolds number corresponding to an ejection velocity of 100 cm/\nsec and a diameter of 2 cm is approximately 5000, higher than the Reynolds\nnumber for transition to turbulence in steady pipe flow. However, since the\nwall vorticity has diffused inward only one tenth of the arterial radius, transition in the usual sense can hardly occur.\nFlow near the heart and in the larger arteries is thus dominated by inertial stresses and is not turbulent in the usual statistical sense. Flows in this\nregime are nevertheless greatly modified by the action of viscosity (separation, vortical flow), though they are typically insensitive to the magnitude\nof the viscosity.\nFigure 3 shows the resistance of a sphere, approximately the size of an\nartificial heart valve, plotted against the relative viscosity. Without viscosity\nthe sphere would have no drag, yet a 100-fold variation in p hardly affects\nthe magnitude.\nAlthough the flow in the heart is probably quite irregular, it is nwerthelw\nless instructive to examine some simplified mathematical models of f o in\na pulsating bulb [see (14)]. For this purpose we consider flowsFith a potential\n4 given by\n5.\n9 = ua+ Pr\' w*\n\n+ +\n\n,\n\nBLOOD FLOW\n\nVISCOSITY\n\nFIG.3. Effect of viscosity on resistance o sphere.\nf\n\nwhere a,p, y are functions of the time with\n\n+B(4 + A t ) = 0\n\n40\n\n6.\n\nand x , y , e are Cartesian coordinates. Such flows have the property that initially plane surfaces convected with the fluid remain plane. Successive\nchanges in the shape of a bulb are thus related to an (arbitrary) initial shape\nby affine transformations.\nIf the time dependence in Equation 5 is represented by a single function,\nas in\n7.\n0 = f 0.I\n\xe2\x80\x99.\nby\xe2\x80\x99 6 4 = f(t)0(z, 4\nY,\n\n+ +\n\nwhere a, b,\n\nG\n\nare constants with\n8.\n\n.+b+c=O\n\nthen the streamlines will be stationary though the flow is time dependent.\nFigure 4 shows streamlines for a flow of this type. Here a= 2, b = - 1, G = - 1,\nand the flow is axially symmetric with a stagnation point a t the prigin. Starting with a bulb of arbitrary shape, successive shapes are obtained by a simple\nstretching transformation. Figure 4 illustrates this process. In order to approximate the condition of a fixed outlet or mouth of the bulb, the shape\nshould be drawn so that i t becomes a tangent to the streamlines in the neighborhood of the exit.\nWith the effect of viscosity omitted, the pressure a t points within the\nbulb will be given by\n\n+ + w\xe2\x80\x9d>lr(Ol\xe2\x80\x99 -\n\nP = Po($)- b/Z)(%*\xc2\xb6I*\n\nPf\xe2\x80\x99(t)\n\n9.\n\nwhere u=&, v =A, w =&. Streamlines for collapsing bulb.\n\ntrary function of the time, P&), which must be determined by the impedance\ninto which the bulb works.\nFor flows with stationary streamlines the isobaric surfaces given by\nua+vz+w2 and Cp in Equation 7 are also stationary. Figure 5 shows these\n/\n\nP=\n\nu2 + v2 + w2 8 CONST\n\npo - P,*(u2+v2+we1f\n\n(tP-p\n\n4 f\'( t)\n\nFIG.5. Isobaric surfaces.\n\n982\n\nBLOOD FLOW\nisobaric surfaces for flows with axial symmetry. The component associated\nwith (b may be termed the \xe2\x80\x9cacceleration pressure\xe2\x80\x9d while (p/2) (a2+u2+d)\nLf(t)12is the \xe2\x80\x9cBernoulli pressure.\xe2\x80\x9d In an oscillatory flow the latter component\nwill oscillate a t twice the frequency of the former.\nFigure 6 shows pressures computed by the above formulae for the initial\ninstant of collapse of the bulb shown. Here w2+u2+w2=0, and the pressures\nare entirely due to acceleration of the flow [P=Po--p(&/dt)]. For an ejection\ncurve of the type shown on Figure 2, the pressure changes within the bulb\n\nP\n\nI\n\nBULB SURFACE\n\nOUTLET PRESSURE\n\nX\n\nFIG.6. Initial distribution of pressure within collapsing bulb.\n\namount to 4 or 5 mm Hg, while the outlet pressure may be 70 mm. Pressures\ndue to the acceleration of flow within the heart are thus of the same order as\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cBernoulli\xe2\x80\x9d pressures.\nIf the aorta behaved as a rigid pipe, the inertial reaction would lead to\nexcessive outlet pressures. The elastic compliance of the aorta serves an important function in smoothing out pressure fluctuations from the heart.\nThus the simplest theory of the action of the aorta is known as the \xe2\x80\x9cwindkessel theory\xe2\x80\x9d (15), relating its action to that of the pneumatic chamber\nformerly used to smooth the impulses from fire engine pumps.\nAccording to the windkessd theory, the aorta acts simply as an elastic\nbag or, in electrical terms, as a capacitor. The incremental pressure developed\nin the aorta is then proportional to the volume ejected into it. Typically,\nthe ejection of 50 cc of blood into the aorta will raise the pressure from 70\nmm to 120 mm, or by 62X108 dynes/cm2, so that dP/dQ=(62x108)/50.\n\n983\n\nJONES\nConsidered together with a "lumped" peripheral resistance, the windkessd theory leads to a simple exponential decay of pressure in the aorta\nduring diastole according to the formula\nPa\n\n-\n\nP.t?-U\n\n1.\n0\n\nwhere A- (l/R)(dP/dQ).\nValues for R may be estimated from data given in textbooks on physiology. For a mean aortic pressure of 100X 18 dynes/cmz and a cardiac output\nof 70 cc/sec, the value of R works out to 1400. The time constaht 1/x is then\napproximately 0.9 sec.\nThe windkessel theory gives remarkably good predictions of pressure in\nthe larger arteries during diastole. The inflation of the arterial system is,\nhowever, complicated by the phenomenon of wave propagation and reflection, which involves the lengths of the arteries. The propagation of pulse\nwaves was first investigated mathematically in 1808 by T. Young (16) who\ngave the basic formulation.\nPULSE WAVE PHENOMENA\nPerhaps the most comprehensive recent analysis of pulse wave phenomi\nena is that by Womersley (17). An excellent review o modern work is given\nf\nby Skalak (18).\nAn instructive derivation of Young\'s formula results if one chooses axes\nin which the pulse waves are stationary and the flow steady. Consider a long\nelastic tube filled with incompressible liquid flowing a t a velocity t. Small\nwavelike changes in diameter of the tube will be opposed by changes in the\nelastic tension of the wall. In addition to the pressure developed by elastic\nstress, bulges in the tube will also cause changes in the flow velocity and,\nhence, the pressure developed in the fluid. For small flow velocities the elastic\npressure will dominate, restoring the tube to its initial straight form. However, for a sufficiently high velocity t, the changes in fluid pressure can overcome the elastic restoring tension. At this speed the tube is neutrally stable\nand variations in cross-sectionalarea will retain whatever form is given them.\nThe internal pressure associated with circumferential tension T in the tube\nwall is\nT\n\nP=-f_\nR\n\nand\ndP\ndR\n\n1\nRs\n\n-=-E7\nor\ndP\nE\n7\n_ - 2AR\n-dA\n\nwhere A = TRP\n\nHere E is the elastic modulus, and T is the thickness of the wall.\n\n11.\n\nBLOOD FLOW\n\nTurning to the pressure developed by the motion of the fluid we can write\n\nP\nRC)\n\n= Pa\n\n- (p/2)(c\n\n+\n\n2)\n4\xe2\x80\x99\n\n12.\n\nthat\nA@\n\n-P W\n\n1.\n3\n\nHere u is the perturbation (assumed small) produced by the change in crosssectional area. From continuity we may write\ncdA = - U A\nso that dfi=pc2(dA/A), or\ndP\n-=dA\n\nPC9\n\nA\n\nEquating this \xe2\x80\x9cBernoulli pressure\xe2\x80\x9d to the pressure developed elastically\n(Equation 11) we obtain\n14.\n\nIf the flow velocity exceeds G , then the Bernoulli pressures will dominate the\nelastic restoring pressures and stationary waves will grow in amplitude. I t\nmay be expected that attempts to force fluid through an elastic tube (with\nfixed ends) a t a velocity greater than c will result in unstable distortions.\nTransforming to axes moving a t the velocity - c we obtain Young\xe2\x80\x99s\nformula for the wave speed, Equation 14, in a tube with zero mean velocity.\nMore generally, if the mean velocity is U we find that the waves travel a t\no\nthe velocity c in either direction relative to axes moving a t the velocity\nUO, the waves are convected with the fluid. The pressure is now given\ni.e.,\nby Equation 13 with the sign reversed if we adopt the convention that u is\npositive in the direction of the wave.\nThe foregoing analysis presents the problem in its simplest terms.\nOlsen & Shapiro (19)have investigated several of the nonlinear effects associated with waves of larger amplitude. One interesting result of their analysis\nis that the nonlinear elasticity of a material like rubber cancels the nonlinear\ncomponent of the hydrodynamic pressure, producing a \xe2\x80\x9clinear\xe2\x80\x9d behavior for\nlarge-amplitude waves.\nOur analysis has assumed one-dimensional flow. However, solutions that\nshow the effect of radial motions of the liquid are available in the hydrodynamic literature [e.g., Lamb (20a) p. 4721. Figure 7 shows the effect of radial\nmotions in reducing the speed of shorter waves. A more complete treatment,\nincluding unsymmetrical modes, will be found in the paper by Anliker &\nMaxwell (20).\nSince the arteries are imbedded in tissue, an estimate of the effect of a\nsurrounding medium on the pulse is of interest. Figure 8 shows the influence\nof a surrounding liquid on the wave velocity of tubes filled with the same\n\n~\n\n985\n\nJONES\nliquid. Such an effect simulates the inertial impedance of the surrounding\ntissue, but does not simulate viscous or elastic effects.\nA treatment of the tapered artery based on the assumption of constant\nwave speed c leads to the well-known differential equation used in the study\nof acoustic horns. An analysis of an exponentially tapered artery, on this\nbasis, has been given by R. L. Evans (21). A somewhat simpler analysis,\nadaptable to a conical taper, utilizes the spherical wave equation; Le.,\n\nIn this case, pressure pulses retain their shape but vary in amplitude inversely as the vessel diameter. The velocity, given by d+/dR, shows a more\ncomplicated dependence.\n\nBRANCHING\nARTERIES:\n\nPERIPHERAL IMPEDANCE\n\nProceeding from the large arteries to smailer branching vessels, viscosity\nbegins to play an increasingly important role. A very complete treatment of\nthe effects of viscosity in pulsatile flow has been given by Womersley. In the\nlarger arteries vorticity can diffuse only a short distance into the flow during\na pulse. In smaller arteries, however, the unsteady boundary layer begins to\n\n*\n\nOO\n\nI\n\n2\n\n3\n\n4\n\n2n-3FIG.7. Effect o radial motions on pulse wave velocity.\nf\n\n986\n\nI .o\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\n2\n\nI\n\n3\n\ni\n\n4\n\n2T\nf\n\nFIG. Effect of surrounding liquid on pulse wave velocity.\n8.\noccupy the total cross section of the artery. As an introduction to Womersley\xe2\x80\x99s results, it is instructive to consider the oscillatory shearing motion of a\nviscous liquid produced by a flat surface oscillating in its own plane. In this\ncase a well-known solution gives\nB\nU.,.CSYCOS (nt - ky)\n15.\nE\n\nwhere R =(n/2v)l/%.\nHere u is the velocity (parallel to the plate), y is the distance normal to the surface, and Y is the kinematic viscosity. For a normal\nheart rate n is about 10. Taking v as 0.05 we obtain R = 10; henbe, the oscillatory shearing motions diminish to l/e of the surface value at y =O.l,or 1 mm.\nFor a vessel 2 cm in diameter the viscosity hardly modifies the velocity\nproiile. Such a thin boundary layer, however, leads to values of wall-shearing\nstress considerably higher than those for steady Poiseuille flow. The shearing\ns\nstress on the oscillating plate i given by\n7=p&k&(acoB\n\n(nt+- 3\n\n1\n6.\n\nand is thus 45O out of phase w t the velocity. For a peak velocity u of\nih\n,\n100 cm/sec, v=0.05, K = 10 as above, we obtain\nT\n-\n\n= 140 dynes/cm\n\n987\n\nJONES\n\nFor an artery 50 cm long, this value corresponds to a pressure drop of approximately 11 mm Hg at peak flow-about 7 times that associated with\nsteady Poiseuille flow.\nOur rough calculation is intended only to give an intuitive picture of the\nproblem. For rigorous theory and results one should refer to Womersley\'s\npaper. Oscillatory shearing motion adjacent to a flat surface is simply a\ndamped sinusoid with surface traction 45" out of phase with the velocity for\nall frequencies. In a circular tube the oscillations are described by Bessel\nfunctions and the phase shift is a function of the frequency.\nFor blood vessels below a certain diameter, the diffusion of vorticity is\nessentially complete at every stage of an oscillatory flow. Since the Reynolds\nnumber is quite small, the flow is dominated by viscosity. In this limiting\ncase the equation of motion is simply Poiseuille\'s formula\n17.\n\nThe continuity relation is, however, modified by the elasticity of the vessel;\ni.e.,\naA\na\n_ - - -ax A ~\nP\nat\n\n18.\n\nIntroducing the relation between the pressure and the elastic distension of\nthe cross section by means of the pulse wave velocity G, we write\n1.\n9\n\nso that Equation 18 becomes\n1 aP\n\n--+p--eo\ncz at\n\na%\nax\n\n20.\n\nEliminating u between Equations 17 and 20 we obtain for the pressure\n21.\n\nwhich is the well-known diffusion equation. Evidently in vessels of this size\nthe pulse no longer travels as a wave, but is reduced to a diffusion of pressure\nby the action of viscosity. Equation 21 has a one-parameter family of solutions corresponding to a step input of pressure, viz.,\n22.\n\nThe phenomenon of diffusion of pressure is evidently restricted to vessels\nsmaller than 1 mm in diameter. To determine the critical size, we may compare the pressure a t a point along the artery with the pressure that would\narrive at that point if the pulse wave were unimpeded. Hence, we set t in\n\n988\n\nBLOOD FLOW\nEquation 22 equal to X / G . For G = 1000, r = 0.05 we find that the pulse is reduced to one half in a distance of 6 cm.\nPerhaps the most doubtful quantity in the foregoing estimate is the\nmagnitude of c in such small vessels. A constant value of c would correspond\nto a constant ratio of wall stress to pressure and, hence, would give large and\nsmall vessels the same margin of safety. Measurements show, however, t h a t\nthe wave speed is higher in branching arteries than in the aorta. Whether\nthis tendency persists to very small vessels in not known.\n\nAORTIC\nPRESSURE\nPULSE\nSince the collective area of the arterial branches increases with distance\nfrom the heart, the average flow velocity must decrease. Thomas Young\nsupposed that the pulse pressure would decrease also. However, D. McDonald (22,23) and others have shown that pulsatile components of the pressure\nactually increase for a certain distance in going toward the periphery. The\nincrease of harmonic components with distance from the heart corresponds\nto the well-known sharpening of the pulse in the distal radial and femoral\narteries.\nT h e phenomenon of pulse sharpening can be demonstrated quite well\nwith a simple physical model of the aortic system. Figure 9 shows such a\nmodel in use at Avco Everett Research Laboratory (see 2 ) This model\n4.\nconsists of an untapered rubber tube having geometric and elastic properties\n\n\xe2\x80\x99\n\nFIG.9. Simplified physical model of aorta.\n\n989\n\nJONES\n\nFIG. 0 Proximal and distal pulse shapes produced by simplified model.\n1.\n\nFIG. Later version of aortic model.\n11.\n\n990\n\nBLOOD FLOW\nsimilar to those of the aorta. Pulsatile flow is produced by an electric motor\nand a mechanical linkage that imitates the ejection curve of the heart. A t its\nlower end the rubber \xe2\x80\x9caorta\xe2\x80\x9d enters a box filled with plastic sponge, intended\nto simulate the peripheral resistance. Aortic and mitral valves are plastic\nflaps. Figure 10 shows the forms of the pressure curves in the aorta for positions near the (rubber) \xe2\x80\x9cheart\xe2\x80\x9d and near the peripheral resistance. These\ncurves show a striking similarity to physiological pressure pulses.\nA direct physical model such as described above has been found useful in\nisolating and studying purely mechanical phenomena connected with the\ncirculation. Figure 11 shows a later version in which the aorta (silicone rubber) is tapered and is equipped with rudimentary carotid and renal-celiac\n\nPrnmHg\n100\n\n0\n200\n\n100\n-Hg\n0\n\n200\n100\n0\n\n0 .2 4 6 .e 10\n.\nTIME, SECONDS\n\nFIG.12. Transient pulses produced by model.\n\nbranches. The rectangular reservoirs that supply the ventricle are separated\nf\nby an orifice plate so that the difference in level is an indication o mean flow.\nThis model has been used at Avco Everett Research Laboratory for the investigation of various \xe2\x80\x9ccirculatory assist\xe2\x80\x9d devices.\nFigure 12 shows transient pulses in the left ventricle and the aorta, obtained by starting and stopping the drive motor. About four strokes are\nrequired to build the aortic pressure up to its steady value. When the motor\nis stopped the pressure decays exponentially, accompanied by outflow\nthrough the peripheral resistances. Evidently the windkessel theory gives a\ngood representation of the phenomenon except during the early part of the\npulse, where the pressures are complicated by wave reflections and vary\nwith position.\nBefore proceeding to the discussion of reflections, i t is useful to consider\n\n991\n\nJONES\n\nthe effect of a stepwise input of flow (assumed frictionless) into an elastic\ntube. Figure 13 illustrates this phenomenon. The injection of \xe2\x80\x9cnew\xe2\x80\x9d fluid\ninto the tube sets into motion a part of the fluid already there, creating a\nbulge which travels at the velocity c, greater than u. The new fluid is separated from the old by a \xe2\x80\x9ccontact surface.\xe2\x80\x9d The change in momentum at the\nwave front is pu and occurs at the velocity c, so t h a t the pressure is\n23.\n\nA# = p w\n\nSince (p/2)u2is usually small compared with puc, the pulse is not very sensitive to variations in the velocity profile of the injection, depending primarily\non the volume influx.\nIf A is the cross-sectional area of the tube, the volume flow will be Q =u A .\n\n\xe2\x80\x98NEW\xe2\x80\x9c FLUID\nCONTACT SURFACE\n\n.VELOCITY = u\nAP=pUC\n\nFIG.13. Injection of fluid into an elastic tube.\nThe pressure required is in phase with the flow rate and, hence, the elastic\ntube without reflections and with frictionless flow presents a simple resistive\nimpedance\n\n,\nIn the electrical analogue, Z is termed the \xe2\x80\x9ccharacteristic\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9csurge\xe2\x80\x9d impedance.\nTypical values of mean flow to various organs, together with the mean\naortic pressure, may be used to estimate the resistive impedance associated\nwith various branching arteries. Values corresponding to Figure 1 are shown\non Figure 14. It will be seen that the resistance associated with the capillary\nbeds is an order of magnitude greater than the pulse impedance of the aorta.\nFigure 15 shows by means of a characteristics diagram how the aortic\n\n992\n\nBLOOD FLOW\n\nP\nFIG.14. Thus, the Euler-Maclaurin summation formula gives\n\nThis equivalence may be used to show the relation between the pulse wave\ntheory and the windkessel theory of the aorta. The Euler-Maclaurin series\nwill further provide a first-order correction of the Windkessd theory for the\nf\neffect of finite length o the aorta. Equation 25 now becomes\n31.\n\nEquations 25 and 31 are analogous to equations for electromagnetic\nwaves in transmission lines and are most conveniently treated by Heaviside\xe2\x80\x99s\nmethod (25). The flow and pressure in arteries are\noften analyzed by Fourier\xe2\x80\x99s series. In this case the terms of the series will involve\nfn(t) =\n\nA,,eint\n\n37.\n\nThe substitution of in for D in Equation 35 will then yield the \xe2\x80\x9ccoiqplex\nimpedance\xe2\x80\x9d as a function of frequency [see (25)].\nExpansion of Equation 36 for small values of L / c yields again the windkessel theory with a correction for transient wave reflections. In this case the\nformula incorporates the effect of an exponentially-decaying outflow through\nthe peripheral resistances by virtue of the reflection coefficients k and k\xe2\x80\x98.\nThe above treatment is frankly heuristic and by no means complete.\nThus we have assumed that the impedance of the aortic branches is purely\nresistive. A more precise treatment would incorporate reactive components\nin the reflection coefficients k and k\xe2\x80\x99, and, of course, more branching arteries.\nA considerable improvement in accuracy might be achieved by treating the\nl\nmain branching arteries as s m ~ l windkessels interposed between the aorta\nand the terminal capillary resistances. Taking, for example, a carotid artery\n(26) gives as the wave velocity 1800 cm/sec, or about 3 times that in the\naorta. Assuming a length of 20 cm and a heart rate of bO/min, we find the\ncarotid artery is about 1/70 of a wave in length. Evidently, even the larger\nbranching arteries may be treated approximately as lumped capacitors. The\ncapacitance will be given by\n\nor about 0.6 cc change in volume for 100 mm change in pressure. Such a\nbranching artery may terminate in a resistance of 8000 (cgs) and the \xe2\x80\x9cRC\xe2\x80\x9d\ntime constant will then be approximately 0.04 sec. Evidently the capacitance\nof the branching arteries, though small, is great enough t o modify the shapes\nof the reflected pulses significantly.\n\n996\n\nBLOOD FLOW\n\nMore detailed treatment of arterial flow leads rapidly to a great increase\nin analytical complexity. Thus, Womersley (17) has calculated the impedance and reflection at a branching artery on the basis of time-dependent\nviscous flow. The actual impedance a t a branch of the larger arteries will be\ndetermined primarily, however, by smaller branching arteries farther down.\nHence, Womersley\xe2\x80\x99s analysis must be continued for several stages to obtain\nthe true impedance a t a branch. For such detailed calculations, the electrical\nanalogue [see (27)] becomes useful. In this connection Jager, Westerhof &\nNoordergraaf (28) have succeeded in devising an electrical circuit to approximate Womersley\xe2\x80\x99s formula.\n\n997\n\nJONES\nLITERATURE CITED\n1.
