Jones\n\nMay 1970\n\n999\n\nJones, R. T. "Fluid Dynamics of Heart Assist Devices,\'\' in Biomechanics: Its\nFoundations and Objectives. Edited by Y. C. Fung, N. Perrone, and\nM. Anliker. Englewood Cliffs, N. J., Prentice-Hall, 1972. @ 1972.\nReprinted by permission of Prentice-Hall, Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N. J.\n\n1000\n\nFrom BIOMECHANICS: ITS FOUNDATIONS AND OBJECTIVES,\nY. C. Fung, N. Perrone and M. Anliker, editors.\n@ Prentice-Hall, Inc., Englewood Cliffs, New Jersey.\nAll rights reserved. printed in the United States of America.\n\n2\n1\nf\nROBERT T. JONES\n\nIn this article certain hemodynamic phenomena that arise in connection\nwith the use of artificial blood pumping devices will be reviewed. Among these\nare: 1) flows produced by collapsing bulbs, 2) the impedance presented by\nthe aorta, 3) limiting velocities and instability of flow in elastic vessels, 4\n)\neffectiveness of valveless arterio-arterial pumps, and 5 ) wave reflection\nphenomena and instabilities associated with the intra-aortic balloon pump.\n\n*\n\n*\n\n*\n\nMaintenance of life by an artificial blood pump is an everyday occurrence\nin most large hospitals. The pump-oxygenator which takes over the function\nof both the heart and the lungs during surgery seems, however, to be limited\nin use to a maximum of several hours. Beyond this time one looks for certain\nsymptoms which are taken as evidence of changes in the physiological\nconstituents of the blood, that is, loss of red blood cells (hemolysis) and\nplatelets as well as denaturation of protein components. In spite of this\ndeficiency the pump-oxygenator is considered adequate for most surgical\nprocedures, though not suited in its present form to chronic support of a\nweakened or failing heart.\nPending the development of an ideal total heart replacement, there have\nbeen numerous attempts to provide partial assistance to the heart (see references) for periods longer than the few hours available with the pump\noxygenator. These have generally taken the form of pumps to assist the left\nventricle, since left ventricular function is most critical and evidently most\noften deficient.\n\n1001\n\nFLUID DYNAMICS OF HEART ASSIST DEVICES\n\nSeveral types of left ventricular assist pumps are illustrated in Fig. 1.\nIn Fig. la the pump is equipped with inflow and outflow valves and is placed\nin parallel with the ventricle (atrio-arterial pump) where it may divert all or\npart of the flow around the left heart. By contrast, pumps placed in series\nwith the ventricle may not significantly alter the flow but may be expected to\nrelieve all or part of the systemic pressure from the heart. It is interesting that\nthe series pump may accomplish this function even without valves if it is\nproperly phased with the pulsatile outflow from the ventricle. The centrifugal\npump described by Dorman et a1 (1969) operates by magnetic coupling\nthrough the intact skin and, of course, requires no valves.\n\n(A)\n\nTHORACIC AUXILIARY VENTRICLE\n\n( 8 ) AUXILIARY VENTRICLE IN DESCENDING AORTA\n\n(C)\n\nI\n\nINTRA-AORTIC BALLOON PUMP\n\nFig.1: Heart assist devices\n\nIn order to understand the operation of such devices, it is first of all necessary to gain at least a crude understanding of the function of the left ventricle\nand the aorta in mechanical terms.\nOur first curiosity here is in the flow produced by a collapsing or squeezing\nbulb since both the natural and the artificial ventricles operate in this fashion.\nAs has been shown (Jones, 1969) potential flows of the type\n(1)\n\nWx,Y , Z,t ) = ax2 + Byz + yz2\n\nprovide perhaps the simplest starting point for mathematical modeling of the\n\n1002\n\nROBERT T. JONES\n\nbulb flows. Here @ is the velocity potential, x, y, z are Cartesian coordinates\nand a, j?, y are constants or functions of the time such that\n\nSuch flows are trivial solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations and, of\ncourse, of Laplace\xe2\x80\x99s equation. If x, y and z are taken as the initial coordinates\nof a particle of fluid (or of the boundary) we have\n\nfor the Lagrangian coordinates. The Lagrangian coordinates are thus related\nto the initial coordinates by simple affine transformations. Plane surfaces\nremain plane and a bulb of initially arbitrary shape undergoes distortions tha!\ncan be represented by stretching its coordinates in different directions while\npreserving a constant volume.\nFigure 2 shows streamlines emanating from a collapsing bulb together,\nwith pressures calculated by the foregoing method on the assumption of\nfrictionless flow. The motion of the liquid in a bulb does not completely\ndetermine the pressures, but there remains an arbitrary function of the time to\nbe determined by the impedance into which the bulb works, that is, the\nrelation between pressure and flow in the aorta.\nIn a typical case the diastolic pressure in the aorta will be 70-80 mm H g\nand the ejection of blood from the ventricle will raise this pressure by 60-70\nmm. Pressures arising from dynamic motions within the bulb, however, are\nof the order of 3 4 mm only. Thus it seems that very little of the effort of the\nheart is directed against the inertia of the blood but appears initially in elastic\ndistension of the arteries ;later to be dissipated in frictional resistance through\nthe capillaries.\nExamination of the heart cavity shows a surface far from streamlined\nform, with deep furrows (trabeculae) and tendons to support the mitral valve.\nSimilarly, the architecture of the aortic system shows little disposition toward\nflow dynamics as ordinarily understood. Branching arteries often show no\npreference for the flow direction. Here again we find but a small fraction of\nthe pressure in kinetic form; pu2/2is of the order of a few millimeters.\nIn prosthetic heart pumps streamlining does not play an important role in\nthe purely mechanical function, though the flow does seem most important\nin relation to clotting. The clotting phenomenon is at present a dominant\nfactor in the success or failure of artificial heart devices including prosthetic\nvalves and assist pumps. Though beyond the scope of the present discussion,\n\n1003\n\nY\n\nP\n\nf\n\nBULB SURFACE\n\n----X\n\n- __-----\n\nFig. 2: Streamlines and pressures in collapsing bulb.\n\n1004\n\nROBERT T. JONES\n\nthe relation between clotting and flow has become a major item of research\nat our laboratory and elsewhere.\nNearly all current heart assist pumps operate by pneumatically driven\nplastic bulbs. In our experience we have found it essential that the bulb not\nchange its volume by stretchingbut rather by folding. The\na change of extrinsic geometry without altering the intrins\nsurface. The solution appears by reflection of the convex s\nthat progressively larger areas of the surface change from convex to concave,\nalong a singular curve determined by the intersection of the plane. In practice\nthe bulb has finite thickness and the surface bends to a finite radius along this\ncurve. In spite of the concentration of bending strain, bulbs of silicone rubber\nhave very satisfactory fatigue life in this mode of deformation.\nSuch bulbs are occasionally made by fitting initially flat sheets of fabric\nand silicone rubber over a convex form. Here one encounters a problem well\nknown to tailors and known to mathematicians from the properties of the\nTschebyschev net. It seems that such a net (as a handkerchief) can be fitted\nover a convex surface whose integrated solid angle does not exceed 2d.\nThe function of the aorta and the major vessels as an elastic compliance is\nwell characterized by the simplest theory of aortic impedance known as the\n\xe2\x80\x9cwindkessel\xe2\x80\x9d theory (Taylor, 1965). Here the aorta acts simply as a lumped\ncapacitance, and if the peripheral resistance is linear, one obtains an exponential decay of pressure following ejection of a volume of blood from the\nheart.\nFigure 3 illustrates our attempt to make a direct physical model of the aortic system. In medical circles such devices are known by the term \xe2\x80\x9cmock\ncirculation.\xe2\x80\x9d We have found such a model useful in studying and isolating\nthe purely mechanical effects of cardiac assist devices. The model aorta\nis made of silicone elastomer with compliance determined so as to lie within\nthe physiological range. The substitute ventricle is made of the same material\nand is placed in an air tight box so that it can be actuated pneumatically\nby a linkage and piston drive as shown. Figure 4 shows the type of pressure\npulse produced by our model compared with natural pulses taken from a\ntextbook on physiology.\nWith such a model one has control of various parameters such as source\nimpedance of the heart, cardiac output, wave speed and diameter of the aorta,\nand peripheral resistance. In addition, since the aorta is transparent, we have\nbeen able to observe visually the action of the intra-aortic balloon pump.\nlw\nFortunately, because of the high Reynolds number of the f o in the larger\narteries, one is not required to duplicate the detailed rheological properties\nof the blood in such experiments. A rough calculation will show that the\nunsteady laminar boundary layer on the inner wall of the aorta has time\nto grow to a thickness of only about one millimeter during the heart beat.\nSeparation vortices of the order of a centimeter in diameter may be expected\n\n1005\n\nFLUID DYNAMICS OF HEART ASSIST DEVICES\n\nFig. 3: Aortic circulation model.\n\nto persist for two or more heart beats. It should be borne in mind, however,\nthat the dynamic pressure associated with the flow is small compared with\nthe actual pressure. Hence, flow irregularities do not normally have a great\ninfluence on the mechanical performance of heart assist pumps. They may,\nhowever, influence the behavior of artificial valves and, of course, the\nformation of thrombi.\nIn our early effort at Avco Everett Research Laboratory, we sought to\ndevelop and perfect the Kantrowitz auxiliary ventricle, illustrated in Fig. lb.\nThis device comprises a simple compliant pumping chamber which is fitted\ninside a more rigid plastic case. The space between the bulb and the case communicates by a small gas tube through a percutaneous connector to the control system outside the body. The bulb can then be alternately compressed and\n\n1006\n\nROBERT T JONES\n.\n\nLEFT VENTRICULAR PRESSURE\n\nLEFT VENTRICULAR PRESSURE\n\n1 1\n1 l\nPROXIMAL AORTIC PRESSURE\n\nPROXIMAL AORTIC PRESSURE\n\n3 time\n\nDISTAL PRESSURE\nMECHANICAL PULSE\n\n. recondr\n\nDISTAL PRESSURE\n\nNATURAL PULSE\n(Adaped from \xe2\x80\x9cA Primer of Grdiac\nGt heteriut ton\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99 1965)\n\nFig. 4: Comparison of pulses produced by model with physiologic pulse.\n\nexpanded by pneumatic pressure from an external power source. Since the\nblood pumping chamber has no valves, it is necessary that its stroke be synchronized and properly phased with the action of the heart. This synchronization was accomplished with the aid of electrocardiac signals obtained from\nelectrodes attached to the heart muscle. By withdrawing blood from the aorta\nprior to systole the pressure required for ejection by the heart can be reduced,\nthus lessening the effort of the heart. After the ejection from the natural\nheart is complete and the aortic valve is closed, the blood withdrawn into the\nauxiliary ventricle can be pumped back into the aorta, raising the pressure\nand supplying energy for the systemic circulation. This technique has the advantage of creating higher pressures in the aorta during diastole and hence\nthe possibility of increased coronary perfusion (in practice the coronary flow\nhas in some cases been observed to diminish, perhaps because the assisted\nheart requires less). If we suppose, for example, that the stroke volume of the\nartificial ventricle Q, is as great as the output stroke of the natural ventricle\nQ, then it is clear that the pressure rise during systole may be suppressed and\nthe pressures in the natural ventricle need hardly exceed diastolic pressure.\nThis special situation requires that the withdrawal stroke of the AV imitate\nthe ejection stroke of the natural ventricle in reverse. In practice somewhat\nbetter results are obtained by reducing the pressure in the aorta prior to\nsystole, permitting the aortic valve to open at a lower pressure and reducing\nthe pressure during isometric contraction.\n\n1007\n\nFLUID DYNAMICS OF HEART ASSIST DEVICES\n\nThe intra-aortic balloon pump (Fig. IC), functions by a similar principle\n(Moulopoulos et al, 1962) since inflation and deflation of the balloon affects\naortic pressures in much the same way as injection and withdrawal of a corresponding quantity of blood. The balloon pump has the advantage that it\ncan be inserted through a femoral artery under local anesthesia. In this case\nelectric signals for timing are obtained from skin electrodes.\nThe reduction of outflow pressure during systole may, of course, permit\nthe heart to eject a greater flow quantity. Hence, the auxiliary ventricle (or\nthe balloon pump) may increase the cardiac output as well as effect a reduction in left ventricular pressure. The precise division of effort between flow\nand pressure will depend on what may be termed the \xe2\x80\x9csource-impedance\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x99\nof the heart. Animal experiments with such pumps indicate that a healthy\nheart has a very high source impedance (is flow-limited). The primary effect\nof the auxiliary pump then appears as a reduction of pressure in the left\nventricle. However, experience with human patients in cardiac distress indicates that the weakened heart may be pressure limited. In such cases the\narterio-arterial pump will act primarily to increase the cardiac output.\nBecause of its dependence on pathology, it seems unlikely that any\nuniversal relation for cardiac impedance can be found. However, the reduo\ntion of ventricular pressure and the increase of flow can be combined linearly\ninto a quantity which may be thought of as total effectiveness and which can\nbe simply related to the stroke volume of the pump and to the unassisted\naortic pulse (Jones et al, 1968). This cycle analysis of the arterio-arterial pump\nis based on the windkessel theory of aortic impedance. Figure 5 illustrates\nthe essential idea of the cycle analysis. Here the pump injects its stroke\n\nEFFECTIVENESS OF PU\n\nQ=Qb(l-e-ATz)\n\n: Analysis of arterio-arterial pump.\n\n1008\n\nROBERT T. JONES\n\nvolume into the aorta which distends as a windkessel. The pressure increment\nso produced then decays exponentially as the volume flows out through the\nperipheral resistances. All of the added volume would ultimately find its way\ninto the periphery if enough time were available. However, the pump must\nwithdraw volume and lower the pressure in the aorta prior to the next heart\nbeat. It must therefore withdraw a portion of the blood previously injected,\nnamely the fraction\n\n,\n\nwhere Iz = I/RC. R is the peripheral resistance and C the aortic compliance\nor capacitance. Q, is the stroke volume of the pump and td is the diastolic\ninterval. The complete analysis, which entails the assumption that operation\nof the pump does not change systolic or diastolic intervals, leads to the formula\n\nThe quantity (1 - e-lrd) may be conveniently replaced by the quantity\n(Pi PJP, where PI and Pz are systolic and diastolic pressures with the\nunaided heart. In this form it is evident that the operation of such valveless\npumps depends on the pulsatile character of the aortic pressure. In order\nto obtain an upper bound for the effectiveness, it has been assumed that\n,\nthe pump displaces its volume Q instantaneously. Other variations of the\n,\nstroke Q as a function of the time will require a convolution of Q, with\nthe decay factor e-\xe2\x80\x9d.\nThe use of the windkessel theory for aortic impedance corresponds to an\nassumption that the arterio-arterial pump will be equally effective at any\nposition along the aorta. Experiments with animals and with our artificial\ncirculation model tend to support this assumption provided the timing of the\npump cycle is adjusted to account for the delay in wave propagation.\nFigure 6 shows the result of an experiment made in the circulation model\nto check this assumption. Here the pumping effect of an intra-aortic balloon\nplaced in the descending thoracic aorta is compared with the effect of an\nauxiliary ventricle placed near the heart. In each case the same stroke volume\nwas used, but the timing of the balloon was advanced slightly. The curves on\nthe left of the chart recordings show the rather large aortic pressure produced\nby the pump during diastole. Near the center of each diagram the chart speed\nwas reduced, compressing the pulses. The rise in left ventricular pressure when\nthe pumps were turned off is clearly evident here and is approximately the\nsame for the balloon and the AV. During the compressed portions of the records an integrating circuit was switched on to record mean aortic pressures.\nThe mean pressures are an indication of the flow, and it will be noted that each\n\n1009\n\nFLUID DYNAMICS\n\nOF HEART ASSIST DEVICES\n\nPUMP ON\n\nt\n\nf\n\nPUMP OFF\n\nI\n\nLEFT VENTRICULAR PRESSURE\n\nPROXIMAL AORTIC PRESSURE\n\nDISTAL AORTIC PRESSURE\n\nLEFT VENTRICULAR PRESSURE\n\n-M\nPROXIMAL AORTIC PRESSURE\n\nDISTAL AORTIC PRESSLJRF\n\nFig. 6: Comparativeeffects of balloon pump and a\n-\n\nventricle.\n\npump increased the cardiac output by the same amount. In spite of the obstruction presented by the balloon in the aorta, the distal mean pressure is\nvery effectively increased.\nThe action of the arterio-arterial pump will evidently depend not only\non the source impedance of the heart, but also on the complex impedance\npresented by the aortic system. The impedance of the aorta is, of course,\ncomplicated by the phenomenon of pulse wave propagation. (McDonald,\n1960; Young, 1808, 1809; Womersley; 1956 Anliker and Maxwell, 1966).\nThe elastic tube, except for reflections, presents a characteristic resistive\nimpedance. With an injection velocity u the pressure developed is\ndp = guc\n\n1010\n\nROBERT T. JONES\n\nwhere c is the wave propagation velocity of the order of 500-1000 cmlsec.\nThe flow quantity will be uA where A is the cross-sectional area of the artery.\nThe characteristic impedance is then\n\nFor a wave speed of 600 cm/sec and an area A of 4 sq cm, we obtain\n(10)\n\n2, = 150 (cgs)\n\nEstimates of the capillary resistance associated with the various outlets may\nbe made from data on mean pressures and flow to various organs given in\nphysiology textbooks. Values of peripheral resistance vary over a wide range,\nespecially in pathologic conditions such as shock. However, it is significant\nthat the values are an order of magnitude greater than either the pulse\nimpedance or the frictional resistance of the aorta. Hence, we may suppose\nthat the pulse wave will be strongly reflected by large resistances which are:\nrather closely coupled through the main branching arteries. Furthermore,\nsince the time for a pulse wave to traverse the length of the aorta is short\ncompared with the duration of the heart beat one can expect the pressure and\nflow to be dominated by multiple reflections from the periphery during a\nsingle heart beat.\nThe foregoing characteristics of the aortic system lead us to what might be\ntermed a \xe2\x80\x9cslender windkessel\xe2\x80\x9d theory of aortic impedance. Clearly, if an\nelastic tube of finite length is inflated sufficiently slowly it will behave simply\nas a compliance. With more rapid inflation waves and their reflections from\n)\nthe ends will become prominent (Fig. 7. The important parameter here is\nthe characteristictime for reflection along the length of the tube, &/e,\ncompared\nwith the time scale of the inflation process. By expanding the wave reflection\nformulas in ascending powers of &/e,one obtains, first of all, the result of the\nwindkessel theory followed by a succession of terms which correct the windkessel theory for the finite length of the aorta (Jones, 1969). Curiously, the\nfirst correction does not involve the length of the windkessel at all but merely\ntakes account of the fact that the windkessel is an elastic tube. By considering\none of the two families of characteristics, there is obtained\n\nThus the first correcting term is simply 1/2 the characteristic pressure, puc.\nFigure 7 illustrates the process of inflation of an elastic tube for the case of a\nstepwise inflow velocity u(t) and shows the nature of the correction. Applying\nthis calculation to the aorta, one should take account of outflow at the reflection sites. Such outflow leads to progressive diminution of the reflected\n\n1011\n\nFLUID DYNAMICS OF HEART ASSIST DEVICES\nP\n\nTIME\n\nFig. 7: Inflation of an elongated windkessel.\n\npulses by a fixed fraction (reflection coefficient K ) and thence to an exponential\ndecay of aortic pressure. The windkessel theory (Pwk)shows this behavior\nby a convolution of the inflow pulse with the factor e-". However, since it\ndepends on the integral curve of the inflow pulse, Pwk shows too slow an\ninitial rise of pressure. This behavior is illustrated in Fig. 8.\nA method of arterio-arterial pumping not illustrated in Fig. 1 consists\nof withdrawing blood directly through cannulae inserted in the femoral\narteries and reinjecting the same blood during diastole. While the effect of\ndistance from the heart is rather small in the case of the balloon or the\nabdominal ventricle, such effects will certainly be larger here. In particular,\nthe taper of the artery will be significant since the femoral vessels may be only\n6 mm in diameter while the aorta near the heart is approximately 20-25 mm.\nThe pulse wave phenomenon in a tapered elastic tube leads, in the case of\nconstant wave speed, to an equation similar in form to that employed in the\nanalysis of acoustic horns. A treatment of the exponentially tapered tube has\n\n1012\n\nROBERT T. JONES\n\nSuperpition of reflected waves\nin proximal ond distal awta\n\nF g 8: Superposition of reflected waves i proximal and distal aorta.\ni.\nn\n\nbeen given (Evans, 1960). A transformation which yields a one-parameter\nfamily of solutions in which the wave speed and the tube diameter vary\ntogether is described by McMahon et a1 (1969).\nPerhaps the simplest treatment is that employing the spherical wave\nequation as suggested by Thomas Young (1808, 1809) for a straight conical\ntaper. Here the velocity potential will have the well-known form\n\nwhere R is the distance from the virtual apex of the aorta. Figure 9 shows a\ncalculation on this basis which illustrates the transformation between pressure\nand flow effected by a conically tapered elastic tube. Here we have assumed\nthat a quantity A Q = 10 cc is withdrawn from the narrow (6 mm) end of the\nconical tube, following the pressure and velocity variations shown. At the\nupper, wider end of the tube the pressure pulse is much reduced, although\nthe flow quantity temporarily withdrawn has increased to 40 cc.\nPulsatile pumping by direct withdrawal and injection through a small\nartery must evidently be restricted to certain levels of pressure and velocity\nin order to avoid blood damage. The flow velocity is in any case limited to\nvalues less than the pulse wave velocity. In the balloon pump the fluid withdrawn can be a light gas such as helium, enabling greater volumes to be\n\n1013\n\nFLUID DYNAMICS OF HEART ASSIST DEVICES\n\nI\n300\n\nAQ.40 CC\n\n200\n\nCMISEC\n\nI oc\n\nPRESSURE, mm Hg\n24mm\n\nG/\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98\n\nI\n\nI\n\nI\n\nSPEED C = 500\n\ng\nc\n\nI\n\ni\n\nAQ = 1 CC\n0\n\n:\n\nI\n6 mm\n\nrVELOCiTY\n\n0\n\nTIME, SECONDS\nFig. 9: Transmission of pulse i tapered artery.\nn\n\npumped. The balloon, however, has its own peculiar instability which we\nhave termed \xe2\x80\x9cbubble trapping.\xe2\x80\x9d The origin of this phenomenon becomes\nevident when we attempt to calculate the flow and pressure produced by an\nexpanding cylindrical balloon in a circular tube. For this purpose we use the\npotential\n\nwhich satisfies the boundary condition for a cylinder expanding within a fixed\nCalculation shows a parabolic pressure discylinder of radius r, =\ntribution along the length of the expanding cylinder with pressures at the\ncenter as much as 100 mm higher than the pressures at the ends. An ordinary\nlimp balloon cannot, of course, support such pressure gradients, and the\n\nm.\n\n1014\n\nROBERT T. JONES\n\ninflating gas simply rushes toward the ends of the balloon inflating them first\nand sealing off the aorta. As Professor Shapiro of M. I. T. has pointed\nout, any manner of expelling blood from the space around the balloon must\ninvolve such a fallingpressure gradient and will lead to bubble trapping unless\ncorrective measures are taken.\nFigure 10 shows the bubble trapping phenomenon as it appears in our\nAvco circulation model. The blood trapped between the ends of the balloon\nis, of course, not effective in the pumping cycle, and the aorta in this region\nmay be subjected to high pressures of the order of the drive pressure.\nOne method we have found successful in limiting this phenomenon is to\ndivide the balloon along its length into a number of compartments, inflating\nthe compartments selectively through orifices of different size. Sound Level Meter\nAlthough both v i o l i n s have a powerful tone and easy response, t h e f i r s t\none i s judged not acceptable because of t o o much emphasis i n t h e bass region\nand because of a "nasal" q u a l i t y . It w i l l be noted t h a t i n t h i s case t h e\novertone peaks are highest i n t h e 1500 cylce region, corresponding t o t h e\nobservation by Meinel (J. Acous, SOC.h e r . , vol. 2 9 , J u l y 1957) t h a t overtones\ni n t h i s range produce a n a s a l q u a l i t y .\nI n order t o test Meinel\'s statement more s p e c i f i c a l l y , I arranged t o m i x\nt h e tones from two audio o s c i l l a t o r s and played them through an ordinary\nloudspeaker. M son and daughter, who have considerable musical experience\ny\nand who did not know t h e expected outcome of t h e experiment, d e f i n i t e l y\npreferred 500 p l u s 2000 Hz t o t h e combination 500 p l u s 1500.\nActually (as mentioned f o r example by M6ckel i n D i e Kunst des Geigenbaues)\nt h e n a s a l range i s probably between 1350 and 1700 Hz. M tests i n which\ny\nvarious d i s t o r t e d wave shapes w e r e played through a loudspeaker both with\nand without an LC f i l t e r centered i n t h i s range tend t o confirm t h i s impression.\nIt w i l l be noted t h a t t h e second v i o l i n has accentuated overtones i n t h e\n2000 t o 3000 Hz range, t h e main body resonance i s a t 450 Hz, and t h e a i r\nresonance peak is somewhat lower i n amplitude. This v i o l i n is preferred\nby musicians who have t r i e d both.\n\n1022\n\nProduction and i n t e r p r e t a t i o n of Chladni p a t t e r n s - To c a l c u l a t e t h e sound\nr a d i a t i o n from a v i o l i n one would l i k e t o know t h e v i b r a t i o n amplitude as\na function of p o s i t i o n over t h e top and bottom surfaces. The holographic\ntechnique permits t h i s , but not everyone has access t o such equipment.\nGross p a t t e r n s of t h e v i b r a t i o n modes can be obtained very simply however\nby t h e old-fashioned Chladni method. The f a c t t h a t t h e v i o l i n p l a t e s are\ncurved introduces some d i f f i c u l t y and most powders w i l l be influenced too\nmuch by gravity. The p i c t u r e s shown were taken with t h e a i d of pumice powder\nwhich seems t o have j u s t t h e ri:;ht amount of "stickiness" and w i l l flow\nu p h i l l away from a v i b r a t i n g arca.\n\nA t 390 Hz, i t w i l l be\nnoted t h a t a p o r t i o n of\nt h e back p l a t e opposite\nt h e bass bar i s v i b r a t i n g .\nThis v i b r a t i o n i s evidentl y being communicated\nthrough t h e r i b s and i s\ndoubtless j u s t i n phase\nwith t h e v i b r a t i o n of\nt h e top.* Following John\nSchelleng\'s\'analysis\n( N e w s l e t t e r No. 16,Nov.\n1971) i t can be seen t h a t\nt h i s motion of t h e back\np l a t e , f a r from adding t o\nt h e sound, w i l l a c t u a l l y\ns u b t r a c t from i t , s i n c e\ni t s u b t r a c t s from t h e\nvolume changes of t h e\nv i o l i n . The p a t t e r n a t\n1300 Hz i s remarkably\nsymmetrical. It i s tempting t o a s s o c i a t e t h e perf e c t i o n of v i s u a l symmetry\ni n t h e s e v i b r a t i o n patt e r n s with acoustic perf e c t i o n of t h e v i o l i n .\nA l i t t l e thought w i l l show however t h a t t h e sound r a d i a t i o n might w e l l be enhanced i f t h e Chladni p a t t e r n were not so symmetrical.\n\n*This statement t u r n s out t o be i n c o r r e c t . The v i b r a t i o n of t h e back a t\n390 Hz i s i n opposite phase t o t h a t of t h e top. The v i b r a t i o n of t h e area\nappearing i n t h e photo does c o n t r i b u t e volume changes and i s responsible f o r\na s i g n i f i c a n t portion of t h e output a t 390 Hz.\n1023\n\n1024\n\nFOUNDED BY FREDERICK A.
